Full text: Fact sheet

GDP per head (US$; at market exchange rates) 33,992 GDP per head (US$; at market exchange rates) 35,110
Inflation (av; %) 1.7 Inflation (av; %) 1.5
Background: The political geography of Europe has been defined by two world wars and the legacy of the cold war, during which Europe was divided into two blocs. The ending of Soviet control over central and eastern Europe from 1989, followed by the collapse in 1991 of the Soviet Union, provided an opportunity to expand the EU eastwards. Ten new member states (eight from the former communist bloc) were admitted to the EU in 2004, followed by a further two in 2007, and Croatia in 2013. In June 2016 the UK electorate voted in a referendum to withdraw from the EU. The economic transition of the Visegrad countries (the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia) has proceeded more smoothly than that of other east European countries. The effects of war in former Yugoslavia in the 1990s and a slower pace of reform have shaped developments in south-east Europe.
Political structure: All 28 EU member states are parliamentary democracies, although in some of the newer, former communist members in particular the substance of democracy-including a political culture based on trust and healthy levels of political participation-is often absent. The communist period lasted much longer in the former Soviet Union, and political developments in most parts of that region have been characterised by a drift towards authoritarianism.
Policy issues: Many aspects of domestic policy for EU member states-in particular those relating to the single market-are decided collectively at the EU level. Nineteen EU member states share the euro as their currency. These countries are subject to a single monetary policy administered by the European Central Bank (ECB). They are supposed to comply with common fiscal rules, although these have often been ignored. During the euro zone debt crisis several member states (Cyprus, Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain) ceded varying degrees of policy control to the EU and the IMF in exchange for receiving financial support. Although the euro zone crisis has passed its peak, normalisation remains a long way off. The Economist Intelligence Unit continues to attach a 60% probability to Greece leaving the euro zone during its medium-term forecast period (2018-22). Outside the EU, the speed and extent of reform and institutional change vary widely. Countries with proximity to Western markets and with stable political outlooks have proceeded faster and more successfully with economic stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation. Institutional problems, such as weakness in the rule of law and widespread corruption, plague much of non-EU Europe.
Taxation: Individual tax regimes operate in all countries. All EU member states must operate a system of value-added tax (VAT), with a minimum of 15% as the standard rate.
Foreign trade: If intra-EU trade is included, the EU accounts for about half of all global trade. About 60% of trade conducted by EU member states is intra-regional.
EU28, leading non-EU export markets 2016 % of total EU28, leading non-EU sources of imports 2016 % of total
US 20.8 China 20.2

Switzerland 8.2 Switzerland 7.1
Turkey 4.4 Russia 7.0
Russia 4.1 Turkey 3.9
Summary
Political stability
Popular disaffection with mainstream parties will persist in the forecast period. Anti-establishment parties performed well in Italy's general election in March, but political fragmentation means the process of forming a government will be protracted. The next government is likely to be unstable and short-lived.
A government was formed in Germany in March, six months after the election. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects political instability in the coming years, with the Social Democratic Party (SPD) trying to distinguish itself from the Christian Democratic Union (CDU), and the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) having entered the Bundestag (the lower house of parliament).
We expect the UK and the EU to negotiate a framework deal on the future trading relationship by the time the UK leaves the EU in March 2019. The risk that negotiations will break down is significant.
Vladimir Putin was re-elected as president for a fourth term in March. We expect a greater focus on domestic policy, but even modest liberalising reforms are unlikely. Russia will continue to pursue a muscular foreign policy. We expect EU sanctions on Russia to be maintained and for relations to remain difficult.
Economic policy
We do not expect the EU to undertake the sort of ambitious reforms advocated by the French president, Emmanuel Macron, which will meet resistance from some member states, including from Germany, which is wary of EU-level stabilisation instruments that mean an increase in risk sharing.
Tensions arising from negotiations over the EU's seven-year budget framework for 2021-27 will play into the debate on EU reform, hampering progress in this area. Agreement on the budget framework is unlikely until the second half of 2019, after the European Parliament elections in May 2019.
We expect the European Central Bank (ECB) to take a first step towards normalising its main refinancing rate in early 2020, before embarking on a gradual tightening cycle that would bring the interest rate to 1.5% by end-2022.
Economic growth
We forecast average real GDP growth in the EU28 of 1.9% in 2018-22, following estimated growth of 2.5% in 2017.
We expect a real GDP growth slowdown in the UK in 2018-19, to 1.5% per year, owing to Brexit uncertainty. It will pick up in 2019-22.
Business environment rankings
The business environment has improved in most European countries as the post-crisis economic recovery has gathered pace. However, fragilities remain.

Political outlook: Political stability
The UK's vote in June 2016 to leave the EU represents a serious challenge to the future cohesion of the bloc. Despite the professed unity of the other 27 member states, the departure of one of the biggest members is a profound shock that has reverberated and will continue to do so. The EU's management of the Brexit crisis has been further complicated by the weakened position of the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, after it took almost six months to form a government following the September 2017 general election. The government is another grand coalition of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU)/Christian Social Union (CSU) and the Social Democratic Party (SPD). The election dealt a blow to the two leading parties, which recorded their worst results since the 1950s, and also brought the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) into the Bundestag (the lower house of parliament). The next few years are likely to be a testing time for Germany, with the SPD seeking to distinguish itself from the CDU/CSU and the AfD being a vocal opponent of the government both inside and outside parliament. The March 2018 general election in Italy resulted in a victory for insurgent, anti-establishment parties and a highly fragmented parliament, which will make it almost impossible to form a stable and lasting government. The Catalonia crisis, which escalated in October 2017 after pro-independence citizens voting in an illegal referendum on the region's independence from the rest of Spain encountered state violence, poses another threat to the cohesion of the EU. Nor is the populist challenge to established parties across the bloc likely to dissipate. In addition, escalating tensions with Russia pose a serious geopolitical risk.
There is no room for complacency, as underlying problems remain unresolved
The lesson of the past eight years, since the onset of the euro zone crisis in late 2009, is that politicians have underestimated the economic and political challenges facing the bloc and have prematurely claimed that the worst is over. Threats to the future of the EU, including the sovereign debt crisis, the migration crisis and the populist insurgency, have not been resolved. The existential threat to the euro has certainly lessened since the height of the sovereign debt crisis in 2010-13, when the danger of one of the peripheral economies being forced out of the euro zone, through a loss of investor confidence and a spike in bond yields, weighed heavily on sentiment and investment. The commitment of the European Central Bank (ECB) to the euro has largely neutralised speculative pressure in the bond markets, but the single currency is still vulnerable. Greece is the most obvious cause for concern given its very high public debt/GDP ratio, and The Economist Intelligence Unit thinks it more likely than not that the country will leave the euro zone by the end of the 2018-22 forecast period. Another migration crisis could unfold if the deal between the EU and Turkey were to break down because of a deterioration in relations between the two sides. Most seriously, popular disaffection with the political order in Europe remains substantial, which is likely to fuel support for anti-establishment parties and bring about destabilising political realignments across the continent in the coming years.
The French president, Emmanuel Macron, has sought to re-energise the Franco-German partnership, and has laid out sweeping plans for EU and euro zone reform. His idea for a euro zone budget and finance minister will face strong resistance in Germany. Plans for greater EU integration in areas such as defence and security have a greater chance of success. Many of Mr Macron's ideas are not new-and some enjoy widespread support in the EU already-but the energy he is putting into championing his vision for Europe marks a sharp change from the more managerial European leadership style of Ms Merkel. The problem is that there is little appetite for some of his bolder ideas in Germany or elsewhere in Europe.
A decision on reform proposals will be made at the EU summit in June 2018. Suggestions put forward by the European Commission in December 2017 included turning the European Stability Mechanism (ESM)-the euro zone's bail-out fund-into a European Monetary Fund (EMF) that would provide a backstop for the banking union; setting up a fiscal capacity with a stabilisation function for the euro area; and appointing a euro zone economy and finance minister.
We expect some agreement on steps towards completing the banking union and deepening the capital markets union, and expanded powers for the ESM. However progress on reform may be hampered by the outcome of the recent election in Italy, with the formation of the government set to be a protracted process, probably resulting in a coalition that contains one or more parties that are hostile towards Europe. Aspects of the reform plans will meet resistance from some member states, including from Germany, which is wary of EU-level stabilisation instruments that mean an increase in risk sharing. We expect only superficial changes.
Budget negotiations will test EU cohesion
Tensions arising from negotiations over the EU's next seven-year budget framework for 2021-27 will also play into the debate on EU reform, hampering progress in this area. The European Commission has proposed that all member states increase their financial contribution to meet the shortfall in the budget created by the withdrawal of the UK, the fourth-largest contributor. Germany and eight central and east European countries are willing to pay more into the budget, whereas others (including Austria, the Netherlands, Sweden and Denmark) would prefer to reduce the budget post-Brexit. Agreement on the budget framework is unlikely until the second half of 2019, after the European Parliament elections in May 2019. We expect the Commission to secure larger budget contributions from all EU member states, but achieving this is likely to involve a reallocation (or "modernisation") of funds and will also reflect a shift in the balance of power within the EU post-Brexit, with the Netherlands, Sweden and Denmark having lost the UK as an ally.
German election delivers blow to coalition parties
The centre-right CDU, together with its Bavarian sister party, the CSU, won the largest vote share in Germany's federal election on September 24th 2017, with 32.9% of the vote. The centre-left SPD scored its worst result in the post-war period, with 20.5% of the vote. The far-right, populist AfD won 12.6%, enough to enter the Bundestag for the first time, and the pro-business Free Democratic Party (FDP) re-entered the Bundestag, with 10.7% of the vote. The other, smaller parties, the Left Party and The Greens, were also beneficiaries of popular dissat-isfaction with the political mainstream, polling at 9.2% and 8.9% respectively.
The AfD outperformed the polls and did especially well in the former east Germany, where the party became the second-largest political force. Exit polls showed that the issue of migration and refugees was the main reason given for voting for the AfD, with many voters also indicating that this was a protest vote. The CDU and the SPD tried to downplay the issue in the campaign, which goes some way to explaining both the success of the AfD and the drop in vote share for the two large mainstream parties.
A government was finally formed in March 2018, but we expect a more turbulent political scene in Germany in the coming years. Having reluctantly agreed to another grand coalition, the SPD will be keen to distinguish itself from Ms Merkel's CDU. The CDU will also have to start planning for a successor to Ms Merkel. Meanwhile, the AfD will do its best to test the government.
The general election in Italy on March 4th 2018 yielded an acutely fragmented parliament. It also produced a resounding victory for the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S), which won about 32% of the vote, and the Eurosceptic anti-immigrant Lega, which won about 17% and overtook the more moderate Forza Italia (FI) led by Silvio Berlusconi to assume the leadership of the centre-right bloc that contested the election. The new parliament convened on March 23rd, and a prolonged period of post-election talks has now started. The possibility of a government that includes M5S and Lega has risen. Political instability risks disrupting Italy's fragile economic recovery.
Few policy changes after the re-election of Mr Putin
On March 18th Vladimir Putin was re-elected to a fourth term as president, securing a record 76.7% of the vote on a turnout of 67%. Mr Putin's re-election was widely expected, given his approval ratings of around 80%, and in the absence of credible opposition candidates. Although the election itself was a non-event, it ushers in a period of political uncertainty as various factions of the elite jockey to secure their position in the coming post-Putin political order-assuming that Mr Putin stands down at the end of his term in 2024. In Mr Putin's fourth term we expect a greater focus on domestic policy, in an effort to arrest falling living standards and bolster growth following the 2015-16 recession. However, even modest liberalising reforms are unlikely and we expect the state to retain its dominant role in the economy. In the foreign policy arena, we believe that Russia will continue to pursue a muscular policy, with the aim of asserting its status as a major player on the global stage. The country's international influence will be strengthened by the conclusion of international business deals in strategic sectors such as oil, nuclear-power plants and military equipment.
Conventional politics upended across the continent
Recent elections across Europe have followed the Italian and German pattern, in that electorates are increasingly favouring alternative or populist parties over the mainstream parties and candidates. The result has been more political fragmentation, protracted negotiations to form a government and the emergence of unusual government coalitions. Elections held in the Netherlands, Norway, Austria, Iceland and the Czech Republic in 2017 also illustrated the trend towards increased political fragmentation, as well as a more complicated policymaking outlook.
Spain faces a constitutional crisis over the Catalan question
Another impetus towards the breakdown of post-war political arrangements and fragmentation comes from regional movements demanding more autonomy or independence in countries such as Belgium, Italy, Scotland, Spain and elsewhere, including in eastern Europe. Spain has been plunged into a political crisis by an illegal referendum and unilateral declaration of inde-pendence in Catalonia. The central government responded by using Article 155 of the constitution to dismiss the Catalan government and assume control of the region in late October, and called new regional elections for December 21st.
In the regional election in Catalonia on December 21st 2017, as we forecast, pro-independence parties won a parliamentary majority, with less than 50% of the popular vote. The liberal, pro-unity Ciudadanos (Citizens) topped the poll with 25.4% of the vote. The election confirms the polarisation of views on independence. It produced little numerical change in the balance of power between the electoral blocs of pro-independence and pro-unity parties, despite a turnout above 80%, which the unionists hoped would deliver them victory.
The separatist parties-the Catalan Republican Left (ERC), the centre-right Junts per Catalunya (JuntsxCat; Together for Catalonia) and the anti-capitalist Popular Unity Candidates (CUP)-won a combined 47.5% of the vote and 70 seats in the 135-seat parliament, compared with 47.7% and 72 seats in 2015. The three pro-unity parties-Ciudadanos, the Socialists' Party of Catalonia (PSC) and the conservative People's Party (PP)-won a combined 43.5% and 57 seats, up from 39.2% and 52 in 2015. The non-aligned Catalunya en Comú (the Comuns, associated with Podemos-We Can) polled 7.5% (eight seats).
Ciudadanos is the largest party, with 37 deputies and 25.4% of the vote. Its strong performance came mainly at the expense of the PP, whose support slumped from 8.5% to 4.2%. Ciudadanos will be unable to form a government, but its success in Catalonia is a warning to the two main national parties, the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE) and the PP, led by the prime minister, Mariano Rajoy. Mr Rajoy's mishandling of the Catalan crisis could benefit Ciudadanos at the next general election. The regional election result was in line with our forecast. It represents a major blow for Mr Rajoy, and his government will come under pressure to negotiate with the separatists. Mr Rajoy is unlikely to make concessions, and the conflict is set to continue.
With a number of prominent pro-independence politicians in custody and facing serious charges, ranging from rebellion and sedition to misappropriation of funds, and the former regional president and several other ministers claiming to lead a government in exile in Belgium, the pro-independence movement faces serious challenges in agreeing on the political direction for Catalan separatism. This could take the form of a renewed push for independence or, as is more likely, pressure for a legal referendum, as well as protests over what the pro-independence movement regards as the unjust treatment of its leaders at the hands of the Spanish state.
The Brexit negotiations will test EU cohesion
The Brexit negotiations began in June 2017, after the UK government invoked Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union on March 29th, beginning the formal two-year process of the country's withdrawal from the bloc. In the Article 50 letter, Theresa May, the prime minister, confirmed that the UK would not seek membership of the EU's single market. This is in line with the government's intention to honour the Brexit vote by taking control of laws, borders and budget. The UK will also leave the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice (ECJ).
The UK would like to have tariff-free access to EU markets, but customs union membership would mean a common external tariff and would prevent the UK from negotiating trade deals with other countries. The UK will therefore try to negotiate a free-trade agreement with the EU and has proposed alternatives to customs union membership, including a "highly streamlined" arrangement and a new customs "partnership" that reduce non-tariff barriers to trade such as technical regulations, compliance requirements and rules of origin docu-mentation. We expect the new relationship to be phased in gradually, to minimise disruption. This could mean continued adherence to EU rules for a period after withdrawal.
A deal would be mutually beneficial, but the risk of no deal is high
On March 19th UK and EU negotiators reached agreement on large parts of the draft withdrawal agreement that was published by the European Commission in late February. This includes agreement on the terms of the transition period, which will last for 21 months after the UK's formal withdrawal from the EU at end-March 2019. EU leaders approved the terms of the transition period at a summit on March 22nd-23rd. There is a risk that a clash between the EU and the UK on the Irish border issue could scupper the withdrawal agreement, but this is not our forecast.
The draft agreement has been colour-coded: areas of the text on which UK and EU negotiators have agreed are in green; areas that need further clarification are highlighted in yellow; and areas in which discussions are continuing are white. The majority of the text is green, reflecting agreement on citizens' rights, the financial settlement, Euratom and on most areas relating to separation provisions (the continued circulation of goods placed on the market and customs procedures). There is also full agreement on the terms of the transition period-the UK will maintain access to the single market, but will be bound by the obligations of membership. UK negotiators have made several concessions that will be unpalatable to Brexiteers within the government: EU law will still be applicable; EU budget contributions will continue; the UK will have no say over fishing quotas; and there will be reciprocal free movement and subsequent entitlement to settled status until the end of the transition. A win for the UK is that it will not be bound by the EU's trade policy, allowing it to agree new trade deals during the transition.
The transition agreement provides businesses with some certainty that they will have time to adjust to the new UK-EU relationship. However, as "nothing is agreed until everything is agreed" the transition is conditional on the completion of the withdrawal agreement, and some important parts remain in white. The most critical is the "protocol on Ireland/Northern Ireland", which in February had established the legal basis of a common regulatory area within Ireland as a fallback option to avoiding a hard border on the island of Ireland, and which the UK had rejected outright. Agreement was reached only on a common travel area within Ireland, and some areas of north-south co-operation.
Political exigencies on both sides reduce the scope for an amicable divorce and the risk that the negotiations will break down is high. If they do, and an extension of the Article 50 deadline is not agreed by all 27 EU members, the UK will leave the EU in 2019 without a deal and revert to World Trade Organisation (WTO) trade rules. However, both sides have an incentive to agree on a deal, given the mutual benefits of maintaining economic, political and security relations.
Brexit uncertainties have been heightened because of divisions in the government over the shape of the UK's future relationship with the EU. Mrs May's decision to call an early general election in June 2017 backfired disastrously for the Conservative Party, which lost its majority. The prime minister's authority was badly damaged, but Mrs May will stay in place for now because there is no obvious alternative who could unite both wings of the party. The Conservatives fear another general election given that the momentum is with the main opposition Labour Party. Lacking a parliamentary majority and divided over Brexit, the government will do well to last the duration of the Brexit negotiations, until March 2019, and there is a significant risk of another pre-term election.
Political outlook: No easy options in Italy
Italy's 2018 general election produced an unprecedented level of political fragmentation. No party or coalition emerged with a majority, and official seat counts suggests that no government can be formed without the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) or the populist Eurosceptic Lega. The process of forming a government will be protracted, and another election cannot be discounted. Whatever coalition is eventually assembled, it is likely to be unstable and short-lived, limiting the scope for reform or even policymaking of any sort.
The centre right is far from having a majority, despite having won the largest vote share, of about 37%. M5S emerged as the biggest single party, with about 33% of the popular vote. Assuming that the current parliamentary groups remain disciplined, the seat counts in the table below suggest that no coherent government can be formed without the support of M5S, the Lega, or both. Given the extreme fragmentation, coalition talks are likely to be long and difficult.

Sources: Quorum/YouTrend; Sky TG24.
The convening of the new parliament on March 23rd will provide a first procedural signpost for coalition negotiations. First, the formation of parliamentary groups, scheduled for March 25th, could give a sense of which members of parliament (MPs) might be amenable to crossing party lines. Second, the election of the presidents of the two chambers of parliament (the Chamber of Deputies, the lower house; and the Senate, the upper house) may also shed light on emerging alliances.
This process may not be completed until late March or early April, and the president, Sergio Mattarella, will not hold consultations with the leaders of political parties to nominate a prime minister-designate until it is completed. There is no time limit on the president's consultations, which could potentially take weeks. Several possible outcomes are listed below. Regardless of the kind of government that is formed, the administration is likely to be unstable and short-lived.
Centre-right government (low probability)
The centre-right coalition, composed of the Lega, Forza Italia (FI) and the right-wing Fratelli d'Italia, collectively won the biggest vote share and the largest number of seats. It remains unclear to whom Mr Mattarella might give a full or "exploratory" mandate to form a government, although in the past the mandate has typically gone to a prime minister-designate from the winning coalition. This could mean that Matteo Salvini, the leader of the Lega, will be given the first chance to assemble a majority if the mandate does not go to M5S.
Statements from party leaders suggest that the centre-right bloc will remain united for the time being, with Mr Salvini for now ruling out "strange coalitions", understood to mean an agreement with M5S. However, as the table above shows, the centre right would have to fill a sizeable deficit of seats to reach a majority, particularly in the Chamber of Deputies. Unless the Partito Democratico (PD) and M5S parliamentary groups splinter, it is unclear where sufficient support would be found. It also remains to be seen whether Mr Salvini, a caustic and polarising figure, would be successful in attracting breakaway MPs from the more moderate formations.
M5S-Lega government (medium probability)
Before the election there was speculation that if M5S passed the threshold of 30% of the vote and the Lega topped FI, the Lega and M5S might conclude a government pact. Having satisfied both of these conditions, M5S and the Lega would have a majority in both parliamentary houses, and a comfortable one if Fratelli d'Italia is included. Despite ideological differences, they share common ground in their criticism of the EU (albeit to differing degrees, as M5S has shifted towards the centre and the Lega further to the right), opposition to recent labour and pension reforms, calls for tax cuts and welfare spending to support low earners, and a desire for tougher immigration and security policies.
The strong performance of Mr Salvini's party means that he should have been given a relatively free hand by Silvio Berlusconi, the leader of FI, who has long dominated the centre right, to negotiate with other parties. However, we believe that Mr Salvini would prefer a role as leader of the centre right to one as junior coalition partner to M5S. Moreover, doing a deal with M5S could risk alienating a significant portion of the Lega's rural, conservative base in the north. Mr Salvini will also be concerned that support for his party could dissipate in government if the inexperienced M5S makes a mess of policy. Arguably, he stands to do even better at the next election if an M5S-led government proves to be ineffectual and short-lived.
At the same time, M5S may be reluctant to do a deal with the Lega, at least in the early stages of negotiations. Luigi Di Maio, M5S's prime ministerial candidate, has signalled a strong desire to govern, proposing a group of ministers before the election and saying he was open to negotiations with other parties after the vote-something that M5S had previously eschewed. However, like Mr Salvini, Mr Di Maio will also be constrained by his base. Although M5S has moved steadily towards the centre, its roots lie on the political left, and much of its younger, progressive core could desert it if it formed a coalition with the Lega. The same may be true of many of M5S's southern supporters, who regard the Lega with distrust.
If M5S-Lega talks fail: M5S-PD government (medium probability)
Having previously rejected the PD's overtures to support a centre-left government after the 2013 general election, M5S has now declared its willingness to have discussions with all parties on the left, as well as the right, about forming the next government. The party leadership would reportedly prefer a coalition with the left (including the PD and Liberi e Uguali) to one with the Lega (conditional on the resignation of the PD's leader, Matteo Renzi). On March 5th Mr Renzi said that the PD was going into opposition in the next parliament and that he would resign as party leader, but only after the government formation process was over. This caused severe tensions within the PD. On March 12th, when the national executive of the PD met to put in place a new, temporary leadership, Mr Renzi's resignation took immediate effect. This will give the new PD leadership greater flexibility later in the government formation process. The party's interim leader, Maurizio Martina, has promised that he will manage the party collegially, which will mean that the views of Mr Renzi's opponents in the PD, some of whom advocate talks with M5S, will have to be taken into account. Initially, the PD will leave the onus of trying to form a government to M5S and the centre right led by the Lega. However, if other options fail and a rerun of the election appears imminent and investors start to get nervous, we expect that the PD and the wider left will re-enter the process at a later stage.
President's government (low probability)
Party cohesion tends to be weak in Italy, and parliamentary rules make it relatively easy to change parliamentary group. Almost 600 MPs out of a total of 945 changed groups at least once in the 2013-18 term. Prolonged inconclusive negotiations on forming a government would be likely to cause strains in M5S and between the parties on the centre right and the centre left. This could lead to the breakdown of party discipline and a fracturing of the parliamentary blocs that have emerged from the election, opening up new coalition options and making possible some form of broad coalition. However, at present such an arrangement would appear to be numerically difficult.
A major cause for concern for MPs that might persuade them to converge on a government programme would be the high cost of getting elected and the need to establish tenure to gain parliamentary pension rights. The president's insistence, and possibly volatility in financial markets, could be additional push factors. Such a government would be likely to have a limited policy remit.
Rerun election (low to medium probability)
The level of political fragmentation is such that the risk of a new election has risen. In the past political parties have generally found a compromise to break political deadlock after a messy election or government crisis. Mr Mattarella would probably be reluctant to call for a rerun vote, which would be likely to yield a similar outcome. However, if parties cling stubbornly to their red lines and the parliamentary groups remain mostly intact, a new vote may become unavoidable. There has been some speculation about the formation of a short-term administration to reform the voting law before a new election is held. If political parties remain deeply divided, an agreement on electoral reform seems highly improbable.
However, when faced with the possibility of a fresh election under the same voting rules, and the financial volatility that might accompany it, we believe that it is likely that a combination of M5S, the PD, FI and several small centrist groups would agree to form a government.
Political outlook: Election watch
We expect political risk to remain high in Europe throughout the forecast period. In the euro zone, in particular, the negative political fallout from the financial crisis, coming on top of the long-term erosion of the post-war political party system, is proving to be electorally disruptive. Moreover, recent evidence suggests that fragmentation and difficulties forming a government occur even in countries that are registering solid rates of growth, such as Ireland, and in traditionally politically stable countries, such as the UK.
Fine Gael minority coalition government will not survive full term
The collapse of Leo Varadkar's Fine Gael-led minority coalition government in Ireland was narrowly averted in late November 2017. Our view remains that the government does not have the capacity or cohesion to address effectively the mounting economic and political challenges facing Ireland. As a result, we continue to believe that the government will not survive a full term to February 2021 and that a snap election will take place in the second half of 2018 or in early 2019. The timing is complicated by the planned referendum on abortion, which is likely to be held in late May. The topic is divisive; barring another government crisis, Mr Varadkar may choose to wait before calling a general election if the referendum campaign or the outcome of the vote were to damage his party's support, which cannot be ruled out.
Given voter disillusionment with the three established parties-Fine Gael, Fianna Fail and the Labour Party-we expect the next election to be incon-clusive, as in February 2016. Another such outcome would put greater pressure on Fine Gael and Fianna Fail to set aside their historical differences and form a grand coalition.
At the 2016 general election none of the established parties was willing to contemplate entering a coalition with the nationalist Sinn Fein party led by Gerry Adams, which had links to the now disbanded Irish Republican Army (IRA). We think that this is unlikely to change after the next election, but a transition is now under way in the party. The leadership has passed to Mary Lou McDonald, one of Sinn Fein's younger members, who is not associated with the conflict in Northern Ireland.
In Spain political dysfunction has been pronounced. At end-October 2016, following an inconclusive general election in December 2015 and a rerun ballot six months later, parliament elected Mr Rajoy, the leader of the PP, as prime minister for a second term. However, Mr Rajoy's PP minority government is one of the weakest in Spain's democratic history, and we do not expect it to serve a full four-year term. It relies on just 170 votes-those of the PP, Ciudadanos and the Canary Island Coalition (CC)-in the 350-seat Congress of Deputies (the lower house of parliament). With Ciudadanos now topping the polls as the largest party, pressure is mounting on Mr Rajoy.
The parliamentary term ends in June 2020, but an early election is likely to be held in 2018 or 2019. The Catalonia crisis represents another threat to government stability. Over the medium term Spanish politics will remain fluid, with scant prospects for major political or economic reforms until a stronger administration enters office.
The next parliamentary and presidential elections in Turkey are due to be held in 2019, but they could be called earlier if Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the president, decides to accelerate the transfer of executive powers to the presidency once the institutions and instruments of the new presidential system are in place. Given Mr Erdogan's popularity, and his party's ability to control the election process, we expect him to win the presidential election and to remain in office with enhanced powers for at least one more five-year term, if not two (the maximum allowed), up to 2029. The president's popularity is unrivalled, and the opposition is fragmented and currently appears to have no candidates capable of challenging him.

Political outlook: Intra-regional tensions
East-West political tensions are at their highest since the dissolution of the Soviet Union. Russia is slowly dismantling the security and arms control agreements that were put in place in at the end of the cold war. Russia's opposition to the post-cold war security architecture was evident in its decision to withdraw from the Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe (CFE) and its breach of the 1987 Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) treaty, which bans short- and medium-range ballistic missiles. Western countries have accused Russia of funding opposition parties in western Europe and employing cyber warfare against Western targets, as well as engaging in a propaganda war through media outlets that it controls in the West.
Russia-West tensions intensified when a former Russian intelligence officer, Sergei Skripal, and his daughter Yulia were found unconscious on March 4th, having been attacked with a rare nerve agent in the UK city of Salisbury. Little is known at this stage about the circumstances surrounding the attack, which also affected the first police officer who arrived at the scene. All three are in a critical condition in hospital. The UK government accused the Russian state of being behind the attack, citing a previous assassination in 2006 when polonium, a radioactive agent, was used to murder Alexander Litvinenko, a former member of the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB, the Russian domestic intelligence service), in London. The UK government, and in particular Boris Johnson, the foreign secretary, used strong language in their condemnation of Russia. Russian diplomats and officials made the most of the hostile UK response and the ratcheting up of tensions to mobilise support for Mr Putin, who stood for election for a fourth presidential term on March 18th. Despite the tough talk from the UK, so far the measures taken, including the expulsion of 23 Russian diplomatic staff from the embassy in London, have been rather modest. Should a Russian connection be established, especially in view of the method used, which potentially endangered many civilians, UK-Russia relations would worsen further and there would be pressure on the UK to respond more decisively.
Tensions with Russia are unlikely to abate
Russia has said that the EU and the US are interfering in its sphere of influence, supporting the so-called "Colour Revolutions" in former Soviet space. Russia has accused NATO of going back on its post-cold war commitments by expanding relentlessly, first taking in central Europe and the Baltic republics, then Albania and Croatia in 2009 and, most recently, Montenegro in June 2017. Bosnia and Hercegovina (BiH), Macedonia and Georgia are now in the waiting room for admission. The Iraq War and Colour Revolutions fuelled Russian insecurity and convinced Russia that the US wanted "regime change" in the country, and possibly the break-up of the Russian Federation. In the face of such an existen-tial threat, from the Kremlin's perspective any countermeasures are justified.
In March 2014 Russia annexed Crimea and has since been providing military support to pro-Russian rebels in eastern Ukraine. The EU imposed sanctions on Russia's energy, defence and banking sectors in July 2014 following the downing of a passenger plane over Ukrainian territory controlled by Russian-backed separatists. The sanctions are subject to regular renewal, requiring the approval of all 28 EU member states.
The Minsk II ceasefire agreement, signed in February 2015, is highly unlikely to lead to a resolution of the conflict in Ukraine. Russia sees Ukrainian integration with the EU and NATO as a direct threat to its national interests. The current status quo, of a regularly breached ceasefire with contained levels of fighting, seems likely to endure for several years. This will serve Russia's interests, as a frozen conflict will prevent any Ukrainian move towards the EU.
Russia will remain vehemently opposed to EU and NATO integration with the countries of the former Soviet Union. Regime change in any country in Russia's immediate neighbourhood, particularly via a popular uprising similar to the Ukrainian Maidan revolution in 2014, would trigger a crisis in relations between Russia and the West.
We do not expect political or economic upheaval in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) region in 2018. The exceptions to this outlook are Uzbekistan, where the new president will continue pursuing a reformist course, and Armenia and Georgia, which will hold presidential elections this year and outpace most of the region in terms of economic growth. In Kazakhstan uncertainty will increase regarding the succession of the long-time president, Nursultan Nazarbayev, and the launch of the Astana International Finance Centre (AIFC) will not be an investment game-changer. We believe that no significant political or economic change will take place in the other central Asian countries (Uzbekistan, the Kyrgyz Republic, Turkmenistan and Tajikistan). The vulnerability of several countries, including Tajikistan and the Kyrgyz Republic, to political and social instability will remain high.
Policy-related tensions remain high within the euro zone, but the risk that they will prompt a breakdown in inter-governmental relations has fallen sharply over the past year, as economic growth has picked up across the bloc. The ECB has successfully overcome objections in a number of countries-notably in Germany-to its use of unconventional policy instruments. However, the breathing space created by the ECB's programme of sovereign quantitative easing has, up to now, not been used by political leaders to bolster the economic recovery with a strong united position on fiscal policy and structural reform.
The rise of anti-establishment political sentiment across much of the bloc has generated increased pressure for economic policymaking that is focused on national considerations rather than on the integrity of the euro zone, creating new centrifugal forces at a time when policymakers are already struggling to remedy the institutional shortcomings of the single currency. Huge political capital has been invested in keeping the euro zone together in recent years. This should ensure its survival in the short term, but the risk of a partial break-up in the medium term remains significant. We attach a 60% probability to Greece leaving the euro area during our five-year forecast period.
The refugee relocation policy will be a bone of contention in the EU
The issue of refugee relocation is a focal point for existing tensions between integration-minded countries of west Europe and a core of central European countries. In September 2015 the European Council established a temporary scheme to relocate across the EU some of the Syrian refugees who had arrived in Italy and Greece, with the aim of sharing the burden of accommodating them. This was particularly controversial in central and eastern Europe, where governments characterised it as an attempt by western Europe to export the consequences of misguided foreign policies, and said that it raised the prospect of terrorist attacks as a result of Islamist infiltration. Public opposition to the scheme has been substantial across the region.
Tension between Turkey and the EU will remain high
Despite talk of agreeing a new roadmap to ease tensions and improve co-operation in the main areas of interest such as security, trade and investment, neither Turkey nor the EU is genuinely interested in Turkish membership of the bloc anymore. However, neither has yet been willing to suspend negotiations unilaterally. If Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, as Mr Erdogan has suggested, the EU might not be able to avoid suspending the process. This would almost certainly prompt the country to end its collaboration with the EU to stem the movement of migrants and refugees into Europe. A settlement of the de facto division of Cyprus between the Greek Cypriot south and the Turkish Cypriot north could help to improve Turkey's relations with the EU, but talks collapsed in July 2017. We maintain our forecast that a settlement is unlikely during the forecast period.
Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved. Russia has lifted almost all sanctions, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly in relation to the conflict in Syria, where both are militarily involved but have pursued contrasting goals. We expect relations to remain largely transactional, and the risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Mr Erdogan's state visit to Greece on December 7th-8th 2017-the first such visit by a Turkish president in 65 years-was a tense affair. Greater co-operation on issues such as trade and security may result, but points of contention will continue to fuel distrust. Historical territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea or more recent events, such as the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the failed coup in Turkey in July 2016, and the arrest and imprisonment of Greek soldiers who strayed over the Turkish border on March 1st 2018, will continue to be flashpoints. We expect relations to remain tense, with sporadic flare-ups, but we do not expect an outbreak of conflict.
Economic policy
Euro zone reform efforts are being stepped up
The threat of a euro zone break-up has receded in recent years as the region's economic recovery has strengthened and broadened, and as its institutional underpinnings have become more resilient. The commitment in July 2012 by the president of the European Central Bank (ECB), Mario Draghi, to "do whatever it takes" to preserve the euro represented a turning point for the bloc, the resilience of which to shocks has also been bolstered by the establishment of an EU banking union and a permanent rescue fund. EU leaders are currently making a renewed push for further integration of the economic and monetary union. Proposals put forward by the European Commission on December 6th 2017 included turning the European Stability Mechanism (ESM)-the euro zone's bail-out fund-into a European Monetary Fund (EMF) that would provide a backstop for the banking union; a stabilisation function for the euro area, which would deal with asymmetric shocks by providing resources to support investment at the national level; and a euro zone economy and finance minister who would oversee the EMF and serve as vice-president of the European Commission.
Some aspects of these plans will meet internal resistance and will struggle to get off the ground. In The Economist Intelligence Unit's view, strengthening the existing structures would be helpful, but such proposals are not necessary for the region's economic recovery to continue in the coming years. EU leaders will present reform proposals at a summit in June 2018.
The UK's departure from the EU will encourage policymakers to address some of the structural deficiencies that have held back the economy in recent years, including lacklustre productivity growth, insufficient innovation and poor infra-structure. The chancellor, Philip Hammond, announced a National Productivity Investment Fund to boost the UK's digital infrastructure and spending on research and develop-ment over the next five years. Proposals to reform the UK's housing market have focused on introducing greater speed and flexibility into the planning process. There will also be a new effort to improve vocational skills. We expect these measures to support the recovery in productivity, but they are still too modest in size and scope to close the UK's productivity gap with its G7 peers.
The Queen's Speech in June 2017 set out the government's legislative agenda, which was dominated by Brexit. Eight of the 27 bills relate to the transfer of EU law into British law, a UK customs regime, independent trade policy, controls on immigration, fisheries policy, agricultural policy, nuclear safeguards and the UK's ability to impose international sanctions. In a further sign that Brexit is the government's priority, the parliamentary session will last for two years rather than one, ending two months after the UK's withdrawal at end-March 2019.

A conservative fiscal bias has prevailed across most of the region since the global crisis in 2008-09, leaving policymakers to rely heavily on low interest rates and unconventional monetary policy tools as the main levers with which to manage their economies. This created a significant degree of exposure to the impact of the monetary policy cycle in the US, where we expect further tightening in 2018-19. Although we continue to expect monetary policy to remain accommodative in most countries, we now expect fiscal policies to be slightly more supportive during our five-year forecast period (2018-22).
We expect fiscal consolidation to exert a much less powerful drag on growth in 2018-22 compared with the preceding five years. Almost all European countries improved their fiscal positions in 2009-16 (2017 data are not yet available), with the star performers being Iceland (by 25.6 percentage points of GDP), Greece (15.6), Ireland (13.1) and Lithuania (9.4). In the EU only Spain and France had deficits larger than the EU's 3% of GDP limit in 2016 (4.5% and 3.4% respectively). Although we expect fiscal policies to be slightly more supportive of economic growth, significant fiscal loosening remains off the agenda for most countries, especially for those with high public debt loads, owing to the rigidity of the rules agreed by EU members at the height of the euro zone crisis. The average EU government debt/GDP ratio was 85.4% at end-2016, but Belgium, Cyprus, Greece, Italy and Portugal had debt ratios in excess of 100%, and those for France and Spain were only slightly below 100%. Hefty debt loads will remain a challenge for much of the euro zone for many years. Although the cost of debt servicing has fallen dramatically in recent years owing to the exceptionally low interest rates that currently prevail across the bloc, borrowing costs are set to rise gradually as monetary policy is normalised.
The UK government is targeting steady deficit reduction
The UK's fiscal position improved in 2016-17, and we expect this improvement to be maintained in 2018-22, despite a fiscal loosening in the November 2017 autumn budget. We forecast that the deficit will stabilise at about 3% of GDP in 2018, after averaging 2.9% in 2016-17, as the government eases off its austerity drive. However, in the remainder of our forecast period the government will aim to nudge down discretionary spending as a proportion of GDP. We expect the deficit to narrow to 1.9% of GDP by 2021 and 1.6% by 2022. The public debt burden stood at 88.2% of GDP in 2016. We forecast that public debt will peak at just below 89% of GDP in 2018, before falling thereafter.
Within the EU, over the past two years a number of national governments have shown signs of pushing back against centralised fiscal constraints, which are significantly more rigorous as a result of changes introduced in response to the crisis. In 2016 tensions between several member states and the European Commission, which enforces the EU's budgetary rules, came to a head. In early July 2016 the Commission proposed that Spain and Portugal should be fined for their failure to meet deficit targets in 2015, but the Commission ultimately stepped back from this position. The episode highlighted the growing tension between the strict fiscal rules agreed at the height of the crisis and the mounting political and economic arguments within member states for a greater degree of fiscal flexibility.
The Russian government faces tight budget constraints as a result of low commodity prices. However, despite international sanctions and the reluctance of Western banks to handle international bond issuances, Russia placed two oversubscribed Eurobonds in June 2017, followed by two more in March 2018. The budget deficit narrowed sharply in 2017, to 1.4% of GDP (from 3.4% of GDP in 2016), on the back of higher average oil prices. We expect the Ministry of Finance to continue to trim the deficit in 2018-22, but the adjustment to expenditure is likely to be less radical than planned, particularly in the short term, given the recent social spending promises of the president, Vladimir Putin. We believe that the government is unlikely to hold expenditure fixed in nominal terms in 2018-19 as projected, although spending will still decline in real terms, and plans to reduce defence spending have been announced. Under the three-year budget outlook the finance ministry aims to cut the deficit as a share of GDP to 1.6% in 2018, 0.9% in 2019 and 0.8% in 2020, in line with our projections of annual budget deficits of less than 1% of GDP in 2019-22.

Despite the healthy economic outlook across the region, an absence of corresponding inflationary pressure means that the ECB will keep monetary policy accommodative this year. Policy interest rates will remain below zero and an asset purchase programme (APP) will run at EUR30bn (US$37bn) per month until September. In March 2018 the ECB dropped a sentence from its policy statement that had demonstrated its willingness to expand the APP if the outlook worsened. This implies that the bank is preparing to cease monthly net asset purchases under the APP, reinforcing our view that they will be reduced in the fourth quarter of 2018, before coming to an end.
The ECB and regional central banks are moving towards policy normalisation
Rising commodity prices and evidence of domestic price pressure should mean that sufficient inflation will begin to emerge in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take a first step towards normalising its main refinancing rate in early 2020, before embarking on a gradual tightening cycle that brings it to 1.5% by end-2022. The next increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability. We expect the ECB to maintain its stock of assets, which we expect to total close to EUR2.6trn (US$3.2trn), throughout the forecast period.
Anticipating a build-up of inflationary pressures, other central banks across the region have started, or are preparing, steps towards policy normalisation. The Bank of England (BoE, the UK's central bank) and the Czech National Bank (CNB, the Czech central bank) both raised their main policy rate in late 2017, and are expected to follow up with at least one more rate increase this year. Meanwhile, we expect rate rises from Norges Bank (Norway's central bank) and the Riksbank (Sweden's central bank) in late 2018. The Swiss National Bank (SNB, Switzerland's central bank) is likely to reduce its foreign-exchange interventions in 2018, and to lift its policy interest rate by a small amount in 2019.
The BoE is keen to normalise monetary policy
The UK economy has been sufficiently resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote for its central bank to increase the main policy interest rate from 0.25% to 0.5% in November 2017, the first rate rise in a decade. In March 2018 the BoE voted to keep policy unchanged, although two of its nine-member monetary policy committee (MPC) voted to increase the policy rate by 25 basis points, to 0.75%. The MPC is keen to begin normalising its policy rate and most members agree that a further tightening will take place at some point this year. Revised forecasts from the BoE at the time of the February meeting showed stronger economic growth prospects over the next few years, with real GDP growth set to average 1.7% in 2018-20-above consensus estimates. Survey-based indicators suggest that preliminary GDP data for the first quarter of 2018 will confirm a picture of firm activity when they are released on April 27th, setting the stage for a majority vote in favour of a small rate increase in May, or at the time of the next quarterly inflation report, in August. We maintain our view that this will be followed by a gradual tightening cycle.
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector and its dynamic, diversified private business sector. However, the risk of an intensification of political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity could disrupt foreign capital inflows during the forecast period. These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, but tend to be short term and highly volatile. Shifts in capital flows triggered by expectations of tighter US monetary policy and geopolitical tensions in the neighbouring region have already put the lira under severe pressure on several occasions since late 2016, fuelling an acceleration in inflation. Under political pressure to not raise interest rates further, especially ahead of the 2019 elections, the Central Bank of Turkey is constrained in its ability to tighten monetary policy. In the event of another severe weakening of the lira, an abrupt tightening of policy, which could strangle Turkey's economic recovery, may be necessary. However, this is not our baseline scenario.
In Russia the fall in oil prices, which led to a significant contraction in real GDP and household consumption in 2015-16, has underlined the imperative for reforms to encourage investment and diversification away from commodity exports. However, we do not expect significant reforms to be undertaken during Mr Putin's fourth term, and the Russian president will continue to prioritise social and political stability. We expect state involvement in the economy to remain substantial. In his March 1st state of the nation speech, Mr Putin set out some of his socioeconomic goals for his next presidential term. His agenda appeared to include fragments of competing policy agendas proposed by Aleksei Kudrin, a former finance minister, and the Stolypin Club, an economic research group led by a business ombudsman, Boris Titov. The Kudrin camp emphasises the need to reduce the role of the state in the economy and to increase competitiveness and productivity by investing in human capital, in contrast to the Stolypin Club's call for a more statist and Keynesian policy agenda. Reform of the tax system and a gradual rise in the pension age appear likely. Institutional reform to strengthen the rule of law and protection for businesses looks much more difficult to achieve.
Policy to be kept tight to support the Turkish lira and lower inflation
The Turkish lira has been highly volatile and on a generally depreciating path against all major currencies since mid-2013, when the prospect of a gradual reduction in ultra-loose global liquidity and an eventual tightening of policy took shape. After a fall in the nominal value of the lira of about 17% against the US dollar in 2017, we expect the pace of depreciation to slow during the forecast period, keeping the currency broadly stable in real terms. There are substantial risks to this forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows as well as the impact on investor confidence of domestic political tensions and geopolitical turmoil in the region. We expect the lira to average TL4.26:US1 in 2022, compared with TL3.65:US$1 in 2017.
Inflationary pressures have continued to weaken in Russia in 2017
Russia has seen steady consumer price disinflation since late 2015, with inflation hitting a record low of 2.2% year on year in February 2018, well below the CBR's 4% inflation target. Disinflation has been assisted by record harvests in 2016-17, as well as the relative strength of the rouble (against the US dollar and the euro). We expect inflation to pick up in the second half of 2018, reaching the 4% target near the end of the year as the CBR loosens policy, the rouble depreciates modestly against the dollar and consumer demand increases. In 2019-22 we expect inflation to remain close to-but slightly above-the 4% target (very low levels by Russian historical standards). In 2018 a tightening of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank) and the possible imposition of new US sanctions will lead to a modest depreciation of the rouble against the dollar, to an average of Rb60.6:US$1. We forecast an overall slight nominal appreciation in 2019-22 owing to increasing oil prices, although a downturn in the US business cycle will lower oil prices slightly and weaken the rouble in 2020. The rouble is correlated with oil prices, so any rapid fall in oil prices could lead to renewed volatility.
For central and east European countries with currencies pegged to or managed against the euro (mostly in the western Balkans), risks of volatility have moved in line with expectations of tightening by the Fed. However, we do not see significant risks to the currency boards in Bosnia and Hercegovina (BiH) or Bulgaria, or to the peg in Macedonia. Croatia had been more of a concern, in the light of the 2015 legislation to force banks to convert Swiss franc-denominated loans into euro. However, the country's improved external and fiscal positions, and increased demand for the kuna as a result of a strong tourism performance have driven appreciation, which we forecast will continue in 2018.
Currencies across the former Soviet Union depreciated sharply in 2015 as a result of the weakening of the rouble and lower oil prices, which have hit commodity exporters. Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan both officially abandoned their US dollar pegs in 2015. In practice, the commitment of both countries to a free float would be seriously tested in the event of further oil price volatility. We would expect the central banks of both countries to intervene-at least temporarily-in such a scenario to prevent sharp fluctuations in the currency and to maintain financial and monetary stability.

Average annual real GDP growth in the UK was firm in 2016 and 2017, at 1.9% and 1.8% respectively. However, the annual pace of growth slowed throughout 2017, from 2.1% in January-March to 1.5% in October-December. The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts a further modest growth slowdown in the next two years, to 1.5% in 2018 and 1.4% in 2019, led by a slowdown in domestic demand. A looser fiscal stance will provide some positive support to real GDP growth throughout the 2018-22 forecast period, but consumer spending will weaken in response to the squeeze on household disposable incomes from falling real wages. Consumer spending was fairly resilient to this pressure in 2017, reflecting employment gains, high levels of household borrowing and a sharp drawdown of savings. In 2018 we expect employment growth to slow and greater uncertainty about the economic outlook to push up precautionary savings. Consumer spending will recover in 2019-22 as inflation eases, uncertainty recedes and unemployment edges lower. However, increased borrowing costs arising from tighter monetary policy will hold back the pace of the recovery in these years. We forecast that investment spending will decelerate in 2018-19 as a result of heightened uncertainty during difficult Brexit trade negotiations and higher cost pressures as a result of sterling's depreciation, before recovering in 2020-22 as these effects fade.
Mitigating the extent of the domestically driven slowdown in 2018 will be a positive contribution to GDP growth from the external balance as export volumes benefit from a competitiveness boost as a result of sterling's depreciation, and the weaker domestic demand environment reduces import growth. The export boost will ease in 2019, after which we expect the trade balance to exert a drag on GDP growth owing to our forecast for a recovery in domestic demand, which will push up import growth again. Our expectation of a business cycle downturn in the US in 2020 and a deal on the UK's new trading relationship with the EU, which should take effect in 2021 and result in looser trade ties than before, will also constrain exports in 2020-22. We expect real GDP growth to pick up to 1.8% on average in 2020-22.
The economic impact of the UK's vote to leave the EU on the wider regional economy could be substantial. In addition to the direct effect via trade and investment channels, over time the referendum result is also likely to compound centrifugal political and institutional dynamics in the EU and the euro zone. However, the short-term economic fallout from Brexit will be modest for Europe as a whole.

Euro area 2.5 2.2 1.9 1.7 1.7 1.7
The euro zone recovery has gathered pace
The outlook for the European economy has improved greatly. Real GDP growth gained momentum in 2017 as the recovery that had been building since 2013 became more broad based. We expect EU28 growth to accelerate this year, from 1.9% in 2016 to 2.4%, before slowing to an annual average of 1.8% in 2018-22. Virtually all euro zone member states have registered firmer rates of expansion, and although country-level disparities persist, the region's recovery is looking healthier. In our view the economic recovery has further to run, partly because it is rooted in factors that will underpin sustainable demand, such as rising employment and household deleveraging. Furthermore, there remains significant slack in the euro zone economy that has yet to be absorbed.
We expect growth in the euro zone to moderate this year, from 2.5% in 2017 to 2.2%, before slowing to an annual average of 1.8% in 2019-22. The upswing in the euro zone and the broader EU mitigates the risk to the region's economic prospects from external factors, notably monetary policy tightening in the US and an expected slowdown in China.
Nevertheless, the longer-term outlook for the single currency area will remain challenging. Demographic factors will begin to exert a more powerful drag on an increasing number of countries in the bloc. We do not expect policymakers to find solutions to some of the euro zone's institutional shortcomings. In particular, they are unlikely to reform the bloc's fiscal policy framework. This means that tensions will persist between member states over targets for budget deficits.
In Germany the domestic demand-driven pick-up in real GDP growth accelerated in 2017, bringing headline growth to 2.5%. We forecast 2.4% growth in 2018, with the rate of economic expansion easing gradually thereafter, to 1.7% on average in 2019-22. Growth will be slower in France (owing to structural rigidities in the tax system and the labour market) and Italy (reflecting a weak demographic profile, political instability and a slow pace of reform).
In southern Europe, the economic recovery on the Iberian peninsula may have peaked in 2017. After real GDP growth of 3% in Spain in 2017, we forecast average growth of 2.2% in 2018-22. Portugal recorded real GDP growth of2.7% in 2017, and we forecast an expansion of 2.3% this year and 1.7% on average in 2019-22. Meanwhile, Greece will exit its third bail-out programme this year, but we are sceptical that the country will experience rapid growth. The Greek economy returned to growth in 2017 and should experience a modest rebound in 2018-22. The UK economy has been resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote, but is losing momentum and will slow in 2018-19 as economic uncertainty weighs on spending and investment, before recovering gradually.
The Visegrad countries can look forward to above-average growth rates
Much of central and eastern Europe also faces a challenging environment in the longer term. However, countries that benefit from EU funding in particular will see real GDP growth well above the EU average in 2018-22. A deadline at the end of 2015 for fund drawdowns from the EU's 2007-13 fiscal period brought an end to a surge in investment spending. Funding inflows for projects under the 2014-20 funding period were slow to begin in 2016, holding back activity last year, but funds began to flow again in 2017 and projects are under way that will lift economic growth rates during the forecast period. We expect that growth in Germany-a major market for these countries-will remain solid. The German economy's changing structure, with investment and private consumption rising, will provide a boost to central and east European countries with strong trade links to their larger neighbour.
Economic activity is picking up in south-east Europe
In south-east Europe the situation is generally improving after a protracted and difficult post-crisis recovery. We expect continued strong real GDP growth in the region's biggest economy, Romania, which grew by 7% in 2017, of 5.5% in 2018 and of 3.7% per year in 2019-22. However, rapid wage growth is driving a consumer boom that is sucking in imports and inflating the current-account deficit, and tax cuts have widened the fiscal deficit. Bulgaria will also maintain the momentum established in 2015-17. In 2018-22 we expect real GDP growth to average 3%. This sustained pick-up is driven by improved performance in the euro zone, robust export performance and increased expenditure on infrastru-cture projects, which received a boost from a surge in the inflow of EU funds.
Growth in the western Balkans to accelerate; Baltics and Visegrad to slow
Economic activity in the western Balkans has picked up in the past three years, reflecting a combination of favourable base effects and externally driven cyclical factors such as low oil prices. In 2015-16 private investment and exports were the main drivers of growth in Albania, Montenegro and Serbia, with private consumption remaining weak, pointing to a more balanced growth trajectory. The region has undergone a significant economic adjustment in the years since the global economic crisis in 2007-09, largely correcting fiscal and current-account imbalances (with some notable exceptions, such as Montenegro). Inflation has fallen to historical lows for the region, allowing a more accommodative monetary policy that has supported growth. The revival of investment is set to continue, and over the medium and long term the western Balkans should benefit from the structural reforms that are now under way in most countries. On the downside, high public and/or private debt loads, and (in some cases) continued large fiscal deficits remain impediments to faster growth. We do not think that the fallout from the Brexit vote will be unduly negative for the Balkans, whose slow progress towards EU membership is set to continue.
We forecast average real GDP growth in the western Balkans (Albania, Bosnia and Hercegovina-BiH-Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia) of about 3.2% in 2018. Growth in the three Baltic states is estimated at 4.3% in 2017 and we expect it to average 3.4% per year in 2018-19.
Greece's economy has been in almost permanent recession since 2008. Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than a quarter during this period, government consumption also by nearly a quarter, house-hold consumption by a fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery that got under way in 2017 is fragile and vulnerable to domestic and external developments. We estimate that real GDP will expand by 1.9% per year on average in 2018-22, following growth of 1.3% in 2017.
In Turkey domestic political instability, the perceived risk of terrorist attacks and uncertainty about the global economic outlook weighed on the economy in 2015-16, but relative stability following the April 2017 presidential reform referendum and fiscal stimulus measures have supported a rebound to estimated growth of 7% in 2017. We expect growth to slow to an annual average of 4.1% in 2018-22, reflecting the impact of tax increases, higher interest rates and a gradual tightening of global liquidity. The main downside risk is that further political instability stemming from the transition to a presidential system of government could deter foreign capital inflows. Upside risk stems from government plans to extend stimulus measures, but this could also result in a larger than expected fiscal deficit.
Russia's economy has moved into a recovery phase
According to a first estimate by the Federal State Statistics Service (Rosstat), real GDP in Russia grew by 1.5% in 2017, up from a contraction of 0.2% in 2016. The return to growth was mainly driven by private consumption and, to a lesser extent, by fixed investment. In 2018 we expect the factors supportive of private consumption to persist, with inflation low and the rouble relatively stable. As indicated in the March state of the nation address given by Vladimir Putin, the president, government spending on wages and pensions should pick up this year. Economic stabilisation and a higher average oil price are supportive of a rise in gross fixed capital formation, but international sanctions, the lack of a "culture of failure", and broader political and business uncertainty will remain significant constraints. We expect import growth to slow, lessening the negative contribution from the external balance. Overall, this points to a slight increase in real GDP growth, to 1.7% in 2018. In the medium term outdated capital stock, a declining workforce, dependence on natural-resource sectors, institutional weaknesses, subdued investment levels, a weak financial sector, international sanctions, low productivity growth, a difficult business environment and statist policies will limit real GDP growth. We forecast that growth will average 1.7% per year in 2018-22, mainly driven by private consumption and, to a lesser extent, fixed investment, as in 2017.
The possible end of Russian gas transit in 2019 represents a big risk
Real GDP fell by a cumulative 16.4% in Ukraine in 2014-15 amid conflict and a chaotic political situation. The disruption of these years accentuated a structural change in the Ukrainian economy away from heavy industry and towards agriculture. The economy recovered in 2016, driven by vigorous growth in private invest-ment, alongside a recovery in private consumption. We estimate that real GDP grew by 2.2% in 2017, given better external conditions, increased social spending (boosting consumption) and a solid recovery in investment (domestically funded). In 2018 we expect real GDP growth to rebound, to 3%, and in 2019-22 we expect growth to average 2.6%, led by household consumption. The possible end of Russian gas transit in 2019-when the current transit contract expires and the Nord Stream 2 pipeline connecting Russia to the EU through the Baltic Sea is supposed to begin operations-represents a risk.
Growth and exchange-rate movements in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) region are highly correlated to movements in global oil prices, especially in large oil exporters such as Russia, Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan. Owing to important trade links and high levels of remittance flows, the performance of the Russian economy has a direct impact on that of smaller CIS countries in Central Asia (the Kyrgyz Republic and Tajikistan) and the South Caucasus (Armenia and Georgia, not CIS members). We forecast growth of 1.7% in Russia, 1.6% in Azerbaijan, 3.2% in Kazakhstan and 3% in Ukraine in 2018. Given our forecast for a broadly stable oil price of around US$60/barrel in 2018-22, barring other major developments the growth outlook for most countries is unlikely to change significantly from this year's final outturn.

The slump in global oil prices in late 2014 exacerbated a marked disinflationary trend in Europe, but helped to boost the region's real economy in 2015, and to a limited extent in 2016, as households benefited from higher real earnings and businesses from lower input costs. Since late 2016 inflation has picked up, with base effects-notably those related to energy prices-providing much of the initial impetus in early 2017. As base effects have fallen out of the arithmetic, inflation has stabilised again. We expect it to average 1.7% in the EU28 in 2018 and 1.9% per year in 2019-22.
In a number of specific instances across the region, very different inflationary patterns will be recorded-Turkey, for example, will struggle throughout the forecast period to bring its inflation rate down to its 5% official target. Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high, as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disinflationary effects of plunging global oil prices since mid-2014. Assuming that the Central Bank of Turkey keeps monetary policy tight and does not loosen it again too soon, we see inflation gradually easing, achieving the 5% target by end-2022.
