The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings model seeks to measure the attractiveness of a country's business environment and its major components. The model's assessment of the business environment-based on the opportunities for and hindrances to the conduct of business-enables us to rank each of the 82 countries covered on its overall position and in each of ten categories on a global and a regional basis. The model uses quantitative data and expert assessments to measure the attractiveness of countries' business environments. The framework has been designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies in formulating their global business strategies and investment location decisions. The overall scores (on a 1-10 scale) and rankings are based on scores for 91 indicators, grouped into ten categories.
There is a moderate improvement in Europe's aggregate regional scores between the historical period (2013-17) and the forecast period (2018-22), reflecting the transition from the post-crisis period to one in which recovery and repair, although patchy, have, in most countries, been under way for some time. Western Europe's score remains broadly stable, rising from 7.46 in the historical period to 7.67 in the forecast period, and eastern Europe's score moves up from 6.07 to 6.50 over the same timeframe. Across the region, the strongest ranking improvements are recorded by Denmark, Romania, Croatia and Cyprus. By contrast, Turkey drops by ten places, Switzerland by six, and Greece and Ireland by four. Western Europe is ranked second globally out of six regions, after North America (8.21), and eastern Europe is ranked fourth, after North America, western Europe and Asia and Australasia (6.79), but performs above Latin America (5.74), and the Middle East and Africa (5.62).
EU countries remain well represented in the top 20 of our global rankings. Two non-EU countries, Switzerland and Norway, also occupy leading positions. The large number of west European countries in the top 20 reflects the high degree of political stability in the region (a post-crisis rise in social and political tension notwithstanding), large and competitive domestic markets, and a strong degree of openness to world trade. Although we continue to highlight the risks of political fragmentation and rising anti-establishment sentiment, we do not forecast a marked anti-market backlash in policy choices.
Recent years have brought considerable improvement to the investment climate of central and eastern Europe. The early reformers among the countries of central Europe led the way in the early 1990s in adopting far-reaching stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation programmes. Reform in the Balkans has been much more uneven and subject to periodic reversals, but significant progress has been made even here. Factors such as a low-cost but well-qualified labour force, proximity to developed markets and, in some cases, ample natural-resource endowments have attracted considerable foreign direct investment to the region during the past decade. However, many east European countries still face fundamental reform challenges; meeting those challenges will test already fraying relations between governments and electorates, and heighten the risk of political instability and social unrest.
The outlook for the business environment in the countries of the former Soviet Union is mixed. In Russia the business environment has suffered as a result of Western sanctions and a rise in tariff and non-tariff barriers. There is little evidence that the government intends to undertake disruptive structural reform to improve the dynamism of the economy. Low energy prices have prompted some regional commodity exporters, notably Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan, to attempt to open up and diversify their economies. Ukraine has committed itself to an ambitious reform programme; however, its economic prospects will be harmed by disruption of trade and financial ties with Russia. Throughout the region the barriers to enacting wide-ranging reform remain formidable.
Data sources and definitions
Methodology
The forecast tables have been constructed from the individual data series available in the respective Economist Intelligence Unit Country Forecasts. In addition, the Economist Intelligence Unit runs the National Institute's Global Econometric Model (NIGEM), which is developed and maintained by the London Business School at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines ten separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, and infrastructure. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 16 (infrastructure), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
The main sources used in the business rankings model include CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce; Freedom House, Annual Survey of Political Rights and Civil Liberties; Heritage Foundation, Index of Economic Freedom; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; UN, Human Development Report; US Social Security Administration, Social Security Programs Throughout the World; World Bank, World Development Report; World Development Indicators; Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Report.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Although the regime of the president, Nicolás Maduro, will strengthen its grip on power following the installation of a Constituent Assembly in 2017 and rigged presidential elections this coming May, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect Mr Maduro to remain in office beyond 2019. The most likely scenarios for a transition to an opposition-led government are through ad hoc elections after economic collapse or a military coup. There is a risk that the regime will cling to power beyond 2019 if it finds financing to meet its debt obligations or boosts dwindling oil production.
We estimate that inflation exceeded 2,000% at the end of 2017 and will average over 10,000% in 2018. GDP will continue to contract in 2018-20. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption, and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. Following a change in policy under a new government, we expect economic growth to resume in 2021.
Sweeping reforms are required to restore confidence in contract and property rights, and thereby promote a recovery in investment. The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will encourage private investment, re-establish market mechanisms for price stability and attempt to undo the constraints imposed by the government on private firms.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and quadruple-digit inflation will hit private consumption, and an increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate the fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices, and the economy will not return to growth until 2021-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
US dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, GDP contraction and extremely high inflation (driven by shortages of foreign exchange and basic goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. After 2020, under a new government, we expect purchasing power and the business environment to improve.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela is in 80th position globally in The Economist Intelligence Unit business environment rankings for 2018-22, out of 82 countries covered, making it one of the least attractive investment locations in the world. This reflects state interventionism, highly heterodox macroeconomic policies, a lack of legal security and weak institutions. Regionally, Venezuela remains last of the 12 countries covered, notwithstanding our assumption of improvements after 2019.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Nationalisation poses a diminished threat, given fiscal weaknesses. Property rights remain weak. Price fixing undermines profitability.
2020-22: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists. A new government in 2019 brings new policies.
2020-22: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain fairly low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2018-19: Unorthodox exchange-rate policy framework adds to uncertainty. The state continues to exercise tight control over access to official-rate US dollars. New government in 2019 removes exchange controls.
2020-22: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2018-19: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2020-22: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2018-19: Credit growth remains firm, but sectoral allocation is distorted by administrative interventions. Banks remain highly profitable, although unpredictable enforcement and a weak regulatory framework heighten instability.
2020-22: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2018-19: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2020-22: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Access to water and electricity supplies remains precarious. Underinvestment in power transmission ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2020-22: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued electricity rationing.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez was diagnosed with cancer in 2011 but, after declaring in July 2012 that he had fully recovered, won a fourth presidential term in October 2012. However, his health quickly deteriorated and he died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has since plummeted.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is a federal republic, successive administrations have proven reluctant to devolve political authority, with the transfer of financial resources from federal to local level highly dependent on the central government. The legislature is unicameral, and elections for the National Assembly take place every five years. In December 2015 the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the legislature. In August 2017 the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) installed a Constituent Assembly with powers over all branches of government and a remit to rewrite the 1999 Constitution-apparently a ploy to entrench the PSUV in power.
Policy issues: Political radicalisation has been reflected in increasingly heterodox economic policies, with massive fiscal and monetary stimulus and nationalisation of industries deemed strategically important. This approach has created large distortions , with inflation rising sharply in spite of price controls, and capital controls spawning a rampant black market for foreign exchange. Failure to invest part of the past oil windfall has led to a startling decline in physical infrastructure. Non-oil production has ground to a halt, leaving the economy entirely dependent on the energy sector. With large oil shipments going to China to repay loans, and (on subsidised terms) to regional neighbours via the PetroCaribe oil-financing scheme (although this is winding down), the country is running short of US dollars, forcing cuts in import spending.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 60% for oil firms. Since 2011 a maximum royalty of 95% has applied to oil extraction. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Using IMF data, we estimate that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$16.5bn in 2017 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. We estimate the current-account deficit at 0.4% of GDP that year.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Even as Venezuela's severe economic woes deepen amid an intensifying debt crisis and hyperinflation, the governing Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has strengthened its hold on power while the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) has slid into disarray. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects worsening economic conditions to result in a chaotic political transition process, most likely ushering the MUD into power in 2019.
The president, Nicolás Maduro, is poised to be re-elected on May 20th in fraudulent elections. Administrative obstacles have disfranchised opposition parties, including the MUD itself, and most of the opposition is boycotting the election. The PSUV controls almost all subnational governments, has outsized influence on the judiciary and has created its own de facto legislature by instituting, in 2017, the PSUV-only Constituent Assembly (ANC) to supplant the MUD-controlled National Assembly. Although economic conditions in the country continue to deteriorate, sparking protests and violence, the MUD has little chance of effecting change by itself. The PSUV's continued hold on power and the MUD's historical penchant for infighting has meant that the MUD's own base has become increasingly demoralised and demobilised.
The PSUV's permanence in power hinges on continued support of three key backers: the state's coercive apparatus (the security forces and military); a sizeable sector of the population dependent on government handouts; and the so-called colectivos, activist groups that are a cross between community organisers and PSUV paramilitaries. The key backer is the military, which controls most of the ministries related to management of the economy and security. This includes-since November-the Ministry of Oil and PDVSA, the state-owned oil company. The government plies these groups with resources, with the vast majority coming from PDVSA. We believe that a prolonged interruption in exports by PDVSA would destabilise this patronage system and hence undermine the regime's base of support.
We see three main paths towards such interruption. The first two paths involve the curtailment of trade with the US, from where PDVSA obtains most of its hard-currency earnings through exports while also importing vital production inputs. In the short term, it would be logistically impossible to replace the US as a trading partner. The most immediate way in which access to the US market would be denied is by the imposition of sanctions on the oil trade by the US government. Despite threats, American authorities have so far not introduced such sanctions, perhaps mindful of internal socio-economic costs, as Venezuelan oil is refined and distributed in the US by Citgo, a PDSVA subsidiary. A similar curtailment of trade with the US may take place owing to asset seizures stemming from legal action by the holders of the bonds on which the government and PDVSA are in arrears. Although seizures could potentially take place in any jurisdiction, seizures in the US, including of Citgo assets, would be the most immediate and damaging. However, no such legal action has yet been taken and the timing of potential seizures is uncertain. The third path towards a destabilising reduction in foreign-exchange earnings is related to PDVSA's falling output due to mismanagement and underinvestment. Oil output has fallen by over 20% since Mr Maduro took office, and we expect production to continue dropping, dragging with it PDVSA's foreign-exchange earnings. Politically motivated investment from Russia and China, once abundant, seems unlikely to return in enough volumes to prop up production.
Although we expect further concessions to the military in 2018, we expect that the declining oil output will put the government's patronage system at risk by late 2018 or early 2019. What happens next is difficult to predict, especially in the light of the close relationship between military leaders and PSUV civilians. An outright military government is a possibility. An internal re-organisation of the regime, whereby the military takes on increased powers while maintaining civilian figureheads, Mr Maduro included, is also possible. However, we continue to believe that the profound economic crisis and desperate humanitarian situation will fuel a combination of social upheaval and concerns regarding the loyalty of the military's lower ranks that will force the military's hand, prompting it to remove Mr Maduro from power, accept foreign humanitarian aid and call for elections.
Regardless of how and when political transition occurs, the second half of our forecast period is likely to remain volatile and uncertain. In addition to having to contend with holdovers in the colectivos, the military and every branch of the state, the opposition will have to confront huge economic distortions and deep political differences that would test even a unified political party.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
On March 1st the National Electoral Council agreed to postpone the presidential elections scheduled for April 22nd to May 20th, while also expanding them to include municipal and state legislatures. Owing to administrative chicanery, the majority of the opposition parties, including the MUD, are either banned or are boycotting the election. The only opposition politician of national relevance participating is Henri Falcón, a former member of the PSUV, who now heads an opposition party, Avanzada Progresista. We expect Mr Maduro to be victorious in elections riddled with irregularities. We do expect relatively free and fair elections following the PSUV's exit from power.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Venezuela has come under increasing regional and international pressure. Mercosur (a regional bloc comprised of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) and the so-called Lima Group (a group of 12 Latin American nations) have denounced the regime. The EU and the US have applied individual sanctions on regime members. In addition, the US has instituted country-level sanctions that deny Venezuela the possibility of refinancing its debts. Although the application of sanctions on the oil trade is not part of our baseline forecast owing to the potential cost to American business and consumers, should such measures be introduced they would be politically destabilising to the administration and could potentially prove a trigger to regime change.
A key priority for the Maduro administration will be the maintenance of good relations with Russia. The latter continues to provide limited financial backing, but it seems increasingly unlikely to provide the several billions of dollars needed each year not just to reverse default but also to stem the decline of oil output. China, a previous major source of financing, has seemingly with-drawn; there is no public evidence of any significant new Chinese financing since 2015.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The government's immediate economic policy concern will be fending off debt default and associated legal challenges. The government has gone into arrears on some sovereign and state-owned firms' bonds (including PDVSA bonds), while also reportedly making late payments on others. We estimate current arrears in excess of US$1.7bn. The government has restated its commitment to pay while blaming payments delays on US sanctions and the payment system. Mr Maduro has called for a debt restructuring, but this appears impossible owing to US financial sanctions and, more fundamentally, because the government lacks a credible economic programme
There is no sign yet of lawsuits by bondholders, who so far appear to prefer the promise of late payment to lengthy legal battles. The expectation of policy changes following the May elections, something that we consider unlikely, may also be influencing bondholder's behaviour. Eventually, this stance is likely to change. To avoid PDVSA asset seizures, the government may choose to openly default on sovereign bonds but adhere to PDVSA's repayment schedule. So far it has done neither. If it did openly default, sovereign creditors would undoubtedly ask US courts to define PDVSA as an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government in order to seize its assets. However, such claims will take time, making timing of likely seizures unclear. When they do happen, the consequences on the economy will be devastating and would potentially trigger a regime change.
In the meantime, the government must also grapple with a build-up of huge inflationary and currency depreciation pressures. Monetisation of large public deficits has led to foreign currency rationing and hyperinflation. In line with our expectations, the government undertook a maxi-devaluation in February 2018, but even at current rates the currency remains overvalued and foreign exchange remains rationed. Economic policy will remain unstainable and ad hoc policy intervention and heavy state control of the economy will persist.
Under our baseline scenario we expect the opposition to come to power in 2019. An adjustment package, including a restructuring of debt, would follow. We have factored into our forecasts a financing agreement with the IMF to support the process, assuming lending of US$19bn in 2019-22. We also expect significant financial and real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
The authorities' failure to publish data on the non-financial public-sector (NFPS) accounts since 2012 demonstrates the opacity of the public finances and complicates accurate forecasting of the size of the deficit. We estimate a NFPS deficit of 19.3% of GDP for 2017 and expect the deficit to remain in double digits in 2018. A transition to a new government should help to ease the deficit to 4.5% of GDP by 2022. The large deficits of the present are mostly being financed by printing money. High inflation and an overvalued currency are eroding the relative value of domestic and external debt, making debt/GDP ratios unreliable indicators of fiscal stability. There is considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing, mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China. As these items are excluded from the public debt statistics, the true size of total public liabilities is understated. Under our baseline forecast of severe economic stress that would see the opposition taking power in 2019, we expect a restructuring with external creditors to happen.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
Monetary policy under the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) will continue to be driven by the government's financing needs, forcing the BCV to print money. Money supply (M2) rose by 1,845% year on year in February. In the context of hyperinflation, we expect real rates to remain deeply negative until 2019. After that, we forecast substantial currency and fiscal adjustment under a new government, which will lead to a return to real positive interest rates.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Amid ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending, we project further contractions in real GDP in 2018-20, following an estimated contraction of 13.9% in 2017. Our forecast for a recovery in 2021-22 rests on an assumption of a political transition that, supported by IMF financial and institutional assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme, including management of the country's oil wealth. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, given the scale of the recession, and our forecasts therefore imply only a partial rebound, after a real GDP decline of over 50% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2018, reflecting the effect on real wages of soaring inflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will continue to contract as well, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange, and remitting profits. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition, progress on long­delayed joint projects with Chinese firms in energy and-later in the forecast period-a pick-up in public-sector investment. Oil output will continue to shrink throughout 2018-19, reflecting a combination of severe mismanage-ment, underinvestment and depletion of oil fields. We expect output to bottom out at 1.30m barrels/day (b/d) in 2019, down from 1.95m b/d in 2017. Under our baseline forecasts, oil production will pick up in 2020, reflecting renewed investment under a new government. Exports, however, will only recover in 2021, as domestic demand has been artificially constrained. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply. Dependence on oil will persist in 2018-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
A decimation of domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. We do not expect a policy reversal under the PSUV government, meaning that inflation will remain extremely high in the short term. Official data has not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly has estimated that monthly inflation was 84% in January, bringing year-on-year inflation to over 4,000%. We now expect inflation to average over 10,000% in 2018. Shortages of basic goods will continue, as the lack of foreign currency limits imports. There is a high risk of a hyperinflationary spiral in coming months that increases inflation to well above our current forecast and necessitates a dramatic adjustment, probably involving a resort to currency substitution.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
Despite the recent announcement of exchange-rate unification and maxi-devaluation, the currency remains overvalued and further currency adjustment will be necessary. Rationing of foreign currency will continue in the short term. In late January the BCV announced that the Dicom system, a heavily managed auction platform, would be used by both the private and public sectors. In late February, after a months-long suspension, the Dicom rate was BsF24,898:US$1, a massive devaluation from the previous Dicom rate of BsF3,445:US$1. The Dicom rate has continued to depreciate, but the system remains opaque and provides no guarantee that the government-which monopolises the country's export business-will provide foreign exchange, making the auction system unsustainable. Indeed, in addition to rationing foreign exchange, the BCV has already announced difficulties in settling trades since February. This, coupled with runaway growth in the money supply, will continue to put pressure on the exchange rate. The black-market foreign-exchange rate was at around BsF205,000:US$1 in early March.
Given the existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market and growing hyperinflation, the government may introduce a new domestic currency or attempt some kind of currency substitution in the future. In our baseline scenario of a MUD-led government in 2019, similar measures may be undertaken. The exact nature and implementation of the plan is hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
We expect the current-account surplus to reach US$2.9bn in 2018 (0.6% of GDP at the distorted exchange rate, which overstates the GDP in dollar terms). Even though we assume that extreme compression of imports will continue (we estimate imports in 2018 will be one-fifth their level of 2012), Venezuela's lack of access to foreign finance means that the current-account surplus will not be enough to meet the country's financing needs. Indeed, excluding arrears, we calculate that principal repayments of sovereign and state companies' bonded debt alone amount to US$4.2bn. As such, we expect further arrears in 2018 and 2019. By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following a debt renegotiation-external financing will be restored and that imports will begin a recovery. We foresee the current account to go into a deficit of 4.8% of GDP in 2020 at the no-longer so highly distorted exchange rate. Recovering oil production and the re-structured interest payment schedule facilitate a narrowing of the current-account deficit to 1.1% of GDP in 2022.
With the opposition in power, financial and investment inflows will provide sufficient financing and help to rebuild reserves coverage. This will buttress the stability of the external accounts and facilitate the gradual removal of foreign-exchange controls, narrowing the gap between official and parallel exchange rates. There are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. It hinges on a substantial assistance package from the IMF, the quick implementation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt renegotiation process within 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-22, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Turkey is due to hold municipal elections in March 2019 and parliamentary and presidential elections in November that year. However, the parliamentary and presidential elections could be held earlier than scheduled, either with the municipal elections or even in 2018, if the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his Justice and Development Party (AKP) believe they have sufficient support to win, or if economic headwinds pose a risk to their electoral dominance.
After the presidential and parliamentary elections an executive presidency will replace the current parliamentary system of government. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win the elections and remain in power until 2024, and probably beyond. The new system provides few checks on the president's powers, moving Turkey closer to one-man rule. Since the failed coup in 2016 Mr Erdogan's domestic political goal, notably to become president with executive powers, has heavily conditioned foreign policy. This has resulted in a deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. We expect a complete rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high.
The AKP has enjoyed 15 years of single-party rule, and for most of that period political and government effectiveness have improved. However, since 2013 economic policymaking institutions have become increasingly politicised. We expect annual budget deficits to widen moderately, to 2.4% of GDP on average in 2018-19, before narrowing gradually after the elections to 1.6% of GDP in 2022. The risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances cannot be ruled out.
We forecast a slowdown in real GDP growth from an estimated 7% in 2017 to a still robust 4.1% per year on average in our forecast period (2018-22), reflecting higher taxes and the withdrawal of stimulus measures. Our growth forecast assumes that domestic political conditions will stabilise and foreign investor confidence in Turkey will hold up, maintaining foreign capital inflows.
After a fall in the nominal value of the Turkish lira of about 17% against the US dollar in 2017, we expect the pace of depreciation to slow, keeping the currency broadly stable in real terms. Constrained in its ability to raise interest rates, we expect the Central Bank of Turkey to have to resort to unorthodox and less effective tools to respond to currency weakness and high inflation.
We expect the current-account deficit to remain broadly unchanged in 2018 at 5.7% of GDP before narrowing to a still large annual average of 5.2% of GDP in 2019-22. This will make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is severely constrained and investor confidence deteriorates.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2018-22, but in the global rankings the country falls by ten places, to 55th. There is consensus among policymakers on the need to maintain macroeconomic stability. However, the failed coup and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2020-22: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2020-22: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade and tourism following the lifting of Russian sanctions.
2020-22: The customs union with the EU could be extended, but negotiations are likely to be protracted given the deterioration in Turkish-EU relations. More free-trade agreements may come into force with the EU's trading partners.
Taxes
2018-19: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Some tax rate rises, including on company profits, have been announced for 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit.
2020-22: A broader income tax base as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2018-19: Monetary policy remains cautious, but political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey not to raise interest rates continues. Risk of the US imposing fines on several Turkish banks over alleged violations of US sanctions on Iran.
2020-22: The banking system remains stable, despite some weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2018-19: Labour market remains rigid, with relatively high costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. Wage moderation after 30% minimum wage rise in 2016. Obstacles to employing foreigners have eased.
2020-22: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Progress, albeit slow, continues on investment plans in energy, transport and communications. The first phase of the third Istanbul airport becomes operational.
2020-22: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West, becoming a member of the Council of Europe (1949) and NATO (1952), and signing an association agreement with the then European Community (1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup at-tempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a unicameral parliamentary system of government, with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. A presidential system of government will come into effect by late 2019, and possibly earlier. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president and leader of the AKP, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015 and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted institutional weaknesses, which, with the AKP's consent until 2013, allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence from the government. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax has been raised, from 20% to 22%, in 2018. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2017 goods exports (fob) came to US$166bn and imports (fob) to US$224bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$59bn-a sharp widening from US$41bn in 2016. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Turkey is due to hold municipal elections in March 2019 and parliamentary and presidential elections in November that year. However, the parliamentary and presidential elections could be held earlier than scheduled, either with the municipal elections or even in 2018, if the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his ruling, religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) believe that they have sufficient support to win, or if economic headwinds pose a risk to their electoral dominance. After these votes an executive presidential system of government will replace the current parliamentary system. The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, will win the elections and remain in power until 2024, and probably beyond. The constitutional reforms to establish a presidential system, which were approved in a referendum in April 2017, provide few checks and balances on the powers of the president. This will further weaken Turkey's democratic institutions and governance structures, effectively moving the country into a system of one-man rule by Mr Erdogan. Although an unlikely prospect, failure by Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win the elections could throw the political system into chaos and open up irreparable divisions in the AKP.
We expect social and political tensions to remain high during the period up to the elections in 2019, and possibly beyond. The narrow presidential reform referendum victory, amid allegations of vote tampering, has further polarised the country. It also raised concerns among the AKP's leaders that Mr Erdogan and his party were losing support. With the president's political future dependent on clear victories in all three elections, the government will continue its campaign against political opponents, critics and perceived enemies of the state, using the state of emergency law. Emergency rule was initially introduced after the failed coup to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. We expect emergency rule to remain in place until after the elections, because it will effectively allow Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is fully in place. The politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence from the government.
The operational capacity problems created by the purge of the Turkish Armed Forces (TSK) and the police after the attempted coup appear to have eased to a large extent, but security risk remains high. Turkey is vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK are interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1980s levels. Turkey's military operations in Syria are seeking to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK, but risk further fuelling the conflict with the PKK in Turkey's south-east. The defeat of IS in Syria and Iraq could result in renewed attacks in Turkey and elsewhere.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
As things stand, we expect Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win the next presidential and parliamentary elections and remain in power until 2024, and probably beyond. The opposition is fragmented, Mr Erdogan's popularity is still unrivalled and he has the support of the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP). Importantly, the AKP also has the ability to control the election process. However, there are concerns within the AKP that the party has lost support since the referendum, and that victory for Mr Erdogan in the presidential election is far from assured, especially if Abdullah Gul, a former president and co-founder of the AKP, decides to run. The challenge of Mr Gul, combined with that of the charismatic Meral Aksener-who recently formed the Good Party (IP), a breakaway group from the MHP-and the leader of the main opposition Republican People's Party (CHP), Kemal Kilicdaroglu, could prevent Mr Erdogan from reaching the 50% threshold for victory in the first round. This would transform the second-round run-off between Mr Erdogan and the candidate with the second-largest share of votes into a deeply polarising referendum on Mr Erdogan's leadership.
The clampdown on the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) since mid-2015, the decision of the MHP leadership to back the presidential reform, and the hardline nationalist stance adopted by Mr Erdogan and the AKP could have a considerable effect on voting patterns at the next parliamentary election. The HDP risks falling below the high 10% national vote threshold for parliamentary representation. This would boost the AKP's seat share. Support for the MHP has also fallen, but in exchange for the MHP's backing of Mr Erdogan in the presidential election the two parties have agreed an electoral alliance to ensure that the MHP retains its representation in parliament. Under the constitutional changes approved in the referendum there will be 600 seats in a much weakened parliament from the next election, up from 550 currently.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. There is a considerable risk of a rupture in Turkey's ties with its traditional Western allies, compounding their concerns that under Mr Erdogan the country is pivoting eastwards. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration, including political upheaval in Europe and the US; a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; the US's military backing of PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups; the Turkish government's authoritarian tendencies and its strident anti-Western rhetoric; and Turkey's forging of closer relations with Russia, China and Iran. Turkey's confrontational approach to its traditional Western allies should also be viewed in the context of Mr Erdogan's need to maintain the support of the country's nationalists to achieve his domestic political goals, notably to become president with executive powers after the next elections, due in 2019.
Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and increasingly transactional rather than strategic, but we expect Turkey and its Western allies to avoid a complete breakdown in relations. However, this might become unavoidable if the EU suspends the country's moribund accession negotiations, the migrant deal with the EU collapses, the US imposes sanctions on Turkey over alleged violations by Turkish banks of US sanctions against Iran, Turkey closes the Incirlik air base to US forces, or it withdraws from NATO, none of which can be ruled out completely. Operation Olive Branch, Turkey´s crossborder military operation in Afrin in north-western Syria that was launched in January 2018, has accentuated tensions with the US. The operation aims to clear the area of US-backed, PKK-affiliated Kurdish groups that are intent on establishing a continuous autonomous region along Syria's northern border with Turkey.
Turkey's involvement in the conflict in neighbouring Syria will continue to influence the direction of Turkey's foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly regarding the conflict in Syria, where they are co-operating but have been pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to continue to be largely transactional. The risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector and its dynamic, diversified private business sector. However, the risk of an intensification of political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity could disrupt foreign capital inflows during the forecast period (2018-22). These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, but tend to be short term and highly volatile. Shifts in capital flows triggered by expectations of tighter US monetary policy and geopolitical tensions in the neighbouring region have already put the lira under severe pressure on several occasions since late 2016, fuelling an acceleration in inflation. Under political pressure to not raise interest rates further, especially ahead of the 2019 elections, the Central Bank of Turkey is constrained in its ability to tighten monetary policy. In the event of another severe weakening of the lira, an abrupt tightening of policy, which could strangle Turkey's economic recovery, may be necessary. However, this is not our baseline scenario.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The current direction of policy appears to be towards a difficult balancing act between moderate fiscal loosening and relatively tight monetary policy, at the same time as encouraging banks to lend to households and businesses.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios-reflecting the impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past and major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-have given the government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy in the aftermath of the attempted coup in July 2016. As a result, we expect the central government deficit, which captures most of the public sector, to have expanded from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to an estimated 1.5% in 2017. Despite a series of tax increases this year, we expect increased government spending on defence, security, infrastructure projects and public employment ahead of the elections next year to cause the deficit to widen further, to an average of 2.4% of GDP in 2018-19, before narrowing to 1.6% in 2022. We expect the central government debt/GDP ratio to remain stable at about 28.5% in 2017-19, before declining gradually to 27.5% in 2022. Our baseline forecast is predicated on the assumption that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight to support investor confidence and to prevent a surge in domestic demand from causing an unsustainable widening of the current-account deficit. However, the risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances has increased, reflecting the impact of political instability ahead of the next elections.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The central bank will have to keep its monetary policy tight in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent further depreciation of the lira amid political volatility and expectations of higher US interest rates and balance sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank). However, because of political pressure not to raise interest rates further, we expect the central bank to have to resort to unorthodox and less effective tools to respond to the challenge, which will periodically test investor confidence in the bank's policy mix of moderate rate increases and macroprudential measures. The bank raised most of its main policy rates between November 2016 and April 2017, but since November 2017 it has focused on using its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate to fund the banking system. This rate was gradually raised by a total of 275 basis points in 2017, to 12.75% in mid-December, pushing the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system to 12.75% since January 2018, compared with 7.8% in November 2016.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
We estimate that real GDP growth accelerated sharply, from an annual average of 3.3% in 2016 to 7% in 2017. The rebound has been supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand. We expect growth to slow to an annual average of 4.1% in 2018-22, reflecting the impact of tax increases, higher interest rates and a gradual tightening of global liquidity. The main downside risk is that further political instability stemming from the transition to a presidential system of government could deter foreign capital inflows. Upside risk stems from government plans to extend stimulus measures, but this could also result in a larger than expected fiscal deficit.
We are forecasting that household consumption growth will moderate from an estimated 5.5% of GDP in 2017 to a still solid 3.4% per year in 2018-22 as a result of higher interest rates and the withdrawal in late 2017 of government incentives to support household spending, but some of these could be extended. We expect government consumption growth to accelerate from an estimated annual average of 2.5% in 2017 to 5.8% in 2018-19, easing after the elections to a more moderate, but still robust, 4.8% in 2020-22.
The deterioration in the business environment since the attempted coup and an increase in the corporation tax rate to 22% from 2018 will continue to hold down private-sector fixed investment growth. However, we expect this to be offset by government investment, especially in infrastructure, generating real growth of 5.5% per year in 2018-19. In 2020-22 we forecast a deceleration to annual growth of 4.8% per year, reflecting public-sector retrenchment and firms' response to a more moderate expansion of domestic and external demand.
The lifting of Russian sanctions on Turkey, especially in the tourism sector, the positive effect of a weaker lira on export competitiveness and strong external demand have contributed to a rebound in exports of goods and services. However, we expect growth to slow from an estimated 11.9% in 2017 to an annual average rate of 4.7% in 2018-22, reflecting base effects and our view that 2017 probably represented the recent peak in global economic growth.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target-as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disinflationary effects of low global oil prices. We expect the pass-through effects of past currency weakness and a moderate recovery in oil and other commodity prices from 2017 to keep consumer price inflation well above the official target during the first half of the forecast period. Assuming that the central bank does not loosen monetary policy too soon, we expect inflation to ease gradually, achieving the 5% target by end-2022. There are significant upside risks to our forecast if the lira depreciates much more rapidly than we are currently forecasting.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
After a fall in the nominal value of the lira of about 17% against the US dollar in 2017, we expect the pace of depreciation to slow during the forecast period, keeping the currency broadly stable in real terms. There are substantial risks to this forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows as well as the impact on investor confidence of domestic political tensions and geopolitical turmoil in the region. We expect the lira to average TL4.26:US1 in 2022, compared with TL3.65:US$1 in 2017.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
The moderately higher cost of imported energy and inputs for manufactured import-intensive exports has offset the boost to Turkey's main exports from a weaker lira and the lifting of Russian sanctions. Owing to particularly large trade deficits at the end of 2017 and in early 2018, we now expect the current-account deficit to remain broadly unchanged in 2018 at 5.7% of GDP, compared with 5.6% of GDP in 2017. Reflecting moderating domestic demand growth and more stable global commodity prices, we forecast that the deficit will narrow to a still large annual average of 5.2% of GDP in 2019-22. Turkey's substantial external financing needs will be difficult to meet if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates. The rebound in tourist arrivals in 2017 will remain vulnerable to a possible resurgence of terrorist attacks in the country.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
Global data
OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate

Oil prices: dated Brent
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP growth and components: Turkstat
Population: UN Population data base and Economist Intelligence Unit interpolation

Exchange rates and interest rates: IMF, IFS

Abstract: [...]he led the ÖVP to a plurality of the vote in the early election on October 15th, winning a 31.5% share-up by 7.5 percentage points on its result in 2013. In order to assuage concerns from Mr Kurz and the president, Alexander Van der Bellen, about the FPÖ's previous Euroscepticism, the party has agreed not to push for a referendum on EU membership. Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
An early election in October 2017 was won by the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP), led by the young minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, who has since become chancellor at the head of a coalition government of the ÖVP and the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ).
The inclusion of the FPÖ in the government will not lead to significant tensions with other EU member states, as it did in 2000, when the party was last part of a coalition. This is largely because of the normalisation of the far right in Europe since then.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the new government to focus on integration and immigration policy, and to attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and introduce some additional flexibility in labour and product markets. However, low government cohesion is likely to lead to limited progress.
We forecast that the government budget will remain in deficit, albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP, throughout the forecast period (2018-22), as the fiscal consolidation process is likely to be restrained by limited government cohesion and effectiveness. The public debt/GDP ratio will fall gradually, to just below 70% by 2022, from an estimated 79.7% in 2017.
After several years of underperformance compared with its regional peers, the economy has performed relatively strongly since the start of 2016, growing by 3.1% in 2017. We forecast a continuation of strong growth this year, at 2.5%, and for growth to moderate to 1.7% on average in 2019-22.
Consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) will continue to exceed the euro zone average in 2018-22, driven by structural domestic factors including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets. Annual inflation averaged 0.9% in 2015-16 and 2.2% in 2017. We expect annual average EU harmonised inflation of 2% in 2018-22.
The current-account surplus has been relatively stable in recent years, at about 2%. Although we expect small changes in the composition of the surplus, we expect it to remain stable overall, at 2.2% of GDP on average in 2018-22, driven mainly by a strong surplus on the services balance, supported by tourism inflows.

Austria's business environment score rises between the historical period (2013-17) and the forecast period (2018-22), mainly owing to the improving economy. Austria's strengths as a business location include good infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited.
2020-22: Modest strengthening of competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2020-22: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal.
2020-22: EU maintains focus on bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate. No progress on EU-US trade deal. Free-trade agreement between EU and UK.
Taxes
2018-19: Limited changes to the tax system aimed at reducing the sizeable income tax wedge.
2020-22: Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform, and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2018-19: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe.
2020-22: Further uptake in corporate bond issuance. Credit conditions continue to ease as banks' profitability recovers, in part supported by a gradual uptick in interest rates.
The labour market
2018-19: Economy-wide minimum wage introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment continues to fall.
2020-22: Continued modest expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2020-22: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure.

Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election was held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government will focus on migration and integration issues, including in the EU context. It will also attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and implement other measures to improve the business environment, including through enabling more flexibility in the labour market.
Taxation: Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is among the highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: In 2016 the value of exported goods was US$142.7bn and the goods import bill was US$142.3bn. The services surplus, traditionally boosted by tourism receipts, was US$12.2bn. Along with a modest primary income deficit and significant secondary income deficit, this yielded a current-account surplus equivalent to 2.1% of GDP.
