Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
In May 2017, after several years of little progress on reforms, and coalition, as well as party, in-fighting, the grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart following the resignation of Reinhold Mitterlehner from the positions of vice-chancellor, economy minister and leader of the ÖVP. The popular 31-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, took over the leadership of the ÖVP and reformed the party around himself. As a result, he led the ÖVP to a plurality of the vote in the early election on October 15th, winning a 31.5% share-up by 7.5 percentage points on its result in 2013. The SPÖ's vote share was unchanged, at 26.9%. The far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) increased its share of the vote by 5.5 percentage points, to 26%. The liberal NEOS returned to parliament with just over 5% of the vote, and the Greens failed to cross the 4% electoral threshold for the first time in 31 years, in part because List Pilz, led by a former leader of the Greens, narrowly managed to cross it.
The ÖVP and the FPÖ formed a coalition in mid-December after just over a month and a half of negotiations. Under Mr Kurz the ÖVP has moved close to the FPÖ in many policy areas (during the campaign the leader of the FPÖ, Heinz-Christian Strache, regularly accused Mr Kurz of copying the FPÖ's programme) and the negotiations thus went relatively smoothly. In order to assuage concerns from Mr Kurz and the president, Alexander Van der Bellen, about the FPÖ's previous Euroscepticism, the party has agreed not to push for a referendum on EU membership. Moreover, EU policy will be handled by the chancellery instead of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which is headed by an FPÖ appointee.
Although the chancellor is from the ÖVP, the election should still be seen as a further step in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the ÖVP has, to a large extent, been replaced by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties had together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, but a renewed grand coalition had become almost impossible following the breakdown of relations between them and the gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited both from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz also owes much of his popularity to his strong stance on this issue and his plans to curtail migration into Europe and Austria.
Despite the overlap between the ÖVP's and the FPÖ's programmes, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to struggle to implement its policies, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters, where they are significantly less well aligned than they are on social and cultural matters. In addition, the FPÖ could struggle to translate its opposition stance on topics such as immigration and integration into concrete policy proposals, owing in part to internal party upheaval. As a result, we expect limited progress on significant structural reforms. The initial phase of the government's term is likely to be relatively smooth, owing in part to the country's role as president of the Council of the European Union in the second half of 2018. Later in the term the FPÖ might struggle to distinguish itself from the ÖVP, which could lead to tensions between the parties, creating a moderate risk of an early election.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The last general election was held on October 15th 2017. Unless the government falls before then, it will sit in the Nationalrat (the lower house of parliament) until the end of its term in late 2022. The next election for the primarily ceremonial post of federal president will be in 2022.
Three elections for state parliaments have already been held so far in 2018, with one more planned. These tend to be fought on local issues and give only a limited view of national political developments. Nevertheless, the FPÖ's recent underperformance in Carinthia could push it to take stronger stances on the national level.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions, including the leading role that it played in closing the migration route through the Balkans. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this inflow, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high. All three of the large parties have hinted that they want to limit labour migration within the EU, or at least give preferential treatment to Austrian citizens in the labour market, which could exacerbate tensions with many EU member states.
Nevertheless, Mr Kurz has been at pains to point out that his government will be pro-EU, and that Austria's EU membership will not be questioned in the coming years. The new government plans for Austria to be a leading voice in the bloc in the coming years, especially on reform of migration, and this should be facilitated by the country's role as president of the Council of the European Union in the second half of 2018. We expect the government to find broad support for proposals such as tighter controls of the EU's outer borders and processing asylum applications outside the EU.
Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ in government following the 1999 election led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations in 2000, the reception has been more muted this time. At that time a far-right nationalist party entering government was an unusual development, but since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority governments in several EU countries, including some Nordic countries and the Netherlands.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The new govern-ment plans to move integration and immigration policy further to the right, including through curtailing benefits for asylum-seekers and cutting child benefits sent abroad. It has also presented plans that focus on improving the business environment, including by reducing corporate tax rates and introducing more flexibility for working hours. Furthermore, it plans to cut a number of labour market programmes aimed at the long-term unemployed and integrating migrants into the labour market. However, it does not plan to reform the country's so-called Proporz system, under which the ÖVP and SPÖ had apportioned public life-state companies, public services, subsidies, regulatory responsibilities-despite suggestions from both coalition parties in the past, especially from the FPÖ, that they would want to do this. We therefore expect reform momentum to be limited and for the government to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
In 2014 Austria's fiscal accounts deteriorated, mainly reflecting the govern-ment's decision to create a bad bank to deal with the toxic assets of Hypo Group Alpe Adria. The fiscal deficit widened to the equivalent of 2.7% of GDP, from 2% in 2013, and public debt rose to 83.7% of GDP. Mainly in response to steady direct revenue growth, the deficit narrowed to 1% of GDP in 2015, but widened again in 2016, to 1.6%, owing in part to fiscally expansionary tax reforms and higher migrant-related public spending. Strong growth contributed to an estimated narrowing of the deficit to an estimated 1.1% of GDP in 2017.
We expect the budget to remain in modest deficit throughout the forecast period (2018-22), albeit safely within the EU mandated limit of 3% of GDP. Although there will be only limited fiscal consolidation, robust economic growth will help to narrow the deficit slightly. The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from an estimated 79.7% in 2017 to just below 70% in 2022. Although the public finances will remain worse than in peers such as Germany or the Netherlands, the low-interest-rate environment and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals mean that funding risks are extremely low in our view.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The European Central Bank (ECB) is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that ran at EUR60bn per month until the end of 2017, and is running at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. However, the ECB's view of the outlook improved markedly during 2017 and, although it remains dovish, we expect a more upbeat tone to emerge this year, and an end to monthly asset purchases under the QE programme by early 2019. Rising commodity prices and evidence of building domestic price pressure in some parts of the euro zone should mean that sufficient inflationary pressures will begin to emerge on the policy horizon in 2019-20. In response, we expect the ECB to take steps towards normalising its policy stance with an increase of 25 basis points in the main refinancing rate, to 0.25%, in early 2020, followed by five more rises that lift the main refinancing rate to 1.5% by end-2022. An increase in the deposit rate, which currently stands at -0.4%, may come sooner, in 2019, easing the pressure on banks' lending margins and supporting profitability.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy largely stalled and underperformed in comparison with regional peers, notably Germany. This was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. A faltering reform process in recent years contributed to higher inflation compared with regional peers and weakened productivity growth, admittedly from fairly high levels. However, the economic recovery gained significant momentum from the second half of 2016. Although in previous years the labour market had struggled to integrate the significant increase in the labour force, it seemed to have turned a corner in late 2016 and early 2017, owing in part to a surge in employment in the manufacturing sector, and we expect a continued gradual improvement in labour market indicators in the coming years. This is supporting private consumption, which we expect to grow by 1.8% this year. Export and investment growth have also picked up. As a result, real GDP growth was 3.1% in 2017-above growth in Germany for the first time since 2005 and Austria's fastest growth rate since 2007.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-following an under-performance even compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue this year, although we forecast slower growth, at 2.5%, as we expect the impulse from the manufacturing sector in 2017 to have largely been a one-off. In the following years we expect a moderation of growth. Domestic demand will be the main driver of growth, which is likely to converge towards its potential growth rate in these years. We therefore expect average real GDP growth of 1.7% in 2019-22. Government policy is likely to be supportive of growth in the coming years, and the main risks are external. As a highly open economy, Austria is vulnerable to global economic developments, including any shocks to global trade.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.9% in 2015-16-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets, and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices and energy price base effects fostered a gradual increase in inflation in 2017, leading to a full-year average of 2.2%. The recent strengthening of the euro will weigh slightly on inflation, but we expect price growth to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-22, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors seen in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
For most of 2015-16 the euro moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1, before a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. However, in 2017 the euro rallied as the region's economic recovery strengthened and expectations of QE tapering increased, and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. The exchange rate peaked at almost US$1.25:EUR1 at the beginning of February 2018 and has since receded, but it remains above US$1.20:EUR1. The value of the euro could yet come under pressure from political risk-especially in the wake of the March 2018 general election in Italy-and monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a gradual appreciation on average, to US$1.21:EUR1 by 2020-21, as the euro is supported by an ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, while the business cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020. Thereafter we expect the euro to appreciate to US$1.24:EUR1 on average in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values helped the trade balance to move into surplus in recent years, from a deficit in 2009-13. We expect the trade balance to gradually decline, moving closer to balance in the coming years as robust export growth is outweighed by higher import costs and strengthening domestic demand pushes up import volumes. However, this will be compensated for by a healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourist inflows. Modest primary income surpluses will not be enough to outweigh consistent secondary income deficits. However, the services balance will ensure that the current-account surplus remains broadly flat throughout 2018-22, at 2.2% of GDP on average.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Following the snap general election on June 8th, in which the Conservative Party lost its parliamentary majority, the prime minister, Theresa May, formed a minority government based on a "confidence and supply" agreement with the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP). The government will be fragile, and The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect it to last a full five-year term; its working majority of 13 (down from 17 before the election) will be eroded by by-elections, and it will face domestic and external challenges during the Brexit process.
Mrs May's position, which had become increasingly difficult, was boosted by the deal achieved in December 2017 on the first phase of the Brexit negotiations. However, there is a risk that tensions within the cabinet and the Conservative Party over the government's Brexit strategy will come to a head in 2018-19, resulting in a political crisis.
In March 2017 parliament approved Article 50, beginning the two-year process by which the UK will leave the EU. Completing the agreement on the terms of the UK's withdrawal will take priority in 2018, but talks on the future trading relationship will begin this year. The government intends to leave the single market and the customs union, and will aim to reach a comprehensive free-trade agreement with the EU. The UK will formally leave the single market in March 2019, but a transition period should minimise disruption while trade negotiations continue. We expect a trade deal to be in place by 2021.
The economy has been resilient in the wake of the Brexit vote, growing by 1.9% in 2016 and 1.8% in 2017, but is likely to lose momentum in 2018-19 as rising inflation and uncertainty about the Brexit negotiations dampen domestic demand. We forecast real GDP growth of 1.5% in 2018 and 1.4% in 2019 as the economy adjusts, picking up to an average of 1.8% per year in 2020-22.
The government's budget deficit has narrowed from 4.3% of GDP in 2015, but we expect it to stabilise at close to 2016 and 2017 levels (2.8% of GDP) in 2018 as the government eases off its austerity drive. A deficit will persist throughout the forecast period (2018-22), contracting to less than 2% of GDP in 2021. The Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) has signalled a readiness to raise interest rates again after doing so in November 2017 for the first time in a decade. However, we expect that a slowdown in economic growth in early 2018 will delay a move to normalise policy until later in the year.

The UK's business environment score improves in 2018-22 compared with 2013-17, lifting the country by four places in the global ranking and by two places in the regional ranking. The Brexit vote has introduced some policy uncertainty. However, the UK's traditional strengths as a business location-a pro-business policy orientation, a welcoming attitude to foreign investment, and flexible labour and product markets-will endure.
Country forecast overview: United Kingdom's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Lloyds, one of two banks rescued post-crisis by the state, returns to full private ownership; government retains big stake in struggling Royal Bank of Scotland. Brexit focus constrains reforms to improve weak trends in investment and productivity.
2020-22: Shake-up of regulatory and competition frameworks post-Brexit. Continued state support underpins house prices.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Business lobbying for government "assurances" will intensify during Brexit talks. Government pursues policies to encourage foreign direct investment inflows.
2020-22: Infrastructure plans offer investment opportunities. Likely changes in tax policies to bolster inward investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Talks begin on post-Brexit UK-EU free-trade agreement. UK leaves EU single market (and probably customs union). Possible disruption to crossborder trade. Risk of no deal, with UK subject to World Trade Organisation (WTO) trade rules.
2020-22: Terms of new UK-EU trading arrangement phased in.
Taxes
2018-19: Gradual rise in total tax burden, alongside further reduction in corporate tax rate. Changes to system of business rates. Possible tax incentives to encourage investment and prevent companies from relocating outside UK prior to Brexit.
2020-22: Ongoing efforts to reduce revenue lost to tax evasion. Possible tax increases to support the public finances.
Financing
2018-19: Modest tightening in financial conditions likely in run-up to Brexit. Loose monetary policy persists. "Ring-fencing" bank reforms and ongoing capital strengthening (ahead of 2019 deadlines). Demand for alternative forms of debt financing.
2020-22: Availability of finance unchanged. Possible loss of "passporting" rights and restrictions on EU services trade.
The labour market
2018-19: Firms defer some hiring decisions amid Brexit uncertainty. Possible modest decline in inflows of EU workers. New apprenticeship levy and phased increase in compulsory "national living wage". Wage growth remains subdued.
2020-22: Some form of restrictions on free movement of labour from EU, but likely to be flexible in response to business concerns. Policymakers struggle to respond to weak productivity and deficit in intermediate skills.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Modest rise in spending on housing, roads and digital infrastructure. Crossrail service in London begins operating.
2020-22: Construction continues on high-speed rail link between London and the north of England. Steady decline in EU-funded investment activity across UK.

Background: The end of the second world war coincided with the decline of the UK as an imperial power. Residual links with former colonial territories, close relations with the US and a separate sense of identity delayed UK membership of the European Community (now the EU) until 1973. Successive governments have resisted closer EU integration. In a referendum in June 2016 the UK electorate voted to leave the EU. The future contours of the UK's relationship with the EU are uncertain, but a diminution of UK influence in the region looks inevitable.
Political structure: The UK is a constitutional monarchy. The head of state is Queen Elizabeth II. Parliament has an elected House of Commons (the lower house, 650 seats) and a non-elected House of Lords (the upper house, non-fixed membership of about 800). The general election in June 2017 produced a minority centre-right Conservative Party government, dependent on the support of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) for a working majority. The main opposition Labour Party increased its parliamentary seats by 30 in the June 2017 snap general election, but its ability to compete with the Conservatives will be undermined when the government redraws parliamentary constituency boundaries, which are currently favourable to Labour.
Policy issues: UK economic policy has yet to return to normal after the financial crisis, with an exceptionally loose monetary stance. Real GDP growth slowed in 2015-16. The fallout from the Brexit vote will dominate the policy agenda; The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to focus efforts on negotiating the terms of its departure from the EU and on reducing the damaging effect on the economy of the uncertainty created by the vote. This has led to a shift in the UK's monetary and fiscal policy mix, with fiscal policies becoming more significant. Managing Brexit could force policymakers to address structural deficiencies in the UK, such as weak productivity.
Taxation: The headline rate of corporation tax has been steadily reduced, from 28% in 2010 to 20% since April 2015. There are three bands of personal income tax, set at 20%, 40% and 45% (the 45% rate came into effect in April 2013, replacing the 50% rate that was introduced in 2010). The standard rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 20% (raised from 17.5% in 2011). Excise duties on tobacco and alcohol are among the highest in Europe.
Foreign trade: In 2016 exports of goods totalled US$408.1bn and imports amounted to US$591bn, resulting in a trade deficit of US$182.9bn. The traditional services surplus fell to US$127.8bn. The overall current-account deficit widened in absolute terms, to US$154.9bn, from US$149.8bn in 2015, and expanded as a share of GDP, to 5.8%, from 5.2%.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
The decision of the prime minister, Theresa May, to call an early general election in June 2017 backfired disastrously for the Conservative Party, which lost its majority. Mrs May's authority was further undermined by a calamitous speech at the Conservative Party conference in October, prompting calls by some in the party for a leadership contest. However, Mrs May will stay in place for now, because there is no obvious alternative who could unite both wings of the party. The Conservatives fear another general election given that the momen-tum is with the main opposition Labour Party. Lacking a parliamentary majority and divided over Brexit, the government will do well to last the duration of the Brexit negotiations, until March 2019, and there is a significant risk of another pre-term election.
The Conservatives have formed a working government, based on a "confidence and supply" arrangement with Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP). This arrangement is likely to work in the short term, because neither party wants another election-they are natural allies on questions of sovereignty and the EU, and the DUP is committed to preventing the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, from coming to power given his past association with Northern Ireland's main nationalist party, Sinn Fein. However, the arrangement is politically fragile, and the government's 13-seat working majority (down from 17 seats before the election) will dwindle with each by-election.
In late 2017 the government was rocked by a series of scandals related to allegations of sexual and procedural misconduct by members of parliament, leading to the resignation of several senior members of the government. The cabinet and government reshuffle that followed in January further illustrated the prime minister's weakened authority. However, the reshuffle has neither altered the balance of power in the government nor its standing in the country, particularly after it secured a deal with the European Commission in December that allowed Brexit talks to move to a second phase. The deal was an important accomplishment for Mrs May and appears to have guaranteed her political survival in the short term.
Nevertheless, divisions in the cabinet and on the Conservative backbenches over Brexit are likely to resurface this year as ministers discuss the government's aims in the next stage of the negotiations. Brexiteers in the cabinet have been supportive of Mrs May since the election because they want her to hold fast to her pledges to leave the single market, the customs union and the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice (ECJ). This faction includes the Brexit secretary, David Davis; the international trade secretary, Liam Fox; the environment minister, Michael Gove; and the foreign affairs minister, Boris Johnson. They will support the prime minister as long as she pursues their vision of Brexit. However, Mrs May is also under pressure from those advocating a "softer" Brexit, who favour an extended post-2019 transition period, during which the UK would retain single-market and/or customs union access. This group includes the chancellor of the exchequer, Philip Hammond, and the home secretary, Amber Rudd. These divisions could sharpen, presenting a threat to government stability in 2018.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
A snap general election was held on June 8th 2017, three years ahead of schedule. Mrs May's decision to call the election was a political miscalculation, resulting in the Conservatives losing 13 seats, leaving them with 318 seats in the 650-seat House of Commons (the lower house of parliament). The Labour Party won 30 seats in a swing of almost 10 percentage points from the 2015 election, giving it 262 parliamentary seats. The DUP, which increased its share of parliamentary seats from eight to ten, became kingmaker.
The next general election is scheduled for May 2022. Despite Mrs May's weakened position, the Conservatives remain on about 40% in opinion polls-a few percentage points below Labour. Risks to political stability are high, and some within the government have called for a leadership contest. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Conservative Party to see through the Brexit negotiations in 2018-21 before contemplating changing the party leadership and risking precipitating another early general election, for which there is no appetite.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
The Brexit negotiations will shape the UK's international relations during our forecast period (2018-22) and beyond. In line with the government's intention to honour the Brexit vote by taking control of laws, borders and the budget, the UK will formally leave the single market at the end of the Article 50 process in March 2019, but we expect a transition period to minimise disruption while trade negotiations continue. This is likely to mean continued adherence to many EU rules for a period of about two years after withdrawal. Despite political pressure to stay in the EU customs union, the UK government's official line is that it will leave to pursue an independent trade policy. However, we expect some degree of regulatory alignment that will mean less new physical and technological infrastructure at border areas that might otherwise have been required outside the customs union. The government is likely to seek a complete alignment of regulations in some areas; "mutual recognition" sufficient to sustain trade flows in others; and divergence in other areas where the UK would like to set its own regulations.
At the end of 2017 UK and EU negotiators reached an agreement in principle across the three areas under discussion in the first phase of the Brexit talks-citizens' rights, the Irish border and the divorce bill-enabling the talks to move on to transition arrangements and trade. These will come with their own set of challenges, with competing interests among the member states likely to complicate the process. During trade talks the EU will resist any attempt by the UK to cherry-pick from the benefits of membership, but the end result is still likely to be a more comprehensive trade deal than that negotiated by the EU and Canada in 2016.
There are numerous obstacles to the successful conclusion of the negotiations, but we believe that compromises will make a deal possible, particularly given the economic incentive to maintain existing trade ties. Realistically, only the framework of a trade deal will be agreed by the time the UK withdraws in 2019, as completing the withdrawal agreement will take priority in 2018. However, transition arrangements will allow negotiations to continue, and we expect a deal to be in place by 2021.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The UK's departure from the EU will encourage policymakers to address some of the structural deficiencies that have held back the economy in recent years, including lacklustre productivity growth, insufficient innovation and poor infra-structure. Mr Hammond announced a National Productivity Investment Fund to boost the UK's digital infrastructure and spending on research and develop-ment over the next five years. Proposals to reform the UK's housing market have focused on introducing greater speed and flexibility into the planning process. There will also be a new effort to improve vocational skills. We expect these measures to support the recovery in productivity, but they are still too modest in size and scope to close the UK's productivity gap with its G7 peers.
The Queen's Speech in June 2017 set out the government's legislative agenda, which was dominated by Brexit. Eight of the 27 bills relate to the transfer of EU law into British law, a UK customs regime, independent trade policy, controls on immigration, fisheries policy, agricultural policy, nuclear safeguards and the UK's ability to impose international sanctions. In a further sign that Brexit is the government's priority, the parliamentary session will last for two years rather than one, ending two months after the UK's withdrawal at end-March 2019.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
In the autumn budget in November 2017 the chancellor undertook fiscal loosening while avoiding radical steps. The centrepieces of the budget were a sizeable increase in spending on the National Health Service (NHS) and measures designed to address a dysfunctional housing market. Mr Hammond allocated more money to the government's flagship productivity plan, and a raft of smaller policy measures addressed specific issues related to low incomes, welfare, education and tax avoidance. The new policy measures, combined with cuts to the UK's growth forecast by the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR), pushed up the borrowing profile. Mr Hammond did not give a timeline for balancing the budget. In a new Spring Statement in March Mr Hammond will present updated forecasts from the OBR, although this is not expected to contain major adjustments to the existing budget plans.
After a better than expected performance, we estimate that the deficit stabilised at 2.9% of GDP in 2017, and we expect it to stay at around that level in 2018 as the government eases off from its austerity drive. However, in the remainder of our forecast period the government will aim to nudge down discretionary spending as a proportion of GDP. We expect the deficit to narrow to 1.9% of GDP by 2021 and 1.6% by 2022. The public debt burden stood at 88.2% of GDP in 2016. We forecast that public debt will peak at just below 89% of GDP in 2018, before falling thereafter.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
At its meeting in February the monetary policy committee (MPC) of the Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) voted unanimously to keep the main policy interest rate unchanged at 0.5%, four months after raising it by 25 basis points for the first time in a decade. Nevertheless, the BoE revised up its forecasts for GDP growth which-combined with the bank's expectation that there will be only modest growth in supply capacity in the coming years-now implies that there will be greater demand-driven price pressures in the economy, keeping inflation above its 2% target and squeezing real incomes. As a result, there was a more hawkish tone in the bank's communication; it signalled that the next rate rise would occur much sooner in 2018 than markets had previously expected.
The MPC is clearly ready to tighten policy, but our forecast suggests that growth will be slower than the BoE's projection, meaning that it is likely to delay the next move until the end of 2018. We expect a gradual tightening cycle to follow, with a series of 25-basis-point increases in the policy rate over the next five years, taking it to 2.25% by end-2022. If the economy performs more strongly than anticipated in the early part of 2018, the bank could very well move sooner than the fourth quarter, possibly at the time of the next inflation reports in May or August.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
The economy has been resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote. Average annual real GDP growth was firm in 2016 and 2017, at 1.9% and 1.8% respectively. However, the annual pace of growth slowed throughout 2017, from 2.1% in January-March to 1.5% in October-December. We forecast a further modest growth slowdown in the next two years, to 1.5% in 2018 and 1.4% in 2019, led by a slowdown in domestic demand. A looser fiscal stance will provide some positive support to real GDP growth throughout the forecast period, but consumer spending will weaken in response to the squeeze on household disposable incomes from falling real wages. Consumer spending was fairly resilient to this pressure in 2017, reflecting employment gains, high levels of household borrowing and a sharp drawdown of savings. In 2018 we expect employment growth to slow and greater uncertainty about the economic outlook to push up precautionary savings. Consumer spending will recover in 2019-22 as inflation eases, uncertainty recedes and unemployment edges lower. However, increased borrowing costs arising from tighter monetary policy will hold back the pace of the recovery in these years. We forecast that investment spending will decelerate in 2018-19 as a result of heightened uncertainty during difficult Brexit trade negotiations and higher cost pressures as a result of sterling's depreciation, before recovering in 2020-22 as these effects fade.
Mitigating the extent of the domestically driven slowdown in 2018 will be a positive contribution to GDP growth from the external balance as export volumes benefit from a competitiveness boost as a result of sterling's depreciation, while the weaker domestic demand environment reduces import growth. The export boost will ease in 2019, after which we expect the trade balance to exert a drag on GDP growth owing to our forecast for a recovery in domestic demand, which will push up import growth again. Our expectation of a business cycle downturn in the US in 2020 and a deal on the UK's new trading relationship with the EU, which should take effect in 2021 and result in looser trade ties than before, will also constrain exports in 2020-22. We expect real GDP growth to pick up to 1.8% on average in 2020-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
The headline rate of annual inflation-as measured by the consumer price index including owner occupiers' housing costs (CPIH)-accelerated to 2.6% on average in 2017, up from 1% in 2016. The increase partially reflected a rebound in oil prices, but has been amplified by the sharp depreciation of sterling since the Brexit vote. The pound has since reversed much of this appreciation, but we expect it to weaken again in 2018-20, and oil prices are likely to rise further this year. As retailers continue to pass on high input costs to customers, we expect inflation to remain above the BoE's official 2% target for much of 2018, averaging 2.5%, even as domestic price pressure weakens. Tighter monetary policy from 2019 will bring inflation back towards its target; we forecast that it will ease to 2.2% next year and 2.1% on average in 2020-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
There was a sharp drop in the external value of sterling after the Brexit vote. Sensitivity in the foreign-exchange markets to the Brexit news flow has led to significant volatility in the value of the pound, albeit within a range of US$1.20-1.27:£1 until April 18th 2017, when Mrs May called the snap election. This initially boosted the value of the pound, but it fell back sharply in June in response to the shock result. The pound appreciated in the second half of 2017, supported by expectations of tighter monetary policy and a breakthrough in the first round of Brexit talks in December. An increase in political risk in the US in January 2018 then triggered a surge in the US dollar:pound exchange rate to a post-referendum high of US$1.43:£1.
The exchange rate has since receded from this level, but it remained close to US$1.40:£1 in February, and we now forecast that it will average US$1.35:£1 this year, after averaging US$1.29:£1 in full-year 2017. This forecast reflects the recent resilience in the pound (partly because of the performance of the economy), but also assumes that it will weaken as Brexit negotiations enter their most challenging phase and as the economy slows. We expect sterling to depreciate further against the US dollar and the euro in 2019, before making a gradual recovery in the final years of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
The merchandise trade balance will keep the current account in deficit through-out 2018-22, offsetting surpluses on the services account. We expect a narrowing of the current-account deficit, from an estimated 4.9% of GDP in 2017 to 4.6% in 2022 (following a current-account deficit of 5.8% of GDP in 2016), reflecting a shift in the primary income balance as the under-performance of the UK economy reduces income debits (the return that foreign residents receive on their investments in the UK) relative to credits (the return that UK residents receive from their foreign direct investment), and a reduction in secondary transfers from 2021 as the UK reduces its contribution to the EU budget.

Full text: Economist Intelligence Unit commodity price index: food, feedstuffs and beverages
Price forecast summary
(US$ index; 1990=100; % change year on year)
  Index         %        
  2015 2016 2017 2018 2019 2015 2016 2017 2018 2019
WCF 156.8 152.1 163.7 166.6 168.8 -17.3 -3.0 7.6 1.8 1.3
FFB 169.1 163.2 161.8 161.5 165.8 -18.7 -3.5 -0.9 -0.2 2.7
 Beverages 200.3 197.4 189.0 179.6 185.6 -10.3 -1.4 -4.3 -5.0 3.3
 Grains 165.9 147.4 151.4 154.6 160.3 -20.4 -11.1 2.7 2.2 3.7
 Oilseeds 163.4 168.3 165.6 166.4 166.9 -21.9 3.0 -1.6 0.5 0.3
 Sugar 107.1 143.9 127.6 123.5 129.8 -21.0 34.4 -11.3 -3.2 5.1
Source: The Economist Intelligence Unit.
Note. WCF (World commodity forecasts) is an index of 22 hard and soft commodities. FFB (Food, feedstuffs and beverages) is a price index of 13 soft commodities. The beverages sector has a weight of 20% in the FFB index, grains 46.4%, oilseeds 28.6% and sugar 4.9%. The FFB index has a weight of 55.6% in the WCF index.
Agricultural prices will remain weak in early 2018, sinking the annual average
In 2018 The Economist Intelligence Unit's food, feedstuffs and beverages (FFB) price index is set to halt its seven-year decline, with prices rising by a marginal 0.2%. This follows a relatively moderate drop in the price index in 2017, of 0.9%, as the markets for some agricultural goods, including oilseeds and grains such as wheat, maize and rice are beginning to tighten slightly. Nonetheless, most agricultural markets remain comfortably supplied, following several years of bumper harvests. Several crops registered record harvests in 2016/17, including wheat and soybeans, and large carryover stocks will limit the potential for price growth in 2018. The rising possibility of a La Niña weather phenomenon poses some uncertainties, but risks to our forecasts are fairly moderate, given that forecasters expect a mild and short-lived episode. In general, La Niña tends to have a more muted effect than El Niño events, with drier than normal weather in some producing regions of South America and Asia often being offset by better growing conditions in West Africa. We expect the FFB index to begin to firm from late 2018 and to rise by an average of 2.7% in 2019 as some markets tighten further, causing prices for goods such as coffee, cocoa and wheat, to recover from rock bottom. Overall, we expect rising populations and incomes to continue to support modest growth in demand (and therefore prices) of FFB goods in the medium and long term.
The recovery in agricultural prices in 2019 will be fairly modest
Nonetheless, the road ahead will be bumpy. Agricultural markets have been well supplied for several consecutive seasons, providing ample stocks to draw upon. We expect global GDP growth to remain fairly robust, at an average of 2.9% per year in 2018-19, down only slightly from estimated growth of 3% in 2017. However, uncertainty about global monetary policy, together with the risk of a disorderly economic slowdown in China (which is not our core forecast), continue to pose downside risks to demand. In addition, exchange-rate trends may help to keep a lid on global commodity prices. We expect the US dollar (in which most raw materials are traded) to remain fairly strong against most emerging-market currencies in 2018-19; this will weigh on import demand in many emerging markets and encourage exporters to increase output, further inflating global supplies. As a result, even though prices will begin to recover in 2019, we expect the FFB index to remain well below 2014 levels.
Grain prices will post small rises, failing to recover to 2015 levels in 2018-19
We expect grain prices to rise by a relatively modest 2.2% in 2018, as comfortable supplies continue to weigh on wheat and maize prices. Nonetheless, the price growth follows several years of decline as supply surged and global stocks accumulated. For wheat in particular, international prices appear to have found a floor. In 2017 initial concerns over drought in the northern US Plains region and dryness in parts of the EU, Australia and the Black Sea region proved to be overblown. Global supplies were more than adequate that season, limiting price gains to 7.1% in 2017. Wheat prices have proved more resilient in recent months; however, amid overall heavy world availabilities and strong competition for available export business, we expect prices to rise only modestly, by 2.6% per year on average in 2018-19. Maize prices will remain fairly weak in the first half of 2018, undermined by the bumper 2016/17 crop, before inching up steadily in late 2018 and 2019 as global consumption rises-particularly for use in animal feed-and the market tightens.
Oilseed prices will rise in 2018-19 as oversupplied markets begin to tighten
Oilseed prices fell by an estimated 1.6% in 2017, owing largely to the bumper soybean crop in major producers such as the US and Brazil. Despite strong global demand, this has driven global soybean stocks higher. However, we expect the price of soybeans, as well as sunflowerseed oil and rapeseed oil, to see fairly strong growth in 2018-19 as market supply begins to tighten and global demand continues to expand. However, this will be largely offset by a drop in palm oil prices as global production surges but with changing consumer habits resulting in lower demand growth-particularly in developed economies, where health concerns have shifted consumer tastes to alternative products.
A forecast recovery in coffee prices in 2019 will lift the beverages sub-index
We forecast the beverages sub-index, which includes coffee, cocoa and tea, to fall again in 2018, for the sixth consecutive year. We forecast cocoa prices to decline at a modest rate of 1.8% per year in 2018-19; however, this follows a massive drop in 2017, of nearly 30%, which was caused by soaring global production and fairly weak demand growth. Global coffee prices are forecast to fall by 7.1% in 2018, on the back of higher than expected production from Central America, as well as the relatively strong US dollar-which will encourage exporters to sell their stocks, bringing new supplies onto the market. In 2019, however, we expect prices of higher-value arabica coffee beans to rebound, by 10.2%, as several consecutive years of market deficits begin to erode global supplies.
Sugar prices will recover in 2018-19, but by a marginal amount
Sugar prices declined by 11.3% in 2017 as the market corrected after a price spike in late 2016 related to fears that supply from Thailand would be heavily affected by poor weather conditions. We expect global sugar consumption to expand by a relatively modest 1.4% per year in 2018-19, in part as high domestic prices limit demand in India, the second-largest global consumer. On the back of modest demand, we expect prices to weaken in 2018. The recent recovery in global oil prices will also play a role, as this incentivises farmers to divert more cane to ethanol (rather than to its rival, sugar), further increasing sugar supply and limiting price growth through--out the forecast period.

Cocoa
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that, after having contracted for two consecutive crop years, cocoa consumption grew by a marginal 0.4% in the 2016/17 season (October-September). Although cocoa demand is expected to accelerate slightly during the forecast period, by an average of 1.1% per year in 2017/18-2018/19, it remains fairly weak by historical comparison. Recent cocoa grind data point to a stronger third quarter of 2017 in Asia, the US and to a lesser extent Europe, in line with our projection for a pick-up in demand. However, none of the major developed markets will be in a position to fuel rapid growth in cocoa demand, reflecting high existing cocoa consumption levels per head. In contrast to some other soft commodity markets, where producing countries are starting to become major consumers, cocoa consumption levels among producers are (and will remain) extremely low, hampering the scope for firmer global growth in cocoa consumption. Meanwhile, recent falls in cocoa prices will be slow to feed through to retail prices, which will continue to push some consumers towards non-chocolate confectionery. The average size of many chocolate bars has shrunk-partly in response to consumer concerns about obesity, but also to protect profits during a time of high cocoa prices-also hampering cocoa consumption growth in the forecast period.
Balancing demand between cocoa powder and butter will be challenging
Asian countries will see slightly faster growth in cocoa demand than the global average, as these markets are far less saturated and GDP growth will remain higher than in much of the OECD-even factoring in a gradual slowdown in China in 2018. Stronger demand in Asia will have implications for global demand for cocoa butter (used in richer products, such as chocolate confectionery) and cocoa powder (used to add chocolate flavour to products such as biscuits, cakes and drinks). The demand balance between cocoa powder and butter is both delicate and cyclical. We expect demand for cocoa butter to remain strong in the short term, but it will not outstrip demand for powder indefinitely. Given that Asia accounts for 26% of the world's imports of cocoa powder, compared with just 13% of global imports of cocoa butter, firmer consumption growth in that market is likely to boost demand for powder.
Higher prices will slow consumption growth in developed markets
Consumers in the US (the largest cocoa-consuming country, which accounts for nearly 20% of global demand) and Europe (which collectively accounts for 40% of global demand) are showing an increasing preference for premium chocolate (with a higher cocoa content), but with less frequent purchases. Recent sales figures from the main chocolate manufacturers indicate that, on balance, this is pushing down overall consumption. This is illustrated by data from 2015/16, which show that cocoa demand contracted in several large markets (including the US and Canada) and grew only marginally in others (including in Europe), despite fairly strong underlying economic conditions in many of these areas.
We forecast modest but positive growth in demand for cocoa in developed markets in 2017/18-2018/19. Health concerns, market saturation and changing retail habits will constrain demand (the rise of internet grocery shopping is eroding spur-of-the-moment in-store chocolate purchases). However, rising demand for dark chocolate-which has a higher cocoa content than milk chocolate and is perceived to be healthier-will support overall consumption.
Russian and Brazilian cocoa consumption will begin to recover
Lower cocoa consumption in 2015/16 in Brazil and Russia, which together account for nearly 10% of global demand, demonstrate the extent to which cocoa demand is affected by underlying economic conditions, particularly in developing economies, where chocolate is not regarded as a basic good. We estimate that both of these countries saw consumption contract further in 2016/17-reflecting the high cost of cocoa in local-currency terms. For Russia, restrictions on a number of imports from the EU that have been in place since mid-2014 are having an adverse effect on demand for many consumer goods. We expect cocoa demand in Russia to continue to stage a gradual recovery in 2017/18-2018/19, growing by an average 1.4% per year, as underlying economic growth recovers. The same is true of Brazil, where we expect cocoa demand to return to growth, of 1.5% per year on average, assuming that the economy continues to recover slowly.
Cocoa consumption growth will slow in Asia
China and India have huge potential for further expansion in cocoa demand, given currently low per-head consumption levels (at just 37 g in India and 59 g in China in 2015/16, compared with 2-6 kg in developed markets). However, demand will be hampered by high retail prices and, in China, consumer caution, particularly in 2018-19. Although Chinese demand will continue to rise, we expect the pace of growth to slow to an average of 3.4% per year in 2017/18-2018/19, from an estimated 5% in 2016/17. In India, however, we expect demand growth to pick up from 3.4% in 2016/17 to 4.1% per year in the forecast period.

Supply
Global cocoa production surged by an estimated 15.6% in 2016/17 on the back of improved weather conditions, after a particularly difficult El Niño event and a severe harmattan season (a dry winter wind blowing from the Sahara) cut cocoa output in many of Africa's main producers in 2015/16. We expect global cocoa production to fall during 2017/18 and 2018/19, by 7.2% and 1.2% respectively, mainly reflecting a projected drop in production in Côte d'Ivoire-the world's largest cocoa producer. Its output will remain high by historical comparison, but another bumper crop is unlikely, reflecting lower farm gate prices and weaker confidence among growers. Overall, recent price weakness is likely to dissuade farmers from investing in fertiliser and pesticide, raising the incidence of crop disease and contributing to the broader decline in global cocoa production. The rising possibility of a La Niña weather phenomenon poses some uncertainties, but risks to our forecasts are fairly moderate, given that forecasters expect a mild and short-lived episode, if it arrives. Although El Niño episodes do tend to disrupt production, La Niña tends to have a more muted effect, with drier than normal weather in cocoa-producing regions in South America and Asia often being offset by better growing conditions in West Africa. As a result, our supply-side forecasts remain largely unchanged for now.
Structural and geographic factors will hamper long-term supply
Longer-term structural problems will also constrain supply. Not only have farm gate prices in several large producing countries begun to fall in line with lower market prices for cocoa but farmers also receive a much smaller share of the final retail price than in the previous decades, owing to higher costs further down the supply chain. In West Africa, for example, many farmers remain below the poverty line, and as a result few young people are choosing to work in the cocoa sector. Governments are trying to lift farmers' incomes to attract new workers, but it is uncertain how effective this will be in the long term.
Geographical considerations will also hamper the diversification of production. Cocoa can be grown only in certain regions (three-quarters of world production comes from regions that are located within eight degrees of the equator) under warm and humid conditions. Cocoa production is therefore likely to remain concentrated among a small group of countries, limiting the scope for strong and sustained output growth. Periodically, there is speculation that climate change will hamper production in these countries to such an extent that cocoa production will plummet; most recently, a spate of press articles have warned that chocolate will disappear entirely from 2040. However, we believe that some countries have significant potential to expand production, mainly in Latin America, where high-quality cocoa is produced. The expansion of manufacturing facilities to grind beans in producing countries may also encourage new investment to lift output.
Côte d'Ivoire's production soared in 2016/17
In Côte d'Ivoire, cocoa production jumped by nearly 30% in 2016/17, to a record of just over 2m tonnes. However, this upward trend is not expected to continue, and we forecast that cocoa production will fall by 11.2% in 2017/18 and 2.2% in 2018/19. The authorities are unlikely to be able to replicate the exceptionally high level of output registered in 2016/17, with the state-run cocoa authority, the Conseil du Café-Cacao (CCC), issuing fewer export licences and projecting production in 2017/18 in the range of 1.73m-1.75m tonnes. Port arrivals have fallen by around 11% in the first three months of the 2017/18 crop year, despite relatively favourable weather conditions. Although our production forecast is fairly strong by historical comparison, we expect output to fall steadily in the forecast period. Policy will not be particularly supportive: following a sharp cut to farm gate prices ahead of the mid-crop in March 2017, the CCC has kept prices on hold for the 2017/18 harvest, with price levels around one-third lower than a year ago. This has discouraged use of fertiliser and pesticide, with crop disease rising as a result. The government had hoped to raise farm gate prices, but any increase in the producer price would mean cutting export duties and therefore forgoing fiscal revenue, which is unlikely. A stabilisation fund is supposed to protect farmers' revenue from price volatility, but these funds have been insufficient to shield farmers' incomes and-given the lack of transparency over the financial reserves held by the CCC-neither farmers nor exporters have confidence that losses arising from low global prices will be recouped.
Ghanaian government will struggle to boost cocoa production significantly
Similar production trends will be evident in Ghana. Cocoa production rebounded firmly in 2016/17, with favourable weather and a mild harmattan season lifting cocoa production to an estimated 925,000 tonnes (well above the official target of 800,000 tonnes). However, we do not expect further significant and sustained growth in production during 2018-19. For now, Ghana's cocoa board (Cocobod) has been more reluctant than the Ivorian authorities to cut prices paid to farmers, but Cocobod was forced to seek a bridging loan from Bank of Ghana (the central bank) last year, indicating that farm gate prices may need to be cut, particularly if global cocoa prices fail to recover. Combined with anxiety among farmers about the government's intentions to evolve agriculture towards other crops, ongoing encroachment by gold miners, the government's decision to stop providing free fertiliser and the fact that around one-fifth of trees are affected by swollen shoot disease (which cuts yields), production is forecast to fall by 10.3% in 2017/18, before staging a partial (but weak) recovery in 2018/19, of 3.6%.
In the longer term, the New Patriotic Party government plans to rehabilitate cocoa farms, cutting down trees that are over 30 years old and replanting them while providing financial compensation to farmers until the trees start yielding fruit (generally three to five years). The authorities ultimately aim to raise production to 1.5m tonnes within four years, driven by better soil management, and better pest and disease control. These plans are positive, since Ghana has a large share of unproductive trees (Cocobod estimates 40%) and a consequent low average yield per hectare (at 400 kg/ha, compared with 600 kg/ha in Côte d'Ivoire and 1 tonne/ha in Indonesia). However, it will be difficult to secure the necessary funding; we think that it is unlikely that these ambitious plans will come to fruition, since the weak macroeconomic backdrop is likely to hamper public investment and external creditors are unlikely to fund the project.
Cameroon's and Nigeria's production targets will prove overambitious
After recovering to 231,000 tonnes in 2016/17, according to Cameroon's cocoa authorities, production is forecast to weaken during 2018-19. Cuts in farm gate prices will be a disincentive to farmers, meaning that the government will remain significantly off track from its 2020 production target of 600,000 tonnes-a level that even the national Cocoa Development Corporation has described as "unrealistic and unattainable". Port arrivals fell by around one-fifth during the first quarter of the 2017/18 crop year. Moreover, plans to increase the harvested area by 100,000 ha each year have failed to materialise, with the area under cocoa cultivation rising by only around 3,000 ha since 2014, which will hamper the expansion of the cocoa sector.
Cocoa production in Nigeria has slumped in recent years as government initiatives meant to support farmers-including efforts to introduce high-yielding cocoa and to increase the distribution of free seedlings-have not been successful. With the country's mining and energy sector suffering from moderate inter-national oil prices, there is official acknowledgement that investment in raising cocoa production could generate greater foreign-exchange earnings, and the Ministry of Agriculture has recently outlined its ambitious goal of boosting cocoa production above the levels recorded in Côte d'Ivoire. Its short-term goal is to lift cocoa production to 300,000-320,000 tonnes in 2017/18, with the medium-term target of raising output to 1m tonnes/year. However, problems with weak infrastructure, corruption, poor (and expensive) access to financing along with weak implementation will hamper these efforts.

Prospects are weak for Indonesia's cocoa sector
The authorities in Indonesia have ambitious plans to triple cocoa output by 2020, from 325,000 tonnes in 2014/15, but these are highly unlikely to materialise. Adverse weather hampered both the 2015/16 and the 2016/17 harvest, with cocoa output registering its third consecutive annual decline in the latter season. Assuming more stable weather conditions, output should resume growth in 2017/18 and 2018/19, but at an expected 320,000 tonnes at the end of the forecast period, cocoa output will remain weak by historical comparison. Indonesian firms are likely to rely increasingly on imported processed cocoa from neighbouring Malaysia to meet domestic demand.
Strong potential for growth in Latin America will not be realised in 2018-19
Agriculture in Latin America's two largest cocoa producers, Brazil and Ecuador, was affected by El Niño in 2015/16. However, with better weather conditions, output is estimated to have recovered firmly in both countries in 2016/17. Structurally, there is scope for both countries to lift cocoa output as manufacturers look to boost investment in the region in an attempt to diversify production away from West Africa. The region's reputation for producing high-quality cocoa will help in this respect, given rising global demand for premium chocolate. However, some of this investment will be slow to materialise, as global prices remain depressed amid excess supply, which will act as a brake on growth potential.
Stocks and prices
We expect the surplus in the global cocoa market to narrow gradually, from an estimated 561,000 tonnes in 2016/17 to 98,000 tonnes by 2018/19. Although production is forecast to fall steadily, the fact that it will do so from such a high base (output was exceptionally strong in 2016/17) means that cocoa production will remain higher than consumption by some margin. Moderate demand growth makes a return to a market deficit unlikely during the forecast period. Stocks are forecast to reach just under 2.3m tonnes at the end of the 2018/19 season, which is high by historical comparison. Moreover, there is potential for stocks to rise even more strongly; Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana have started discussions about how to bolster global market prices, and are considering stockpiling part of their output.

Ample global cocoa supplies will keep prices low during 2018-19
After remaining high for much of 2014-16, at around US$3,000/tonne, cocoa prices plummeted between December 2016 and late April 2017, hitting a low point of under US$1,900/tonne. Prices recovered somewhat during the remainder of 2017, but continued to trade at a comparatively low level, between US$2,000/tonne and US$2,100/tonne. Although global production prospects will remain weak in the near term, we consider a sustained recovery in prices to be unlikely, owing to the global supply glut. We forecast that prices will contract by 2.7% in 2018, to an average of US$1,975/tonne, and by a further 1% in 2019, to US$1,955/tonne.

Coffee
Demand
Global coffee consumption expanded by around 2.7% in both 2015/16 and 2016/17, largely boosted by rising consumption in coffee-importing countries (mainly developed economies), which account for two-thirds of global demand. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the pace of consumption growth to accelerate to 3.1% in 2017/18, aided by stronger underlying economic conditions in many of the large consuming markets, before slipping to 2% in 2018/19. Notwithstanding ongoing monetary policy tightening in some of the large coffee consumers, overall domestic demand is expected to remain firm, supporting coffee consumption. In coffee-producing countries (many of which are emerging markets) consumption growth will continue to average 2.4% per year, held back somewhat by tepid demand growth in Brazil (which currently accounts for around 40% of exporting countries' consumption, owing to the sheer size of its domestic market). Consumption growth will be strongest in Asia-notably China. Although we expect China's GDP growth rate to slow from 2018, the deceleration will be concentrated in the investment and industrial sectors, and we expect average income levels to continue to rise steadily, meaning that there is little risk of a fall in coffee demand growth. However, coffee consumption levels are low in China, so even as domestic coffee demand rises quickly, this will contribute only modestly to global consumption growth.
Coffee habits are shifting around the world
Consumption trends will change in both the home and out-of-home sectors. In the latter, the expansion of coffee-shop chains will continue, providing a boost to demand, particularly in North America (with 46% of coffee in the US now consumed out of the home) and Europe, but store formats will evolve. Increasing demand for "on the go" beverages will result in larger numbers of smaller shops, including within petrol stations and supermarkets. In some markets-including the US and China-the large coffee chains are increasingly moving towards prepayment through smartphone apps, allowing customers to pick up their purchases without having to queue. These technological developments are likely to help the out-of-home sector to defend its market share at a time when a large number of consumers have single-serve coffee-capsule machines at home. This will be accompanied by heavy marketing of other coffee beverages, including iced coffee and cold brew. Although comprising a small market share of the out-of-home segment, sales of these products are likely to grow rapidly.
Single-serve coffee will help to drive growth in developed markets
Demand for coffee at home that rivals the quality of beverages found in cafes will result in a shift away from the consumption of instant coffee. On a global level, coffee pod sales are approaching the total combined value of instant and ground coffee, although the higher cost of pods means that, in volume terms, the instant and ground coffee market remains larger. Although sales of machines and capsules are slowing sharply after initial firm growth, the coffee pod market will continue to provide important support for overall demand of arabica coffee (most pods contain predominantly arabica beans).
Coffee consumption growth in North America will increase steadily
US coffee consumption growth is forecast to average 1.6% a year in 2017/18-2018/19. Data from the US National Coffee Association show that the percentage of people drinking coffee is rising rapidly (up from 57% in early 2016 to 62% in early 2017). Daily consumption is rising and consumers are increasingly attracted to a variety of products (US consumption of cold coffee products has risen by 75% over the past two years). There are indications that long-term consumption growth may continue to rise, with the number of coffee shops increasing at around 3.6% per year and the share of 13-18-year-olds drinking coffee rising from 23% in 2014 to 37% in early 2017. Demand growth among 18-24-year-olds also rising strongly.
Similar dynamics are evident in Canada, with the share of 18-24-year-olds drinking coffee jumping from 48% in 2015 to 58% in 2016 (up from just 32% in 2009). Younger consumers in particular show a much stronger preference for speciality coffees and for drinking coffee in out-of-home locations. We expect Canada's demand growth, which has been fairly steady at around 2.5% in recent years, to pick up slightly, to an average of 2.7%, in 2017/18-2018/19.
Coffee consumption in Brazil is expected to falter
Brazil is the world's second-largest coffee consumer, but consumption levels per head are still modest (at around one-third of those in most European countries), so there is scope for a significant increase in demand. However, a sharp economic recession has caused coffee consumption to remain flat in recent years, following firm growth in 2005-15. We expect coffee consumption growth to recover in 2017/18-2018/19, but to a fairly moderate pace of 1.3% per year on average. While economic growth is recovering, household consumption will remain constrained by high unemployment, rising fuel prices and higher inflation, which will all drag on disposable income.
Fairly firm coffee consumption growth is expected in Japan and South Korea
Japan is the largest coffee market in Asia (and the fourth-largest in the world), with coffee boasting around the same share of the beverages market as tea. After rising by 3.1% in 2016/17, we expect coffee consumption growth to rise by an average of 2.3% per year in 2017/18-2018/19. The slower pace of growth will reflect slightly weaker underlying economic conditions, after a comparatively rapid pace of economic growth in 2017. Nonetheless, annual growth in coffee con-sumption of 2.3% is firm given the size of the market, and will be under-pinned by rising coffee sales in convenience stores, as the number of coffee shops is falling. In South Korea the coffee market has expanded rapidly in recent years, with imports more than trebling between 2006 and 2016 and the number of coffee shops increasing even more rapidly. Although we forecast somewhat weaker growth in coffee consumption in 2017/18-2018/19, the pace of growth will remain firm by global standards, at an annual average of 3.1%.
Coffee consumption in China and India-currently both small consumers-will continue to grow. Much of the growth in Chinese coffee consumption will be in the out-of-home sector, reflecting the rising popularity of a coffee-shop culture in urban centres. A significant share of the new stores opened by Starbucks in 2016-17 is in Asia. The company now runs 3,000 outlets in 135 Chinese cities (nearly 600 in Shanghai alone, Starbucks' largest presence in a single city), up from 2,300 last October, and is planning to have 5,000 stores open by 2021. We expect an economic slowdown in China in 2018, but the deceleration will be gradual and will largely be concentrated in the construction and industrial sectors. Given that we expect average income levels to continue to rise steadily, there is little risk of a fall in coffee demand growth during 2017/18-2018/19.
Following a recent rapid expansion of the out-of-home sector in India, driven by comparatively low consumer price inflation, rising disposable income and favourable demographics (around one-half of the population is aged under 25), coffee consumption remained flat in 2016/17. We expect a return to growth in 2017/18-2018/19, with coffee consumption rising by an average of 3.3% per year. South-east Asia also has relatively low levels of coffee consumption per head, but demand is increasing rapidly in some countries, mainly in coffee-producing economies such as Indonesia and Vietnam). Rising incomes are encouraging companies such as Starbucks to expand in Indonesia and the Philippines, where consumption is increasing. Costa Coffee is expanding in Thailand, Singapore and Cambodia, and opened its first store in Vietnam last October.
Asian markets will drive demand for robusta beans
Given taste preferences for soluble and instant coffee (which generally use the robusta variety) in faster-growing Asian markets, demand will be stronger for robusta beans than for the more expensive arabica blends. Improved quality of robusta will also play a part here, with such beans slowly losing their reputation for inferior taste. In addition, improvements in processing technology mean that it is possible to use a larger proportion of robusta in coffee blends while maintaining quality.

Supply
After rising by 3.4% in the 2016/17 crop year (October-September), reflecting firm output growth in Brazil-the world's largest producer-coffee production is forecast to fall by 0.5% in 2017/18. This is mainly due to a forecast decline in Brazilian production as the biennial crop alternates between higher- and lower-producing years (2017/18 is an "off-season" crop year). This will be only partly offset by firmer output growth in most other producing countries. There is a risk that global coffee production could decline more rapidly than currently forecast, depending on whether a La Niña weather phenomenon develops in the coming months. This brings a fall in Pacific Ocean water temperatures, typically disrupting coffee output by bringing heavy rains to many of Asia's coffee producers and drought to the main Latin American growers. Our baseline forecast assumes that if it does, the episode will be short-lived and mild, so we have not downgraded our forecast at this stage. Global coffee production growth is expected to be much stronger in 2018/19, at 4.5%, as Brazil's crop shifts to an "on-season" year.
We envisage a growing concentration of coffee production among the world's largest producers. Currently, a large number of countries (around 70) produce coffee, but the smaller producers have been struggling as a result of low world prices and rising overheads. In many of these countries, where coffee is not a particularly important area of the economy, farmers wield less power and are less likely to secure government support than in leading producers. Partly as a result, we expect coffee output in "other" countries to decline from 8.9m 60-kg bags in 2015/16 to 7.8m bags in 2018/19. Output in these countries-which fall outside the world's top 17 producers-will account for less than 5% of global production in 2018/19, down from nearly 15% in 2008/09.
Annual coffee production in Brazil is expected to remain well over 50m bags
In Brazil, by far the world's largest producer, final data from the on-season 2016/17 crop were more positive than expected, with coffee output rising by over 9%. This could reflect the weak local currency, which incentivised local growers, as international coffee prices are denominated in US dollars. Prospects for the off-season 2017/18 crop year are fairly strong and we forecast output of 52m bags. This is higher than projections from Conab (the government's crop supply agency), but official forecasts usually prove conservative. Our forecast remains similar to local private-sector expectations and to that of the US Department of Agriculture. Although adverse weather in mid-2016-including drought in some areas and irregular rainfall in others-raised concerns that beans might be damaged ahead of the harvest, recent weather has been much more supportive, and the quality and quantity of beans have been good. Moreover, the still-weak local currency is continuing to provide an incentive to growers. Problems at some ports have hampered export capacity, but we do not expect this to have a major impact on overall supply.
Output projections for the 2018/19 crop year remain highly speculative. Local commentators have stated that they believe that there is potential for a bumper crop in 2018/19, with some even suggesting that output of up to 60m bags is possible, which would be a record high by some margin (to date, the highest production was recorded in 2012/13, at 55.4m bags). Although we believe that this figure is out of reach, we have upgraded our coffee production forecast from 55.5m to 56.2m bags, reflecting supportive weather conditions.
Coffee production in Vietnam is set to recover from a severe drought
In Vietnam, the worst drought in three decades hampered production in 2016/17, with coffee output dropping by 11.3%. Assuming that weather conditions stabilise for the 2017/18 crop, there is scope for a rebound in Vietnam's coffee output; we forecast production of 27m bags, implying growth of 5.9%, followed by 3% growth (to 27.8m bags) in 2018/19. The authorities remain pessimistic about the medium-term prospects for production, forecasting coffee output to stabilise or decline slightly. However, government efforts to replant 140,000 ha of coffee, targeting 25,000 ha a year, as well as a rising arabica crop, will support firmer output, particularly given that yields from new bushes are typically high. Market jitters about widespread damage to coffee bushes from severe storms in coffee-growing areas in November 2017 were quickly allayed, and it appears that this bout of weather had minimal impact on coffee beans. In addition, firm demand for robusta in the domestic market and other Asian countries will encourage growers.
Output from Mexico and Central America will rise moderately
Coffee production rebounded strongly in Mexico and Central America in 2016/17-rising by 17.5% year on year to 19.4m bags. This followed a severe outbreak of coffee rust, followed by an El Niño weather phenomenon, which damaged plantations in the three previous seasons. We have upgraded our forecast for the subregion this month; previously we expected production to slide moderately in 2017/18 as coffee rust returned to some countries. However, signs of another bumper crop in Honduras, as well as rising coffee output in Costa Rica and Mexico, will contribute to a continued rise in production during the forecast period. Recent purchases of fungicides and fertiliser will also provide support. We now expect regional production to rise by an average of 0.7% per year in 2017/18-2018/19.
Colombian production is set to stagnate in 2017/18 but rise again in 2018/19
Coffee production in Colombia has risen steadily in recent years, reaching a 24-year high of 14.5m bags in 2016/17. Prospects for 2017/18 are uncertain. The sector's fundamentals are strong, including a comparatively high percentage of rust-resistant bushes. In addition, recent additional planting in existing plantations has focused on increasing average yields, which at 18 bags per hectare in 2016 was much lower than in other large growers (27 bags per hectare in Brazil and 35 bags per hectare in Vietnam). However, recent cloudy weather conditions are affecting flowering on coffee bushes, prompting us to cut our 2017/18 production forecast; we now expect output to remain flat (4.1% increase previously). In 2018/19 production should start to benefit from recent efforts to improve productivity; we expect output to rise by 5.5% that season, to 15.3m bags. In the medium term the 2016 peace agreement between the government and the then FARC rebels, will allow coffee cultivation to expand in previously isolated areas of the country (the government has speculated that output could reach 20m bags by 2020 as a result).
In Indonesia coffee production is recovering, but remains weak overall
Indonesia's ambitious expansion plans for the coffee sector-which include more than doubling production within five years to make the country the world's second-largest producer after Brazil-have been completely derailed. El Niño brought excessive dry weather to the main coffee-growing areas, affecting the 2016/17 harvest, when output fell by 6.7%. However, prospects for the 2017/18 season are stronger, and we expect production to rise by 4.4%. We expect production to grow by a further 2.5% in 2018/19, but, at just 12.3m bags, output will remain low by historical comparison.
Production prospects in Africa, which accounts for around 11% of total global coffee output, are relatively bright. Many of the continent's coffee producers have very low levels of output; together, Ethiopia and Uganda account for 70% of African coffee output. Production rose solidly in both countries in 2016/17, mainly on the back of better weather conditions. We expect coffee production to continue to rise over the forecast period, but for the increase to be sharper in Uganda, reflecting an extensive re-seeding programme in recent years and an expansion of the coffee-growing area. Progress in these areas has been more gradual in Ethiopia, where we expect production growth to be more modest.
