Stocks and prices
After rising marginally in 2016/17, we expect global coffee stocks to fall in 2017/18-2018/19 as a larger market deficit offsets continued sales of stocks, with producers taking advantage of relatively weak local currencies against the US dollar. By end-2018/19 we expect global stocks to have fallen to 25.6m bags, from an estimated 31.6m bags in September 2017, which will support a partial recovery in prices.

Investment trends are likely to weigh on arabica prices again in 2018
Arabica prices fell steadily over the course of 2017, from an average of US$1.69/lb in January to US$1.37/lb in December. The full-year average price of US$1.50/lb marked an 8.3% decline compared with 2016. Given that the global market is set to register its third consecutive annual deficit in 2016/17, the fall in prices-to levels not seen since 2013-is curious. We believe that coffee prices are increasingly driven by investment trends, with swings in sentiment often due to a spate of positive or negative news on the supply side. Coffee prices are also becoming increasingly reactive to changes in the strength of the US dollar, with dollar depreciation tending to lead to higher coffee prices. In late 2017 speculation about bumper production in Brazil pushed prices lower. The fact that several large exporting countries are continuing to sell spare stock in order to take advantage of weak local currencies is also suppressing prices, because this has been accompanied by a rise in coffee stocks in importing countries, which in turn may contain demand in the future.
We believe that speculation about the 2018/19 harvest in Brazil and firm output in Mexico and Central America will continue to suppress prices, and have downgraded our 2018 forecast to an average of US$1.40/lb, from US$1.52/lb previously. This is in line with recent developments in futures markets, with prices for various delivery dates throughout the year remaining low. If production is disrupted on the back of a severe La Niña weather phenomenon, there is potential for prices to rebound sharply, given that prices remain low by historical comparison.However, this is not our core forecast. Given that the next "off-season" in Brazil (2019/20) is likely to hit market confidence during the 2019 calendar year, we forecast a recovery of prices, to an average of US$1.54/lb.
Tighter supplies of robusta beans and firm Asian demand will support prices
Prices for cheaper robusta held up better during much of 2017, reflecting concerns about the supply of robusta beans in the context of disappointing weather conditions in Vietnam and Indonesia, but dipped sharply in November-December as bean supply picked up. We expect prices to average 97 US cents/lb in 2018 (a 4.2% year-on-year decline) and US$1.04/lb in 2019.

Maize
Demand
Maize is the most consumed (and produced) grain in the world, with total annual demand now in excess of 1bn tonnes/year (t/y). It is a versatile grain, with around 60% of the total used for animal feed, almost 30% for industrial processing (mainly fuel ethanol and starch) and the rest consumed directly as food or seed, or lost through waste. After a period of spectacular growth, demand for maize-based biofuels is now increasing more slowly, even though overall levels of consumption are still setting new records each year. However, following reports about China's plans for a massive expansion of its own fuel ethanol sector, world use for biofuels could potentially rise sharply from current levels over the medium term. Furthermore, maize is the primary energy source in compound feed mixes, and with ample supplies predicted across the world, it is well placed to meet predicted gains in demand in meat-exporting countries, as well as in parts of Africa, Asia and Latin America, where consumption of animal protein continues to expand. Maize is by far the dominant feed grain in much of the world, with annual consumption typically more than four times that of wheat. In 2017/18 The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global demand to rise by 2.7% year on year, with stronger uptake expected across the animal feed, industrial and food sectors. A similar trend is projected for 2018/19, with overall demand rising by 1.5%, to 1.1bn tonnes. Incorporating revised historical supply and demand estimates for Sub-Saharan Africa, mainly for direct human food use, global consumption forecasts back to 2009/10 to 2017/18 have been lifted in the period since the last report. However, the underlying trend remains unchanged, with consumption expanding almost every year.
World feed demand will rise by 2% in 2017/18
World demand for meat and other animal proteins shows no sign of slowing, with consumption gains driven by population growth, greater purchasing power and changes in diets and tastes. Maize is an extremely useful ingredient in animal feed, which can contribute to rapid livestock weight gain. Overall use, however, depends on availabilities and price relationships with other grains-mainly wheat-as well as high-protein oilmeals. A multitude of other factors can also have a direct impact on feed demand in any particular year, with producers having to consider pasture conditions and availability, as well as desired livestock weight, the economics of the meat industry and feed efficiency ratios. In 2017/18 we expect global growth in use of maize for livestock feed to slow to around 2%, down from almost 7% in the previous season. Further growth in maize feed demand is likely in 2018/19, with total feed use forecast to reach a new all-time high.
Trade continues to increase year after year
Global maize trade in 2017/18 (July-June) is forecast to grow by 6.9% year on year, to reach a new record. Amid large surpluses across all the major exporters, global prices are soft, and maize remains very competitively priced for inclusion in feed rations. A number of large buyers are expected to increase imports, with particularly strong growth likely in Mexico, the EU and Taiwan. This will easily compensate for a reduction in purchases by Brazil and South Africa, two countries that secured unusually large amounts in 2016/17 owing to severe weather difficulties. The EU is expected to displace Japan as the world's leading importer this year, with shipments pegged at a record 17m tonnes, up by more than a quarter compared with 2016/17. Mexico's imports are projected to rise by 1.5m tonnes, to 15.5m tonnes, also a new all-time peak, relegating Japan to third place on the league table of the world's biggest buyers.
China announces plans to boost ethanol production
Years of supply and demand imbalances in China have led to a massive surplus, with stocks soaring to an unprecedented level in recent years. Over-production was mainly linked to a now discontinued official stockpiling scheme, under which farmers in the largest maize provinces were able to sell unlimited amounts into state reserves at guaranteed minimum prices. At the same time, cheaper feed grain imports flooded into southern consuming regions, choking off demand for locally produced maize. Authorities are now working hard to unwind part of these burdensome stocks. Under a plan jointly announced by 15 ministries and commissions in September, the government is seeking a massive expansion of the biofuel sector, targeting the blending of 10% ethanol (E10) into all automotive petrol by 2020. The move is seen as a part of broader efforts to reduce China's carbon footprint. If E10 plans are fully implemented, an additional 35-40m tonnes of maize would be required as a feedstock each year.
China's maize stocks are likely to be larger than previously thought
Calls for such a steep and sustained increase in China's maize consumption suggest that local inventories could be much larger than we had previously expected. Our supply and demand estimates for the past decade have therefore recently been revised, with forecasts for feed use across this period lowered by an average of 18m t/y, equivalent to around 10% of total annual consumption. Given the sheer size of its grain economy, any revisions for China can appear to have an outsized impact. Nevertheless, it should be stressed that the underlying trend is unchanged from before, and with so much of China's grain economy operating separately from the global market, these revisions do not have any wider price implications. We forecast China's overall maize demand to rise by 4.3% in 2017/18, and by a further 5% in 2018/19, as maize use in industrial processing begins to accelerate.

Supply
World maize supplies (production plus carryover stocks) have increased to record highs in recent seasons, topping 1bn tonnes most years since 2011/12. Encouraged by high market prices, production gains have stemmed from increases in plantings, as well as improved yields, with growers using new seed varieties, fertilisers and better farming practices to great effect. After surging by an estimated 10.6% in 2016/17 to the highest level ever recorded, global output is projected to drop by 3.1% in 2017/18. Boosted by ample carryovers from 2016/17, global supplies are likely to remain comfortable, especially in the major exporting countries, where traders will compete for available business. Forecasts for 2018/19 remain highly provisional, especially in the southern hemisphere, and will be subject to revision in the coming months. Overall, we expect global output to be slightly lower in that season as a modest expansion in area is offset by lower yields.
A weak La Niña appears to be forming
Some of the world's leading meteorological agencies, including the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) recently indicated the presence of a weak La Niña weather event, which is likely to persist until February-April 2018. Previous La Niña events have sometimes been linked to drier than normal weather in southern Brazil and northern Argentina, two important maize producing areas. In contrast, La Niña normally brings beneficial rains to parts of southern Africa, a factor that lifted South Africa's 2016/17 maize crop to a record high.
US output will drop in 2017/18, but by a lower margin than expected
US maize production is officially estimated at 370.3m tonnes in 2017/18, almost 8% higher than the average annual outturn in the last five seasons. Although average yields were the best ever, at around 11 tonnes per hectare, output declined by about 4% from the 2016/17 record because of an overall drop in plantings. Although the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) has maintained a generally optimistic outlook throughout the growing season, many other forecasters were more cautious because of poor weather earlier in the season. However, temperatures cooled in August, before warming again in September, thereby extending the growing period and helping to offset some of the effects of previous unfavourable conditions. The latest hybrid maize seeds, in combination with better farming practices and equipment, have allowed crops to perform well even under short periods of adverse weather. Planting decisions for 2018/19 will once again depend on price relationships with alternatives, mainly soybeans, in the spring. After two seasons of losing ground to soybeans, 2018/19 rotation needs could favour maize sowings, especially if fertiliser prices remain low. However, the current heavy maize supply outlook means that any upside is likely to be limited. For the time being, we expect a 2% rise in seedings, enough for a crop of around 361.8m tonnes, down by about 2% year on year.
Lower area and smaller yields in Brazil
Owing to low prices and extremely strong competition from soybeans, the full season 2017/18 maize area in Brazil is officially estimated to have declined by 10% year on year. Although sowings were completed a little later than usual in Minas Gerais, the top full-season producing state, recent rains have maintained generally favourable production prospects. Comparatively drier conditions have prevailed in Rio Grande do Sul, where farmers have expressed concerns about reduced yield potential. As overall productivity is expected to be lower than last year, nationwide production is on track to decline by as much as 18%, to 25.1m tonnes. This crop is, however, used almost exclusively to meet domestic feed needs in the southern livestock producing states, with very little typically used for export. The country's exportable surplus stems almost entirely from the second (safrinha) crop, sowings of which will start only after soybeans are harvested, usually from February onwards. Follow-through delays from late soybean planting mean that the planting window for safrinha maize is likely to be unusually short, raising the risk of crops entering pollination later in the year, when temperatures are typically hotter and soil moisture reserves are shorter. Because of low profitability at current market prices, a number of farmers could therefore be dissuaded from growing a second maize crop at all this year. Some land previously sown to safrinha maize may be switched into alternatives, including sorghum, sunflower seed or cotton, prices of which have held up well amid strong background demand. Taking into account the latest area, yield and production estimates from state forecasters in Mato Grosso and Parana, we have lowered our total 2017/18 crop estimate by 2m tonnes, to 89m tonnes, potentially a 9% year-on-year contraction. Nonetheless, with carryover stocks at close to 20m tonnes, marketing-year supplies could actually be even larger this season, with no threat to overall export availabilities. A return to more seasonal growing conditions in 2018/19 could see output recover to around 92m tonnes.
Northern Argentina is very dry
By the first week of January, about 78% of Argentina's next maize crop had been planted, about 5 percentage points behind the same point a year ago, and much slower than normal. Although seeding in the southern and central provinces was more or less complete, only about 10% of intended area had been sown in the country's northern maize growing regions. Delays have stemmed mainly from prolonged spells of very dry weather, consistent with the current weak La Niña, with many fields simply too dry to plant. Although showers in recent weeks have been useful, more rains will be required if average yields are to achieve the lofty levels seen in recent seasons. With planting in Argentina now stretching over an almost five-month timeframe, the dry conditions have also coincided with the key pollination period of the earliest-sown crops. There is still time to sow late-season varieties in the northernmost regions, but the optimal planting window in northern Buenos Aires province has already passed, and yield potential may now be limited should farmers still choose to sow maize.
Given the uncertainty about the final level of seedings and yields, it seems prudent to trim our production projections, especially as some weather models are predicting more dry weather to come. Output is now placed at 39m tonnes, down by 1m tonnes on our previous forecast, but 29% more than the recent average. Large carryover stocks from the previous season mean that exportable supplies will remain ample, easily big enough to cement Argentina's position as the world's third-largest exporter. Projections for the 2018/19 season are highly provisional at this stage and much will hinge on how the 2017/18 season turns out. In the light of the monthly reduction in Argentinian soybean export taxes planned for the next 24 months, there may be some renewed interest in producing oilseeds in the 2018/19 season, which could keep a lid on maize acreage. The production outlook at this stage is therefore static, pegged at about 40m tonnes.
South Africa's next crop is expected to be much smaller
After a bin-busting crop last season, exporters in South Africa have been unable to fully offload a very large surplus, resulting in a sharp build-up in stocks. With local maize prices under pressure, particularly for white maize, thin profit margins are expected to result in a 6% drop in 2017/18 commercial plantings. It has been a fairly dry start to the season, with fieldwork in parts of Free State province and in the western cropping areas hindered by below-average rains during much of October and November. Despite better rains in the first part of December, there was a lack of follow-up moisture across the north-west, where some farmers may be forced to plant alternatives, including sunflowerseed, which can be seeded a little later. However, owing to the local meteorological agency's expectations for normal to above-normal rains during the first five months of 2018, which coincide with the key yield formation stage of crop development, farmers will probably be keen to sow as much intended maize area as possible. Assuming that final yields are closer to average, we expect production to drop by almost 30% year on year, to 12.5m tonnes. As we currently predict very little change in planting intentions in the following year, a similar sized crop is expected in 2018/19.

Stocks and prices
Global maize stocks in 2017/18 are forecast at 335m tonnes, virtually unchanged from the previous year. Following a detailed reassessment of China's maize supply and demand numbers over the past decade, we recently raised our estimate of world stockpiles by 60%. Maize production in China is trending lower, and with consumption expected to rise strongly in the years ahead it has become clear that our previous forecast was too conservative and would have resulted in the depletion of China's stocks in just a few years. With feed use adjusted lower from 2011/12 onwards, projections for China's stocks were lifted across the whole period and are now forecast at 204m tonnes at the end of 2017/18, a figure much closer to that circulating in the local press. We now expect China to account for 61% of total world stocks (40% previously). Yet with so much uncertainty about the size, location and quality of its stocks, many analysts prefer to exclude China when modelling world inventories. Combined stocks in the four main maize exporters (Argentina, Brazil, Ukraine and the US) are forecast to remain above the recent average in 2017/18, at a total of 74.7m tonnes, up by 3.2% year on year, with more than three-quarters of these concentrated in the US. Mainly because of modest destocking in China, a relatively sharp drop is predicted in 2018/19, to 316m tonnes. Although exporter stocks will also tighten further, overall market supplies will remain at comfortable levels.
China's stock estimate is revised sharply higher
China's grain stocks have long been considered a state secret, with all parts of the grain balance sheet quite notional and based on limited information. Sometimes the assumptions are proven to be incorrect, as highlighted by new information or a change in underlying market conditions. Although our revised stock forecast diverges from those of the USDA and other major forecasting bodies, it brings stocks in China much closer to the levels that have been reported widely in the local press in recent years, including figures quoted by key policy advisers and other Communist Party officials. We expect stocks to be drawn down further in 2018-19 as the government seeks to boost domestic consumption, particularly in the biofuels industry. However, given that these stocks are primarily held as a domestic food security measure, and with China being only a small importer, this is unlikely to influence global prices.

With consumption failing to keep track with the surge in supplies, US ending stocks are expected to rise for a fifth consecutive season by the end of 2017/18, reaching 62m tonnes, a 6.4% year-on-year gain. The stocks-to-use ratio is forecast at 20%, up by 4 percentage points from the season before and the highest since 2005/06, suggesting that supplies are very comfortable. Based on early projections for the next season, including another large crop and a marginal drop in consumption, carryover stocks are projected to decline by around 3m tonnes, to 59m tonnes, still well above average. After a series of huge US crops, a grain storage crunch has been reported in several states in recent years, with many farmers reluctant to sell at low prices. Kansas has faced a particularly acute shortage, partly because of producers switching area from lower-yielding wheat to maize crops. However, shortfalls have been noted in the traditional maize states of Illinois, Iowa and Nebraska too. Plastic silo bags have been a quick, low-cost solution for many growers, allowing grains to be stored cheaply directly on the farm. Although this offers logistical advantages, allowing farmers to avoid storage and handling fees, the maize being stored must already be at the desired moisture content and the silo bags still require active monitoring in order to avoid rupture losses.
Prices are unlikely to show any significant growth in 2018-19
World maize export prices have shown very little movement in recent months, with US fob quotations trading in a narrow, US$10/tonne range across the final quarter of 2017. Although occasional price support stemmed from heightened concerns about abnormally dry weather in parts of South America, overall gains were tempered by plentiful global exportable supplies, which were large enough to counter any production shortfalls south of the equator. The overall bearish market tone was highlighted by the latest data from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which confirmed that speculators held a massive net short position in futures and options at the start of 2018. Given background uncertainty about South American crops, there remains some upside risk to prices in the coming months. However, maize market fundamentals currently point to a low price environment, at least for the next year or so. We expect prices to rise slightly during the second half of this year; however, given ample global stocks and easy feedgrain availabilities, prices are likely to remain well below recent peaks in 2018-19.

Palm oil
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global palm oil consumption to accelerate over the 2017/18 and 2018/19 seasons, by 2.7% and 3.3% respectively. This is roughly on a par with the average growth rate in the past four seasons, but well below the peak, of 10.5% growth, seen in 2012/13. Palm oil imports are reportedly picking up in a number of countries as palm oil prices fall, making it more competitive compared with most other oils. However, negative sentiment against palm oil and palm oil-based biodiesel in the US and EU continues to weigh on demand there. Both Indonesia and Malaysia are looking to expand their exports; strong forecast consumption in China, primarily from its biodiesel market, is most likely to generate additional demand.
India will remain the largest market for palm oil
In India, strong overall GDP growth in the coming seasons will help to support moderate growth in palm oil consumption. Nonetheless, changes in duties applied to imported palm oil will prevent faster consumption growth in 2017/18. India's imports grew quickly at the beginning of the 2017/18 season, but data for November-December show some tailing off of import activity. With stocks at ports at around normal levels, this suggests a moderation of consumer demand. As a result, we have revised down our forecast for India's overall palm oil consumption slightly, to 9.7m tonnes this season (9.8m tonnes previously). Nonetheless, this represents growth of 3.8% year on year, on a par with the average growth rate of the last five seasons. We expect demand growth to accelerate to 4.9% in 2018/19, encouraged by strong GDP growth.
Indonesia's biodiesel sector will post decent growth in 2017/18-2018/19
Prospects for palm oil demand in Indonesia have been encouraged by recent increases in forecasts of prices for mineral oil. However, the biodiesel industry in Indonesia is searching for new markets to make up for the loss of sales in the US. The recent implementation by the EU of reduced duties for Argentinian biodiesel is expected to be followed by a similar reduction for Indonesian biodiesel. A decision by the World Trade Organisation (WTO) on EU anti-dumping duties on Indonesian supplies was due to be released by end-2017; the deadline has now lapsed, and the decision is likely to come in the near term. Recent data is consistent with our forecast of consumption growth of 6.6% in 2017/18, to a total of 9.8m tonnes. In 2018/19 we expect lower demand for biodiesel exports to limit Indonesia's palm oil consumption growth to 2.5%, to just over 10m tonnes.
China's palm oil demand is hindered by competition from soybean oil
Palm oil will continue to face strong competition from soybean oil in China in 2017/18. However, import data from the start of the 2017/18 season has been generally encouraging. We have increased our 2017/18 demand growth forecast to 5.2% (4.4% previously). This would bring total consumption up to 5.3m tonnes, well above the 2016/17 level, but still below average consumption of 6m tonnes each year from 2010/11-2014/15. Rising demand for biofuels underpins our forecast for another year of moderate demand growth, of 3.3%, in 2018/19.
Energy demand in the EU will rise, boosting usage
The market for palm oil in the EU has been broadly flat since 2013/14, hovering around 7.2m tonnes. At best we forecast only limited growth in the next two seasons. In the biodiesel sector, palm oil faces increased competition in some member states from recycled fats and oils, while sustainability concerns hang over medium-term consumption prospects. Palm oil imports in the season to date are marginally above year-earlier levels, although this is thought to be mainly to replenish low stocks. Changes in incorporation mandates may encourage higher biodiesel consumption in the EU over the next two years. While other feed-stocks are likely to be the main beneficiaries of this growth, palm oil consumption volumes should be maintained. Palm oil's use in the edible sector is also likely to be maintained but show minimal growth.
Biodiesel consumption in Malaysia faces challenges
Malaysian palm oil consumption was hampered in 2016/17 by delays in implementing biodiesel incorporation mandates. These delays are unlikely to be resolved in the near future, despite government efforts to get the B10 mandate accepted by automobile manufacturers. Faced with rising domestic stockpiles, the Malaysian authorities temporarily suspended export taxes on crude palm oil in early January 2018, in an attempt to compete with other regional exporters. The high levels of domestic stocks fit with our forecast for only moderate domestic consumption growth, reflecting the sluggish growth for biodiesel in local markets.
Prospects for palm oil consumption in other countries are broadly positive
The geographical markets for palm oil are diverse, with the top five consumers accounting for less than 55% of global consumption. There have been sharp increases in exports to a number of these destinations including Pakistan, Iran, Philippines and a number of other Asian and African destinations. The largest of these "other" consumers, Pakistan, is likely to show sustained growth given that attempts to encourage local oilseeds production have been largely unsuccessful. Buying activity from these other consumers is reported to be increasing, justifying a rise in the consumption estimate of for these "other" countries.

Supply
We have increased our forecast for palm oil production across the board in 2016/17, reflecting monthly output reports that have exceeded our initial expectations. We now expect global production to expand by 5.4% in 2017/18 (4.9% previously), to a total of 69.4m tonnes. In 2018/19 we do not expect yields to match those of 2017/18 as a result of tree stress and the lower use of inputs. Therefore, an expected increase in the mature area will be the main factor driving any growth in output. Overall, we expect output to expand by a modest 0.7% year on year.
Yields in Indonesia are slowly recovering from the 2015/16 drought
Indonesia's palm oil output has grown strongly since March 2016. This reflects both the recovery from the drought that had previously affected output, as well as the favourable age profile of Indonesia's oil palm plantings. There are now indications that this strong growth in output is moderating-a pattern that is likely to continue during the remainder of the 2017/18 season. While we have raised our 2017/18 production forecast to 37.7m tonnes, this represents seasonal growth of only 3.7%, far below the estimated growth of 15.8% achieved in 2016/17. In 2018/19 the larger mature area is likely to offset any negative effects from the slower rate of planting. However, yield growth is likely to be minimal reflecting both the strong yield growth in the previous two seasons and lower input use, given falling palm oil prices. We forecast output of 38.6m tonnes in 2018/19, up by 2.3% year on year.
Malaysian production is set to return to 2013/14 peak in 2017/18
Official data continues to show Malaysian palm oil output well above previous seasons. In October and November recorded ouptut was at least 20% above year-ago levels, and this trend is estimated to have continued in December. As a result, we have raised our forecast for Malaysia's prdouction growth in 2017/18 to 8.5% (7.5% previously). With an ageing tree population, yield growth will be difficult to achieve in 2018/19, especially given the continuing labour shortages and low international palm oil prices. Assuming a slight drop in average yields, we expect the total outturn to contract by 0.9% that season.
For Thailand, we expect an increase in the mature area to ensure continued growth in palm oil output in 2017/18, despite low prices inhibiting the use of crop inputs. Monthly output is running above earlier expectations, and we expect overall production to increase by 5.7% year on year in 2017/18. However, we forecast production growth to moderate in the 2018/19 season, to 2.4%; crop yields are likely to weaken in that season, as low global prices undermine the use of inputs, preventing faster output growth. In addition, difficulties in securing new land for planting will also act as a brake on potential growth. The slow growth in palm oil output is expected to result in a lower target for biodiesel use in Thailand. We expect Colombian output to grow steadily over the forecast period as its mature area expands. The recent peace agreement with the FARC may open up even more land for palm oil cultivation. Recent yields have largely been above year-earlier levels, and returns to the crop have been favourable. A higher biodiesel incorporation rate mandate should also help to maintain interest in the crop.

Stocks and prices
Recorded palm oil stocks in Malaysia and Indonesia have continued to increase. In Malaysia, inventories reached an estimated 2.7m tonnes at end-December 2017, a two-year high. Seasonal declines in production may provide some relief over the next quarter but the market surplus for the season as a whole is expected to be substantial. At the end of the 2017/18 season we expect that palm oil stocks will be similar to those at the end of the 2014/15 season, when measured as a share of average daily consumption. Our forecast suggests that stocks will continue to rise in 2018/19.

Rising stock levels will push prices down further in 2018
Like most other vegetable oils, physical prices for palm oil declined over the course of December 2017, as stocks rose quickly. Futures prices were also generally lower, despite a brief recovery in the middle of the month. Given the seasonal decline in palm oil production, which typically lasts until February, price falls during the first and second quarters of 2018 are forecast to be relatively modest. Price declines are likely to be more substantial in the second half of 2018 and early 2019. As global supplies remain comfortable, we expect average palm oil prices to fall to US$570/tonne in 2019, a low not seen since the end of 2015.

Rapeseed oil
Demand
Although mineral oil prices are rising, which would normally encourage higher rates of rapeseed oil consumption, this is being offset by the current high international prices for rapeseed oil. Rapid growth in rapeseed oil prices has started to ease in early 2018, but high global stocks will continue to inhibit new consumption. The Economist Intelligence Unit has raised its forecast for global rapeseed oil consumption in 2016/17, reflecting improved availability. However, we still expect consumption to have declined for the third consecutive year in 2016/17, by 3.2% (6.9% decline previously). We expect global rapeseed oil production to recover in 2017/18, which will support consumption growth of 5% that season-although overall consumption will remain below the volume seen in 2014/15-2015/16.
EU consumption limited by supply constraints
Rising imports of Argentinian biodiesel are already having a negative effect on EU rapeseed oil consumption in 2017/18. An expected resumption of Indonesian biodiesel imports in mid-2018 will also be problematic in the near term. In addition, sunflowerseed oil will continue to provide strong competition in the food sector. On the positive side, rising mineral oil prices in 2018 will be supportive of EU rapeseed oil demand. The recent tightness of rapeseed oil stocks has eased, improving the availability of rapeseed oil for consumption. Nonetheless, we still do not expect EU consumption to reach the 10m-tonne mark (last seen in 2015/16) during the forecast period. An increase in domestic production of rapeseed oil in 2018/19 should allow consumption to grow, by a modest 0.3%, as the competitive pressures on rapeseed oil persist.
Demand in China will be aided in 2018/19 by the release of reserve stocks
In China, limited stocks of rapeseed will exert negative pressure on potential consumption. Imports of rapeseed oil to date have been disappointing, although these have been partly offset by higher imports of canola for local crushing. We have revised down our forecast for 2017/18 rapeseed oil consumption marginally, reflecting recent import data. However, the consumption forecast is vulnerable to any change in price differentials between rapeseed oil and other oils. Recent falls in rapeseed oil prices, if maintained, will feed through into higher consumption. Any increase in consumption in 2018/19 relies on a recovery in local availability. Rapeseed remains a relatively unprofitable crop, and the planting area in 2017/18 was further hit by poor conditions. We expect the planted area to rise again to normal levels in 2018/19, which would allow a recovery in local availability, consistent with our consumption forecast of 5.8m tonnes.
India's consumption will rebound in 2017/18 in line with local availability
An improving outlook for domestic availability, together with strong real GDP growth levels, should stimulate rapeseed oil consumption in India in 2017/18. Demand levels will be vulnerable to changes in international rapeseed oil availability and competition from other oils. For now, we expect an improvement in availability, owing to stronger domestic purchasing power, to boost rapeseed oil consumption to around 2.6m tonnes on average in 2018-19. The main downside risk is related to gradual increases in import duties on vegetable oils, which could raise domestic rapeseed oil prices, dampening consumption growth.
Only modest demand growth is likely in the US market
Imports of rapeseed oil into the US continue to sustain consumption growth. Higher levels of Canadian production should stimulate further increases. The potential application of anti-dumping duties on biodiesel from Argentina and Indonesia could stimulate additional demand for rapeseed oil as a feedstock during the forecast period. Overall, we expect US rapeseed oil consumption to continue to grow steadily, exceeding 2.9m tonnes in the 2018/19 season. Several smaller consumers switched away from rapeseed oil in 2016/17, and improving availability may encourage some consumers to buy additional rapeseed oil. Our estimate of 2017/18 consumption among these "other" consumers has been raised but still remains below the 2016/17 level. A recovery in consumption among the other consumers is now expected to be delayed until 2018/19.

Supply
An unusually large increase in the official estimate of Canadian canola production has had a significant impact on supplies of rapeseed and rapeseed oil. The estimate of Australian output is also higher. Overall, we now expect a global rapeseed crop of 65m tonnes, still well short of the record 70m tonnes produced in 2013/14, but larger than each of the last two seasons. We have raised our forecast for global rapeseed oil production slightly, to 24.8m tonnes in 2017/18. However, this still represents a modest decline year on year, of 0.4% (0.8% decline previously). If the rapeseed crop were to be larger than we expect, this would result in higher production growth of oil. Output in 2018/19 will, of course, depend on the level of rapeseed production. Early indications suggest that the crop size will be similar to that of 2017/18; this should help to improve global rapeseed stocks, boosting production of rapeseed oil by 4.8% year on year.
The EU rapeseed crop will recover partially in 2017/18
Our estimate of the size of the EU 2017/18 rapeseed harvest has been reduced to 21.8m tonnes, mainly on account of a reduction in the estimate for France. Import levels have been buoyant, most notably from Ukraine. Higher Australian estimates may mean that import levels are maintained in the latter part of the season. We continue to expect rapeseed oil output in the EU to easily exceed 10m tonnes in 2017/18; there is a chance that output will be even higher, depending on developments in the biofuel market. Reports suggest a small drop in winter rapeseed sowings in the EU despite favourable prices for rapeseed compared with wheat. Normal yields would be above those recorded in 2017/18 and would lead to a crop in excess of 22m tonnes. Our forecast of 2018/19 rapeseed oil production is maintained at 10.6m tonnes, up by 4.2% year on year.
China will rely on imports for oil production
The improved availability of canola from Canada and Australia has provided a boost to expected rapeseed oil production in China despite the uncertainties surrounding estimates of the domestic rapeseed crop. We now expect 2017/18 rapeseed oil production to reach 3.7m tonnes. Although this is above last season's output, it is well below the 2015/16 levels. It remains unclear whether Chinese farmers will expand the planted area for the 2018/19 season. It is more likely that higher rapeseed oil production for the 2018/19 season will require yet more imports. We forecast oil output to expand to almost 4m tonnes for 2018/19.
Canada's 2017/18 harvest will rise
According to the final estimate from Statistics Canada, the 2017/18 harvest will have risen to a record 21.3m tonnes, owing largely to an increase in the area planted to canola. In addition, yields were resilient in the face of earlier adverse growing conditions. We maintain our forecast that Canada's canola oil production will surpass 4m tonnes in 2017/18. There is an upside risk depending on the rate of export of canola to China, as well as the availability of markets for the oil. Despite recent price falls, canola remains an attractive crop to Canadian farmers. However, for 2018/19 we assume a reduction in the harvested area from the peak in 2017/18. Normal yields should allow Canadian canola oil output to rise to 4.2m tonnes.
India's production is poised for growth in 2016/17
In India, 2017/18 rapeseed production is forecast to remain well below 2016/17 levels. High temperatures and sporadic rainfall has caused a 10% drop in the rapeseed area according to recently published estimates. Growing conditions have also been adverse, putting a question mark over likely yields. We are using a crop estimate of 6m tonnes, marginally below that assumed in our previous forecast. Nonetheless, the comparatively high carry-in stocks of rapeseed will help local rapeseed oil production levels to be maintained, despite the smaller crop. We now expect that 2017/18 rapeseed oil production will approach 2.3m tonnes, before falling to around 2.2m tonnes in 2018/19, given the lower level of rapeseed carry-over stocks.

Australian production is likely to fall in 2017/18 owing to dry conditions
The 2017/18 canola crop in Australia has turned out better than previously expected. Most estimates now put the crop at about 3.2m-3.5m tonnes. The increase mainly reflects better than expected yields in Western Australia. Despite this recent upgrade, the crop remains well below the 4.4m tonnes harvested in 2016/17. In Ukraine, official estimates of the 2017/18 rapeseed crop put the total at 2.2m tonnes. With winter planting now ended, the area of winter rapeseed has further expanded, reflecting increased margins from the crop. Germination and crop condition levels are reportedly better compared with those in the past four years.
Stocks and prices
As a result of the upgrade to our 2017/18 production forecast, we now expect the global rapeseed oil market to be more or less in balance. In addition, current forecasts indicate that rapeseed stocks will return to almost normal levels. Higher crushing levels than currently forecast can be achieved, which could put the rapeseed oil market into surplus. By contrast, we expect the rapeseed oil market deficit to widen in 2018/19, with only limited scope to reduce this deficit with higher rapeseed crushings.

Low stocks will put upward pressure on prices from late 2017
Physical prices of rapeseed oil dropped significantly in December 2017, reversing the gains recorded in November. Futures prices for rapeseed and canola were also on a consistent downward trend during December. The increase in the Canadian production estimate has clearly changed market sentiment. With only the Indian crop to be harvested during 2017/18, this market weakness is likely to be maintained during the remainder of the 2017/18 season. On the other hand, stock levels remain at historically low levels, and current projections suggest that 2018/19 will see a return to market deficit conditions. Our expectation is that prices will drift lower through the first two quarters of 2018 but could then start to rise, assuming that current assessments of 2018/19 production are maintained. Prices will remain below US$900/tonne throughout the 2017/18 season but will rise above that level during the 2018/19 season.

Rice
Demand
With human consumption of rice continuing to drive up overall use in Asia, where populations are rising, global demand for rice is expected to increase by 1.5% in 2017/18, to a record 492m tonnes. As in the past, relatively small volume increases are likely in other regions, including Africa and South America. However, other components of demand, such as feed and the industrial sector, are expected to contract. The outlook for the 2018/19 season depends on factors that will remain unknown for quite some time, such as policy frameworks, local crop outcomes and import needs. As such, The Economist Intelligence Unit's projection of 1.4% annual growth, to a total of 499m tonnes, assumes that consumption growth will return close to trend.
Trade in rice will continue to grow, but at a slower rate than in 2017
Africa and Asia account for three-quarters of all rice imports, primarily white and parboiled grades sourced from Thailand, India, Pakistan and Vietnam. In Sub-Saharan Africa particularly, a significant share of demand-mainly for high-quality white and parboiled supplies-is met by imports. With buyers in those regions expected to remain active in the global market, trade is projected to continue to grow in the next two years, to reach 45.5m tonnes in 2019, the largest volume on record. However, growth will be relatively marginal, as it is assumed that many Asian buyers are likely to be well stocked after the heavy purchases in 2017/18. Further strong demand for Thai rice from African buyers in 2017 was largely linked to availabilities of attractively priced rice from the government's stockpile. With those supplies having been disposed of, demand should taper.
China's needs are expected to be central to the rice trade in 2018-19
China is the world's largest consumer of rice by far, accounting for about 30% of global demand. The bulk of national consumption is made up of locally produced rice, but in recent years China has also become the biggest importer of rice, mainly of high-quality broken types from Thailand and Vietnam. Prices for domestic long-grain milled rice still command hefty premiums over supplies from other major origins in Asia, owing to the easy availability of rice from major suppliers outside China, supporting China's import demand.
Lower duties will encourage rice imports by Bangladesh in 2018-19
Bangladesh is one of the leading rice markets within Asia, with annual demand reaching at least 35m tonnes. Three domestic crops are cut each year, namely the boro (seeded in December-January and harvested in April-May), aus (planted in March-April and cut in June-July) and aman (sown in July-August and normally threshed in November-December). Although the bulk of the country's rice needs are met by domestic crops, significant quantities are sometimes procured from the world market. Bangladeshi importers and millers have sought to get tariffs reduced as a means of boosting imports, primarily from Thailand and India, with the latter typically the largest supplier in recent years. The country has recently entered into a long-term arrangement with Vietnam for up to 1m tonnes/year (t/y) of imports until 2022. Trade reports have also highlighted the possibility of significant purchases from Myanmar. The government is looking to boost rice imports to build reserves and rein in local prices after flash floods hit domestic output. To this end, the government announced a tariff reduction from 28% to 10% on rice imports in 2017.
The Philippines may be a large buyer, as state reserves are historically low
In the Philippines, stocks held by the National Food Authority, the grain procurement agency, have dwindled to their lowest level in about a decade. By contrast, however, inventories held by private households and commercial warehouses remain especially comfortable. Underscoring thin state reserves, imports progressed strongly in 2017, and are expected to reach 1.4m tonnes, up from 800,000 tonnes in the previous year. We anticipate that the Philippines will remain a significant importer in the future as it aims to ensure domestic supply.

a Local marketing years.
Supply
We have raised our forecast for global rice production in 2017/18 to 489m tonnes-year-on-year growth of 0.2%, compared with a 0.2% fall in our previous forecast-narrowly surpassing the previous year's record owing to a marginal increase in area and solid yields. This comes despite a smaller outturn in the US and prospects for a reduction in output in India, largely by way of the country's main (kharif) crop. The outlook for 2018/19 is highly provisional. Nonetheless, given that only a small expansion of paddy plantings is likely, an increase in global output will almost certainly be dependent on better yields. At 496m tonnes, the world outturn is projected to be up by 1.5% year on year. All of our scenarios assume continued state support to farmers in Asia and beneficial weather conditions.
In India, where the kharif planting season was completed by early October, the area planted to paddy was slightly smaller year on year, but still fairly solid compared with the average of recent seasons. The 2017 monsoon was about 5% below the long-term average; taking into account its impact on yield potential in some regions, as well as prospects for the winter-sown rabi crop, we project total acreage to be broadly steady year on year. According to official data, 2017/18 rabi plantings were complete on 1.6m ha by end-December, up from 1.2m ha a year earlier.
Full-season production in 2017/18 is forecast at 107m tonnes, representing a small contraction year on year. Nevertheless, this should still ensure that availabilities for domestic use and exports are sufficiently comfortable. In 2018/19 the outcome will depend on the pattern of the monsoon, which will begin around June 1st.
India is expected to export 11-12m tonnes in both 2018 and 2019
Based on their continued robust pace to date, which has been supported by large ship-ments to Africa and South Asia, India's exports in 2017 are expected to have totalled 11.5m tonnes, the largest on record, making the country the biggest exporter for the sixth consecutive year. Shipments in both 2018 and 2019 are now anticipated to be of a similar size. In part, this stems from the likelihood that the country's exporters will provide even stronger competition to their counterparts in Thailand. This follows the conclusion of the Thai government's state reserves sales programme last year, which is likely to tighten attracively priced supplies for export. India's exportable surplus will be larger in comparison, despite the aformentioned fall in output in 2017/18.
China's exports in 2017 were the largest in a decade
Although China has emerged as the world's biggest importer of rice in recent years, it has, for the most part, been a tiny exporter. Over recent seasons its exports have fluctuated between 200,000 tonnes and 500,000 tonnes, with most heading to markets in Asia, including South Korea and Japan-these being part of minimum commitments to import by those nations under World Trade Organisation (WTO) obligations. Shipments normally comprise mostly small- and medium-grain varieties.
The current year has been different, however, with unusually large shipments of long-grain rice recorded each month, including particularly heavy deliveries to Côte d'Ivoire, Liberia, Mozambique, Senegal and Sierra Leone. For 2017 in full, total imports, which are based on January-November data, are likely to have reached 1.2m tonnes, up from less than 400,000 tonnes in 2016 and the highest annual total in a decade. It is unclear whether such high sales can be maintained, especially since some of these shipments may have come in the form of food aid. Nevertheless, reports from the China Grain Network note that the heavy increase in exports reflects an acceleration of the disposal of excess rice stockpiles and describes the exports as a "structural adjustment". It is possible that shipments could be sustained at a similar level in coming years.
The government may lower minimum support prices for rice farmers
China is believed to sit on massive state reserves of rice, with some private estimates well in excess of 100m tonnes (on a rough weight basis). In addition to use of the international market to offload reserves, there has been speculation that the authorities are considering a reduction in government support prices for farmers, in order to facilitate a drop in output, and therefore stockpiles. Cutting support prices is also likely to result in a drop in imports by reducing the spread between low-priced supplies from Thailand and Vietnam, for example, and domestic rice, which is propped up by state support. In the period since 2012 China has entrenched its position as the world's largest buyer by some considerable distance, with purchases forecast to be at least 5m tonnes in 2018 and 2019. Given the potential for a lowering of state support to growers, we forecast only a modest increase in production during the next two years. Should the change be confirmed and significant, it would almost certainly result in a reduction in output and stocks.
Production prospects for 2017/18 in Thailand are positive
For many years Thailand was the biggest supplier of rice to world markets. However, a combination of its intervention buying programme in earlier years (beginning in late 2011) and heavy competition from India resulted in it losing that position. More recently, exports during 2017 were boosted by availability from the government's stockpile, but prospects for production will ultimately shape the country's exportable surplus over the next two years.
In the current season (2017/18), prospects for the main crop have been solid, with harvesting taking place in the latter stages of last year. Cumulative precipitation during 2017 is estimated to be around one-quarter higher than average, and the impact of flooding in September was minimal. Good water levels will also be important during the development of the irrigated, off-season crop, which will be threshed next year. Assuming that the planted area is expanded in both seasons, total production is projected at 20.5m tonnes, up from 19m tonnes in the previous year and a five-year high. A further increase in main-crop sowings is projected to push output up to 22m tonnes in 2018/19.
Exports of all varieties of rice totalled 10.5m tonnes during the January-November period and, with shipments of about 500,000 tonnes anticipated in December, total shipments in 2017 are estimated at 11m tonnes, up from 9.9m tonnes the year before. The strong increase was mainly due to a large expansion of shipments to markets in Africa, with a portion of these almost certainly being older state reserves. Since the government has now successfully sold off food-quality stocks from past harvests, exporters will not have access to attractively priced inventories that can be sold to buyers in Africa and other regions. Consequently, total exports in 2018 are expected to fall by 700,000 tonnes, to 10.3m tonnes, before edging up in the following year.
Vietnam faces competition from smaller and established exporters in Asia
Vietnam is a medium-sized rice producer but a major exporter. It typically accounts for 5-6% of global production but 15% of exports, making it the world's third-largest exporter behind India and Thailand. Vietnam's exporters have performed well in 2017, with bigger sales to a number of markets in Asia pushing up total volumes in January-November to a forecast 5.5m tonnes, around 25% higher than in the same period of the previous calendar year. Analysis of customs data show that, although exports to African nations were smaller year on year, China bought considerably bigger amounts from Vietnam, as did the Philippines, a long-standing traditional buyer.
However, a real boon for the nation was firm demand from Bangladesh, a country that has tended to source its import requirements from India. However, the need to build stocks after local supplies fell short meant that the government diversified its origins for imports. We expect Vietnam to maintain its position as the world's third-biggest exporter in 2018-19 and beyond, although volumes are unlikely to exceed 7m tonnes in any season, given continued heavy sales by India and Thailand, as well as growing competition from other, relatively small, exporters such as Cambodia and Myanmar.
A much smaller crop will constrain US rice exports in 2017/18
The US rice harvest was completed during October. Based on a heavy drop in plantings, production in 2017/18 is officially estimated to have fallen to just 5.7m tonnes, down from 7.1m tonnes in the previous season. This would be the smallest outturn in more than two decades, and is expected to tighten availabilities for sale on the international market, notwith-standing a drop in domestic use. Nevertheless, the contraction will be limited by large opening stocks. Shipments in the local marketing year, starting on August 1st 2017, are forecast at 3.3m tonnes, down from 3.4m tonnes in the previous year. US rice is sold globally, but major markets, mainly for paddy (rough rice) exports, include Central and Latin America, owing to proximity.

Stocks and prices
Reflecting adjustments to the historical data series in a number of countries, including China, by far the largest producer and stockholder, world carryovers in 2017/18 are significantly higher than in our previous forecast. Nevertheless, the underlying theme remains unchanged; at 107.7m tonnes, reserves are now expected to be slightly smaller in year-on-year terms. Moreover, although we expect China's supportive policies for farmers to ensure another rise in inventories, this will be in contrast to falls in the major global suppliers, as well as in other countries. Inventories held by the world's leading exporters, which include India, Pakistan, the US and Vietnam, are forecast at 22m tonnes, down by 5m tonnes year on year, but unchanged from December. This would be the smallest amount in a decade and highlights a global market that appears to be tighter than headline figures might suggest.
Stocks are expected to drop in the next two seasons on rising consumption
Despite rising global rice production in 2018, faster consumption growth will cut into global stocks, pushing them down to 107.7m tonnes. It is assumed that stockbuilding in China will continue, especially since imports are set to remain high, but exporters' reserves may fall once more, to just 21m tonnes, the bulk of which will be located in India. By contrast, Thailand's end-of-season reserves are likely to be much lower than in recent years, highlighting the government's successful programme of offloading old state reserves.
Trading in markets for export grades of white and parboiled rice in Asia has been fairly light and routine in recent months, underscoring the impact of a seasonal slowdown in many regions of the world. Highlighting this, the price of the benchmark 100% B grade in Thailand fell by 1% in the month to early January 2018.

In Vietnam, where exporters enjoyed a solid year, with shipments rising by more than 20% compared with the previous year, prices were up slightly. However, this was mostly linked to very tight supplies ahead of the main (winter-spring) crop harvest campaign. In India, where the focus is on the main kharif crop harvest, export values gained on demand from buyers in the region, principally Bangladesh, although similar increases in Pakistan were largely due to local markets and logistical difficulties.
The final quarter average price for Thailand's 100% B grade was US$391/tonne, a little higher than predicted and translating into a full-year value of US$390/tonne, only a fraction higher month on month. Accordingly, although we have made some historic changes to our base for stocks, the broader outlook is maintained from before. This results in only minor changes to our price forecasts moving forward. By the first quarter of 2020, we forecast a price of US$430/tonne and, although this would equate to a multi-year high-tied to a modest tightening of global stocks-it would still be well below the levels seen in 2009-13.

Soybeans
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global soybean consumption to expand by an average of 4.9% per year in our forecast period, to reach a total of 357.5m tonnes in 2018/19. This will be driven by rising demand for meat-and therefore animal feed ingredients, including high-protein oilseed meals-in China and many other Asian countries. Nonetheless, we expect growth to slow compared with 2016/17, when consumption rose by an estimated 6.1%. Looking beyond Asia, some smaller consuming regions, including the EU, Africa and the Middle East, will also contribute to rising demand. However, uncertainty regarding crop yields poses a downside risk to this forecast.
Trade volumes are nearly double their level from a decade ago
Partly reflecting stronger than anticipated demand in the latter stages of the 2016/17 trade year (ending September 30th), we have revised up our forecast for global soybean trade to 153m tonnes in 2017/18. This will be the seventh consecutive year of expansion, due mostly to rising demand from China, as well as some smaller markets in Asia. With demand from China and other smaller markets in Asia expected to increase again in 2018/19, global trade volumes could rise to another record of 159m tonnes.
Feed usage will drive overall demand up and will mostly be met by imports
China is by far the world's largest consumer and importer of soybeans, with growth largely driven by expanding demand from the country's vast animal feed sector. In 2017/18 we expect China's total consumption to reach a new record of 107m tonnes, representing impressive growth of 8.1%, nearly one-third of the amount used globally. China's imports are forecast to total 100m tonnes, meeting more than 90% of its total soybean consumption. Although the government is looking to boost local output, it seems that imports will continue to account for the majority of overall requirements, especially in feed sectors. Most of what is produced locally is likely to be channelled to food and other smaller markets.
China's import demand has been robust despite reports of large stocks of soybeans and associated pressure on crush margins, with buyers encouraged by ample global supply and attractive prices. Therefore, although the outlook for 2018/19 is tentative, we expect another year of strong full-season purchases, of 104m tonnes. Nonetheless, the Chinese government's intention to end maize stockpiling, announced in 2016, remains a downside risk. The move aims to encourage the use of maize at the expense of other feed grains, possibly driving down imports of other grains, which have been imported in great quantities in recent years. Higher maize consumption in the pork and poultry sectors could also raise questions surrounding the use of high-protein meals, primarily soybean meal. However, the impact is expected to be marginal, as soybean meal is the most abundantly produced oilseed meal, and provides higher protein quality and nutritional value compared with alternatives.
Ample domestic supplies will support demand in the US
With another bumper crop expected to result in a further swelling of domestic supplies, US consumption in 2017/18 is forecast to remain close to the previous season's high, at 56m tonnes. Aside from local requirements, total use will be underpinned by rising exports of soybean meal. Similar trends will enable domestic demand to edge up in 2018/19, to 57m tonnes.
Soybean consumption in Argentina will also continue to be driven by growing international demand for soybean meal, of which Argentina is the dominant supplier. In Brazil, further increases in consumption are anticipated as bigger local soybean crops boost supplies for processing.
Imports are central to EU requirements
The EU has achieved successive record crops in recent seasons. Nevertheless, at less than 3m tonnes, domestic outturns represent only a tiny share of overall requirements. The remainder is typically met by imports of soybeans and soybean meal, typically accounting for up to 35m tonnes. In 2017/18 soybeans imports are likely to rise after the previous season's fall, but any increase is likely to be capped in the future by a much better local rapeseed harvest; in 2018/19 and beyond, the availability of alternatives, including rapeseed, will play a crucial role in determining volume requirements. Throughout the period we expect the region's soybean meal imports to remain above 20m tonnes, making it easily the world's largest buyer of soybean meal (while China remains the largest buyer of soybeans).

Supply
A notable increase in the global planted area is expected in 2017/18, but the high yields achieved in 2016/17 are unlikely to be replicated. Accordingly, we forecast global soybean production to fall marginally, by 0.7% year on year, to 345m tonnes. Nonetheless, this is a slight upward revision from our previous forecast, owing to better prospects for the outturn in South America. In 2018/19 output could recover slightly, rising by a forecast 1.7% to nearly 351m tonnes, which would eclipse the 2016/17 record outturn. This reflects our outlook for a modest increase in area and trend yields.
US exports could be marginally higher in 2017/18, hitting a new record
At a record of 120.4m tonnes, US output was about 3% higher year on year in 2017/18. Together with high carryover stocks from the 2016/17 season, a crop of that size will ensure ample supplies for domestic use and export. US exports progressed strongly during the 2016/17 season, totalling 59m tonnes by August 31st 2017 (the close of the US marketing year), up by 5m tonnes from 2015/16. The solid pace was shaped by international demand from Asia, but also by a range of other importers, including smaller markets in Africa and the Middle East. For 2017/18 we expect shipments to expand to at least 60.5m tonnes, a new record. Although the pace of sales has stepped up significantly in recent weeks, these remained 14% behind those of a year earlier at end-December 2017.
US area is expected to remain broadly unchanged year on year in 2018/19
Planting intentions for the 2018/19 season in the northern hemisphere are tentative at this stage. In the US, much will depend on relative prices at the time of planting, as well as crop rotation. Although there is an argument in favour of increased corn plantings at the expense of soybeans following 2017/18 seeding patterns, support for soybean acreage could come from the recent growth in global trade, driven largely by China. We have adjusted our expectations of US soybean sowings in 2018/19, and now expect these to be broadly unchanged on the prior season. Overall, we tentatively expect the outturn to reach 118m tonnes, only marginally below the 2017/18 outturn.
A huge crop will be cut in Canada, with further increases likely in the long term
The area for harvest in Canada is estimated at a record 2.9m ha in 2017/18, an unprecedented year-on-year expansion of 33%, driven by expanded acreage in the non-traditional growing areas of Manitoba and Saskatchewan, largely at the expense of wheat and canola. One of the key attractions is that Canadian growers are able to tap in to a fast-growing global market. Added to this, the crop requires less intensive application of inputs, such as fertilisers, compared with alternatives, and new varieties have been developed that can be cultivated in areas that were previously unsuitable. Despite the significant expansion of seeded area, some reduction in yields was expected, especially as earlier reports from Manitoba and Saskatchewan pointed to difficulties with crop development owing to challenging weather conditions. Based on the recent official assessment issued by Statistics Canada, our estimate of total output has been lowered slightly, to 7.7m tonnes (from 8m tonnes), but this would still be easily the biggest crop on record, up by 17% year on year. Exports are projected to rise to 5.6m tonnes, up from 4.4m tonnes in the previous season.
Brazil's exports will continue to rise, supported by strong Chinese demand
Rising yields pushed Brazil's huge 2016/17 crop to record levels, positioning the country to export heavy volumes in the local marketing year (which closes at end-January 2018). Our forecast remains unchanged, and we believe that total shipments could reach a record of 67.5m tonnes in 2017/18, up by around 5.5m tonnes from the previous year.
Conditions for Brazil's developing crop improved in late 2017, following the arrival of beneficial rains in core areas. The only exception (in late December) was ongoing dryness in the state of Rio Grande do Sul. The Northeast region of Brazil was also dry, although the situation was deemed to be easily recoverable after precipitation levels improved in January. Crops in Brazil are reported to be flowering and setting pods, and are in good condition in many areas.
Brazil's sowings will rise in 2017/18, given the ample available land
With plenty of land available, a further expansion of soybean area in Brazil, of 2% year on year to 34.5m ha, is expected in 2017/18. Nevertheless, downside risks remain. It seems likely that, despite area increases, some growers may have scaled back expenditure on essential inputs to minimise costs. However, maize prices in Brazil are signficantly below year-earlier levels-having fallen by a larger margin than soybean prices-which makes it likely that some farmers will have switched a portion of their intended primary, or full-season, maize cropland to soybeans. With yields set to be a little below the levels achieved in 2016/17, we forecast output to fall slightly in 2017/18, to 111m tonnes. Nevertheless, this is still a marginal increase from our previous forecast, due to favourable weather in recent weeks.
The government aims to resolve logistical obstacles to moving the crop to port
In the early months of 2017 heavy rains in Brazil caused the closure of the BR-163, also known as the "soybean highway", for quite some time, resulting in significant disruption to logistics on routes to Northern Arc ports. Mindful of last year's difficulties, the government is reportedly taking steps to avoid a poor outcome this time. The army will play a key role, and has done preliminary drainage work to keep unpaved sections passable. It will also respond to any problems that suddenly arise on the route during the course of the season. Planting of the 2018/19 crop will not begin until mid-September 2018, so the outlook is highly provisional. Based on further area expansion and trend productivity, output could be close to the 2016/17 high.
The ports on the Amazon River and along the north-eastern Atlantic Coast of Brazil are part of what is called the "Northern Arc" of ports in Brazil. Many of these ports are being expanded to handle increased volumes. A railway is also being planned from Mato Grosso to the more northerly Port of Miritituba, but completion will take many more years. BR-163 is thus the only major northbound highway, and completion of the paving project is therefore vital. The amount of grains and oilseeds moving along the northern highway will increase once the harvest has ramped up in Mato Grosso in January 2018, and industry stakeholders are encouraging the government to take action to avoid potential supply disruptions at ports.
Argentina's 2017/18 output could fall owing to area declines and dryness
Fieldwork for Argentina's 2017/18 crop is well under way and was estimated by the Bolsa Cereales to be 88% complete by January 3rd. According to the Bolsa Cereales, despite better progress in recent weeks, fieldwork continued to be hampered by hot and dry conditions, especially in northern regions. With the closure of the seeding window for soybeans (in mid-January), some areas, including in central and south-west regions of Buenos Aires, along with southern La Pampa province, could be left unseeded. In terms of yield potential, this will depend on whether beneficial rains arrive in the coming period. The critical time for the crop is during the pod-filling period-typically around February/March. With some area reduction now expected, and with a fall in average yields, production is projected to drop by 3.5m tonnes year on year for 2017/18, to 53m tonnes. Although the government is expected to reduce export levies gradually over the course of 2018-19, the crop is unlikely to be as attractive as other options.
China's output is rising, but still meets only a fraction of domestic demand
Despite being the world's largest importer by far, China is only a minor producer of soybeans. Its potential is capped by limited yield gains compared with those of the world's big players, as well as the attraction of alternative crops such as wheat, corn and rice. Nonetheless, in August 2016 the Chinese authorities published a National Oilseed Development Plan, which aims to boost domestic production to 60m tonnes by 2020. The scheme will provide support for oilseed production, processing, technical extension and innovation.
In 2016/17 total acreage was up by an estimated 10% from the previous season, and a further increase is likely in 2017/18, with a portion of land coming from the switching-out of corn production in north-eastern areas. Total output in the season is expected to rise to a peak of 14.3m tonnes, up from 13.1m tonnes in the previous year, and the same influences will underpin another increase in output, to 15.2m tonnes, in 2018/19.

Stocks and prices
At the end of the 2017/18 season global soybean carry-over stocks are forecast to reach a new record of 122m tonnes, with further accumulation in the US compensating for stock declines in other major producers. This should ensure that supplies in the world market are comfortable and, in the absence of a significant supply-side disturbance, that prices stay in check. Nevertheless, the nominal increase in stocks in 2017/18 (4m tonnes) would be much smaller than in 2016/17 (22m tonnes), when production soared. In 2018/19 prospects are highly provisional, but world inventories are expected to tighten, falling to 115m tonnes, although this is still large by historical comparison. Should conditions worsen in South America, we would revise down our stock forecast.
Looking below top-line data, US ending stocks (based on end-August 2018) are forecast to rise to 11.6m tonnes, up from 8.1m tonnes at the end of the previous season and the highest level since 2006/07. The bumper crop in 2016/17 helped to push stocks to this record level, despite growth in domestic consumption and exports. Inventory build-up in the US will help to offset expected falls in both Argentina and Brazil, where 2017/18 crops are likely to be smaller year on year in the face of high exports and local consumption.
World export prices for soybeans weakened in the month to early January, although activity was sometimes muted owing to seasonal holidays in a number of regions. Although international demand remained supportive at times, many leading buyers-notably China-are likely to have remained sidelined, awaiting new crop availabilities in Brazil. Earlier concerns about difficult weather patterns and the potential impact on crops in Argentina eased in some areas during December. Nevertheless, with some parts of Argentina still abnormally dry, and planting behind schedule when compared with a year ago, overall declines in international values were limited.

More recently there has been some support to US cash prices via strengthening export premiums, as freezing weather on important rivers in the Midwest led to tighter supplies at Gulf ports. There was even talk that some exporters were having to renege on original contract specifications owing to reduced availability. On January 4th US Gulf export prices for nearby shipment were quoted at US$373/tonne, a drop of 3% from the previous month, with new crop offers in Argentina and Brazil showing similar falls.
The 2017 fourth-quarter price averaged US$376/tonne, resulting in a full year value of US$377/tonne. Although there are some changes in the forecast, particularly in production and trade, the fundamental picture is broadly unchanged. Accordingly, we maintain our forecast for modest price growth through to early 2020. However, our production outlook rests on the assumption of normal growing conditions across the full season in leading producing countries. Should crops fall significantly short of expectations in any of the main exporters, especially in Brazil, there could be significant market support, pushing prices well above projected levels.
