Sugar
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that global annual sugar consumption will expand by an average of 1.4% in 2017/18-2018/19 (October-September), roughly in line with the average over the past four seasons. Rising demand will continue to be underpinned by population growth and rising incomes in emerging markets, where urbanising populations are adopting the food-and-drink habits of developed countries. Sugar plays a key role in this dietary shift, as a sweetener in food and beverages, and as a binding and preserving agent in processed foods. However, heightened awareness about the health implications of excess sugar in diets will put pressure on consumption growth, amid consumer pressure on the food processing industry to reduce sugar and, in some markets, the introduction of "sin taxes" on sugary products. Moreover, owing to the growing supply of cheaper, starch-based sweeteners in both Asia (where Chinese production is expanding rapidly) and Europe (whose market was liberalised in September 2017), a gradual shift towards these alternatives will further limit demand for sugar in the food and drinks industry. Meanwhile, the impact of relatively low global sugar prices on demand will be muted by long-standing domestic pricing policies, which will limit the extent to which lower prices pass through to consumers.
Although its demand growth will ease, China will remain a key consumer
Rising urbanisation and changing consumer tastes will continue to spur demand for sugar in China, although we expect the rate of demand growth to ease in 2018-19, in line with a modest slowdown in overall GDP growth. Demand will also be held back by the growing supply of starch-based sweeteners, which are cheaper rivals to sugar in the beverages industry, and higher domestic sugar prices, which are a likely consequence of the government's moves to restrict imports. Amid pressure from domestic producers to support the local industry, the government reduced permits in mid-2017 (to 1m tonnes/year-t/y-roughly half the previous level) and raised duties on out-of-quota sugar imports (from 50% to 95%). As a result, sugar imports fell by 24% year on year in January-November. Similar restrictions will remain in place in the coming years (albeit with the out-of-quota import tariff falling slightly over time), thereby constraining import demand. Nevertheless, China is unlikely to be able to scale up domestic production to a level that could fully satisfy its domestic demand and preserve its strategically high levels of stocks. It will therefore continue to make purchases overseas, with the government timing its import decisions to coincide with favourable global prices or seasonal spikes in demand.
Consumption in India is forecast to recover as prices normalise
Potential consumption growth in India has been constrained in recent years by high post-drought prices and unsupportive policy moves (including demonetisation and the removal of some consumer subsidies). However, we expect demand to recover fairly briskly over the forecast period, rising from 0.8% growth in 2017/18 to 2% in 2018/19. The government raised import duties in mid-2017 (from 40% to 50%), but the near-term impact of protectionism on local prices will be muted by strong local harvests. Hence, as large domestic supplies from the 2017/18 crop hit the market, domestic prices will soften. This, together with rising incomes and further urbanisation, will support demand.
Demand growth elsewhere in Asia is threatened by starch-based rivals
Beyond China and India, the outlook for sugar consumption in Asia is positive. Demand in the more developed countries, such as Malaysia and South Korea, is likely to grow only slowly as markets mature, but this will be more than offset by demand in populous developing countries such as Indonesia, Thailand and Vietnam. However, demand growth in this region will be somewhat dampened by a gradual shift in the food and drink industry to cheaper, starch-based sweeteners as China (Asia's largest producer) seeks export markets. Tax measures to ensure that sugar consumption remains within recommended health guidelines could also dampen demand, with Thailand, the Philippines and Indonesia pursuing plans to introduce a so-called sugar tax. This has the potential to put a sharp brake on demand; for example, the introduction of a sugar tax in Mexico in 2015 has contributed to a 12% drop in sugar demand since then. Nevertheless, we assume that any such policies in Asia will be rolled out only slowly over the coming years, amid concerns over restricting growth in the otherwise burgeoning food and drink manufacturing industries.
Health warnings may eventually dent sugar demand in the developed world
Demand growth in the mature EU market is likely to be sluggish in 2017/18-2018/19. Many EU countries already average far higher consumption levels of sugar than recommended by the World Health Organisation (WHO), much of which is hidden in processed foods, and the EU Consumer Organisation is urging the food industry to take notice of WHO guidelines. So far, tax measures have been proposed to curb use in countries including the UK, Spain and Belgium. The policy response is likely to be watered down somewhat by opposition from the powerful food and drink industry, but consumer pressure is driving a gradual shift in the food industry towards lower sugar levels. More imminently, however, the liberalisation of the EU's sugar regime in September 2017-when production quotas, guaranteed farmgate prices and export caps were abolished-will limit the need for imports and bring European sugar prices (which have historically traded at a premium) closer to the global norm. The production of isoglucose (a starch-based sweetener) was also liberalised in September 2017 and, as in the US, this is likely to steal market share gradually. As well as the adjustment to the new liberalised regime, the UK's exit from the EU is generating uncertainty in the European sugar industry, as the UK is the largest importer of EU sugar.
Changing consumer tastes will boost demand growth in Africa
African consumption will continue to increase, with the bulk of growth coming from rising local supplies that make sugar more affordable. Several consumers (including Nigeria, the region's largest importer, as well as Kenya and Ghana) are pursuing long-term investment plans in the sugar sector in the hope of becoming self-sufficient. But inefficient domestic supply chains will impede the development of Africa's sugar industries, and aggregate import demand from Sub-Saharan Africa is expected to remain well above 5m t/y in 2017/18-2018/19. A sugar tax will come into effect in South Africa in April 2018, but we expect the impact to be fairly minor, as manufacturers (particularly beverage companies) and consumers should be able to withstand the slightly higher cost. If this policy were to be replicated across the region, it would negatively affect demand in the medium term, but, amid considerable resistance from food and beverage industries, we think that this is unlikely.
Policy changes will shift the dynamics of the global sugar trade
The overhaul of EU sugar policy in 2017 is likely to have a significant effect on global trade patterns as the bloc transitions from being a net importer to becoming a net exporter. We expect this transition to be complete by the end of the 2017/18 season. The smaller producers, particularly in Africa and the Caribbean, which supply the EU under preferential trade deals, will be hit hardest by this shift. Global trade dynamics will also be affected by the introduction of heavy import tariffs in China, with small producers (exempt from the new tariffs) likely to increase their market share. Aside from China, trade patterns in Asia will be affected by the liberalisation of sugar sales under the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) free-trade agreement, which comes into effect in 2018. This will probably cause less-efficient producers (such as Vietnam) to rely more heavily on imports from elsewhere in the region (probably Thailand). Intra-regional trade is also likely to increase in North America, following a trade deal between the US and Mexico that came into effect in July. This tightened the rules for Mexican producers and granted Mexico the right of first refusal for the US's above-quota import demand.
These trade deals and policy measures will shift the direction of global trade flows, but trade volumes will ultimately be defined by countries' preference for holding strategic stockpiles of sugar to hedge against future shocks. We therefore expect trade to increase in 2017/18 as countries (notably China) rebuild stocks after several years of low domestic production and relatively high global prices, before trade flows slow in 2018/19 on the back of large local harvests in markets that typically swing between net imports and net exports (notably India).

Supply
After fairly modest growth of 2.1% in 2016/17, world sugar production is forecast to increase by 7% in 2017/18, to 179.6m tonnes. This is slightly lower than our previous forecast (of 7.2%) as the latter part of the local season in Brazil, the world's largest producer, fell short of our expectations. Nevertheless, Brazil has still benefited from a second consecutive year of crop-friendly growing conditions in 2017/18 and, with a significant amount of output locked into generously priced forward contracts, the supply of cane to sugar production will remain above average. Global supply will also be supported by strong crop revivals in India and Thailand, following weather-related shocks during the previous harvest, and strong output growth in the EU as producers seek to capitalise on the newly liberalised sugar regime. In 2018/19 we expect global output to remain fairly flat, with growth of just 0.8%, as a slowdown in Brazil is offset by growth among most other producers. This is, however, contingent on normal weather conditions, and even fairly modest disruptions to rainfall patterns pose significant risks to the forecast.
Output growth in Brazil is in prospect as cane supply increases
Brazil is on course for a strong cane harvest, with volumes surpassing market expectations in the early months of the local 2017/18 season (April-March) and quality deteriorating only slightly as the harvest has progressed. In the latter part of the season, however, mills have closed earlier than we had expected in the crucial Centre South region (which produces some 90% of Brazilian sugar) owing to wet weather and rising ethanol prices. This has caused an unusually high proportion of cane to be diverted to biofuel production at the expense of sugar. Mills had favoured sugar production over recent years, as ethanol demand waned during a period of low oil prices and weak economic growth. However, the government reduced a federal ethanol tax in mid-2017 and this, together with rising oil prices (which boost demand for biofuels), will draw in more cane.
Even so, the overall diversion of cane to the sugar industry in 2017/18 will still be above historical norms of 44%. We therefore expect sugar output to reach 39.4m tonnes in 2017/18; this is up from an average of 37.7m tonnes over the past five years but is a slight downward revision on our previous forecast owing to dynamics in the Centre South. In 2018/19 the weakness of the Real will support the attractiveness of the export-oriented sugar industry, but higher global oil prices and a modest economic recovery in Brazil will spur demand for biofuels. These counteracting factors will probably leave ethanol and sugar prices close to parity, and this is likely to bring the diversion rate in line with historical norms. Moreover, sugarcane fields are ageing and field renewal rates are low. This will begin to take a toll on cane output from 2018/19, thereby reducing the overall cane crush. With a less favourable diversion rate and lower cane production, sugar output is therefore forecast to moderate to 38.3m tonnes in 2018/19.
Strong post-drought crop revival is expected in India
Production in India is poised for a strong recovery following drought-related supply disruptions in 2015/16-2016/17. We expect output to reach 26m tonnes in 2017/18 on the back of an expansion of the crop area under cultivation and stronger yields. In 2018/19 planting will be encouraged by decent farmgate prices in the previous season, while the wider use of high-yielding seed varieties will boost output. Limited crushing capacity will probably keep output below official projections of 30m tonnes, but we expect a second year of strong production in 2018/19. High production levels will, however, put pressure on sugar prices. Low domestic sugar prices, together with higher state-imposed ethanol prices from December 2017, as the government seeks to develop a biofuel industry, could lead to the diversion of cane away from the sugar industry. However, with ethanol production still costly and cane in plentiful supply, we doubt that rising ethanol production will have a significant impact on sugar output in the near term. Moreover, the draft biofuel policy restricts the diversion of cane to ethanol production to years of surplus production, which should mitigate the medium-term threat to sugar output.
EU production will recover as the sugar regime is liberalised
In Europe, sugar output is poised for brisk growth as producers seek to take advantage of the lifting of the EU's 50-year-old sugar quota system. Under the new regime, which came into effect at the start of the 2017/18 season, producers (led by France, Germany and the Benelux countries) will extend their crush seasons, thereby making better use of existing capacity without significant additional investments. This will be supported by higher supplies of beet, with some integrated sugar companies reporting that the area under cultivation has been increased by 15% year on year in 2017/18. Weather conditions have also been favourable, with the authorities in France projecting a record high harvest in 2017/18. Higher supply and greater efficiency should also leave the region's main producers able to withstand lower prices as the price of European sugar falls closer to the global average. We expect EU production to reach 18.8m tonnes in 2018/19, which will surpass EU demand and spur export growth.
In Russia, sugar production is expected to remain robust, following significant investment in the modernisation of sugar factories in recent years. Output since the start of beet processing in August has been strong (up by 13% year on year in mid-November), aided by favourable crop-growing conditions. The ensuing surplus will support Russia's emergence as a notable exporter as the government seeks to prevent stock build-ups from depressing domestic prices and deterring planting. However, we think that the authorities' forecast that exports will reach almost 1m t/y is overoptimistic, owing to soft demand for imports in Central Asia (Russia's main market) and the country's limited output of high-value sugar (which is in higher demand globally).
Output in Thailand is recovering from El Niño's long reach
In Thailand, favourable rainfall will support a bumper harvest in 2017/18 of 11.9m tonnes. Assuming that rainfall normalises in 2018/19, we forecast a more moderate, albeit still decent, outturn of 10.5m tonnes. The industry is facing a regulatory overhaul, after Brazil successfully argued that Thailand was violating World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules on free competition. The Thai govern-ment aims to introduce legislation to liberalise the sugar industry in early 2018, despite fierce resistance from manufacturers. Most importantly, this will phase out quotas for sugar production and revoke the domestic price-fixing system. Mills are, however, still obliged to reimburse farmers if the final sale price drops below a pre-agreed price, and this should offer farmers some protection from global volatility. Liberalisation is likely to lead to some consolidation of the industry, but we continue to believe that total production will expand. Increasing mechanisation will help to boost yields, and the sugarcane area will grow as farmers turn away from less profitable rice crops. Moreover, producers will be incentivised by export opportunities to other Asian markets, where demand is rising and Thai sugar enjoys favourable access under the ASEAN free-trade arrangement. However, weather-related risks to our Thai forecast are rising as production moves towards more drought-prone interior regions.
A major recovery in China's sugar sector appears unlikely for now
China's sugar output fell sharply in 2013/14-2016/17, owing to unfavourable weather and the impact of rapidly rising costs for labour, land and farm machinery. Amid political pressure from the local industry, some government support has been forthcoming in the form of input subsidies and soft loans, and the government has raised duties on out-of-quota sugar imports in a bid to protect local producers from cheaper imports. These measures will support the profitability of the local industry and should spur some investment, but we doubt that they will lead to a significant surge in domestic supply growth. The sector is dominated by smallholder farmers, labour costs are high and sugarcane areas do not lend themselves to mechanisation. Indeed, the cost of producing sugarcane in China is almost double that in Thailand, and this will deter investment. Owing to more favourable growing conditions, we expect output to rise modestly, to an average of 10.4m t/y in 2017/18-2018/19, but this is well below the 10% annual growth that would be needed for the state to meet its medium-term production goals.

Stocks and prices
After successive supply deficits and a period of relatively high global prices, global sugar stocks shrank to 87.4m tonnes at end-2016/17. We expect stocks to recover to 98m tonnes by end-2018/19 as the market swings back into surplus. The market surplus is forecast to reach 6.1m tonnes in 2017/18, amid bumper harvests from key producers, before moderating to 4.5m tonnes in 2018/19 as output remains flat and consumption accelerates slightly. Although overall stocks will remain comfortable (equivalent to an average of 54.7% of annual consumption in 2017/18-2018/19), the uneven distribution of these stocks means that reserves will not always be available to the market, and occasional supply squeezes are possible.

Prices will drift higher, but slowly and from a low base
After peaking at over 23 US cents/lb in late 2016, global sugar prices fell by 30% over the first half of 2017, before stabilising at about 14.4 US cents/lb in the latter half of the year. In part, this reflects a market correction after overshooting, with speculative investors unwinding the long positions that they had adopted during the price boom. More fundamentally, crop-friendly weather conditions in key producer markets are fuelling expectations of a global sugar surplus in the coming years, and policy moves to restrict import dependence in key consumers (notably, China, India and Europe) have further weakened market sentiment.
After having fallen sharply in late 2017, we expect sugar prices to drift higher from this low base over the course of 2018-19. This modest price recovery from the nadir of mid-2017 will be driven partly by market tightening from 2018 as the crucial Brazilian market diverts more cane to ethanol production over the coming years and therefore produces less sugar. A swing to ethanol that is substantial enough to bring the global sugar market into balance seems unlikely, however, and the prospects of global oversupply will probably prevent a more significant rebound in prices. Our forecast of a modest price recovery is also based on the expectation that the sugar trading market will gradually begin pricing in more risk, after prices dropped so low in 2017 that they effectively excluded a risk premium. With traders still seemingly taking their price cues from the expectation of a global surplus in 2017/18, we have revised down our price projection for early 2018. But as crude oil prices rise and the sugar market tightens, we expect a rising risk premium to provide some support to prices. Sugar prices are therefore forecast to average 15.5 US cent/lb in 2018 (a downward revision to our previous forecast of 16.1 US cent/lb, due to the expectation of lower prices in early 2018), before hovering at about 16-16.5 US cents/lb in 2019.

Sunflowerseed oil
Demand
Global demand for sunflowerseed oil remains fairly strong, owing in part to its attractive pricing compared with other oils. Nonetheless, The Economist Intelligence Unit has revised down its forecast for global demand growth in 2017/18, to 2.2% (2.8% previously), reflecting concerns about availability. Sunflower-seed oil enjoys positive consumer perceptions in many countries, and this underpins our expectation of further consumption growth in 2018/19. We forecast global consumption growth to pick up to 4.1% that season, to a total of 19.4m tonnes; this forecast assumes that sunflowerseed oil will maintain its competitive position against the price of other oils.
Sunflowerseed oil's improving price competitiveness will boost EU usage
Although the gap narrowed slightly in late 2017, sunflowerseed oil continues to be traded at a historically large discount to rapeseed and soybean oils. Partially as a result, consumption remains buoyant in the EU. We expect regional demand to rise by another 2% in 2017/18, buidling on remarkable (estimated) growth of 15.1% in 2016/17. However, this level of consumption implies a modest decrease in imports of sunflowerseed oil compared with the previous year. Assuming that imports pick up again in 2018/19, supported by sunflower-seed oil's favourable consumer image, demand could expand by 4.3% that season.
Russian consumption will rise modestly as the economy emerges from recession
In Russia, lower production estimates will cause local availability to tighten in 2017/18. This is likely to be reflected in higher local prices; we expect this to hinder demand growth in 2017/18, which we have revised down to a marginal 0.4% year on year (1% previously). In the 2018/19 season we expect consump-tion growth to pick up to 4.7% year on year, encouraged by slightly faster GDP growth in 2018 and 2019.
Robust GDP growth and shifting preferences will boost India's usage
Indian imports of sunflowerseed are continuing to run at high levels despite the imposition of higher import tariffs. Internal Indian prices show sunflowerseed oil to be increasingly competitive with other oils. The growing consumer preference for sunflowerseed oil, especially in the south of India, and sustained economic growth should also be positive for demand growth. We expect 2017/18 consumption to rise by 8.2%, to over 2.3m tonnes, followed by further growth of 3.7% in 2018/19.

Consumption growth to moderate in "other" countries in 2017/18
Many countries have been increasing their purchases of sunflowerseed oil to take advantage of competitive prices. Countries increasing their use of sunflower-seed oil include Turkey, Iran, Iraq and Egypt, as well as several smaller countries. With more uncertainty over 2017/18 supplies, some of these countries are reducing their purchases. We have reduced our expectations of consumption growth in these "other" countries to 1.2% in 2017/18 (2.2% previously).
Supply
The estimates of the 2017/18 sunflowerseed crop have mainly been revised downwards compared with our previous forecast. Lower estimates for Russia and Argentina are only partially offset by a higher EU estimate. Despite the reductions, the global harvest will still be a large one by recent standards although significantly below last season's record output. With comparatively low carry-in stocks of seeds, we expect production of sunflowerseed oil to contract by 2.5% year on year in 2017/18, to 18.4m tonnes, from 18.9m tonnes in 2016/17. Early indications suggest another large harvest in 2018/19, supporting growth of 3.3% in sunflowerseed oil production. In addition, the size of the crop would allow some rebuilding of stocks to more normal levels.
Crush rates to slow as the season progresses
Ukraine's sunflowerseed crop has failed to live up to early estimates for the 2017/18 season; we maintain our forecast that the outturn will reach 13.2m tonnes. However, with relatively plentiful sunflowerseed stocks carried over, this is not likely to have an immediate impact on crush rates. Indeed, exports of sunflowerseed oil in the year to date from the Ukraine have been running above year-earlier levels, encouraging continued high levels of crushing. However, it is expected that crush rates will slow as the season progresses and as seed stocks are worked through, reducing availability and therefore crush volumes. Official statistics reported that sunflowerseed stocks were lower by 11.5% at the start of December 2017. Although the outlook for 2018/19 is provisional, some local observers have raised concerns that falling profit margins will act as a disincentive to farmers. However, given the industry's strong expansion in recent years, we maintain our relatively optimistic view. At this stage, we assume an unchanged area which, with normal yields, would result in a crop of 14.7m tonnes. This would provide sufficient raw material to push sunflowerseed oil output in 2018/19 to 6.1m tonnes-below the record outturn in 2016/17 but still up by 5% from 2017/18.
Sunflowerseed crush rates contingent on availability
In Russia, official reports suggest that 13% of the sunflowerseed crop was unharvested in mid-December, compared with less than 5% a year earlier. As a result, we have further reduced our estimate of the final outturn to 11m tonnes, with risks primarily on the downside. Sunflowerseed crush rates will be affected by the lower availability-we have therefore reduced our forecast for sunflowerseed oil production to 4.4m tonnes in 2017/18 (4.6m tonnes previously). In 2018/19 we expect that the sunflowerseed area will be similar to 2017/18. Normal yields would give a record crop of more than 12m tonnes. Sunflowerseed oil production could reach almost 4.9m tonnes in 2018/19, provided that sufficient markets can be found.
Estimates for the EU sunflowerseed harvest in 2017/18 have improved
There has been a further small increase in our estimate for EU sunflowerseed production in the 2017/18 season, reflecting a higher estimate for Spanish production. With sunflowerseed production almost 1m tonnes higher than 2016/17, we expect sunflowerseed imports to fall and EU crushing volumes to rise compared with the previous year. We forecast EU sunflowerseed oil production to reach 3.5m tonnes in 2017/18 (3.4m tonnes previously). Sunflower-seed sowings for 2018/19, which start in the spring, are expected to be marginally lower than in 2017/18. At this level, a potential crop of more than 9m tonnes is in prospect. Sunflowerseed oil production could approach 3.5m tonnes.
Prospects for Argentina's crop remain good, but downside risks are mounting
In Argentina the 2017/18 sunflowerseed area has expanded by around 10% year on year. Yet growing conditions have been relatively unfavourable, with conditions too dry, and assessments of the likely harvest have been reduced to around 3.7m tonnes. Despite the reduction, if achieved this will be the largest crop in the last decade. We continue to expect that sunflowerseed oil production will exceed 1.4m tonnes in 2017/18 and reach 1.5m tonnes in 2018/19. Export availability of sunflowerseed in 2017/18 will also be higher than in 2016/17, even with the reduced crop estimate.

Stocks and prices
Stocks of sunflowerseed oil remain plentiful, and this situation is likely to persist for the 2017/18 season, despite the fact that we forecast a small deficit in the global market in that season. That position will only be achieved by running down sunflowerseed stocks, which may consequently turn out to be overoptimistic. Current projections suggest a recovery in sunflowerseed stocks in 2018/19, which may encourage crushers to maintain activity during the latter part of the 2017/18 season. Nonetheless, as consumption expands at a relatively firm pace, we expect the global market to remain in deficit in 2018/19.

Upward pressure on prices will be felt in the coming months
Sunflowerseed oil prices retained their value in December despite falls in the prices of other vegetable oils. Clearly, the reductions in production estimates were enough to raise concerns about future supplies, keeping a floor under prices. As the market moves into deficit in 2017/18, we expect prices to trend upwards. Nonetheless, with ample global stocks in place, price gains are likely to be modest. We forecast growth of 4.3% in sunflowerseed oil prices in 2018, followed by stronger growth, of 7.2%, over the course of 2019.

Tea
Demand
Global tea consumption is growing steadily, driven mainly by China, which accounts for one-third of world tea consumption and is consuming ever-greater quantities of green tea. However, demand is also growing in other major consuming regions, including India. Demand for tea is less exposed to economic cycles than other commodities owing to its low cost, implying that tea demand is mainly driven by demographics. This explains why The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast for tea consumption growth, of 3.8% a year on average in 2018-19, is relatively high and in line with the long-term historical average. It also explains why our demand-side forecasts tend to remain relatively stable, since tea consumption is determined by structural factors to a much greater degree than other beverages. Global demand for black tea will continue to rise, particularly driven by its increasing popularity in China, but the pace of growth will be outstripped by that for green tea, fruit tea, herbal tea, rooibos (from South Africa), purple tea (mainly from Kenya) and high-end organic tea, reflecting their greater reported health benefits and heavy marketing. Iced tea and "ready to drink" tea beverages account for a small share of the tea market but have enjoyed rapid growth in sales-even in traditional markets such as China.
Tea demand will benefit from changing consumer habits
The main tea-consuming countries are also the largest producers, with a rising share of output retained for domestic consumption (this explains why many producers are trying to boost output, in an effort to raise exports). In producing countries, tea will benefit from changing consumption habits related to rising incomes, but in most places will remain a consumer staple. The fact that a smaller share of tea than coffee is consumed in the out-of-home sector-owing partly to customer perceptions that tea in cafés offers less value for money-will shield tea consumption from adverse economic developments, which tend to have less of an impact on at-home consumption.
Both India and China will continue to see robust demand growth in 2017-18
Tea consumption will remain dominated by Asian consumers, particularly China and India, which together accounted for an estimated 57% of global demand in 2017, up from 48% in 2010. In China, we expect the government's efforts to rein in credit growth to contribute to a managed economic slowdown from 2018; nonetheless, this will have only a muted impact on tea demand growth, which is forecast to rise by 4% per year, compared with 5% in 2017. This forecast is relatively cautious, with the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) projecting average annual Chinese demand growth of 15% until 2024, suggesting an upside risk to our forecasts. Average consumption per head stands at just over 1 kg/year, ranking China just 14th in the world. This leaves room for growth, particularly as only around 35% of the population drinks tea.
Given that tea is regarded as a traditional drink, it will suffer from mounting com-petition from coffee and soft-drink retailers, owing to a growing preference for these beverages among younger Chinese consumers. Moreover, younger segments of the population are also showing a preference for black tea over green tea (black tea consumption has risen by an average of 40% per year since 2002, while green tea consumption has risen more gradually), which should bolster demand for black tea, albeit from a low base. Other changes in consumer habits will also affect tea sales, with greater demand for teabags globally (these are less wasteful than loose-leaf tea). However, given the importance attached to the quality of tea, sales of leaf teas will continue to dominate the local market.
In India, strong economic growth will be accompanied by higher household spending, firm consumer confidence and supportive demographics, driving annual average growth in tea consumption of 6.4% in 2018-19, marginally lower than estimated growth of 6.5% in 2017. Structurally, the Indian market has significant potential-aside from its sheer size, average consumption per head is lower than in China, at just 740 g per year, which bodes well for longer-term demand growth. Currently, the out-of-home sector accounts for just under 50% of tea consumption, compared with 85% of the coffee market. The expansion of tea bars across many cities aims to lift this share, as well as fuelling overall tea consumption growth.
Tea: consumption

Structural constraints will hamper tea consumption growth in many markets
Demand in some large consuming countries will be hampered in 2018-19 by market saturation and weakening demographics. The FAO forecasts an overall contraction until 2024 in many EU markets (which together account for just under 5% of global consumption), despite a firmer economic performance, as well as in Russia (2.5% of global consumption). Turkey, which also accounts for around 5% of global consumption, has a particularly saturated market, with the highest consumption of tea per head in the world by some margin. The EU also registers some of the world's highest levels, particularly in the UK and Ireland. Although our forecasts anticipate further growth in demand, reflecting continued population growth and steady growth in private consumption, the pace will be fairly mild. We forecast average annual growth in tea demand in 2018-19 of 1.9% in the EU and 0.4% in Turkey. Russian demand growth will be stronger, at an average of 2.5% per year, but is flattered by a weak base of comparison following a sharp decline in consump-tion in 2013-16.
There is plenty of room for market growth in the US
The US is a small market for tea, accounting for less than 2.5% of global consumption, and consumption per head is low. However, with most of the larger tea markets dominated by loose-leaf tea, the US remains one of the most important single markets for instant tea and iced tea. It also remains one of the world's largest tea importers. We expect demand to increase by an annual average of 2.6% in 2018-19, partly reflecting our fairly upbeat forecast for economic growth. Health concerns will also sustain demand for tea, with a gradual shift away from carbonated beverages towards healthier alternatives.
New tea markets are emerging
Export data from tea-producing countries reveal that new markets for tea are emerging, with the number of countries buying tea at the major auction houses in Asia and Africa on the rise. Demand from these new joiners in the tea market, mainly fast-growing emerging countries, is set to increase in 2018-19, underpinning our forecast for average consumption growth of 2.5% a year across all "other" countries, which together account for 18% of global consumption.
Supply
We estimate that global tea production contracted by 0.6% in 2017-the first fall in output since our data series (which is based on historical data from the FAO) began in 2000. Nonetheless, this is an upward revision from our previous estimate (of a 1.7% drop), as Kenya's tea production improved markedly in late 2017. We expect global production to rebound in 2018-19, rising by an average of 2.8% per year. Yet, these growth rates remain weak by historical comparison; annual growth in tea output averaged 4.4% during 2004-14. Along with weather-related concerns, several structural factors will prevent faster production growth. In inflation-adjusted terms, farmers' profits are lower than in past decades owing to the higher cost of inputs, resulting in a fall in investment. In addition, many local currencies will remain comparatively weak against the US dollar in 2018-19, which will hamper operating conditions for farmers. It looks increasingly likely that a La Niña weather phenomenon will develop in the coming months: this can bring unusually cold temperatures to some Chinese tea-growing regions, drought to Kenya and very wet conditions to Vietnam. Depending on how weather conditions develop (currently it looks set to be a comparatively weak La Niña, which may well have a minimal impact on tea production), this has the potential to lead to another year of declining output.
Much of the forecast growth in 2018-19 will come from a rise in green tea output, where growth has outpaced black tea by a significant margin in recent years. Green tea now accounts for one-third of total global tea production, compared with less than one-quarter a decade ago. This mainly reflects rising production in China, where loose-leaf green tea accounts for 68% of domestic production, and in Vietnam, where it now represents 55% of tea output, up from 43% a decade ago. We expect these trends to continue in 2018-19.
As in 2016, adverse weather will harm Chinese tea production in 2017
China experienced the second year of disappointing tea production growth in 2017. We estimate that output expanded by 2.2%, after heavy rains hit several of the large tea-producing provinces in southern China, including Hunan, Jiangxi and Zhejiang, in June. The rains were followed by extremely hot weather in some areas (including parts of Zhejiang), which probably hampered production.
We expect tea production growth to pick up to an annual average of 3.7% in 2018-19. The government's focus on eliminating rural poverty is likely to improve farmers' access to credit from the Agricultural Development Bank of China, the Agricultural Bank of China and rural credit co-operatives. Coupled with more supportive underlying weather conditions, these efforts are likely to lift tea production more substantially than in 2017. Structural efforts on the part of the authorities to lift product quality and quantity in order to boost exports (only about 15% of tea production was exported in 2016) will also bolster output. Given that China's average yield per hectare is low by global standards (at 801 kg in 2014-16, compared with 2,153 kg in India and 2,088 kg in Kenya), there is certainly potential for gains in productivity.
India's tea production will continue to grow slowly in 2018 and 2019
We estimate that tea production rose by 1% in India in 2017. Output fell in the first quarter of 2017, reflecting dry conditions in Assam (India's largest tea-growing state), as well as in Bengal and parts of southern India, but weather conditions improved subsequently. Assuming supportive weather conditions in 2018-19, we expect tea production to continue to rise, albeit gradually. Continued efforts to channel funding to tea growers will provide support, but several structural factors will hold back production. There has been little progress on reforms to boost foreign direct investment in several sectors, including agriculture. Furthermore, India's tea bushes are old: nearly 40% of existing bushes are over 50 years old, compared with Kenya, where fewer than 30% are over 40 years old, and Vietnam, where the entire tea plantation is less than 20 years old. Replanting has progressed slowly and rising input costs have eroded profits, implying that in the long term India may struggle to increase growth as significantly as other major producers. We forecast average growth in tea production of 1.6% per year in 2018-19.
High costs will prevent a significant recovery in Sri Lanka's 2018-19 output
We estimate a double-digit decline in tea output in Sri Lanka in 2017, reflecting torrential rain that caused landslides and the worst flooding in over a decade. Many of the 400,000 farmers, who account for 70% of national tea output, saw their bushes submerged by muddy water. Sri Lanka's tea production is forecast to rise in 2018, by 5.8%, but this will largely reflect a cyclical recovery after several disappointing years. As in India, there are several structural hurdles that will hamper growth, assuming that weather conditions improve. Despite some replanting as a result of a 20% increase in subsidies to small tea farmers, the replanting rate is not sufficiently high to lead to a significant and sustained increase in output. Local reports also show that fertiliser use has been low, and the risk of industrial unrest persists. Sharp wage rises and low mechanisation mean that production costs in Sri Lanka are some of the highest among the world's main tea producers. These factors explain why our production growth forecast in 2019, of 1.8%, is relatively weak.
A partial recovery in output is likely in Kenya in 2018-19
After a massive jump in tea production in Kenya in 2016, with output hitting an all-time high of 473,000 tonnes, weather conditions deteriorated sharply in the first three quarters of 2017, with a renewed and persistent dry spell damaging tea plantations. However, despite forecasts of further bad weather in the fourth quarter of the year, with heavy rains and flooding feared to hit tea production and deepen the already sharp decline in output, weather conditions ended up being much more favourable than had been projected in the latter months of the year. This led to a significant increase in tea production in October and November, with output about 50% higher than had been recorded mid-year. On a year-to-date basis this reduced the fall in tea production to 8.3% in the first eleven months of the year, compared with a drop of over 35% earlier in the year. We have adjusted our full-year estimate to a contraction of 11.2%, compared with about 30% previously.
Tea output will rise gradually in 2018-19, by an annual average of 3.3%. Periodic industrial action in the sector over pay disputes, combined with a change in the tea levy on farmers, so that it is based on the value rather than the volume of sales, will undermine profitability and prevent more rapid output growth. Although the government has pledged to support small farmers and reduce the tax burden, conflicting interests and a lack of funds will hinder progress.

Investment will have an impact beyond our forecast period
Many countries have been investing to stimulate tea production, including large producers such as India (which is raising subsidies for plantation rejuvenation), Kenya (where processing plants are being expanded and production is being diversified to non-black varieties) and China (which is concentrating on raising black tea output for export), and even a minor producer, Ethiopia (where Saudi investment is seeking to expand tea production). Smaller producers, such as Tanzania, Uganda, Rwanda and Bangladesh, have also seen renewed investment. However, we assume that some of these investment plans will be scaled back or suspended altogether, while others will progress only slowly, reflecting overambitious investment plans, bureaucratic hurdles and broader concerns about long-term global oversupply. In addition, it takes three to five years for a tea bush to become commercially productive, so the impact on output of recent price falls will be evident only after the forecast period.
Stocks and prices
We estimate a fourth consecutive year of market deficits in 2017, reflecting increasing consumption and a contraction in output from several of the main tea-producing countries. We expect consumption growth to outstrip production growth during 2018-19, meaning that we forecast deepening market deficits in those years.
Given that there is no global measure of total tea stocks, it is impossible to gauge how significantly these widening market deficits will affect stock levels. The fact that prices fell during 2015-16 despite market deficits in both years indicates that stock movements have only a limited effect on prices, not least because much of the increase in consumption and production is the result of consumption and output in China, which mainly consists of green tea. Although some of the production data are broken down into green and black tea, the consumption data are not, which prevents a calculation of the market balance in relation to black tea.

Only a fraction of the increase in production will be exported, and even this will not be in any of the three markets (Colombo, Kolkata and Mombasa) where our average tea price is measured. Prices in these markets respond to demand and supply dynamics in Sri Lanka, India and Kenya, respectively (essentially, black tea). Often prices diverge between these three markets on the back of local developments that have an impact on supply and demand in the respective auction or to reflect the quality of tea offered at each auction. As an example, prices at the Colombo and Mombasa auctions rose sharply in 2017, by 25% and 22% respectively as production fell, while prices at the Kolkata auction rose by a much more muted 2% year on year. Although some of the auction houses are becoming digitised, we do not believe that the tea market will attract sufficient interest from investors to make price dynamics vulnerable to broader global macroeconomic changes (there is no futures market). Prices will therefore remain volatile and largely led by local supply-and-demand factors.
Prices will retreat slightly in 2018-19
After averaging US$3.11/kg in 2017, a 17.8% year-on-year increase, recovering production is expected to reduce prices by 3.4%, to an average of US$3/kg in 2018, and by a further 6.3% in 2019, to US$2.81/kg.

Wheat
Demand
Global wheat consumption has nearly tripled since the 1960s, to more than 700m tonnes in recent years. Although stronger demand for wheat has mainly been tied to a rising global population, it should also be noted that wheat demand growth has persistently outpaced population growth. Wheat's popularity in diets has been sustained, as has its use as an animal feed ingredient. A small proportion is also used for brewing and for the manufacture of starch and ethanol. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global consumption to rise marginally, by 0.9%, to 741m tonnes in 2017/18. Although wheat use for food is expected to increase in line with the recent trend, it appears likely that world feed consumption will decline, owing partly to competition from alternative products. A similar pattern is expected in 2018/19. Although use for feed is expected to slip back further, a rise for milling and food use should see total demand increase by 0.3%, to 743m tonnes.
Rising food use is being driven by emerging and developing markets
Annual growth in global food-wheat consumption has remained relatively consistent over the past decade, with increases averaging 1.4% a year. Urbanisation, together with shifts in diets and incomes, has also resulted in greater consumption of wheat-based convenience foods such as noodles, as well as Western-style bakery products, which are best produced using high-quality wheat and flour. With much of the growth in demand stemming from countries outside the main wheat-producing belts, rising demand for milling wheat and flour has been accompanied by an increase in imports in most years. We expect world food use to rise by 1.5% in 2017/18, exceeding 500m tonnes for the first time. Growth will be driven mostly by India, Indonesia and Sub-Saharan Africa. These trends are well established and are expected to continue into 2018/19, when food consumption could rise to 511m tonnes.
World livestock feed use to fall in 2017/18
Wheat is the world's second most important grain for use in animal feed, although it is typically equivalent to one-quarter of feed-use of maize, with annual wheat use roughly matching that of barley, sorghum, oats and rye combined. Assuming strong competition from maize-especially in the EU, China, and the US-we expect use for livestock feed to fall back by 3.7% year on year in 2017/18, to around 144m tonnes and remain at similar levels in 2018/19. The drop stems mainly from a projected small decline in Russia, where a smaller crop is likely to limit discretionary on-farm feeding. Feed use in Canada is also forecast to be sharply lower than in 2016/17, dropping by about half, to 3m tonnes, on much smaller feed grade supplies.
Russia's feed industry has expanded quickly
Spurred by a series of government support measures aimed at boosting domestic meat production, Russia's feed sector has undergone massive changes over the past decade. With particularly sharp expansion in the poultry and pork sectors, overall feed use is estimated to have increased by as much as 10% per year over the decade, with growth now reported to be stabilising. The trend is likely to continue given that the country is now targeting its own meat export programme in the medium term. Because of its reliance on domestic ingredients and large local availability, grains account for a relatively high proportion of feed, seen by some industry watchers at as much as 70%. While wheat is the most important feedgrain in Russia, large amounts of barley, maize and oats are also used in compound feed rations and for on-farm feeding. Total wheat consumption is forecast at 45m tonnes in 2017/18, with 21m tonnes expected to be used for feed, 4m tonnes more than the previous year. For the following year, total use is predicted to drop back to around 42m tonnes, as a smaller local crop will limit discretionary on-farm feeding and, consequently, feed consumption.
Consumption is rising quickly in Sub-Saharan Africa
Wheat demand in Sub-Saharan Africa has increased relatively quickly in recent years, owing to rapid population growth. Wheat-based foods have gained in popularity over traditional staples such as maize porridges, cassava and millet. Higher incomes, migration to cities and more women participating in the workforce have contributed to greater demand for convenience-and often wheat-based-foods. With climatic conditions in most countries unsuitable for producing wheat except for a select few, demand is mainly being met by imports, which are now well in excess of 20m tonnes per year. Regional consumption is estimated at around 29m tonnes in 2017/18, up by around 500,000 tonnes from 2016/17. Almost all wheat is consumed for food purposes, with less than 2% of total demand channeled into feed sectors. South Africa, Nigeria, Ethiopia, Sudan and Kenya are the five-largest consumers of wheat in the region, accounting for around 65% of overall consumption. Of these countries, Nigeria is by far the least self-sufficient, importing virtually all of its domestic needs, forecast to be around 4.7m tonnes in 2017/18. Wheat demand in Africa will eventually begin to slow in response to an anticipated moderation in population growth and the inclusion of more animal proteins in diet, but such changes are unlikely in the forecast period.

Supply
World wheat production has reached unprecedented levels in recent seasons, driven by the Black Sea region, but China, India and parts of Latin America have also contributed bigger crops. The harvested area has increased across many parts of the globe, and average yields have also risen, despite concerns about years of underinvestment in wheat seed technology. The 2017/18 crop year has seen spells of occasionally poor weather in parts of the US, Canada and Australia, but yields were better than expected earlier on in the season. Disparities between pre-harvest expectations and final results are not easily explained, but may be linked to the latest seed technology and farming methods, which seemingly better mitigate against sub-optimal cropping weather. Incorporating a series of upgrades, including for Russia, where production and yields superseded all previous records, we have raised our global crop forecast for 2017/18 by 7m tonnes, to 758m tonnes, a new all-time high and the fifth successive annual rise. With prices at relatively low levels, there is unlikely to be much incentive for farmers to increase 2018/19 plantings. Crop rotation needs will again be important, but in countries where there are few alternatives, seeded area is unlikely to show much year-on-year change. Assuming average yields, the world crop is forecast to contract by 1.4% in 2018/19, to 747m tonnes.
After a small EU crop last year, output should rise in 2017/18
Despite a mixed year for the main EU wheat growers, the 2017/18 crop is expected to be slightly larger than average, at 152m tonnes. Yields have rebounded strongly in France-which accounts for around one-quarter of the bloc's total output-following the previous season's sub-par results. Survey results also confirm its good quality, with a much higher percentage than last year meeting milling specifications. In contrast, a wet finish to the German harvest has led to a series of quality downgrades in key northern export-producing areas. Spain's wheat crop was also negatively affected by a punishing drought, which lasted for virtually the entire year. Producers are now wrapping up 2018/19 winter wheat planting. Low prices, forecast to be below production costs in some countries, are expected to be a general disincentive. However, with earlier wet conditions preventing some producers from switching wheat area to rapeseed as intended, there is unlikely to be much overall change in plantings for next year's harvest. Assuming normal yields, output is likely to be in line with the average, at around 150m tonnes.
Russian production outperforms market expectations in 2017/18
Preliminary 2017/18 production data from Russia's statistical agency were higher than market expectations and above those released by the Ministry of Agriculture during the harvest campaign, with all wheat output officially pegged at 84.9m tonnes, 12m tonnes more than last season's huge crop and 50% more than the previous five-year average. Winter and spring wheat crops enjoyed near-perfect growing conditions, benefitting from timely and abundant rains. The massive crop has kept exporters extremely busy in recent months, pushing the country's infrastructure to the limit. With unusually warm weather allowing port operations to continue over the normally frigid winter months, shipments have continued at a record pace and are now on track to reach 35m tonnes in the period ending June 2018.
Sowing of the 2018/19 winter wheat crop was hindered by spells of unfavourable weather, including dryness in key southern regions, where up to 50% of the sowings were completed outside of the optimal planting window. Total winter grains area (mainly wheat) failed to meet the official estimate, dropping by around 1% year on year. Moreover, unseasonable warmth has kept protective snowcover to a minimum so far this winter with some plants still growing. These crops could be especially vulnerable to yield loss should freezing temperatures emerge in the coming weeks and months. With better productivity from the last harvest lifting the trend yield higher, we have raised our production forecast slightly from our previous report, to 74m tonnes, down by 13% year on year but still potentially 12% above average.
US wheat production fell sharply in 2017/18
US wheat production in 2017/18 is forecast at 47.4m tonnes, down by 25% year on year, and at a 15-year low. The sharp drop in output mainly reflects a drop in plantings, with the smallest harvested area in almost 130 years. Depressed prices and limited potential for profits mean that another fall in winter and spring plantings is likely in 2018/19. Because of limited precipitation across much of the southern plains during December, Hard Red Wheat (HRW) crop ratings worsened in December, with scouts in Kansas and Oklahoma reporting the worst year-end conditions in five years. Because of limited insulating snowcover, the onset of extreme cold temperatures affecting almost the whole country during the initial weeks of January 2018 is likely to have resulted in at least some winterkill damage. As is always the case, the extent of any damage will be impossible to gauge until crops emerge in the spring. For now, production projections are held unchanged, but with some downside risk. Assuming reduced abandonment and better overall yields, mainly for spring-sown wheat, 2018/19 production is forecast to rise by 4.9%, to 49.7m tonnes.
Harvest results in Canada were much better than originally expected
According to the final crop update from Statistics Canada, 2017/18 all wheat production totalled 30m tonnes, a 5% drop from the previous season but 2.8m tonnes more than the agency predicted in October. The total included 22.2m tonnes of spring wheat, up 8% year on year, with gains tied to a rise in both area and yields, which increased despite spells of very hot and dry weather in southern parts of the Prairies. The drop in overall output was instead attributed to a smaller winter crop and in particular, a decline in durum, production of which slumped by 36%, to just 5m tonnes. Looking ahead to the next year, farmers have reported a second successive drop in winter wheat plantings, seen at a 13-year low. However, with spring sown varieties accounting for around 90% of output, the 2018/19 outlook is still far from certain. Comparatively firm prices versus canola and reduced competition from pulses could see spring wheat area staying high, with production projected at around 30m tonnes, unchanged versus the previous year.
China's wheat support policies to realign with international prices
Latest official data from China confirmed a small rise in 2017/18 wheat production, as an improvement in yields more than compensated for a minor reduction in harvested area. After focusing first on efforts to realign cotton, maize, rapeseed and soybean markets with international prices, authorities are now beginning to tweak foodgrain price support policies too. Following changes to rice subsidy programmes last year, the government recently announced a 2.5% reduction in the 2018/19 minimum state purchase price for wheat, the first cut since its start. With winter wheat planting for next year's crop already mostly finished, the policy shift is unlikely to have much of an impact for 2018/19. Sowings are expected to stay relatively high, with production tentatively placed at 129m tonnes.
Early challenges for Indian wheat farmers due to poor air conditions
India's government recently raised the minimum support price (MSP) for the 2018/19 wheat crop by around 7%, a slightly sharper rise than in previous years. As part of wider efforts to support farmers and curb cheap imports (mainly from the Black Sea region), authorities confirmed that the wheat import duty would be doubled to 20%. Although both initiatives were expected to support planting decisions this season, sowings have consistently lagged behind the year-earlier rate and the recent trend. In early January sowings were down by 5% year on year. The delayed sowings is partly because of air pollution. With authorities cracking down harder on farmers flouting the ban on stubble burning, there were delays in removing crop residues from paddy fields earlier on in the season. Faced with few alternative means of disposal, however, many growers continued to burn rice straw, contributing to the air pollution. The smog and accompanying lack of sunlight has added to fieldwork delays in some states, where late planting adds to the risk of potentially lower yields. A shift in acreage from wheat to pulses is also being reported in Madhya Pradesh, the country's second-largest wheat producing state, where the state government is buying chickpeas at guaranteed minimum pricing this year. Climatic conditions have been broadly favourable so far, including normal temperatures and beneficial showers. Importantly, there has also been a notable absence of the yellow rust fungal disease. Based on a downgraded area estimate, we have trimmed our production forecast for 2018/19 by 1m tonnes, to 96.5m tonnes, potentially a larger than average crop.

A much smaller crop is expected in Australia for 2017/18
It has been a challenging year for Australia's wheat farmers, with production set to fall far short of the previous season's record-breaking results. Conditions have been especially poor in parts of northern New South Wales and southern Queensland, where low rainfall and warmer than average temperatures prevailed during much of the spring and summer. In contrast, timely springtime rains revived prospects in Western Australia, resulting in successive upgrades to crop estimates in recent months. The harvest was much better than expected in that state, but protein content is said to be a little lower than normal due to reduced fertiliser use. Despite some occasional disruptions due to rains, harvesting across the country was almost finished by the first week of January, in line with schedule. With encouraging results from the key western growing areas, we have raised our production forecast by 1m tonnes to 21.5m tonnes. With supplies boosted by large carryover stocks, next year's exportable surplus is expected to be large, enough for shipments of at least 17.5m tonnes (22.5m tonnes last year). For the following year, a return to normal yields should sustain a larger crop, currently expected at 25m tonnes.
Stocks and prices
Cumulative world stocks are forecast to rise for the fifth consecutive season in 2017/18 to 257m tonnes, up by 7% year on year to an all-time high. However, this aggregate masks some important features, as gains in world inventories are mostly attributed to end-season stock rises in India and China, whose stocks are not available to the world market. Indeed, with China's stocks having doubled over a five-year period, many observers have argued that China should be excluded from global stock calculations. Other organisations suggest that it is perhaps more useful to use carryovers in the eight largest exporters as a proxy for global supplies. Cumulative stockpiles in those countries are forecast to drop by around 2% year on year, to 74.7m tonnes, but will still be up by 18% from the average in recent years. The projection for 2018/19 is provisional, but suggests a continuation of the most recent trend. World stocks are likely to remain high, perhaps even in excess of 2017/18 levels. Exporter stocks of 63.4m tonnes, although not considered tight, would be the smallest in five years.
Russia's wheat stocks have tripled in just three years
Although Russia's exports have been running at a record pace in recent months, infrastructure capacity constraints mean that July-June shipments could be limited to around 35m tonnes, nowhere near enough to prevent a further build-up in 2017/18 stocks. Works to upgrade existing terminals are ongoing, and although new port facilities are also being planned for construction, including in eastern parts of the country, close to China, these projects are expected to take three or more years to complete. Therefore, following two successive massive crops, wheat stocks are expected to reach a record high at the end of 2017/18, potentially reaching 18.5m tonnes, up from just 5.6m tonnes two seasons ago. High stock levels are expected to keep a lid on prices heading into the next season and, even if 2018/19 production falls short of recent levels, the additional supplies should provide a cushion, allowing Russia to maintain its dominant position on the world export market.

Ample Russian supplies will cap potential price rises
World wheat prices have risen since bottoming out at the end of November. Net gains of about 3% during the past six weeks have been tied mainly to advances in high quality milling wheat values, supplies of which remain in comparatively shorter supply. Stronger fob Gulf export premiums also reflected better overseas buying interest for some HRW wheat grades. Some strength in US futures was also evident in the first week of January, as speculative funds scrambled to cover a very large net short position amid widespread talk of possible winterkill damage across parts of the southern and eastern wheat belt. Amid overall heavy world availabilities and strong competition for available export business, wheat prices are expected to show only limited upside potential over the next few years, especially if Russian shipments stay high. However, with prices proving more resilient in recent months than previously expected, we have raised our price projections (HRW, 12% protein, fob Gulf) through to the first quarter of 2020 by around USUS$10/tonne. However, this remains well down from the lofty levels seen a few seasons ago. Higher protein supplies are expected to command a hefty price premium, at least until the 2018/19 northern hemisphere crops enter the pipeline.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Although the regime of the president, Nicolás Maduro, will strengthen its grip on power in the wake of the installation of a Constituent Assembly in 2017 and rigged presidential elections this coming April, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect Mr Maduro to remain in power beyond 2019. The most likely scenarios for a transition to an opposition-led government are through ad hoc elections after economic collapse or a military coup. There is a risk that the regime will cling to power beyond 2019 if it finds financing to meet its debt obligations or boosts dwindling oil production.
We estimate that inflation exceeded 2,000% at the end of 2017 and will average over 10,000% in 2018. GDP will continue to contract into 2019. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. We forecast a recovery beginning in 2020, by which time the current opposition is expected to be in government, leading to macro-economic adjustments, and institutional and structural reforms.
Sweeping reforms are required to restore confidence in contract and property rights, and thereby promote a recovery in investment. The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will encourage private investment, re-establish market mechanisms for price stability and attempt to undo the constraints imposed by the government on private firms.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and quadruple-digit inflation will hit private consumption, and an increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate the fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices, and the economy will not return to growth until 2021-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
US dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, GDP contraction and extremely high inflation (driven by shortages of foreign exchange and basic goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. After 2020, under a new government, we expect purchasing power and the business environment to improve.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela is in 80th position globally in our business environment rankings for 2018-22, out of 82 countries covered, making the country one of the least attractive investment locations in the world. This reflects state interventionism, highly heterodox macroeconomic policies, a lack of legal security and weak institutions. Regionally, Venezuela remains last of the 12 countries covered, notwithstanding our assumption of improvements after 2019.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Nationalisation poses a diminished threat, given fiscal weaknesses. Property rights remain weak. Price fixing undermines profitability.
2020-22: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists. A new government in 2019 brings new policies.
2020-22: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain fairly low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2018-19: Unorthodox exchange-rate policy framework adds to uncertainty. The state continues to exercise tight control over access to official-rate US dollars. New government in 2019 removes exchange controls.
2020-22: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2018-19: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2020-22: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2018-19: Credit growth remains firm, but sectoral allocation is distorted by administrative interventions. Banks remain highly profitable, although unpredictable enforcement and a weak regulatory framework heighten instability.
2020-22: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2018-19: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2020-22: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Access to water and electricity supplies remains precarious. Underinvestment in power transmission ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2020-22: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued electricity rationing.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Chávez was diagnosed with cancer in 2011 but, after declaring in July 2012 that he had fully recovered, won a fourth presidential term in October 2012. However, his health quickly deteriorated and he died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has since plummeted.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is a federal republic, successive administrations have proven reluctant to devolve political authority, with the transfer of financial resources from federal to local level highly dependent on the central government. The legislature is unicameral, and elections for the National Assembly take place every five years. In December 2015 the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the legislature. In August 2017 the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) installed a Constituent Assembly with powers over all branches of government and a remit to rewrite the 1999 Constitution-apparently a ploy to entrench the PSUV in power.
Policy issues: Political radicalisation has been reflected in increasingly heterodox economic policymaking, with massive fiscal and monetary stimulus and the nationalisation of industries deemed strategically important. Distortions created by this approach have become evident, with inflation rising sharply in spite of price controls, and capital controls spawning a rampant black market for foreign exchange. Failure to invest part of the oil windfall has led to a startling decline in physical infrastructure. Non-oil production has ground to a halt, leaving the economy entirely dependent on the energy sector. With large oil shipments going to China to repay loans, and (on subsidised terms) to regional neighbours via the PetroCaribe oil-financing scheme (although this is winding down), the country is running short of US dollars, forcing cuts in import spending.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 60% for oil firms. Since 2011 a maximum royalty of 95% has applied to oil extraction. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Official data are unavailable, but we estimate that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$11bn in 2016 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages, narrowing the current-account deficit to 0.7% of GDP.
