Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Even as Venezuela's severe economic woes deepen amid an intensifying debt crisis and hyperinflation, the governing Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has strengthened its hold on power as the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) has slid into disarray. The government, led by the president, Nicolás Maduro, has unilaterally set presidential elections for April 22nd. As in the past, the PSUV has used fraudulent administrative obstacles to ban the majority of opposition parties, including the MUD itself. We expect further chicanery to ensure that Mr Maduro will be re-elected. The Economist Intelligence Unit then expects worsening economic conditions to result in a chaotic political transition process, most likely ushering the MUD into power in 2019.
In August, following a fraudulent referendum amid widescale protests across the country, the MUD-controlled National Assembly was superseded by the PSUV-only Constituent Assembly (ANC). The PSUV also holds almost all municipalities in the country and 20 of 24 governorships, following elections late last year that were neither free nor fair. The PSUV's tight control of the justice and electoral systems means that at present the MUD has no real chance of gaining power democratically. On top of this, the MUD's propensity for infighting has been compounded by the PSUV's own tactic of generating divergent interests by rewarding co-operation from some factions while penalising others. Furthermore, MUD's support base has become increasingly demoralised and demobilised. Although hard data is unavailable, the increasingly large Venezuelan diaspora may well be mostly composed of anti-PSUV sympathisers.
The PSUV's future currently depends on the support of three key backers: the state's coercive apparatus (the security forces and military); a sizeable sector of the population dependent on government handouts; and the so-called colectivos, activist groups that are a cross between community organisers and PSUV paramilitaries. The key backer is the military, which controls most of the ministries related to management of the economy and security. This includes-since November-the Ministry of Oil and PDVSA, the state-owned oil company. The government plies these groups with resources, with the vast majority coming from PDVSA. We believe that a prolonged interruption in exports by PDVSA would destabilise this patronage system.
There are three main paths towards a destabilising interruption in PDVSA exports. The most immediate path is legal action in the US, as permitted in the contracts of external bonds on which PDVSA and the government have fallen into arrears. Concerted, widespread legal action resulting in seizures of PDVSA's assets (such as those of Citgo, a PDVSA-owned, US-based refinery) could curtail exports dramatically. Secondly, a similar interruption of exports would take place if the US imposes a ban on Venezuelan oil exports, a threat that the US government has often made. We believe that replacing US demand with other sources would be logistically impossible for the government in the short term.
Our third path relates to PDVSA's falling output. This works independently of the first two scenarios and, unlike them, means a permanent reduction of export earnings. Oil output has fallen by over 20% since Mr Maduro took office, and we expect production to continue dropping, dragging with it PDVSA's US dollar earnings. Politically motivated investment from Russia and China, once abundant, seems unlikely to return in enough volume to prop up production.
Although we expect further concessions to the military in 2018, declining oil output will put the government's patronage system at risk by late 2018 or early 2019. In the current context of political polarisation, our baseline scenario has the military pushing out the PSUV while paving the way for elections, leading to a democratically elected opposition government in office in 2019. However, there is a risk that free and fair elections would be significantly delayed, given that the military's democratic values have eroded following years of co-operation with the PSUV.
Regardless of how and when political transition occurs, the second half of our forecast period is likely to remain volatile and uncertain. In addition to having to contend with holdovers in the colectivos and in the military, the opposition will have to confront huge economic distortions and deep political differences that would test even a unified political party.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The government has decreed that a presidential election will take place on April 22nd. The regime has barred most opposition parties, including the MUD itself. Given the tight electoral schedule-candidacies must be decided by February 27th-the opposition may not come to an agreement on a unified candidate. The risk of a partial or complete boycott by the opposition has grown. Regardless, we expect the elections to go ahead and for Mr Maduro to be victorious in elections riddled with irregularities. We do expect relatively free and fair elections following the PSUV's exit from power.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Venezuela has come under increasing regional and international pressure. Mercosur (a regional bloc comprised of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) and the so-called Lima Group (a group of 12 Latin American nations) have denounced the regime. Internationally the EU and the US have applied sanctions. US sanctions remain the most relevant, as they have made it nearly impossible for PDVSA and the government to renegotiate their debts. In addition, the US has often (most recently in early February) threatened sanctions on the oil trade. As Venezuela gets the vast majority of its hard currency earnings from exports to the US (in addition to importing production inputs) the embargo would have a destabilising effect on the government's patronage system, and could potentially prove a trigger to regime change. So far, the US has been reticent to enact oil sanctions, perhaps mindful of the socio-economic costs to American workers and consumers.
A key priority for the Maduro administration will be the maintenance of good relations with Russia. The latter continues to provide limited financial backing, but it seems increasingly unlikely to provide the several billions of dollars needed each year not just to avoid default but also to stem the decline of oil output. China, a previous major source of financing, has seemingly with-drawn; there is no public evidence of any new Chinese financing since 2015.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The government's immediate economic policy concern will be fending off debt default and associated legal challenges. The government has gone into arrears on some sovereign and state-owned firms' bonds (including PDVSA bonds), while also reportedly making late payments on others. The government has restated its commitment to pay while blaming payments delays on US sanctions and the payment system. Mr Maduro has called for a debt restructuring, but this appears impossible. This is owing to logistical challenges imposed by US sanctions and, more fundamentally, because the government lacks an economic programme that would be acceptable to creditors.
There is no sign yet of lawsuits by bondholders, who so far appear to prefer late payment to lengthy legal battles. Eventually, this stance is likely to change. To avoid PDVSA asset seizures, the government may choose to openly default on sovereign bonds but adhere to PDVSA's repayment schedule. So far it has done neither. If it did openly default, sovereign creditors would undoubtedly ask US courts to define PDVSA as an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government in order to seize its assets. However, such claims will take time, meaning that the timing of likely seizures is unclear. When they do happen, the consequences on the economy will be devastating. We assume that they would trigger a transition of power and, eventually, a change of economic policy direction.
In the meantime, the government must also grapple with a build-up of huge inflationary and currency depreciation pressures. In line with our expectations, the government undertook a maxi-devaluation in February 2018, but even at current rates the currency remains overvalued and foreign exchange remains rationed, with the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) claiming "difficulties" in settling trades. Economic policy will remain unstainable. Monetisation of large public deficits will continue and ad hoc policy intervention and heavy state control of the economy will persist. Amid subdued oil prices, import compression will remain necessary, as other sources of foreign exchange will be hard to find.
Under our baseline scenario we expect the opposition to come to power in 2019. An adjustment package, including a re-structuring of debt, would follow. We have factored in a financing agreement with the IMF to support the process, forecasting lending of US$19bn in 2019-22. We also expect significant financial and real investment inflows, the vast majority going into the oil sector.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
The authorities' failure to publish data on the non-financial public-sector (NFPS) accounts since 2012 demonstrates the opacity of the public finances and complicates accurate forecasting of the size of the deficit. We estimate a NFPS deficit of 19.3% of GDP for 2017 and expect the deficit to remain in double digits in 2018. A transition to a new government should help to ease the deficit to 4.5% of GDP by 2022. The large deficits of the present are mostly being financed by printing money. High inflation and an overvalued currency are eroding the relative value of domestic and external debt, making debt/GDP ratios unreliable indicators of fiscal stability. There is considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing, mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China. As these items are excluded from the public debt statistics, the true size of total public liabilities is understated. Under our baseline forecast of severe economic stress that would see the opposition taking power in 2019, we expect a restructuring process with external creditors to happen.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
Monetary policy under the BCV will continue to be driven by the government's desire to keep real interest rates negative and to print money to finance large fiscal deficits; money supply (M2) rose by 1,311% year on year in January. In the context of hyperinflation, we expect real rates to remain deeply negative until 2019. After that, our forecast of substantial currency and fiscal adjustment under a new government will see real interest rates turn positive.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Amid ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending, we project further contractions in real GDP in 2018-20, following an estimated contraction of 13.6% in 2017. Our forecast for a recovery in 2021-22 rests on an assumption of a political transition that, supported by IMF financial and institutional assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme, including management of the country's oil wealth. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, given the scale of the recession, and our forecasts therefore imply only a partial rebound, after a real GDP decline of over 50% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2018, reflecting the effect on real wages of soaring inflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will continue to contract as well, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange, and remitting profits. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition, progress on long­delayed joint projects with Chinese firms in energy and-later in the forecast period-a pick-up in public-sector investment. Oil output will continue to shrink throughout 2018-19, reflecting a combination of severe mismanage-ment, underinvestment and depletion of oil fields. We expect output to bottom out at 1.35m barrels/day (b/d) in 2019, down from 1.95m b/d in 2017. Under our baseline forecasts, oil production will pick up in 2020, reflecting renewed investment under a new government and a removal of constraints to domestic production. Exports, however, will only recover in 2021, as domestic demand has been artificially constrained. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply. Dependence on oil will persist in 2018-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
A decimation of domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. The govern-ment continues to decree maximum prices and fines as its main policy tool to fight inflation, with closures of supermarket a common occurrence. We do not expect a policy reversal under the PSUV government, meaning that inflation will remain extremely high in the short term. Official data has not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly has estimated that monthly inflation was 84% in January, bringing year-on-year inflation to over 4,000%. We now expect inflation to average over 10,000% in 2018. Shortages of basic goods will continue, as the lack of foreign currency limits imports. There is a high risk of a hyperinflationary spiral in coming months that increases inflation to well above our current forecast and necessitates a dramatic adjustment, probably involving a resort to currency substitution.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
Despite the recent announcement of exchange-rate unification and maxi-devaluation, the currency remains overvalued and further currency adjustment will be necessary. Rationing of foreign currency will continue in the short term.
In late January the BCV announced that the Dicom exchange rate would be used by both the private and public sectors and in late February announced a massive devaluation to BsF24,898:US$1 (the previous Dicom rate was BsF3,445:US$1). The new Dicom system remains opaque and provides no guarantee that the government-which monopolises the country's export business-will provide foreign exchange, making the auction system unsustainable. Indeed, the BCV has already announced difficulties in settling trades at the new rate. This, coupled with runaway growth in the money supply, will continue to put pressure on the exchange rate. The black-market foreign-exchange rate was at around BsF230,000:US$1 in early February.
Given the existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market and growing hyperinflation, the government may introduce a new domestic currency or attempt some kind of currency substitution in the future. In our baseline scenario of a MUD-led government in 2019, similar measures may be undertaken. The exact nature and implementation of the plan is hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Following higher-than-expected import compression in 2017, we have revised our current-account forecast for 2018, and we now expect a surplus of US$3.3bn (0.7% of GDP at the distorted exchange rate, which overstates the GDP in dollar terms). Even though we assume that extreme compression of imports will continue (we estimate imports in 2017 were a fifth of those of 2012), Venezuela's lack of access to foreign finance means that the current-account surplus will not be enough to meet the country's financing needs. Indeed, excluding arrears, we calculate that principal repayments of sovereign and state companies' bonded debt alone amount to US$4.2bn. As such, we expect further arrears in 2018 and 2019. By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following a debt renegotiation-external financing will be restored and that imports will begin a recovery. We foresee the current account to go into a deficit of 4.5% of GDP in 2020 at the no-longer highly distorted exchange rate. Recovering oil production and the re-structured interest payment schedule will see the current-account deficit narrow to 1.1% of GDP in 2022.
With the opposition in power, financial and investment inflows will provide sufficient financing and help to rebuild reserves coverage. This will buttress the stability of the external accounts and facilitate the gradual removal of foreign-exchange controls, narrowing the gap between official and parallel exchange rates. There are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. It hinges on a substantial assistance package from the IMF, the quick implementation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt renegotiation process within 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-22, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe

External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
An early election in October 2017 was won by the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP), led by the young minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, who has since become chancellor at the head of a coalition government of the ÖVP and the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ).
The inclusion of the FPÖ in the government will not lead to significant tensions with other EU member states, as it did in 2000, when the party was last part of a coalition. This is largely because of the normalisation of the far right in Europe since then.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the new government to focus on integration and immigration policy, and to attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and introduce some additional flexibility in labour and product markets. However, low government cohesion is likely to lead to limited progress.
We forecast that the government budget will remain in deficit, albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP, throughout the forecast period (2018-22), as the fiscal consolidation process is likely to be restrained by limited government cohesion and effectiveness. The public debt/GDP ratio will fall gradually, to just below 70% by 2022, from an estimated 79.8% in 2017.
After several years of underperformance compared with its regional peers, the economy has performed relatively strongly since the start of 2016, growing by 3.1% in 2017. We forecast a continuation of strong growth this year, at 2.5%, and for growth to moderate to 1.7% on average in 2019-22.
Consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) will continue to exceed the euro zone average in 2018-22, driven by structural domestic factors including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets. Annual inflation averaged 0.9% in 2015-16 and 2.2% in 2017. We expect annual average EU harmonised inflation of 2% in 2018-22.
The current-account surplus has been relatively stable in recent years, at about 2%. Although we expect small changes in the composition of the surplus, we expect it to remain stable in the forecast period, at 2.2% of GDP on average in 2018-22, driven mainly by a strong surplus on the services balance, supported by tourism inflows.

Country forecast overview: Business environment rankings

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Austria's business environment score improves only marginally between the historical period (2013-17) and the forecast period (2018-22). As a result, the country drops one place in the regional ranking, to 11th, and two places in the global ranking, to 18th. Austria's strengths as a business location include good infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited.
2020-22: Modest strengthening of competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2020-22: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal.
2020-22: EU maintains focus on bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate. No progress on EU-US trade deal. Free-trade agreement between EU and UK.
Taxes
2018-19: Limited changes to the tax system aimed at reducing the sizeable income tax wedge.
2020-22: Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform, and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2018-19: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe.
2020-22: Further uptake in corporate bond issuance. Credit conditions continue to ease as banks' profitability recovers, in part supported by a gradual uptick in interest rates.
The labour market
2018-19: Economy-wide minimum wage introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment continues to fall.
2020-22: Continued modest expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2020-22: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure.

Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election was held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government will focus on migration and integration issues, including in the EU context. It will also attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and implement other measures to improve the business environment, including through enabling more flexibility in the labour market.
Taxation: Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is among the highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: In 2016 the value of exported goods was US$142.7bn and the goods import bill was US$142.3bn. The services surplus, traditionally boosted by tourism receipts, was US$12.2bn. Along with a modest primary income deficit and significant secondary income deficit, this yielded a current-account surplus equivalent to 2.1% of GDP.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
In May 2017, after several years of little progress on reforms and coalition, as well as party in-fighting, the grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart following the resignation of Reinhold Mitterlehner from the positions of vice-chancellor, minister of economy and leader of the ÖVP, citing frustration within his party. The popular 31-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, took over the leadership of the ÖVP and reformed the party around himself. As a result, he led the ÖVP to a plurality of the vote in the early election on October 15th, winning a 31.5% share-up by 7.5 percentage points on its result in 2013. The SPÖ's vote share was unchanged, at 26.9%. The far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) increased its vote by 5.5 percentage points, to 26%. The liberal NEOS returned to parliament with just over 5% of the vote, and the Greens failed to cross the 4% electoral threshold for the first time in 31 years, in part because List Pilz, led by a former leader of the Greens, narrowly managed to cross it.
The ÖVP and the FPÖ formed a coalition in mid-December after just over a month and a half of negotiations. Under Mr Kurz the ÖVP has moved close to the FPÖ in many policy areas (during the campaign the leader of the FPÖ, Heinz-Christian Strache, regularly accused Mr Kurz of copying the FPÖ's programme) and the negotiations thus went relatively smoothly. In order to assuage concerns from Mr Kurz and the president, Alexander Van der Bellen, about the FPÖ's previous Euroscepticism, the party has agreed not to push for a referendum on EU membership. Moreover, EU policy will be handled by the chancellery instead of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which is headed by an FPÖ appointee.
Although the chancellor is from the ÖVP, the election should still be seen as a further step in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the ÖVP has, to a large extent, been replaced by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties had together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, and a renewed grand coalition had become almost impossible following the breakdown of relations between the two parties and the gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited both from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz owes much of his popularity to his strong stance on this issue and his plans to curtail migration into Europe and Austria.
Despite the overlap between the ÖVP's and the FPÖ's programmes, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to struggle to implement its policies, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters. In addition, the FPÖ could struggle to translate its opposition stance on matters such as immigration and integration into concrete policy proposals, owing in part to internal party upheaval. As a result, we expect limited progress on significant structural reforms. The initial phase of the government's term is likely to be relatively smooth, owing in part to the country's role as president of the Council of the European Union in the second half of 2018. Later in the term the FPÖ might struggle to distinguish itself from the ÖVP, which could lead to tensions between the parties. The risk of an early election is high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The last general election was held on October 15th 2017. Unless the government falls before then, it will sit in the new Nationalrat (the lower house of parliament) until the end of its term in late 2022.
Elections for several state parliaments are planned for the first half of 2018 but give only a limited view of national political trends, as they are fought mostly on local issues. The next election for the primarily ceremonial post of federal president will be in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions, including the leading role that it played in closing the migration route through the Balkans. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this influx, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high. All three of the large parties have hinted that they want to limit labour migration within the EU, or at least give preferential treatment to Austrian citizens in the labour market, which could exacerbate tensions with many EU member states.
Nevertheless, Mr Kurz has been at pains to point out that his government will be pro-EU, and that Austria's EU membership will not be questioned in the coming years. The new government plans for Austria to be a leading voice in the EU in the coming years, especially on reform of migration, and this should be facilitated by the country's role as president of the Council of the European Union in the second half of 2018. We expect the government to find broad support for proposals such as tighter controls of the EU's outer borders and processing asylum applications outside the EU.
Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ in government following the 1999 election led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations in 2000, the reception has been more muted this time. At that time a far-right nationalist party entering government was an unusual development, but since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority governments in several EU countries, including some Nordic countries and the Netherlands.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Alongside the 2016 tax reform, which provided about EUR5bn in tax relief to households, government policy in recent years has focused on challenges facing the country's financial sector. These have included the clean-up and debt restructuring of Heta Asset Resolution, a "bad bank" that was created to deal with the toxic assets of Hypo Group Alpe Adria (HGAA). The uncertainty surrounding Heta was removed in October 2016, when creditors accepted a debt-restructuring deal.
The new govern-ment plans to move integration and immigration policy further to the right, including through curtailing benefits for asylum seekers and cutting child benefits sent abroad. It has also presented plans that focus on improving the business environment, including by reducing corporate tax rates and introducing more flexibility for working hours. However, it does not plan to reform the country's so-called Proporz system under which the ÖVP and SPÖ had apportioned public life-state companies, public services, subsidies, regulatory responsibilities-despite suggestions from both coalition parties in the past, especially from the FPÖ, that they would want to do this. We therefore expect reform momentum to be limited and for the government to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
In 2014 Austria's fiscal accounts deteriorated, mainly reflecting the govern-ment's decision to create a bad bank to deal with HGAA's toxic assets. The fiscal deficit widened to the equivalent of 2.7% of GDP, from 2% in 2013, and public debt rose to 83.7% of GDP. Mainly in response to steady direct revenue growth, the deficit narrowed to 1% of GDP in 2015, but widened again in 2016, to 1.6%, owing in part to fiscally expansionary tax reforms and higher migrant-related public spending. Strong growth contributed to an estimated narrowing of the deficit to 1.1% of GDP in 2017.
We expect the budget to remain in deficit throughout the forecast period (2018-22), albeit safely within the EU mandated limit of 3% of GDP. Despite only limited fiscal consolidation, robust economic growth will help to narrow the deficit slightly. The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from an estimated 79.8% in 2017 to just below 70% in 2022. Although the public finances will remain worse than in peers such as Germany or the Netherlands, the low interest-rate environment and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals mean that funding risks are extremely low in our view.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The European Central Bank (ECB) is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that ran at EUR60bn per month until the end of 2017, and is running at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. The economic recovery in the euro zone strengthened in 2017 and became more broad based. We expect another healthy expansion of real GDP in the euro zone in 2018, of 2.2%, after growth of 2.5% in 2017. The ECB continues to take stock of this growth momentum, but maintains a clearly dovish policy stance, with the reduction in the amount of monthly QE purchases in 2018 designed to extend its presence in the bond markets. The bank also plans to delay raising interest rates and will reinvest the principal payments from maturing securities for a period well beyond the end of the QE programme. We expect the pace of monthly QE purchases to be reduced to zero in early 2019, but owing to subdued price pressure and persistent downside risks to growth, we expect the bank will keep policy rates unchanged throughout the first half of our forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy largely stalled and underperformed in comparison with regional peers, notably Germany. This was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. A faltered reform process has contributed to higher inflation compared with regional peers and weakened productivity growth, admittedly from fairly high levels. However, the economy recently started to gain momentum again, with average quarterly growth of 0.9% between July 2016 and September 2017. Although in previous years the labour market had struggled to integrate the significant increase in the labour force, it seemed to have turned a corner in late 2016 and early 2017, owing in part to a surge in employment in the manufacturing sector, and we expect a continued gradual improvement in labour market indicators in the coming years. This is supporting private consumption, which we expect to grow by 1.9% this year. Export and investment growth have also picked up. As a result, real GDP growth was 3.1% in 2017-above growth in Germany for the first time since 2005 and Austria's fastest growth rate since 2007.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-following an under-performance even compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue next year, although we forecast slower growth, at 2.5%, as we expect the impulse from the manufacturing sector in 2017 to have largely been a one-off. In the following years we expect a moderation of growth. Domestic demand will be the main driver of growth, which is likely to converge towards potential growth in these years. We therefore expect average real GDP growth of 1.7% in 2019-22. Government policy is likely to be supportive of growth in the coming years, and the main risks are external. As a highly open economy, Austria is vulnerable to global economic developments, including any shocks to global trade.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.9% in 2015-16-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices and energy-price base effects fostered a gradual increase in inflation in 2017, leading to full-year average inflation of 2.2%. Recent strengthening of the euro will weigh slightly on inflation, but we expect it to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-22, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors seen in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
For most of 2015-16 the euro moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1, before a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. However, in 2017 the euro rallied as the region's economic recovery strengthened and as political risk waned in Europe but rose in the US. In the second half of the year a rise in expectations of QE tapering by the ECB prompted a sharp appreciation in the euro against the dollar, leading to a year-end rate of US$1.20:EUR1. The value of the euro could yet come under pressure from political risk-especially in relation to the March 2018 general election in Italy-and monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a gradual appreciation on average, to US$1.21:EUR1 by 2020-21, as the euro is supported by an ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, while the business cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values helped the trade balance to move into surplus in recent years, from a deficit in 2009-13. We expect the trade balance to gradually move into balance in the coming years as robust export growth is outweighed by higher import costs and strengthening domestic demand pushes up import volumes. However, this will be compensated for by a healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourist inflows. Modest primary income surpluses will not be enough to outweigh consistent secondary income deficits. However, the services balance will ensure that the current-account surplus remains broadly flat throughout 2018-22, at 2.2% of GDP on average.

Country Forecast Turkey February 2018 Updater

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-turkey-february-2018-updater/docview/2002581315/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: Since the failed coup in 2016 foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by Mr Erdogan's domestic political goals, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government. Under the AKP, Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019, and possibly earlier. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. According to Turkey, the Syrian Kurdish groups are affiliated with the PKK and are intent on establishing a continuous autonomous region along Syria's northern border with Turkey. The neighbouring conflicts are also likely to continue influencing the direction of Turkey's foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly regarding the conflict in Syria, where both are militarily involved but have been pursuing contrasting goals.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Despite a narrow victory and allegations of vote fraud in the presidential reform referendum on April 16th 2017, the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, is moving ahead with his plan to install a presidential system of government after the elections due in 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that Mr Erdogan and his ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) will win the elections. The presidential system will further undermine Turkey's fragile democratic institutions and governance structures. It provides few checks on the powers of the president and moves the country closer to one-man rule.
Since the failed coup in 2016 foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by Mr Erdogan's domestic political goals, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government. This has resulted in a marked deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. We expect a complete rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high.
The AKP has enjoyed 15 years of single-party rule, and for most of that period political and government effectiveness have improved. However, since 2013 economic policymaking institutions have become increasingly politicised. Despite tax increases in 2018, we expect annual deficits to widen moderately, to 2.3% of GDP on average in 2018-19. After the elections we forecast that the deficit will shrink gradually, to 1.6% of GDP in 2022. The risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances cannot be ruled out.
We expect real GDP growth to slow from an estimated 7% in 2017 to a still robust 4.1% per year on average in the forecast period (2018-22), reflecting higher taxes and the withdrawal of stimulus measures. Our growth forecast assumes that domestic political conditions will stabilise and foreign investor confidence in Turkey will hold up, maintaining foreign capital inflows.
After a fall in the nominal value of the Turkish lira of about 17% against the US dollar in 2017, we expect the pace of depreciation to slow, keeping the currency broadly stable in real terms. Constrained in its ability to raise interest rates, we expect the Central Bank of Turkey to have to resort to unorthodox and less effective tools to respond to currency weakness and high inflation.
We expect the current-account deficit to narrow moderately, from an estimated 5.5% of GDP in 2017 to an annual average of 4.7% of GDP in 2018-22. This is still sufficiently large to make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is severely constrained and investor confidence deteriorates.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2018-22, but in the global rankings the country falls by ten places, to 55th. There is consensus among policymakers on the need to maintain macroeconomic stability. However, the failed coup and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2020-22: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in a wide range of sectors, although the opening up of the energy market makes progress.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2020-22: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade and tourism following the lifting of Russian sanctions.
2020-22: The customs union with the EU could be extended, but negotiations are likely to be protracted given the deterioration in Turkish-EU relations. More free-trade agreements may come into force with the EU's trading partners.
Taxes
2018-19: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Some tax rate rises, including on company profits, have been announced for 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit.
2020-22: A broader income tax base as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2018-19: Monetary policy remains cautious, but political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey not to raise interest rates continues. Risk of the US imposing fines on several Turkish banks over alleged violations of US sanctions on Iran.
2020-22: The banking system remains stable, despite some weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2018-19: Labour market remains rigid, with relatively high costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. Wage moderation after 30% minimum wage rise in 2016. Obstacles to employing foreigners have eased.
2020-22: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Progress, albeit slow, continues on investment plans in energy, transport and communications.
2020-22: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Third Istanbul airport becomes operational. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks could persist.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West, becoming a member of the Council of Europe (1949) and NATO (1952), and signing an association agreement with the then European Community (1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup at-tempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey has a unicameral parliamentary system of government, with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Under the AKP, Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019, and possibly earlier. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions will require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing political issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015 and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted long-standing institutional weaknesses, which, with the AKP's consent until 2013, allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Further politicisation of the judiciary is likely following the coup attempt. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax has been raised from 20% to 22% in 2018. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2016 goods exports (fob) came to US$150.2bn and imports (fob) to US$191bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$40.9bn-a contraction from US$48.1bn in 2015. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade."

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Among the most important political events in the 2018-22 forecast period will be the three crucial votes in 2019: municipal elections, due to be held in March; and parliamentary and presidential elections, due in November. After these votes an executive presidential system of government will replace the current parliamentary system. The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his ruling, religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, will win the elections and remain in power until 2024, and probably beyond. The constitutional reforms to establish a presidential system, which were approved in a referendum in April 2017, provide few checks and balances on the powers of the president. This will further weaken Turkey's democratic institutions and governance structures, effectively moving the country into a system of one-man rule by Mr Erdogan. Although an unlikely prospect, failure by Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win the elections could throw the political system into chaos and open up irreparable divisions in the AKP.
The intense political instability that followed the failed coup has eased partially, but we expect social and political tensions to intensify during the period up to the elections in 2019, and possibly beyond. The narrow presidential reform referendum victory, amid allegations of vote tampering, further polarised the country. It also raised concerns among the AKP's leaders that Mr Erdogan and his party were losing support. With the president's political future dependent on clear victories in all three elections, the government will continue its campaign against political opponents, critics and perceived enemies of the state, using the state of emergency law. Emergency rule was initially introduced after the failed coup to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. We expect emergency rule to remain in place until after the elections, because it will effectively allow Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is fully in place.
Security risk will remain high, with negative implications for the economy. The state is seeking to end an insurgency by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) in the south-east of Turkey, address the domestic security risk of terrorist attacks by Kurdish militants and Islamic State (IS), and implement military operations in Syria and Iraq against IS and the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds. The operational capacity problems created by the purge of the Turkish Armed Forces (TSK) and the police after the attempted coup appear to have eased to a large extent, but Turkey remains vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the PKK and IS. In the short to medium term neither the government nor the PKK appears to be interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will intensify.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
We expect Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win the municipal, presidential and parliamentary elections in 2019. The opposition is fragmented, Mr Erdogan's popularity is still unrivalled, and he has the support of the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP). Importantly, the AKP also has the ability to control the election process. However, there are concerns within the AKP that the party has lost support since the referendum, and that victory for Mr Erdogan in the presidential election is far from assured, especially if Abdullah Gul, a former president and co-founder of the AKP, decides to run. The challenge of Mr Gul, combined with that of the charismatic Meral Aksener, who recently formed the Good Party (IP), a breakaway group from the MHP, and the leader of the main opposition Republican People's Party (CHP), Kemal Kilicdaroglu, could prevent Mr Erdogan from reaching the 50% threshold for victory in the first round. This would transform the second-round run-off between Mr Erdogan and the candidate with the second-largest share of votes into a deeply polarising referendum on Mr Erdogan's leadership.
The clampdown on the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) since mid-2015, the decision of the MHP leadership to back the presidential reform, and the hardline nationalist stance adopted by Mr Erdogan and the AKP could have a considerable effect on voting patterns at the next parliamentary election. Both the MHP and the HDP have been weakened since the 2015 election and run the risk of falling below the high 10% national vote threshold for parliamentary representation. This would boost the AKP's seat share, even if we expect that in exchange for the MHP's support for Mr Erdogan in the presidential election there will be an electoral alliance between the AKP and MHP to ensure that the MHP retains its representation in parliament. Under the constitutional changes approved in the referendum there will be 600 seats in a much weakened parliament from the next election, up from 550 currently.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. There is a considerable risk of a rupture in Turkey's ties with its traditional Western allies, compounding their concerns that under Mr Erdogan the country is pivoting eastwards. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration, including political upheaval in Europe and the US; a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; the US's military backing of Syrian Kurdish groups, which Turkey regards as terrorist organisations affiliated to the PKK; the Turkish government's authoritarian tendencies and its strident anti-Western rhetoric; and Turkey's forging of closer relations with Russia, China and Iran. Turkey's confrontational approach to its traditional Western allies should also be viewed in the context of Mr Erdogan's need to maintain the support of Turkey's nationalists to achieve his domestic political goals, notably to become president with executive powers after the elections in 2019.
Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and increasingly transactional rather than strategic, but we expect Turkey and its Western allies to avoid a complete breakdown in relations. However, this might become unavoidable if the EU suspends Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, the migrant deal with the EU collapses, the US imposes sanctions on Turkey over alleged violations by Turkish banks of US sanctions against Iran, Turkey closes the Incirlik air base to US forces, or it withdraws from NATO, none of which can be ruled out completely. Operation Olive Branch, Turkey´s crossborder military operation in north-western Syria against US-backed Kurdish groups that was launched on January 20th 2018, will accentuate existing tensions. According to Turkey, the Syrian Kurdish groups are affiliated with the PKK and are intent on establishing a continuous autonomous region along Syria's northern border with Turkey.
The spillover of violence from the conflicts in neighbouring Syria and Iraq will continue to pose serious domestic and external security threats to Turkey. In addition to terrorist attacks carried out in Turkey by IS, the country will face growing threats from the PKK, which has camps in the mountains in northern Iraq, not least as potential retaliation for Turkey's operations in north-western Syria.
The neighbouring conflicts are also likely to continue influencing the direction of Turkey's foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly regarding the conflict in Syria, where both are militarily involved but have been pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to continue to be largely transactional. The risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector and its dynamic, diversified private business sector. However, the risk of an intensification of political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity could disrupt foreign capital inflows during the forecast period. These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, but tend to be short-term and highly volatile. Shifts in capital flows triggered by expectations of tighter US monetary policy and geopolitical tensions in the neighbouring region have already put the lira under severe pressure on several occasions since late 2016, fuelling an acceleration in inflation. Under political pressure not to raise interest rates further, especially ahead of the 2019 elections, the Central Bank of Turkey is constrained in its ability to tighten monetary policy. In the event of another severe weakening of the lira, an abrupt tightening of policy, which could strangle Turkey's economic recovery, may be necessary. However, this is not our baseline scenario.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The current direction of policy appears to be towards a difficult balancing act between moderate fiscal loosening and tight monetary policy, at the same time as encouraging banks to lend to households and businesses.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios-reflecting the impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past and major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-give the government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy. Our baseline forecast remains that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight to support investor confidence and to prevent a surge in domestic demand from causing an unsustainable widening of the current-account deficit. Nevertheless, we expect the central government deficit, which captures most of the public sector, to have expanded from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to an estimated 1.5% in 2017. Despite a series of tax increases this year, we expect increased government spending on defence, security, infrastructure projects and public employment ahead of the elections next year to cause the deficit to widen further, to an average of 2.3% of GDP in 2018-19, before narrowing to 1.6% in 2022. We expect the central government debt/GDP ratio to remain stable at about 28.5% in 2017-19, before declining gradually to 27.4% in 2022. The risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances cannot be ruled out.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The Central Bank of Turkey will have to keep its monetary policy tight in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent further depreciation of the lira amid political volatility and expectations of higher US interest rates and balance sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank). However, because of political pressure not to raise interest rates further, we expect the central bank to have to resort to unorthodox and less effective tools to respond to the challenge, which will periodically test investor confidence in the bank's policy mix of moderate rate increases and macroprudential measures. The bank raised most of its main policy rates between November 2016 and April 2017, but since November 2017 it has focused on using its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate to fund the banking system. This rate was gradually raised by a total of 275 basis points in 2017, to 12.75% in mid-December, pushing the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system to 12.75%, compared with 7.8% in November 2016.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
We estimate that real GDP growth accelerated sharply, from an annual average of 3.3% in 2016 to 7% in 2017. The rebound has been supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit and a pick-up in global demand. We expect growth to slow to an annual average of 4.1% in 2018-22, reflecting the impact of tax increases, higher interest rates, the withdrawal of government stimulus measures introduced to support the economy after the coup attempt in July 2016 and a gradual tightening of global liquidity. There are downside risks to our forecast, which is predicated on the assumption of a smooth transition to a presidential system of government without further political instability that could deter foreign capital inflows.
We forecast that household consumption growth will moderate from an estimated 5.5% in 2017 to a still solid 3.4% per year in 2018-22 as a result of higher interest rates and the withdrawal of government incentives to support household spending. We also expect government consumption growth to be strong, at an annual average rate of 5.8% in 2018-19, easing after the elections to a more moderate but still robust 4.8% in 2020-22.
The deterioration in the business environment since the attempted coup and an increase in the corporation tax rate to 22% from 2018 will continue to hold down private-sector fixed investment growth. However, we expect this to be offset by government investment, especially in infrastructure, generating real growth of 5.5% per year in 2017-19. In 2020-22 we forecast a deceleration to annual growth of 4.8% per year, reflecting public-sector retrenchment and firms' response to a more moderate expansion of domestic and external demand.
The lifting of Russian sanctions on Turkey, especially in the tourism sector; the positive effect of a weaker lira on export competitiveness; and strong external demand have contributed to a rebound in exports of goods and services. However, we expect growth to slow from an estimated 12% in 2017 to an annual average rate of 4.7% in 2018-22, reflecting base effects and our view that 2017 probably represented the recent peak in global economic growth. We continue to expect a cyclical downturn in the US in 2020 to dampen external demand growth in that year.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target-as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disinflationary effects of low global oil prices. We expect the pass-through effects of past currency weakness and a moderate recovery in oil and other commodity prices from 2017 to keep consumer price inflation well above the official target during the first half of the forecast period. Assuming that the central bank does not loosen monetary policy too soon, we expect inflation to ease gradually, achieving the 5% target by end-2022. There are significant upside risks to our forecast.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
After a fall in the nominal value of the lira of about 17% against the US dollar in 2017, we expect the pace of depreciation to slow during the forecast period, keeping the currency broadly stable in real terms. There are substantial risks to this forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows as well as the impact on investor confidence of domestic political tensions and geopolitical turmoil in the region. We expect the lira to average TL4.34:US1 in 2022, compared with TL3.66:US$1 in 2017.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Although we expect the current-account deficit to narrow moderately from an estimated 5.5% of GDP in 2017 to an annual average of 4.7% of GDP in 2018-22, Turkey's external financing needs will still be difficult to meet if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates. Although a weaker lira and the lifting of Russian sanctions will boost Turkey's main exports, we expect this to be largely offset by the moderately higher cost of imported energy and inputs for manufactured import-intensive exports. The rebound in tourist arrivals in 2017 will remain vulnerable to a possible resurgence of terrorist attacks in the country.

Full text: Economist Intelligence Unit commodity price index: food, feedstuffs and beverages

Source: The Economist Intelligence Unit.
Note. WCF (World commodity forecasts) is an index of 22 hard and soft commodities. FFB (Food, feedstuffs and beverages) is a price index of 13 soft commodities. The beverages sector has a weight of 20% in the FFB index, grains 46.4%, oilseeds 28.6% and sugar 4.9%. The FFB index has a weight of 55.6% in the WCF index.
Agricultural prices will remain weak in early 2018, sinking the annual average
The Economist Intelligence Unit's food, feedstuffs and beverages (FFB) price index is set to fall in year-on-year terms in 2018-the seventh consecutive year of decline-by 0.4%. This is a smaller margin than the estimated drop in prices in 2017, of 0.9%, as the markets for some agricultural goods, including oilseeds and grains such as wheat, maize and rice are beginning to tighten slightly. Nonetheless, most agricultural markets remain comfortably supplied, following several years of bumper harvests. Several crops registered record harvests in 2016/17, including wheat and soybeans, and large carryover stocks will limit the potential for price growth in 2018. Although there is a risk that a La Niña weather event will have a negative effect on crop yields in some regions in the 2017/18 season, therefore pushing up prices, the impact is likely to be mixed; therefore, we have not included an agricultural price shock in our forecast. We expect the FFB index to begin to firm from late 2018 and to rise by an average of 2.3% in 2019, as some markets tighten further, causing prices for goods such as coffee, cocoa and wheat, to recover from rock bottom. Overall, we expect rising populations and incomes to continue to support modest growth in demand (and therefore prices) of FFB goods in the medium and long term.
The recovery in agricultural prices in 2019 will be fairly modest
Nonetheless, the road ahead will be bumpy. Agricultural markets have been well supplied for several consecutive seasons, providing ample stocks to draw upon. We expect global GDP growth to remain fairly robust, at an average of 2.8% per year in 2018-19, down only slightly from estimated growth of 2.9% in 2017. However, the looming economic slowdown in China and uncertainty about global monetary policy continue to pose downside risks to demand. In addition, exchange-rate trends may help to keep a lid on global commodity prices. We expect the US dollar (in which most raw materials are traded) to remain fairly strong against most emerging-market currencies in 2018-19, and this will weigh on import demand in many emerging markets and encourage exporters to increase output, further inflating global supplies. As a result, even though prices will begin to recover in 2019, we expect the FFB index to remain well below 2014 levels, on the back of ample global supply.
Grain prices will post small rises, failing to recover to 2015 levels in 2018-19
We expect grain prices to contract by an average of 0.4% in 2018, as comfortable supplies weigh on wheat and maize prices. Nonetheless, the price declines in 2018 will be modest relative to those of 2014-16, when supply surged and global stocks accumulated. For wheat in particular, international prices appear to have found a floor after two years of sharp decline. Average world wheat prices surged in mid-2017, as drought in the northern US Plains region and dryness in parts of the EU, Australia and the Black Sea region raised concerns over tighter global supply. However, the damage to crops was less serious than initially expected, and we forecast prices to ease gradually throughout 2018 as the rapid growth in 2017 proves difficult to replicate, before rising again in 2019. Maize prices will remain fairly weak into the first half of 2018, undermined by the bumper 2016/17 crop, before inching up steadily over the course of 2018-19 as global consumption rises-particularly for animal feed-and the market tightens.
Oilseed prices will rise in 2018-19 as oversupplied markets begin to tighten
Oilseed prices fell by an estimated 1.5% in 2017, owing largely to the bumper soybean crop in major producers, such as the US and Brazil. Despite strong global demand, this has driven global soybean stocks higher. However, we expect the price of soybeans, as well as sunflowerseed oil and rapeseed oil, to see fairly strong growth in 2018-19 as market supply begins to tighten and global demand continues to expand. However, this will largely be offset by a drop in palm oil prices, as global production surges but changing consumer habits-particularly in developed economies, where health concerns have shifted consumer tastes to alternative products-will result in lower demand growth.
A forecast recovery in coffee prices in 2019 will lift the beverages sub-index
We forecast the beverages sub-index, which includes coffee and cocoa, to fall again in 2018, for the sixth consecutive year. We forecast cocoa prices to decline at a fairly modest rate of 2% per year in 2018-19; however, this follows a massive drop in 2017, of nearly 30%, which was caused by soaring global production and fairly weak demand growth. Global coffee prices are set to remain fairly flat in 2018, as the relatively strong US dollar encourages exporters to sell their stocks, bringing new supplies onto the market. In 2019, however, we expect prices of higher-value arabica coffee beans to grow more quickly, by 9%, as several consecutive years of market deficits finally begin to erode global supplies.
Sugar prices will recover in 2018-19, but by a marginal amount
Sugar prices declined by an estimated 11% in 2017 as the market corrected after a price spike in late 2016 related to fears that supply from Thailand would be heavily affected by poor weather conditions. We expect global consumption to expand by a modest 0.7% per year on average in 2018-19 (1.3% previously) as high domestic prices limit demand in India, the second-largest global consumer. Recent weakness in global oil prices will also play a role as cheaper energy products incentivise farmers to divert more cane to sugar (rather than to its rival, ethanol), further increasing sugar supply and limiting price growth through--out the forecast period.

Cocoa
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that, after having contracted for two consecutive crop years, cocoa consumption grew by a marginal 0.4% in the 2016/17 season (October-September). Although cocoa demand is expected to accelerate slightly during the forecast period, by an average of 1.1% per year in 2017/18-2018/19, it remains fairly weak by historical comparison. Recent cocoa grind data point to a somewhat stronger third quarter of 2017 in Europe, in line with our current projections for a gradual pick-up in demand, but none of the main developed markets will be in a position to fuel rapid growth in cocoa consumption, reflecting high existing cocoa consumption levels per head. In contrast to some other soft commodity markets, where producing countries are starting to become major consumers, cocoa consumption levels among producers are (and will remain) extremely low, hampering the scope for firmer global growth in cocoa consumption. Meanwhile, recent falls in cocoa prices will be slow to feed through to retail prices, which will continue to push some consumers towards non-chocolate confectionery. The average size of many chocolate bars has shrunk-partly in response to consumer concerns about obesity, but also to protect profits during a time of high cocoa prices-also hampering cocoa consumption growth in the forecast period.
Balancing demand between cocoa powder and butter will be challenging
Asian countries will see slightly faster growth in cocoa demand than the global average, as these markets are far less saturated and GDP growth will remain higher than in much of the OECD-even factoring in a gradual slowdown in China in 2018. Stronger demand in Asia will have implications for global demand for cocoa butter (used in richer products, such as chocolate confectionery) and cocoa powder (used to add chocolate flavour to products such as biscuits, cakes and drinks). The demand balance between cocoa powder and butter is both delicate and cyclical. We expect demand for cocoa butter to remain strong in the short term, but it will not outstrip demand for powder indefinitely. Given that Asia accounts for 26% of the world's imports of cocoa powder, compared with just 13% of global imports of cocoa butter, firmer consumption growth in that market is likely to boost demand for powder.
Higher prices will slow consumption growth in developed markets
Consumers in the US (the largest cocoa-consuming country, which accounts for nearly 20% of global demand) and Europe (which collectively accounts for 40% of global demand) are showing an increasing preference for premium chocolate (with a higher cocoa content), but with less frequent purchases. Recent sales figures from the main chocolate manufacturers indicate that, on balance, this is pushing down overall consumption. This is illustrated by data from 2015/16, which show that cocoa demand contracted in several large markets (including the US and Canada) and grew only marginally in others (including in Europe), despite fairly strong underlying economic conditions in many of these areas.
We forecast modest but positive growth in demand for cocoa in developed markets in 2017/18-2018/19. Health concerns, market saturation and changing retail habits will constrain demand (the rise of internet grocery shopping will erode spur-of-the-moment in-store chocolate purchases). However, rising demand for dark chocolate-which has a higher cocoa content than milk chocolate and is perceived to be healthier-will support overall consumption.
Russian and Brazilian cocoa consumption will begin to recover
Lower cocoa consumption in 2015/16 in Brazil and Russia, which together account for nearly 10% of global demand, demonstrate the extent to which cocoa demand is affected by underlying economic conditions, particularly in developing economies, where chocolate is not regarded as a basic good. We estimate that both of these countries saw consumption contract further in 2016/17-reflecting the high cost of cocoa in local-currency terms. For Russia, restrictions on a number of imports from the EU that have been in place since mid-2014 are having an adverse effect on demand for many consumer goods. We expect cocoa demand in Russia to continue to stage a gradual recovery in 2017/18 and 2018/19, growing by an average 1.4% per year, as the country emerges from two years of economic recession. The same is true of Brazil, where we forecast cocoa consumption to return to growth in 2017/18-2018/19, averaging 1.5% per year, assuming that the economy continues to recover slowly.
Cocoa consumption growth will slow in Asia
China and India have huge potential for further expansion in cocoa demand, given currently low per-head consumption levels (at just 37 g in India and 59 g in China in 2015/16, compared with 2-6 kg in developed markets). However, demand will be hampered by high retail prices and, in China, consumer caution, particularly in 2018-19. Although Chinese demand will continue to rise, we expect the pace of growth to slow from 5% in 2017/18 to 3.5% in 2018/19. In India, we expect demand growth to accelerate from 3.4% in 2017/18 to 4.2% in 2018/19, owing to firmer underlying economic conditions.
