Supply
Global cocoa production surged by an estimated 15% in 2016/17 on the back of improved weather conditions, after a particularly difficult El Niño event and a severe harmattan season (a dry winter wind blowing from the Sahara) cut cocoa output in many of Africa's main producers in 2015/16. We expect global cocoa production to fall during 2017/18 and 2018/19, by 6.6% and 1.2% respectively, mainly reflecting a projected drop in production in Côte d'Ivoire-the world's largest cocoa producer. Its output will remain high by historical comparison, but another bumper crop is unlikely, reflecting lower farm gate prices and weaker confidence among growers. Overall, recent price weakness is likely to dissuade farmers from investing in fertiliser and pesticide, raising the incidence of crop disease and contributing to the broader decline in global cocoa production. The rising possibility of a La Niña weather phenomenon poses some uncertainties, but risks to our forecasts are less pronounced than for some of the other agricultural commodities. Although El Niño episodes do tend to disrupt production, La Niña tends to have a more muted effect, with drier than normal weather in cocoa-producing regions in South America and Asia often being offset by better growing conditions in West Africa.
Structural and geographic factors will hamper long-term supply
Longer-term structural problems will also constrain supply. Not only have farm gate prices in several large producing countries begun to fall in line with lower market prices for cocoa but farmers also receive a much smaller share of the final retail price than in the previous decades, owing to higher costs further down the supply chain. Many farmers in West Africa remain below the poverty line, and as a consequence few young people in the region are choosing to work in the cocoa sector. Governments are trying to lift farmers' incomes to encourage people to work in the cocoa sector, but it is uncertain how effective these methods will be in the long term.
Geographical considerations will also hamper the diversification of production. Cocoa can be grown only in certain regions (three-quarters of world production comes from regions that are located within eight degrees of the equator) under warm and humid conditions. Cocoa production is therefore likely to remain concentrated among a small group of countries, limiting the scope for strong and sustained output growth. Nonetheless, there are countries that have significant potential to expand production, mainly in Latin America, where high-quality cocoa is produced. The expansion of manufacturing facilities to grind beans in producing countries may also encourage new investment to lift output.
Côte d'Ivoire's production has soared in 2016/17
In Côte d'Ivoire, cocoa production jumped by nearly 30% in 2016/17, to a record of just over 2m tonnes. However, this upward trend is not expected to continue, and we forecast that cocoa production will fall by 11.2% in 2017/18 and 2.2% in 2018/19. The authorities are unlikely to be able to replicate the exceptionally high level of output registered in 2016/17, with the state-run cocoa authority, the Conseil du Café-Cacao (CCC), issuing fewer export licences and projecting production in 2017/18 in the range of 1.725m-1.75m tonnes. Although our production forecast is fairly strong by historical comparison, we expect output to fall steadily in the forecast period. Policy will not be particularly supportive: following a sharp cut to farm gate prices ahead of the mid-crop in March 2017, the CCC has kept prices on hold for the 2017/18 harvest, with price levels around one-third lower than a year ago. This has discouraged use of fertiliser and pesticide, with crop disease rising as a result. The government had hoped to raise farm gate prices, but any increase in the producer price would mean cutting export duties and therefore forgoing fiscal revenue, which is unlikely. A stabilisation fund is supposed to protect farmers' revenue from global price volatility, but these funds have seemingly been insufficient to shield farmers' incomes and-given the lack of transparency over the financial reserves held by the CCC-neither farmers nor exporters have confidence that losses arising from low global prices will be recouped.
Ghanaian government will struggle to boost cocoa production significantly
Similar production trends will be evident in Ghana. Cocoa production rebounded firmly in 2016/17, with favourable weather and a mild harmattan season lifting cocoa production to an estimated 925,000 tonnes (well above the official target of 800,000 tonnes). However, we do not expect further significant and sustained growth in production during 2017/18-2018/19. For now, Ghana's cocoa board (Cocobod) has been more reluctant than the Ivorian authorities to cut prices paid to farmers, but Cocobod has been forced to seek a bridging loan from the central bank, indicating that farm gate prices may need to be cut, particularly if global cocoa prices fail to recover. Combined with anxiety among farmers about the government's intentions to evolve agriculture towards other crops, ongoing encroachment by gold miners and the government's decision to stop providing free fertiliser, production is forecast to fall by 10.3% in 2017/18, before staging a partial (but weak) recovery in 2018/19, of just 3.6%.
In the longer term, the New Patriotic Party government plans to rehabilitate cocoa farms, cutting down trees that are over 30 years old and replanting them while providing financial compensation to farmers until the trees start yielding fruit (generally three to five years). The authorities ultimately aim to raise production to 1.5m tonnes within four years, also driven by better soil management, and better pest and disease control. These plans are positive, since Ghana has a large share of unproductive trees (Cocobod estimates 40%) and a consequent low average yield per hectare (at 400 kg/ha, compared with 600 kg/ha in Côte d'Ivoire and 1 tonne/ha in Indonesia). Replanting, in particular, will help to address the problem of swollen shoot disease, which affects nearly one-fifth of cocoa trees and is associated with low yields. However, we think it unlikely that these ambitious plans will reach fruition, since the weak macroeconomic backdrop is likely to hamper public investment.
Cameroon's and Nigeria's production targets will prove overambitious
After falling for the second consecutive crop year in 2016/17, cocoa production in Cameroon will remain weak during 2017/18-2018/19. Cuts in farm gate prices will be a disincentive to farmers, meaning that the government will remain significantly off track from its 2020 production target of 600,000 tonnes-a level that even the national Cocoa Development Corporation has described as "unrealistic and unattainable". The fact that plans to increase the harvested area by 100,000 ha each year have failed to materialise, with the area under cocoa cultivation rising by only around 3,000 ha since 2014, will severely hamper the expansion of the cocoa sector.
Cocoa production in Nigeria has slumped in recent years, and the country has slipped from being the world's fourth-largest producer to the sixth-largest (on a par with Brazil). Government initiatives designed to support farmers have not proved successful, with efforts to introduce high-yielding cocoa and increase the distribution of free seedlings floundering. With the country's mining and energy sector suffering from moderate inter-national oil prices, there is official acknowledgement that investment in raising cocoa production could generate greater foreign-exchange earnings, and the Ministry of Agriculture has recently outlined its ambitious goal of boosting cocoa production above the levels recorded in Côte d'Ivoire. Its short-term goal is to lift cocoa production to 300,000-320,000 tonnes in 2017/18, with the medium-term target of raising output to 1m tonnes/year. However, problems with weak infrastructure, corruption, poor (and expensive) access to financing and weak implementation capacity will hamper these efforts.
Prospects are weak for Indonesia's cocoa sector
The authorities in Indonesia have ambitious plans to triple cocoa output by 2020, from 325,000 tonnes in 2014/15, but these are highly unlikely to materialise. Adverse weather hampered both the 2015/16 and the 2016/17 harvest, with cocoa output registering its third consecutive annual decline in the latter season. On the assumption of more stable weather conditions, output should resume growth in 2017/18 and 2018/19, but at an expected 320,000 tonnes at the end of the forecast period, cocoa output will remain weak by historical comparison. Indonesian firms are likely to rely increasingly on imported processed cocoa from neighbouring Malaysia to meet domestic demand.
Strong potential for growth in Latin America will not be realised in 2018-19
Agriculture in Latin America's two largest cocoa producers, Brazil and Ecuador, was affected by El Niño in 2015/16. However, with better weather conditions, output is estimated to have recovered firmly in both countries in 2016/17. Structurally, there is scope for both countries to lift cocoa output as manufacturers look to boost investment in the region in an attempt to diversify production away from West Africa. The region's reputation for producing high-quality cocoa will help in this respect, given rising global demand for premium chocolate. However, some of this investment will be slow to materialise, as global prices remain depressed amid excess supply, which will act as a brake on growth potential.

Stocks and prices
We expect the global cocoa market to remain in surplus during the forecast period, and for the surplus to narrow gradually, from an estimated 536,000 tonnes in 2016/17 to 98,000 tonnes by 2018/19. Although production is forecast to fall steadily, the fact that it will do so from such a high base (output was exceptionally strong in 2016/17) means that cocoa production will remain higher than consumption by some margin. Tepid demand growth makes a return to a market deficit unlikely during the forecast period. Stocks are forecast to exceed 2.2m tonnes at the end of the 2018/19 season, which is very high by historical comparison. Moreover, there is potential for stocks to rise even more strongly; Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana have started discussions about how to bolster global market prices, and are considering stockpiling part of their output.

After remaining high for much of 2014-16, at around US$3,000/tonne, cocoa prices plummeted between December 2016 and late April 2017, to less than US$1,900/tonne. Although prices have recovered somewhat, they averaged less than US$2,000/tonne each month from May-September, only increasing to around US$2,100/tonne in October on the back of weaker production prospects in Côte d'Ivoire. Although global production prospects will remain weak in the near term, we see little likelihood of a sustained recovery in average prices, owing to the global supply glut. We forecast prices to fall by 3% in 2018, to an average of US$1,975/tonne, and by a further 1% in 2019, to US$1,955/tonne.

Coffee
Demand
Global coffee consumption expanded by around 2.7% in both 2015/16 and 2016/17, largely boosted by rising consumption in coffee-importing countries (mainly developed economies) that account for two-thirds of global demand. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the pace of consumption growth to accelerate to 3.1% in 2017/18, aided by stronger underlying economic conditions in many of the large consuming markets, before slipping to 2% in 2018/19. Notwithstanding ongoing monetary policy tightening in some of the large coffee consumers, overall domestic demand is expected to remain firm, supporting coffee consumption. In coffee-producing countries (many of which are emerging markets), consumption growth will continue to average 2.4% per year, held back somewhat by tepid demand growth in Brazil (which currently accounts for around 40% of exporting countries' consumption, owing to the sheer size of its domestic market). Consumption growth will be strongest in Asia-notably China. Although we expect China's GDP growth rate to slow from 2018, the deceleration will be concentrated in the investment and industrial sectors, and we expect average income levels to continue to rise steadily, meaning that there is little risk of a fall in coffee demand growth. However, coffee consumption levels are low in China, so even as domestic coffee demand rises quickly, this will contribute only modestly to global consumption growth.
Coffee habits are shifting around the world
Consumption trends will change in both the home and out-of-home sectors. In the latter, the expansion of coffee-shop chains will continue, providing a boost to demand, particularly in North America and Europe, but store formats will evolve. Increasing demand for "on the go" beverages will result in larger numbers of smaller shops, including within petrol stations and supermarkets. In some markets-including the US and China-the large coffee chains are increasingly moving towards prepayment through smartphone apps, allowing customers to pick up their purchases without having to queue. These technological developments are likely to help the out-of-home sector to defend its market share at a time when a large number of consumers have single-serve coffee-capsule machines at home. This will be accompanied by heavy marketing of other coffee beverages, including iced coffee and cold brew. Although comprising a small market share of the out-of-home segment, sales of these products are likely to grow rapidly.
Single-serve coffee will help to drive growth in developed markets
Demand for coffee at home that rivals the quality of beverages found in cafes will result in a shift away from the consumption of instant coffee. On a global level, coffee pod sales are approaching the total combined value of instant and ground coffee, although the higher cost of pods means that, in volume terms, the instant and ground coffee market remains larger. Although sales of machines and capsules are slowing sharply after initial firm growth, the coffee pod market will continue to provide important support for overall demand of arabica coffee (most pods contain predominantly arabica beans).
Coffee consumption growth in North America will increase steadily
US coffee consumption growth is forecast to average 1.6% a year in 2017/18-2018/19. Data from the US National Coffee Association show that the percentage of people drinking coffee is rising rapidly (up from 57% in early 2016 to 62% in early 2017). Daily consumption is rising and consumers are increasingly attracted to a variety of products (US consumption of cold coffee products has risen by 75% over the past two years). There are indications that long-term consumption growth may continue to rise, with the number of coffee shops increasing at around 3.6% per year and the share of 13-18-year-olds drinking coffee rising from 23% in 2014 to 37% in early 2017, and demand growth among 18-24-year-olds also rising strongly.
Similar dynamics are evident in Canada, with the share of 18-24-year-olds drinking coffee jumping from 48% in 2015 to 58% in 2016 (up from just 32% in 2009). Younger consumers show a much stronger preference for speciality coffees and for drinking coffee in out-of-home locations than other age brackets. We expect coffee consumption growth, which has been fairly steady at around 2.5% in recent years, to pick up slightly, to an average of 2.7%, in 2017/18-2018/19.
Coffee consumption in Brazil is expected to falter
Brazil is the world's second-largest coffee consumer, but consumption levels per head are still modest (at around one-third of those in most European countries), so there is scope for a significant increase in demand. However, a sharp economic recession has hampered coffee consumption growth, which has flatlined in recent years, following firm growth in 2005-15. We expect coffee consumption growth to recover to an average pace of 1.3% per year in 2017/18-2018/19. Although underlying economic growth is expected to pick up, household consumption will remain constrained by high unemployment, rising fuel prices and higher inflation, which will all drag on disposable income.
Fairly firm coffee consumption growth is expected in Japan and South Korea
Japan is the largest coffee market in Asia (and the fourth-largest in the world), with coffee boasting around the same share of the beverages market as tea. After rising by 3.1% in 2016/17, we expect coffee consumption growth to rise by an average of 2.3% per year in 2017/18-2018/19. The slower pace of growth will reflect somewhat less supportive underlying economic conditions, after a stellar pace of economic growth in 2017. Nonetheless, annual growth in coffee con-sumption of 2.3% is fairly firm, given the size of the market, and will be under-pinned by coffee sales in convenience stores, as the number of coffee shops is falling. In South Korea the coffee market has expanded rapidly in recent years, with coffee imports more than trebling between 2006 and 2016 and the number of coffee shops increasing even more rapidly. Although we forecast somewhat weaker growth in coffee consumption in 2017/18-2018/19, the pace of growth will remain firm by global standards, at an annual average of 3.1%.
Coffee consumption in China and India-currently both small consumers-will continue to grow. Much of the growth in Chinese coffee consumption will be in the out-of-home sector, reflecting the rising popularity of a coffee-shop culture in urban centres. A significant share of the new stores opened by Starbucks in 2016-17 are in Asia. The company now runs 3,000 outlets in 135 Chinese cities (nearly 600 in Shanghai alone, Starbucks' largest presence in a single city), up from 2,300 last October, and is planning to have 5,000 stores open by 2021. We expect an economic slowdown in China in 2018, but the deceleration will be gradual and will largely be concentrated in the construction and industrial sectors. Given that we expect average income levels to continue to rise steadily, there is little risk of a fall in coffee demand growth during 2017/18-2018/19.
Following a recent rapid expansion of the out-of-home sector in India, driven by comparatively low consumer price inflation, rising disposable income and favourable demographics (around one-half of the population is aged under 25), coffee consumption remained flat in 2016/17. We expect a return to growth in 2017/18-2018/19, with coffee consumption rising by an average of 3.3% per year. South-east Asia also has relatively low levels of coffee consumption per head, but demand is increasing rapidly in some countries (mainly coffee-producing economies such as Indonesia and Vietnam), and rising incomes are encouraging companies such as Starbucks to expand in Indonesia and the Philippines, where consumption is increasing. Costa Coffee is expanding in Thailand, Singapore and Cambodia, and recently opened its first store in Vietnam.
Asian markets will drive demand for robusta beans
Given taste preferences for soluble and instant coffee (which generally use the robusta variety) in faster-growing Asian markets, demand will be stronger for robusta beans than for the more expensive arabica blends. Improved quality of robusta will also play a part here, with such beans slowly losing their reputation for inferior taste. In addition, improvements in processing technology mean that it is possible to use a larger proportion of robusta in coffee blends while maintaining quality.

Supply
Final data from the 2016/17 crop year (October-September) were much more positive than earlier market expecations, with coffee production rising by 3.4%, reflecting firm growth in output in Brazil-the world's largest producer. Coffee production is forecast to fall by 0.7% in 2017/18 as production in Brazil declines as the biennial crop alternates between higher- and lower-producing years (2017/18 is an "off-season" crop year). This will be only partly offset by firmer output growth in most other producing countries. However, there is a risk that global coffee production could decline more rapidly than currently forecast, depending on whether a La Niña weather phenomenon develops in the coming months. This brings a fall in Pacific Ocean water temperatures, typically disrupting coffee output by bringing heavy rains to many of Asia's coffee producers and drought to the main Latin American growers. Global coffee production growth is expected to be much stronger in 2018/19, at 3.9%, as Brazil's crop shifts to an "on-season" year.
We envisage a growing concentration of coffee production among the world's largest producers. Currently, a large number of countries (around 70) produce coffee, but the smaller producers have been struggling as a result of low world prices and rising overheads. In many of these countries, where coffee is not a particularly important area of the economy, farmers wield less power and are less likely to secure government support than in leading producers. Partly as a result, we expect coffee output in "other" countries to decline from 8.9m 60-kg bags in 2015/16 to 7.8m bags in 2018/19. Output in these countries-which fall outside the world's top 17 producers-will account for 5% of global production in 2018/19, down from nearly 15% in 2008/09.
Annual coffee production in Brazil is expected to remain well over 50m bags
In Brazil, by far the world's largest producer, final data from the on-season 2016/17 crop were more positive than expected, with coffee output rising by over 9%. This could reflect the weak local currency, which incentivised local growers, as international coffee prices are denominated in US dollars. Prospects for the off-season 2017/18 crop year are fairly strong and we are forecasting output of 52m bags. This is higher than projections from Conab (the government's crop supply agency), but official forecasts usually prove conservative. Our forecast remains similar to local private-sector expectations, and that of the US Department of Agriculture. Although adverse weather in mid-2016-including drought in some areas and irregular rainfall in others-raised concerns that beans might be damaged ahead of the harvest, recent weather has been more supportive, and the quality and quantity of beans have been good. Moreover, the still-weak local currency is continuing to provide an incentive to growers. Problems at some ports have hampered export capacity, but we do not expect this to have a significant impact on overall supply.
The 2018/19 crop year remains some way off, with coffee bushes only just beginning to flower, so output projections remain highly speculative. Local commentators have stated that they believe that there is potential for a bumper crop in 2018/19, with some even suggesting that output of up to 60m bags is possible, which would represent a record high by some margin (to date, the highest production was recorded in 2012/13, at 55.4m bags). At the moment, we forecast coffee production to rise to 55.5m bags. Although weather conditions have been supportive in most places, some coffee-producing states have seen below-average rainfall, which is likely to hamper faster production growth.
Coffee production in Vietnam is set to recover from a severe drought
In Vietnam, the worst drought in three decades hampered production in 2016/17, with coffee output dropping by 11.3%. Assuming that weather conditions stabilise for the 2017/18 crop, there is scope for a rebound in Vietnam's coffee output; we forecast production of 27m bags, implying growth of 5.9%, followed by 3% growth (to 27.8m bags) in 2018/19. The authorities remain pessimistic about the medium-term prospects for production, forecasting coffee output to stabilise or decline slightly. However, government efforts to replant 140,000 ha of coffee, targeting 25,000 ha a year, as well as a rising arabica crop, will support firmer output, particularly given that yields from new bushes are typically high. Market jitters about widespread damage to coffee bushes from severe storms in coffee-growing areas in early November were quickly allayed and it appears that this bout of weather had minimal impact on coffee beans. In addition, firm demand for robusta in the domestic market and other Asian countries will encourage growers.
Output from Mexico and Central America will slip in 2017/18
Coffee production rebounded strongly in Mexico and Central America in 2016/17-rising by 17.5% year on year to 19.4m bags. This followed a severe outbreak of coffee rust, followed by an El Niño weather phenomenon, which damaged plantations in the three previous seasons. However, the sharp jump in 2016/17 mainly reflected a rebound in output in Honduras and, to a lesser extent, Mexico. Nonetheless, there are reports that coffee rust is returning to some areas in the region, which could threaten output in 2017/18. Purchases of fungicides and fertiliser will help to prop up yields, but we nevertheless forecast a fall in coffee production of 5.3% in 2017/18. Assuming that coffee rust does not spread significantly and that weather conditions stay favourable, we expect coffee output to grow by 1.6% in 2018/19.
Colombian production is set to continue to rise in the medium term
Coffee production in Colombia has risen steadily in recent years, reaching a 24-year high of 14.5m bags in 2016/17. Prospects for 2017/18 are uncertain. The structural underpinnings of the sector are strong, including a comparatively high percentage of rust-resistant bushes. In addition, efforts are being made to increase productivity, with recent additional planting in existing plantations aiming to raise average production per hectare, which at 18 bags per hectare in 2016 was much lower than in other large growers (27 bags per hectare in Brazil and 35 bags per hectare in Vietnam). However, recent cloudy weather conditions are affecting flowering on coffee bushes; if this continues, the crop yield will be hampered. For the time being, we project coffee production growth of 4.1% in 2017/18, but will monitor this closely in the coming months. In 2018/19 production should start to benefit from a 2016 peace agreement between the government and the left-wing FARC rebels, as coffee cultivation will increase in previously isolated areas of the country (the government has speculated that output could reach 20m bags by 2020 as a result). We forecast coffee production growth of 4.6% in 2018/19, to 15.8m bags.
In Indonesia coffee production is recovering, but remains weak overall
Indonesia's ambitious expansion plans for the coffee sector-which include more than doubling production within five years to make the country the world's second-largest producer after Brazil-have been completely derailed. El Niño brought excessive dry weather to the main coffee-growing areas, affecting the 2016/17 harvest, when output fell by 6.7%. However, exports have recently begun to recover owing to more supportive weather conditions, providing momentum heading into the 2017/18 season, when we expect production to rise by 4.4%. We expect production to grow by a further 2.5% in 2018/19, but at just 12.3m bags, output will remain low by historical comparison.
Production prospects in Africa, which accounts for around 11% of total global coffee output, are relatively bright. Many of the continent's coffee producers have very low levels of output; together, Ethiopia and Uganda account for 70% of African coffee output. Production rose solidly in both countries in 2016/17, mainly on the back of better weather conditions. We expect coffee production to continue to rise over the forecast period, but for the increase to be sharper in Uganda, reflecting an extensive re-seeding programme in recent years and an expansion of the coffee-growing area. Progress in these areas has been more gradual in Ethiopia, where we expect production growth to be more modest.

Stocks and prices
After stabilising in 2016/17, we expect global coffee stocks to fall in 2017/18-2018/19, reflecting a persistent market deficit. Even assuming some continued sales of stocks, as producers take advantage of the relatively weak local currencies against the US dollar, the market deficit is forecast to remain large throughout the forecast period. By end-2018/19 we expect global stocks to have fallen to 24.2m bags, from 31.6m bags in September 2016, which will support a partial recovery in prices.

After slumping again in 2017, arabica prices are set to rise in 2018
Arabica prices have fallen steadily during 2017, from an average of US$1.69/lb in January to US$1.41/lb in November. Given that the global market is set to register its third consecutive annual deficit in 2016/17, the fall in prices-to levels not seen since 2013-is curious. We believe that coffee prices are increasingly driven by investment trends, with swings in sentiment often due to a spate of positive or negative news on the supply side. Coffee prices are also becoming increasingly reactive to changes in the strength of the US dollar, with dollar depreciation tending to lead to higher coffee prices. In recent months speculation about bumper production in Brazil has pushed prices lower. The fact that several large exporting countries are continuing to sell spare stock in order to take advantage of weak local currencies is also suppressing prices, because this has been accompanied by a rise in coffee stocks in importing countries, which in turn may contain demand in the future.
We believe that speculation about the 2018/19 harvest in Brazil will continue to suppress prices; we forecast arabica prices to remain flat year on year, at an average of US$1.52/lb in 2018. This is in line with recent developments in futures markets, with coffee for March 2018 delivery trading at below US$1.3/lb. If production is disrupted on the back of an El Niño weather phenomenon, there is potential for prices to rebound sharply, given that prices remain low by historical comparison (and have arguably been over-sold given underlying market fundamentals). Given the likelihood that the next "off-season" in Brazil (2019/20) will hit market confidence during the 2019 calendar year, we forecast a recovery of prices, to an average of US$1.66/lb.
Tighter supplies of robusta beans and firm Asian demand will support prices
Prices for cheaper robusta held up better during much of 2017, reflecting concerns about the supply of robusta beans in the context of disappointing weather conditions in Vietnam and Indonesia, but dipped sharply in November as bean supply picked up. We expect prices to average US$1.01/lb in 2018 and US$1.04/lb in 2019, supported by rising Asian demand.

Maize
Demand
Maize is the most consumed (and produced) grain in the world, with total annual demand now in excess of 1bn tonnes/year (t/y). It is a versatile grain, with around 60% of the total used for animal feed, almost 30% for industrial processing (mainly fuel ethanol and starch) and the rest consumed directly as food or seed, or lost through waste. After a period of spectacular growth, demand for maize-based biofuels is now increasing more slowly, even though overall levels of consumption are still setting new records each year. However, following reports about China's plans for a massive expansion of its own fuel ethanol sector, world use for biofuels could potentially rise sharply from current levels over the medium term. Furthermore, maize is the primary energy source in compound feed mixes, and with ample supplies predicted across the world, it is well placed to meet predicted gains in demand in meat-exporting countries, as well as in parts of Africa, Asia and Latin America, where consumption of animal protein continues to expand. Maize is by far the dominant feed grain in much of the world, with annual consumption typically more than four times that of wheat. In 2017/18 The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global demand to rise by 2.4% year on year, with stronger uptake expected across the animal feed, industrial and food sectors. A similar trend is projected for 2018/19, with overall consumption rising by 1.6%, to 1.05bn tonnes.
World feed demand will rise by 2% in 2017/18
World demand for meat and other animal proteins shows no sign of slowing, with consumption gains driven by population growth, greater purchasing power and changes in diets and tastes. Maize is an extremely useful ingredient in animal feed, which can contribute to rapid livestock weight gain. Overall use, however, depends on availabilities and price relationships with other grains-mainly wheat-as well as high-protein oilmeals. A multitude of other factors can also have a direct impact on feed demand in any particular year, with producers having to consider pasture conditions and availability, as well as desired livestock weight, the economics of the meat industry and feed efficiency ratios. In 2017/18 we expect global growth in use of maize for livestock feed to slow to around 2%, down from almost 7% in the previous season. Further growth in maize feed demand is likely in 2018/19, with total feed use forecast to reach a record 595m tonnes.
Trade continues to increase year after year
Global maize trade in 2017/18 (July-June) is forecast to grow by 6.5% year on year, to reach a new record. Amid large surpluses across all of the major exporters, global prices are soft, and maize remains very competitively priced for inclusion in feed rations. A number of large buyers are expected to increase imports, with particularly strong growth likely in Mexico, the EU and Taiwan. This will easily compensate for a reduction in purchases by Brazil and South Africa, two countries that secured unusually large amounts in 2016/17 owing to severe weather difficulties. The EU is expected to displace Japan as the world's leading importer this year, with shipments pegged at a record 17m tonnes, up by more than a quarter compared with 2016/17. Mexico's imports are projected to rise by 1.5m tonnes, to 15.5m tonnes, also a new all-time peak, relegating Japan to third place on the league table of the world's biggest buyers.
China announces plans to boost ethanol production
Years of supply and demand imbalances in China have led to a massive surplus, with stocks soaring to an unprecedented level in recent years. Over-production was mainly linked to a now discontinued official stockpiling scheme, under which farmers in the largest maize provinces were able to sell unlimited amounts into state reserves at guaranteed minimum prices. At the same time, cheaper feed grain imports flooded into southern consuming regions, choking off demand for locally produced maize. Authorities are now working hard to unwind part of these burdensome stocks. Under a plan jointly announced by 15 ministries and commissions in September, the government is seeking a massive expansion of the biofuel sector, targeting the blending of 10% ethanol (E10) into all automotive petrol by 2020. The move is seen as a part of broader efforts to reduce China's carbon footprint. If E10 plans are fully implemented, an additional 35-40m tonnes of maize would be required as a feedstock each year.
China's maize stocks are likely to be larger than previously thought
Calls for such a steep and sustained increase in China's maize consumption suggest that local inventories could be much larger than we had previously expected. Our supply and demand estimates for the past decade have therefore recently been revised, with forecasts for feed use across this period lowered by an average of 18m t/y, equivalent to around 10% of total annual consumption. Given the sheer size of its grain economy, any revisions for China can appear to have an outsized impact. Nevertheless, it should be stressed that the underlying trend is unchanged from before, and with so much of China's grain economy operating separately from the global market, these revisions do not have any wider price implications. We forecast China's overall maize demand to rise by 3.8% in 2017/18, and by a further 5.8% in 2018/19, as maize use in industrial processing begins to accelerate.

Supply
World maize supplies (production plus carryover stocks) have increased to record highs in recent seasons, topping 1bn tonnes most years since 2011/12. Encouraged by high market prices, production gains have stemmed from increases in plantings, as well as improved yields, with growers using new seed varieties, fertilisers and better farming practices to great effect. After surging by an estimated 10.7% in 2016/17, global output is projected to drop by 4.3% in 2017/18. Boosted by ample carryovers from 2016/17, global supplies are still likely to remain comfortable, especially in the major exporting countries, where traders are likely to compete hard for available business. Forecasts for 2018/19 remain highly provisional, especially in the southern hemisphere, and will be subject to revision in the coming months. Overall, we expect global output to be flat in that season as a modest expansion in area is offset by lower yields.
A weak La Niña appears to be forming
Some of the world's leading meteorological agencies, including the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) recently indicated the presence of a weak La Niña weather event, which is likely to persist until February-April 2018. Previous La Niña have sometimes been linked to drier than normal weather in southern Brazil and northern Argentina, two important maize producing areas. In contrast, La Niña normally brings beneficial rains to parts of southern Africa, a factor that lifted South Africa's 2016/17 maize crop to a record high. With a long way still to go in the southern hemisphere cropping season, it is still too early to adjust our crop forecasts solely on the basis of these updated long-range weather outlooks. However, with South American crops now playing a central role on the world market, the situation will be kept under close scrutiny in the months ahead.
US output will drop in 2017/18, but by a lower margin than expected
In its mid-month supply and demand update, the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) provided additional downside impetus to an already bearish maize market, raising its nationwide yield estimate by 2% from October to 11 tonnes/ha. With upgrades for all key states apart from Nebraska, average productivity is now forecast to be at its highest ever, lifting production to 370.3m tonnes in 2017/18, almost 8% higher than the average annual outturn in the last five seasons. However, because of a drop in plantings, total output will still be down by about 4% from the 2016/17 record. While the USDA has maintained a generally optimistic outlook throughout the growing season, many other forecasters, were more cautious because of poor weather earlier in the season. However, temperatures cooled in August, before warming again in September, thereby extending the growing period and helping to offset some of the effects of previous unfavourable conditions. The latest hybrid maize seeds, in combination with better farming practices and equipment, have allowed crops to perform well even under short periods of adverse weather. With crop development lagging behind average for much of the season, this year's harvest has been the slowest in around three years. There are some issues with above-normal moisture content in some states, which may necessitate costly mechanical drying. In areas where storage facilities are already close to capacity, there are concerns that soggy grain may be at risk of spoiling if it cannot be dried and stored correctly.
Planting decisions for 2018/19 will once again depend on price relationships with alternatives, mainly soybeans, in the spring. After two seasons of losing ground to soybeans, 2018/19 rotation needs could favour maize sowings, especially if fertiliser prices stay low. However, the current heavy maize supply outlook means any upside is likely to be limited. For the time being, we expect a 2% rise in seedings, enough for a crop of around 361.8m tonnes, down by about 2% year on year.
Southern hemisphere harvests are expected to be smaller in 2017/18
Planting of 2017/18 maize crops began in September in some parts of South America, with fieldwork stretching through until February. The heavy supply outlook and current weak market prices suggest that a pullback in area is likely. Assuming a normalisation of yields, cumulative production in the three top exporters could decline by about 8%, to 156.5m tonnes.
Lower area, smaller yields in Brazil
The price outlook in Brazil is especially weak, with average local prices down by more than 40% year on year. Potentially better returns from soybeans mean that more area in the south of the country is likely to be diverted to oilseeds. A recent report from the Mato Grosso Institute of Agriculture Economics (Imea) predicts that 2017/18 safrinha (second crop) output in Mato Grosso, the country's single largest producing state, could decline by almost 20% year on year. The projected decline is linked to increasingly poor returns and follow-through delays from late soybean planting in the state. Imea's projection is more pessimistic than currently assumed by the country's official crop agency and could imply some downside risk to our current forecast, which does not assume such a steep drop in safrinha plantings. The situation will become clearer closer to the start of safrinha sowing, due to start after soybeans are harvested in February. We expect the outturn to fall to 91m tonnes in 2017/18, down by 7% year on year.
Similarly, a slump in South African prices means that sown area is likely to decline by around 7%. Based on average yields, the crop could drop by 29%, to 12.5m tonnes. The situation in Argentina is somewhat different. Encouraged by the farm-friendly policies of the Macri administration, producers are expected to boost plantings, with output down by only 1m tonnes from the previous season, at 40m tonnes. For 2018/19 we anticipate a modest expansion in South American crops but another static year in South African output.

Ukraine and Russia have become big players on the world market
Maize production in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) has increased massively during the past decade, rising from around 21.7m tonnes in 2008/09 to an estimated 42.3m tonnes in the current season. Nearly all of the growth stems from much larger harvests in Ukraine and more recently, in Russia, with the other countries still relatively small producers. In 2016/17 maize overtook wheat as Ukraine's biggest export crop by volume, and the country now ranks as the world's fourth-largest exporter, behind the US, Brazil and Argentina. After peaking at a record 30.9m tonnes in 2013/14, production has edged lower in subsequent years as plantings fell back slightly. The 2017/18 harvest is estimated at 25m tonnes, 10.7% lower than the record 2016/17 crop, and slightly lower than the five-year average. With a strong export base expected to encourage plantings early next year, output is forecast to rebound to 27.5m tonnes in 2018/19.
Russia has traditionally been only a small producer of maize, with output dropping to a low of 3.1m tonnes in 2010/11. However, like the situation in neighbouring Ukraine, harvested area has nearly tripled over this period, to a new peak of 2.9m ha in the current season. Owing to disappointing yields, production in 2017/18 is expected to dip to 14m tonnes, down by 8% from last season's record but still 18% above the recent average. This will limit this season's exportable surplus to around 4.2m tonnes, still enough to retain the country's position as the world's fifth-largest exporter.
Stocks and prices
Owing to the upgraded US figure, we have raised our forecast for global maize stocks in 2017/18 slightly, to 329m tonnes (324m tonnes previously), down by just 0.7% year on year. Following a detailed reassessment of China's maize supply and demand numbers over the past decade, we recently raised our estimate of world stockpiles by 60%. Maize production in China is trending lower, and with consumption expected to rise strongly in the years ahead, it has become clear that our previous forecast was too conservative and would have resulted in the depletion of China's stocks in just a few years. With feed use adjusted lower from 2011/12 onwards, projections for China's stocks were lifted across the whole period and are now forecast at 201m tonnes at the end of 2017/18, a figure much closer to that circulating in the local press. We now expect China to account for 62% of total world stocks (40% previously). Yet with so much uncertainty about the size, location and quality of its stocks, many analysts prefer to exclude China when modelling world inventories. Combined stocks in the four main maize exporters (Argentina, Brazil, Ukraine and the US) are forecast to remain above the recent average in 2017/18, at a total of 76.2m tonnes, up by 5.2% year on year, with more than three-quarters of these concentrated in the US. A relatively sharp drop is predicted in 2018/19, to 310m tonnes. Although exporter stocks will also tighten further, overall market supplies will remain at comfortable levels.
China's stock estimate is revised sharply higher
China's grain stocks have long been considered a state secret, with all parts of the grain balance sheet quite notional and based on limited information. Sometimes the assumptions are proven to be incorrect, as highlighted by new information or a change in underlying market conditions. Although our revised stock forecast diverges from those of the USDA and other major forecasting bodies, it brings stocks in China much closer to the levels that have been widely reported in the local press in recent years, including figures quoted by key policy advisers and other Communist Party officials. We expect stocks to be drawn down further in 2018-19 as the government seeks to boost domestic consumption, particularly in the biofuels industry. However, given that these stocks are primarily held as a domestic food security measure, and with China being only a small importer, this is unlikely to influence global prices.

With consumption failing to keep track with the surge in supplies, US ending stocks are expected to rise for a fifth consecutive season by the end of 2017/18, reaching 63.2m tonnes, an 8.5% year-on-year gain. The stocks-to-use ratio is forecast at 20%, up by four percentage points from the season before and the highest since 2005/06, suggesting that supplies are very comfortable. Based on early projections for the next season, including another large crop and a marginal drop in consumption, carryover stocks are projected to decline by around 3m tonnes, to 60.2m tonnes, still well above average. After a series of huge US crops, a grain storage crunch has been reported in many states in recent years, with many farmers reluctant to sell at low prices. Kansas has faced a particularly acute shortage, partly because of producers switching area from lower-yielding wheat to maize crops. However, shortfalls have been noted in the traditional maize states of Illinois, Iowa and Nebraska too. Plastic silo bags have been a quick, low-cost solution for many growers, allowing grains to be stored cheaply directly on the farm. While this offers logistical advantages, allowing farmers to avoid storage and handling fees, the maize being stored must already be at the desired moisture content and the silo bags still require active monitoring in order to avoid rupture losses.
Prices are unlikely to show any significant growth in 2018-19
World maize prices have eased slightly in recent months, averaging 9% lower year on year in late November. Although US export prices were initially pulled higher by concerns about worse than normal Midwest crop conditions, early summer gains have eroded as participants shed speculative long positions on signs that final yields would outperform earlier expectations. Light seasonal harvest pressure has also weighed on markets recently as newly harvested supplies added to bountiful US stockpiles, with speculative non-commercial funds establishing a record net short position in CME corn futures. Export prices in South America ticked slightly higher in recent weeks, as farmers there become more reluctant sellers given heightened concerns about recent dry weather, possibly linked to a La Niña weather event. Although upside risk remains, if a damaging weather pattern were to emerge over the coming months, maize market fundamentals currently point to a low price environ-ment. We expect prices to rise slightly from the fourth quarter of 2017; however, given ample global stocks and easy feedgrain availabilities, prices are likely to stay well below recent peaks in 2018-19.

Palm oil
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global palm oil consumption to accelerate over the 2017/18 and 2018/19 seasons, by 2.6% and 3.3% respectively. Nonetheless, these growth rates remain fairly moderate, below the previous five-year average of 4.5%. With the exception of sunflowerseed oil, palm oil's discount to other major oils is above normal levels which will stimulate additional consumption. However, negative sentiment against palm oil and palm oil-based biodiesel in the US and EU continues to weigh on demand there. Both Indonesia and Malaysia are looking for growth opportunities, with the biodiesel market in China the most likely to generate demand.
India will remain the largest market for palm oil
Changes in duties applied to imported palm oil will constrain Indian consumption growth in 2017/18. Nonetheless, strong overall GDP growth in the coming seasons will help to support demand. We have raised our forecast for 2017/18 palm oil consumption slightly, to 5% (4.8% previously), a growth rate in line with recent averages. We expect a similar growth rate, of 4.5%, in 2018/19, bringing consumption up to a total of10.3m tonnes.
Indonesia's biodiesel sector will post decent growth in 2016/17 and 2017/18
Prospects for palm oil demand in Indonesia have been encouraged by recent increases in forecasts of prices for mineral oil. However, the biodiesel industry in Indonesia is searching for new markets to make up for the loss of sales in the US. The recent implementation by the EU of reduced duties for Argentinian biodiesel is expected to be followed by a similar reduction for Indonesian biodiesel. A decision by the World Trade Organisation (WTO) on EU anti-dumping duties on Indonesian supplies is expected in December 2017. At this stage, we maintain our forecast that Indonesia's palm oil consumption will expand by 6.1% in 2017/18, to 9.8m tonnes. In 2018/19 we expect lower demand for biodiesel exports to limit Indonesia's palm oil consumption growth to 2.8%, to just over 10m tonnes.
China's palm oil demand is hindered by competition from soybean oil
Palm oil will continue to face strong competition from soybean oil in China in 2017/18. However, there is some hope of recovery in 2018/19, owing partly to a sustained recovery in instant noodle production, as higher quality products have rekindled consumer interest. More significantly, the planned expansion of biodiesel use has the potential to absorb large quantities of palm oil. Rising demand for biofuels underpins our forecast for steady demand growth of 3.7% per year on average in 2017/18-2018/19, to reach a total of 5.4m tonnes in the 2018/19 season.
Energy demand in the EU will rise, boosting usage
The market for palm oil in the EU has been broadly flat since 2013/14, hovering around 7.2m tonnes. However, EU consumption is likely to slip modestly during the forecast period. In the biodiesel sector, palm oil faces increased competition in some member states from recycled fats and oils, while sustainability concerns hang over medium-term consumption prospects. Palm oil imports in the season to date are marginally above year-earlier levels, although this is thought to be mainly to replenish low stocks. We forecast EU palm oil consumption to slip marginally, to 7.1m tonnes. Biodiesel consumption in the EU is expected to increase over the next two years, reflecting changes in incorporation mandates. While other feed-stocks are likely to be the main beneficiaries of this growth, palm oil consumption volumes should be maintained. Palm oil's use in the edible sector is also likely to be maintained, and as a result we expect consumption to remain fairly flat in 2018/19.
Biodiesel consumption in Malaysia faces challenges
Malaysian palm oil consumption was hampered in 2016/17 by delays in implementing biodiesel incorporation mandates. These delays are unlikely to be resolved in the near future, despite government efforts to get the B10 mandate accepted by automobile manufacturers. However, there are reports of increasing biodiesel exports. Despite this, we have made a further small reduction in our forecasts for consumption in 2017/18 and 2018/19 to reflect the sluggish growth for biodiesel in local markets.
Prospects for palm oil consumption in other countries are broadly positive
The top five consumers account for less than 55% of global demand, and a large number of other countries also consume palm oil. A number of these countries are the target of palm oil exporters, especially in Africa and the Middle East. For example, recent reports highlight strong growth in palm oil imports into Ghana. The largest of these "other" consumers, Pakistan, is also showing steady growth in palm oil consumption. Attempts to encourage local oilseeds production have been largely unsuccessful since neither sunflowerseed nor rapeseed fit in with more profitable crops. By 2018/19 Pakistan's palm oil consumption should be at almost 3m tonnes, similar to expected consumption in Malaysia. Buying activity from these other consumers is reported to be increasing, supporting steady consumption growth over the forecast period.

Supply
Our forecast of global palm oil output in 2017/18 remains virtually unchanged, at 68.9m tonnes. A small reduction in our estimate of output in Indonesia is offset by small increases for Malaysia and Colombia. At 4.9%, our production growth forecast for 2017/18 is in line with the previous five-year average. In 2018/19 we expect growth to slip further, to a marginal 1.2%, owing to the impact of stressed trees and a slowdown in mature areas growth.
Yields in Indonesia are slowly recovering from the 2015/16 drought
There has been a further increase in estimates of Indonesia's palm oil output in 2016/17. The most recent data indicate production of 36.3m tonnes, more than 15% higher than the previous season. The age profile of Indonesia's oil palms explains the strong rise in yields, which have outstripped those in all other palm oil producers. Yields are likely to rise further in 2017/18, albeit at a slower rate. We forecast production of 37.7m tonnes, representing a below-average growth rate of 3.8%. In 2018/19 the larger mature area is likely to offset any negative effects from the slower rate of planting. We forecast output of 38.6m tonnes in 2018/19. This forecast represents yields below trend; the relatively low prices are likely to result in low usage of crop inputs.
Malaysian production is set to return to 2013/14 peak by 2017/18
The recovery in Malaysia's October palm oil production mentioned in our last issue has been substantially exceeded by the official estimate of production in that month. Recorded output has been put at 20% higher than October 2016. Over the 2017/18 season as a whole, we expect Malaysian palm oil production to reach 20.3m tonnes (20.2m tonnes previously). Given the difficulties of finding new land for planting, growth in Malaysian output relies on replacing ageing trees with younger, higher-yield trees. The rate of replanting in recent years has been too low to prevent a slump in yields. As a result, we expect yields to be comparatively low in 2018/19, at 20.2m tonnes, especially as input use is likely to contract.
For Thailand, we expect an increase in the mature area to ensure continued growth in palm oil output in 2017/18, despite low prices inhibiting the use of crop inputs. We forecast output of 2.2m tonnes, marginally above 2016/17 levels. Difficulties in securing new land for planting will inhibit future growth, although the improving age profile will help yields. The slow growth in palm oil output is expected to result in a lower target for biodiesel use in Thailand. We expect Colombian output to grow steadily over the forecast period as its mature area expands. The recent peace agreement with the FARC may open up even more land for palm oil cultivation. Recent yields have largely been above year-earlier levels, and returns to the crop have been favourable. A higher biodiesel incorporation rate mandate should also help to maintain interest in the crop.

Stocks and prices
Recorded palm oil stocks in Malaysia and Indonesia have continued to increase. With palm oil production now set to reduce seasonally, stocks are likely to remain comparatively tight for the first half of the 2017/18 season. However, over the season as a whole, the market surplus will be greater than in 2016/17 and will allow stocks to recover to higher than normal levels. At the end of the 2017/18 season we expect that palm oil stocks will be at the equivalent of 71 days of average consumption, a level similar to that at the end of the 2014/15 season. Current projections suggest that stocks will continue to rise in 2018/19.

Rising stock levels will push prices down further in 2018
Physical prices for palm oil increased in November, helped by rising prices for other oils, especially for rapeseed oil. Futures prices have been relatively stable from September to the end of October, but have since declined. We expect physical prices to follow the downward trend in futures prices and to be persistently weak throughout the 2017/18 season. However, there remain significant uncertainties about the prospective increases in production, and markets are likely to show only small declines until evidence of the production growth is more firmly established. Given the seasonal decline in palm oil production, which typically lasts until February, price falls during the first and second quarters of 2018 may be relatively modest. Price declines are likely to be larger during the second half of 2018 and into 2019. By the end of 2019, prices are forecast to be below US$600/tonne, a low not seen since the end of 2015.

Rapeseed oil
Demand
Higher international prices for rapeseed oil are having a negative effect on consumption, despite an anticipated rise in mineral oil prices over the forecast period. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global rapeseed oil consumption to contract for the third consecutive year in 2017/18, by 1.7%, to only 24.7m tonnes. This is well below the 27m tonnes recorded in 2014/15 and 2015/16. An expected recovery in rapeseed oil output will help to push consumption up by nearly 5% in 2018/19, to 25.9m tonnes, with all the major consuming countries recording growth with the exception of India. However, low stocks are likely to prevent faster consumption growth.
EU consumption in 2016/17 will be limited by availability
Rising imports of Argentinian biodiesel are already having a negative effect on EU rapeseed oil consumption in 2017/18. An expected resumption of Indonesian biodiesel imports in mid-2018 will also be problematic. In addition, sunflowerseed oil will continue to provide strong competition in the food sector. On the positive side, a forecast increase in mineral oil prices from 2018 will be supportive of EU rapeseed oil demand. We have made a small upward revision to our forecast to reflect this but we do not expect EU consumption to reach the 10m-tonne mark (last seen in 2015/16) during the forecast period. An increase in domestic production of rapeseed oil in 2018/19 should allow consumption to grow, by a modest 0.6%, as the competitive pressures on rapeseed oil persist.
Demand in China will be aided in 2018/19 by the release of reserve stocks
In China, limited stocks of rapeseed will exert negative pressure on potential consumption. Imports of rapeseed oil to date have been disappointing, although these have been partly offset by higher imports of canola for local crushing. At 5.1m tonnes, rapeseed oil consumption in 2017/18 will be at its lowest level over the past decade. The forecast is vulnerable to any change in price differentials, especially between rapeseed oil and palm oil (the latter is currently trending upward). Any increase in consumption in 2018/19 relies on a recovery in local availability. Rapeseed remains a relatively unprofitable crop, and the planting area in 2017/18 was further hit by poor conditions. We expect the planted area to rise again to normal levels in 2018/19, which would allow a recovery in local availability, consistent with our consumption forecast of 5.8m tonnes.
India's consumption will rebound in 2016/17 in line with local availability
An improving outlook for domestic availability, together with strong real GDP growth levels, should stimulate rapeseed oil consumption in India during 2017/18. However, the continuing increases in import duties on vegetable oils may cause increases in internal prices, which could dampen any consumption growth. We have retained our 2017/18 forecast of consumption in excess of 2.5m tonnes. However, this forecast implies an increasing volume of rapeseed oil imports and is therefore vulnerable to changes in international rapeseed oil availability and competition from other oils.
Only modest demand growth is likely in the US market
Imports of rapeseed oil into the US continue to sustain consumption growth. The recent application of anti-dumping duties on biodiesel from Argentina and Indonesia could stimulate additional demand for rapeseed oil as a feedstock during the forecast period. Overall, we expect US rapeseed oil consumption to continue to grow steadily, to reach 2.9m tonnes in the 2018/19 season. Several smaller consumers have switched away from rapeseed oil during 2016/17-a pattern that is likely to continue into 2017/18 as a result of its comparatively high price relative to other oils. A recovery in consumption among these "other" consumers is now expected to be delayed until 2018/19.

a Years ending September 30th.
Supply
We expect a further, although marginal, decline in global rapeseed oil production in 2017/18. Our revised assessment puts total output at 24.5m tonnes, down by 0.8% year on year (from a decrease of 1.1% previously). There remains significant uncertainty over crop sizes, mainly in Canada and Australia. Assuming that current forecasts are realised, stocks of rapeseed/canola would allow a small increase in oil production. The main reduction occurs in the large number of "other" producers (including Mexico, Japan and Pakistan) who are expected to respond to higher prices of rapeseed with smaller crush volumes. Output in 2018/19 will, of course, depend on a recovery in rapeseed production. A return to normal yields will be the main element of any increase and would allow a significant jump in rapeseed oil output in 2018/19. We forecast output of 25.9m tonnes.
The EU rapeseed crop will recover only partially in 2017/18
Despite the small local crop, EU rapeseed crushers managed to produce more than 10m tonnes of rapeseed oil during 2016/17, only marginally below the 2015/16 total. Output in the 2017/18 season should also easily exceed 10m tonnes given that EU farmers have produced almost 22m tonnes of rapeseed. Current rapeseed import levels are running well above year-earlier levels, although these rates are likely to slow later in the season given the small Australian crop. Our current output forecast is consistent with lower import levels over the season as a whole. Reports suggest a small drop in winter rapeseed sowings in the EU despite favourable prices for rapeseed compared with wheat. Poor weather at sowing time is responsible for the fall. Our forecast of 2018/19 rapeseed oil production is lower, and now stands at 10.6m tonnes, just below the record output of 10.7m tonnes recorded in 2014/15.
Chinese production will fall in 2016/17
The uncertainty surrounding estimates of the Chinese rapeseed crop continues. We estimate just over 5m tonnes for the 2017/18 rapeseed crop. China's rapeseed oil production increasingly relies on imported rapeseed/canola through the additional capacity located at ports. We continue to forecast 2017/18 rapeseed oil production to be only marginally higher than that of 2016/17, at 3.6m tonnes. Output at this level implies a significant increase in rapeseed imports which may be difficult to achieve. Although rapeseed oil and rapeseed prices are likely to be higher, it remains unclear whether Chinese farmers will respond by higher plantings for the 2018/19 season. Instead, it is more likely that higher rapeseed oil production for the 2018/19 season will require yet more imports. We forecast oil output to expand to almost 4m tonnes for 2018/19.
Canada's 2016/17 harvest may be below expectations
Despite the early harvest, the size of the 2017 Canadian canola harvest remains uncertain. Statistics Canada releases its final harvest estimate in December, but trade estimates put the total higher than previously thought, at more than 20m tonnes. Assuming that this higher estimate is confirmed, Canadian crushing during 2017/18 will expand from previously projected levels. We have increased our estimate of Canadian canola oil production to just over 4m tonnes. Canola remains an attractive crop to Canadian farmers, and we assume an expansion of the planted area in 2018/19 to levels similar to the 2012/13 record. Normal yields should allow canola oil output to rise further, to 4.2m tonnes.
India's production is poised for a rebound in 2016/17
In India, 2016/17 rapeseed oil production of 2.1m tonnes was well below potential output based on the size of the rapeseed crop that season. The higher carry-in stocks of rapeseed will be required to maintain domestic rapeseed oil production. The monsoon season was recorded as normal and should, in principle, allow at least average yields for the 2017/18 rapeseed crop. However, there was significant regional variation in the rainfall totals, and the distribution of rainfall was weighted towards the early part of the season. Estimates of rape-seed sowings suggest that the area planted is about 10% lower than normal. Estimates of the size of the 2017/18 rapeseed crop therefore err on the cautious side. Normal yields would result in a crop of 6.1m tonnes. This would allow only a modest increase in 2017/18 rapeseed oil production, to 2.2m tonnes.

Australian production is likely to fall in 2017/18 owing to dry conditions
There is considerable uncertainty over the 2017/18 canola crop in Australia, with estimates ranging from 2.6m tonnes to 3.2m tonnes. It appears that yields in Western Australia may not be as bad as previously feared, but the harvest in the eastern states has been hampered by poor weather. We forecast 3m tonnes for 2017/18, well below the 4.4m tonnes harvested in 2016/17 and the lowest total since 2010/11. In Ukraine, official estimates of the 2017/18 rapeseed crop put the total at 2.2m tonnes. With winter planting now ended, the area of winter rapeseed has further expanded, with the crop in generally good condition.
Stocks and prices
We expect to see the global market remain in deficit in 2017/18, for the fourth consecutive season. However, revisions to supply and consumption forecasts this month mean that the deficit is lower, at only 200,000 tonnes (560,000 tonnes previously). At the end of the 2017/18 season, rapeseed oil stocks (when measured against consumption), will be the equivalent of 23 days' consumption, a low not seen since the 2006/07-2007/08 seasons. However, rapeseed stocks will remain available during 2017/18 and could result in higher crushings than currently expected. On the supply side of the seed market, the only major uncertainty is the size of the Indian crop to be harvested in the February-April 2018 period. Our current forecast suggests that the market will be near balance in 2018/19. However, this can only be achieved through low rapeseed stocks.

Low stocks will put upward pressure on prices from late 2017
Physical prices of rapeseed oil increased significantly in November-indeed, they recorded the largest increase among the major vegetable oils. Futures markets for canola/rapeseed in Canada and Europe both increased through to mid-November, but have eased somewhat since. Sustained price rises are the most likely course for rapeseed oil prices, although price gains will be limited by the high availability of other oils. However, prices look set to rise persistently, to reach US$940 by the end of 2018. Further price rises during 2019 could see prices edge up towards US$975/tonne.

Rice
Demand
With human consumption of rice continuing to drive up overall use in Asia, where populations are rising, global rice demand is expected to reach a new high of 494m tonnes in 2017/18, up by almost 1.6% from the previous season. As in the past, relatively small volume increases are likely in other regions, such as Africa and South America. However, other components of demand, such as feed and the industrial sector, are expected to contract. The outlook for the 2018/19 season depends on factors that will remain unknown for quite some time, such as policy frameworks, local crop outcomes and import needs. As such, our projection of 502m tonnes rests on the assumption that annual consumption growth will return close to trend.
Trade in rice will continue to grow, but at a slower rate than in 2017
Africa and Asia account for three-quarters of all rice imports, primarily white and parboiled grades sourced from Thailand, India, Pakistan and Vietnam. In Sub-Saharan Africa particularly, a significant share of demand-mainly for high-quality white and parboiled supplies-is met by imports. With buyers in those regions expected to remain active in the global market, trade is projected to continue to grow in the next two years, to reach 44.5m tonnes in 2019, the largest volume on record. However, growth will be relatively marginal, as it is assumed that many Asian buyers are likely to be well stocked after the heavy purchases in 2017/18. Further strong demand for Thai rice from African buyers in 2017 was largely linked to availabilities of attractively priced rice from the government's stockpile. With the bulk of that now sold, demand should taper.
China's needs are expected to be central to the rice trade in 2018-19
China is the world's largest consumer of rice by far, accounting for about 30% of global demand. The bulk of national consumption is made up of locally produced rice, but in recent years China has also become the biggest importer of rice, mainly of high-quality broken types from Thailand and Vietnam. Prices for domestic long-grain milled rice still command hefty premiums over supplies from other major origins in Asia, owing to the easy availability of rice from major suppliers outside China, supporting China's import demand.
Lower duties will encourage rice imports by Bangladesh in 2018-19
Bangladesh is one of the leading rice markets within Asia, with annual demand reaching at least 35m tonnes. Three domestic crops are cut each year, namely the boro (seeded in December-January and harvested in April-May), aus (planted in March-April and cut in June-July) and aman (sown in July-August and normally threshed in November-December). Although the bulk of the country's rice needs are met by domestic crops, significant quantities are sometimes procured from the world market. Bangladesh importers and millers have sought to get tariffs reduced as a means of boosting imports, primarily from Thailand and India, with the latter typically the largest supplier in recent years. The country has recently entered into a long-term arrangement with Vietnam for up to 1m tonnes of imports per year until 2022. Trade reports have also highlighted the possibility of significant purchases from Myanmar.
The government is looking to boost rice imports to build reserves and rein in local prices after flash floods hit domestic output. To this end, the government announced a tariff reduction from 28% to 10% on rice imports in mid-2017.
The Philippines may be a large buyer, as state reserves are historically low.
In the Philippines, stocks held by the National Food Authority, the grain procurement agency, have dwindled to their lowest level in about a decade. By contrast, however, inventories held by private households and commercial warehouses remain especially comfortable. Underscoring thin state reserves, imports progressed strongly over the course of 2017, with the total for the first six months of the year at 530,000 tonnes, an 80% increase on the same period of 2016. Purchases are likely to remain high in the following years.
