Supply
Our forecast for world rice production in 2017/18 has been revised down further, by 3m tonnes, to 484m tonnes, representing a marginal retreat from the record of 2016/17. Although this would be the second largest crop ever harvested, with stellar outturns expected in much of Asia on the basis of area increases and better yields, the fall mainly reflects prospects for reduced output in India and the US. The outlook for 2018/19 is highly provisional. Nonetheless, given that only a small expansion of paddy plantings is likely, an increase in global output will almost certainly be dependent on better yields. At nearly 492m tonnes, the world outturn is projected to be up by 1.5% year on year. All of our scenarios assume continued state support to farmers in Asia and beneficial weather conditions.
The 2017 monsoon was 5% below average, reducing output slightly
India's main agricultural crops are cultivated during two distinct seasons: kharif crops are sown between June and October and rabi crops in November-December. Kharif crops, of which rice is by far the most important, are rain-fed and therefore critically reliant on monsoon precipitation, which typically arrives in the southern state of Kerala in early June and lasts for about four months, accounting for 70% of the country's annual rains.
In India, where the kharif-planting season was completed by early October, the area planted to paddy was slightly smaller year on year, but still fairly solid compared with the average of recent seasons. The 2017 monsoon was around 5% below the long-term average; taking into account its impact on yield potential in some regions, as well as prospects for the winter-sown rabi crop, we project total acreage to be broadly steady year on year. Accordingly, we have revised down slightly our forecast for full-year output in 2017/18, by a further 500,000 tonnes, to 108m tonnes, representing a small contraction year on year. Nevertheless, this should still ensure that availabilities for domestic use and exports are sufficiently comfortable. In 2018/19 everything will again depend on the pattern of the monsoon, which will begin around June 1st 2018.
India should remain the biggest rice exporter during the forecast period
Based on their continued robust pace to date, which has been supported by large ship-ments to Africa and South Asia, India's exports in 2017 are expected to reach 10.7m tonnes, making it the largest supplier to the world market for the sixth consecutive season. Shipments in 2018 are likely to be slightly smaller year on year, at 10.5m tonnes. We assume that in 2019 competition from Thailand and, to a lesser extent, Vietnam, will result in sales of 10.8m tonnes.
China's exports have expanded in 2017, mainly because of sales to Africa
Although China has emerged as the world's biggest importer of rice in recent years, it has, for the most part, been a tiny exporter. Over recent seasons its exports have fluctuated between 200,000 tonnes and 500,000 tonnes, with most heading to markets in Asia, including South Korea and Japan-these being part of minimum commitments to import by those nations under World Trade Organisation obligations. Shipments normally comprise mostly small and medium-grain varieties.
Exports could surpass 1m tonnes in 2017, before receding slightly
The current year has been much different, however, with unusually large shipments of long-grain rice recorded in each month. Data from the General Administration of Customs show that total (cumulative) exports in January-September reached around 890,000 tonnes, compared to just 239,000 tonnes in the same period of 2016, with particularly heavy deliveries to Cote d'Ivoire, Senegal and Sierra Leone. It is unclear whether such high sales can be sustained, especially since some of these shipments may have come in the form of food aid. Nevertheless, it is worth noting that China is believed to sit on massive state reserves, of at least 120m tonnes on a paddy weight basis, despite a significant share of it being unfit for human consumption. China's exports have occasionally risen above 2m tonnes, notably in 2003, with much of the increase going to Africa and the Americas. For the 2017 year in full, volumes could be as large as 1.1m tonnes, but are likely to fall in 2018 and 2019.
Production prospects for 2017/18 in Thailand are positive
For many years Thailand was the biggest supplier of rice to world markets. However, a combination of its intervention buying programme in earlier years (beginning in late 2011) and heavy competition from India resulted in it losing that position. More recently, exports have been boosted by availabilities from the government's stockpile, but prospects for production will ultimately shape the country's exportable surplus over the next two years.
In the current season (2017/18) prospects for the main crop appear solid, with harvesting due to take place in the latter stages of the current year. Cultivation is currently in the reproductive stage and progressing well. Cummulative precipitation during 2017 is estimated to be around one-quarter higher than average, while the impact of flooding in September was minimal. Good water levels will also be important during the development of the irrigated, off-season crop, which will be threshed next year. Assuming the planted area is expanded in both seasons, total production is projected at 20.4m tonnes, up from 19m tonnes in the previous year and a five-year high. A further increase in main-crop sowings is projected to push output up to 22m tonnes in 2018/19.
The government will support farmers to store rice from the main harvest
In mid-September the Thai government approved a THB73bn (US$2.2bn) budget for 2017/18 on farm paddy pledging program to include main-crop rice varieties from November 1st 2017 through to the end of February 2018. The scheme is aimed at supporting domestic prices during the main crop harvest, with up to 2m tonnes of paddy set to be procured. The intervention price for white rice is 3% above that of the previous season. Additional measures have been announced, with farmers, millers and traders also receiving support in the form of subsidies and soft loans, as a means of encouraging participants to store rice through to 2018.
In mid-November 2017 the government announced the extension of a deadline to offload outstanding old rice stocks (estimated at about 2m tonnes) for animal feed and industrial use. The deadline for sales was pushed back into 2018, so as to counter the potential for oversupply in the local market, especially at a time when the main crop harvest is underway. Nevertheless, the fact that just a small amount of stocks remain to be sold represents a dramatic turnaround from May 2014 when the military administration inherited a stockpile of close to 19m tonnes. Exports of all varieties of rice totalled 9.2m tonnes during the first ten months of 2017, representing a strong increase on the same period of the previous year. For the year in full, we now expect Thailand to sell 10.3m tonnes, up from 9.9m tonnes in the previous calendar year owing to significant sales to markets in Africa, as well as to non-traditional buyers in Asia such as Bangladesh. In the coming years, volumes are likely to edge lower but stay high.
Vietnam faces competition from smaller and established exporters in Asia
Vietnam is a medium-sized rice producer but a major exporter. It typically accounts for 5-6% of global output but 15% of exports, making it the world's third-largest exporter behind India and Thailand. Vietnam's exporters have performed well in 2017, with bigger sales to a number of markets in Asia pushing up total volumes in January-November to a forecast 5.5m tonnes, around 25% higher than in the same period of the previous calendar year. Analysis of customs data show that, although exports to African nations were smaller year-on-year, China bought considerably bigger amounts from Vietnam, as did the Philippines, a longstanding traditional buyer. However, a real boon for the nation was firm demand from Bangladesh, a country that has tended to source its import requirements from India. However, the need to build stocks after local supplies came up short meant that the government diversified its origins for imports. We expect Vietnam to maintain its position as the world's third biggest exporter in 2018-19 and beyond, although volumes are unlikely to exceed 7m tonnes in any season, given continued heavy sales by India and Thailand, as well as growing competition from other, relatively small exporters such as Cambodia and Myanmar.
A much smaller crop will constrain US rice exports in 2017/18
The US rice harvest was completed during October. Based on a heavy drop in plantings, production in 2017/18 is officially estimated to have fallen to just 5.7m tonnes, down from 7.1m tonnes in the previous season. This would be the smallest outturn in more than two decades, and is expected to tighten availabilities for sale on the international market, notwith-standing a drop in domestic use. Nevertheless, the contraction will be limited by large opening stocks. Shipments in the local marketing year, starting on August 1st 2017, are forecast at 3.4m tonnes, down from 3.6m tonnes in the previous year. US rice is sold globally, but major markets, mainly for paddy (rough rice) exports, include Central and Latin America, owing to proximity.
A smaller crop is likely in Brazil in 2017/18 as yields retreat
Conab, the official supply agency of Brazil, released its first formal outlook for rice supply and demand in 2017/18 in early October. The southern state of Rio Grande do Sul is the most important producing region, accounting for the bulk of acreage. Together with other states, rice plantings for the 2017/18 crop, which will be harvested in the first half of the following year, was expected to hold steady compared to 2016/17, at around 2m hectares. But with the agency expecting yields to fall away from the previous year's level, production (paddy weight basis) was forecast to fall by 4% year on year, to 11.8m tonnes. Aside from the potential for bigger plantings in Rio Grande do Sul, there appears limited potential for an increase in area anywhere else in the country in the longer term. In 2018/19 production is expected to ease to 11.5m tonnes.
The South Korean rice sector is relatively small compared with India and China. The planted area has steadily fallen over a number of decades, although this has been partly offset by improved yields, helping production-of japonica varieties-to stay high enough to meet domestic consumption needs. The decline in seeding is linked to increased demand for land for residential and commercial purposes, as well as a switch to other relatively profitable cash crops. To this end, the government has also requested that local rice farmers cultivate other crops instead of paddy, with a rice reduction programme to be introduced in 2018.
Total rice consumption in South Korea is forecast at 4.9m tonnes in 2017/18, broadly equivalent to around 1% of global use, representing a modest increase from the year before. Although rice consumption by humans is declining owing to continued rising incomes and the increased inclusion of western foods in diets, feed use is likely to expand due to the existence of ample government stocks. According to industry reports, around 700,000 tonnes of rice is expected to be channelled into the feed sector in 2018.

Stocks and prices
Our forecast for global rice stocks remains unchanged, with inventories forecast to fall appreciably in 2017/18, to a seven-year low of 95.2m tonnes. Although we expect China's supportive policies for farmers to ensure another rise in inventories, this will be in contrast to falls in the major global suppliers, as well as in other countries. Inventories held by the world's leading exporters, which also include India, Pakistan, the US and Vietnam, are forecast at 22m tonnes, down by 5m tonnes year on year. This would be the smallest amount in a decade and highlights a global market that appears to be tighter than headline figures might suggest.
Stocks are expected to drop in the next two seasons on rising consumption
In 2018/19 although world output is still expected to climb from this season's record level, rising consumption will also cut into stocks, pushing them to another multi-year low of 85m tonnes. It is assumed that stockbuilding in China will continue, especially since imports are set to remain high, but exporters' reserves may fall once more, to just 21m tonnes, the bulk of which will be located in India.

Markets for export grades of white and parboiled rice in Asia exhibited contrasting trends during the month of November. Compared with October, quotations for broken rice in Thailand rose significantly; the 100% B grade rose by 5% to US$403/tonne fob Bangkok, the highest since the closing days of September. The pace of exports has provided some support to the market during 2017. Since it is understood that the Thai government has sold off all its food quality stocks, availability for the world market has become tight, especially with harvesting of the main season crop still ongoing.
In Vietnam, where exporters have enjoyed a solid year, quotations initially fell before edging up because of thin, old, crop stocks-highlighted by expectations that the end-season carry-over stocks expected will be much smaller year on year. As a result, prices on November 27th were steady compared with four weeks ago. In India, where the focus is on the main kharif crop harvest, export values have eased, with the 5% broken grade down by US$7, to US$393 fob.
In contrast, the US market for milled rice has recorded sharp gains in 2017, almost entirely due to a season in which domestic production has fallen significantly because of a large fall in long-grain plantings. In late November Gulf quotations for 4% broken stood at US$518/tonne fob, a shade higher than a month earlier but almost 30% above equivalent offers in November 2016.
Our price projections for Thailand's 100% B grade are again subject to some minor revisions, although this does not change the broader fundamental backdrop. In the final quarter of 2017 prices are expected to average US$385/tonne, feeding through to a full-year value of US$388/tonne, only a fraction above the previous year's average. Our supply and demand forecasts suggest there is potential for some upward pressure on prices as global supplies begin to tighten, owing to contractions in major exporters. By the fourth quarter of 2019 we forecast a price of US$425/tonne and, while this would equate to a five-year high, it would still be well below the levels witnessed in 2009-13. Another gentle rise to US$430/tonne is likely in the first quarter of 2020.

Soybeans
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts global consumption of soybeans to expand by 4.9% year on year 2017/18, to a record of 341m tonnes. This will partly be driven by rising demand for meat-and therefore animal feed ingredients, including high-protein oilseed meals-in China and many other Asian countries. Although we expect growth to slow relative to that in 2016/17, it will match the average of the two previous seasons. Looking beyond Asia, some smaller consuming regions, including the EU, Africa and the Middle East, will also contribute to rising demand. We expect a similar rate of demand growth in 2018/19, owing to rising usage in animal feed. However, uncertainty regarding crop yields poses a downside risk to this forecast.
We have revised up our forecast for global soybean trade slightly, to almost 150m tonnes in 2017/18. This will be the seventh consecutive year of expansion, due mostly to rising demand from China, as well as some smaller markets in Asia. With demand from these countries expected to increase again in 2018/19, trade could approach 155m tonnes in that season.
Feed usage will drive overall demand up and will mostly be met by imports
China is by far the world's largest consumer and importer of soybeans, with growth largely driven by expanding demand from the country's vast animal feed sector. In 2017/18 we expect China's total consumption to reach a new record of 107m tonnes, representing impressive growth of about 8% and approaching one-third of the amount used globally. Imports are forecast to total 100m tonnes, or more than 90% of consumption, highlighting the global market's dependence on Chinese processors. Although the government is looking to boost local output, it seems that imports will continue to account for a dominant and possibly rising share of overall requirements, especially in feed sectors. Most of what is produced locally is likely to be channelled to food and other smaller markets.
China's imports in 2018/19 are expected to exceed 100m tonnes
Despite reports of large stocks of soybeans and associated pressure on crush margins, import demand growth has remained robust throughout 2017, with buyers encouraged by ample global supply and attractive prices. The outlook for 2018/19 is tentative, but China's full-season purchases are likely to reach 104m tonnes.
Nonetheless, the Chinese government's intention to end maize stockpiling, announced in 2016, remains a downside risk. The move aims to encourage the use of maize at the expense of other feed grains, which have been imported in great quantities in recent years. Higher maize consumption in the pork and poultry sectors could also raise questions surrounding the use of high-protein meals, primarily soybean meal. However, the impact is expected to be marginal, as soybean meal is the most abundantly produced oilseed meal, and provides both higher protein quality and nutritional value compared with alternatives.
Ample domestic supplies will support demand in the US
With another bumper crop expected to result in a further swelling of domestic supplies, US consumption in 2017/18 is forecast to remain close to the previous season's high, at 56m tonnes. Aside from local requirements, total use will be underpinned by rising exports of soybean meal. Similar trends will enable domestic demand to edge up in 2018/19, to 57m tonnes.
Soybean consumption in Argentina will continue to be driven by growing international demand for soybean meal, of which Argentina is the dominant supplier. In Brazil, further increases in consumption are anticipated as bigger local soybean crops boost supplies for processing.
Imports are central to EU requirements
The EU has achieved successively larger record crops in recent seasons. Nevertheless, at less than 3m tonnes, domestic outturns represent only a tiny share of overall requirements, with combined imports of soybeans and soybean meal typically accounting for up to 35m tonnes. In 2017/18 imports of soybeans are likely to rise after the previous season's fall, but any increase is likely to be capped by a much better local rapeseed harvest. In 2018/19 and beyond, availabilities of alternatives, including rapeseed, will play a crucial role in determining volume requirements. Throughout the period we expect the region's soybean meal imports to remain above 20m tonnes, making it easily the world's largest buyer of soybean meal (while China remains the largest buyer of soybeans).

Supply
Although planting is now under way in Latin America's leading producers, considerable uncertainty remains over prospects for the global outturn in 2017/18. Never-theless, in the northern hemisphere another season of large harvests is expected, judging by completed and intended plantings and early field reports. We expect these factors to support the second-largest harvest ever.
A notable increase in the global planted area is expected, but yields are unlikely to be replicated at the record level that was achieved in 2016/17. Accordingly, production is forecast to fall marginally year on year, to 342m tonnes. In 2018/19 output could recover slightly, but would still fall a little short of the 2016/17 high: our projection of a 0.8% increase year on year, to 345m tonnes, reflects our assumption of a slight rise in sowings and trend yields.
US production in 2017/18 is likely to set a new record owing to a larger area
The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) expects seeded area in 2017/18 to increase by around 7% year on year, to 36.2m ha, the largest on record. In addition to a switch of acreage from maize and spring wheat, expanded area also stems from a steep contraction in winter wheat sowings. Weather patterns during the current growing season were a cause for concern at times in parts of the Midwest, with dry and hot conditions in the east and the northern Plains, and excessive rains being a problem in eastern regions. It therefore seems likely that average yields will not match those of the previous year. Nonetheless, local official projections and recent field reports reflect a positive yield outlook.
At a record of 120.4m tonnes, output is expected to be almost 3% higher year on year in 2017/18. Together with high carryover stocks from the season before (which ends on August 31st), a crop of that size will ensure ample supplies for domestic use and export. We assume that recent delays to harvesting in parts of the Midwest will not have a detrimental effect.
US exports could establish a new record in 2017/18
US exports progressed strongly during the 2016/17 season, totalling 59m tonnes by August 31st 2017 (the close of the US marketing year), up by 5m tonnes from 2015/16. The solid pace was shaped by international demand from Asia, but also by a range of other, relatively small importers, including those in Africa and the Middle East. For 2017/18 we expect shipments to expand to at least 60m tonnes, a new record. Although the pace of sales has stepped up significantly in recent weeks, these remain well behind a year earlier. The slower pace is almost certainly linked to heavy shipments by Brazil, with some buyers hesitant to enter the world market, preferring to wait for northern hemisphere supplies to come on stream at attractive prices.
US growers are expected to reduce the area planted to soybeans in 2018/19
Planting intentions for 2018/19 in the northern hemisphere are tentative at this stage. In the US much will depend on relative prices at the time of planting, as well as crop rotation. Although there is an argument in favour of increased corn plantings at the expense of soybeans following 2017/18 seeding patterns, support for soybean acreage could come from the continued expansion of global trade, driven largely by China's needs. We anticipate that the area planted to soybeans in the US will fall by between 2% and 3% in 2018/19. Combined with yields, the outturn is projected at 114m tonnes, which is 5% lower than the previous season, but still the third-largest harvest on record.
A huge crop will be cut in Canada, with further increases likely in the long term
The area for harvest in Canada is estimated at a record of 2.9m ha in 2017/18, an unprecedented year-on-year expansion of 33%, driven by expanded acreage in the non-traditional growing areas of Manitoba and Saskatchewan, largely at the expense of wheat and canola. One of the key attractions is that Canadian growers are able to tap in to a fast-growing global market. Added to this, the crop requires less intensive application of inputs, such as fertilisers, compared with alternatives, and new varieties have been developed that can be cultivated in areas that were previously unsuitable. Despite the significant expansion of seeded area, some reduction in yields is expected, especially as earlier reports from Manitoba and Saskatchewan pointed to difficulties with crop development owing to challenging weather conditions. According to Canada's Department of Agriculture and Agri-Food, output is expected to increase by 1.5m tonnes to 8m tonnes in 2017/18. Exports are projected to rise to 5.6m tonnes, up from 4.4m tonnes in the previous season.
Brazil's exports are likely to smash previous records in 2017/18
Brazil's huge 2016/17 crop boosted availabilities to record levels and, given expected growth in trade, positioned Brazil to export significantly larger volumes in the local marketing year (which closes at end-January 2018). Our forecast remains unchanged, and we believe that total shipments could reach a record of 62m tonnes, up by 12.3% from the previous year. A marked rise in domestic prices in Brazil is unlikely, given current conditions, which means that farmers are likely to finish the season with larger than normal stocks.
After a sluggish start to the 2017/18 planting season in Brazil, progress has since been improved-especially during November, following the arrival of beneficial rains in central growing states. As at November 27th Ag Rural, a leading local consultancy, estimated plantings to be complete on 84% of the intended area, 5 percentage points ahead of the five-year average. In the main producing states of Parana and Mato Grosso, fieldwork was close to being finished. However, concern remains about a developing La Niña and its potential impact on crops there, as well as in Argentina, where conditions are already drier than normal. Moreover, Brazilian weather forecasters have pointed to the increased chance of a La Niña event, with drier than normal conditions in southern Brazil in December to February, and normal to above-normal rainfall in central Brazil.
Growth in sowings in Brazil is expected in 2017/18, but may be limited by low prices
With plenty of land available, a further expansion of soybean area in Brazil is expected in 2017/18, of 2% year on year, to 34.5m ha. Nevertheless, downside risks remain. It seems likely that, despite the area increase, some growers could scale back expenditure on essential inputs to minimise costs. However, maize prices in Brazil are signficantly below year-earlier levels-having fallen by a larger margin than soybean prices did-which makes it likely that some farmers will have switched a portion of their intended primary, or full-season, maize cropland to soybeans. With yields unlikely to be near those achieved in 2016/17, we forecast output to fall slightly in 2017/18, by 5% year on year, to 108m tonnes. Planting of the 2018/19 crop will not begin until mid-September 2018, so the outlook is highly provisional. Based on further area expansion and trend productivity, output could be close to the 2016/17 high.
Production in Argentina could fall in 2017/18 on potential area declines
Fieldwork for Argentina's 2017/18 crop is well under way and was estimated by the Bolsa Cereales to be about one-third complete by November 22nd, matching the previous season's progress. However, satellite images and local reports indicate that conditions are still too dry in the provinces of Cordoba and Sao Luis, with concerns, too, about parts of Santa Fe, Entre Rios, and northern Buenos Aires. Generally, the driest areas are in the western and north-western production areas, but dry conditions are now becoming an issue in the core regions too. Even if dryness resulted in some crop damage, there is still time to recover later in the growing season if the weather is mostly favourable. The critical time for the crop is during the pod-filling period-typically around February/March for Argentina.
With relatively better returns for maize, growers are expected to favour plantings of the grain over soybeans. With some area reduction likely, and together with a fall in average yields, production is projected to drop by 3.5m tonnes year on year for 2017/18, to 53m tonnes. Although the government is expected to reduce export levies gradually over the course of 2018-19, the crop will still not be as an attractive as other options.
China's output is rising, but still only meets a fraction of domestic demand
Despite being the world's largest importer by far, China is only a minor producer of soybeans. Its potential has been capped by limited yield gains compared with those of the world's big players, as well as the attraction of alternative crops such as wheat, corn and rice. Nonetheless, in August 2016 the Chinese authorities published a National Oilseed Development Plan, which aims to boost domestic production to 60m tonnes by 2020. The scheme will provide support for oilseed production, processing, technical extension and innovation.
In 2016/17 total acreage was up by an estimated 10 % from the previous season, and a further increase is likely in 2017/18, with a portion of land coming from the switching out of corn production in north-eastern areas. Total output in that season is expected to rise to a peak of 14.3m tonnes, up from 13.1m tonnes in the previous year, and the same influences will underpin another increase in output to 15.2m tonnes in 2018/19.

Stocks and prices
World ending stocks in 2017/18 are forecast at 119.1m tonnes. Although this represents a further increase and would be an all-time peak, the actual rise from the previous season would be less than 1m tonnes (compared with an increase of about 22m tonnes in 2016/17). Should conditions worsen in any way in South America, the number for the combined end-of-year carryout would be reduced. In 2018/19 prospects are highly provisional, but world inventories are expected to tighten by more than 12m tonnes, dropping to a total of 106.8m tonnes.
Looking below top-line data, US ending stocks (based on end-August 2018) are forecast to rise to 11.6m tonnes, up from 8.1m tonnes at the end of the previous season, and the highest level since 2006/07. This is linked to the largest crop ever produced, despite growth in domestic consumption and international sales. Inventory build in the US will help to offset expected falls in both Argentina and Brazil, where 2017/18 crops are likely to be smaller year on year in the face of high exports and local consumption.

Global markets for soybeans were mostly stronger during the month of November, although day-to-day price movements were often small, with losses often offsetting gains. Chicago soybean futures were shaped by heightened worries about ongoing dry weather (often associated with a La Niña weather system) for crops in Latin America, with the most acute of those being in Argentina.
Markets were also influenced by export demand, technical activity and external influences, such as currencies. Nevertheless, quotations were kept in check by expectations for another season of ample supplies, tied to above-average output in leading exporting countries. This includes the US, where the harvesting of a record outturn was completed during November. The USDA's official supply and demand update was generally seen as bearish by traders and ensured that the potential for gains was limited. With export premiums showing little movement over the past four weeks, as the US harvest wrapped up, export prices were up only slightly, by 2%, to US$381/tonne fob. With South American markets shaped by US futures and the aforementioned supply-side concerns, export prices in Argentina and Brazil were similarly firmer.
Based on recent price trends and underlying fundamentals, our projections for prices over the next two years remain broadly unchanged. The final-quarter value is placed just US$4/tonne higher than in our last report, at US$379/tonne, resulting in just a US$1/tonne rise in the full year average price quotation. In the remainder of the outlook period, prices are expected to rise on mildly supportive fundamentals. However, our production outlook rests on the assumption of normal growing conditions across the full season in leading producing countries. Should crops fall significantly short of expectations in any of the main exporters, especially in Brazil in the early stages of 2018, there could be significant market support, pushing prices well above projected levels.

Sugar
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that global annual sugar consumption will expand by an average of 1.4% in 2017/18-2018/19 (October-September), roughly in line with the average over the past four seasons. Rising demand will continue to be underpinned by population growth and rising incomes in emerging markets, where urbanising populations are adopting the food-and-drink habits of developed-world countries. Sugar plays a key role in this dietary shift, as a sweetener in food and beverages, and as a binding and preserving agent in processed foods. However, heightened awareness about the health implications of excess sugar in diets will put pressure on consumption growth. Amid consumer pressure on the food processing industry to reduce sugar and, in some markets, the introduction of "sin taxes" on sugary products, a gradual shift towards synthetic sweeteners will somewhat lessen demand for sugar. Moreover, owing to the growing supply of starch-based sweeteners in both Asia (where Chinese production is expanding rapidly) and Europe (whose market was liberalised in September 2017), these cheaper alternatives will further limit demand for sugar in the food and drinks industry. Meanwhile, the impact of relatively low global sugar prices on demand will be muted by long-standing domestic pricing policies in many developed countries and protectionist moves in several emerging markets, which will limit the extent to which lower prices pass through to consumers.
Although its demand growth will ease, China will remain a key consumer
Rising urbanisation and changing consumer tastes will continue to spur demand for sugar in China. We expect the rate of China's demand growth to ease in the coming years, in line with softening GDP growth; nonetheless, we have revised up our sugar demand projections slightly to reflect somewhat higher forecasts for income growth. However, consumption growth will be held back by the growing supply of starch-based sweetener, which is a cheaper rival to sugar in the beverages industry, and higher domestic sugar prices, which are a likely consequence of the government's moves to restrict imports. Amid pressure from domestic producers to support the local industry, the government has reduced permits (to 1m tonnes, roughly half the previous level) and raised duties (from 50% to 95%) on out-of-quota sugar imports. Sugar imports fell by 26% year on year in the first ten months of 2017 as a result. China will continue to make purchases overseas, as it is unlikely to be able to scale up domestic production in 2017/18-2018/19 to a level that could fully satisfy its domestic demand and preserve its strategically high level of stocks. With the government timing its import decisions to coincide with favourable global prices, this will cause occasional spikes in imports (as seen in October, when imports increased by some 60% year on year). However, while it will remain a significant player in the global market, China is unlikely to remain the world's largest importer under the current import policy environment.
Consumption in India is forecast to recover as prices normalise
Potential consumption growth in India was constrained in 2015/16 by high post-drought prices and unsupportive policy moves (including demonetisation and the removal of some consumer subsidies). However, we expect demand to recover over the coming years, reaching a record high of 25.7m tonnes in 2018/19. The near-term impact of protectionism on local prices, following the government's decision in mid-2017 to hike import duties (from 40% to 50%), will be muted by strong local harvests. Hence, as large domestic supplies from the 2017/18 crop hit the market, domestic prices will soften. This, together with rising incomes and further urbanisation, will support demand.
Demand growth elsewhere in Asia is threatened by starch-based rivals
Beyond China and India, the outlook for sugar consumption in Asia is positive. Some of the more developed countries, such as Malaysia and South Korea, are likely to grow only slowly as markets mature, but this will be more than offset by populous developing countries such as Indonesia, Thailand and Vietnam. However, demand growth in this region will be somewhat dampened by a gradual shift in the food and drink industry to cheaper, starch-based sweeteners as China (Asia's largest producer) increases production and seeks export markets. Tax measures to ensure that sugar consumption remains within recommended health guidelines could also dampen demand, with Thailand, the Philippines and Indonesia pursuing plans to introduce a so-called sugar tax. This has the potential to put a sharp brake on demand; for example, the introduction of a sugar tax in Mexico in 2015 has contributed to a 12% drop in sugar demand since then. Nevertheless, we assume that any such policies in Asia will be rolled out only slowly over the coming years, amid concerns over restricting growth in the otherwise burgeoning food and drink manufacturing industries.
Health warnings may eventually dent sugar demand in the developed world
Demand growth in the mature EU market is likely to be sluggish in 2017/18-2018/19. Many EU countries already average far higher consumption levels of sugar than recommended by the World Health Organisation (WHO), much of which is hidden in processed foods, and the EU Consumer Organisation is urging the food industry to take notice of WHO guidelines. So far, tax measures have been proposed to curb use in countries including the UK, Spain and Belgium. The policy response is likely to be watered down somewhat by opposition from the powerful food and drink industry, but consumer pressure is driving a gradual shift in the food industry toward lower sugar levels. More imminently, however, the liberalisation of the EU's sugar regime in September 2017-when production quotas, guaranteed farmgate prices and export caps were abolished-will limit the need for imports and bring European sugar prices (which have historically traded at a premium) closer to the global norm. However, the production of isoglucose (a starch-based sweetener) was also liberalised in September 2017 and, as in the US, this is likely to steal market share gradually from sugar over the medium term. As well as the adjustment to the new liberalised regime, the UK's exit from the EU is generating uncertainty in the European sugar industry, as the UK is the largest importer of EU sugar.
Changing consumer tastes will boost demand growth in Africa
African consumption will continue to increase, with the bulk of growth coming from expanding indigenous supplies that make sugar more affordable. Several consumers (including Nigeria, the region's largest importer, as well as Kenya and Ghana) are pursuing long-term investment plans in the sugar sector in the hope of becoming self-sufficient. But inefficient domestic supply chains will impede the development of Africa's sugar industries, and aggregate import demand from Sub-Saharan Africa is expected to remain well above 5m t/y in 2017/18-2018/19. Health warnings could temper the pace of consumption growth, with South Africa set to introduce a sugar tax in April 2018. However, as in EU countries, this is meeting considerable resistance from its food and beverage industries, and there remains uncertainty over the level (and therefore the impact) of the tax. Moreover, with the tax evolving into a political row in South Africa between health consumers and business lobbyists, its experience is likely to deter other governments from following suit and a widespread roll-out on the sin tax across the continent seems unlikely.
Policy changes will shift the dynamics of the global sugar trade
The overhaul of EU sugar policy in 2017 is likely to have a significant effect on global trade patterns as the bloc transitions from being a net importer to becoming a net exporter. We expect this transition to be complete by the end of the 2017/18 season. The smaller producers, particularly in Africa and the Caribbean, which supply the EU under preferential trade deals, will be hardest hit by this shift. Global trade dynamics will also be affected by the introduction of heavy import tariffs in China, with small producers (exempt from the new tariffs) likely to increase their market share. Aside from China, trade patterns in Asia will be affected by the liberalisation of sugar sales under Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) free-trade agreement, which comes into effect in 2018. This will probably cause less efficient producers (such as Vietnam) to rely more heavily on imports from elsewhere in the region (probably Thailand). Intra-regional trade is also likely to increase in North America, following a trade deal between the US and Mexico that came into effect in July. This tightened up the rules for Mexican producers and granted Mexico the right of first refusal for the US's above-quota import demand.
These trade deals and policy measures will shift the direction of global trade flows, but trade volumes will ultimately be defined by countries' preference for holding strategic stockpiles of sugar to hedge against future shocks. We therefore expect trade to increase in 2017/18 as countries (notably China) rebuild stocks after several years of low domestic production and relatively high global prices, before trade flows slow in 2018/19 on the back of large local harvests in markets that typically swing between net imports and net exports (notably India).

Supply
After fairly modest growth of 2.1% in 2016/17, and shrinking global supply in the two previous years, world sugar production is forecast to increase by 7.2% in 2017/18, to 179.8m tonnes. This is slightly higher than our previous forecast (6.8%) as the Russian harvest is outperforming expectations. Global supply will also be supported by strong crop revivals in India and Thailand, following weather-related shocks during the previous harvest, and strong output growth in the EU as producers seek to capitalise on the newly liberalised sugar regime. The world's largest producer, Brazil, will benefit from a second consecutive year of crop-friendly growing conditions in 2017/18 and, with a significant amount of output locked into generously priced forward contracts, the supply of cane to sugar production will remain above-average. In 2018/19 we expect global output to remain fairly flat, with a slowdown in Brazil offset by growth among most other producers. We now expect global production to rise by 0.8% in 2018/19 (0.1% previously), to a total of 181.3m tonnes, owing to higher projections in India and Russia. This is contingent on normal weather conditions; even fairly modest disruptions to rainfall patterns pose significant risks to the forecast.
Output growth in Brazil is in prospect as cane supply increases
Brazil is on course for a strong cane harvest, with volumes surpassing market expectations in the early months of the local 2017/18 season (April-March) and quality deteriorating only slightly as the harvest has progressed. With cane supply robust, the main factor shaping Brazil's sugar output will be the supply of cane for sugar vis-à-vis ethanol production. Mills have favoured sugar production in recent years, as ethanol demand waned during a period of low oil prices and weak economic growth. However, the government reduced a federal ethanol tax in late July, which is boosting ethanol demand and prompting crushers to divert cane back to the fuel industry. Indeed, less than 43% of cane supply was used for sugar production in the first half of November, down from over 50% in the first half of 2017. The overall diversion of cane to the sugar industry in 2017/18 will, however, still be above historical norms of 44%. In 2018/19 the weakness of the Real will support the attractiveness of the export-oriented sugar industry, but higher global oil prices and a modest economic recovery in Brazil will spur demand for biofuels. These counteracting factors will probably leave ethanol and sugar prices close to parity, and this is likely to bring the diversion rate in line with historical norms. However, sugar cane fields are ageing and field renewal rates are low. This will begin to take a toll on cane output from 2018/19, thereby reducing the overall cane crush. With a less favourable diversion rate and lower cane production, sugar output is therefore forecast to moderate to 38.6m tonnes in 2018/19, from 39.6m tonnes in 2017/18.
Strong post-drought crop revival is expected in India
Production in India is poised for a strong recovery following drought-related supply disruptions in 2015/16-2016/17. We expect output to reach 26m tonnes in 2017/18 as growth is supported by stronger yields (particularly in the two main growing regions, Uttar Pradesh and Maharashtra, where weather conditions are favourable) and an expansion of the crop area under cultivation (by some 5%). Industry officials in India anticipate another year of strong supply growth in 2018/19, with some forecasts as high as 30m tonnes. Planting will be encouraged in 2018/19 by decent farmgate prices in the previous season, while the wider use of high-yielding seed varieties will boost output. We have increased our 2018/19 production forecast to reflect these dynamics, but, with crushing capacity unlikely to increase as quickly as cane supply, we doubt sugar production will reach 30m tonnes. A medium-term threat to sugar production in India stems from the government's ambition to develop a biofuel industry, which could compete for cane supply. The draft biofuel policy restricts the diversion of cane to ethanol production to years of surplus production, but potential biofuel investors are unlikely to accept this restriction.
EU production will recover as the sugar regime is liberalised
In Europe sugar output is poised for brisk growth as producers seek to take advantage of the lifting of the EU's 50-year-old sugar quota system. Under the new regime, which came into effect at the start of the 2017/18 season, producers (led by France, Germany and the Benelux countries) will extend their crush seasons, thereby making better use of existing capacity without significant additional investments. Extended crush seasons will be supported by higher supply of beet, with some integrated sugar companies reporting that the area under cultivation has been increased by some 15% year on year in 2017/18. Favourable weather conditions are also supporting the beet crop, with the authorities in France projecting a record high harvest in 2017/18. Higher supply and greater efficiency should also leave the region's main producers able to withstand lower prices as the price of European sugar falls closer to the global average. We therefore expect EU production to reach 18.8m tonnes in 2018/19, which will surpass EU demand and spur export growth.
In Russia, sugar production is expected to remain robust, following the significant investment in the modernisation of sugar factories in recent years. Output since the start of beet processing in August has exceeded our expectations (up by 13% year on year in mid-November), aided by favourable crop-growing conditions, and this has prompted an upward revision to our projections. The ensuing surplus will support Russia's emergence as a notable exporter, as the government seeks to prevent stock build-ups from depressing domestic prices and deterring planting. However, we think that the authorities' forecast that exports will reach almost 1m t/y is overoptimistic, owing to soft demand for imports in Central Asia (Russia's main market) and the country's limited output of high-value sugar (which is in higher demand globally).
Output in Thailand is recovering from El Niño's long reach
In Thailand, favourable rainfall will support a bumper harvest in 2017/18 of 11.9m tonnes. Assuming that rainfall normalises in 2018/19, we forecast a more moderate, albeit still decent, outturn of 10.5m tonnes. Producers will be incentivised by export opportunities to other Asian markets, where demand is rising and Thai sugar enjoys favourable access under the ASEAN free-trade arrangement. However, producers are facing considerable regulatory uncer-tainty. Following a challenge by Brazil, which argued that Thailand was violating World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules on free competition, the Thai government agreed to liberalise its sugar industry in December 2017. But the government is yet to legislate on these reforms and, since the removal of subsidies will coincide with a period of low global prices, the authorities are likely to rely on indirect mechanisms to support farmers. Nonetheless, increasing mechanis-ation will help to boost yields, and the sugar cane area will continue to expand as farmers turn away from less profitable rice crops. Risks to our Thai forecast are rising, as production moves towards more drought-prone interior regions.
A major recovery in China's sugar sector appears unlikely for now
China's sugar output has fallen sharply in recent years, owing to unfavourable weather and the impact of rapidly rising costs for labour, land and farm machinery. Amid political pressure from the local industry, some government support has been forthcoming in the form of input subsidies and soft loans, and the government has raised duties on out-of-quota sugar imports in a bid to protect local producers from cheaper imports. These measures will support the profitability of the local industry and should spur some investment, but we doubt that they will lead to a significant surge in domestic supply growth. The sector is dominated by smallholder farmers, labour costs are high and sugar cane areas do not lend themselves to mechanisation. Indeed, the cost of producing sugar cane in China is almost double that in Thailand, and this will deter investment. The government is attempting to encourage consolidation among the many disparate industry players in the country's main sugar region of Guangxi in an attempt to improve its competitiveness. However, similar moves in the past have not yielded impressive results. Given more favourable growing conditions, we expect output to rise modestly, to an average of 10.4m t/y in 2017/18-2018/19-well below the 10% annual growth that would be needed for the state to meet its medium-term production goals.

Stocks and prices
After successive supply deficits and a period of relatively high global prices, global sugar stocks shrank to 87.4m tonnes at end-2016/17. We expect the stocks to recover to 98.5m tonnes at end-2018/19 as the market swings back into surplus. The market surplus is forecast to reach 6.3m tonnes in 2017/18, amid bumper harvests from key producers, before moderating to 4.8m tonnes in 2018/19 as output remains flat and consumption accelerates slightly. Although overall stocks will remain comfortable (equivalent to an average of almost 55% of annual consumption in 2017/18-2018/19), the uneven distribution of these stocks means that reserves will not always be available to the market, and occasional supply squeezes are possible.

The latest sugar price rally has peaked
After peaking at over 23 US cents/lb in late 2016, global sugar prices fell by 30% over the first half of 2017, before stabilising in the third quarter, at 14.5 US cents/lb. In part, this reflects a market correction after overshooting in late 2016, with speculative investors unwinding the long positions that they had adopted during the price boom. More fundamentally, crop-friendly weather conditions in key producer markets are fuelling expectations of a global sugar surplus in the coming years, and policy moves to restrict import dependence in key consumers (notably, China, India and Europe) have further weakened market sentiment. Amid oversupply in the global market, we expect prices to average 16 US cent/lb in 2017, down by 11% on the previous year.
Beyond 2017 we expect prices to drift higher, to between 15.5 US cents/lb and 16.5 US cents/lb in 2018-19. This modest price recovery from the nadir of mid-2017 will be driven largely by market tightening from 2018 as the crucial Brazilian market diverts more cane to ethanol production over the coming years and therefore produces less sugar. A swing to ethanol that is substantial enough to bring the global sugar market into balance seems unlikely, however, and the prospects of global oversupply will probably prevent a more significant rebound in prices. Nonetheless, our market surplus forecast is based on the assumption of normal weather conditions in all producing countries, and there therefore remains a risk of sharp supply shocks if crop conditions change. The sugar trading market is seemingly pricing in little risk at the moment, but, as the market tightens in 2018/19, we think that this will change. Higher-risk premiums will therefore probably provide some support to prices in 2019.

Sunflowerseed oil
Demand
Demand for sunflowerseed oil remains strong as a result of attractive prices relative to other oils. The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast of sunflowerseed oil consumption in 2017/18 shows growth of 2.8% to 18.7m tonnes. Higher estimates of supply mean that the risk to consumption due to lack of supply is reducing. Sunflowerseed oil enjoys a strong consumer franchise in many countries, and this underpins our expectation of further consumption growth in 2018/19. Consumption is likely to exceed 19.4m tonnes in that season, although this relies on sunflowerseed oil maintaining its competitive position against other oils.
Sunflowerseed oil's improving price competitiveness will boost EU usage
Given the increasing discounts to rapeseed and soybean oils, EU sunflowerseed oil consumption in the 2017/18 season is getting off to a good start. The increased estimate of local availability will also provide a further boost to consumption. We have raised our forecast of EU consumption to just over 4.6m tonnes. Consumption at this level can now be achieved without any increase in imports of sunflowerseed oil. Sunflowerseed enjoys a favourable consumer image, and with production set to increase again to 4.8m tonnes in 2018/19, we can reasonably expect further growth in consumption.
Russian consumption will rise modestly as the economy emerges from recession
In Russia, we expect local availability to tighten slightly in 2017/18, which may be reflected in local prices; however, we expect supply to remain comfortable enough to support continued demand growth. Nonetheless, we remain cautious about prospects, with our consumption forecast representing growth of only 1%. In 2018/19 consumption prospects are encouraged by a small increase in expected economic growth in 2019. Overall, we currently expect growth to accelerate to a more normal 3.8%.
Robust GDP growth and shifting preferences will boost India's usage
Indian imports of sunflowerseed are continuing to run at high levels despite the imposition of higher import tariffs. Internal Indian prices show sunflowerseed oil to be increasingly competitive with other oils. The growing consumer preference for sunflowerseed oil, especially in the south of India, and sustained economic growth should also be positive for demand growth. We think that 2017/18 consumption could exceed 2.3m tonnes, with further growth to more than 2.4m tonnes in 2018/19.
Consumption growth to moderate in "other" countries in 2017/18
Many countries have been increasing their purchases of sunflowerseed oil to take advantage of competitive prices. Supplies are likely to remain comfortable throughout the forecast period. Countries increasing their use of sunflowerseed oil include Turkey, Iran, Iraq and Egypt, as well as several smaller countries. We expect consumption growth in these "other" countries to moderate in 2017/18, to 2.2%, as the rapid growth seen in 2016/17 (13.9%) is unlikely to be replicated as sunflowerseed oil becomes less competitive with other products, including palm and soybean oils.

Supply
The outlook for the 2017/18 sunflowerseed crop is mixed. The most recent estimates indicate that output in Russia, Ukraine and Argentina will not meet earlier expectations. However, these reductions have been more than offset by a large rise in the estimate of EU sunflowerseed production and a smaller increase in estimated US production. Overall, the global harvest looks likely to be only marginally smaller than the large 2016/17 outturn. Early indications suggest another large crop in 2018/19, along with further growth in sunflowerseed oil production. In addition, the size of the crop would allow some rebuilding of stocks to more normal levels.
Ukraine's 2016/17 sunflowerseed harvest exceeds our expectations
The latest harvest estimates for Ukraine suggest that the sunflowerseed crop has failed to live up to early estimates for the 2017/18 season. This has prompted a further reduction in our harvest estimate to 13.2m tonnes (previously 13.7m tonnes). However, with relatively plentiful sunflowerseed stocks carried over, this is not likely to have an immediate impact on crush rates. Exports of sunflowerseed oil in the year to date from the Ukraine have been running above year-earlier levels. However, for the season as a whole, the smaller harvest will have an impact on crushing volumes. Although the 2018/19 outlook is still provisional, the industry's strong expansion in recent years should ensure ample seed availability despite concerns about crop rotations. We expect that normal yields would lead to a sunflowerseed harvest similar to the record output achieved in 2016/17. This would provide sufficient raw material for sunflowerseed oil output in 2018/19 to rise to nearly 6.2m tonnes, only slightly lower than the record outturn in 2016/17.
Sunflowerseed will remain a popular crop in Russia
There have been delays to the sunflowerseed harvest in Russia, leading to concerns that some fields may not be harvested. We have reduced our estimate of the final outturn to 11.4m tonnes, marginally below last season's record production. However, our current assessment puts sunflowerseed oil output at an unchanged 4.6m tonnes in 2017/18. We expect that the 2018/19 sunflowerseed area will be similar to 2017/18. Normal yields would give a record crop of more than 12m tonnes. Sunflowerseed oil production could reach almost 4.9m tonnes, provided that sufficient markets can be found.
Estimates for the EU sunflowerseed harvest in 2016/17 have improved
The production of sunflowerseed in the EU for the 2017/18 season has surpassed previous expectations. Yields have been especially high in France. Current assessments put the total crop at a new record high of 9.5m tonnes. The higher availability will lead to a reduction in sunflowerseed imports but should also result in higher EU crushing volumes. Consequently, our forecast of EU sunflowerseed oil production in 2017/18 has been raised again, to 3.4m tonnes (3.3m tonnes previously). Sunflowerseed sowings for 2018/19, which start in the spring, are expected to be marginally lower than in 2017/18. At this level, a potential crop of more than 9m tonnes is in prospect. Sunflowerseed oil production could approach 3.5m tonnes.
Prospects for Argentina's crop remain good, but downside risks are mounting
In Argentina, around 90% of the intended area of sunflowerseed for 2017/18 is planted. Sowings got off to a good start, although wet conditions have hampered later plantings. The area looks set to be 9% higher than in 2016/17 and could lead to a crop of around 3.9m tonnes. We continue to expect that sunflowerseed oil production will exceed 1.4m tonnes in 2017/18 and reach 1.5m tonnes in 2018/19. Export availability of sunflowerseed in 2017/18 will also be higher than in 2016/17, even with the reduced crop estimate.

Stocks and prices
Stocks of sunflowerseed oil remain plentiful, and this situation is likely to persist for the 2017/18 season. Previous concerns over the level of sunflowerseed stocks have, to a degree, been allayed by the increases in harvest estimates. However, the 2017/18 sunflowerseed production total continues to rely on a drawdown of sunflowerseed stocks and may consequently turn out to be overoptimistic. Nonetheless, current projections suggest a recovery in sunflowerseed stocks in 2018/19, which may encourage crushers to maintain activity during the latter part of the 2017/18 season.

Upward pressure on prices will be felt in the coming months
Sunflowerseed oil prices showed a small increase in November, encouraged by higher rapeseed oil prices. Despite this, sunflowerseed oil continues to trade at historically substantial discounts to soybean and rapeseed oils, and at only a small premium to palm oil. The small market deficit expected in 2017/18 should be positive for future sunflowerseed oil prices, and we therefore we expect this upward trend to persist. Price rises are likely to be comparatively small, and by the end of the 2017/18 season prices will have remained below US$900/tonne. The 2018/19 season should see a continuation of price gains. Although current projections suggest an oil deficit, the increase in sunflowerseed stocks may dampen any increase in values. Nonetheless, the US$900/tonne level should be breached towards the end of the 2018/19 season.

Tea
Demand
Global tea consumption is growing steadily, driven mainly by China, which accounts for one-third of world tea consumption and is consuming ever-greater quantities of green tea. However, demand is also growing in other major consuming regions, including India. Demand for tea is less exposed to economic cycles than other commodities owing to its low cost, implying that tea demand is mainly driven by demographics. This explains why The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast for tea consumption growth, of 3.8% a year on average in 2018-19, is relatively high and in line with the long-term historical average. It also explains why our demand-side forecasts tend to remain relatively stable, since tea consumption is determined by structural factors to a much greater degree than other beverages. Global demand for black tea will continue to rise, but the pace of growth will be outstripped by that for green tea, fruit tea, herbal tea, rooibos (from South Africa), purple tea (mainly from Kenya) and high-end organic tea, reflecting their greater reported health benefits and heavy marketing. Iced tea and "ready to drink" tea beverages account for a small share of the tea market but have enjoyed rapid growth in sales-even in traditional markets such as China.
Tea demand will benefit from changing consumer habits
The main tea-consuming countries are also the largest producers, with a rising share of output retained for domestic consumption. In producing countries, tea will benefit from changing consumption habits related to rising incomes, but in most places will remain a consumer staple, despite increase in consumption of other beverages, including coffee. The fact that a smaller share of tea than coffee is consumed in the out-of-home sector-owing partially to customer perceptions that tea in cafés offers less value for money-will shield tea consumption from adverse economic developments, which tend to have less of an impact on at-home consumption.
Both India and China will continue to see robust demand growth in 2017-18
Tea consumption will remain dominated by Asian consumers, particularly China and India, which together accounted for an estimated 59% of global demand in 2017, up from 48% in 2010. In China, we expect the government's efforts to rein in credit growth to contribute to an economic slowdown from 2018; nonetheless, this will have only a muted impact on tea demand growth, which is forecast to rise by 4% per year, compared with 5% in 2017. This forecast is relatively cautious, with the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) projecting average annual Chinese demand growth of 15% until 2024, suggesting an upside risk to our forecasts. Average consumption per head stands at just over 1 kg/year, ranking China just 14th in the world. This leaves significant room for growth, particularly as only around 35% of the population drink tea.
Given that tea is regarded as a traditional drink, it will suffer from mounting com-petition from coffee and soft-drink retailers, owing to a growing preference for these beverages among younger Chinese consumers. Moreover, younger segments of the population are also showing a preference for black tea over green tea (black tea consumption has risen by an average of 40% per year since 2002, while green tea consumption has risen more gradually), which should bolster demand for black tea, albeit from a low base. Other changes in consumer habits will also affect tea sales, with greater demand for teabags globally (these are less wasteful than loose-leaf tea). However, given the importance attached to the quality of tea, sales of leaf teas will continue to dominate the local market.
In India, strong economic growth will be accompanied by higher household spending, firm consumer confidence and supportive demographics, driving annual average growth in tea consumption of 6.4% in 2018-19, marginally lower than estimated growth of 6.5% in 2017. Structurally, the Indian market has significant potential-aside from its sheer size, average consumption per head is lower than in China, at just 740 g per year, which bodes well for longer-term demand growth. Currently, the out-of-home sector accounts for just under 50% of tea consumption, compared with 85% of the coffee market. The expansion of tea bars across many cities aims to lift this share, as well as fuelling overall tea consumption growth.
Structural constraints will hamper tea consumption growth in many markets
Demand in some large consuming countries will be hampered in 2018-19 by market saturation and weakening demographics. The FAO forecasts an overall contraction until 2024 in many EU markets (which together account for just under 5% of global consumption), despite a firmer economic performance, as well as in Russia (2.5% of global consumption). Turkey, which also accounts for around 5% of global consumption, has a particularly saturated market, with the highest consumption of tea per head in the world by some margin. The EU also registers some of the world's highest levels, particularly in the UK and Ireland. Although our forecasts anticipate further growth in demand, reflecting continued population growth and steady growth in private consumption, the pace will be fairly mild. We forecast average annual growth in tea demand in 2018-19 of 1.9% in the EU and 0.4% in Turkey. Russian demand growth will be stronger, at an average of 2.5% per year, but is flattered by a weak base of comparison following a sharp decline in consump-tion in 2013-16.
There is plenty of room for market growth in the US
The US is a small market for tea, accounting for less than 2.5% of global consumption, and consumption per head is low. However, with most of the larger tea markets dominated by loose-leaf tea, the US remains one of the most important single markets for instant tea and iced tea. We expect demand to increase by an annual average of 2.6% in 2018-19, partly reflecting our fairly upbeat forecast for economic growth. Health concerns will also sustain demand for tea, with a gradual shift away from carbonated beverages towards healthier alternatives.
New tea markets are emerging
Export data from tea-producing countries reveal that new markets for tea are emerging, with the number of countries buying tea at the major auction houses in Asia and Africa on the rise. Demand from these new joiners in the tea market, mainly fast-growing emerging countries, is set to increase in 2018-19, underpinning our forecast for average consumption growth of 2.5% a year across all "other" countries, which together account for 18% of global consumption.

Supply
After an estimated 1.7% contraction in global tea production in 2017-the first fall in output since our data series (which is based on historical data from the FAO) began in 2000-tea production is forecast to recover in 2018-19, rising by 3.5% and 2.1% respectively. However, these growth rates remain weak by historical comparison; annual growth in tea output averaged 4.4% during 2004-14. Along with weather concerns, several structural factors will prevent faster production growth. In inflation-adjusted terms, farmers' profits are lower than in past decades owing to the higher cost of inputs, resulting in a fall in investment. Notwithstanding a recent softening of the US dollar, many currencies will remain comparatively weak against the dollar in 2018-19, which will hamper operating conditions for farmers. Production would be affected if a La Niña weather phenomenon develops in the coming months: this often brings unusually cold temperatures to some Chinese tea-growing regions, drought to Kenya and very wet conditions to Vietnam. Depending on how weather conditions develop, this has the potential to lead to another year of declining tea production.
Much of the forecast increase in global tea production in 2018-19 will come from a rise in green tea output, where growth has outpaced black tea by a significant margin in recent years. Green tea now accounts for one-third of total global tea production, compared with less than one-quarter a decade ago. This mainly reflects the rise in tea production in China, where loose-leaf green tea accounts for 68% of domestic production, and in Vietnam, where it now represents 55% of tea output, compared with 43% a decade ago. We expect these trends to continue during the 2018-19 forecast period.
As in 2016, adverse weather will harm Chinese tea production in 2017
China experienced the second consecutive year of disappointing tea production growth in 2017. We estimate that output expanded by 2.2%, after heavy rains hit several of the large tea-producing provinces in southern China, including Hunan, Jiangxi and Zhejiang, in June. The rains were followed by extremely hot weather in some areas (including parts of Zhejiang), which will also have hampered production.
Even on the assumption that weather conditions will improve in 2018-19, production growth is forecast to slow further, to an annual average of 2%. Under-lying economic growth will slow gradually during 2018 as the govern-ment takes action to bring debt levels under control, and is not projected to accelerate significantly in 2019. We expect government efforts to modernise the agri-cultural sector through large-scale lending from the state-owned Agricultural Development Bank of China to progress slowly, with some Chinese tea investors instead seeking to expand production overseas rather than in China. These factors will combine to undermine growth in tea output.
Beyond the forecast period there is scope for return to firmer rates of tea production growth. The authorities are engaged in efforts to lift product quality and quantity in order to boost exports (only about 15% of tea production was exported in 2016). Given that China's average yield per hectare is low by global standards (at 785 kg in 2012-14, compared with 2,085 kg in India and 2,105 kg in Kenya), there is certainly potential for gains in productivity.
India's tea production will continue to grow in 2018 and 2019
We estimate tea production growth of 3.3% in India in 2017. Output fell in the first quarter of 2017, reflecting dry conditions in Assam (India's largest tea-growing state), as well as in Bengal and parts of southern India, but weather conditions improved subsequently. Assuming supportive weather conditions in 2018-19, we expect tea production to continue to rise, albeit more gradually. Continued efforts to channel funding to tea growers will provide support, but several structural factors will hold back production. There has been little progress on reforms to boost foreign direct investment in several sectors, including agriculture. Furthermore, India's tea bushes are old: nearly 40% of existing bushes are over 50 years old, compared with Kenya, where fewer than 30% are over 40 years old, and Vietnam, where the entire tea plantation is less than 20 years old. Replanting has progressed slowly and rising input costs have eroded profits, implying that in the long term India may struggle to increase growth as significantly as other major producers. We forecast average growth in tea production of 2% per year in 2018-19.
High costs will prevent a significant recovery in Sri Lanka's 2018-19 output
We estimate a double-digit decline in tea output in Sri Lanka in 2017, reflecting recent torrential rain that caused landslides and the worst flooding in over a decade. Many of the 400,000 farmers, who account for 70% of national tea output, saw their bushes submerged by muddy water. Sri Lanka's tea production is forecast to rise in 2018, by 5.8%, but this will largely reflect a cyclical recovery after several disappointing years. As in India, there are several structural hurdles that will hamper growth, assuming that weather conditions improve. Despite some replanting as a result of a 20% increase in subsidies to small tea farmers, the replanting rate is not sufficiently high to lead to a significant and sustained increase in output. Local reports also show that fertiliser use has been low, and the risk of industrial unrest persists. Sharp wage rises and low mechanisation mean that production costs in Sri Lanka are some of the highest among the world's main tea producers. These factors explain why our production growth forecast in 2019, of 1.8%, is relatively weak.
Moreover, the main customers for Sri Lankan tea-Russia, Turkey, Iran and Syria-have all experienced economic turbulence in recent years. Economic conditions are expected to improve markedly in Iran with the lifting of sanctions, and to a lesser degree in Russia and Turkey, but this is unlikely to be enough to boost demand for Sri Lankan tea significantly. Most of the country's tea is loose leaf, rather than mass-produced tea bags, which limits the extent to which the country can diversify its tea exports towards Europe and the US. The Ministry of Plantation Industries has stated that it is considering a proposal to allow tea imports for blending in an attempt to boost export potential, and the Tea Board is continuing to urge the government to take measures to make the tea industry more competitive, but it is unclear if there is sufficient support domestically to push the measures through, as there is a strong perception among farmers that this would undermine local production.

A partial recovery in output is likely in Kenya in 2018-19
After a massive jump in tea production in Kenya in 2016, with output hitting an all-time high of 473,000 tonnes, weather conditions deteriorated sharply in 2017, with a renewed and persistent dry spell damaging tea plantations. Kenya's agriculture minister has stated that tea output is likely to fall by 12%, but our estimate envisages a much sharper drop, of 30%, given that production was down by about one-third in the first eight months of the year. Although tea production is forecast to stage a partial recovery in 2018-19, rising by 24.2% and 4.9% respectively, output levels even in 2019 will remain relatively weak. Periodic industrial action in the sector over pay disputes, combined with a change in the tea levy on farmers, so that it is based on the value rather than the volume of sales, will also undermine profitability in the medium term. Although the government has pledged to support small farmers and reduce the tax burden, conflicting interests and a lack of funds will hinder progress.
Investment will have an impact beyond our forecast period
Many countries have been investing to stimulate tea production, including large producers such as India (which is raising subsidies for plantation rejuvenation), Kenya (where processing plants are being expanded and production is being diversified to non-black varieties) and China (which is concentrating on raising black tea output for export), and even a minor producer, Ethiopia (where Saudi investment is seeking to expand tea production). Smaller producers, such as Tanzania, Uganda, Rwanda and Bangladesh, have also seen renewed investment. However, we assume that some of these investment plans will be scaled back or suspended altogether, while others will progress only slowly, reflecting overambitious investment plans, bureaucratic hurdles and broader concerns about long-term global oversupply. In addition, it takes three to five years for a tea bush to become commercially productive, so the impact on output of recent price falls will be evident only after the forecast period.
Stocks and prices
We estimate a fourth consecutive year of market deficits in 2017, reflecting increasing consumption and a contraction in output from several of the main tea-producing countries. We expect consumption growth to outstrip production growth during 2018-19, meaning that we forecast deepening market deficits in those years.
Given that there is no global measure of total tea stocks, it is impossible to gauge how significantly these widening market deficits will affect stock levels. The fact that prices fell during 2015-16 despite market deficits in both years indicates that stock movements have only a limited effect on prices, not least because much of the increase in consumption and production is the result of consumption and output in China, which mainly consists of green tea. Although some of the production data are broken down into green and black tea, the consumption data are not, which prevents a calculation of the market balance in relation to black tea.

Only a fraction of the increase in production will be exported, and even this will not be in any of the three markets (Colombo, Kolkata and Mombasa) where our average tea price is measured. Prices in these markets respond to demand and supply dynamics in Sri Lanka, India and Kenya respectively (essentially, black tea). Often prices diverge between these three markets on the back of local developments that have an impact on supply and demand in the respective auction or to reflect the quality of tea offered at each auction. As an example, prices at the Colombo and Mombasa auctions have risen sharply in 2017 (with the former hitting record levels of US$4/kg as production has slumped), while prices at the Kolkata auction have remained similar to their year-earlier levels for much of the year. Although some of the auction houses are becoming digitised, we do not believe that the tea market will attract sufficient interest from investors to make price dynamics vulnerable to broader global macroeconomic changes (there is no futures market). Prices will therefore remain volatile and largely led by local supply-and-demand factors.
Prices will retreat slightly in 2018-19
We estimate a full-year average price of US$3.11/kg in 2017, an 18.1% year-on-year increase, reflecting the weak outlook for production and continued firm consumption growth. Although the market deficit will remain large in 2018-19, recovering production is expected to reduce prices by 3.6%, to an average of US$3/kg in 2018, and by a further 6.3% in 2019, to US$2.81/kg.
