Wheat
Demand
Global wheat consumption has nearly tripled since the 1960s, to more than 700m tonnes in recent years. Although stronger demand for wheat has mainly been tied to a rising global population, it should also be noted that wheat demand growth has persistently outpaced population growth. Wheat's popularity in diets has been sustained, as has its use as an animal feed ingredient. A small proportion is also used for brewing and for the manufacture of starch and ethanol. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global consumption to rise marginally, by 0.7%, to nearly 740m tonnes in 2017/18. Although wheat use for food is expected to increase, in line with the recent trend, it appears likely that world feed consumption will decline, owing partly to competition from alternative products. A similar pattern is expected in 2018/19. Although use for feed is expected to slip back further, a rise for milling and food use should see total demand increase by 0.3%, to 742m tonnes.
Rising food use is being driven by emerging and developing markets
Annual growth in global food-wheat consumption has remained relatively consistent over the past decade, with increases averaging 1.4% a year. Urbanisation, together with shifts in diets and incomes, has also resulted in greater consumption of wheat-based convenience foods such as noodles, as well as Western-style bakery products, which are best produced using high-quality wheat and flour. With much of the growth in demand stemming from countries outside the main wheat-producing belts, rising demand for milling wheat and flour has been accompanied by an increase in imports in most years. We expect world food use to rise by 1.5% in 2017/18, exceeding 500m tonnes for the first time. Growth will be driven mostly by India, Indonesia and Sub-Saharan Africa. These trends are well established and are expected to continue into 2018/19, when food consumption could rise to 511m tonnes.
World feed use is forecast at a higher than usual level in 2016/17
Wheat is the world's second most important grain for use in animal feed, although it is typically equivalent to one-quarter of feed-use of maize, with annual wheat use roughly matching that of barley, sorghum, oats and rye combined. Assuming strong competition from maize-especially in the EU, China, and the US-we expect use for livestock feed to fall back by 3.7% year on year in 2017/18, to around 144m tonnes. The figure for Canada is also forecast to be sharply lower than last year, dropping by about half, to 3m tonnes, on much smaller feed grade supplies. At the moment, we forecast a modest decline in global demand for feed-grade wheat in 2018/19, to around 144m tonnes. The drop stems mainly from a projected small decline in Russia, where a smaller crop is likely to limit discretionary on-farm feeding.
Consumption is rising quickly in Sub-Saharan Africa
Wheat demand in Sub-Saharan Africa has increased relatively quickly in recent years, mainly due to rapid population growth. Wheat-based foods have gained in popularity over traditional staples such as maize porridges, cassava and millet. Higher incomes, migration to cities and more women participating in the workforce have all contributed to greater demand for convenience-and often wheat-based-foods. With climatic conditions in most countries unsuitable for producing wheat except for in a few select countries, including Ethiopia and South Africa, demand is mainly being met by imports, which are now well in excess of 20m tonnes per year. Regional consumption is estimated at around 29m tonnes in 2017/18, up by around 500,000 tonnes from 2016/17. Almost all wheat is consumed for food purposes, with less than 2% of total demand channeled into feed sectors. South Africa, Nigeria, Ethiopia, Sudan and Kenya are the five-largest consumers of wheat in the region, accounting for around 65% of overall consumption. Of these countries, Nigeria is by far the least self-sufficient, importing virtually all of its domestic needs, forecast to be around 4.7m tonnes in 2017/18. Wheat demand in Africa will eventually begin to slow in response to an anticipated moderation in population growth and the inclusion of more animal protein in diets, but such changes are unlikely in the next few years.
Mexico is eyeing wheat imports from Argentina
Mexico's phytosanitary authority recently finalised a long-awaited protocol al-lowing for the import of wheat from Argentina. A group of millers have already contracted a trial shipment, which will first be assessed for quality before further purchases are considered. Although there is talk that the move is in some way linked to the ongoing North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA) renegotiations, private importers have indicated that the deal instead reflects very competitive pricing in Argentina. Indeed, local users have proven quite willing to switch origins in recent years, sourcing a number of cargoes from the Black Sea and occasionally the EU. Mexico typically imports around two-thirds of its annual needs, with domestic consumption increasing steadily in recent decades, forecast at around 7.8m tonnes in 2017/18. Although a series of anti-obesity campaigns have curbed demand for cakes, pastries and cookies in the past few years, production of other, plainer bread products remains strong, and population growth continues to drive demand.

Supply
World wheat production has reached unprecedented levels in recent seasons, these gains have mainly stemmed from the Black Sea region, predominantly in Russia, but China, India and parts of Latin America have also contributed bigger crops. The harvested area has increased across many parts of the globe, and average yields have also risen, despite concerns about years of underinvestment in wheat seed technology. However, given recent spells of poor weather across wheat belts in both hemispheres, the recent growth trend is expected to come to a halt. In 2017/18 we forecast global wheat production to decline by 0.6% year on year, to 750m tonnes, owing largely to lower output from the US, Canada and Australia. Russia's massive 2017/18 crop has diverted some attention away from the fact that supplies of the best quality, high-protein wheats from North America and parts of Europe will be below average levels and will therefore command a price premium. With prices at relatively low levels, there is unlikely to be much incentive for farmers to increase 2018/19 plantings. Crop rotation needs will again be important, but in countries where there are few alternatives, seeded area is unlikely to show much year-on-year change. Assuming average yields, the world crop is forecast to contract by 1% in 2018/19, to 742m tonnes.
After a small EU crop last year, output should rise in 2017/18
Despite a mixed year for the main EU wheat growers, the 2017/18 crop is expected to be slightly larger than average, at 151.5m tonnes. Yields have rebounded strongly for wheat growers in France-which accounts for around one-quarter of the bloc's total output-following the previous season's sub-par results. Survey results also confirm its good quality, with a much higher percentage than last year meeting milling specifications. In contrast, a wet finish to the German harvest has led to a series of quality downgrades in key northern export-producing areas. Spain's wheat crop was also negatively affected by a punishing drought, which lasted for virtually the entire year. Producers are now wrapping up 2018/19 winter wheat planting. Low prices, forecast to be below production costs in some countries, are expected to be a general disincentive. However, with earlier wet conditions preventing some producers from switching wheat area to rapeseed as intended, there is unlikely to be much overall change in plantings for next year's harvest. Assuming normal yields, output is likely to be in line with the average, at 148m tonnes.
An enormous crop in Russia
Average 2017/18 yields in Russia were easily the best ever, with production rising by 14.5%, to a record 83m tonnes. The forecast is raised by 1m tonnes from November and could be raised again in the coming months, once final clean-weight harvest data is finalised. Winter and spring wheat crops enjoyed near-perfect growing conditions, benefitting from timely and abundant rains. Attention is now beginning to switch to 2018/19 prospects. Recent dry weather in southern areas has not been ideal for early crop establishment but has allowed for a quick start to planting, with winter sowings slightly exceeding the official target by late November. Assuming that yields are similar to the recent trend, but down from the record-breaking results achieved this year, we expect 2018/19 output to decline by around 13.3%, to 72m tonnes, which is still an impressive outturn.
US wheat production fell sharply in 2017/18
US all-wheat production in 2017/18 totals 47.4m tonnes, down by 25% year on year, and at a 15-season low. The sharp drop in output mainly reflects a pullback in plantings, with the smallest harvested area in almost 130 years. The winter wheat outturn was 34.5m tonnes (down by 24% year on year), with durum at 1.5m tonnes (down by 47%) and other spring varieties at 10.7m tonnes (down by 27%). Sowing of next season's winter wheat crop was finished slightly later than average. Reflecting a dry start to the season in some states, only half the crop was estimated to be in good or excellent condition-eight percentage points lower than at the same point a year ago. Depressed prices and limited potential for profits mean that another drop in winter and spring plantings is now likely. Assuming reduced abandonment and better overall yields, mainly for spring-sown wheat, 2018/19 production is forecast to rise by 4.9%, to 49.7m tonnes, about 11% below the previous five-year average.
China's wheat support policies are starting to change
Latest official data from China confirmed a small rise in 2017/18 wheat production, as an improvement in yields more than compensated for a minor reduction in harvested area. High- and low-gluten wheat varieties, needed to produce Western style breads and cakes, accounted for almost 28% of this year's crop, up by nearly 3 percentage points from 2016/17. After focusing first on efforts to realign cotton, maize, rapeseed and soybean markets with international prices, authorities are now beginning to tweak foodgrain price support policies too. Following changes to rice subsidy programmes last year, the government recently announced a 2.5% reduction in the 2018/19 minimum state purchase price for wheat, the first such cut since the initiative was introduced 11 years ago. Although unusual, next year's minimum price of Rmb2,300/tonne (US$348/tonne) is still about double the current price of US winter wheat and around US$100/tonne above milling wheat import prices, including freight costs. However, it must be stressed that imports are, in effect, limited by the country's tariff rate quota (TRQ), under which the private sector is only eligible to buy slightly less than 1m tonnes at the reduced 1% import duty. The policy announcement was not a big surprise and had been well-flagged by party officials in recent months.
With winter wheat planting for next year's crop already mostly finished, the policy shift is unlikely to have much of an impact for 2018/19. Sowings are expected to stay relatively high, with production tentatively placed at 129m tonnes. The announcement could, however, mark the start of some wider-ranging reforms in the years ahead as the government looks to unwind its excessively large wheat stocks, which have been built up in recent years. Should the lower support price feed through into lower market values for common wheat, a wider price differential could encourage farmers to further expand production of the higher-quality wheats in the years ahead. This could have some implications for imports, which have ranged from 1.9m tonnes to 6.8m tonnes during the past five years, and are mostly used to plug shortfalls in local high-quality wheat supplies.
Some early challenges for wheat farmers in India
India's government recently raised the minimum support price (MSP) for the 2018/19 wheat crop by around 7%, a slightly sharper rise than in previous years. As part of wider efforts to support farmers and curb cheap imports (mainly from the Black Sea region), authorities confirmed that the wheat import duty would be doubled to 20%. Both initiatives are expected to support planting decisions in the months ahead, potentially keeping the planted area close to the 2017/18 record high. However, lower than normal irrigation water supplies could affect rabi (winter) crop choices in some state. Because of a mixture of cold and occasionally dry weather, seeding has progressed quite slowly so far, with sowings to date around two-thirds behind average as at November 24th. With a long way still to go before the planting window closes, we retain our forecasts for now, with next year's crop still pegged at 97.5m tonnes-down by 1% year on year, but nearly 7% above the previous five-year average.
Wheat is back in favour with Argentinian farmers
In Argentina, policy changes made under the government that came to power in late 2015, including exchange-rate liberalisation and the removal of export quotas and taxes, have greatly incentivised the country's wheat farmers. Sown area for 2017/18 is officially estimated to be down by 7% year on year, with earlier flooding preventing access to low-lying fields across southern parts of Buenos Aires and La Pampa provinces. Despite the drop, acreage is still over 20% higher than the five-year average. By late November the harvest was around one-fifth complete, with progress most advanced in the northern provinces, where results to date have shown confirmed disappointing yields but good quality. For now, production is forecast to decline by 8% year on year, to 16m tonnes.

Stocks and prices
Cumulative world stocks are forecast to rise for the fifth consecutive season in 2017/18 to 251m tonnes, up by 4% year on year to an all-time high. However, this large total figure masks some important features, as gains in world inventories are mostly attributed to rises in end-season stocks in India and China, whose stocks are not available on the world market. Indeed, with China's stocks having doubled over a five-year period, many observers have argued that China should be excluded from global stock calculations. Other organisations suggest that it is perhaps more useful to use carryovers in the eight largest exporters as a proxy for global supplies. Cumulative stockpiles in those countries are forecast to drop by around 7% year on year, to 70.7 m tonnes, but will still be up by 11% from the average in recent years. The projection for 2018/19 is provisional, but suggests a continuation of the most recent trend. World stocks are likely to remain high, probably on a par with 2016/17 levels. Exporter stocks of 62.7m tonnes, although not considered especially tight, would be the smallest in five years.
Russia's wheat stocks have almost tripled in just three years
Although Russia's exports have been running at a record pace in recent months, infrastructure capacity constraints mean that July-June shipments could be limited to around 33m tonnes, nowhere near enough to prevent a further build-up in 2017/18 stocks. Works to upgrade existing terminals are ongoing, and although new port facilities are also being planned for construction, including in eastern parts of the country, close to China, these projects are expected to take three or more years to complete. Therefore, following two successive massive crops, wheat stocks are expected to reach a record high at the end of 2017/18, potentially reaching 16.8m tonnes, up from just 5.6m tonnes two seasons ago. According to the Russian Grain Union, a non-governmental farmers' association, the country currently has 120m tonnes of grain-storage capacity, around two-thirds of which consists of mostly on-farm barns and warehouses, which are susceptible to greater post-harvest losses. Most of the country's storage facilities are in need of upgrading, with the best facilities mainly located close to the key southern producing and exporting areas. High stock levels are expected to keep a lid on prices heading into the next season and, even if 2018/19 production falls short of recent levels, the additional supplies should provide a cushion, allowing Russia to maintain its dominant position on the world export market.

Wheat prices are likely to remain weak in the short term
Trading in world wheat markets has fluctuated in recent months. Steep early-summer gains, linked primarily to a drought in parts of the US and Canada, were later erased on the back of better than expected results from harvests in the Black Sea region, predominantly in Russia. Amid overall heavy world availabilities and strong competition for available export business, wheat prices at most major origins dipped again in November, edging down by 1% on average. Declines in the US were tied partly to sluggish overseas demand and a bearishly interpreted USDA supply-and-demand report. While buoyant export demand and logistical bottlenecks shored up Black Sea export quotations earlier in the month, particularly in Russia, regional traders were keen to maintain market share and prices began to weaken again in recent weeks. With Russian shipments expected to remain high throughout the season, strong export competition is likely to keep a lid on prices, at least for next year. Assuming that crop prospects do not deteriorate further, we expect Hard Red Winter (HRW) wheat export prices (12% protein, fob Gulf) to fall steadily until mid-2018, before strengthening slightly thereafter. However, higher protein supplies are expected to command a hefty price premium, at least until the 2018/19 northern hemisphere crops enter the pipeline.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Although the regime of the president, Nicolás Maduro, will strengthen its grip on power in the wake of the installation of a Constituent Assembly in 2017, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect Mr Maduro to remain in power beyond 2019. The most likely scenarios for a transition to an opposition-led government are through ad hoc elections after economic collapse or a military coup. There is a risk that the regime will cling to power beyond 2019 if the government finds financing to avoid a disorderedly default or if it manages to boost dwindling oil production.
We estimate that inflation exceeded 2,000% at the end of 2017 and will average over 3,000% in 2018. GDP will continue to contract into 2019. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. We forecast a recovery beginning in 2020, by which time the current opposition is expected to be in government, leading to macro-economic adjustments, and institutional and structural reforms.
Sweeping reforms are required to restore confidence in contract and property rights, and thereby promote a recovery in investment. The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will encourage private investment, re-establish market mechanisms for price stability and attempt to undo the constraints imposed by the government on private firms.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and quadruple-digit inflation will hit private consumption, and an increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate the fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices, and the economy will not return to growth until 2020-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
US dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, GDP contraction and extremely high inflation (driven by shortages of foreign exchange and basic goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. After 2020, under a new government, we expect purchasing power and the business environment to improve.

Venezuela is in 80th position globally in our business environment rankings for 2018-22, out of 82 countries covered, making the country one of the least attractive investment locations in the world. This reflects state intervention-ism, highly heterodox macroeconomic policies, a lack of legal security and weak institutions. Regionally, Venezuela remains last of the 12 countries covered, notwithstanding our assumption of improvements after 2019.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Nationalisation poses a diminished threat, given fiscal weaknesses. Property rights remain weak. Price fixing undermines profitability.
2020-22: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists. A new government in 2019 brings new policies.
2020-22: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain fairly low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2018-19: Unorthodox exchange-rate policy framework adds to uncertainty. The state continues to exercise tight control over access to official-rate US dollars. New government in 2019 removes exchange controls.
2020-22: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2018-19: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2020-22: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2018-19: Credit growth remains firm, but sectoral allocation is distorted by administrative interventions. Banks remain highly profitable, although unpredictable enforcement and a weak regulatory framework heighten instability.
2020-22: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2018-19: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2020-22: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Access to water and electricity supplies remains precarious. Underinvestment in power transmission ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2020-22: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued electricity rationing.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Chávez was diagnosed with cancer in 2011 but, after declaring in July 2012 that he had fully recovered, won a fourth presidential term in October 2012. However, his health quickly deteriorated and he died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has since plummeted.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is a federal republic, successive administrations have proven reluctant to devolve political authority, with the transfer of financial resources from federal to local level highly dependent on the central government. The legislature is unicameral, and elections for the National Assembly take place every five years. In December 2015 the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the legislature. In August 2017 the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) installed a Constituent Assembly with powers over all branches of government and a remit to rewrite the 1999 Constitution-apparently a ploy to entrench the PSUV in power.
Policy issues: Political radicalisation has been reflected in increasingly heterodox economic policymaking, with massive fiscal and monetary stimulus and the nationalisation of industries deemed strategically important. Distortions created by this approach have become evident, with inflation rising sharply in spite of price controls, and capital controls spawning a rampant black market for foreign exchange. Failure to invest part of the oil windfall has led to a startling decline in physical infrastructure. Non-oil production has ground to a halt, leaving the economy entirely dependent on the energy sector. With large oil shipments going to China to repay loans, and (on subsidised terms) to regional neighbours via the PetroCaribe oil-financing scheme (although this is winding down), the country is running short of US dollars, forcing cuts in import spending.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 60% for oil firms. Since 2011 a maximum royalty of 95% has applied to oil extraction. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Official data are unavailable, but we estimate that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$11bn in 2016 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages, narrowing the current-account deficit to 0.7% of GDP.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Even as Venezuela's severe economic woes deepen amid an intensifying debt crisis and hyperinflation, the governing Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has strengthened its hold on power as the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) has slid into disarray. Elections are theoretically due in December 2018, but the electoral schedule remains uncertain. Regardless, and despite the unpopularity of the president, Nicolás Maduro, the govern-ment's history of electoral manipulation means that it is unlikely that the PSUV would leave power via elections. Instead, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects worsening economic conditions to result in a chaotic political transition process, most likely ushering the MUD into power in 2019.
The PSUV's concerted efforts at undermining the MUD explain the latter's inability to effect change. Government tactics have included banning candidacies, jailing popular politicians and stripping all power from the MUD-controlled National Assembly, which in August was superseded by a new Constituent Assembly (ANC). The PSUV-only ANC is formally concerned with rewriting the constitution, but has also taken over all legislative powers during its two-year remit. In addition, the PSUV has fostered divisions within the MUD, rewarding co-operation from some factions while penalising others. This has often created divergent interests within the MUD, leading to a divided front.
The PSUV's future currently depends on the support of three key backers: the state's coercive apparatus (the security forces and military); a sizeable sector of the population dependent on government handouts; and activist groups (so-called colectivos) whose actions place them somewhere between community organisers and PSUV paramilitaries. The key backer in the arrangement is the military. Gendarmerie and armed forces generals control nine of 14 ministries related to infrastructure and the management of the economy. Since November a gendarmerie general, Manuel Quevedo, has served as oil minister and head of PDVSA, the state owned oil company. To maintain the support of its backers, the government plies these groups with resources, with the vast majority coming from PDVSA. We believe that a prolonged interruption in exports by PDVSA would make continuation of such benefits difficult, while at the same time worsening an already calamitous economic situation.
There are two main paths towards a destabilising interruption in PDVSA exports. The most immediate possible path is a disorderly default of sovereign and/or PDVSA external debt. Legal action in the US (as permitted by bond contracts) could result in seizures of PDVSA's assets (such as those of Citgo, a PDVSA-owned, US-based refinery). Such actions, if widespread, could curtail exports dramatically, despite the possibility that PDVSA would take defensive measures to limit the effectiveness of seizures. The second path, which works independently of legal action, relates to PDVSA's falling output. Output has fallen by 20% since Mr Maduro took office, and we expect production to continue dropping into 2018, dragging with it PDVSA's US dollar earnings. However, there is a risk that the Maduro administration could avoid this fate if sufficient Chinese, Indian or Russian investment in the sector supports output.
Although we expect further concessions to the military in 2018, we foresee an ongoing decline in hard-currency earnings, putting the government's patronage system at risk by late 2018 or early 2019. In the context of political polarisation, it would be difficult for the PSUV to appease critics by replacing Mr Maduro with another high-ranking PSUV figure, although such attempts might be made in the first instance. It also seems unlikely that the PSUV would allow free and fair elections. Instead, the most likely progression of events would involve the military pushing the PSUV out and restoring order while paving the way for elections. Under this baseline scenario, an elected MUD government would take office in 2019. However, there is a risk that free and fair elections would be significantly delayed.
Regardless of how and when political transition occurs, the second half of our forecast period is likely to remain volatile and uncertain. In addition to having to contend with holdovers in the colectivos and in the military, the MUD will have to confront huge economic distortions and deep political differences that would test even a unified political party.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The opposition boycotted the nationwide municipal elections held on December 10th 2017, which led to a PSUV sweep. Theoretically, a presidential election is due in December 2018. However, given the PSUV's history of electoral manipulation, postponement or an early election are both possibilities. The latter is more likely, as it would allow the regime to take advantage of the opposition's disarray and pre-empt the effects of a worsening economic situation. Regardless, any presidential election under the PSUV is unlikely to be free and fair. We do expect relatively free and fair elections following the PSUV's exit from power.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Venezuela has come under increasing regional and international pressure. The EU has denounced the regime's anti-democratic practices and banned weapons sales to Venezuela. Similar steps have been taken by Mercosur (a regional bloc comprised of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) and the so called Lima Group, a group of 12 Latin American nations.
Relations with the US have also deteriorated. Both individual sanctions (the last coming on January 5th) and sanctions prohibiting transactions of new Venezuelan debt by US persons have made it nearly impossible for PDVSA or the government to renegotiate its debts. Given Venezuela's extreme dependency on trade with the US (Venezuela exports oil to and imports distillates from the US), the oft-rumoured embargo would have a destabilising effect on the government's patronage system, likely triggering our regime change baseline forecast. A key priority for the Maduro administration will be the maintenance of good relations with Russia, which continues to provide limited financial backing. China, a previous major source of financing, has seemingly with-drawn, as there is no public evidence of new Chinese financing since 2015.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The government's immediate economic policy concern will be fending off debt default and associated legal challenges. The government has gone into arrears on some sovereign and state-owned firms' bonds (including PDVSA), while also making late payments on others. Despite announcing its intention to restructure debt, the government has also restated its commitment to pay while blaming payments delays on US sanctions and the payment system. The situation has been classified as technical default. A successful restructuring by the Maduro regime appears impossible. This is owing to logistical challenges imposed by US sanctions and, more fundamentally, because the government lacks an economic programme agreeable to creditors.
There is no sign yet of lawsuits by bondholders, who so far appear to prefer late payment to lengthy legal battles. Eventually, this stance is likely to change. To avoid PDVSA asset seizures, the government may choose to default on sovereign bonds but adhere to PDVSA's repayment schedule. Sovereign creditors would undoubtedly ask US courts to define PDVSA as an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government in order to seize its assets. However, such claims will take time. In this environment, the timing of likely seizures is unclear. When they do happen, the consequences for import capacity will be devastating. We assume that they would trigger a transition of power and, eventually, a change of economic policy direction.
In the meantime, the government must also grapple with a build-up of huge inflationary and currency depreciation pressures. We assume that the Maduro government will be forced to weaken the currency more substantially in 2018 than it has done so far. However, other much-needed reforms are unlikely to be introduced. Fiscal and monetary policies will remain expansionary, and ad hoc policy intervention and heavy state control of the economy will persist. Amid subdued oil prices, import compression will remain necessary, as other sources of foreign exchange will be hard to find.
Under our baseline scenario we expect the opposition to come to power in 2019, ushering in adjustments designed to correct currency distortions, tighten expansionary fiscal policy and rebuild institutional capacity. We have factored in a financing agreement with the IMF to support the adjustment process, forecasting lending of US$19bn in 2019-22. Efforts to secure increased inflows of foreign direct investment would also be likely under a new government, and would help to improve the balance-of-payments dynamics, although we expect direct investors to remain cautious for some time with regards to Venezuela, with the possible exception of investors in the oil sector.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
The authorities' failure to publish data on the non-financial public-sector accounts since 2012 demonstrates the opacity of the public finances and complicates accurate forecasting of the size of the deficit. We estimate a non-financial public-sector deficit of 19.4% of GDP for 2017 and expect the deficit to remain in double digits in 2018. A transition to a new government should help to ease the deficit to 4.7% of GDP by 2022. The large deficits of the present are mostly being financed by printing money. High inflation and an overvalued currency are eroding the relative value of domestic and external debt, making debt/GDP ratios unreliable indicators of fiscal stability. There is considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing, mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China. As these items are excluded from the public debt statistics, the true size of total public liabilities is understated. Under our baseline forecast of severe economic stress that would see an MUD-led opposition government in 2019, we expect a restructuring process with external creditors to happen.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
Monetary policy under the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) will continue to be driven by the government's desire to keep real interest rates negative and to print money to finance large fiscal deficits; money supply (M2) rose by 874% year on year in November, and preliminary data for December indicates further acceleration in that month. In the context of extremely high inflation, we expect real rates to remain deeply negative until 2019. After that, our forecast of substantial currency and fiscal adjustment under a new government, which implies a substantial tightening of monetary policy, will see real interest rates turn positive.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Amid ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending, we project further contractions in real GDP in 2018-19, following an estimated contraction of 14% in 2017. Our forecast for a recovery in 2020-22 rests on an assumption of slightly higher oil prices (in 2021-22), alongside a political transition that produces a combination of macroeconomic adjustment (supported by IMF financial assistance), and institutional and structural reform. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, given the scale of the recession, and our forecasts therefore imply only a partial rebound, after a real GDP decline of over 40% in 2014-19.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2018, reflecting the effect on real wages of soaring inflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will continue to contract as well, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange, and remitting profits. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition, progress on long­delayed joint projects with Chinese firms in energy and-later in the forecast period-a pick-up in public-sector investment. Exports will continue to shrink throughout 2018 as oil production falls further (we expect output to average below 1.9m barrels/day (b/d) in 2018, compared with an estimated 2m b/d in 2017), but will pick up thereafter, reflecting renewed investment under a new government and a removal of constraints to domestic production. Import demand will rise sharply, in line with an alleviation of basic goods shortages and the release of pent-up demand. Even after the change in govern-ment, however, dependence on oil will persist.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
A decimation of domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have caused elevated inflation for the past two years. The government continues to decree maximum prices as its main policy tool to fight inflation, with the latest attempt coming in mid-November. We do not expect a policy reversal under the PSUV government, meaning that inflation will remain extremely high in the short term. Official data has not been published since 2015, but the opposition-led National Assembly has estimated that prices rose by 1,369% in January-November, following monthly inflation of 56.7% in November. We expect inflation to average over 3,000% in 2018. Shortages of basic goods will continue, as the lack of foreign currency limits imports. We continue to forecast a decline in inflation over time, under the assumption of a recovery in oil output and corrective economic policies under an MUD-led government.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
Currently, a dual exchange-rate system is in operation, comprising an official peg, known as the Dipro, which is limited to priority public-sector imports and set at BsF10:US$1, and a heavily managed auction-based rate known as the Dicom, used for private-sector operations (but where demand for US dollars vastly outstrips supply). Public Dicom auctions were suspended in August, with Mr Maduro announcing the future usage of a "basket of currencies" (such as the rupee, rouble, yuan and euro) to replace the use of the dollar. However, the system is yet to be implemented, as the government seems to be hoarding all foreign exchange available to meet its debt obligations. Amid huge pressures on the dual-currency exchange-rate system, our forecasts assume substantial devaluations in 2018, but the exchange rate will remain extremely overvalued. The suspension of the Dicom, coupled with runaway growth in the money supply, has led to a spike in the black-market foreign-exchange rate, which exceeded BsF130,000:US$1 by early January.
We assume that major currency adjustment under a new, MUD-led government in 2019 would involve immediate exchange-rate unification. Until that occurs, given existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market, there is an extremely high risk of a debilitating currency crisis in the short term. If confidence in the bolívar collapses amid hyperinflation, dollarisation-or the launch of a new domestic currency-could occur.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
We forecast a current-account deficit of 1.8% of GDP in 2018, as exports, held back by decaying infrastructure, falling oil production and lack of exploration, will be unable to offset imports, despite the government's best efforts at dampening them (we estimate that the value of imports in 2017 will be equivalent to one-fifth of those of 2012). After 2019, with a new administration in place, exports and imports will begin a recovery. Our assumption of economic adjustment in the medium term suggests a recovery in investment inflows, particularly into the oil sector. In addition, financial inflows in the wake of debt re-structuring, and financial and technical assistance from the IMF, should help to rebuild reserves coverage. This will buttress the stability of the external accounts and facilitate the gradual removal of foreign-exchange controls, as reflected by a convergence of the official and parallel exchange rates.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Despite a narrow victory and allegations of vote fraud in the presidential reform referendum on April 16th 2017, the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, is moving ahead with his plan to install a presidential system of government after elections due in 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that Mr Erdogan and his ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) will win the elections. The presidential system will further undermine Turkey's fragile democratic institutions and governance structures. It provides few checks on the powers of the president and moves the country closer to one-man rule.
Since the failed coup foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by Mr Erdogan's domestic political goals, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government. This has resulted in a marked deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. We expect a complete rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high.
The AKP has enjoyed 15 years of single-party rule, and for most of that period political and government effectiveness have improved. However, since 2013 economic policymaking institutions have become increasingly politicised. Despite tax increases in 2018, we expect annual deficits to widen moderately, to 2.4% of GDP on average in 2018-19. After the elections we forecast that the deficit will shrink gradually, to 1.6% of GDP in 2022. The risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances cannot be ruled out.
We expect real GDP growth to slow from an estimated 7% in 2017 (revised up from 5.5%), to a still robust 4.1% per year on average in the forecast period (2018-22), reflecting the withdrawal of stimulus measures and higher taxes. Our growth forecast assumes that domestic political conditions will stabilise and foreign investor confidence in Turkey will hold up, maintaining foreign capital inflows.
After a fall in the nominal value of the Turkish lira of about 17% against the US dollar in 2017, we expect the pace of depreciation to slow, keeping the currency broadly stable in real terms. Constrained in its ability to raise interest rates, we expect the Central Bank of Turkey to have to resort to unorthodox and less effective tools to respond to currency weakness and high inflation.
We expect the current-account deficit to narrow moderately, from an estimated 5% of GDP in 2017 to an annual average of 4.5% of GDP in 2018 22. This is still sufficiently large to make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is severely constrained and investor confidence deteriorates.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2018-22, but the country's global ranking falls by ten places, to 55th. There is consensus among policymakers on the need to maintain macroeconomic stability. However, the failed coup and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2020-22: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in a wide range of sectors, although the opening up of the energy market makes progress.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2020-22: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade and tourism following the lifting of Russian sanctions.
2020-22: The cstoms union with the EU could be extended, but negotiations are likely to be protracted given the deterioration in Turkish-EU relations. More free-trade agreements may come into force with the EU's trading partners.
Taxes
2018-19: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Some tax rate rises, including on company profits, have been announced for 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit.
2020-22: A broader income tax base as exemptions and exceptions are reduced.
Financing
2018-19: Monetary policy remains cautious, but political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey not to raise interest rates continues. Risk of the US imposing fines on several Turkish banks over alleged violations of US sanctions on Iran.
2020-22: The banking system remains stable, despite some weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2018-19: Labour market remains rigid, with relatively high costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. Wage moderation after 30% minimum wage rise in 2016. Obstacles to employing foreigners have eased.
2020-22: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Progress, albeit slow, continues on investment plans in energy, transport and communications.
2020-22: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Third Istanbul airport becomes operational. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks could persist.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West, becoming a member of the Council of Europe (1949) and NATO (1952), and signing an association agreement with the then European Community (1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup at-tempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey has a unicameral parliamentary system of government, with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Under the AKP, Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019, and possibly earlier. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions will require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing political issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015 and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted long-standing institutional weaknesses, which, with the AKP's consent until 2013, allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Further politicisation of the judiciary is likely following the coup attempt. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax has been raised from 20% to 22% in 2018. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2016 goods exports (fob) came to US$150.2bn and imports (fob) to US$191bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$40.9bn-a contraction from US$48.1bn in 2015. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Among the most important political events in the 2018-22 forecast period will be the three crucial votes in 2019: municipal elections, due to be held in March; and parliamentary and presidential elections, due in November. After these votes an executive presidential system of government will replace the current parliamentary system. The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his ruling, religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, will win the elections and remain in power until 2024, and probably beyond. The constitutional reforms to establish a presidential system, which were approved in a referendum in April 2017, provide few checks and balances on the powers of the president. This will further weaken Turkey's democratic institutions and governance structures, effectively moving the country into a system of one-man rule by Mr Erdogan. Although an unlikely prospect, failure by Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win the elections could throw the political system into chaos and open up irreparable divisions in the AKP.
Although the intense political instability that followed the failed coup has eased partially, we expect social and political tensions to intensify during the period up to the elections in 2019, and possibly beyond. The narrow presidential reform referendum victory, amid allegations of vote tampering, has further polarised the country. It has also raised concerns among the AKP's leaders that Mr Erdogan and his party are losing support. With the president's political future dependent on clear victories in all three elections, the government will continue its campaign against political opponents, critics and perceived enemies of the state, using the state of emergency law. Emergency rule was initially introduced after the failed coup to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. We expect emergency rule to remain in place until after the elections, because it will effectively allow Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is fully in place.
Security risk will remain high, with negative implications for the economy. The state is seeking to end an insurgency by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) in the south-east of Turkey, address the domestic security risk of terrorist attacks by Kurdish militants and Islamic State (IS), and implement military operations in Syria and Iraq against IS and the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds. The operational capacity problems created by the purge of the Turkish Armed Forces (TSK) and the police after the attempted coup appear to have eased to a large extent, but Turkey remains vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the PKK and IS. In the short to medium term neither the government nor the PKK appears to be interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will intensify.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
We expect Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win the municipal, presidential and parliamentary elections in 2019. The opposition is fragmented, Mr Erdogan's popularity is still unrivalled and he has the support of the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP). Importantly, the AKP also has the ability to control the election process. However, there are concerns within the AKP that the party has lost support since the referendum, and that victory for Mr Erdogan in the presidential election is far from assured, especially if Abdullah Gul, a former president and co-founder of the AKP, decides to run. The challenge of Mr Gul, combined with that of the charismatic Meral Aksener, who recently formed the Good Party (IP), a breakaway group from the MHP, and the leader of the main opposition Republican People's Party (CHP), Kemal Kilicdaroglu, could prevent Mr Erdogan from reaching the 50% threshold for victory in the first round. This would transform the second-round run-off between Mr Erdogan and the candidate with the second-largest share of votes into a deeply polarising referendum on Mr Erdogan's leadership.
The clampdown on the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) since mid-2015, the decision of the MHP leadership to back the presidential reform, and the hardline nationalist stance adopted by Mr Erdogan and the AKP could have a considerable effect on voting patterns at the next parliamentary election. Both the MHP and the HDP have been weakened since the 2015 election and run the risk of falling below the high 10% national vote threshold for parliamentary representation. This would boost the AKP's seat share, even if we expect that in exchange for the MHP's support for Mr Erdogan in the presidential election there will be an electoral alliance between the AKP and MHP to ensure that the MHP retains its representation in parliament. Under the constitutional changes approved in the referendum there will be 600 seats in a much weakened parliament from the next election, up from 550 currently.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. There is a considerable risk of a rupture in Turkey's ties with its traditional Western allies, compounding their concerns that under Mr Erdogan the country is pivoting eastwards. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration, including political upheaval in Europe and the US; a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; the US's military backing of Syrian Kurdish groups, which Turkey regards as terrorist organisations affiliated to the PKK; the Turkish government's authoritarian tendencies and its strident anti-Western rhetoric; and Turkey's forging of closer relations with Russia, China and Iran. Turkey's confrontational approach to its traditional Western allies should also be viewed in the context of Mr Erdogan's need to maintain the support of Turkey's nationalists to achieve his domestic political goals, notably to become president with executive powers after elections in 2019.
We expect Turkey and its Western allies to seek to avoid a complete breakdown in relations. However, this might become unavoidable if the EU suspends Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, the migrant deal with the EU collapses, the US imposes sanctions on Turkey over alleged violations by Turkish banks of US sanctions against Iran, Turkey closes the Incirlik air base to US forces, or it withdraws from NATO, none of which can be ruled out completely. Regardless, Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and increasingly transactional rather than strategic.
The spillover of violence from the conflicts in neighbouring Syria and Iraq will continue to pose serious domestic and external security threats to Turkey. In addition to terrorist attacks carried out in Turkey by IS and the PKK, which has camps in the mountains in northern Iraq, Turkey now has military forces de-ployed in two areas in Syria, ostensibly as part of the fight against IS and other jihadi groups, but also to prevent US-backed, PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurds from establishing a continuous autonomous region along Syria's northern border with Turkey.
The neighbouring conflicts are also likely to continue influencing the direction of Turkey's foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly in relation to the conflict in Syria, where both are militarily involved but have been pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to continue to be largely transactional. The risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector and its dynamic, diversified private business sector. However, the risk of an intensification of political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity could disrupt foreign capital inflows during the forecast period. These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, but tend to be short-term and highly volatile. Shifts in capital flows triggered by expectations of tighter US monetary policy and geopolitical tensions in the neighbouring region have already put the lira under severe pressure on several occasions since late 2016, fuelling an acceleration in inflation. Under political pressure not to raise interest rates further, especially ahead of the 2019 elections, the Central Bank of Turkey is constrained in its ability to tighten monetary policy. In the event of another severe weakening of the lira, an abrupt tightening of policy, which could strangle Turkey's economic recovery, may be necessary. However, this is not our baseline scenario.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The current direction of policy appears to be towards a difficult balancing act between fiscal loosening and tight monetary policy at the same time as encouraging banks to lend to households and businesses.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios-reflecting the impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past and major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-give the government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy. Our baseline forecast remains that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight to support investor confidence and to prevent a surge in domestic demand from causing an unsustainable widening of the current-account deficit. Nevertheless, we expect the central government deficit, which captures most of the public sector, to have expanded from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to an estimated 1.9% in 2017. Despite a series of tax increases this year, we expect increased government spending on defence, security, infrastructure projects and public employment ahead of elections next year to cause the deficit to widen further, to an average of 2.4% of GDP in 2018-19, before narrowing to 1.6% in 2022. We expect the central government debt/GDP ratio to remain stable at about 29.2% in 2017-19, before declining gradually to about 28% in 2022. The risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances cannot be ruled out.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The Central Bank of Turkey will have to keep its monetary policy tight in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent further depreciation of the lira amid political volatility and expectations of higher US interest rates and balance-sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank). However, because of political pressure not to raise interest rates further, we expect the central bank to have to resort to unorthodox and less effective tools to respond to the challenge, which will periodically test investor confidence in the bank's policy mix of moderate rate rises and macroprudential measures. The bank raised most of its main policy rates between November 2016 and April 2017, but since November 2017 it has focused on using its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate to fund the banking system. This rate was gradually raised by a total of 275 basis points in 2017, to 12.75% in mid-December, pushing the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system to 12.75%, compared with 7.8% in November 2016.
The central bank is seeking gradually to normalise its monetary policy frame-work to establish a single policy interest rate, which would help to improve transparency regarding monetary policy decisions. However, it is unlikely that this will happen until inflation is more firmly on a downward path towards its medium-term target of 5% and domestic political uncertainty eases.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Real GDP growth is estimated to have accelerated sharply, from an annual average of 3.3% in 2016 to 7% in 2017 (revised up from 5.5% following the release of stronger than expected third-quarter national accounts in December). The rebound has been supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit and a pick-up in global demand. We expect growth to slow to an annual average of 4.1% in the forecast period, reflecting the impact of tax increases, higher interest rates, the withdrawal of government stimulus measures introduced to support the economy after the coup attempt in July 2016 and a gradual tightening of global liquidity. There are downside risks to our forecast, which is predicated on the assumption that the transition to a presidential system of government will not lead to further political instability that could deter foreign capital inflows.
We forecast that household consumption growth will moderate from an estimated 5.5% in 2017 to a still solid 3.2% per year in 2018-22 as a result of higher interest rates and the withdrawal of government incentives to support household spending. We also expect government consumption growth be strong, at an annual average rate of 5.8% in 2018-19, easing after the elections to a more moderate but still robust 4.8% in 2020-22.
The deterioration in the business environment since the attempted coup and an increase in the corporation tax rate to 22% from 2018 will continue to hold down private-sector fixed investment growth. However, we expect this to be offset by government investment, especially in infrastructure, generating real growth of 6.7% per year in 2017-19. In 2020-22 we forecast a deceleration to annual growth of 4.8% per year, reflecting public-sector retrenchment and firms' response to a more moderate expansion of domestic and external demand.
The lifting of Russian sanctions on Turkey, especially in the tourism sector; the positive effect of a weaker lira on export competitiveness; and strong external demand have contributed to a rebound in exports of goods and services. However, we expect growth to slow from an estimated 11.5% in 2017 to an annual average rate of 4.7% in 2018-22, reflecting base effects and our view that 2017 probably represented the recent peak in global economic growth. We continue to expect a cyclical downturn in the US in 2020 to dampen external demand growth in that year.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target-as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disinflationary effects of low global oil prices. We expect the pass-through effects of past currency weakness and a moderate recovery in oil and other commodity prices from 2017 to keep consumer price inflation well above the official target during the first half of the forecast period. Assuming that the central bank does not loosen monetary policy too soon, we expect inflation to ease gradually, achieving the 5% target by end-2022. There are significant upside risks to our forecast.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
After a fall in the nominal value of the lira of about 17% against the US dollar in 2017, we expect the pace of depreciation to slow during the forecast period, keeping the currency broadly stable in real terms. There are substantial risks to this forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows as well as the impact on investor confidence of domestic political tensions and geopolitical turmoil in the region. We expect the lira to average TL4.345:US1 in 2022, compared with TL3.648:US$1 in 2017.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Although we expect the current-account deficit to narrow moderately from an estimated 5% of GDP to an annual average of 4.5% of GDP in 2018-22, Turkey's external financing needs will still be difficult to meet if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates. Although a weaker lira and the lifting of Russian sanctions will boost Turkey's main exports, we expect this to be largely offset by the moderately higher cost of imported energy and inputs for manufactured import-intensive exports. The rebound in tourist arrivals in 2017 will remain vulnerable to a possible resurgence of terrorist attacks in the country.

Abstract: [...]the country drops one place in the regional ranking, to 11th and two places in the global ranking, to 18th. [...]he led the ÖVP to a plurality of the vote in the early election on October 15th, winning a 31.5% share-up by 7.5 percentage points on its result in 2013. In order to assuage worries from Mr Kurz and the president, Alexander Van der Bellen, about the FPÖ's previous Euroscepticism, the party has agreed not to push for a referendum on EU membership. [...]EU policy will be handled by the chancellery instead of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which will be headed by an FPÖ appointee. [...]we expect real GDP growth to accelerate to 3.1% this year-above growth in Germany for the first time since 2005 and Austria's fastest growth rate since 2007.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart in May 2017 following the resignation of the ÖVP leader. An early election was held on October 15th.
The popularity of the ÖVP's new leader, the young minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, propelled his party into first place. In mid-December he managed to form a coalition together with the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ).
The inclusion of the FPÖ in the government will not lead to sanctions from other EU member states as in 2000, when the party was last part of a coalition, owing largely to the normalisation of the far right in Europe since then.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the new government to focus on integration and immigration policy, and to attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and introduce some additional flexibility in labour and product markets. However, low government cohesion is likely to lead to limited progress.
The government budget is forecast to remain in deficit, albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP, throughout the forecast period (2018-22), as the fiscal consolidation process is likely to be restrained by limited government cohesion and effectiveness. The public debt/GDP ratio will fall gradually, to just below 70% by 2022, from an estimated 79.6% in 2017.
After several years of underperformance compared with its regional peers, the economy has performed relatively strongly since the start of 2016, growing by 1.4% in that year. We estimate an acceleration of growth this year, to 3.1%, and forecast that growth will moderate to 1.8% on average in 2018-22.
Consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) will continue to exceed the euro zone average in 2017-22, driven by structural domestic factors including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets. Annual inflation averaged 0.9% in 2015,-16 and was above 2% throughout the first ten months of 2017. We expect annual average EU harmonised inflation of 2.1% in 2017-22.
The current-account surplus has been relatively stable in recent years, at about 2%. Although we expect small changes in the composition of the surplus, we expect it to remain relatively stable in the forecast period, at 1.9% of GDP on average in 2017-22.

Austria's business environment score improves slightly between the historical period (2013-17) and the forecast period (2018-22). As a result, the country drops one place in the regional ranking, to 11th and two places in the global ranking, to 18th. Austria's strengths as a business location include good infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited.
2020-22: Modest strengthening of competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2020-22: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal.
2020-22: EU maintains focus on bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate. No progress on EU-US trade deal. Free-trade agreement between EU and UK.
Taxes
2018-19: Limited changes to the tax system aimed at reducing the sizeable income tax wedge.
2020-22: Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform, and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2018-19: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe.
2020-22: Further uptake in corporate bond issuance. Credit conditions continue to ease as banks' profitability recovers, in part supported by a gradual uptick in interest rates.
The labour market
2018-19: Economy-wide minimum wage introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment starts to fall.
2020-22: Continued modest expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2020-22: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure.

Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election was held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government will focus on migration and integration issues, including in the EU context. It will also attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and implement other measures to improve the business environment, including through enabling more flexibility in the labour market.
Taxation: Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is among the highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: In 2016 the value of exported goods was US$142.7bn and the goods import bill was US$142.3bn. The services surplus, traditionally boosted by tourism receipts, was US$12.2bn. Along with a modest primary income deficit and significant secondary income deficit, this yielded a current-account surplus equivalent to 2.1% of GDP.
