Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
In May 2017, after several years of little progress on reforms and coalition and party in-fighting, the grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart following the resignation of Reinhold Mitterlehner from the positions of vice-chancellor, minister of economy and leader of the ÖVP, citing frustration within his party. The popular 31-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, took over the leadership of the ÖVP and reformed the party around himself. As a result, he led the ÖVP to a plurality of the vote in the early election on October 15th, winning a 31.5% share-up by 7.5 percentage points on its result in 2013. The SPÖ's vote share was unchanged, at 26.9%. The far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) increased its vote by 5.5 percentage points, to 26%. The liberal NEOS returned to parliament with just over 5% of the vote, and the Greens failed to cross the 4% electoral threshold for the first time in 31 years, in part because List Pilz, led by a former leader of the Greens, narrowly managed to cross it.
The ÖVP and the FPÖ formed a coalition in mid-December after just over a month and a half of negotiations. Under Mr Kurz the ÖVP has moved close to the FPÖ in many policy areas (during the campaign the leader of the FPÖ, Heinz-Christian Strache, regularly criticised Mr Kurz for stealing the FPÖ's programme) and the negotiations thus went relatively smoothly. In order to assuage worries from Mr Kurz and the president, Alexander Van der Bellen, about the FPÖ's previous Euroscepticism, the party has agreed not to push for a referendum on EU membership. Moreover, EU policy will be handled by the chancellery instead of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which will be headed by an FPÖ appointee.
Although the chancellor is from the ÖVP, the election should still be seen as a further step in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the ÖVP has been replaced to a large extent by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties have together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, and a renewed grand coalition had become almost impossible following the breakdown of relations between the two parties and the gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited both from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz owes much of his popularity to his strong stance on this issue and his plans to curtail migration into Europe and Austria.
Despite the overlap between the ÖVP's and the FPÖ's programmes, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to struggle to implement its policies, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters and the FPÖ could struggle to translate its opposition stance on matters such as immigration and integration into concrete policy proposals. As a result, we expect limited progress on significant structural reforms. Although the initial phase of the government's term is likely to be relatively smooth, once the focus shifts to international and EU issues, tensions between the ÖVP and the FPÖ are likely to increase and the risk of an early election is high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The last general election was held on October 15th 2017. Unless the government falls before then, it will sit until the end of the term of the new Nationalrat (the lower house of parliament) in late 2022.
Elections for several state parliaments are planned for the first half of 2018. The next election for the primarily ceremonial post of federal president will be in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions, including the leading role that it played in closing the migration route through the Balkans. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this influx, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high. All three of the large parties have hinted that they want to limit labour migration within the EU, or at least give preferential treatment to Austrian citizens in the labour market, which could exacerbate tensions with many EU member states.
Nevertheless, Mr Kurz has been at pains to point out that his government will be pro-EU, and that Austria's EU membership will not be questioned in the coming years. The new government plans for Austria to be a leading voice in the EU in the coming years, especially on reform of migration. We expect it to find broad support for proposals such as tighter controls of the EU's outer borders and processing asylum applications outside the EU.
Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ in government following the 1999 election led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations in 2000, we do not expect this to be repeated this time. At that time a far-right nationalist party entering government was an unusual development, but since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority govern-ments in several EU countries, including some Nordic countries, Italy and the Netherlands.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Alongside the 2016 tax reform, which provided about EUR5bn in tax relief to households, government policy in recent years has focused on challenges facing the country's financial sector. These have included the clean-up and debt restructuring of Heta Asset Resolution, a "bad bank" that was created to deal with the toxic assets of Hypo Group Alpe Adria (HGAA). The uncertainty surrounding Heta was removed in October 2016, when creditors accepted a debt-restructuring deal.
In the renegotiation of its coalition agreement in January 2017 the previous coalition decided on a number of measures that it hoped to implement before the end of its term in 2018. These included a new annual minimum wage of EUR21,000, as opposed to only sector-specific negotiated minimum wages, and reducing red tape for employers, including more flexible rules on working hours. The new govern-ment will move integration and immigration policy further to the right and plans to focus on improving the business environment, including by reducing the sizeable tax wedge, but we expect it to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly. Whereas the parties mentioned plans to reform the country's corporatist system, the coalition agree-ment suggests only limited change in this regard.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
In 2014 Austria's fiscal accounts deteriorated, mainly reflecting the govern-ment's decision to create a bad bank to deal with HGAA's toxic assets. The fiscal deficit widened to the equivalent of 2.7% of GDP, from 2% in 2013, and public debt rose to 83.7% of GDP. Mainly in response to steady direct revenue growth, the deficit narrowed to 1% of GDP in 2015, but widened again in 2016, to 1.6%, owing in part to fiscally expansionary tax reforms and higher migrant-related public spending.
We expect the budget to remain in deficit throughout the forecast period (2018-22), albeit safely within the EU mandated limit of 3% of GDP. Despite only limited fiscal consolidation, robust economic growth will help to narrow the deficit slightly. The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from an estimated 79.6% in 2017 to just below 70% in 2022. Although the public finances will remain worse than in peers such as Germany or the Netherlands, the low interest-rate environment and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals mean that funding risks are extremely low in our view.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The European Central Bank (ECB) is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that will run at EUR60bn per month until the end of 2017, and at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. The economic recovery in the euro zone has strengthened this year and has become more broad based. We expect another healthy expansion of real GDP in the euro zone in 2018, of 2.1%, after estimated growth of 2.4% in 2017. The ECB continues to take stock of this growth momentum, but maintains a clearly dovish policy stance, with the reduction in the amount of monthly QE purchases in 2018 designed to extend its presence in the bond markets. The bank also plans to delay raising interest rates and will reinvest the principal payments from maturing securities for a period well beyond the end of the QE programme. We expect the pace of monthly QE purchases to be reduced to zero in early 2019, but owing to subdued price pressure and persistent downside risks to growth, we forecast that the bank will delay raising policy rates until 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy largely stalled and under-performed in comparison with regional peers, notably Germany; this was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. A faltered reform process has contributed to higher inflation compared with regional peers and weakened productivity growth, admittedly from fairly high levels. Real GDP growth was sluggish even by euro zone standards in 2012-16.
However, the economy recently started to gain momentum again, with average quarterly growth of 0.9% between July 2016 and September 2017. Although in previous years the labour market had struggled to integrate the significant increase in the labour force, it seemed to have turned a corner in late 2016 and early 2017, in part owing to a surge in employment in the manufacturing sector. This is supporting private consumption, which we expect to grow by 1.5% this year. Furthermore, export and investment growth have also picked up. As a result, we expect real GDP growth to accelerate to 3.1% this year-above growth in Germany for the first time since 2005 and Austria's fastest growth rate since 2007.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-following an under-performance even compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue next year, although we forecast slower growth, at 2.4%, as we expect the impulse from the manufacturing sector in 2017 to have been a one-off. In the following years we expect a moderation of growth. Domestic demand will be the main driver of growth, which is likely to converge towards potential growth in these years. We therefore expect average real GDP growth of 1.7% in 2019-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.9% in 2015-16-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices and energy-price base effects fostered a gradual increase in inflation from October 2016 into 2017, when we estimate full-year average inflation of 2.2%. Recent strengthening of the euro will weigh slightly on inflation, but we expect it to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-22, at 2.1% on average, as similar structural factors as in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
The euro has moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1 since mid-2015. The annual average exchange rate was US$1.11:EUR1 in 2016, although a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. The euro has since rallied as the region's economic recovery has strengthened, and as political risk has waned in Europe but risen in the US. More recently, a rise in expectations of QE tapering by the ECB has prompted a sharp appreciation in the euro against the dollar. The value of the euro could yet come under pressure from political risk-especially in relation to the next general election in Italy, which we expect to take place in early 2018-and monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a gradual appreciation on average, to US$1.20:EUR1 by 2020-21, as the euro is supported by an ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, while the business cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020. We expect the euro to appreciate further in 2022 as the monetary policy tightening cycle begins.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values helped the trade balance to move into surplus in 2014-16, from a deficit in 2009-13. We expect the trade balance to move back into a modest deficit from 2017 as robust export growth is outweighed by higher import costs and strengthening domestic demand pushes up import volumes. However, this will be compensated for by a healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourist inflows. Modest primary income surpluses will not be enough to outweigh consistent secondary income deficits. However, we expect the services balance largely to offset the weakening trade balance and the current-account surplus to remain broadly flat throughout 2017-22, at about 2% of GDP on average.

Background: The political geography of Europe has been defined by two world wars and the legacy of the cold war, during which Europe was divided into two blocs. The ending of Soviet control over central and eastern Europe from 1989, followed by the collapse in 1991 of the Soviet Union, provided an opportunity to expand the EU eastwards. Ten new member states (eight from the former communist bloc) were admitted to the EU in 2004, followed by a further two in 2007, and Croatia in 2013. In June 2016 the UK electorate voted in a referendum to withdraw from the EU. The economic transition of the Visegrad countries (the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia) has proceeded more smoothly than that of other east European countries. The effects of war in former Yugoslavia in the 1990s and a slower pace of reform have shaped developments in south-east Europe.
Political structure: All 28 EU member states are parliamentary democracies, although in some of the newer, former communist members in particular the substance of democracy-including a political culture based on trust and healthy levels of political participation-is often absent. The communist period lasted much longer in the former Soviet Union, and political developments in most parts of that region have been characterised by a drift towards authoritarianism.
Policy issues: Many aspects of domestic policy for EU member states-in particular those relating to the single market-are decided collectively at the EU level. Nineteen EU member states share the euro as their currency. These countries are subject to a single monetary policy administered by the European Central Bank (ECB). They are supposed to comply with common fiscal rules, although these have often been ignored. During the euro zone debt crisis several member states (Cyprus, Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain) ceded varying degrees of policy control to the EU and the IMF in exchange for receiving financial support. Although the euro zone crisis has passed its peak, normalisation remains a long way off. The Economist Intelligence Unit continues to attach a 60% probability to Greece leaving the euro zone during its medium-term forecast period (2018-22). Outside the EU, the speed and extent of reform and institutional change vary widely. Countries with proximity to Western markets and with stable political outlooks have proceeded faster and more successfully with economic stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation. Institutional problems, such as weakness in the rule of law and widespread corruption, plague much of non-EU Europe.
Taxation: Individual tax regimes operate in all countries. All EU member states must operate a system of value-added tax (VAT), with a minimum of 15% as the standard rate.
Foreign trade: If intra-EU trade is included, the EU accounts for about half of all global trade. About 60% of trade conducted by EU member states is intra-regional.

Summary
Political stability
Popular disaffection with mainstream parties will persist in 2018 and Europe will remain subject to heightened geopolitical risk.
The failure to form a new government coalition in Germany after the September 2017 federal election has led to difficult and potentially protracted negotiations between the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and the Social Democratic Party (SPD), and the risk of another election.
Political uncertainty in Germany, an election in Italy, the Catalonia crisis, the Brexit process, Russia-EU tensions and vulnerability to political instability in parts of the CIS and the Balkans will test Europe in 2018.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Brexit negotiations between the UK and the EU to result in a deal in March 2019 on a transitional period lasting up to two years, but the risk that negotiations will break down is significant.
We expect Vladimir Putin to win the presidential election in Russia in 2018. We expect EU sanctions on Russia to be maintained over the medium term and for relations to remain difficult, competitive and conflict-prone.
Economic policy
In late 2017 the Bank of England reversed its post-referendum interest-rate cut of 0.25%. It is likely to keep policy accommodative given Brexit uncertainty, but we now expect it to normalise policy in mid-2019 rather than early 2020.
We expect the European Central Bank (ECB) to increase policy rates in 2022, continuing the very loose monetary stance of recent years. The ECB will reduce net asset purchases to EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018.
There may be attempts to rebalance the monetary and fiscal policy mix in the euro zone, but the bloc's fiscal rules could make this a contentious process.
Economic reform has progressed well in some countries, including Spain and Ireland, but for most the main challenges lie ahead. With political fragmentation on the rise, policymaking is becoming more difficult.
Economic growth
We forecast average real GDP growth in the EU28 at an average of 1.8% in 2018-22, following estimated growth of 2.4% in 2017.
We expect a real GDP growth slowdown in the UK in 2018-19, to 1.5% per year, because of Brexit uncertainty, and an acceleration in 2019-22.
Business environment rankings
The business environment has improved in most European countries as the post-crisis economic recovery has gathered pace. However, fragilities remain.

Political outlook : Political stability
The UK's vote in June 2016 to leave the EU represents a serious challenge to the future cohesion of the bloc. Despite the professed unity of the other 27 member states, the departure of one of the biggest members is a profound shock that is likely to reverberate. The EU's management of the Brexit crisis has been further complicated by an outbreak of political instability in Germany, where the outcome of the September 2017 federal election dealt a blow to the two leading parties, the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) of the chancellor, Angela Merkel, and the Social Democratic Party (SPD). The failure to form a so-called Jamaica coalition-comprising the CDU; its partner, the Christian Social Union (CSU); the Free Democratic Party (FDP); and The Greens-was a further blow to the authority of the chancellor. The prospect of difficult negotiations between the CDU/CSU and the SPD dragging on into early 2018 has created more political uncertainty at a testing time for the EU. The Catalonia crisis, which burst into focus in October after pro-independence citizens voting in an illegal referendum encountered state violence, poses another threat to the cohesion of the EU. Nor is the populist challenge to established parties across the bloc likely to dissipate, and a general election in Italy in 2018 is likely to result in a victory for the insurgent Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S), although because of the new electoral system the party is unlikely to obtain a parliamentary majority, and is unlikely to be willing to join a coalition with mainstream parties.
The lesson of the past eight years, since the onset of the euro zone crisis in late 2009, is that politicians have underestimated the economic and political challenges facing the bloc and have prematurely claimed that the worst is over. Threats to the future of the EU, including the sovereign debt crisis, the migration crisis and the populist insurgency, have not been resolved. The existential threat to the euro has certainly lessened since the height of the sovereign debt crisis in 2010-13, when the danger of one of the peripheral economies being forced out of the euro zone, through a loss of investor confidence and a spike in bond yields, weighed heavily on sentiment and investment. The commitment of the European Central Bank (ECB) to the euro has largely neutralised speculative pressure in the bond markets, but the single currency is still vulnerable, with Greece and Italy being the most obvious causes for concern. Another migration crisis could unfold if the deal between the EU and Turkey were to break down because of a deterioration in relations between the two sides. Most seriously, popular disaffection with the political order in Europe remains substantial, which is likely to fuel support for anti-establishment parties and bring about destabilising political realignments across the continent in the coming years.
The French president, Emmanuel Macron, has sought to re-energise the Franco-German partnership, and in an ambitious speech in September laid out sweeping plans for EU and euro zone reform. His ideas for a euro zone budget and finance minister will face strong resistance in Germany. Plans for greater EU integration in areas such as defence and tax harmonisation have a greater chance of success, although progress is unlikely to be possible until a new German government is formed. Many of Mr Macron's ideas are not new-and some enjoy widespread support in the EU already-but the energy he is putting into championing his vision for Europe marks a sharp change from the more managerial European leadership style of Ms Merkel. The problem is that there is little appetite for some of his bolder ideas in Germany or elsewhere in Europe.
German election delivers blow to coalition parties
The centre-right CDU, together with its Bavarian sister party, the CSU, won the largest vote share in Germany's federal election on September 24th, with 32.9% of the vote. The centre-left SPD scored its worst result in the post-war period, with 20.5% of the vote. The far-right, populist Alternative for Germany (AfD) won 12.6%, enough to enter the Bundestag (the lower house of parliament) for the first time, and the pro-business Free Democratic Party (FDP) re-entered the Bundestag, with 10.7% of the vote. The other, smaller parties, the Left Party and The Greens, were also beneficiaries of popular dissatisfaction with the political mainstream, winning 9.2% and 8.9% of the vote respectively.
The AfD outperformed the polls and did especially well in the former east Germany, where the party became the second-largest political force. Exit polls showed that the issue of migration and refugees was the main reason given for voting for the AfD, with many voters also indicating that this was a protest vote. The CDU and the SPD tried to downplay the issue in the campaign, which goes some way to explaining both the success of the AfD and the drop in vote share for the two large mainstream parties.
Conventional politics upended across the continent
Recent elections across Europe have followed the German pattern, in that electorates are increasingly favouring alternative or populist parties over the mainstream parties and candidates. The result has been more political fragmentation, protracted negotiations to form a government and the emergence of unusual government coalitions. Elections held in the Netherlands, Norway, Austria, Iceland and the Czech Republic in 2017 illustrate the trend towards increased political fragmentation, as well as a more complicated policymaking outlook.
The parliamentary election in the Netherlands on March 15th 2017 led to a fragmented result, with the centre-right People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD) winning the most seats in the 150-seat parliament, with 33, down from 41 in 2012. The right-wing, populist Party for Freedom (PVV), led by Geert Wilders, which is the main outlet for public frustration with much of the traditional political mainstream, came second, albeit with 13 seats fewer than the VVD.
After almost seven months of negotiations following the parliamentary election, in early October the VVD, the Christian Democratic Appeal (CDA), Democrats 66 (D66) and the Christian Union (CU) finalised a coalition agreement and the government-the third of the prime minister, Mark Rutte-was sworn in on October 26th. A wafer-thin majority of one seat in both houses of parliament means that the coalition will be under threat from the start from dissident members of parliament (MPs), and it is therefore likely to prove unstable. Risks will increase following the provincial elections in 2019, which function as an indirect election for the Senate (the upper house of parliament). The previous government was the first in almost 20 years to sit out its full term, and there is an elevated risk of this government falling over any contentious issue, given the deep ideological differences between some of its members, especially between D66 and the CU. The Economist Intelligence Unit therefore expects the government to increasingly seek co-operation with opposition parties. Mr Rutte's previous experience in this area should support government stability and we expect the government to be relatively effective in implementing policy.
Despite a slightly disappointing election result, the PVV remains the main conduit for dissatisfaction with the traditional political mainstream, with the Netherlands having been a bellwether for the rise of right-wing populism in Europe since the early 2000s. The PVV has been a mainstay on the political scene since its founder, leader and only member, Mr Wilders, left the VVD in 2006 and supported a minority government in 2010-12. It became the second-largest party this year, but managed to gain only five seats compared with the election in 2012-it now has 20, compared with 24 after the 2010 election, its best result so far-despite having led the polls throughout most of 2016. The party will continue to be ostracised by the political mainstream; however, it is the main opposition party and, together with the right-wing populist Forum for Democracy (FvD), which is now almost as big as the PVV in some polls, should remain a thorn in the sides of the established parties.
Mainstream implosion in France
Despite the relatively poor performance of Marine Le Pen of the Front national (FN) in the presidential election in France in May 2017, the virtual collapse of the established political parties of both right and left was probably the most striking feature of the campaign. As a result, Mr Macron, the leader of a new centrist party, La République en marche (LRM), began a five-year term as president on May 14th 2017, succeeding François Hollande of the centre-left Parti socialiste (PS), under whom he had served as economy minister in 2014-16. His new party won the largest share of the vote in the legislative elections in June.
Mr Macron has promised a policy programme that is "both left and right", and his government reflects this. The prime minister, Édouard Philippe, hails from the main centre-right party, Les Républicains, and leads a post-partisan government with several figures from the private sector. LRM and its centrist ally, François Bayrou's Mouvement démocrate (MoDem), have a comfortable majority in the National Assembly (the lower house of parliament), with 413 out of 577 seats between their two parliamentary groups. The government also benefits from informal support from a "constructive group" of 35 deputies from Les Républicains and its ally, Union des démocrates et indépendants (UDI).
Mr Macron's popularity has fallen since he took office, with an initially large share of "undecideds" now rating him as unsatisfactory. This is not surprising. There was an unusually high abstention rate in both the presidential and parliamentary elections, and many people voted for Mr Macron primarily to keep out the far right. Moreover, since taking office Mr Macron has pursued a number of unpopular reforms-in recognition that tough changes must be made now in order to show results within his five-year term-and has also made some political missteps. The resignation of the head of the armed forces, General Pierre de Villiers, in response to cuts to the defence budget, particularly shocked the public. Mr Macron's actions in the foreign policy arena have been more successful, and indicate his intention to restore France's profile as an influential world power. In the latest survey his approval rating had risen back to 50%-a comparatively high figure for a French president.
Mr Macron's public support is unlikely to affect policymaking progress, given the share of support that his agenda enjoys in the National Assembly. However, managing his party may prove challenging. Many LRM deputies are new to politics, and the idea of party discipline is in sharp contrast to the sense of creative disruption that powered the En Marche! movement before the election. LRM's transition from a radical centrist movement building its platform through a grassroots-led, bottom-up process into a vehicle for passing laws determined by the executive is likely to result in some friction in the National Assembly.
Coalition talks are continuing in Norway
Norway has a history of coalition governments and cross-party consensus that typically delivers a high level of political stability. The Storting (parliament) cannot be dissolved before completing its full four-year term. In the September 2017 general election the centre-right parties in the Storting-comprised of the Conservatives, the Progress Party (FrP), the junior Christian Democrats (KrF) and the Liberals-emerged as the winners. The centre-right bloc controls 88 seats out of 169, giving it a working majority of three. Erna Solberg, the incumbent prime minister and leader of the Conservatives, managed a strong campaign, focusing on policy continuity and capitalising on the economic recovery, whereas the far-right FrP played to its voter base by sharpening its rhetoric on immigration in the final weeks of the election campaign. One notable result from the election was the drop in support for Labour (the largest party in parliament), from 31% in the previous election, in 2013, to 27.4%-its worst election result since 2001. All the remaining centre-left parties enjoyed an uptick in their vote shares, with the Centre Party (Sp) emerging as the best performing party (doubling its vote share from 5.5% to 10.3%).
Government-formation talks between the centre-right parties are ongoing. The KrF's decision in late September to withdraw from negotiations-driven by its long-standing refusal to support another coalition that includes the anti-immigrant FrP-means that another minority government will take office. The Liberals are still participating in talks and are likely to back Ms Solberg in exchange for concessions on environmental policy; the party will probably demand another ban on opening up the northern region to oil drilling as the pressure increases for those areas to be explored. However, it is unclear at this stage whether the Liberals will choose to enter government or remain an external ally. We expect another minority govern-ment consisting of the Conservatives and the FrP to be formed in early 2018.
The KrF's decision to go into opposition increases its power in parliament, as it enables the party to strike deals on a case-by-case basis. Although Knut Arild Hareide, the KrF chairman, has stated that he will continue to co-operate with a Conservative-led government, we expect this arrangement to make the policy-making process more difficult and protracted than in the previous term, when both the KrF and the Liberals acted as the government's external allies. This is likely to undermine government effectiveness, making it harder for the ruling coalition to implement measures sought by the FrP, especially in areas such as immigration, foreign aid and the environment, where the two parties have opposite stances. There is a risk of increased political instability in Norway over the next term, but it will remain limited by European standards.
Austria is no exception to the general trend
In Austria the early election on October 15th was won by the Austrian People's Party (ÖVP), led by the young foreign minister, Sebastian Kurz. The ÖVP won a plurality of the vote, with a 31.5% share, up by 7.5 percentage points on its result in 2013. The Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) received 26.9% of the vote, unchanged since the previous election. The far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) increased its vote share by 5.5 percentage points, to 26%. The liberal NEOS returned to parliament with just over 5% of the vote, and the Greens failed to cross the 4% electoral threshold for the first time in 31 years, in part because List Pilz, led by a former leader of the Greens, managed to edge over the threshold.
After two months of talks Mr Kurz and Heinz-Christian Strache, the leader of the FPÖ, announced to the press on December 15th that they had successfully concluded negotiations regarding the formation of the next government. The following day they met with the president, Alexander Van der Bellen, who confirmed that he was content, following introductory meetings with the proposed ministerial team, to appoint the new government. On December 18th Mr Van der Bellen, in line with our forecast, swore in a government comprising the ÖVP and the FPÖ. The 31-year-old Mr Kurz is the new chancellor.
The situation is different to 2000, when the FPÖ last entered government (also in a coalition with the ÖVP). At that time the president rejected two FPÖ ministers because of their links to the far right, there were mass protests on the streets of Vienna, the capital, and the EU imposed diplomatic sanctions on Austria. Although there have been protests against the new coalition, they have not been of the same scale, and the new government has been warmly welcomed by Mr Van der Bellen-who was strongly critical of the FPÖ during his own election campaign-and by other EU leaders.
This shift is in part due to a changed European political context, with right-wing populist parties in power in other EU member states; Mr Kurz's proactive courting of EU leaders, such as Ms Merkel, since the election, building on relationships established during his time as foreign minister; and a conscious effort on the part of the FPÖ to present itself as a credible party of government. For example, Mr Strache praised his constructive working relationship with both Mr Kurz and Mr Van der Bellen during his media interviews, in sharp contrast to his criticism of both figures during the election campaign, and he has agreed to a pro-EU line in the coalition agreement. The impact of the FPÖ's moderation of various of its stances on its popularity among voters and how it responds to a potential decline in support, and Mr Kurz's ability to assert his authority over the notoriously difficult and fractious ÖVP, will be the main issues to watch during the coming months.
Despite the overlap between the ÖVP and the FPÖ's programmes, we expect the government to struggle to implement its policies, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters, and the FPÖ could struggle to translate its opposition stance on issues such as immigration and integration into concrete policy proposals. As a result, we expect limited progress on significant structural reforms, and the risk of an early election is high.
ANO wins the Czech election and struggles to form a government
In the general election in the Czech Republic held on October 20th-21st the centrist ANO movement, led by Andrej Babis, a billionaire businessman and former minister of finance, won 29.6% of the vote and 78 seats in the 200-member Chamber of Deputies (the lower house of parliament). This is 53 seats more than the second-largest party, the centre-right Civic Democratic Party (ODS), which won 11.3% of the vote. The new parliament will be highly fragmented, with nine parties represented, up from seven previously. Anti-establishment parties made strong gains, with the anti-corruption Czech Pirate Party (CPS) entering parliament for the first time and the far-right Freedom and Direct Democracy (SPD) grouping, led by Tomio Okamura, capitalising on public fears about refugees. Meanwhile, the senior coalition partner in the outgoing government, the centre-left Czech Social Democratic Party (CSSD), saw its share of the vote collapse, after failing to sell its administration's achievements. Credit for the economic upswing instead accrued overwhelmingly to Mr Babis, who was the finance minister until May 2017.
Forming a government is proving difficult. The mainstream parties are reluctant to govern with ANO because of concerns over the legality of its leader's business affairs. The police have requested that parliament remove Mr Babis's immunity from prosecution so that a criminal investigation can be pursued into the use of EU subsidies in the construction of his Stork's Nest conference centre. Meanwhile, Mr Babis has ruled out working with the parties on the far left and the far right. Nonetheless, we believe that a minority ANO government led by Mr Babis is the most likely outcome. Milos Zeman, the president, has two chances to nominate someone to form a government and has stated that he will give both to the ANO leader. Should Mr Babis fail to win a confidence vote on both attempts, the speaker of parliament-an ANO deputy-could provide him with a third attempt. Mr Babis's chances of success are further supported by there being no other plausible government at present, as even if all the other mainstream parties and the CPS worked together they would not have enough seats for a majority (working with the far-left and far-right parties is out of the question).
This scenario implies significant policy continuity with the previous administration, and could still lead to a stable and functional government, given ANO's political dominance and the fragmented state of the parliamentary opposition. Alternative scenarios include an ANO government led by someone else appointed by Mr Babis (which would probably result in more support from the mainstream parties) or a new election (which would probably benefit ANO). Risks to political stability may come from further corruption and conflict-of-interest scandals, with the legal investigations into Mr Babis a potential stress point, as well as potentially difficult relations with the other mainstream parties in parliament, upon which ANO may depend for support in passing its policymaking agenda. The Czech Republic has a history of unstable governments, with the outgoing coalition the first in 15 years to have completed its four-year term.
Mr Babis is likely to play a dominant role on the political scene throughout our forecast period (2018-22). A charismatic figure who claims that he is "too rich to steal", he agreed to put his business holdings in a blind trust in January after a bill-aimed specifically at him-was passed to prevent government ministers from owning media companies or firms that rely on state support. His stated aim is to clean up politics and run the country "like a firm", and his movement is pro-business without any ideological slant. He is a populist figure, and has voiced anti-EU sentiments when this has suited his purposes, but an illiberal or nationalist turn along the lines of that seen in Hungary and Poland is unlikely, not least because of his extensive business links with the rest of the EU.
Iceland holds its second snap poll in the space of a year
Exactly a year after the previous early election, held in October 2016, Iceland went to the polls again on October 28th. Five weeks later the Left-Green Movement (LGM) formed a grand coalition government with the centre-right Independence Party (IP), which has led Iceland's past two governments, and the centrist Progressive Party (PP). The government is led by the LGM, which came second in the election, making Katrin Jakobsdottir, the popular LGM leader, Iceland's new prime minister. The three parties have announced their intention to restore stability to the political environment in the wake of two snap elections in as many years, both of which were triggered by scandals surrounding high-profile political figures.
However, the coalition will prove to be an uncomfortable one, and could be damaging for the LGM. Two LGM MPs have already resigned, reducing the coalition's majority to one seat. We do not expect the LGM-led government to last in its current form. The political environment is therefore set to remain unstable and uncertain.
The formation of this three-party government has defied expectations. Not only is it made up of an unlikely combination of parties-two of which triggered the past two elections owing to their links to high-profile political scandals-but the fragmentation of the Althingi (parliament) after the vote made it difficult to form a comfortable majority government without involving at least four parties. The LGM, IP and PP grouping is an uncomfortable one, but they formed a government much faster than anticipated (in 2016 coalition talks took 11 weeks), overcoming policy disagreements owing to a shared commitment to restore political stability.
With robust economic growth supported by the booming tourism sector and strong tax revenue, plans to finance increased spending on healthcare and infrastructure are well within the coalition's grasp. However, this is, fundamentally, an uncomfortable coalition, and its ideological cracks may begin to show as economic growth slows in 2018-19.
Spain faces a constitutional crisis over the Catalan question
Spain has been plunged into a political crisis by a referendum and unilateral declaration of independence in Catalonia. The central government responded by using Article 155 of the constitution to dismiss the Catalan government and assume control of the region in late October, and new regional elections have been called for December 21st. With a number of prominent pro-independence politicians in custody and facing serious charges, ranging from rebellion and sedition to misappropriation of funds, and the former regional president and several other ministers claiming to lead a government in exile in Belgium, the pro-independence movement faces serious challenges in agreeing on the political direction for Catalan separatism after the election. This could take the form of a renewed push for independence or, more likely, pressure for a legal referendum, as well as protests over what the pro-independence movement regards as the unjust treatment of its leaders at the hands of the Spanish state.
Opinion polls for the regional election in December should be treated with caution, but point to a narrow lead for unionist parties. However, even if these parties win, the region will remain polarised for the foreseeable future. If pro-independence formations win the election, the central government would face pressure to offer serious concessions to Catalonia, including constitutional reform. A protracted stalemate or a constitutional compromise that keeps Catalonia in Spain are the most likely outcomes over the forecast period. However, the Catalonia issue is not going to go away and over the longer term independence cannot be ruled out.
The Brexit negotiations will test EU cohesion
The Brexit negotiations began in June 2017, after the UK government invoked Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union on March 29th, beginning the formal two-year process of the country's withdrawal from the bloc. In the Article 50 letter, Theresa May, the prime minister, confirmed that the UK would not seek membership of the EU's single market. This is in line with the government's intention to honour the Brexit vote by taking control of laws, borders and budget. The UK will also leave the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice (ECJ).
The UK would like to have tariff-free access to EU markets, but customs union membership would mean a common external tariff and would prevent the UK from negotiating trade deals with other countries. The UK will therefore try to negotiate a free-trade agreement with the EU and has proposed alternatives to customs union membership, including a "highly streamlined" arrangement and a new customs "partnership" that reduce non-tariff barriers to trade such as technical regulations, compliance requirements and rules of origin docu-mentation. We expect the new relationship to be phased in gradually, to minimise disruption. This could mean continued adherence to EU rules for a period after withdrawal.
A deal would be mutually beneficial, but the risk of no deal is high
On December 8th UK and EU negotiators reached an agreement in principle across the three areas under discussion in the first phase of the Brexit talks: citizens' rights; the Irish border; and the divorce bill. The joint agreement enabled the European Commission to say that "sufficient progress" had been made-a condition for the talks to move on to the transition arrangement and trade. On December 15th the European Council agreed to allow negotiations to proceed to the next stage.
Political exigencies on both sides reduce the scope for an amicable divorce and the risk that the negotiations will break down is high. If they do, and an extension of the Article 50 deadline is not agreed by all 27 EU members, the UK will leave the EU in 2019 without a deal and revert to World Trade Organisation (WTO) trade rules. However, both sides have an incentive to agree on a deal, given the mutual benefits of maintaining economic, political and security relations.
Brexit uncertainties have been heightened because of divisions in the government over the shape of the UK's future relationship with the EU. Mrs May's decision to call an early general election in June 2017 backfired disastrously for the Conservative Party, which lost its majority. The prime minister's authority was further undermined by a calamitous speech at the Conservative Party conference in October, prompting calls by some in the party for a leadership contest. However, Mrs May will stay in place for now because there is no obvious alternative who could unite both wings of the party. The Conservatives fear another general election given that the momentum is with the main opposition Labour Party. Lacking a parliamentary majority and divided over Brexit, the government will do well to last the duration of the Brexit negotiations, until March 2019, and there is a significant risk of another pre-term election.
The Conservatives have formed a working government, based on a "confidence and supply" arrangement with Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP). This arrangement is likely to work in the short term because neither party wants another election, they are natural allies on questions of sovereignty and the EU, and the DUP is committed to preventing the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, from coming to power given his past association with Northern Ireland's main nationalist party, Sinn Fein. However, the arrangement is politically fragile, and the government's 13-seat working majority (down from 17 seats before the election) will dwindle with each by-election.
In early November 2017 the government was rocked by a series of scandals, resulting in the resignation of Michael Fallon as defence secretary and of Priti Patel as international development secretary. Mrs May's position received welcome reinforcement on December 8th, when the European Commission and the UK government reached a deal that allowed the Commission to recommend that the Brexit talks to move on to the next stage. The deal is an important accomplishment for Mrs May and her government. Securing a deal has also guaranteed the prime minister's political survival in the short term.
However, divisions over Brexit are likely to resurface as the negotiations move to the next stage, as illustrated by the legislative defeat on December 13th over parliament's role in the implementation of a final deal. Brexiteers in the cabinet have been supportive of Mrs May since the election because they want her to hold fast to her earlier pledges to leave the single market, the customs union and the jurisdiction of the ECJ. This faction includes the Brexit secretary, David Davis; the international trade secretary, Liam Fox; the environment minister, Michael Gove; and the foreign affairs minister, Boris Johnson. They will support the prime minister as long as she pursues their vision of Brexit. However, Mrs May is also under pressure from those advocating a "softer" Brexit, who favour an extended post-2019 transition period during which the UK retains single market access. This group includes the chancellor of the exchequer, Philip Hammond, and the home secretary, Amber Rudd. These divisions could sharpen, presenting a threat to government stability in 2018.
Political outlook : Political uncertainty comes to Germany
Germany seems to be rapidly catching up with its neighbours in terms of the rise of far-right populism and political fragmentation.
The failure on November 19th of preliminary talks for a so-called Jamaica coalition-comprising the Christian Democratic Union (CDU), the Christian Social Union (CSU), the liberal Free Democratic Party (FDP) and The Greens-shocked the country.
Despite an earlier vow to go into opposition, the Social Democratic Party (SPD) has agreed to negotiations on forming another grand coalition with the CDU.
However, the process is riddled with uncertainties and a new election remains a distinct possibility. A minority government is also possible and might even be favoured by voters.
The collapse of the Jamaica talks was unexpected, despite several warnings that they could fail, especially from the FDP camp. Although officially only exploratory, the assumption was that, in line with historical experience, the start of talks between the parties would automatically lead to agreement. Given that the parties share sufficient programmatic overlap, it was thought that the presence of four parties at the negotiating table would simply make for prolonged negotiations before the formation of a government. In the end, it was not entirely clear why the FDP chose to break off talks, besides a feeling that the parties lacked a broad, common vision. The FDP leadership gave several explanations, ranging from the behaviour of the chancellor, Angela Merkel, during the talks to fundamental differences with The Greens on issues such as migration policy.
Germany politically catching up with its neighbours
This was not the first shockwave to hit the German political scene in late 2017. The inclusion in the Bundestag (the lower house of parliament) of the far-right populist Alternative for Germany (AfD) caused a small tremor, despite polls having indicated that this would happen for two years. It marks the first time in several decades that such a party has won political representation on the national stage. Until recently it had seemed that historical experience weighed too heavily on the German electorate to elect such a party into the Bundestag, let alone with almost 13% of the vote, around the same share won by the AfD's Dutch sister party, the Party for Freedom (PVV), only a few months earlier.
The current stalemate and probably protracted coalition-building period means that German political leaders are confronted with another new challenge-or at least a new challenge for them, as the current situation will look very familiar to leaders in many other European countries. One of Ms Merkel's key allies in the EU, the Dutch prime minister, Mark Rutte, has only recently concluded seven months of coalition negotiations. Negotiations have been in progress for more than a month in Austria following the election there in mid-October, and those in Norway have been continuing since September and were even temporarily put on hold to pass the budget for 2018. Most of these countries have had to deal with far-right populist parties winning representation in parliament for decades, and in many cases the increased difficulty of forming majority governments is because the populist parties are not considered to be viable coalition partners.
The proportional nature of Germany's voting system, as in many of its regional peers, means that as voters have become more mobile in recent decades, the dominance of the traditional large mainstream parties has waned more than in more majoritarian systems, such as those in the UK and the US. Whereas in the 1990s the CDU/CSU and the SPD would together win more than 75% of the vote, they barely managed to win a majority together this year, down from just over 60% in 2013. With the introduction of a new party in parliament and the return of the FDP, party leaders will no longer be able to create a comfortable two- or three-party coalition very often, a new reality that many of their colleagues around Europe have already been forced to confront.
Germany will have to deal with uncertainty
German politicians have never before faced the current level of political fragmentation, reflected in the rise of the AfD, meaning that politicians are struggling with how to move forward. Although the constitutional procedures for the current situation are largely untested, they are sufficiently strong. The Basic Law (constitution) was drafted in part with the experience of the Weimar era in mind, when the country went through significant political turmoil and a rapid succession of unstable and short-lived governments. As a result, it is not easy for the chancellor to call an early election. Even in the case of a minority government, it would be difficult for the opposition to remove the chancellor, as the Bundestag would have to agree on a replacement first.
This framework will keep discussions going, and means that a protracted period of uncertainty on what the next government will look like will be manageable. Ms Merkel's previous government will remain in place in its current caretaker capacity, and although the Bundestag will not be able to vote on major legislation, the government should be able to find majorities for any critical decisions that cannot be put off. The EU reforms promoted by the French president, Emmanuel Macron, will be affected by this, as Germany will not be able to agree on any major legislation, or even the direction thereof, until there is a new government in place. On a domestic level the impact will be minimal. The economy is growing at a rapid pace and there is little need for immediate decisions on big reforms in Germany, giving those involved in the talks the time to work through this situation.
Amid heightened uncertainty, movement towards another grand coalition
The first response in political circles after the collapse of the Jamaica talks seemed to be one of paralysis, as nobody seemed quite clear on what the next steps should or could be. Ms Merkel quickly noted that she preferred an early election over a minority government. Although minority governments have shown themselves to be perfectly workable in many other European countries, that they are untested on a federal level in Germany means that there is little support for this option either among the political elite or the general public.
The SPD initially stuck to its plans to go into opposition, but intervention by the president, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, and public pressure seemed to change this. On December 7th, at the SPD conference, party members approved plans to start exploratory talks with the CDU to possibly form another grand coalition. They also re-elected Martin Schulz as party leader, albeit by a significantly smaller margin than in March. The party leadership had already recommended starting discussions, and with the membership's consent the first talks with representatives of the CDU and the CSU started on December 13th. On December 15th the SPD leadership will decide whether to start formal exploratory talks, which should start in early January and would still need to be followed by actual coalition negotiations. This means that, even if the parties manage to reach agreement rapidly, it will be at least another few months before a new government is in place.
The SPD is likely to make significant demands of the CDU, as another term as junior partner under Ms Merkel will be regarded as damaging for the SPD's prospects at the next election. Should these negotiations fail, a new election is more likely than a minority government. Regardless of the outcome, German politics will remain mired in uncertainty over the coming weeks and months.
Political outlook : Election watch
We expect political risk to remain high in Europe throughout the forecast period. In the euro zone, in particular, the negative political fallout from the financial crisis, coming on top of the long-term erosion of the post-war political party system, is proving to be electorally disruptive. Moreover, recent evidence suggests that fragmentation and difficulties forming a government occur even in countries that are registering solid rates of growth, such as Ireland, and in traditionally politically stable countries, such as the UK. The EU's cohesion may be sorely tested in 2018, starting with a key election in Italy early in the new year.
Italy is a particular pressure point and weak link within the euro zone. We expect the country to hold its next general election in early 2018, at the end of the current parliamentary term. Because of the fragmentation of the political system and the use of a newly approved, predominantly proportional electoral system, none of the three main blocs-the centre left dominated by the Partito Democratico (PD); the centre right, comprising Forza Italia (FI), the populist, Eurosceptic Lega Nord and the right-wing Fratelli d'Italia; and the anti-establish-ment, Eurosceptic M5S-is likely to win a majority of seats next year. This will complicate government formation, which is likely to lead to the creation of another executive backed by a broad centre-left/centre-right coalition. We expect the next government to be unstable, limiting its effectiveness and its ability to pass long-overdue political and economic reforms.
Paolo Gentiloni, the PD prime minister since December 2016, has had a difficult policy remit, including trying to keep the economic recovery on track while controlling the public finances, managing problems in Italy's banking sector and dealing with a renewed inflow of migrants. The government has been especially vulnerable to political manoeuvrings within the PD and the wider governing coalition. There is a strong chance that parliament will be dissolved shortly after the passage of the 2018 budget, which is due to be approved by end-2017. This would result in an election in early 2018, as we currently forecast.
After Matteo Renzi's flagship constitutional reform was rejected in a referendum in December 2016 he resigned first as prime minister and then as PD leader. In April 2017 Mr Renzi was re-elected as leader of the PD, but this has not put an end to divisions in the party. A large group of leftists broke away ahead of the PD leadership contest and fissures have deepened further as Mr Renzi has sought to position the PD further to the right on issues such as immigration in an attempt to respond to the growing electoral challenge of M5S and the re-emerging centre-right alliance. The tensions on the centre left will hinder Mr Renzi's efforts to become prime minister after the 2018 general election. Calls have emerged for a centre-left coalition primary contest ahead of the vote, and possibly even for the candidacy of Mr Gentiloni instead of Mr Renzi.
A regional election in Sicily, held on November 5th, was the most recent major electoral test prior to next year's general election. The centre-right candidate, Nello Musumeci, backed by FI, the Lega Nord and Fratelli d'Italia, won the contest with close to 40% of the vote. This demonstrates that a united centre right has the potential to defeat both M5S and the centre left. A pre-electoral coalition now appears likely at the national level. Who might lead it currently remains unclear, but support for the former prime minister and FI leader, Silvio Berlusconi (who is seeking to overturn a ban preventing him from holding public office before the next election), is recovering strongly. The Sicilian election also confirmed the strength of M5S, which won more seats than any other single party in the regional parliament, sounding warning bells for Mr Renzi and the PD, which underperformed.
Italy will face difficulties in forming a government in 2018
The 2018 general election will be held under a new voting law, the so-called Rosatellum 2, which was approved by parliament in late October. The law is a one-round, mixed electoral system, which allocates just under two-thirds of seats through proportional representation and the rest through single-member districts. It sets a 3% vote threshold at the national level for single parties, 10% for coalitions and 1% for parties within a coalition. On balance, the new system is even more proportional than the voting laws used in 2013, which yielded a fragmented parliament; it is therefore unlikely to produce a stable government. However, Rosatellum 2 may at least lead to more homogenous results in the two chambers of parliament.
With none of the three main blocs expected to win a majority, forming a government will prove difficult after the vote. We ultimately expect a left-right coalition to emerge, centred on FI and the PD, in order to break the political gridlock. Given M5S's hardline stance towards the established parties across the political spectrum, we believe that it is unlikely that M5S would enter any government constellation.
The next presidential election in Russia will take place in March 2018. We expect Vladimir Putin to contest the election and win by a wide margin in the first round, owing to the lack of any credible alternative candidate. Although he will attempt to campaign, Aleksei Navalny, an anti-corruption blogger and nationalist opposition politician, has been barred from participating following a second conviction for de-frauding Kirovles, a timber company. This suggests that the authorities intend to run a tightly controlled contest, offering voters no meaningful alternatives to Mr Putin. We believe that Ksenia Sobchak, a media personality who recently declared her candidacy, does not represent a credible alternative for the majority of the population. According to a poll conducted by the Levada centre, a Russian polling company, 53% of Russians oppose the idea of having a female president, and 87% of them cannot think of a credible female candidate. The main challenge for the authorities will be to prevent a sharp fall in turnout, which would cast doubt on the legitimacy of Mr Putin's popular mandate.
Fianna Fail could emerge as the biggest party at the next Irish election
The collapse of Leo Varadkar's Fine Gael-led minority coalition government in Ireland was narrowly averted in late November 2017. Our view remains that the government does not have the capacity or cohesion to address effectively the mounting economic and political challenges facing Ireland. As a result, we continue to believe that the government will not survive a full term to February 2021 and maintain our view that a snap election is likely in the first half of 2018. However, there is a possibility that it is delayed until early 2019, depending on the timing of the referendum on abortion, scheduled for next year. Mr Varadkar has indicated May or June 2018 as his preference for the referendum, but the topic is divisive, so barring another government crisis he may choose to wait to call a general election if the referendum campaign or outcome of the vote damages his party's support.
Given voter disillusionment with the three established parties-Fine Gael, Fianna Fail and the Labour Party-we expect the next election to be incon-clusive, as in February 2016. Another such outcome would put greater pressure on Fine Gael and Fianna Fail to set aside their historical differences and form a grand coalition. We expect the election to be a close contest, but if it is held in the first half of 2018 Fianna Fail could emerge as the largest party.
At the 2016 general election none of the established parties was willing to contemplate entering a coalition with the nationalist Sinn Fein party led by Gerry Adams, which had links to the now disbanded Irish Republican Army (IRA). We think that this is unlikely to change after the next election, but a transition is now under way in the party. The leadership is passing to Mary Lou McDonald, one of Sinn Fein's younger members, who is not associated with the conflict in Northern Ireland.
In Spain political dysfunction has been pronounced. At end-October 2016, following an inconclusive general election in December 2015 and a re-run ballot six months later, parliament elected Mariano Rajoy, the leader of the conservative People's Party (PP), prime minister for a second term. However, Mr Rajoy's PP minority government is one of the weakest in Spain's democratic history, and we do not expect it to serve a full four-year term. It relies on just 170 votes-those of the PP, Ciudadanos (Citizens) and the Canary Island Coalition (CC)-in the 350-seat Congress of Deputies.
The parliamentary term ends in June 2020, but an early election is likely to be held in 2018 or 2019. The Catalonia crisis represents another threat to government stability. Over the medium term Spanish politics will remain fluid, with scant prospects for major political or economic reforms until a stronger administration enters office.
The next parliamentary and presidential elections in Turkey are due to be held in 2019, but they could be called earlier if Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the president, decides to accelerate the transfer of executive powers to the presidency once the institutions and instruments of the new presidential system are in place. Given Mr Erdogan's popularity, and his party's ability to control the election process, we expect him to win the presidential election and to remain in office with enhanced powers for at least one more five-year term, if not two (the maximum allowed), up to 2029. The president's popularity is unrivalled, and the opposition is fragmented and currently appears to have no candidates capable of challenging him.
