Political outlook : Intra-regional tensions
East-West political tensions are at their highest since the dissolution of the Soviet Union. Russia is slowly dismantling the security and arms control agreements that were put in place in at the end of the cold war. Russia's opposition to the post-cold war security architecture was evident in its decision to withdraw from the Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe (CFE) and its breach of the 1987 Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) treaty, which bans short- and medium-range ballistic missiles. Western countries have accused Russia of funding opposition parties in western Europe and employing cyber warfare against Western targets, as well as engaging in a propaganda war through media outlets that it controls in the West.
Tensions with Russia are unlikely to abate
Russia accuses the EU and the US of interfering in its sphere of influence, supporting the so-called "Colour Revolutions" in former Soviet space. Russia has accused NATO of going back on its post-cold war commitments by expanding relentlessly, first taking in central Europe and the Baltic republics, then Albania and Croatia in 2009 and, most recently, Montenegro in June 2017. Bosnia and Hercegovina (BiH), Macedonia and Georgia are now in the waiting room for admission. The Iraq War and Colour Revolutions fuelled Russian insecurity and convinced Russia that the US wanted "regime change" in the country, and possibly the break-up of the Russian Federation. In the face of such an existen-tial threat, from the Kremlin's perspective any countermeasures are justified.
In March 2014 Russia annexed Crimea and has since been providing military support to pro-Russian rebels in eastern Ukraine. The EU imposed sanctions on Russia's energy, defence and banking sectors in July 2014 following the downing of a passenger plane over Ukrainian territory controlled by Russian-backed separatists. The sanctions are subject to regular renewal, requiring the approval of all 28 EU member states.
The Minsk II ceasefire agreement, signed in February 2015, is highly unlikely to lead to a resolution of the conflict in Ukraine. Russia sees Ukrainian integration with the EU and NATO as a direct threat to its national interests. The current status quo, of a regularly breached ceasefire with contained levels of fighting, seems likely to endure for several years. This will serve Russia's interests, as a frozen conflict will prevent any Ukrainian move towards the EU.
Russia will remain vehemently opposed to EU and NATO integration with the countries of the former Soviet Union. Regime change in any country in Russia's immediate neighbourhood, particularly via a popular uprising similar to the Ukrainian Maidan revolution in 2014, would trigger a crisis in relations between Russia and the West.
Policy-related tensions remain high within the euro zone, but the risk that they will prompt a breakdown in inter-governmental relations has fallen sharply over the past year, as economic growth has picked up across the bloc. The ECB has successfully overcome objections in a number of countries-notably in Germany-to its use of unconventional policy instruments. However, the breathing space created by the ECB's programme of sovereign quantitative easing (QE) has, up to now, not been used by political leaders to bolster the economic recovery with a strong united position on fiscal policy and structural reform.
The rise of anti-establishment political sentiment across much of the bloc has generated increased pressure for economic policymaking that is focused on national considerations rather than on the integrity of the euro zone, creating new centrifugal forces at a time when policymakers are already struggling to remedy the institutional shortcomings of the single currency. Huge political capital has been invested in keeping the euro zone together in recent years. This should ensure its survival in the short term, but the risk of a partial break-up in the medium term remains significant. We attach a 60% probability to Greece leaving the euro zone during our five-year forecast period.
The refugee relocation policy will be a bone of contention in the EU
The issue of refugee relocation is a focal point for existing tensions between integration-minded countries of west Europe and a core of central European countries. In September 2015 the European Council established a temporary scheme to relocate across the EU some of the Syrian refugees who had arrived in Italy and Greece, with the aim of sharing the burden of accommodating them. This was particularly controversial in central and eastern Europe, where governments characterised it as an attempt by western Europe to export the consequences of misguided foreign policies, and raised the prospect of terrorist attacks as a result of Islamist infiltration. Public opposition to the scheme has been substantial across the region.
The Hungarian foreign minister, Peter Szijjarto, has said that his country will continue to challenge the EU's policy of sharing out some of the refugees that arrived in Greece and Italy during the migration crisis among the other EU members. Mr Szijjarto's comments followed remarks by Mrs Merkel, who said in a newspaper interview on September 12th 2017 that it was "unacceptable" that Hungary was defying a judgment by the ECJ, which had ruled in the same month that the EU's policy on relocating refugees was legal and proportionate. We expect Hungary's nationalist government and its ally, Poland, to continue refusing to accept their quotas of refugees-in contrast to Slovakia, which has said that it will comply with the ruling. The fourth member of the Visegrad group of countries, the Czech Republic, has yet to adopt a clear response following the election in October.
Tension between Turkey and the EU will remain high
Despite talk of agreeing a new roadmap to ease tensions and improve co-operation in the main areas of interest such as security, trade and investment, neither Turkey nor the EU is genuinely interested in Turkish membership of the bloc anymore. However, neither has yet been willing to suspend negotiations unilaterally. If Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, as Mr Erdogan has suggested, the EU might not be able to avoid suspending the process. This would almost certainly prompt Turkey to end its collaboration with the EU to stem the movement of migrants and refugees into Europe. A settlement of the de facto division of Cyprus between the Greek Cypriot south and the Turkish Cypriot north could help to improve Turkey's relations with the EU, but talks collapsed in July 2017. We maintain our forecast that a settlement is unlikely during the forecast period.
Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved. Russia has lifted almost all sanctions, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly in relation to the conflict in Syria, where both are militarily involved but have pursued contrasting goals. We expect relations to remain largely transactional, and the risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Mr Erdogan's state visit to Greece on December 7th-8th-the first such visit by a Turkish president in 65 years-was a tense affair. Greater co-operation on issues such as trade and security may result, but points of contention, such as historical territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea or, more recently, the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the failed coup in Turkey in July 2016, will continue to fuel distrust. We expect relations to remain tense, with sporadic flare-ups, but we do not expect an outbreak of conflict.
Political outlook : Poland undeterred by Article 7 vote
On November 15th the European Parliament approved a resolution on Poland's breach of the rule of law, taking the first step towards triggering Article 7-which is designed to deter serious violations of European fundamental values-of the Treaty on European Union. Such a move could lead to hefty fines or a suspension of Poland's voting rights within the bloc. However, even if the EU were to trigger Article 7, usually dubbed "the nuclear option", Poland would not face any of these consequences, because Hungary will block such a process. The right-wing, conservative Law and Justice (PiS) government in Poland will only harden its stance.
In its motion, the European Parliament raised several concerns, in particular about the independence of Poland's judiciary. It also referred to Poland's failure to comply with a European Court of Justice (ECJ) order to suspend large-scale logging in the Bialowieza Forest, restrictions placed on the availability of contraception and abortion, and the November 11th independence march in Warsaw, the capital, at which extremist organisations displayed xenophobic symbols. The resolution was passed by 438 votes to 152, with 71 abstentions. The European Parliament's civil liberties committee will now draw up a reasoned proposal, which would be the basis for a plenary vote that, if approved, would call on the European Council to trigger Article 7.
It is likely that the European Council would deliver the 22 out of 28 votes necessary to launch the Article 7 procedure. However, it is unlikely to secure the unanimous agreement needed to trigger sanctions. Earlier this year the European Parliament adopted a similar Article 7 resolution regarding Hungary. At the time, Poland and Hungary pledged to veto any such action against each another. The case against Hungary remains stuck, and a similar fate awaits the Polish measure.
Government aware that EU has little leverage
The PiS is well aware that the EU has little leverage over it, meaning that the Polish government will at least retain, and more probably harden, its uncompromising stance. The PiS leader, Jaroslaw Kaczynski, believes that his main mission is to implement institutional change in Poland. He insists that the state remains captive to the former communist "nomenklatura", which according to him is now seeking to retain its elite status by helping the EU to erode national sovereignty. That agenda is encouraged by polls showing that support for the PiS is at record highs, whereas that for the pro-European opposition continues to decline. The PiS is also benefitting from a booming economy. Real GDP growth has accelerated throughout 2017, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects full-year growth to reach 4.6%. Finally, the noisy fight with the EU is also viewed as useful by the governing party for main-taining its conservative-nationalist voter base, as Poland has long maintained that it is being victimised by theEU.
Rather than retreat, the PiS is already moving on with its contested reform agenda. A reworked version of the controversial judiciary reform-which was partially vetoed in July by Andrzej Duda, the president-was sent back to parliament on November 22nd, exactly a week after the European Parliament vote. Mr Kaczynski has used the intervening months since Mr Duda's veto to negotiate the fault lines that have developed across the PiS-dominated government. The re-submission of the judicial reform package suggests that this task is now close to completion.
We do not expect EU sanctions to be applied to Poland in the short term. However, fines remain a risk. The ECJ announced on November 20th that Poland could face a penalty of EUR100,000 (US$113,000) per day should it continue to ignore the Bialowieza Forest ruling. The European Commission may also push the judicial reforms in front of the same court, assuming that its technical concerns on gender discrimination remain in the new package.
Most palpably, there is a rising risk that Poland's potential share of EU structural funds-already under threat from the UK leaving the EU, as Poland will lose its closest EU ally-could be adversely affected in the next seven-year budget framework, which comes into effect in 2021. Owing to the limited leverage of Article 7, a discussion has begun about linking access to funds to a country's observance of rule-of-law standards. A significant drop in EU funding would have a serious negative impact on the Polish economy. With EUR77.6bn (US$87.7bn) available in 2014-20, Poland is the biggest recipient of structural funds in the EU-a fall-off in these funds led investment to contract sharply in 2016. However, the idea of linking funding to the rule of law remains highly controversial, even among EU officials on the frontline of the fight with Poland. Meanwhile, with the next parliamentary election due in 2019, the prospect of lowered funding, which would have little impact before 2022, is unlikely to affect the political calculations of the PiS.
Poland's intractable conflict with the EU may have some impact on the financial markets by raising investor perceptions of political risk. However, investors have now lived with the stand-off for more than two years and markets are increasingly focusing on the economic boom. Nevertheless, there remains a chance that fixed investment may suffer owing to the risks of political instability and policy uncertainty under a PiS government that is increasingly isolated from the EU core.
With Hungary acting as a staunch ally, Poland will remain undeterred by the EU's moves, which it perceives as empty political threats. Far from being afraid of the EU's rhetoric, the Polish government will use the current situation to bolster its domestic support ahead of the election, insisting that it is being bullied by the union.
Economic policy
Euro zone reform efforts are being stepped up
The threat of a euro zone break-up has subsided in recent years as the region's economic recovery has strengthened and broadened, and as its institutional underpinnings have been improved. The commitment in July 2012 by the president of the European Central Bank (ECB), Mario Draghi, to "do whatever it takes" to preserve the euro represented a turning point for the bloc, the resilience of which to shocks has also been bolstered by the establishment of an EU banking union and a permanent rescue fund. EU leaders are currently making a renewed push for further integration of the economic and monetary union. Proposals put forward by the European Commission on December 6th included turning the European Stability Mechanism (ESM)-the euro zone's bail-out fund-into a European Monetary Fund (EMF) that would provide a backstop for the banking union; a stabilisation function for the euro area, which would deal with asymmetric shocks by providing resources to support investment at the national level; and a euro zone economy and finance minister who would oversee the EMF and serve as vice-president of the European Commission.
Some aspects of these plans will meet internal resistance and will struggle to get off the ground. In The Economist Intelligence Unit's view, strengthening the existing structures would be helpful, but such proposals are not necessary for the region's economic recovery to continue in the coming years. EU leaders will lay the groundwork for reform efforts at the forthcoming EU summit in December, although progress will be affected by the recent collapse of coalition talks in Germany, as the country will not be able to agree on any major legislation, or even the direction thereof, until there is a new government in place. EU leaders intend to make a decision on reforms at the EU summit in June 2018.
Upheaval since the EU referendum drives a shift in UK's policy framework
The UK economy has been resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote. However, a heavy depreciation in the value of sterling has pushed up inflation, eroding real incomes. An assessment by the Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) that diminished supply capacity within the economy would keep inflation persistently high over the medium term prompted the bank to increase its main policy interest rate for the first time in a decade in November, by 25 basis points, to 0.5%. Downside risks to the outlook persist, particularly around the Brexit adjustment, and the BoE is likely to go into "wait-and-see" mode following the latest decision. Nevertheless, we now expect the BoE to move again to normalise policy earlier than previously assumed, in mid-2019 rather than early 2021. The stock of asset purchases will remain unchanged.
Another country in which the overall economic policy framework has been clouded by uncertainty is Turkey. Concerns about the policymaking impli-cations of political instability deepened following the failed coup attempt in July 2016. However, since the approval in a referendum in April 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency, household, business and investor sentiment has improved, and the lira and the economy have continued to recover. Given the healthy state of Turkey's public finances, the government is using the considerable room that it has to loosen fiscal policy and support the economy. Despite its concerns about growth, it has allowed the Central Bank of Turkey to tighten monetary policy to counter severe pressure on the lira in early 2017 and a surge in inflation. With the US likely to raise interest rates further in 2018 and 2019, inflation in Turkey still well above the official medium-term target of 5% and the Turkish economy showing signs of overheating, we expect Turkey's central bank to have to tighten monetary policy further, until inflationary pressures ease.
In Russia the fall in oil prices, which led to a significant contraction in real GDP and household consumption in 2015-16, has underlined the imperative for reforms to encourage investment and diversification away from commodity exports. Two competing centres of expertise-one under Aleksei Kudrin, a former minister of finance, and the other centred around the Stolypin Group, headed by Boris Titov, the business ombudsman-have put forward contrasting proposals for structural reforms. However, we do not expect significant reforms to be undertaken before the presidential election in 2018. We expect Vladimir Putin, the incumbent, to be re-elected and to continue prioritising social and political stability. We expect state involvement in the economy to remain substantial. Reform of the tax system and a gradual rise in the pension age appear likely. Institutional reform to strengthen the rule of law and protection for businesses looks much more difficult to achieve.

A conservative fiscal bias has prevailed across most of the region since the global crisis in 2008-09, leaving policymakers to rely heavily on low interest rates and unconventional monetary policy tools as the main levers with which to manage their economies. This created a significant degree of exposure to the impact of the monetary policy cycle in the US, where we expect further tightening in 2018-19. Although we continue to expect monetary policy to remain accommodative in most countries, we now expect fiscal policies to be slightly more supportive during our five-year forecast period (2018-22).
We expect fiscal consolidation to exert a much less powerful drag on growth in 2018-22 compared with the preceding five years. Almost all European countries improved their fiscal positions in 2009-16, with the star performers being Iceland (by 25.6 percentage points of GDP), Greece (15.6), Ireland (13.1) and Lithuania (9.4). In the EU only Spain and France had deficits larger than the EU's 3% of GDP limit in 2016 (4.5% and 3.4% respectively). Although we expect fiscal policies to be slightly more supportive of economic growth, significant fiscal loosening remains off the agenda for most countries, especially for those with high public debt loads, owing to the rigidity of the rules agreed by EU members at the height of the euro zone crisis. The average EU government debt/GDP ratio was 85.4% at end-2016, but Belgium, Cyprus, Greece, Italy and Portugal had debt ratios in excess of 100%, and those for France and Spain were only slightly below 100%. Hefty debt loads will remain a challenge for much of the euro zone for many years, although the cost of debt servicing has fallen dramatically owing to the exceptionally low interest rates that currently prevail across the bloc.
IMF and EU disagree on Greek government debt sustainability
A long-running disagreement between the IMF and some euro zone members on the sustainability of Greece's public debt and debt relief for Greece cast doubt over the country's ability to meet a July 2017 deadline for EUR7bn of bond repayments. However, a Eurogroup meeting on June 15th resulted in an agreement to disburse EUR8.5bn to Greece in two tranches in early July, following the conclusion of the second bail-out programme review. The IMF's managing director agreed in principle to support Greece with a stand-by programme, pending approval by the IMF board. However, there was no agreement on debt relief for Greece, with a discussion of the issue being deferred until after the end of the third bail-out programme, in August 2018. The government is hoping to establish a track record of borrowing on the international capital markets over the coming year and to be invited to join the ECB's quantitative easing (QE) programme. These are essentially pre-conditions for Greece to avoid having to sign a fourth bail-out programme. The Greek government returned to the financial markets in August 2017-its first foray into the debt markets since 2014-but the country is still excluded from the ECB's QE programme.
The UK government is targeting steady deficit reduction
The UK's fiscal position improved in 2016, and we expect this improvement to be broadly maintained in 2017-22, despite a fiscal loosening in the November 2017 autumn budget. After a better than expected performance, we estimate that the deficit will expand only modestly, from 2.9% of GDP in 2016 to 3% of GDP in 2017, and we expect it to stay at around that level in 2018 as the government eases off from its austerity drive. Automatic stabilisers will push up spending on social transfers as unemployment increases in 2018. However, revenue will still be rising, and in the remainder of our forecast period the government will aim to nudge down discretionary spending as a proportion of GDP. We expect the deficit to narrow to 1.9% by 2021 and 1.6% by 2022. The public debt burden edged up to 88.3% of GDP in 2016, from 88.2% in 2015. We forecast that public debt will peak at just below 89% of GDP in 2018, before falling thereafter.
Within the EU, over the past year a number of national governments have shown signs of pushing back against centralised fiscal constraints, which are significantly more rigorous as a result of changes introduced in response to the crisis. In 2016 tensions between several member states and the European Commission, which enforces the EU's budgetary rules, came to a head. In early July 2016 the Commission proposed that Spain and Portugal should be fined for their failure to meet deficit targets in 2015, but the Commission ultimately stepped back from this position. The episode highlighted the growing tension between the strict fiscal rules agreed at the height of the crisis and the mounting political and economic arguments within member states for a greater degree of fiscal flexibility.
The fiscal position has deteriorated across the former Soviet Union
The steep fall in commodity prices and the sharp reduction in export demand and remittance inflows from Russia caused a significant deterioration in economic conditions across the former Soviet Union in 2015-16. This has contributed to a general deterioration in the fiscal picture across the region. The three major former Soviet oil exporters-Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Russia-were particularly hard hit and drew down reserves from their sovereign wealth funds to cover larger budget deficits and maintain investment as bank lending fell. All three countries have announced privatisation programmes to plug funding gaps, but we remain sceptical about the scope and pace of these plans. Russia completed the sale of a 19.5% stake in Rosneft, a major oil producer, in December 2016; however, the state retains control of the company. Russia's financing challenges are acute, as international sanctions make it difficult for the country to increase foreign borrowing.
The Russian government faces tight budget constraints as a result of low commodity prices. However, despite international sanctions and the reluctance of Western banks to handle international bond issuances, Russia placed two Eurobonds in mid-June 2017, which were oversubscribed. In 2016 the deficit was the equivalent of 3.4% of GDP; however, this included extraordinary income from the sale of the Rosneft stake. Without this, the deficit would have exceeded 4% of GDP.
The government's revised 2017 budget estimates a budget deficit equivalent to 2.1% of GDP, assuming an average oil price of US$45.6/barrel and real GDP growth of 1.5-2%. We estimate a higher oil price this year (US$54.5/b) than set out in the revised budget, and a budget deficit of 2.1% of GDP, in line with the government's projections.
We expect the Ministry of Finance to continue to trim the deficit in 2018-22, but the adjustment to expenditure is likely to be less radical than planned, particularly given the forthcoming presidential election. We believe that the government is unlikely to hold expenditure fixed in nominal terms in 2018-19 as officially projected, although spending will still decline in real terms, and plans to reduce defence spending have been announced. Under the three-year budget outlook the finance ministry is aiming to cut the deficit as a share of GDP to 1.6% in 2018, 0.9% in 2019 and 0.8% in 2020, in line with our projections of a budget deficit smaller than 1% of GDP in 2021-22.
Weak institutional structures, high inflation and rapid currency depreciation have limited the ability of many countries in the region to respond to the economic slowdown with an expansive fiscal policy. Tajikistan, which has experienced a serious banking crisis, is seeking funding from the IMF, but is more likely to receive further bilateral support from China or Russia. The most notable exception in Central Asia is Kazakhstan, which is drawing on its substantial reserves to implement an ambitious counter-cyclical spending programme to offset the impact of falling household demand. The country avoided recession in 2016, recording real GDP growth of 0.9%. This is nevertheless significantly below the average growth rate of the past ten years.
Economic policy: Monetary policy and exchange rates

In most of Europe monetary policy remains exceptionally accommodative, and we expect this to remain the case throughout the forecast period. The ECB is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with policy interest rates at or below zero and a QE programme that will run at EUR60bn per month until the end of 2017, and at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. The economic recovery in the euro zone has strengthened this year and become more broad based. Evidence of slack in the labour market suggests that the recovery in domestic demand has further to go, and the pick-up in external demand within the region should have a self-reinforcing effect. We expect a healthy expansion of real GDP in the euro zone in 2017, of 2.4%. The pace of growth should ease to a still solid 2.1% in 2018.
We expect tapering of the ECB's QE programme to begin in 2018
The ECB continues to take stock of this growth momentum, but maintains a clearly dovish policy stance, with the reduction in QE purchases in 2018 designed to extend its presence in the bond markets. We expect the pace of monthly QE purchases to be reduced to zero in early 2019, but owing to subdued price pressure and persistent downside risks to growth, we forecast that the bank will delay raising policy rates until 2022, with a high risk that this move is brought forward to 2021.
The euro has moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1 since mid-2015. The annual average exchange rate was US$1.11:EUR1 in 2016, although a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. The euro has since rallied as the region's economic recovery has strengthened, and as political risk has waned in Europe but risen in the US. More recently, a rise in expectations of QE tapering by the ECB prompted a sharp appreciation in the euro against the dollar. The value of the euro could yet come under pressure from political risk-especially in relation to the next general election in Italy, which we expect to take place in early 2018-and monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a gradual appreciation on average, to US$1.20:EUR1 by 2020-21, as the euro is supported by an ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, while the business cycle down-turn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020. We expect the euro to appreciate further in 2022 as the monetary policy tightening cycle begins.
The BoE is likely to hold rates down until 2021
At its meeting in November 2017, a majority of members of the BoE's monetary policy committee (MPC) voted in favour of increasing the main policy interest rate-for the first time in a decade-by 25 basis points, to 0.5%. There had been no material change in the MPC's assessment of the outlook for growth and inflation in its November Inflation Report since the previous report, in August. Rather, the bank responded to a continuation of positive trends and reversed the rate cut from last year.
Diminished supply capacity within the economy also played into the MPC's decision, which it viewed as necessary to bring inflation back to target in the medium term and prevent a further squeeze in real incomes. However, downside risks to the outlook persist, particularly around the Brexit adjustment. The bank is therefore likely to keep monetary policy accommodative and go into wait-and-see mode following the latest decision.
We now expect the BoE to move again to normalise policy earlier than previously assumed, in the third quarter of 2019 rather than early 2021. The stock of asset purchases-made up of £435bn (US$582bn) of government bonds and £10bn of corporate bonds-will remain unchanged.
There was a sharp drop in the external value of sterling after the Brexit vote. Sensitivity in the foreign-exchange markets to the Brexit news flow has led to significant volatility in the value of the pound, albeit within a range of US$1.20-1.27:£1 until April 18th, when Theresa May, the prime minister, called the snap election. This initially boosted the value of the pound, but it fell back sharply in June in response to the shock result. The pound appreciated to US$1.35:£1 by mid-September, after a stronger than expected inflation outturn and commentary from the BoE that revived expectations of tighter monetary policy, but slipped back to US$1.33:£1 after the fifth round of Brexit talks ended in deadlock. It rallied to US$1.35:£1 after the December 8th Brexit breakthrough on first-phase topics. We forecast that sterling will depreciate against the US dollar and the euro on average in the next couple of years as the economy slows. However, we expect the pound to make a gradual recovery against the dollar in the final years of the forecast period.
Policy to be kept tight to support the Turkish lira and lower inflation
Political pressure on the BoE to lower interest rates in order to support economic activity increased again towards the end of 2017, following a period of gradual tightening. We expect that the bank will have to tighten policy further in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent further depreciation of the lira amid political volatility and expectations of higher US interest rates and Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank) balance sheet tapering. We expect the BoE to use a mix of interest-rate rises, macroprudential measures and other policies. The bank raised most of its main policy rates between November 2016 and April 2017, and from November 2017 will only be funding the banking sector at its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate, which was gradually raised by a total of 25 basis points, to 12.25% in late April, where it has since remained. The weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system has therefore increased to 12.25%, from 12% previously. This is well above its level of 7.8% in November 2016.
The BoE is seeking gradually to normalise its monetary policy framework to establish a single policy interest rate, which would help to improve transparency regarding monetary policy decisions. However, it is unlikely that this will happen until inflation is more firmly on a downward path towards its medium-term target of 5% and domestic political uncertainty eases.
The Turkish lira has been highly volatile and on a generally depreciating path against all major currencies since mid-2013, when the prospect of a gradual reduction in ultra-loose global liquidity and an eventual tightening of policy took shape. Amid further bouts of volatility we estimate that the lira will depreciate against the US dollar in 2017, to an annual average of TL3.66:US$1, a fall of 17.4% compared with 2016. From 2018 we forecast that the exchange rate will remain broadly stable in real terms, depreciating mildly in nominal terms, to an average of TL4.28:US$1 in 2022. The lira will depreciate sharply against the euro in 2017-22. There are substantial risks to our exchange-rate forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows, as well as the impact on investor confidence of domestic political tensions and geopolitical turmoil in the region.
Inflationary pressures have continued to weaken in Russia in 2017
In Russia inflation averaged 15.5% in 2015 as the sharp depreciation of the rouble in the fourth quarter of 2014 fed through into high import prices. A combination of weak demand and relatively tight monetary policy by the Central Bank of Russia (CBR) led to significant disinflation in 2016; full-year inflation averaged 7%. Inflation fell from 5.4% year on year in December 2016 to 2.7% in October 2017, well within the CBR's end-of-year inflation target (currently set at 4%). Disinflation has been assisted by strong harvests in 2016 and 2017, as well as by the relative strength of the rouble. We estimate that consumer price inflation will average 3.7% this year. A tightening of the Fed's monetary policy will lead to a modest depreciation of the rouble in 2018, but external inflationary pressures are likely to be relatively low. Tax changes in 2019 are expected to push up inflation to 4.7% that year. We expect inflation to remain close to-but slightly above-the 4% target in 2018-22.
For central and east European countries with currencies pegged to or managed against the euro (mostly in the western Balkans), risks of volatility have moved in line with expectations of tightening by the Fed. However, we do not see significant risks to the currency boards in Bosnia and Hercegovina (BiH) or Bulgaria, or to the peg in Macedonia. Croatia had been more of a concern, in the light of the 2015 legislation to force banks to convert Swiss franc-denominated loans into euro. However, the country's improved external and fiscal positions, and increased demand for the kuna as a result of a strong tourism performance have driven appreciation, which we forecast will continue in 2018.
Currencies across the former Soviet Union depreciated sharply in 2015 as a result of the weakening of the rouble and lower oil prices, which have hit commodity exporters. Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan both officially abandoned their US dollar pegs in 2015. In practice, the commitment of both countries to a free float would be seriously tested in the event of further oil volatility. We would expect the central banks of both countries to intervene-at least temporarily-in such a scenario to prevent sharp fluctuations in the currency and to maintain financial and monetary stability.
The Central Bank of Azerbaijan (CBA) had to grapple with a serious banking crisis in 2016 and struggled to restore confidence in the manat following the devaluation in December 2015. Ten banks failed in 2016, which further undermined confidence in the banking system and encouraged a flight to the US dollar. In early 2017 substantial foreign-exchange reserves from the State Oil Fund of the Republic of Azerbaijan (SOFAZ, the sovereign wealth fund) were made available to the CBA in an effort to restore confidence in the currency. This appears to have had a positive effect on sentiment.
Officially, the CBA is seeking to establish a free-floating currency and a monetary policy focused on inflation targeting. However, it does not currently have the monetary policy levers to control inflation effectively through open market operations. The financial sector is small, banking penetration rates are low, and the transmission mechanism between the cost of CBA lending and the money supply is weak. Dollarisation of the economy remains high, and oil prices will continue to play a dominant role in shaping inflation expectations, the exchange rate and the money supply.
Uzbekistan liberalises the som
In a significant move on September 5th the Central Bank of Uzbekistan (CBU) ended its long-running policy of administratively supporting the official exchange rate of the som on a crawling peg, allowing it to float freely. This move saw the official exchange rate converge to the black market rate of Som8,100:US$1, marking a depreciation of almost 50%. The president, Shavkat Mirziyoyev, had announced in November 2016 that he would liberalise the exchange rate, allowing it to be determined by market forces. Following his announcement, the som's crawling peg was allowed to depreciate at a faster pace. Ahead of the currency liberalisation, the authorities implemented measures aimed at stemming the use of the black market. For example, after the government issued a decree, GM Uzbekistan, the country's largest automobile manufacturer, abandoned its practice of selling vehicles in foreign currency (primarily US dollars) in June. In addition to allowing the som's depreciation, Mr Mirziyoyev also sanctioned the relaxation of some stringent capital controls on foreign currency for businesses and individuals. Enterprises registered in Uzbekistan are now permitted to buy and sell currency for any purpose, including imports and the repatriation of profits (previously subject to controls). However, Uzbek citizens are still required to credit hard foreign currency to debit cards for spending abroad, leaving in place one significant capital control despite the currency reform. The Mirziyoyev administration has indicated that it will further reduce capital controls in the coming months, which will aid domestic competiveness. After depreciating in 2017-18, we expect broadly stable global commodity prices to bring about a modest appreciation of the manat against the US dollar in 2019-22.
Non-commodity exporters' currencies should stabilise from 2017
The currencies of most non-commodity exporters should continue to stabilise, as the main price adjustment from lower remittances from Russia and the more subdued regional growth outlook has now taken place. However, the outlook remains uncertain. Weaker than forecast commodity prices or a return to fighting in eastern Ukraine could trigger another bout of currency volatility in Russia, which would be transmitted to most of the regional economies. Currency volatility has led to the increased dollarisation of many economies in the region, which will hamper the effectiveness of monetary policy and the ability of the central banks to stabilise inflation and output.

The UK economy has been resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote. Average annual real GDP growth in 2016 was firm, at 1.8%, albeit a modest slowdown from 2.3% growth in 2015. The latest GDP data point to a slowdown in the UK economy in 2017. Real GDP in the third quarter increased by 0.4% quarter on quarter, and by 1.5% year on year, slowing from 1.8% year-on-year growth in the first quarter. We expect a deceleration in the pace of economic growth in full-year 2017, to 1.6%. We expect the pace of real GDP growth to slow further, to an average of 1.5% per year in 2018-19. Rising cost pressures and uncertainty about the Brexit negotiations and the UK's future relationship with the EU are likely to weigh more heavily on economic activity over the next two years.
Mitigating the extent of the economic slowdown this year and in 2018 will be a deceleration in the pace of import growth as export volumes benefit from the depreciation of sterling. A deal on the UK's new trading relationship with the EU is likely to be phased in from 2019. We expect the pace of real GDP growth to accelerate to 1.9% on average in 2021-22.
The economic impact of the UK's vote to leave the EU on the wider regional economy could be substantial. In addition to the direct effect via trade and investment channels, over time the referendum result is also likely to compound centrifugal political and institutional dynamics in the EU and the euro zone. However, the short-term economic fallout from Brexit will be modest for Europe as a whole.
The economic expansion in Europe has gained momentum as the recovery that has been building since 2013 has broadened and become more entrenched. We expect EU28 growth to accelerate this year, from 1.9% in 2016 to 2.4%, before slowing to an annual average of 1.8% in 2018-22. This upswing mitigates the risk to the region's economic prospects from external factors, notably monetary policy tightening in the US and an expected slowdown in China.

Outlook for the euro zone will remain challenging
The economic recovery in the euro zone has gained momentum, and after average growth of 1.9% in 2015-16 we expect a healthy expansion of 2.4% this year, and annual average growth of 1.7% in 2018-22. In our view the economic recovery has further to run, partly because it is rooted in factors that will underpin sustainable demand, such as rising employment and household deleveraging. Furthermore, there remains significant slack in the euro zone economy that has yet to be absorbed.
Nevertheless, the longer-term outlook for the single currency area will remain challenging. Demographic factors will begin to exert a more powerful drag on an increasing number of countries in the bloc. We do not expect policymakers to find a game-changing solution to remedy some of the euro zone's institutional shortcomings. In particular, they are unlikely to reform the bloc's fiscal policy framework. This means that tensions will persist between member states over targets for budget deficits, and it is almost inconceivable that the bloc's fiscal authorities will significantly ease the pressure on their monetary counterparts by pursuing an actively expansionary policy.
The Visegrad countries can look forward to above-average growth rates
Much of central and eastern Europe also faces a challenging environment in the longer term. However, countries that benefit from EU funding in particular will see real GDP growth well above the EU average over 2018-22. A deadline at the end of 2015 for fund drawdowns from the EU's 2007-13 fiscal period brought an end to a surge in investment spending. Funding inflows for projects under the 2014-20 funding period were slow to begin in 2016, holding back activity last year, but funds began to flow again in 2017 and projects are under way that will lift economic growth rates during the forecast period. We expect that growth in Germany-a major market for these countries-will remain solid. The German economy's changing structure, with investment and private consumption rising, will provide a boost to central and east European countries with strong trade links to their larger neighbour.
Within central and eastern Europe there are some divergences in terms of average growth rates and overall economic performance, and we expect these to persist. The Visegrad states-the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary and Poland-are set to record healthy growth rates in 2018-22, with low oil prices, significant trade integration with Germany, generally weighty and competitive external sectors (measured as exports relative to GDP), and a much smaller fiscal drag than previously supporting growth.
In south-east Europe the situation is also improving following a protracted and difficult post-crisis recovery, with growth rates in the region set to equal, or even better, those of the Visegrad states and the Baltics in 2018. On the downside, slow progress on structural reforms, high public and/or private debt loads, and (in some cases) continued large fiscal deficits remain impediments to faster growth.
Growth in the Czech Republic-the star performer in 2015, with 5.4% growth-slowed to 2.5% in 2016, but is estimated to reach 4.5% in 2017 and an average 2.6% per year in 2018-22. In Slovakia real GDP growth slowed from 3.9% in 2015 to 3.3% in 2016; we expect this annual growth rate to be maintained on average over 2018-22. In Hungary growth slowed to 2.1% in 2016, from 3.3% in 2015, but is expected to pick up to 3.8% this year and to average 2.3% per year in 2018-22. In Poland real GDP growth slowed from 3.8% in 2015 to 2.9% in 2016, reflecting a deterioration in policy and the impact of the tail-off in EU-funded projects. We expect real GDP growth to rebound to 4.6% in 2017 and to expand at an average annual rate of 3.3% in 2018-22.
Economic activity is picking up in south-east Europe
In south-east Europe the situation is generally improving after a protracted and difficult post-crisis recovery. We expect continued strong real GDP growth in the region's biggest economy, Romania, which grew by 4.8% in 2016. We expect growth of 7.2% this year and average annual growth of about 4.3% per year in 2018-22. However, rapid wage growth is driving a consumer boom that is sucking in imports and inflating the current-account deficit, and tax cuts have widened the fiscal deficit. Bulgaria will also maintain the momentum established in 2015, with growth in 2017 expected to average 3.8%. In 2018-22 we expect real GDP growth to average 3% per year in Bulgaria. This sustained pick-up is driven by improved performance in the euro zone, robust export performance and increased expenditure on infrastructure projects, which received a boost from a surge in the inflow of EU funds.
Growth in the western Balkans to accelerate; Baltics and Visegrad to slow
We forecast average real GDP growth in the western Balkans (Albania, BiH, Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia) of about 2.8% in 2017 and 3.1% in 2018, up from an annual average of 2.7% in 2015-16. Growth in the three Baltic states is estimated at 4.3% in 2017 and we expect it to average 3.4% per year in 2018-19.
Economic activity in the western Balkans has picked up in the past two years, reflecting a combination of favourable base effects and externally driven cyclical factors such as low oil prices. In 2015-16 private investment and exports were the main drivers of growth in Albania, Montenegro and Serbia, with private consumption remaining weak, pointing to a more balanced growth trajectory. The region has undergone a significant economic adjustment in the years since the global economic crisis in 2007-09, largely correcting fiscal and current-account imbalances (with some notable exceptions, such as Montenegro). Inflation has fallen to historical lows for the region, allowing a more accommodative monetary policy that has supported growth. The revival of investment is set to continue, and over the medium and long term the region should benefit from the structural reforms that are now under way in most countries. On the downside, high public and/or private debt loads, and (in some cases) continued large fiscal deficits remain impediments to faster growth. We do not think that the fallout from the Brexit vote will be unduly negative for the Balkans, whose slow progress towards EU membership is set to continue.
Croatia was the worst-performing economy in the former communist region in 2009-15, when annual growth averaged -1.6%. It emerged from six years of recession in 2015 with growth of 2.3%. Growth accelerated to 3.1% per year in 2016-17, driven by private consumption and investment, and benefiting from favourable base effects and cyclical factors, including low international oil prices and a record tourism season. In 2018-22 we forecast that real GDP will expand by an average of 2.7% per year. Absorption of EU funds is improving. Nevertheless, the economy will only reach its 2008 level towards the end of the forecast period. Croatia is still at a relatively early stage in the reform process and is working off the excesses of the pre-crisis years. The need to pay down large public- and private-sector debt, a deteriorating demographic picture, poor competitiveness and a subdued external outlook will all contribute to the weak trend growth rate.
Greece's economy has been in almost permanent recession since 2008. Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than a quarter during this period, government consumption also by nearly a quarter, house-hold consumption by one-fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery that got under way in 2017 is fragile and vulnerable to domestic and external developments. We estimate that real GDP will expand by 1.3% in 2017 and forecast 1.8% average growth per year in 2018-22.
In Turkey domestic political instability, the perceived risk of terrorist attacks and uncertainty about the global economic outlook weighed on the economy in 2015-16, but relative stability following the April 2017 presidential reform referendum and fiscal stimulus measures have supported a rebound to estimated growth of 5.5% in 2017 (following the release of third-quarter data, this figure is likely to be revised up to 7-7.5%) and an average of 4.2% per year in 2018-22. By far the biggest risk to our growth forecast is the possibility of a severe disruption to capital inflows to Turkey triggered by tighter than currently expected US monetary policy. This is not our central forecast, but the risk of it happening has risen.
Russia's economy has moved into a recovery phase this year
Although low energy prices contributed to a modest recovery in EU growth in 2015, they triggered a deep recession across most of the former Soviet Union. The weakness of the Russian economy, which is an important driver of economies in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), held down growth across the rest of the region, largely through low remittances and export demand. In Russia real GDP contracted by 2.8% in 2015 and remained in negative territory in 2016, as oil prices remained low and households and companies continued to deleverage. Household incomes declined in real terms for a second successive year. This was compounded by a contractionary fiscal policy. The weak banking sector and high political risk continued to depress investment. Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan likewise faced the combined impact of contracting household and government expenditure and corporate deleveraging in 2016. Russian GDP fell by 0.2% in 2016. Kazakhstan's economy posted low growth of just 0.9%, and real GDP in Azerbaijan declined by 3.1%.
Growth in Russia is expected to have rebounded moderately in 2017, driven by a recovery in commodity prices, which has encouraged a strengthening of the rouble and household spending power and helped the banking sector to start to stabilise, allowing for a modest recovery in investment. We expect real GDP growth of an estimated 1.8% in 2017 and a forecast annual average of 1.7% in 2018-22. Risks are to the downside, as household consumption might be weaker than we currently forecast, and fiscal consolidation will continue to constrain public consumption and infrastructure spending. The external political environment remains uncertain, and a further upsurge in tensions with the West cannot be excluded. Moreover, oil prices could remain lower than currently forecast. In the medium term, structural constraints-the weak institutional environment, poor demographics and weak competition-will hold trend growth below 2% per year.
After the shocks of revolution and war real GDP contracted by 9.8% in Ukraine in 2015, before bouncing back by 2.3% in 2016, driven by a recovery in private consumption and investment. Subdued growth in Russia and restrictions on trade will limit the prospects for an export-led recovery. We forecast average annual growth of about 2.1% per year in 2018-22, following estimated growth of 2.1% in 2017, assuming little progress in reforming the economy and stabilising the political system (but no return to all-out war in eastern Ukraine). Ukraine's fiscal position has improved but remains weak, and the potential for political instability to trigger an economic crisis is high.

The slump in global oil prices in late 2014 exacerbated a marked disinflationary trend in Europe, but helped to boost to the region's real economy in 2015, and to a limited extent in 2016, as households benefited from higher real earnings and businesses from lower input costs. Since late 2016 inflation has picked up, with base effects-notably those related to energy prices-providing much of the initial impetus in early 2017. As base effects have fallen out of the arithmetic, inflation has stabilised again. We expect it to average 1.7% in the EU28 in 2017 and 1.6% in 2018 and to average 1.8% per year in 2019-22.
In a number of specific instances across the region, very different inflationary patterns will be recorded-Turkey, for example, will struggle throughout the forecast period to bring its inflation rate down to its 5% official target. Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high, as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disinflationary effects of plunging global oil prices since mid-2014. Assuming that the Central Bank of Turkey keeps monetary policy tight and does not loosen it again too soon, we see inflation gradually easing, achieving the 5% target by end-2021.

a Qualitative grades are assigned according to the following scale: very good: score more than 8; good: 6.5 to 8; moderate: 5.5 to 6.4; poor: 5 to 5.4; very poor: less than 5.
The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings model seeks to measure the attractiveness of a country's business environment and its major components. The model's assessment of the business environment-based on the opportunities for and hindrances to the conduct of business-enables us to rank each of the 82 countries covered on its overall position and in each of ten categories on a global and a regional basis. The model uses quantitative data and expert assessments to measure the attractiveness of countries' business environments. The framework has been designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies in formulating their global business strategies and investment location decisions. The overall scores (on a 1-10 scale) and rankings are based on scores for 91 indicators, grouped into ten categories.
There is a moderate improvement in Europe's aggregate regional scores between the historical period (2013-17) and the forecast period (2018-22), reflecting the transition from the post-crisis period to one in which recovery and repair, although patchy, have, in most countries, been under way for some time. Western Europe's score remains broadly stable, rising from 7.5 in the historical period to 7.6 in the forecast period, and eastern Europe's score moves up from 6.1 to 6.5 over the same timeframe. Across the region, the strongest ranking improvements are recorded by Denmark, Romania and Poland. By contrast, Turkey drops by 13 places, Switzerland by seven and Greece by six.
EU countries remain well represented in the top 20 of our global rankings. Two non-EU countries, Switzerland and Norway, also occupy leading positions. The large number of west European countries in the top 20 reflects the high degree of political stability in the region (a post-crisis rise in social and political tension notwithstanding), large and competitive domestic markets, and a strong degree of openness to world trade. Although we continue to highlight the risks of political fragmentation and rising anti-establishment sentiment, we do not forecast a marked anti-market backlash in policy choices.
Recent years have brought considerable improvement to the investment climate of central and eastern Europe. The early reformers among the countries of central Europe led the way in the early 1990s in adopting far-reaching stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation programmes. Reform in the Balkans has been much more uneven and subject to periodic reversals, but significant progress has been made even here. Factors such as a low-cost but well-qualified labour force, proximity to developed markets and, in some cases, ample natural-resource endowments have attracted considerable foreign direct investment to the region during the past decade. However, many east European countries still face fundamental reform challenges; meeting those challenges will test already fraying relations between governments and electorates, and heighten the risk of political instability and social unrest.
The outlook for the business environment in the countries of the former Soviet Union is mixed. In Russia the business environment has suffered as a result of Western sanctions and a rise in tariff and non-tariff barriers. There is little evidence that the government intends to undertake disruptive structural reform to improve the dynamism of the economy. Low energy prices have prompted some regional commodity exporters, notably Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan, to attempt to open up and diversify their economies. Ukraine has committed itself to an ambitious reform programme; however, its economic prospects will be harmed by disruption of trade and financial ties with Russia. Throughout the region the barriers to enacting wide-ranging reform remain formidable.
Data sources and definitions
Methodology
The forecast tables have been constructed from the individual data series available in the respective Economist Intelligence Unit Country Forecasts. In addition, the Economist Intelligence Unit runs the National Institute's Global Econometric Model (NIGEM), which is developed and maintained by the London Business School at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines ten separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, and infrastructure. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 16 (infrastructure), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2013-17) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2018-22). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2013-17. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2018-22 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
The main sources used in the business rankings model include CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce; Freedom House, Annual Survey of Political Rights and Civil Liberties; Heritage Foundation, Index of Economic Freedom; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; UN, Human Development Report; US Social Security Administration, Social Security Programs Throughout the World; World Bank, World Development Report; World Development Indicators; Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Report.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2013-17 ranges are then used to derive 2018-22 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2018-22, not to the likely situation in 2022 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2015 or 2020). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Although the regime of the president, Nicolás Maduro, will strengthen its grip on power in the wake of the installation of a Constituent Assembly, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect Mr Maduro to remain in power beyond 2019. The most likely scenarios for a transition to an opposition-led government are through ad hoc elections after economic collapse or a military coup. There is a risk that the regime will cling to power beyond 2019 if the government finds financing to avoid a disorderedly default or if it manages to boost dwindling oil production.
We estimate that inflation will exceed 1,600% by end-2017 and average over 2,000% in 2018. GDP will continue to contract into 2019. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption and operating conditions have hurt investment. We forecast a recovery beginning in 2020, by which time the current opposition is expected to be in government, leading to macro-economic adjustments, and institutional and structural reforms.
Sweeping reforms are required to restore confidence in contract and property rights, and thereby promote a recovery in investment. The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will encourage private investment, re-establish market mechanisms for price stability and attempt to undo the constraints imposed by the government on private firms.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and quadruple-digit inflation will hit private consumption, and an increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate the fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices, and the economy will not return to growth until 2020-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
At almost 300bn barrels, Venezuela has the world's largest proven oil reserves, but its oil sector has suffered from disinvestment and mismanagement owing to political interference. The government claims that rising investment in the energy sector will lift oil production significantly in the medium term, but we foresee a continued fall in production until 2019, followed by rising output from 2020 onwards as economic conditions stabilise.

Venezuela is in 80th position globally in our business environment rankings for 2018-22, out of 82 countries covered, making the country one of the least attractive investment locations in the world. This reflects state intervention-ism, highly heterodox macroeconomic policies, a lack of legal security and weak institutions. Regionally, Venezuela remains last of the 12 countries covered, notwithstanding our assumption of improvements after 2019.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Nationalisation poses a diminished threat, given fiscal weaknesses. Property rights remain weak. Price fixing undermines profitability.
2020-22: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists. A new government in 2019 brings new policies.
2020-22: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain fairly low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2018-19: Unorthodox exchange-rate policy framework adds to uncertainty. The state continues to exercise tight control over access to official-rate US dollars. New government in 2019 removes exchange controls.
2020-22: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2018-19: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2020-22: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2018-19: Credit growth remains firm, but sectoral allocation is distorted by administrative interventions. Banks remain highly profitable, although unpredictable enforcement and a weak regulatory framework heighten instability.
2020-22: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2018-19: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2020-22: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Access to water and electricity supplies remains precarious. Underinvestment in power transmission ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2020-22: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued electricity rationing.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Chávez was diagnosed with cancer in 2011 but, after declaring in July 2012 that he had fully recovered, won a fourth presidential term in October 2012. However, his health quickly deteriorated and he died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has since plummeted.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is a federal republic, successive administrations have proven reluctant to devolve political authority, with the transfer of financial resources from federal to local level highly dependent on the central government. The legislature is unicameral, and elections for the National Assembly take place every five years. In December 2015 the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the legislature. In August 2017 the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) installed a Constituent Assembly with powers over all branches of government and a remit to rewrite the 1999 Constitution-apparently a ploy to entrench the PSUV in power.
Policy issues: Political radicalisation has been reflected in increasingly heterodox economic policymaking, with massive fiscal and monetary stimulus and the nationalisation of industries deemed strategically important. Distortions created by this approach have become evident, with inflation rising sharply in spite of price controls, and with capital controls spawning a rampant black market for foreign exchange. Failure to invest part of the oil windfall has led to a startling decline in physical infrastructure. Non-oil production has in effect ground to a halt, leaving the economy entirely dependent on the energy sector. With large oil shipments going to China to repay loans, and (on subsidised terms) to regional neighbours via the PetroCaribe oil-financing scheme, the country is running very short of US dollars, forcing cuts in import spending.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 60% for oil firms. Since 2011 a maximum royalty of 95% has applied to oil extraction. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Official data are unavailable, but we estimate that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$11bn in 2016 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages, narrowing the current-account deficit to 0.7% of GDP.
