Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Even as Venezuela's economic predicament deepens, amid an intensifying default crisis and looming hyperinflation, the governing Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has strengthened its hold on power as the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) has slid into disarray. Although economic crisis has made the president, Nicolás Maduro, extremely unpopular, the government's history of electoral manipulation means that it is unlikely that the PSUV would leave power via free and fair elections. Instead, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects worsening economic conditions to result in a chaotic political transition process, most likely ushering the MUD into power by 2019.
The PSUV's concerted efforts at undermining the MUD explain its inability to effect change. Government tactics have included banning candidates, imprisoning popular opposition figures and stripping all power from the MUD-controlled National Assembly, which in August was superseded by a new Constituent Assembly (ANC). The PSUV-only ANC is formally concerned with rewriting the constitution, but has taken over all legislative powers during its two-year remit. In addition, the PSUV has fostered divisions within the MUD, rewarding co-operation from some factions while penalising others. This has often created divergent interests within the MUD, leading to a divided front.
The PSUV's future in power currently depends on the support of three key backers: the state's coercive apparatus (the security forces and military); a sizeable sector of the population dependent on government handouts; and activist groups (so-called colectivos), which are something between community organisers and PSUV paramilitaries. To remain in power, the government will need to ply these groups with resources, the vast majority of which come from PDVSA, the state-owned oil company. The key backer in the arrangement is the military; in November Mr Maduro appointed Manuel Quevedo, a general, as oil minister and head of PDVSA. We interpret the move as both a reward to the military for its loyalty and an attempt at a further intertwining of the fates of the military and the PSUV. Regardless, we believe that a prolonged interruption in exports by PDVSA would cause this support to waver while also increasing popular dissatisfaction, as it would exacerbate shortages of basic goods and trigger an increase in inflation (already estimated at over 1,000%).
We believe that there are multiple paths towards a dangerous interruption in PDVSA exports. There could be a disorderedly default of sovereign and/or PDVSA external debt. Legal action in the US (as permitted by the debt contracts) could result in seizures of PDVSA's assets (such as those of Citgo, a PDVSA-owned, US-based refinery). Such actions, if widespread, could curtail exports dramatically (although PDVSA has taken defensive measures that may limit the effectiveness of seizures).
Independent of legal action, the PDVSA's falling output is bound to lead to a curtailing of export revenue. Output dipped to 1.9m barrels/day (b/d) in October (it was 2.4m b/d in 2013, when Mr Maduro took office), and we expect production to continue dropping into 2018. PDVA's US dollar earnings will continue to dwindle, eventually reaching a point where the PSUV's backers withdraw support. There is a risk that the Maduro administration will avoid this fate, if sufficient Chinese, Indian or Russian investment in the sector supports output.
Regardless of the path, a drop in hard-currency earnings from exports will make support for the PSUV waver within the ranks of its backers while worsening an already traumatic economic context. Given the level of political violence in the country, it would be difficult for the PSUV to appease critics by replacing Mr Maduro with another high-ranking PSUV figure. It also seems unlikely that the PSUV would quietly leave office via fair and free elections. Instead, the most likely progression of events would involve the military pushing the PSUV out and restoring order while paving the way for eventual elections. Such a transition is our baseline forecast, but, given the military's participation in the PSUV's regime, its commitment to democracy may have eroded by then and free elections may not be immediate.
Regardless of how and when political transition occurs, the second half of our forecast period is likely to remain volatile and uncertain. In addition to holdovers in the colectivos and in the military, the MUD will also have to contend with huge economic distortions and deep political differences that would test even a unified political party.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
Taking advantage of disarray in the MUD following its defeat in gubernatorial elections in October, the government announced municipal elections for December 10th. The largest opposition parties will boycott the contests, meaning an almost guaranteed victory for the PSUV. However, the centralisation of power means that the results will have little impact on overall government policy. A presidential election is due in December 2018, but both an early election (to take advantage of opposition disarray) or an indefinite postponement are possibilities given the PSUV's history of electoral manipulation. Regardless, any presidential election under the PSUV is unlikely to be free and fair. We do expect relatively free and fair elections following the PSUV's exit from power.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Venezuela has come under increasing regional and international pressure. The EU has denounced the regime's anti-democratic practices and banned weapons sales. Mercosur, a regional bloc comprised of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, suspended Venezuela following the installation of the ANC in August. Finally, a regional group of 12 nations has declared both the October gubernatorial elections and the ANC vote illegitimate.
US sanctions remain the most relevant variable. Such sanctions have made it near-impossible for PDVSA or the government to renegotiate its debts. Given Venezuela's extreme dependency on trade with the US (Venezuela exports oil to and imports distillates from the US), an embargo would cripple the economy and probably trigger one of our transition scenarios. A key priority for the Maduro administration will be the maintenance of good relations with Russia, which continues to provide limited financial backing. China, a previous major source of financing, has seemingly withdrawn, as there is no public evidence of Chinese financing since 2015.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The government's immediate economic policy concern will be fending off debt default and associated legal challenges. The government has gone into arrears on some sovereign and state-owned firms' bonds (including PDVSA), while also making late payments on others. Despite announcing its intention to restructure debt, the government has also restated its commitment to pay while blaming payments delays on US sanctions and the payment system. The situation has been classified as technical default. A successful restructuring by the Maduro regime appears impossible. This is partly owing to logistical challenges imposed by US sanctions but also because the Maduro regime has no economic or political programme underpinning restructuring that would be acceptable to creditors.
There is no sign yet of acceleration by bondholders, who so far appear to prefer late payment to lengthy legal battles. Eventually, this stance is likely to change. To avoid PDVSA asset seizures, the government may choose to default on sovereign bonds but adhere to PDVSA's repayment schedule. Sovereign creditors would undoubtedly ask US courts to define PDVSA as an "alter ego" of the government in order to seize its assets. In late November the government reached a deal with a Canadian mining firm, Crystallex, which had sought an alter ego ruling in the US court system, but the latter will be precluded by the agreement. Other firms are also pursuing alter ego rulings, but their cases are not as far along. Thus, the government has bought itself time by avoiding the legal precedent. In this environment, the timing of likely seizures is unclear. When they do happen, the consequences for import capacity will be devastating. We assume that they would trigger a transition of power and, eventually, a change of economic policy direction.
In the meantime, the government must also grapple with a build-up of huge inflationary and currency depreciation pressures. We assume that the Maduro government will be forced to weaken the currency more substantially in 2018 than it has done so far. However, given previous performance, other much-needed reforms are unlikely to be addressed. Fiscal and monetary policies will remain expansionary, and ad hoc policy intervention and heavy state control of the economy will persist. Amid subdued oil prices, import compression will remain necessary, as other sources of foreign exchange will be hard to find.
Under our baseline scenario we expect the opposition to come to power in 2019, ushering in adjustments designed to correct currency distortions, tighten expansionary fiscal policy and rebuild institutional capacity. We have factored-in a financing agreement with the IMF to support the adjustment process;, forecasting lending of US$19bn in 2019-22. Efforts to secure increased inflows of foreign direct investment would also be likely under a new government, and would help to improve the balance-of-payments dynamics, although we expect direct investors to remain cautious for some time with regards to Venezuela, with the possible exception of the oil sector.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
The authorities' failure to publish data on the non-financial public sector since 2012 demonstrates the opacity of the public finances and complicates accurate forecasting of the size of the deficit. We estimate a non-financial public-sector deficit of 19.4% of GDP for 2017 and expect the deficit to remain in double digits in 2018. A transition to a new government should help to ease the deficit to 4.7% of GDP by 2022. The large deficits of the present are mostly being financed by printing money. High inflation and an overvalued currency are eroding the relative value of domestic and external debt, making debt/GDP ratios unreliable indicators of fiscal stability. There is considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing, mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China. As these items are excluded from the public debt statistics, the true size of total public liabilities is understated. Under our baseline forecast of severe economic stress that would see an MUD-led opposition government in 2019, we expect a restructuring process with external creditors to happen.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
Monetary policy under the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) will continue to be driven by the government's desire to keep real interest rates negative and to print money to finance large fiscal deficits; money supply (M2) rose by 644% year on year in October, the highest rate on record. In the context of extremely high inflation, we expect real rates to remain deeply negative until 2019. After that, our forecast of substantial currency and fiscal adjustment under a new government, which implies a substantial tightening of monetary policy, will see real interest rates turn positive.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending mean that we project further contractions in real GDP in 2018-19, following an estimated contraction of 12.5% in 2017. Our forecast for a recovery in 2020-22 rests on an assumption of slightly higher oil prices, alongside a political transition that produces a combination of macroeconomic adjustment (supported by IMF financial assistance), and institutional and structural reform. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, given the scale of the recession, and our forecasts therefore imply only a partial rebound, after a real GDP decline of over 40% in 2014-19.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2018, reflecting the effect on real wages of soaring inflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will continue to contract as well, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange, and remitting profits. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition, progress on long­delayed joint projects with Chinese firms in energy and-later in the forecast period-a pick-up in public-sector investment. Exports will continue to shrink throughout 2018 as oil production falls further, but will pick up thereafter, reflecting renewed investment under a new government and a removal of constraints to domestic production. Import demand will rise sharply, in line with an alleviation of basic goods shortages and the release of pent-up demand. Even after the change in govern-ment, however, dependence on oil will persist.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
A decimation of domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have caused elevated inflation for the past two years. The government continues to decree maximum prices as its main policy tool to fight inflation, with the latest attempt coming in mid-November. We do not expect a policy reversal under the PSUV government, meaning that inflation will remain extremely high in the short term. Official data on inflation has not been released since end-2015, but since the start of the year the National Assembly has begun producing a consumer price index. This showed monthly inflation of 45.5% in October, bringing accumulated inflation for January-October to 826%. We expect inflation to exceed 1,600% by year-end and to average over 2,000% by the end of 2018. We continue to forecast a decline in inflation over time, under the assumption of a recovery in oil output and corrective economic policies under an MUD-led government. However, for now, a lack of funds available for importing basic goods suggests that shortages will be rife, and the risk of hyperinflation (monthly inflation of over 50% for an extended period) will remain substantial.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
Currently, a dual exchange-rate system is in operation, comprising an official peg, known as the Dipro, which is limited to priority public-sector imports and set at BsF10:US$1, and a heavily managed rate known as the Dicom, used for private-sector operations (but where demand for US dollars vastly outstrips supply). The Dicom was suspended in August, with Mr Maduro announcing the future usage of a "basket of currencies" (such as the rupee, rouble, yuan and euro) to replace the use of the dollar. However, the system is yet to be implemented, as the government seems to be hoarding all foreign-exchange available to meet its debt obligations. Amid huge pressures on the dual-currency exchange-rate system, our forecasts assume substantial devaluations in 2018, but the exchange rate will remain extremely overvalued. The suspension of the Dicom, coupled with runaway growth in the money supply, has led to a spike in the black-market foreign-exchange rate, which reached BsF88,235:US$1 on November 28th.
We assume that further major currency adjustment under a new, MUD-led government in 2019 will involve immediate exchange-rate unification. Until that occurs, given existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market, there is an extremely high risk of a debilitating currency crisis in the short term. If confidence in the bolívar collapses amid hyperinflation, dollarisation-or the launch of a new domestic currency-could occur.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
We forecast a current-account deficit of 2.2% of GDP in 2018, as exports, held back by decaying infrastructure, falling oil production and lack of exploration, will be unable to offset imports, despite the government's best efforts at dampening them (we estimate that the value of imports in 2017 will be equivalent to a quarter of those of 2012). In 2019, with a new administration in place, exports and imports will begin a recovery. Our assumption of economic adjustment in the medium term suggests a recovery in investment inflows, particularly into the oil sector. In addition, financial inflows in the wake of a debt re-structuring, and financial and technical assistance from the IMF, should help to rebuild reserves coverage. This will buttress the stability of the external accounts and facilitate the gradual removal of foreign-exchange controls, as reflected by the converging official and parallel exchange rates.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCRP: Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The government, led by Pedro Pablo Kuczynski of the centre-right Peruanos Por el Kambio, will maintain a pragmatic approach to macroeconomic manage-ment within an orthodox policy framework. However, political tension will endure, owing to conflict between the executive and the legislature, in which Mr Kuczynski's party holds just 17 of the 130 seats. Passage of legislation will depend on support from the opposition, which is likely to remain obstructionist.
The government is likely to face challenges in the form of sporadic outbreaks of social unrest over extractive projects, rising urban crime and drug-trafficking, as well as potential violence perpetrated by the remnants of Sendero Luminoso, a terrorist group that had largely been defeated by 2000.
High levels of corruption and institutional inefficiencies will weigh on the business environ-ment and administrative effectiveness, as well as sustain public dissatisfaction with the political establishment. The broad reach of investigations into allegations of corruption will exacerbate political uncertainty, with some members of both the government and opposition already under investigation.
The economy will expand by 3.8% per year on average in 2018-22. Although among the fastest rates in the region, this is well below the highs of the past decade, when annual GDP growth often exceeded 6%. Slowdowns in China and the US will curb GDP expansion in 2018 and 2020. Improved external conditions and more dynamic domestic demand will lift growth in 2021-22.
Despite low inflation, rising copper output, prudent fiscal policies and a manageable current-account deficit, Peru will remain vulnerable to fluctuations in external demand and commodities prices.
Population growth will slow slightly in 2018-22, but the labour force will continue to expand more rapidly than the overall population. The formal economy, despite expanding firmly in recent years, will struggle to absorb new entrants into the labour market, thereby sustaining a substantial informal sector, which will have a negative effect on productivity growth.
Peru is a fairly small (albeit growing) market, and opportunities will remain restricted by relatively low purchasing power, as well as high levels of poverty. Nonetheless, two decades of strong economic growth have fuelled the emergence of a growing middle class, particularly in the capital, Lima. This will continue to support growing consumption levels in 2018-22.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Peru's business environment score rises for the 2018-22 period, boosted by infrastructure improvements. The country improves two places in the global rankings and one place regionally. Peru's key strengths will remain its openness to foreign trade-secured by multiple free-trade agreements-and stable macro-economic environment. A rigid labour market is the country's greatest weakness.
Country forecast overview: Peru's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Reforms to reduce some taxes and streamline bureaucracy are introduced by the government.
2020-22: Government to allow increased private participation in state-run firms, including electricity and water utilities. Policies to induce formalisation in small and medium-sized enterprises expected.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Changes to regulations in order to stimulate foreign investment in value-added mining projects and infrastructure.
2020-22: Foreign investment in infrastructure strengthens, primarily in transportation and telecommunications. Investment picks up in mining, although on a smaller scale than in the past.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Consolidation of the Pacific Alliance, an integration project that also includes Chile, Colombia and Mexico, boosts trade and investment flows.
2020-22: Free-trade agreements signed with Turkey, India and Australia. Companies benefit from conclusion of Trade in Services Agreement, a trade pact involving 52 countries.
Taxes
2018-19: Increasing use of "public works for taxes" schemes, allowing companies to invest part of their tax bill in transport and social infrastructure.
2020-22: Further tax breaks to boost labour market formality. Tax credits for large firms that reinvest profits.
Financing
2018-19: Merger with Colombian, Chilean and Mexican stockmarkets continues to deepen capital markets, as does legislation from late 2015 exempting capital gains tax on the sale of shares until 2018 to increase stockmarket liquidity. Sovereign bonds can now be settled through Euroclear, a platform allowing easier access to international finance. Private firms will follow suit.
2020-22: Deeper penetration of the financial system as new mechanisms, such as an electronic money platform, take hold.
The labour market
2018-19: Labour rigidity remains a serious problem, despite government measures to reduce regulation.
2020-22: Government continues the use of tax incentives in an attempt to increase formality in the labour market to 60%, up from 27% in July 2017. Wages increase in key public sectors, including healthcare, education and law enforcement.
Infrastructure
2018-19: The government's infrastructure plan starts to gain steam, with a focus on roadways and hydraulic structures. Broadband penetration increases. New thermal and hydroelectric plants provide sizeable power surplus, opening the way for electricity exports.
2020-22: Government ramps up investment to provide universal coverage of water and sewerage systems. Work launched on third and fourth lines of metro system in the capital, Lima. Gasoducto del Sur Peruano pipeline completed.

Background: More than 12 years of military rule ended in 1980. Following a decade of economic and social instability, the government of Alberto Fujimori (1990-2000) ended hyperinflation, advanced reforms to liberalise the economy and defeated the Sendero Luminoso, a Maoist insurgent group. However, Mr Fujimori subverted Peru's democratic institutions and committed grave human rights abuses. His government collapsed over a corruption scandal. Subsequent govern-ments have been successful in consolidating macroeconomic stability, but have largely overlooked the structural reforms required to raise productivity levels. The current president, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, took office in July 2016. His term runs to July 2021.
Political structure: The 1993 constitution established a presidential regime with a powerful executive, elected for five years. Consecutive presidential re-election is not permitted. A 130-member unicameral legislature, elected at the same time as the president, also sits for five years. The government is decentralising revenue and responsibility to the 25 regions (including the constitutional province of Callao).
Policy issues: The Economist Intelligence Unit assumes that there will be continuity of orthodox economic policies and that the business environment will remain attractive. Mr Kuczynski is a former World Bank economist and mining minister, and we expect gradual progress on structural reform under his government. The public education and healthcare systems will continue to underperform, despite increases in funding. The government will also increase spending on social programmes to reduce poverty levels. Despite government involvement in the market, private investment in transport, energy and water infrastructure will remain strong. Bilateral free-trade agreements with Peru's main trading partners-including the US, China and the EU-as well as initiatives within Latin America, will help to keep investment and trade flows strong in 2018-22.
Taxation: The corporate income-tax rate is 29.5% (mining companies that do not benefit from tax-stability contracts pay additional taxes). Dividends and other profit distribution schemes are taxed at 5%. Branch-profit tax is levied at 30% and remittance tax at 10%. Interest paid abroad stands at 5%.
Foreign trade: Tariffs are levied on imports at either 0%, 6% or 11%. The World Bank's calculation of the average effective tariff was 1.4% in 2014. Most non-tariff barriers have been eliminated. In 2016 merchandise export earnings increased by 8%, to US$37bn, whereas the import bill declined by 6%, to US$35.1bn.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
The president, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski of the centre-right Peruanos Por el Kambio, is now in the second year of his five-year term (ending July 2021) and will continue to face a challenging political environment, as his party holds just 17 seats in the 130-seat unicameral Congress. To pass legislation, he will need to negotiate with the opposition-in particular, the right-wing Fuerza Popular (FP), which holds a majority, with 71 seats. FP has, on numerous occasions, used its legislative power to force ministerial resignations with a simple majority of 66 votes. The political obstructionism reached a new high when FP cast a vote of no confidence in the cabinet led by the (now former) prime minister, Fernando Zavala, in mid-September. The unprecedented move by Congress forced Mr Kuczynski to appoint six new cabinet members to placate opposition parties. However, tension between the administration and members of the opposition will persist. On October 22nd sustained political pressure forced the resignation of Aníbal Sánchez, director of the national statistics institute, for his supposed mismanagement of the 2017 census. Shortly thereafter, Pablo de la Flor, the head of the Autoridad para la Reconstrucción con Cambios, the body overseeing reconstruction efforts following floods that affected Peru in early 2017, stepped down following criticism that he was trying to centralise the process for execution of investment, leaving municipal and regional authorities out of the dialogue. Given Mr Kuczynski's low approval ratings (27% in November), The Economist Intelligence Unit sees a high risk of additional shake-ups in the short term.
Corruption will continue to be a key issue. In mid-November Mr Kuczynski was forced to deny allegations that he was complicit in a money-laundering and bribery scandal involving Odebrecht, a Brazilian construction firm at the centre of corruption probes across the region. Press reports claimed that the president had received campaign contributions from the company, and was subsequently hired by the firm as a consultant. This development closely follows accusations against the attorney-general, Pablo Sánchez, of his purported mismanagement of the Odebrecht investigation. Nonetheless, despite FP's best efforts to evade perceptions of corruption, party members are also at risk of being implicated in the scandal. Prosecutors are already investigating the leader of FP, Keiko Fujimori, over links to alleged money-laundering operations. Similarly, on November 3rd the Ministry of Public Affairs announced that it was re-opening a money-laundering investigation into Joaquín Ramírez, a former FP congressman and close ally of Ms Fujimori. Although both deny any wrongdoing, the plethora of investigations involving FP and associated figures will undermine the party's reputation.
Weak institutions will allow corruption and mis-management to endure, espe-cially on a local level. According to the most recent Global Corruption Baro-meter survey conducted by Transparency International, a corruption watchdog, 79% of Peruvians believe that the level of corruption had risen in the past year; this will fuel discontent with the political class. Social conflict result-ing from impoverished rural and indigenous communities' opposition to extract-ive projects poses an ongoing risk, given economic dependence on mining.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
Presidential and congressional elections, held every five years, last took place in mid-2016. The next elections are municipal and regional polls in October 2018. Presidential and legislative elections will be held in mid-2021; Mr Kuczynski will not be in the running for the presidency, as consecutive re-election is prohibited. Peru currently lacks a formal nationwide party structure, and local-level parties tend to have little affiliation with national parties, leading to disassociation between the results of local and national elections. In 2021 Ms Fujimori is likely to again be the presidential candidate for FP, despite increasingly clear ambitions for party leadership on the part of her brother, Kenji. Ms Fujimori has twice brought disciplinary action against her brother for flouting party discipline. Polls indicate relatively strong public support for Ms Fujimori, which will give her the authority to keep a tight rein on party members. Verónika Mendoza of the left-wing Nuevo Perú (formerly part of the left-wing Frente Amplio coalition), who came third in the first round of the presidential race in 2016, may also run again. However, the lack of party structures facilitates the rapid ascent of personalities and political outsiders.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Peru will continue to support regional integration efforts, such as the Pacific Alliance, an economic trade pact that also includes Chile, Colombia and Mexico. In late October negotiators from the Pacific Alliance met with represen-tatives from Australia, Canada, New Zealand and Singapore to work out details related to their incorporation as associate members of the bloc. In a related development, the alliance also signed an agreement with the World Bank to issue a pan-regional catastrophe bond in 2018, the first multi-nation bond of its kind. Members of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay; Venezuela was suspended in 2016) have stated a desire for greater integration with the Pacific Alliance, but we do not currently forecast any progress in 2018-22.
In November Peru and another ten of the 12 original signatories of the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreed on a framework to move ahead despite the US's exit from the pact. However, the proposed timeline for ratification of the deal is quite ambitious. In the short term, bilateral agree-ments will remain the focus of Peruvian trade policy. Peru currently has 16 trade deals in place, covering nearly all of the world's largest economies, including Canada, China, the EU, Japan, South Korea and the US. Peru and Australia are slated to sign a free-trade agreement (FTA) in December, which will remove nearly all tariff barriers between the two countries. The government will also enter the second round of talks to finalise an FTA with India in early 2018.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Peru will retain a prudent, business-friendly policy framework in 2018-22. Mr Kuczynski has cast himself as a technocratic reformer with a mandate to address a multitude of longstanding structural shortcomings, but progress will be limited. So far, he has focused on three areas: labour formalisation, admini-strative simpli-fication and infrastructure investment. To achieve the first object-ive, the govern-ment has created new tax brackets for small busines-ses, and changed regulations to make it easier to obtain business licences and register companies in decentral-ised government offices, which will also provide advisory services and training to businesses. In July the government presented a bill to address labour inform-ality and working conditions; the outcome will depend on support from FP.
In terms of more dynamic public procedures and administration, Mr Kuczynski has restructured or overhauled procedures at a variety of government entities, including the tax authority, the state-owned petroleum company, the state investment-promotion agency and government bureaux that administer public investment. The administration hopes that a more streamlined government will entice private investment and facilitate an ambitious infra-structure programme (of which a sizable share consists of public-private partnerships). The latter is a key concern, as the administration has pinned its hopes for GDP expansion on infrastructure investment. However, capital expenditure and budget execution rates for public works remain low (by mid-October only about 44.7% of investment budgeted for 2017 had been executed), and the legislature has proven a significant obstacle to infrastructure plans.
Mr Kuczynski will remain committed to reforms to the pension system, and to education and security policy. We are not optimistic about his prospects in these endeavours. As the president's party has little leverage in Congress, FP has free rein to determine the legislative agenda. It may well support some reforms that are aligned with its own platform, but it has shown a tendency to resist some measures for political gain.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
After reaching an estimated 2.7% of GDP in 2017, the non-financial public-sector (NFPS) deficit is expected to widen to 3.1% of GDP in 2018 as the government ramps up infrastructure spending at both national and regional levels. Thereafter, the deficit will narrow as fiscal policy becomes less expansionary. In September the government submitted its budget proposal to Congress for approval. The budget calls for increased spending across the board, with particular emphasis on capital expenditure. Nearly half of the increased spending in 2018 will be allocated to reconstruction efforts to mitigate damage caused by the coastal El Niño phenomenon that affected Peru in early 2017. Other significant infra-structure expenditure in the budget includes a commitment of US$1.4bn for a long-delayed expansion of the metro system in the capital, Lima, and a US$1.2bn investment in public works aimed at improving sanitation. Other key sectors that will see budgetary increases are healthcare (up by 16%) and education (5%). These enlargements are tied to strikes by teachers and medical professionals, which ended in August following negotiations for wage increments. We expect the budget to be approved with relatively few substantial changes.
The government's infrastructure plan calls for increased outlays, and would push capital and overall expenditure to respective highs of 8.4% of GDP and 31.2% of GDP in 2018. However, the government's capacity to implement all the infrastructure measures is in doubt, given its past performance; our forecast does not foresee complete compliance. As for revenue, we expect improved tax collection in 2018-22. This is due in part to reforms at the tax authority and changes to tax legislation introduced in January 2017, which included an increase in corporate income tax to 29.5% and attempts to broaden the tax base. These changes will result in higher receipts in GDP terms in the forecast period. In 2018 these will only partly offset the rise in spending, but will result in deficit reductions in 2019-22, when we expect public expenditure to be reined in.
We expect that the public debt/GDP ratio will rise in the medium term, from an estimated 25.7% of GDP in 2017, before stabilising at just under 30% of GDP later in the forecast period. This level will be low by regional and global standards. Peru will retain good access to financing from domestic and international mark-ets and, should external conditions deteriorate sharply (not our baseline scenario), the country would be able to access multilateral funding with relative ease.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
Given sluggish economic activity and ebbing core inflation, the Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (BCRP, the central bank) has continued with monetary easing. On November 9th the BCRP cut its policy rate for the fourth time in 2017, to 3.25%. We expect the BCRP to lift the rate by 50 basis points in 2018, as invest-ment in infrastructure is expected to boost economic recovery. The bank will maintain a hawkish position in 2019 as the Federal Reserve continues its tightening cycle, so as to minimise capital flight from Peru. A loosening of monetary policy in the US in 2020 will provide breathing space for the BCRP to implement more expansionary policy to support economic growth. In 2021-22 the economy will be on an upswing, leading to a renewed tightening cycle.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
We expect Peru's economy to pick up in the forecast period, but the annual average GDP growth rate of 3.8% in 2018-22 will be much lower than during the com-modities boom. This partly reflects the dampening effects of forecast slow-downs in China in 2018 and the US in 2020. Growth rates will be moderate and fairly balanced, with private consumption contributing the most, followed by investment.
Growth came in at 2.5% year on year in Q3 2017. This relatively poor perform-ance partially reflects the detrimental impacts of floods earlier in the year. Although we expect a slight pick-up in the remainder of 2017-produc-ing overall GDP growth of 2.7% this year-activity will remain fairly disappointing. Some factors holding back growth will persist in the forecast period as the government struggles to implement infrastructure plans amid transparency issues, congress-sional opposition, and ineffective and cumbersome regulatory procedures that hinder public expenditure and project implement-ation. These problems have been exemplified by two projects: the Gasoducto del Sur, a gas pipeline scheme that reverted to the state after financing fell through owing to corruption investigations, and a project to build the new Chinchero International Airport near Cusco, controversy over which led to the ousting of two ministers and the scrapping of the entire project. Notwith-standing these obstacles, we expect the pace of public investment to accelerate in the forecast period.
Peru's economy will remain dominated by the mining sector, but the main productivity gains will come from the agro-industrial sector, which has grown quickly in recent years. Manufacturing will continue to face constraints related to external competition, fluctuations in global demand competition and a lack of skilled labour. All of this will discourage investment in the sector, leaving foreign investment mainly focused on the mining sector. Services growth will be supported by expansion in retail, finance, tourism and transport. The continued expansion of an emerging middle class will boost the services sector.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Annual inflation, which spiked earlier this year owing to supply shortages caused by extreme weather, fell dramatically in October (to 2%, down from 2.9% in September), following the normalisation of food supplies. Consequently, we have revised our year-end inflation estimate to 1.4%, down from 2.4% previously. Modest demand pressures will help the BCRP to keep inflation within its 1-3% target band in 2018-22, although higher international energy costs and moderate currency weakening will counter this to some extent. There are several risks to this forecast, including sporadic bouts of adverse weather, which could drive up food prices, as well as an unexpected bout of currency depreciation, which would lead to higher import costs.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
For most of 2017 the sol has been stable at around S3.26:US$1, but we expect a slight depreciation toward the end of the year, bringing the rate to S3.3:US$1. We expect real exchange-rate depreciation to be modest in 2018-22, averaging 0.9% per year. Debt and investment inflows will provide support for the sol. We expect the BCRP to continue to intervene in currency markets to smooth volatility while accumulating reserves. The BCRP will continue to support the ongoing process of de-dollarisation and protection of the financial sector, which is moderately exposed to currency risk. The balance of risks is tilted towards greater sol weakening. However, the risk of sharper than expected depreciation is mitigated by confidence in the monetary policy framework, strong reserves and steady long-term capital inflows.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
The trade surplus is estimated at US$4.1bn for 2017 (1.9% of estimated GDP), owing to strong external demand in conjunction with a recovery in prices of Peru's key commodities exports. However, as terms of trade deteriorate slightly and import growth remains robust, the trade surplus will fall to an average of US$3.7bn in 2018-22 (1.5% of GDP). We expect the primary income deficit to remain below the level seen in previous years, at an average of 4.3% of GDP in 2018-22. The secondary income (transfers) surplus will average 1.7% of GDP, owing to high levels of remittances. As a result, the current-account deficit will remain mostly stable, averaging 1.5% of GDP in 2018-22. Peru's current-account deficit will be financed by inward foreign direct investment (FDI) flows, which we expect to reach US$5.8bn (2.7% of GDP) in full-year 2017. We expect inflows to average 2.4% of GDP in a more challenging international environment in 2018-19, before recovering slightly in 2021-22, to 2.8% of GDP. FDI will not reach the levels seen in 2010-12, when inflows averaged 5.5% of GDP.
Foreign reserves stood at US$63.3bn on November 22nd, equivalent to 16 months of import cover. We expect reserves to grow slightly in nominal terms in the forecast period and, although import cover will ease to 12.1 months by 2022, this will offer adequate protection against external shocks.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCRP: Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics

World Commodity Forecasts Food Feedstuffs and Beverages December 2017

https://www.proquest.com/reports/world-commodity-forecasts-food-feedstuffs/docview/1972340036/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: Stocks are forecast to exceed 2.2m tonnes at the end of the 2018/19 season, which is very high by historical comparison. [...]there is potential for stocks to rise even more strongly; Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana have started discussions about how to bolster global market prices, and are considering stockpiling part of their output. Amid consumer pressure on the food processing industry to reduce sugar and, in some markets, the introduction of "sin taxes" on sugary products, a gradual shift towards synthetic sweeteners will somewhat lessen demand for sugar. [...]owing to the growing supply of starch-based sweeteners in both Asia (where Chinese production is expanding rapidly) and Europe (whose market was liberalised in September 2017), these cheaper alternatives will further limit demand for sugar in the food and drinks industry. Nonetheless, demand will remain strong compared with many other markets, helping to underpin continued firm global tea consumption growth. [...]this forecast is relatively cautious, with the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) projecting average annual Chinese demand growth of 15% until 2024, suggesting an upside risk to our forecasts. Given that tea is regarded as a traditional drink, it will suffer from mounting com-petition from coffee and soft-drink retailers, owing to a growing preference for these beverages among younger Chinese consumers. [...]younger segments of the population are also showing a preference for black tea over green tea (black tea consumption has risen by an average of 40% per year since 2002, while green tea consumption has risen more gradually), which should bolster demand for black tea, albeit from a low base.

Full text: Economist Intelligence Unit commodity price index: food, feedstuffs and beverages

Note. WCF (World commodity forecasts) is an index of 22 hard and soft commodities. FFB (Food, feedstuffs and beverages) is a price index of 13 soft commodities. The beverages sector has a weight of 20% in the FFB index, grains 46.4%, oilseeds 28.6% and sugar 4.9%. The FFB index has a weight of 55.6% in the WCF index.
Agricultural prices will remain weak in early 2018, sinking the annual average
The Economist Intelligence Unit's food, feedstuffs and beverages (FFB) price index is set to fall in year-on-year terms in 2018-the seventh consecutive year of decline-by 0.7%. This is a smaller margin than the estimated drop in prices in 2017, of 1.1%, as the markets for some agricultural goods, including oilseeds and grains such as wheat, maize and rice are beginning to tighten slightly. Nonetheless, most agricultural markets remain comfortably supplied, following several years of bumper harvests. Several crops have registered record harvests in 2016/17, including wheat and soybeans, and large carryover stocks will limit the potential for price growth in 2018. Although there is a risk that a La Niña weather event will have a negative effect on crop yields in the 2017/18 season, therefore pushing up prices, this remains unlikely at the moment, and we have not included an agricultural price shock in our forecast. We expect the FFB index to begin to firm from late 2018, rising by an average of 2.6% in 2019, as a number of markets tighten further, causing prices for a number of goods, including coffee, cocoa and wheat, to recover from rock bottom. Overall, we expect rising populations and incomes to continue to support modest growth in demand (and therefore prices) of FFB goods in the medium and long term.
There will be only a mild recovery in prices in 2019
Nonetheless, the road ahead will be bumpy. Agricultural markets have been well supplied for several consecutive seasons, providing ample stocks to draw upon. We expect global GDP growth to remain fairly robust, at an average of 2.8% per year in 2018-19, down only slightly from estimated growth of 2.9% in 2017. However, the looming economic slowdown in China and uncertainty about global monetary policy continue to pose downside risks to demand. In addition, exchange-rate trends may help to keep a lid on global commodity prices. We expect the US dollar (in which most raw materials are traded) to remain fairly strong against most emerging-market currencies in 2018-19, and this will weigh on import demand in many emerging markets and encourage exporters to increase output, further inflating global supplies. As a result, even though prices will begin to recover in 2019, we expect the FFB index to remain well below 2014 levels, on the back of ample global supply.
Grain prices will post small rises, failing to recover to 2015 levels in 2018-19
We now expect grain prices to weaken on average in 2018, by a modest 0.4%, as wheat and maize prices remain weak by historical comparison. Nonetheless, the price declines in 2018 will be modest relative to those of 2014-16, when supply surged and global stocks accumulated. For wheat in particular, international prices appear to have found a floor after two years of sharp decline. Average world wheat prices surged in mid-2017, as drought in the northern US Plains region and dryness in parts of the EU, Australia and the Black Sea region raised concerns over tighter global supply. However, the damage to crops was less serious than initially expected, and we forecast prices to ease gradually throughout 2018 as the rapid growth in 2017 proves difficult to replicate, before rising again in 2019. Maize prices will remain weak through the third quarter of 2017, undermined by the bumper 2016/17 crop, before inching up steadily over the course of 2018-19 as global consumption rises-particularly for animal feed-and the market tightens.
Oilseed prices will rise in 2018-19 as oversupplied markets begin to tighten
Oilseed prices fell by an estimated 2.1% in 2017, owing largely to the bumper soybean crop in major producers, such as the US and Brazil. Despite strong global demand, this has driven global soybean stocks higher. However, we expect the price of soybeans, as well as sunflowerseed oil and rapeseed oil, to see fairly strong growth in 2018-19 as market supply begins to tighten and global demand continues to expand. Only palm oil prices are likely to drop throughout 2018-19 as global production surges, but changing consumer habits-particularly in developed economies, where health concerns have shifted consumer tastes to alternative products-will result in lower demand growth.
A forecast recovery in coffee prices in 2019 will lift the beverages sub-index
We forecast the beverages sub-index, which includes coffee and cocoa, to fall again in 2018, for the sixth consecutive year. We forecast cocoa prices to decline slightly in 2018-19, by an average of 3% per year; nonetheless, this follows a massive drop, of nearly 30%, in 2017, as a result of soaring global production and fairly weak demand growth. Global coffee prices are also expected to dip in 2018, as the relatively strong US dollar encourages exporters to sell their stocks, bringing new supplies onto the market. In 2019, however, we expect prices of higher-value arabica coffee beans to grow more quickly, by 9%, as several consecutive years of market deficits finally begin to erode global supplies.
Sugar prices will recover in 2018-19, but by a marginal amount
Sugar prices declined by an estimated 11% in 2017 as the market corrected after a price spike in late 2016 that was related to fears that supply from Thailand would be heavily affected by poor weather conditions. We expect global consumption to expand by a modest 1.3% per year on average in 2018-19 as high domestic prices limit demand in India, the second-largest global consumer. Recent weakness in global oil prices will also play a role as cheaper energy products incentivise farmers to divert more cane to sugar (rather than to its rival, ethanol), further increasing sugar supply and limiting price growth throughout the forecast period.

Cocoa
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that, after having contracted for two consecutive crop years, cocoa consumption grew by a marginal 0.4% in the 2016/17 season (October-September. Although cocoa demand is expected to accelerate slightly during the forecast period, by an average of 1.1% per year in 2017/18-2018/19, it remains fairly weak by historical comparison. Recent cocoa grind data point to a somewhat stronger third quarter of 2017 in Europe, in line with our current projections for a gradual pick-up in demand, but none of the main developed markets will be in a position to fuel rapid growth in cocoa consumption, reflecting high existing cocoa consumption levels per head. In contrast to some other soft commodity markets, where producing countries are starting to become major consumers, cocoa consumption levels among producers are (and will remain) extremely low, hampering the scope for firmer global growth in cocoa consumption. Meanwhile, recent falls in cocoa prices will be slow to feed through to retail prices, which will continue to push some consumers towards non-chocolate confectionery. The average size of many chocolate bars has shrunk-partly in response to consumer concerns about obesity, but also to protect profits during a time of high cocoa prices. Assuming that bar sizes do not increase, this will also hamper cocoa consumption growth.
Balancing demand between cocoa powder and butter will be challenging
Asian countries will see slightly faster growth in cocoa demand than the global average, as these markets are far less saturated and GDP growth will remain higher than in much of the OECD-even bearing in mind the repercussions of a gradual slowdown in China in 2018. Stronger demand in Asia will have implications for global demand for cocoa butter (used in richer products, such as chocolate confectionery) and cocoa powder (used to add chocolate flavour to products such as biscuits, cakes and drinks). The demand balance between cocoa powder and butter is both delicate and cyclical: manufacturers stepped up grinding in the previous decade in response to a rapid increase in demand for powder, only to be faced with a significant surplus since 2011. This subsequently caused shortages of butter. We expect demand for cocoa butter to remain strong in the short term, but it will not outstrip demand for powder indefinitely. Given that Asia accounts for 26% of the world's imports of cocoa powder, compared with just 13% of global imports of cocoa butter, firmer consumption growth in that market is likely to boost demand for powder.
Higher prices will slow consumption growth in developed markets
Consumers in the US (the largest cocoa-consuming country, which accounts for 20% of global demand) and Europe (which collectively accounts for 40% of global demand) are showing an increasing preference for premium chocolate (with a higher cocoa content), but with less frequent purchases. Recent sales figures from the main chocolate manufacturers indicate that, on balance, this is pushing down overall consumption. This is illustrated by data from 2015/16, which show that cocoa demand contracted in several large markets (including the US and Canada) and grew only marginally in others (including in Europe), despite fairly strong underlying economic conditions in many of these areas.
We forecast modest but positive growth in demand for cocoa in developed markets in 2017/18-2018/19. Health concerns and changing retail habits will constrain demand (the rise of internet grocery shopping will erode spur-of-the-moment in-store chocolate purchases), as will market saturation. Europe's three largest buyers (Germany, France and the UK) have among the highest cocoa consumption rates per head in the world, at 3.5-4.5 kg annually. However, rising demand for dark chocolate-which has a higher cocoa content than milk chocolate and is perceived to be healthier-will support overall consumption.
Russian and Brazilian cocoa consumption will begin to recover
Lower cocoa consumption in 2015/16 in Brazil and Russia, which together account for nearly 10% of global demand, demonstrate the extent to which cocoa demand is affected by underlying economic conditions, particularly in developing economies, where chocolate is not regarded as a basic good. We estimate that both of these countries saw consumption contract further in 2016/17-despite a return to modest GDP growth in both countries in 2017-reflecting the high cost of cocoa in local-currency terms. For Russia, restrictions on a number of imports from the EU that have been in place since mid-2014 are having an adverse effect on demand for many consumer goods. We expect cocoa demand in Russia to stage a gradual recovery in 2017/18 and 2018/19, growing by an average 1.4% per year. Similarly, we forecast Brazil's cocoa consumption to return to growth in 2017/18-2018/19, averaging 1.5% per year, assuming that the economy continues to recover from its two-year recession.
Cocoa consumption growth will slow in Asia
China and India have huge potential for further expansion in cocoa demand, given currently low per-head consumption levels (at just 37 g in India and 59 g in China in 2015/16, compared with 2-6 kg in developed markets). However, demand will be hampered by high retail prices and, in China, consumer caution, particularly in 2018-19. Although Chinese demand will continue to rise, we expect the pace of growth to slow from 5% in 2017/18 to 3.5% in 2018/19. In India, we expect demand growth to accelerate from 3.4% in 2017/18 to 4.2% in 2018/19, owing to firmer underlying economic conditions.

Supply
Recent data show that global cocoa production surged by an estimated 15.3% in 2016/17 (11.9% previously) on the back of improved weather conditions, after a particularly difficult El Niño event and a severe harmattan season (a dry winter wind blowing from the Sahara) cut cocoa output in many of Africa's main producers in 2015/16. We expect global cocoa production to fall during 2017/18 and 2018/19, by 6.6% and 1.2% respectively, mainly reflecting a projected drop in production in Côte d'Ivoire-the world's largest cocoa producer. Its output will remain high by historical comparison, but another bumper crop is unlikely, reflecting lower farmgate prices and weaker confidence among growers. Overall, recent price weakness is likely to dissuade farmers from investing in fertiliser and pesticide, raising the incidence of crop disease and contributing to the broader decline in global cocoa production.
Structural and geographic factors will hamper long-term supply
Longer-term structural problems will also constrain supply. Not only have farmgate prices in several large producing countries begun to fall in line with lower market prices for cocoa, but farmers also receive a much smaller share of the final retail price than has been the case in previous decades, owing to higher costs further down the supply chain. Many farmers in West Africa remain below the poverty line, and as a consequence few young people in the region are choosing to work in the cocoa sector, instead opting for more profitable crops or moving to cities in search of non-agricultural work. Governments are trying to lift farmers' incomes to encourage people to work in the cocoa sector, but it is uncertain how effective these methods will be in the long term, particularly given recent falls in global prices and weak public finances.
Geographical considerations will also hamper the diversification of production. Cocoa can be grown only in certain regions (three-quarters of world production comes from regions that are located within eight degrees of the equator) and in warm, humid conditions. Cocoa production is therefore likely to remain concentrated among a small group of countries, limiting the scope for strong and sustained output growth. Nonetheless, there are countries that have significant potential to expand production, mainly in Latin America, where high-quality cocoa is produced. The expansion of manufacturing facilities to grind beans in producing countries may also encourage new investment to lift output.
Côte d'Ivoire's production has soared in 2016/17
In Côte d'Ivoire, cocoa production jumped by nearly 30% in 2016/17, to a record of just over 2m tonnes as the sector recovered from the impact of dry weather associated with El Niño in 2015/16, when output fell sharply. However, this upward trend is not expected to continue, and we forecast that cocoa production will fall by 11.2% in 2017/18 and by 2.2% in 2018/19. The authorities are unlikely to be able to replicate the exceptionally high level of output registered in 2016/17, with the state-run cocoa authority, the Conseil du Café-Cacao (CCC), issuing fewer export licences than ahead of the 2016/17 season and projecting production in 2017/18 in the range of 1.725m-1.75m tonnes. Although our production forecast is fairly strong by historical comparison, we expect output to fall steadily in the forecast period. Policy will not be particularly supportive: following a sharp cut to farmgate prices ahead of the mid-crop in March 2017, the CCC has kept prices on hold for the 2017/18 harvest, with price levels around one-third lower than a year ago. This has discouraged use of fertiliser and pesticide, with crop disease rising as a result. The government had hoped to raise farmgate prices, but any increase in the producer price would mean cutting export duties and therefore forgoing fiscal revenue, which is unlikely. A stabilisation fund is supposed to protect farmers' revenue from global price volatility, but these funds have seemingly been insufficient to shield farmers' incomes and-given the lack of transparency over the financial reserves held by the CCC-neither farmers nor exporters have confidence that losses arising from low global prices will be recouped.
Ghanaian government will struggle to boost cocoa production significantly
Similar production trends will be evident in Ghana. Cocoa production rebounded firmly in 2016/17, with favourable weather and a mild harmattan season lifting cocoa production to an estimated 925,000 tonnes (well above the official target of 800,000 tonnes). However, we do not expect further significant and sustained growth in production during 2017/18-2018/19. For now, Ghana's cocoa board (Cocobod) has been more reluctant than the Ivorian authorities to cut prices paid to farmers, but Cocobod has been forced to seek a bridging loan from the central bank, indicating that farmgate prices may need to be cut, particularly if global cocoa prices fail to recover. Combined with anxiety among farmers about the government's intentions to evolve agriculture towards other crops, ongoing encroachment by gold miners and the government's decision to stop providing free fertiliser, production is forecast to fall by 10.3% in 2017/18, before staging a partial (but weak) recovery in 2018/19, of just 3.6%.
In the longer term, the New Patriotic Party government plans to rehabilitate cocoa farms, cutting down trees that are over 30 years old and replanting them, while providing financial compensation to farmers until the trees start yielding fruit (generally three to five years). The authorities ultimately aim to raise production to 1.5m tonnes within four years, also driven by better soil management, and better pest and disease control. These plans are positive, since Ghana has a large share of unproductive trees (Cocobod estimates 40%) and a consequent low average yield per hectare (at 400 kg/ha, compared with 600 kg/ha in Côte d'Ivoire and 1 tonne/ha in Indonesia). Replanting, in particular, will help to address the problem of swollen shoot disease, which affects nearly one-fifth of cocoa trees and is associated with low yields. However, we think it unlikely that these ambitious plans will reach fruition, since the weak macroeconomic backdrop is likely to hamper public investment.
Cameroon's and Nigeria's production targets will prove overambitious
After falling for the second consecutive crop year in 2016/17, cocoa production in Cameroon will remain weak during 2017/18-2018/19. Cuts in farmgate prices will be a disincentive to farmers, meaning that the government will remain significantly off track from its 2020 production target of 600,000 tonnes-a level that even the national Cocoa Development Corporation has described as "unrealistic and unattainable". The fact that plans to increase the harvested area by 100,000 ha each year have failed to materialise, with the area under cocoa cultivation rising by only around 3,000 ha since 2014, will severely hamper the expansion of the cocoa sector.
Cocoa production in Nigeria has slumped in recent years, and the country has slipped from being the world's fourth-largest producer to the sixth-largest (on a par with Brazil). Government initiatives designed to support farmers have not proved successful, with efforts to introduce high-yielding cocoa and increase the distribution of free seedlings floundering. With the country's mining and energy sector suffering from still-low inter-national oil prices, there is official acknowledgement that investment in raising cocoa production could generate greater foreign-exchange earnings, and the Ministry of Agriculture has recently outlined its ambitious goal of boosting cocoa production above the levels recorded in Côte d'Ivoire. Its short-term goal is to lift cocoa production to 300,000-320,000 tonnes in 2017/18, with the medium-term target of raising output to 1m tonnes/year. However, problems with weak infrastructure, corruption, poor (and expensive) access to financing and weak implementation capacity will hamper these efforts.
Prospects are weak for Indonesia's cocoa sector
The authorities in Indonesia have ambitious plans to triple cocoa output by 2020, from 325,000 tonnes in 2014/15, but these are highly unlikely to materialise. Adverse weather, widely attributed to El Niño, hampered both the 2015/16 and the 2016/17 harvest, with cocoa output registering its third consecutive annual decline. On the assumption of more stable weather conditions, output should resume growth in 2017/18 and 2018/19, but at a forecast 320,000 tonnes at the end of the forecast period, cocoa output will remain weak by historical comparison. Indonesian firms are likely to rely increasingly on imported processed cocoa from neighbouring Malaysia to meet domestic demand.
Strong potential for growth in Latin America will not be realised in 2018-19
Agriculture in Latin America's two largest cocoa producers, Brazil and Ecuador, was affected by El Niño; in Brazil the main cocoa-producing regions reported drought conditions, and in Ecuador El Niño arrived late but continued for longer than usual. However, with better weather conditions, output is estimated to have recovered firmly in both countries in 2016/17. Structurally, there is scope for both countries to lift cocoa output as manufacturers look to boost investment in the region in an attempt to diversify production away from West Africa. The region's reputation for producing high-quality cocoa will help in this respect, given rising global demand for premium chocolate. However, some of this investment will be slow to materialise, as global prices remain depressed amid excess supply, which will act as a brake on growth potential.

Stocks and prices
We expect the global cocoa market to remain in surplus during the forecast period, but for the surplus to narrow gradually from an estimated 536,000 tonnes in 2016/17 to 98,000 tonnes by 2018/19. Although production is forecast to fall steadily, the fact that it will do so from such a high base (output was exceptionally strong in 2016/17) means that cocoa production will remain higher than consumption by some margin. Tepid demand growth makes a return to a market deficit unlikely during the forecast period. Stocks are forecast to exceed 2.2m tonnes at the end of the 2018/19 season, which is very high by historical comparison. Moreover, there is potential for stocks to rise even more strongly; Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana have started discussions about how to bolster global market prices, and are considering stockpiling part of their output.

Supply concerns will support prices, despite subdued demand growth
After remaining high for much of 2014-16, at around US$3,000/tonne, cocoa prices plummeted between December 2016 and late April 2017, to less than US$1,900/tonne. Although prices have recovered somewhat, they averaged less than US$2,000/tonne each month from May-September, only increasing to around US$2,100/tonne in October on the back of weaker production prospects in Côte d'Ivoire. Although global production prospects will remain weak in the near term, we see little likelihood of a sustained recovery in average prices, owing to the global supply glut. We forecast prices to fall by 2.9% in 2018, to an average of US$1,975/tonne, and by a further 1% in 2019, to US$1,955/tonne.
