Coffee
Demand
Global coffee consumption expanded by around 2.7% in both 2015/16 and 2016/17, largely boosted by rising consumption in coffee-importing countries (mainly developed economies) that account for two-thirds of global demand. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the pace of consumption growth to accelerate to 3.1% in 2017/18, aided by stronger underlying economic conditions in many of the large consuming markets, before slipping to 2% in 2018/19. Notwithstanding ongoing monetary policy tightening in some of the large coffee consumers, overall domestic demand is expected to remain firm, supporting coffee consumption. In coffee-producing countries (many of which are emerging markets), consumption growth will continue to average 2.4% per year, held back somewhat by tepid demand growth in Brazil (which currently accounts for around 40% of exporting countries' consumption, owing to the sheer size of its domestic market). Consumption growth will be strongest in Asia-notably China. Although we expect China's GDP growth rate to slow from 2018, the deceleration will be concentrated in the investment and industrial sectors, and we expect average income levels to continue to rise steadily, meaning that there is little risk of a fall in coffee demand growth. However, coffee consumption levels are low in China, so even as domestic coffee demand rises quickly, this will contribute only modestly to global consumption growth.
Coffee habits are shifting around the world
Consumption trends will change in both the home and out-of-home sectors. In the latter, the expansion of coffee-shop chains will continue, providing a boost to demand, particularly in North America and Europe, but store formats will evolve. Increasing demand for "on the go" beverages will result in larger numbers of smaller shops, including within petrol stations and supermarkets. In some markets-including the US and China-the large coffee chains are increasingly moving towards prepayment through smartphone apps, allowing customers to pick up their purchases without having to queue. These technological developments are likely to help the out-of-home sector to defend its market share at a time when a large number of consumers have single-serve coffee-capsule machines at home. This will be accompanied by heavy marketing of other coffee beverages, including iced coffee and cold brew. Although comprising a small market share of the out-of-home segment, sales of these products are likely to grow rapidly.
Single-serve coffee will help to drive growth in developed markets
Demand for coffee at home that rivals the quality of beverages found in cafes will result in a shift away from the consumption of instant coffee. On a global level, coffee pod sales are approaching the total combined value of instant and ground coffee, although the higher cost of pods means that, in volume terms, the instant and ground coffee market remains larger. Although sales of machines and capsules are slowing sharply after initial firm growth, the coffee pod market will continue to provide important support for overall global coffee demand. Given that most pods contain either exclusively arabica beans or a high proportion of arabica with a small quantity of robusta, this will lift demand for arabica.
Coffee consumption growth in North America will increase steadily
US coffee consumption growth is forecast to average 1.6% a year in 2017/18-2018/19, building on faster than expected demand growth of 6.6% in 2016/17 (compared with our previous estimate of 2.8%). Recent data from the US National Coffee Association show that the percentage of people drinking coffee is rising rapidly (up from 57% in early 2016 to 62% in early 2017). Daily consumption is rising and consumers are increasingly attracted to a variety of products (US consumption of cold coffee products has risen by 75% over the past two years). There are indications that long-term consumption growth may continue to rise, with the number of coffee shops increasing at around 3.6% per year and the share of 13-18-year-olds drinking coffee rising from 23% in 2014 to 37% in early 2017, and demand growth among 18-24-year-olds also rising strongly.
Similar dynamics are evident in Canada, with the share of 18-24-year-olds drinking coffee jumping from 48% in 2015 to 58% in 2016 (up from just 32% in 2009). Younger consumers show a much stronger preference for speciality coffees and for drinking coffee in out-of-home locations than other age brackets. We expect coffee consumption growth, which has been fairly steady at around 2.5% in recent years, to pick up slightly, to an average of 2.7%, in 2017/18-2018/19.
Coffee consumption in Brazil is expected to falter
Brazil is the world's second-largest coffee consumer, but consumption levels per head are still modest (at around one-third of those in most European countries), so there is scope for a significant increase in demand. However, a sharp economic recession has hampered coffee consumption growth, which after firm growth in 2005-15 has flatlined in recent years. We expect coffee consumption to begin to grow more firmly during the forecast period, at an average pace of 1.3% per year in 2017/18-2018/19. Although underlying economic growth is expected to pick up, household consumption will remain constrained by high unemployment, rising fuel prices and higher inflation, which will all drag on disposable income.
Fairly firm coffee consumption growth is expected in Japan and South Korea
Japan is the largest coffee market in Asia (and the fourth-largest in the world), with coffee boasting around the same share of the beverages market as tea. After rising by 3.1% in 2016/17, we expect coffee consumption growth to rise by an average of 2.3% per year in 2017/18-2018/19. The slower pace of growth will reflect somewhat less supportive underlying economic conditions, after a stellar pace of economic growth in 2017. Nonetheless, annual growth in coffee con-sumption of 2.3% is fairly firm, given the size of the market, and will be under-pinned by coffee sales in convenience stores, as the number of coffee shops is falling. In South Korea the coffee market has expanded rapidly in recent years, with coffee imports more than trebling between 2006 and 2016 and the number of coffee shops increasing even more rapidly. Although we forecast somewhat weaker growth in coffee consumption in 2017/18-2018/19, the pace of growth will remain firm by global standards, at an annual average of 3.1%.
Coffee consumption in China and India-currently both small consumers-will continue to grow. Much of the growth in Chinese coffee consumption will be in the out-of-home sector, reflecting the rising popularity of a coffee-shop culture in urban centres. A significant share of the new stores opened by Starbucks in 2016-17 are in Asia. The company now runs 3,000 outlets in 135 Chinese cities (nearly 600 in Shanghai alone, Starbucks' largest presence in a single city), up from 2,300 last October, and is planning to have 5,000 stores open by 2021. We expect an economic slowdown in China in 2018, but the deceleration will be gradual and will largely be concentrated in the construction and industrial sectors. Given that we expect average income levels to continue to rise steadily, there is little risk of a fall in coffee demand growth during 2017/18-2018/19.
Following a recent rapid expansion of the out-of-home sector in India, driven by comparatively low consumer price inflation, rising disposable income and favourable demographics (around one-half of the population is aged under 25), coffee consumption remained flat in 2016/17. We expect a return to growth in 2017/18-2018/19, with coffee consumption rising by an average of 3.3% per year. South-east Asia also has relatively low levels of coffee consumption per head, but demand is increasing rapidly in certain countries (mainly coffee-producing economies such as Indonesia and Vietnam), and rising incomes are encouraging companies such as Starbucks to expand in Indonesia and the Philippines, where consumption is increasing. Costa Coffee is expanding in Thailand, Singapore and Cambodia, and recently opened its first store in Vietnam.
Asian markets will drive demand for robusta beans
Given taste preferences for soluble and instant coffee (which generally use the robusta variety) in faster-growing Asian markets, demand will be stronger for robusta beans than for the more expensive arabica blends. Improved quality of robusta will also play a part here, with such beans slowly losing their reputation for inferior taste. In addition, improvements in processing technology mean that it is possible to use a larger proportion of robusta in coffee blends while maintaining quality.

Supply
Final data from the 2016/17 crop year (October-September) were much more positive than earlier market expecations, with coffee production rising by 3.4% (compared with our previous estimate of a 0.8% decline). Although adverse weather related to the El Niño weather phenomenon undermined the development of beans in Asia, output in Brazil-the world's largest producer-rose firmly. Coffee production is forecast to fall by 1% in 2017/18 as production in Brazil declines as the biennial crop alternates between higher- and lower-producing years (2017/18 is an "off-season" crop year). This will be only partly offset by firmer output growth in most other producing countries. Global coffee production growth is expected to be much stronger in 2018/19, at 3.8%, as Brazil's crop shifts to an "on-season" year.
We envisage a growing concentration of coffee production among the world's largest producers. Currently, a large number of countries (around 70) produce coffee, but the smaller producers have been struggling as a result of low world prices and rising overheads. In many of these countries, where coffee is not a particularly important area of the economy, farmers wield less power and are less likely to secure government support than in leading producers. Partly as a result, we expect coffee output in "other" countries to decline from 8.9m 60-kg bags in 2015/16 to 7.8m bags in 2018/19. Output in these countries-which fall outside the world's top 17 producers-will account for 5% of global production in 2018/19, down from nearly 15% in 2008/09.
Annual coffee production in Brazil is expected to remain well over 50m bags
In Brazil, by far the world's largest producer, final data from the on-season 2016/17 crop were more positive than expected, with coffee output rising by over 9%. This could reflect the weak local currency, which incentivised local growers, as international coffee prices are denominated in US dollars. Prospects for the off-season 2017/18 crop year are fairly strong, and as a result of the better than expected 2016/17 result, we have upgraded our 2017/18 forecast, to 52m bags (previously 50m). Although adverse weather in mid-2016-including drought in some areas and irregular rainfall in others-raised concerns that beans might be damaged ahead of the harvest, recent weather has been more supportive, and the quality and quantity of beans have been good. Moreover, the still-weak local currency is continuing to provide an incentive to growers.
The 2018/19 crop year remains some way off, with coffee bushes only just beginning to flower, so output projections remain highly speculative. Local commentators have stated that they believe that there is potential for a bumper crop in 2018/19, with some even suggesting that output of up to 60m bags is possible, which would represent a record high by some margin (to date, the highest production was recorded in 2012/13, at 55.4m bags). At the moment, we forecast coffee production to rise to 55.5m bags. Although weather conditions have been supportive in most places, some coffee-producing states have seen below-average rainfall, which is likely to hamper faster production growth.
Coffee production in Vietnam is set to recover from a severe drought
In Vietnam, the worst drought in three decades hampered production in 2016/17, with coffee output dropping by 11.3%. Assuming that weather conditions stabilise for the 2017/18 crop, there is scope for a rebound in Vietnam's coffee output; we forecast production of 27m bags, implying growth of 5.9%, followed by 3% growth (to 27.8m bags) in 2018/19. The authorities remain pessimistic about the medium-term prospects for production, forecasting coffee output to stabilise or decline slightly. However, government efforts to replant 140,000 ha of coffee, targeting 25,000 ha a year, as well as a rising arabica crop, will support firmer output, particularly given that yields from new bushes are typically high. In addition, firm demand for robusta in the domestic market and other Asian countries will encourage growers.
Output from Mexico and Central America will slip in 2017/18
A severe outbreak of coffee rust, followed by El Niño, inflicted damage on coffee plantations in Mexico and Central America, and hampered production during three successive crop years, from 2013/14 until 2015/16. However, a solid recovery in 2016/17 saw production rise by 17.5%, to 19.4m bags, mainly reflecting a jump in output in Honduras and, to a lesser extent, Mexico. Nonetheless, there are reports that coffee rust is returning to some areas in the region, which could threaten output in 2017/18. Purchases of fungicides and fertiliser will help to prop up yields, but we nevertheless forecast a fall in coffee production of 5.3% in 2017/18. Assuming that coffee rust does not spread significantly and that weather conditions stay favourable, we expect coffee output to grow by 1.6% in 2018/19.
Colombian production is set to continue to rise in the medium term
Coffee production in Colombia has risen steadily in recent years, reaching a 24-year high of 14.5m bags in 2016/17. Prospects for 2017/18 are uncertain. The structural underpinnings of the sector are strong, including a comparatively high percentage of rust-resistant bushes. In addition, efforts are being made to increase productivity, with recent additional planting in existing plantations aiming to raise average production per hectare, which at 18 bags per hectare in 2016 was much lower than in other large growers (27 bags per hectare in Brazil and 35 bags per hectare in Vietnam). However, recent cloudy weather conditions are affecting flowering on coffee bushes; if this continues, the crop yield will be hampered. For the time being, we project coffee production growth of 4.1% in 2017/18, but will monitor this closely in the coming months. In 2018/19 production should start to benefit from a 2016 peace agreement between the government and the left-wing FARC rebels, as coffee cultivation will increase in previously isolated areas of the country (the government has speculated that output could reach 20m bags by 2020 as a result). We forecast coffee production growth of 4.6% in 2018/19, to 15.8m bags.

In Indonesia coffee production is recovering, but remains weak overall
Indonesia's ambitious expansion plans for the coffee sector-which include more than doubling production within five years to make the country the world's second-largest producer after Brazil-have been completely derailed. El Niño brought excessive dry weather to the main coffee-growing areas, affecting the 2016/17 harvest, when output fell by 6.7%. However, exports have recently begun to recover owing to more supportive weather conditions, providing momentum heading into the 2017/18 season, when we expect production to rise by 4.4%. We expect production to grow by a further 2.5% in 2018/19, but at just 12.3m bags, output will remain low by historical comparison.
Stocks and prices
Following the revision to the 2016/17 coffee production data, we expect the global market deficit to narrow to 2.6m bags, down from our previous estimate of 6.3m bags. Nonetheless, this does materially alter the outlook for falling global coffee stocks in 2017/18-2018/19, as the market remains in deficit and as producers continue to sell some of their old stocks in order to take advantage of the relatively weak local currencies against the US dollar. Even assuming some continued sales of stocks, the market deficit is forecast to remain large throughout the forecast period. By end-2018/19 we expect global stocks to have fallen to 23m bags, from 31.6m bags in September 2016, which will support a partial recovery in prices.

After slumping again in 2017, arabica prices are set to rise in 2018
Arabica prices have fallen steadily during 2017, from an average of US$1.69/lb in January to US$1.44/lb in October. Given that the global market is set to register its third consecutive annual deficit in 2016/17, the fall in prices-to levels not seen since 2013-is curious. We believe that coffee prices are increasingly driven by investment trends, with swings in sentiment often due to a spate of positive or negative news on the supply side. Coffee prices are also becoming increasingly reactive to changes in the strength of the US dollar, with dollar depreciation tending to lead to higher coffee prices. In recent weeks, speculation about bumper production in Brazil has kept prices low. The fact that several large exporting countries are continuing to sell spare stock in order to take advantage of weak local currencies is also suppressing prices, because this has been accompanied by a rise in coffee stocks in importing countries, which in turn may contain demand in the future.
We believe that speculation about the 2018/19 harvest in Brazil will continue to suppress prices; we forecast arabica prices to remain flat year on year, at an average of US$1.52/lb in 2018. This is in line with recent developments in futures markets, with coffee for December 2017 delivery trading at well below US$1.30/lb. Given the underlying fundamentals and the likelihood that the next "off-season" in Brazil (2019/20) will hit market confidence during the 2019 calendar year, we forecast a recovery of prices, to an average US$1.66/lb.
Tighter supplies of robusta beans and firm Asian demand will support prices
Prices for cheaper robusta have fallen slightly since January, but have not seen the same sell-off as arabica beans, reflecting concerns about the supply of robusta beans in the context of disappointing weather conditions in Vietnam and Indonesia. Despite a sharp slide in prices in late April, from US$1.08/lb to 95 US cents/lb in the space of a week-as hedge funds liquidated their positions on the perception that robusta prices were extremely high-prices subsequently recovered quickly, trading at an average US$1.03/lb in the third quarter, albeit slipping just below the US$1/lb mark in October. We expect prices to average US$1.01/lb in 2018 and US$1.04/lb in 2019, supported by rising Asian demand.

Maize
Demand
Maize is the most consumed (and produced) grain in the world, with total annual demand now in excess of 1bn tonnes/year (t/y). It is a versatile grain, with around 60% of the total used for animal feed, almost 30% for industrial processing (mainly fuel ethanol and starch) and the rest consumed directly as food or seed, or lost through waste. After a period of spectacular growth, demand for maize-based biofuels is now increasing more slowly, even though overall levels of consumption are still setting new records each year. However, following reports about China's plans for a massive expansion of its own fuel ethanol sector, world use for biofuels could potentially rise sharply from current levels over the medium term. Maize is the primary energy source in compound feed mixes, and with ample supplies predicted across the world, it is well placed to meet predicted gains in demand in meat-exporting countries, as well as in parts of Africa, Asia and Latin America, where consumption of animal protein continues to expand. Maize is by far the dominant feed grain in much of the world, with annual consumption typically more than four times that of wheat, the second most widely consumed feed cereal. In 2017/18 The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global demand to rise by 2% year on year to 1.03bn tonnes, with stronger uptake expected across the animal feed, industrial and food sectors. A similar trend is projected for 2018/19, with overall consumption rising by 1.7%, to 1.05bn tonnes.
World feed demand will rise by 2% in 2017/18
World demand for meat and other animal proteins shows no sign of slowing, with consumption gains driven by population growth, greater purchasing power and changes in diets and tastes. Maize is an extremely useful ingredient, which, combined with other rations, can contribute to rapid livestock weight gain. Overall use, however, depends on availabilities and price relationships with other grains-mainly wheat-as well as high-protein oilmeals. A multitude of other factors can also have a direct impact on feed demand in any particular year, with producers having to consider pasture conditions and availability, as well as desired livestock weight, the economics of the meat industry and feed efficiency ratios. In 2017/18 we expect global growth in use of maize for livestock feed to slow to around 2%, down from almost 7% in the previous season. Although firmer demand for maize in complex feed rations is anticipated in China, Brazil, Iran, Egypt, the EU and India, discretionary on-farm feeding may drop back amid smaller predicted harvests in some countries, including the US. Predictions for the 2018/19 period remain provisional and will depend on future maize availabilities and pricing relative to alternative feeds. However, with the upward trend in world meat production unlikely to falter, a further increase in maize feed demand is likely, provisionally pegged at a record 595m tonnes. Gains are again likely to be tied to expansions in Asia and Latin America, but with an expected rise in the US too.
Use for fuel ethanol is at a record high, but growth is slowing
A substantial amount of maize is processed for use in a multitude of food, beverage and industrial applications, including corn oil, starches, sweeteners and ethanol. In 2017/18 processing is forecast to account for 27% of total consumption, rising by 4m tonnes year on year, to 286m tonnes, more than four times more than two decades earlier. Consumption in the following year is provisionally placed at 3m tonnes higher, at 289m tonnes
Trade continues to increase year after year
Global maize trade in 2017/18 (July-June) is set to exceed all previous records, and is forecast to reach 148m tonnes, up by 6.5% compared with the previous season. Amid large surpluses across all of the major exporters, global prices are soft, and maize remains very competitively priced for inclusion in feed rations. A number of large buyers are expected to increase imports, with particularly strong growth likely in Mexico, the EU and Taiwan. This will easily compensate for a reduction in purchases by Brazil and South Africa, two countries that secured unusually large amounts in 2016/17 owing to severe weather difficulties. The EU is expected to displace Japan as the world's leading importer this year, with shipments pegged at a record 17m tonnes, up by more than a quarter compared with 2016/17. Purchases to date have progressed quickly in recent months, with local feed users, many of which are able to interchange between maize, wheat and barley, encouraged by current low prices. Mexico's imports are projected to rise by 1.5m tonnes, to 15.5m tonnes, also a new all-time peak, relegating Japan to third place on the league table of the world's biggest buyers. Maize is a staple food in Mexico, with white maize ground into flour and used to make tortillas. However, direct food consumption has remained flat in recent years, with consumption and import growth fuelled instead by rising demand for meat, particularly poultry. With the renegotiation of the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA) currently ongoing, US producers will be mindful of the fact that Mexico has sourced around 99% of its maize imports from across the border in the past few seasons.
China announces plans to boost ethanol production
Years of supply and demand imbalances in China have led to a massive surplus, with stocks soaring to an unprecedented level in recent years. Over-production was mainly linked to a now discontinued official stockpiling scheme, under which farmers in the largest maize provinces were able to sell unlimited amounts into state reserves at guaranteed minimum prices. At the same time, cheaper feed grain imports flooded into southern consuming regions, choking off demand for locally produced maize. Authorities are now working hard to unwind part of these burdensome stocks. Under a plan jointly announced by 15 ministries and commissions in September, the government is seeking a massive expansion of the biofuel sector, targeting the blending of 10% ethanol (E10) into all automotive petrol by 2020. As well as mopping up surplus maize, the move is seen part of broader efforts to reduce China's carbon footprint. Although China is already one of the world's largest producers of biofuels, fuel ethanol is currently used only in a few provinces and accounts for around 1% of overall fuel consumption. The new plans are far more ambitious than those proposed last year, when the government announced its aim to double ethanol production by 2020. If E10 plans are fully implemented, an additional 35-40m tonnes of maize would be required as a feedstock each year.
Processing plants are already being built
China's targets are very ambitious, and it remains to be seen whether they can be achieved in such a short window. However, some local analysts recently reported that more than ten new fuel-ethanol plants are already planned to begin operating in 2018. Depending on how much processing capacity would need to be added, the initiative would require significant investment, tax incentives and probably additional subsidies. The local government in Heilongjiang, the largest maize province, has already issued guidelines on sharply boosting production of maize-based ethanol and high-quality starches.
China's maize stocks are likely to be larger than previously thought
Calls for such a steep and sustained increase in China's maize consumption suggest that local inventories could be much larger than we had previously expected. Our supply and demand estimates for the past decade have therefore recently been revised, with forecasts for feed use across this period lowered by an average of 18m t/y, equivalent to around 10% of total annual consumption. With so much uncertainty about levels of feed demand in almost every country, such revisions are occasionally necessary when new data come to light. However, given the sheer size of its grain economy, any such changes for China can appear very large. Nevertheless, it should be stressed that the underlying trend is unchanged from before, and with so much of China's grain economy operating quite separately from the global market, these revisions do not have any wider price implications. We forecast China's overall maize demand to rise by 3.8% in 2017/18, and by a further 5.8% in 2018/19, as maize use in industrial processing begins to accelerate.

Supply
World maize supplies (production plus carryover stocks) have increased to record highs in recent seasons, topping 1bn tonnes each year since 2011/12. Encouraged by high market prices, production gains have stemmed from increases in plantings, as well as improved yields, with growers using new seed varieties, fertilisers and better farming practices to great effect. After surging by an estimated 10.7% in 2016/17, global output is projected to drop by 4.3% in 2017/18, to just over 1bn tonnes. Boosted by ample carryovers from 2016/17, global supplies are still likely to remain comfortable, especially in the major exporting countries, where traders are likely to compete hard for available business. Forecasts for 2018/19 remain highly provisional, especially in the southern hemisphere, and will be subject to revision in the coming months. Overall, we expect global output to rise by around 0.8% in that season as good underlying demand and slightly tighter stocks encourage planting in some producers.
US output will drop in 2017/18, but by a lower margin than expected
With the US harvest about 54% complete by the start of November, we have revised up our crop estimate to 362.7m tonnes (360.3m tonnes previously), although this is still 5.7% lower than the previous season's record outturn. The latest hybrids and varieties appear to be performing well, even under sub-optimal conditions. Advances in seed technology may also have been amplified by improved farming practices, including quicker seeding and more efficient use of fertilisers. There has been some recent chatter about the potential for a modest increase in sowings for the next crop, to be harvested in late 2018. Although prices nearer the time will shape final planting decisions, some growers are expected to rotate soybean area back into maize, reversing the trend seen in 2016/17. Assuming a 1% rise in planted area and trend yields, output is forecast to dip fractionally, to 361.8m tonnes.
Southern hemisphere harvests are expected to be smaller in 2017/18
Planting of 2017/18 maize crops began in September in some parts of South America, with fieldwork stretching through until February. The heavy supply outlook and current weak market prices suggest that a pullback in area is likely. Assuming a normalisation of yields, cumulative production in the three top exporters could decline by about 8%, to 156.5m tonnes. The price outlook in Brazil is especially weak, with average local prices down by more than 40% year on year. Potentially better returns from soybeans mean that more area in the south of the country is likely to be diverted to oilseeds. As safrinha (second crop) maize will not be sown until soybeans are harvested in February, prices nearer the time will determine exactly how much is sown. We expect the outturn to fall to 91m tonnes in 2017/18, a decrease of 7% year on year. Similarly, a slump in South African prices means that sown area is likely to decline later this year, especially if exporters cannot dispose of the large surplus. Based on average yields, the crop could drop by 29%, to 12.5m tonnes. The situation in Argentina is somewhat different. Producers there, still encouraged by the farm-friendly policies of the Macri administration, are expected to boost plantings, with production down by only 1m tonnes from the previous season, at 40m tonnes. The outlook for 2018/19 maize crops south of the equator is highly provisional, with sowings still 18 months away in some areas. We currently expect a modest expansion in South American crops but another static year in South African output.
Ukraine and Russia have become big players on the world market
Maize production in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) has increased massively during the past decade or so, rising from around 21.7m tonnes in 2008/09 to an estimated 42.3m tonnes in the current season. Nearly all of the growth stems from much larger harvests in Ukraine and more recently, in Russia, with the other countries still relatively small producers. Farmers in both countries have responded to strong overseas demand, switching some land from less profitable crops, including barley and other coarse grains. Growers have also been partly motivated by more limited state intervention in maize markets, compared with traditional, politically sensitive crops such as wheat. Ukraine's rich and fertile soils appear especially well-suited to growing the latest (non-GM) maize hybrids, where changes in weather patterns have also underpinned very good yields in recent years. In 2016/17 maize overtook wheat as Ukraine's biggest export crop by volume, and the country now ranks as the world's fourth-largest exporter, behind the US, Brazil and Argentina. After peaking at a record 30.9m tonnes in 2013/14, production has edged lower in subsequent years as plantings fell back slightly. The 2017/18 harvest was about 60% complete by early November, with farmers confirming disappointing results in areas affected by a summer drought. We have revised down our forecast accordingly, to 25m tonnes in 2017/18, 10.7% lower (7.1% previously) than the record 2016/17 crop, and slightly lower than the five-year average. With a strong export base expected to encourage plantings early next year, output is forecast to rebound to 27.5m tonnes in 2018/19.
Russia has traditionally been only a small producer of maize, with output dropping to a low of 3.1m tonnes in 2010/11. However, like the situation in neighbouring Ukraine, harvested area has nearly tripled over this period, to a new peak of 2.9m ha in the current season. Most farmers use imported, high-yielding hybrid seeds, which have proven particularly well suited to the country's mid-continental, northern latitude climate. Owing to disappointing yields, production in 2017/18 is expected to dip to 14m tonnes, down by 8% from last season's record but still 18% above the recent average. This will limit this season's exportable surplus to around 4.2m tonnes, still enough to retain the country's position as the world's fifth-largest exporter.

Stocks and prices
We recently raised our estimate of global maize stocks substantially, to 324m tonnes in 2017/18 (206m tonnes previously), following a detailed reassessment of China's maize supply and demand numbers over the past decade. Maize production in China is trending lower, and with consumption expected to rise strongly in the years ahead, it has become clear that our previous forecast was too conservative and would have resulted in the depletion of China's stocks in just a few years. With feed use adjusted lower from 2011/12 onwards, projections for China's stocks were lifted across the whole period and are now forecast at 201m tonnes at the end of 2017/18, a figure much closer to that circulating in the local press. We now expect China to account for 62% of total world stocks (40% previously). Yet with so much uncertainty about the size, location and quality of its stocks, many analysts prefer to exclude China when modelling world inventories. Combined stocks in the four main maize exporters (Argentina, Brazil, Ukraine and the US) are forecast to remain above the recent average in 2017/18, at a total of 73.9m tonnes, up by 0.7% year on year, with more than three-quarters of these (59.5m tonnes) concentrated in the US. A relatively sharp drop is predicted in 2018/19, to 307m tonnes. Although exporter stocks will also tighten further, overall market supplies will remain at comfortable levels.

China's stock estimate is revised sharply higher
China's grain stocks have long been considered a state secret, with all parts of the grain balance sheet quite notional and based on limited information. Sometimes the assumptions are proven to be incorrect, as highlighted by new information or a change in underlying market conditions. The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) and other agencies last made major revisions to their own Chinese estimates in 2001, when the cumulative forecast for wheat, maize and rice stocks was more than tripled as it became apparent that inventories were much larger than previously assumed owing to years of feed use being overestimated. Although our revised stock forecast diverges from those of the USDA and other major forecasting bodies, it brings stocks in China much closer to the levels that have been widely reported in the local press in recent years, including figures quoted by key policy advisers and other Communist Party officials. However, the fact remains that these supplies are held primarily as a food security measure and will never be made available on the world market. Indeed, with China being only a small importer, its domestic stock levels are unlikely to have a major impact on global prices. Moreover, the underlying trend for Chinese maize stocks remains unchanged, with stocks having built up since 2007/08 before tightening in recent seasons. We expect stocks to be drawn down further in 2018-19 as the government seeks to boost domestic consumption, particularly in the biofuels industry.
Prices are unlikely to show any significant growth in 2018-19
World maize prices have eased slightly in recent months, averaging more than 11% lower year on year in early November. Although US export prices were initially pulled higher by concerns about worse than normal Midwest crop conditions, early summer gains have eroded as participants shed speculative long positions on signs that final yields would outperform earlier expectations. Light seasonal harvest pressure has also weighed on markets recently as newly harvested supplies added to bountiful US stockpiles. Barring a late-season severe frost, the US crop is widely expected to be one of the biggest on record, and supplies look set to remain ample throughout the next season. Export prices in South America remained weak, hovering close to an eight-year low in Argentina as traders worked hard to secure sales. However, with large customers well aware of the possibility of further price weakness, many have been reluctant to extend coverage. Despite some chatter about a potential La Niña weather shock in South America over the next six months, maize market fundamentals currently point to a low price environment. We expect prices to rise slightly from the fourth quarter of 2017; however, given ample global stocks and easy feedgrain availabilities, prices are likely to stay well below recent peaks in 2018-19.

Palm oil
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that global palm oil consumption increased by 2.2% year on year, to 63.8m tonnes. This is markedly slower than average annual demand growth in the previous five seasons, of 5.4%, owing to low palm oil stocks. We expect palm oil consumption to expand more quickly in 2017/18 and 2018/19 as global supplies become more available, although the rate of growth is likely to remain below recent averages. Both Indonesia and Malaysia are looking for growth opportunities, with the biodiesel market in China the most likely to generate demand. Overall, we forecast global consumption to expand by an average of 3.1% per year over the forecast period, reaching a total of 67.8m tonnes in 2018/19.
India will remain the largest market for palm oil
The 2016/17 season has been relatively disappointing for Indian palm oil demand. We estimate that consumption rose by 1.4% in that season, to 9.3m tonnes-well below the average annual growth of 6.6% observed over the last five seasons. Changes in duties applied to imported palm oil will weigh on consumption in 2017/18 but strong overall GDP growth in the coming seasons will help to support demand. Palm oil imports have risen steadily in the year to date; although some of this is driven by stock replenishment, we also expect consumption to rise as a result. On the assumption that palm oil prices will weaken further from their current levels, greater availability will support average annual consumption growth of 4.6% in 2017/18-2018/19.
Indonesia's biodiesel sector will post decent growth in 2016/17 and 2017/18
Prospects for palm oil demand in Indonesia appear slightly more positive than initially expected. In addition to rising food use, palm oil is likely to become increasingly competitive against mineral oil as a base for biodiesel. The recent implementation by the EU of reduced duties for Argentinian biodiesel is expected to be followed by a similar reduction for Indonesian biodiesel. This good news is partially offset by the impostition of anti-dumping duties on biodiesel by the US on Indonesia, as well as Argentina. Nonetheless, we have revised up our forecast for Indonesian palm oil consumption in 2017/18. While the projected growth rates are below the recent levels, overall consumption in 2018/19 should comfortably exceed 10m tonnes.
China's palm oil demand is hindered by competition from soybean oil
Consumption of palm oil in China during 2016/17 witnessed another year of decline, due to the higher availability of locally produced soybean oil. However, there is some hope of recovery in 2017/18, owing partly to a sustained recovery in instant noodle production, as higher quality products have rekindled consumer interest. More significantly, the planned expansion of biodiesel use, part of a broader biofuels policy, has the potential to absorb large quantities of palm oil. We remain cautious about growth in China's palm oil demand in 2017/18 and 2018/19, given recent declines. An expansion of biofuels use underpins our forecast for steady demand growth, averaging 3.7% per year over the forecast period, to reach a total of 5.4m tonnes in the 2018/19 season.
Energy demand in the EU will rise, boosting usage
The market for palm oil in the EU has been broadly flat since 2013/14, hovering around 7.2m tonnes. We expect this trend to continue in the next two seasons, but risks are on the downside. In the biodiesel sector, palm oil faces increased competition in some member states from recycled fats and oils, while sustainability concerns hang over medium-term consumption prospects. However, biodiesel consumption in the EU is expected to increase over the next two years, reflecting changes in incorporation mandates. While other feed-stocks are likely to be the main beneficiaries of this growth, palm oil consumption volumes should be maintained. Similarly, its use in the edible sector is also likely to be maintained. In the 2017/18 and 2018/19 seasons we forecast that palm oil use will continue at around 7.1m tonnes.
Biodiesel consumption in Malaysia faces challenges
Malaysian palm oil consumption was hampered in 2017 by delays in implementing biodiesel incorporation mandates. We have made a small reduction in our estimate of 2016/17 consumption to reflect the difficulties of the biodiesel sector. The government continues its efforts to get the B10 mandate accepted by automobile manufacturers but the implementation has now been postponed, probably to at least 2019. However, there are reports of increasing biodiesel exports. Despite this, we have made further small reductions in our forecasts of consumption in 2017/18 and 2018/19 to reflect the sluggish growth in the local market for biodiesel.
Prospects for palm oil consumption in other countries are broadly positive
The top five consumers account for less than 55% of global demand, and a large number of other countries also consume palm oil. Consumption growth in these countries has been buoyant, but has slowed during the second half of 2016/17. A number of these countries are the target of palm oil exporters, especially in Africa and the Middle East. For example, recent reports highlight strong growth in palm oil imports into Ghana. The largest of these "other" consumers, Pakistan, is showing steady growth in palm oil consumption. Attempts to encourage local oilseeds production have been largely unsuccessful since neither sunflowerseed nor rapeseed fit in with more profitable crops. By 2018/19, Pakistan's palm oil consumption should be at almost 3m tonnes, similar to expected consumption in Malaysia.

Supply
The recovery in yields in 2016/17, following an earlier dry period, ensured strong growth rates in palm oil production. Among the top four producers, only Malaysia failed to record double-digit output growth. Overall, we estimate that global palm oil production rose by over 12.4% year on year in 2016/17, to reach 65.5m tonnes. We expect the growth rate to slow in 2017/18, on the heels of this record outturn, but to remain above average. In 2018/19 we expect production growth to slip further, to a marginal 0.9%, owing to the impact of stressed trees and a slowdown in mature areas growth.
Yields in Indonesia are slowly recovering from the 2015/16 drought
Indonesia's palm oil output growth in 2016/17 has exceeded expectations. The age profile of Indonesia's oil palms explains the strong rise in yields, which have outstripped those in all other palm oil producers. At an estimated 36.1m tonnes, output in 2016/17 was almost 16% higher than in the drought-affected 2015/16 season. Yields are likely to rise further in 2017/18, albeit at a slower rate. We continue to forecast production of over 37m tonnes, representing a below-average growth rate of 4.4%. In 2018/19 the larger planted area is likely to offset any negative effects from the slower rate of planting and tree stress; overall, we expect output to increase by 2% that season, to 38.5m tonnes.
Malaysian production is set to return to 2013/14 peak by 2017/18
Malaysia's recorded palm oil production continued to underperform in September, even falling below the particularly low level seen in August (at a time when seasonal production tends to rise). Consequently, we now exped production of 18.9m tonnes in 2016/17 (19m tonnes previously). Persistent labour shortages, the age profile of trees and lower extraction rates have all contributed to this shortfall. October's production is thought to have recovered based on early indicators. For 2017/18 we retain our forecast that output will rise by 7.1% year on year. There is fear that the La Niña weather phenomenon may cause excessive rainfall and flooding in the final weeks of 2017, which may adversely impact palm oil output. Given the difficulties of finding new land for planting, growth in Malaysian output relies on replacing ageing trees with younger, higher-yield trees. The rate of replanting in recent years has been too low to prevent a slump in yields. As a result, for 2018/19 we expect output to remain fairly flat year on year, at about 20.1m tonnes as yields continue below the usual levels.

For Thailand, the third-largest producer, we estimate that production will exceed 2.1m tonnes in 2016/17. Higher output is putting pressure on local prices of palm fruit. Some local sources suggest that prices are below the costs of production, inhibiting the use of inputs to stimulate yields. We expect an increase in the mature area to ensure continued growth in palm oil output in 2017/18. Difficulties in securing new land for planting will inhibit future growth although the improving age profile will help yields. The slow growth in palm oil output is expected to result in a lower target for biodiesel use in Thailand. We expect Colombian output to grow steadily over the forecast period as its mature area expands. Recent yields have largely been above year-earlier levels, and returns to the crop have been favourable. A higher biodiesel incorporation rate mandate should also help to maintain interest in the crop.
Stocks and prices
Recorded palm oil stocks in Malaysia at the end of August showed a further substantial increase month on month, and remained above year-earlier levels. Stocks have also risen in Indonesia. Our own estimates suggest that stocks at the end of the 2016/17 season will be adequate but below the historical average. With palm oil production now set to reduce seasonally, stocks are likely to remain comparatively tight for the first half of the 2017/18 season. However, over the season as a whole, the market surplus will be greater than in 2016/17 and allow stocks to recover to higher than normal levels. A surplus, albeit smaller than that of 2017/18, is also expected in 2018/19.

Rising stock levels will push prices down further in 2018
Physical prices for palm oil eased in October, although the decline was small. Futures prices were also little changed from those recorded in September. The unexpected fall in Malaysian palm oil output and the low current stock levels are combining to maintain comparatively firm prices. Given the scale of the prospective surplus for the 2017/18 season, we expect prices to be persistently weak. However, there remain significant uncertainties about the prospective increases in production, and markets are likely to remain firm until evidence of the production growth, and the consequent stock increases, is more firmly established. Given the seasonal decline in palm oil production, which typically lasts until February, price falls may be delayed until the second quarter of 2018. As a result, we expect price drops to be more noticeable in the second half of the 2017/18 season, bringing the annual average down by over 10%. In 2018/19, as global stocks continue to rise, we expect prices to stay below US$600/tonne on average.

Rapeseed oil
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that global rapeseed oil consumption fell by 7% year on year in 2016/17. With prices likely to remain high during 2017/18, we expect a further contraction in 2017/18, largely owing to lower demand in China and the EU. Overall, our estimate for 2017/18 rapeseed oil consumption now stands at 24.9m tonnes, 1.2% lower than in 2016/17. We only expect rapeseed oil consumption volumes to recover in 2018/19, by 4.9% year on year. Given the low oil stocks, this relies on improved production levels.
EU consumption in 2016/17 will be limited by availability
EU consumption in 2016/17 was constrained by the availability of supply although improved availability at the end of the season resulted in consumption of just under 10m tonnes; a total lower than in the previous three seasons. The 10m-tonne mark is unlikely to be breached in the 2017/18 season. On the downside, potential usage is limited by the expected resumption of biodiesel imports from Argentina and possibly from Indonesia in mid-2018, which will weigh on consumption in the latter part of that season. On the other hand, the competition in the edible market from sunflowerseed is thought likely to ease as the season progresses. Overall, we have made a small upward revision to our estimate of 2017/18 consumption, to 9.8m tonnes.
Demand in China will be aided in 2016/17 by the release of reserve stocks
In China drawdowns of official rapeseed stocks helped to support consump-tion of rapeseed oil in 2016/17. It is unlikely that a further drawdown of stocks can be used to maintain consumption in 2017/18. The continual downgrading of local production estimates means that our estimate of usage in 2017/18 has fallen further. We now forecast Chinese consumption to drop by more than 7% to only 5.2m tonnes. Even this level will require either a significant increase in rapeseed imports for local crushing or the maintenance of recent levels of rapeseed oil imports. The forecast is vulnerable to any change in price differentials, especially between rapeseed oil and palm oil.
India's consumption will rebound in 2016/17 in line with local availability
In India, competition from imported oils was strong during the 2016/17 season despite good local supplies. We estimate that consumption climbed by nearly 10% in 2016/17 to reach nearly 2.4m tonnes. An improving outlook for domestic availability, together with strong real GDP growth levels, should stimulate additional consumption during 2017/18. We have increased our 2017/18 forecast and now expect rapeseed oil consumption to exceed 2.5m tonnes. This level is likely to be at least maintained in 2018/19. However, these forecasts imply an increasing volume of rapeseed oil imports and are therefore vulnerable to changes in international rapeseed oil availability.
Limited supplies will keep US and Japanese demand in check
Imports of rapeseed oil into the US continue to run ahead of earlier expectations. Coupled with improved domestic output, we expect consumption to have reached a record of almost 2.7m tonnes in 2016/17. The recent application of anti-dumping duties on biodiesel from Argentina and Indonesia could stimulate additional demand for rapeseed oil as a feedstock during the forecast period. Overall, we expect US rapeseed oil consumption to continue to grow steadily to reach 2.9m tonnes in the 2018/19 season. Several smaller consumers have switched away from rapeseed oil during 2016/17-a pattern that is likely to continue into 2017/18 as a result of its comparatively high price relative to other oils. A recovery in consumption among these "other" consumers is now expected to be delayed until 2018/19.

Supply
Global rapeseed oil production declined for the third consecutive season in 2016/17 by an estimated 2.8% year on year, to 24.7m tonnes. We now expect a further, albeit small, decline in rapeseed oil production in 2017/18. The main reduction occurs in the large number of "other" producers (including Mexico, Japan and Pakistan) who are expected to respond to higher prices of rapeseed with smaller crush volumes. Output in 2018/19 will of course depend on a recovery in rapeseed production. A return to normal yields will be the main element of any increase and would allow a significant jump in rapeseed oil output in 2018/19. We currently forecast growth of 6.2%, to 25.9m tonnes.
The EU rapeseed crop will recover only partially in 2017/18
Despite the small local crop, EU rapeseed crushers during 2016/17 managed to produce almost 10.2m tonnes of rapeseed oil, only marginally below the 2015/16 total. Prospects for rapeseed oil production in the 2017/18 season have been helped by a further increase in the size of the 2017/18 rapeseed harvest. Higher estimates for crops in France and the UK more than offset a further reduction in estimated output in Germany. Indeed, at 22.1m tonnes, the crop looks to have been well above the 2016/17 production although still shy of the record 24.3m tonnes harvested in 2014/15. Greater local availability will be needed to offset expected lower imports from Australia and a recent slowdown in imports from the Ukraine. We forecast production to show only a small increase in 2017/18 to 10.2m tonnes. Assuming a return to normal crop yields in 2018/19, we expect rapeseed oil production to approach the record output of 10.7m tonnes recorded in 2014/15.
Chinese production will fall in 2016/17
There has been a further, albeit small, reduction in the estimate of China's 2017/18 rapeseed crop. Current estimates put the 2017/18 harvest at around 5m tonnes. China's rapeseed oil production increasingly relies on imported rapeseed/canola through the additional capacity located at ports. We currently forecast 2017/18 rapeseed oil production to be only marginally higher than 2016/17, at 3.6m tonnes. Output at this level implies a significant increase in rapeseed imports which may be difficult to achieve. While rapeseed oil and rapeseed prices are likely to be higher, it remains unclear whether Chinese farmers will respond by higher plantings for the 2018/19 season. Instead, it is more likely that higher rapeseed oil production for the 2018/19 season will require yet more imports. We forecast oil output to expand to almost 4m tonnes.
Canada's 2016/17 harvest may be below expectations
At just shy of 4m tonnes, Canadian canola oil production in 2016/17 was easily a new record. Progress with the 2017/18 harvest has run ahead of normal and is virtually complete. Yields are variable in some area but are reported to have been above normal in the largest producing state of Saskatchewan. The earlier Statistics Canada report of a crop of 19.7m tonnes has been confirmed by the most recent estimate. The early harvest has made farmers ready sellers but the Canadian crush industry is facing strong competition for available supplies, especially give the low canola carry-in stocks for the 2017/18 season. We expect Canadian 2017/18 canola oil production to be little changed from the 2016/17 season at around 4m tonnes. Canola remains an attractive crop to Canadian farmers, and we assume an expansion of the planted area in 2018/19 to levels similar to the 2012/13 record. Normal yields should allow canola oil output to rise by 3.7%, to 4.2m tonnes.
India's production is poised for a rebound in 2016/17
In India, 2016/17 rapeseed crushings have been inhibited by imported vegetable oils, despite a large local harvest. Rapeseed oil production of 2.1m tonnes was well below potential output. The monsoon season just ended is recorded as normal and should, in principle, lay the foundation for at least average yields for the 2017/18 rapeseed crop. However, there is significant regional variation in the rainfall totals and the distribution of rainfall was also weighted towards the early part of the season. Estimates of the size of the 2017/18 rapeseed crop therefore err on the cautious side. However, large carry-in stocks of seed mean that 2017/18 rapeseed oil should expand to almost 2.2m tonnes.

Australian production is likely to fall in 2017/18 owing to dry conditions
Overly dry conditions have persisted in most of the main canola producing areas of Australia. For example, in Western Australia, the largest producing state, yields are expected to drop by as much as 35%, owing to the lack of rainfall. Overall, Australian production in 2017/18 is expected to reach less than 3m tonnes, well below the 4.4m tonnes harvested in 2016/17 and the lowest total since 2010/11. In Ukraine, harvesting of the winter rapeseed planted area is complete, with production confirmed at 2.1m tonnes. Winter plantings to date suggest a further increase in output in 2018/19.
Stocks and prices
The global rapeseed oil market in 2016/17 showed a deficit resulting in stocks of both rapeseed and rapeseed oil (when measured against consumption) well below normal levels. In the oil market, 2017/18 is expected to show another deficit; however, at 560,000 tonnes, this will be smaller than our previous forecast (674,000 tonnes). However, rapeseed stocks will remain available during 2017/18 and could result in higher crushings than currently expected. On the supply side of the seed market, the only major uncertainty is the size of the Indian crop to be harvested in the February-April 2018 period. Our current projections suggest that the market will remain in deficit in 2018/19, although this could be relieved to a degree by higher crush rates. In any event, global consumption may need to be further rationed from current projected levels.

Low stocks will put upward pressure on prices from late 2017
Physical prices of rapeseed oil held fairly steady in October, with price rises inhibited by weakness in the sunflowerseed oil and soybean oil markets. Futures markets for canola/rapeseed in Canada and Europe both increased during October, reflecting the growing realisation that the market will tighten during 2017/18. Sustained price rises are the most likely course for rapeseed oil prices although price gains will be limited by the high availability of other oils. However, prices look set to hover around US$900/tonne during 2018 with the potential to approach US$950/tonne in the 2019/20 season.

Rice
Demand
With human consumption of rice continuing to drive up overall use in Asia, where populations are rising, global rice usage is expected to reach a new high of 494m tonnes in 2017/18, an increase of 1.6% from the previous season. As in the past, relatively tiny volume increases are likely in other regions, such as Africa and South America. However, other segments of rice demand, such as the animal feed and industrial sectors, are anticipated to contract. The outlook for the 2018/19 season is still uncertain, since it depends on factors that will remain unknown for quite some time, such as policy frameworks, local crop outcomes and import needs. As such, our forecast for demand growth of 1.5%, to nearly 502m tonnes, assumes that annual growth will return close to trend.
Trade in rice will continue to grow, but at a slower rate than in 2017
Africa and Asia account for three-quarters of all rice imports, primarily white and parboiled grades sourced from Thailand, India, Pakistan and Vietnam. In Sub-Saharan Africa in particular, a significant share of demand-mainly for high-quality white and parboiled supplies-is met by imports. With buyers in those regions expected to remain active in the global market, trade is projected to continue to grow in the next two years, to reach 44.5m tonnes in 2019, which would be the largest volume on record. However, growth will be relatively marginal, as we assume that many Asian buyers will be well stocked after having made heavy purchases in 2017. Further strong demand for Thai rice from African buyers in 2017 was largely linked to availabilities of attractively priced rice from the government's stockpile. With the bulk of that now sold, demand should fade.
China's needs are expected to be central to the rice trade in 2018-19
China is currently the world's leading buyer, with annual imports likely to be between 4.5m and 5m tonnes during the forecast period. Indonesia, Bangladesh and the Philippines are set to be significant importers, as they aim to maintain buffer reserves. In Sub-Saharan Africa, a significant share of total demand-mainly for high-quality white and parboiled supplies-is met by imports. Shipments to Africa are likely to rise in 2017/18-2018/19, after contracting in the two previous seasons, as economic growth improves slightly and international rice prices remain low.
China is by far the world's largest consumer of rice, accounting for about 30% of global demand. The bulk of national consumption is made up of locally produced rice, but in recent years China has also become the biggest importer of rice, mainly of high-quality broken types from Thailand and Vietnam. Prices for domestic long-grain milled rice still command hefty premiums over supplies from other major origins in Asia, owing to the easy availability of rice from major suppliers outside China, supporting China's import demand.
Lower duties will encourage rice imports by Bangladesh in 2018-19
Bangladesh is one of the leading rice markets within Asia, with annual demand reaching at least 35m tonnes. Three domestic crops are cut each year, namely the boro (seeded in December-January and harvested in April-May), aus (planted in March-April and cut in June-July) and aman (sown in July-August and normally threshed in November-December). Although the bulk of the country's rice needs are met by domestic crops, significant quantities are sometimes procured from the world market. Bangladesh importers and millers have sought to get tariffs reduced as a means of boosting imports, primarily from Thailand and India, with the latter country typically the largest supplier in recent years. India has recently entered into a long-term arrangement with Vietnam for up to 1m tonnes of imports per year until 2022. Trade reports have also highlighted the possibility of significant purchases from Myanmar. The government is looking to boost rice imports in order to build reserves and rein in local prices, after flash floods hit domestic output. To this end, the tariff applied to rice imports was cut from 28% to 10% in mid-2017.
The Philippines may be a large buyer, as state reserves are historically low.
In the Philippines, stocks held by the National Food Authority, the grain procurement agency, have dwindled to their lowest level in around a decade. In contrast, however, inventories held by private households and commercial warehouses remain especially comfortable. Underscoring thin state reserves, imports progressed strongly over the course of the 2017, with the total for the first six months of the year at 530,000 tonnes, an 80% increase on the same period of 2016. With more imports expected throughout the rest of the year, arrivals are forecast to be 40% larger in 2017, at 1.4m tonnes. Purchases are likely to remain high in the following years.

a Local marketing years.
Supply
Our forecast for world rice production in 2017/18 has been revised down further, by 3m tonnes, to 484m tonnes, representing a marginal retreat from the record outturn in 2016/17. The fall mainly reflects prospects for reduced output in India and the US. Nonetheless, this would be the second-largest crop ever harvested, with stellar outturns expected in much of Asia on the basis of area increases and better yields. The outlook for 2018/19 is highly provisional. Nonetheless, given that only a small expansion of paddy plantings is likely, an increase in global output will almost certainly be dependent on better yields. Assuming continued state support for farmers in Asia and beneficial weather, we forecast global output to increase by 1.5%, to nearly 492m tonnes, in 2018/19.
The 2017 monsoon was 5% below average, reducing output slightly
India's main agricultural crops are cultivated during two distinct seasons: kharif crops are sown between June and October and rabi crops in November-December. Kharif crops, of which rice is by far the most important, are rain-fed and therefore critically reliant on monsoon precipitation, which typically arrives in the southern state of Kerala in early June and lasts for about four months, accounting for 70% of the country's annual rains.
In India, where the kharif-planting season was completed by early October, the area planted to paddy was slightly smaller year on year, but still fairly solid compared with the average of recent seasons. The 2017 monsoon was around 5% below the long-term average; taking into account its impact on yield potential in some regions, as well as prospects for the winter-sown rabi crop, we project total acreage to be broadly steady year on year. Accordingly, we have revised down slightly our forecast for full-year output in 2017/18, by a further 500,000 tonnes, to 108m tonnes, representing a small contraction year on year. Nevertheless, this should still ensure that availabilities for domestic use and exports are sufficiently comfortable. In 2018/19, everything will depend on the pattern of the monsoon, which will begin around June 1st 2018. Tentatively assuming that it is beneficial, and that support prices are maintained at an attractive level, another above-average kharif outturn is likely.
India should remain the biggest rice exporter in 2017/18 and 2018/19
Based on their continued robust pace to date, which has been supported by large ship-ments to Africa and South Asia, India's exports are expected to reach nearly 11m tonnes in 2017, making it the largest supplier to the world market for the sixth consecutive season. Shipments in 2018 are anticipated to be slightly smaller year on year, at 10.7m tonnes. We assume that in 2019 competition from Thailand and, to a lesser extent, Vietnam, will push sales down slightly again, to 10.5m tonnes.
China's exports have expanded in 2017, mainly because of sales to Africa
Although China has emerged as the world's biggest importer of rice in recent years, it has, for the most part, been a tiny exporter. Over recent seasons its exports have fluctuated between 200,000 tonnes and 500,000 tonnes, with most heading to markets in Asia, including South Korea and Japan-these being part of minimum commitments to import by those nations under World Trade Organisation obligations. Shipments normally comprise mostly small- and medium-grain varieties.
Exports could surpass 1m tonnes in 2017, before receding slightly
The current year has been very different, however, with unusually large shipments of long-grain rice recorded in each month. Data from China's General Administration of Customs show that total (cumulative) exports in January-September reached around 890,000 tonnes, compared with just 239,000 tonnes in the same period of 2016, with particularly heavy deliveries to Côte d'Ivoire, Senegal and Sierra Leone. It is unclear whether such high sales can be sustained, especially since some of these shipments may have come in the form of food aid. Nevertheless, it is worth noting that China is believed to sit on massive state reserves, of at least 120m tonnes on a paddy weight basis, although much of this is unfit for human consumption. China's exports have occasionally risen above 2m tonnes, notably in 2003, with much of the increase going to Africa and the Americas. For 2017 as whole, volumes could be as large as 1.1m tonnes, but are likely to fall back in 2018 and 2019.
Production prospects for 2017/18 in Thailand are very positive
Thailand lost its place as the world's top rice exporter in 2012, owing in part to its intervention buying programme, which began in 2011, and heavy competition from India. More recently, exports have been boosted by availabilities from the government's stockpile, but prospects for production will ultimately shape the country's exportable surplus over the next two years.
In the current season (2017/18) prospects for the main crop appear solid, with harvesting due to take place in the final weeks of 2017. Cultivation is currently in the reproductive stage and progressing well. Cummulative precipitation during 2017 is estimated to be around one-quarter higher than average, and the impact of flooding in September was minimal. Good water levels will also be important during the development of the irrigated, off-season crop, which will be threshed next year. Assuming the planted area is expanded in both seasons, total production is projected at 20.4m tonnes, up from 19m tonnes in the previous year and a five-year high. A further increase in main-crop sowings is projected to push output up to 22m tonnes in 2018/19.
The government will incentivise farmers to store rice from the main harvest
In mid-September the Thai government approved a THB73bn (US$2.2bn) budget for a 2017/18 on-farm paddy pledging programme to include main-crop rice varieties from November 1st 2017 through to the end of February 2018. The scheme is aimed at supporting domestic prices during the main crop harvest, with up to 2m tonnes of paddy set to be procured. The intervention price for white rice is 3% above that of the previous season. Additional measures have been announced, with farmers, millers and traders also receiving support in the form of subsidies and soft loans, as a means of encouraging participants to store rice through to 2018.
The government's stock disposals have been successful
The Thai government has been saddled with excess reserves in recent years, an overhang of its earlier-and much-criticised-intervention buying programmes. However, considerable progress was made in disposing of this stockpile during 2017. Most government-held reserves were of questionable quality, with a large portion being sold to feed (as a substitute for corn and for imported feed wheat in swine feed rations) and industrial (ethanol) producers. However, a considerable volume of food-grade stocks has been made available to exporters at attractive prices, and these have been sold, or earmarked, for shipment to markets in Africa. This will help to sustain Thailand's exports at 10.5m tonnes in 2018, with the potential to edge higher, to 10.6m tonnes, in the following year.
Vietnam's exports, particularly to China, rose quickly in 2017
Vietnam is a medium-sized rice producer, but it is the third-largest global exporter, behind India and Thailand. It typically accounts for 5-6% of global output but 15% of exports. The Vietnam Food Association oversees policy surrounding rice export registration requirements and the setting of the country's minimum export price for grades. Vietnam's exporters have performed well in 2017, with bigger sales to a number of markets in Asia pushing up total volumes in January-October to 5.1m tonnes, up by more than 20% in year-on-year terms. Analysis of customs data show that, although exports to African nations were smaller year on year, exports to both China and the Philippines (a long-time buyer) rose markedly. However, demand has also been much firmer from Bangladesh, a country that has tended to source its import requirements from India. However, the need to build stocks after local supplies came up short pushed the government to diversify its import sources.
We expect Vietnam to export around 300,000 tonnes per month in November and December, bringing full-year exports for 2017 to 5.7m tonnes, representing a solid improvement year on year. We expect Vietnam to maintain its position as the world's third biggest exporter beyond 2019, although volumes are unlikely to exceed 7m tonnes in any season, given continued heavy sales by India and Thailand, as well as growing competition from other, relatively small exporters such as Cambodia and Myanmar.
A much smaller crop will constrain US rice exports in 2017/18
The US rice harvest was completed in October. Based on a large decrease in plantings, production in 2017/18 is expected to fall to just 5.7m tonnes, down from 7.1m tonnes in the previous season. This would be the smallest outturn in more than two decades, and is expected to tighten availabilities for sale on the international market, notwith-standing a drop in domestic use. Nevertheless, the contraction will be limited by large opening stocks. Exports in the local marketing year, which began on August 1st, are expected to fall to 3.4m tonnes, from 3.6m tonnes the previous year. US rice is sold globally, but major markets, mainly for paddy (rough rice) exports, include Central and Latin America.
A smaller crop is likely in Brazil in 2017/18 as yields retreat
Conab, the official supply agency of Brazil, released its first formal outlook for rice supply and demand in 2017/18 in early October. The southern state of Rio Grande do Sul is the most important producing region, accounting for the bulk of acreage. Together with other states, rice plantings for the 2017/18 crop, which will be harvested in the first half of 2018, was expected to hold steady compared with 2016/17, at around 2m ha. But with the agency expecting yields to fall from the previous year's level, production (paddy weight basis) is forecast to fall by 4% year on year, to 11.8m tonnes. Aside from the potential for bigger plantings in Rio Grande do Sul, there appears to be limited potential for an increase in area anywhere else in the country in the longer term. In 2018/19 production is tentatively projected to edge lower, to 11.5m tonnes.

Stocks and prices
World rice stocks are forecast to fall more appreciably in 2017/18, by almost 10m tonnes, to a seven-year low of 95.2m tonnes. Although we expect China's supportive policies for farmers to ensure another rise in inventories, this will be in contrast to falls in the major global suppliers, as well as in other countries. In Thailand, for example, the government has had much success in disposing of state reserves. Inventories held by the world's leading exporters, which also include India, Pakistan, the US and Vietnam, are forecast at 22m tonnes, down by 5m tonnes year on year. This would be the smallest amount in a decade and highlights a global market that appears to be tighter than headline figures might suggest.
Stocks are expected to drop in the next two seasons on rising consumption
In 2018/19, although world output is still expected to climb from this season's record level, rising consumption will also cut into stocks, pushing them to another multi-year low of 85m tonnes. It is assumed that stockbuilding in China will continue, especially since imports are set to remain high, but exporters' reserves may fall again, to just 21m tonnes, most of which will be held in India.

Following significant, demand-driven price increases in earlier months, markets in Asia have generally eased since mid-2017, although the past two months have shown contrasting trends. In Thailand, offers for the 100% B grade fell by around 2% over the past month, to US$381/tonne fob Bangkok on November 2nd, as sluggish international demand and the approach of new crop supplies weighed on sentiment. In India, the same factors affected markets in October.
However, export values in Pakistan were slightly firmer as supplies from the previous crop tightened ahead of the arrival of the main crop harvest in late 2017. Broken rice markets in Vietnam firmed by 4% over the past month on strong underlying demand-illustrated by the 20% year-on-year jump in exports in January-October 2017. US milled rice export prices remain high, despite a slight fall month on month as this year's heavy drop in production has boosted sentiment. The 4% broken variety traded at US$514/tonne in early November, down by 1% on four weeks earlier, but well above the US$400/tonne level seen in April and 29% higher compared with the same point of 2016.
The price outlook for Thailand's 100% B grade rice-the series that we forecast-has been revised down slightly, although market fundamentals are unchanged. Given recent weakness, we now expect prices to average US$385/tonne in the fourth quarter of 2017 (US$395/tonne previously), translating into a full-year average price of US$388/tonne, just slightly above the 2016 average. Our supply and demand forecasts suggest that there is potential for some upward pressure on prices as global supplies begin to tighten in 2018 owing to contractions in major exporters. By the fourth quarter of 2019 we forecast a price of US$425/tonne; however, although this would equate to a five-year high, it would still be well below the levels seen in 2009-13. Another gentle rise, to US$430/tonne, is likely in the first quarter of 2020.
