Soybeans
Demand
As increases in demand in China and many other Asian nations boost demand for feed ingredients, including high-protein oilseed meals, consumption is forecast to expand by 4.3% in 2017/18, reaching a new high of 339m tonnes. Although we expect growth to slow relative to that in 2016/17, it will match the average of recent seasons. Looking beyond Asia, other, smaller consuming regions, including the EU, Africa and the Middle East, will also contribute to rising demand. Prospects for 2018/19 are unclear, as crop outcomes will not be known for another 12-18 months. However, we expect rising usage in the animal feed sector to support similar demand growth that season, of 4.4%, to reach a record 354m tonnes.
World soybean trade in 2017/18 is forecast to rise for the seventh consecutive year, to a record of 148.7m tonnes, with most of the expansion due to rising needs in China, as well as smaller markets in Asia. With demand from these countries provisionally expected to increase, traded volumes could surpass 153m tonnes in 2018/19.
Feed usage will drive overall demand up and will mostly be met by imports
China is by far the world's largest consumer and importer of soybeans, with growth largely driven by expanding demand from the country's vast animal feed sector. In 2017/18 we expect China's total consumption to reach a new record of 105m tonnes, representing impressive growth of about 6% and approaching one-third of the amount used globally. Imports are forecast to total 95.5m tonnes, or more than 90% of consumption, which highlights the global market's dependence on Chinese processors. Although the government is looking to boost local output, it seems that imports will continue to account for a dominant, and possibly rising, share of overall requirements, especially in feed sectors. Most of what is produced locally is likely to be channelled to food and other smaller markets.
China's imports in 2018/19 are expected to reach 100m tonnes
Despite reports of large stocks of soybeans and associated pressure on crush margins, import demand growth has remained robust throughout 2017, with buyers encouraged by a world market that is amply supplied and attractively priced. The outlook for 2018/19 is tentative, but China's full-season purchases are likely to reach 100m tonnes.
Nonetheless, the Chinese government's intention to end maize stockpiling, announced in 2016, remains a downside risk. The move aims to encourage the use of maize at the expense of other feed grains, which have been imported in great quantities in recent years. Higher maize consumption in the pork and poultry sectors could also raise questions surrounding the use of high-protein meals, primarily soybean meal. The impact, however, is likely to be marginal, as soybean meal is the most abundantly produced of all oilseed meals, with its attractiveness as a feed ingredient stemming from its high-protein quality and nutritional value compared with alternatives.
Ample domestic supplies will support demand in the US
With another bumper crop expected to result in a further swelling of domestic supplies, US consumption in 2017/18 is forecast to remain close to the previous season's high, at 56m tonnes. Aside from requirements locally, total use will be underpinned by rising exports of soybean meal. Similar trends will enable domestic demand potentially to edge up in 2018/19, to 57m tonnes.
Soybean consumption in Argentina will continue to be driven by growing international demand for soybean meal, of which Argentina is the dominant supplier to world markets. In Brazil, further increases in consumption are anticipated as bigger local soybean crops boost supplies for processing.
Imports are central to EU requirements
The EU has achieved successively larger record crops in recent seasons. Nevertheless, at less than 3m tonnes, domestic outturns represent only a tiny share of overall requirements, with imports of soybeans and soybean meal typically accounting for anything up to 35m tonnes. In 2017/18 imports of soybeans are likely to rise after the previous season's fall, but any increase is likely to be capped by a much better local rapeseed harvest, estimated at 22m tonnes, up from 20.4m tonnes in the preceding season. In 2018/19 and beyond, availabilities of alternatives, including rapeseed, will play a crucial role in determining volume requirements. Throughout the period we expect the region's soybean meal imports to remain above 20m tonnes, making it easily the world's largest buyer.

Supply
Although planting campaigns in Latin America's leading producers are now under way, there remains a high degree of uncertainty about prospects for the global outturn in 2017/18. Never-theless, in the northern hemisphere another season of big or record crops is expected, judging by completed plantings and intentions, and early field reports. We expect these factors to support the second-largest harvest ever.
A solid increase in the global area for harvesting is expected, but yields are likely to be slightly below the record achieved in 2016/17. Accordingly, production is forecast to fall by 1.6% year on year, to 341m tonnes. In the following season output could recover slightly, but would still fall a little short of the 2016/17 high: our projection of a 1% year-on-year increase, to 344.7m tonnes, reflects our assumption of a slight rise in sowings and trend yields.
US production in 2017/18 is likely to set a new record owing to a larger area
The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) expects seeded area in 2017/18 to increase by around 7% year on year, to 36.2m ha, the largest on record. In addition to a switch of acreage from maize and spring wheat, expanded area also stems from a steep contraction in winter wheat sowings. Weather patterns during the current growing season were a cause for concern at times in parts of the Midwest, including dry and hot conditions in the east and in the northern Plains, with excessive rains being a problem in eastern regions. It therefore seems likely that average yields will not match those of the previous year. Nonetheless, local official projections and recent field reports reflect a positive yield outlook.
At a record of 120m tonnes, output is expected to be almost 3% higher year on year in 2018/19 (compared with a marginal decrease previously). Together with high carryover stocks from the season before (which ends on August 31st), a crop of that size will ensure ample supplies for domestic use and export. We assume that recent delays to harvesting in parts of the Midwest will not have a detrimental impact.
US exports could establish a new record in 2017/18
US exports progressed strongly during the 2016/17 season, totalling 58.1m tonnes by August 31st 2017 (the close of the US marketing year), up by 4m tonnes from 2015/16. The solid pace was shaped by international demand from Asia, but by also a range of other, relatively small importers, including those in Africa and the Middle East. For 2017/18 we expect shipments to expand to at least 60m tonnes, a new record. Although the pace of sales has stepped up significantly in recent weeks, they remain well behind a year earlier. On October 26th cumulative export sales had exceeded 30m tonnes, although this was still a drop of about 16% year on year. The slower pace is almost certainly linked to heavy shipments by Brazil, with some buyers hesitant to enter the world market, preferring to wait for the bulk of northern hemisphere supplies to come on stream at attractive prices.
US growers are expected to reduce the area planted to soybeans in 2018/19
Planting intentions for 2018/19 in the northern hemisphere are tentative at this stage. In the US much will depend on relative prices at the time of planting, as well as crop rotation. Although there is an argument in favour of increased corn plantings at the expense of soybeans following 2017/18 seeding patterns, support for soybean acreage could come from the continued expansion of global trade, driven largely by China's needs. We anticipate that the area planted to soybeans in the US will fall by between 2% and 3% in 2018/19. Combined with yields, the outturn is projected at 114m tonnes, which is 5% lower than the previous season, but still the third-largest harvest on record.
A huge crop will be cut in Canada, with further increases likely in the long term
The area for harvest in Canada is estimated at a record of 2.9m ha, an unprecedented year-on-year expansion of 33%, driven by expanded acreage in the non-traditional growing areas of Manitoba and Saskatchewan, largely at the expense of wheat and canola. One of the key attractions is that Canadian growers are able to tap in to a fast-growing global market. Added to this, the crop requires less intensive application of inputs, such as fertilisers, compared with alternatives, and new varieties have been developed that can be cultivated in areas that were previously unsuitable. Despite the significant expansion of seeded area, some reduction in yields is expected, especially as earlier reports from Manitoba and Saskatchewan pointed to difficulties with crop development owing to challenging weather. According to Canada's Department of Agriculture and Agri-Food, output is expected to increase by 1.5m tonnes to 8m tonnes in 2017/18. Exports are projected to rise to 5.6m tonnes, up from 4.4m tonnes in the previous season.
Brazil's exports are likely to smash previous records in 2017/18
Brazil's huge 2016/17 crop boosted availabilities to record levels and, given expected growth in trade, positioned Brazil to export significantly larger volumes in the local marketing year (which closes at end-January 2018). We have kept our forecast steady from last month's assessment. We believe that total shipments could reach a record of at least 62m tonnes, up by 14% from the previous year. With prospects for a marked rise in domestic prices in Brazil appearing limited given current conditions, farmers are likely to finish the season with larger than normal stocks. Furthermore, with another big US crop anticipated and availabilities coming on stream imminently, there is the potential for significant supplies in late 2017 and early 2018, and associated downward pressure on prices.
Growth in sowings in Brazil is expected in 2017/18, but may be limited by low prices
With plenty of land available, a further expansion of soybean area in Brazil is possible in 2017/18, and we are projecting growth of 2%, to 34.5m ha. Nevertheless, downside risks remain; current market conditions, including low domestic and soybean prices, coupled with exchange-rate uncertainty, will make it hard for many growers to cover production costs. Much will depend on the US harvest and its impact on the global market.
It seems likely that, despite the area increase, some growers will be tempted to scale back expenditure on essential inputs to minimise overall costs. Nevertheless, maize prices in Brazil are signficantly below year-earlier levels-having fallen by a larger margin than soybean prices did-which makes it likely that some farmers will have switched a portion of their intended primary, or full-season, maize cropland to soybeans. Planting of the 2017/18 soybean crop began on September 11th in the state of Paraná-a few days earlier than normal-as part of a government experiment to see if early fieldwork is viable. Other states, including the major producing region of Mato Grosso, followed shortly after.
The planting season is being hampered by difficult weather
Planting has been stalled by difficult conditions, with soils deemed to be too dry for seeding to advance in many areas, while being excessively wet in southern regions. With dry conditions likely to persist in the worst affected areas, some growers are understood to be considering re-sowing fields. Further highlighting difficult conditions, the Mato Grosso Institute of Agricultural Economics put planting at 44% complete by the end of October, down from 67% a year earlier.
However, local analysts and commentators still believe that a good crop can be expected, even if seeding does not begin until November, assuming that weather patterns are favourable. However, if conditions do not improve significantly, some farmers could be tempted not to plant a late soybean crop and instead focus on other options, including full-season cotton, prices for which are likely to be favourable.
Finally, it is worth noting again that the Brazilian National Meteorological Institute (Inmet) has released its forecast for the final quarter of 2017, which highlights the risk that a La Niña weather event will form. Many farmers in Brazil are already concerned about the potentially slow start to the season, so the potential of a mild La Niña-which typically brings below-normal rainfall for east-central and south-eastern Brazil-has added to their concerns. We expect no more than a mild effect on Brazilian output were such an event to occur.
With yields unlikely to be near those achieved in 2016/17, we forecast output to fall slightly in 2017/18, by 5% year on year, to 108m tonnes. Planting of the 2018/19 crop will not begin until mid-September 2018, so the outlook is highly provisional. Based on some further area expansion and trend productivity, output could be close to the 2016/17 high.
Production in Argentina could fall in 2017/18 on potential area declines
Fieldwork for Argentina's 2017/18 crop is now under way. Most of the progress has been in the north, although planting should speed up after farmers have made solid progress with the maize crop. After heavy rains, a period of dry weather is needed to ensure that soils are in good shape. However, as with Brazil, seeding decisions will depend on market conditions at the time of planting. With relatively better returns for maize, growers are expected to favour plantings of the grain over soybeans. With some area reduction likely, and together with a fall in average yields, production is projected to drop by 3.5m tonnes year on year, to 53m tonnes. Although the government is expected to reduce soybean export levies gradually over the course of 2018-19, the crop will still not be as an attractive as other options.

China's output is rising, but still only meets a fraction of domestic demand
Despite being by far the world's largest importer, China is only a minor producer of soybeans. Its potential has been capped by limited yield gains compared with those of the world's big players, as well as the attraction of alternative crops such as wheat, corn and rice. Nonetheless, in August 2016 the Chinese authorities published a National Oilseed Development Plan, which aims to boost domestic production to 60m tonnes by 2020. The scheme will provide support for oilseed production, processing, technical extension and innovation.
In 2016/17 total acreage was up by an estimated 10% from the previous season, and a further increase is likely in 2017/18, with a portion of land coming from the switching out of corn production in north-eastern areas. Total output in that season is expected to rise to a peak of 14.3m tonnes, up from 13.1m tonnes in the previous year, and the same influences will underpin another increase in output to 15.2m tonnes in 2018/19.
Stocks and prices
Following the exceptionally sharp increases of recent years, global stocks are projected to increase by only a modest amount in 2017/18. Although production is likely to fall in that season, linked to smaller crops in Latin America, large carryover inventories will compensate in the face of another strong rise in consumption. At 120.7m tonnes, global reserves are forecast to be around 2m tonnes larger than in the previous season, although this would be substantially above the five-year average.
Looking below the top-line numbers, US ending stocks on August 31st 2018 are projected to be significantly bigger on a year-on-year basis, although this contrasts with potential falls in Argentina and Brazil. China may also see some destocking following recent years of heavy imports.

Although this market outlook suggests little scope for a price recovery in 2017/18, the supply and demand fundamentals assume that conditions for crop development are favourable in most countries. Should crops falter in any of the main producers, the balance sheet could be significantly tighter and may fuel an increase in prices. Nevertheless, based on our current projections, we see a drop in inventories of a little over 9m tonnes in 2018/19. This is significant, as it would be the first annual contraction in carryovers in seven seasons.
Export quotations (Gulf basis) in the US were moderately firmer in the four weeks to November 2nd, rising by 2% to US$381/tonne, although increases in Chicago futures were more pronounced, at more than 3% over the month. Reports of delays to fieldwork in Brazil have also supported prices, as has stronger international demand for US new crop supplies.
Given that US futures and export prices have moved in a narrow range over the past month, and with few changes to the broader fundamental picture, our forecasts for prices are unchanged. We expect prices to contract slightly in the final quarter of 2017, pushing the full-year average price down by around 3% compared with 2016, to US$377/tonne fob. On the basis of our forecast for a modest rise in global stocks, the potential for price gains in 2018 is very limited. We forecast price growth to be fairly marginal, at 1.2% that year, before climbing more quickly, by 3%, in 2019 as global stocks dip slightly.
However, our production outlook rests on the assumption of normal growing conditions across the full season in leading producing countries. Should crops fall significantly short of expectations in any of the main exporters, especially in Brazil in the early stages of 2018, there could be significant market support, pushing prices well above projected levels.

Sugar
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that global annual sugar consumption will expand by an average of 1.2% in 2017/18-2018/19 (October-September), roughly in line with the average over the past four seasons. Rising demand will continue to be underpinned by population growth and rising incomes in emerging markets, where urbanising populations are gradually adopting the food-and-drink habits of developed-world countries. Sugar plays a key role in this dietary shift, as a sweetener in food and beverages, and as a binding and preserving agent in processed foods. However, a modest slowdown in economic growth in emerging markets (particularly in Asia) will dampen the pace of consumption growth in the coming years. Moreover, heightened awareness about the health implications of excess sugar in diets will put pressure on consumption growth. Amid consumer pressure on the food processing industry to reduce sugar and, in some markets, the introduction of "sin taxes" on sugary products, a gradual shift towards synthetic sweeteners will somewhat lessen demand for sugar. Moreover, owing to the growing supply of starch-based sweeteners in both Asia (where Chinese production is expanding rapidly) and Europe (whose market was liberalised in September 2017), these cheaper alternatives will further limit demand for sugar in the food and drinks industry. Meanwhile, the impact of relatively low global sugar prices on demand will be muted by long-standing domestic pricing policies in many developed countries and protectionist moves in several emerging markets, which will limit the extent to which lower prices pass through to consumers.
Slower GDP growth in China will weigh on sugar demand
Sugar consumption in China is low, at around 11 kg per head compared with an average of 24 kg in developed countries, leaving considerable room for growth. Changing consumer tastes and rising urbanisation will continue to spur demand. However, we expect the pace of consumption growth to moderate as slower economic growth dampens investment and weighs on income growth. This will be compounded by the growing supply of starch-based sweetener, which is a cheaper rival to sugar in the beverages industry, and higher domestic sugar prices, which are a likely consequence of the government's recent move to restrict imports. Amid pressure from domestic producers to support the local industry, the government has reduced permits (to 1m tonnes, roughly half the previous level) and raised duties (from 50% to 95%) on out-of-quota sugar imports. These measures have led to a sharp drop in imports, which fell by around 30% year on year in the first nine months of 2017. A sharp rebound in imports is unlikely under the new tariff regime. However, we doubt that China will be able to scale up domestic production in 2017/18-2018/19 to a level that could fully satisfy its domestic demand and preserve its strategically high level of stocks. It is therefore expected to remain a fairly significant player in the global market.
Consumption in India is forecast to recover as prices normalise
Potential consumption growth in India was constrained in 2015/16 by high post-drought prices and unsupportive policy moves (including demonetisation and the removal of some consumer subsidies). We expect demand to recover somewhat in the coming years as domestic supply improves. The government has come under pressure from industry stakeholders to protect the local industry from a flood of imports, as low global sugar prices and a strong rupee left domestic producers struggling to compete. In response, it has made only modest purchases over the course of the year and raised import duties from 40% to 50% in mid-2017. However, the near-term impact of higher tariffs will be muted by the strong local harvest; as large domestic supplies from the 2017/18 crop hit the market, domestic prices will soften. This, together with rising incomes, will support demand.
Demand growth elsewhere in Asia is threatened by starch-based rivals
Beyond China and India, the outlook for sugar consumption in Asia is positive. Some of the more developed countries, such as Malaysia and South Korea, are likely to grow only slowly as markets mature, but this will be more than offset by populous developing countries such as Indonesia, Thailand and Vietnam. However, demand growth in this region will be somewhat dampened by a gradual shift in the food and drink industry to cheaper, starch-based sweeteners as China (Asia's largest producer) increases production and seeks export markets. Tax measures to ensure that sugar consumption remains within recommended health guidelines could also dampen demand, with Thailand, the Philippines and Indonesia pursuing plans to introduce a so-called sugar tax. This has the potential to put a sharp brake on demand; for example, the introduction of a sugar tax in Mexico in 2015 has contributed to a 12% drop in sugar demand since then. Nevertheless, we assume that any such policies in Asia will be rolled out only slowly over the coming years, amid concerns over restricting growth in the otherwise burgeoning food and drink manufacturing industries.
Health warnings may eventually dent sugar demand in the developed world
Demand growth in the mature EU market is likely to be sluggish in 2017/18-2018/19. Many EU countries already average far higher consumption levels of sugar than recommended by the World Health Organisation (WHO), much of which is hidden in processed foods, and the EU Consumer Organisation is urging the food industry to take notice of WHO guidelines. So far, tax measures have been proposed to curb use in countries including the UK, Spain and Belgium. The policy response is likely to be watered down somewhat by opposition from the powerful food and drink industry, but consumer pressure will lead to a gradual shift in the food industry toward lower sugar levels. More imminently, however, the liberalisation of the EU's sugar regime in September 2017-when production quotas, guaranteed farmgate prices and export caps were abolished-will limit the need for imports and bring European sugar prices (which have historically traded at a premium) closer to the global norm. This should support sugar consumption. However, the production of isoglucose (a starch-based sweetener) was also liberalised in September 2017 and, as in the US, this is likely to steal market share gradually from sugar over the medium term. As well as the adjustment to the new liberalised regime, the UK's exit from the EU is generating uncertainty in the European sugar industry, as the UK is the largest importer of EU sugar.
Changing consumer tastes will boost demand growth in Africa
African consumption will continue to increase, with the bulk of growth coming from expanding indigenous supplies that make sugar more affordable. Several consumers (including Nigeria, the region's largest importer, as well as Kenya and Ghana) are pursuing long-term investment plans in the sugar sector in the hope of becoming self-sufficient. But inefficient domestic supply chains will impede the development of Africa's sugar industries, and aggregate import demand from Sub-Saharan Africa is expected to remain well above 5m t/y in 2017/18-2018/19. Health warnings could temper the pace of consumption growth, with a sugar tax being considered in South Africa. However, as in EU countries, this is meeting resistance from its food and beverage industries, and a widespread roll-out on the sin tax across the continent seems unlikely. Overall, changing consumer tastes and population growth will drive average demand growth of 2.1% per year in 2017/18-2018/19.
Policy changes will shift the dynamics of the global sugar trade
The overhaul of EU sugar policy in 2017 is likely to have a significant effect on global trade patterns as the bloc transitions from being a net importer to becoming a net exporter. We expect this transition to be complete by the end of the 2017/18 season. The smaller producers, particularly in Africa and the Caribbean, which supply the EU under preferential trade deals, will be hardest hit by this shift. Global trade dynamics will also be affected by the introduction of heavy import tariffs in China, with small producers (exempt from the new tariffs) likely to increase their market share. Trade patterns in Asia will also be affected by the liberalisation of sugar sales under Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) free-trade agreement, which comes into effect in 2018. This will probably cause less efficient producers (such as Vietnam) to rely more heavily on imports from elsewhere in the region (probably Thailand). Intra-regional trade is also likely to increase in North America, following a trade deal between the US and Mexico that came into effect in July. This tightened up the rules for Mexican producers and granted Mexico the right of first refusal for the US's above-quota import demand.
These trade deals and policy measures will shift the direction of global trade flows, but trade volumes will ultimately be defined by countries' preference for holding strategic stockpiles of sugar to hedge against future shocks. We therefore expect trade to increase in 2017/18 as countries (notably China) rebuild stocks after several years of low domestic production and relatively high global prices, before trade flows slow in 2018/19 on the back of large local harvests in markets that typically swing between net imports and net exports (notably India).

Supply
After fairly modest growth of 2.1% in 2016/17, and shrinking global supply in the two previous years, world sugar production is forecast to increase by 6.8% in 2017/18, to 179.2m tonnes. Global supply will be supported by strong crop revivals in India and Thailand, following weather-related shocks during the previous harvest, and strong output growth in the EU as producers seek to capitalise on the newly liberalised sugar regime. The world's largest producer, Brazil, will benefit from a second consecutive year of crop-friendly growing conditions in 2017/18 and, with a significant amount of output locked into generously priced forward contracts, the supply of cane to sugar production is likely to remain above historical levels. In 2018/19 we expect global production to remain fairly flat, at 179.3m tonnes, with a slowdown in output from Brazil largely offset by production growth in India and the EU. Our forecast is contingent on normal weather conditions, and even fairly modest disruptions to rainfall patterns pose significant upside or downside risks.
Output growth in Brazil is in prospect as cane supply increases
Brazil is on course for a strong cane harvest, with volumes surpassing market expectations in the early months of the local 2017/18 season (April-March) and quality deteriorating only slightly as the harvest has progressed. With cane supply robust, the main factor shaping Brazil's sugar output will be the supply of cane for sugar vis-à-vis ethanol production. The government reduced a federal ethanol tax in late July, which has the potential to boost ethanol demand and therefore to prompt crushers to divert cane to the fuel industry. With sugar and ethanol prices now hovering around parity, mills are shifting back to ethanol production after several months of favouring sugar. Only 43.8% was used for sugar production in the first half of October, which is in line with the historical average of 44%, but down from above 50% in the first half of 2017. Nevertheless, a significant volume of cane was locked into sugar contracts at a time of higher global prices, and the overall production mix for the 2017/18 local season will probably favour sugar. In 2018/19 the weakness of the Real will support the attractiveness of the export-oriented sugar industry, while only marginal growth in global oil prices will sap demand for biofuels. We expect ethanol and sugar prices in Brazil to remain around parity, which is likely to keep the division of cane in line with historical norms. However, sugar cane fields are ageing and field renewal rates are low. This will begin to take a toll on cane output from 2018/19, thereby reducing the overall cane crush. Sugar production is therefore forecast to moderate to 38.6m tonnes in 2018/19, from 39.6m tonnes in 2017/18.
Strong post-drought crop revival is expected in India
Production in India is poised for a strong recovery following drought-related supply disruptions in 2015/16-2016/17. We expect output to reach 26m tonnes in 2017/18 as growth is supported by stronger yields and an expansion of the crop area under cultivation. The strong harvest is expected despite a slightly sub-average monsoon season in some areas, with farmers' improved resilience to weather dynamics a result of new seed varieties and an expansion of drip irrigation technology. Industry officials in India anticipate another year of strong supply growth in 2018/19, with some forecasts as high as 30m tonnes. A robust harvest in the previous year will, however, weigh on domestic prices, and we think this will somewhat temper appetite in the industry to scale up production. Nevertheless, with higher farmgate prices incentivising farmers to increase cane acreage, and rainfall conditions assumed to be normal, decent cane supply will sustain high levels of sugar production in 2018/19.
EU production will recover as the sugar regime is liberalised
In Europe, sugar output is poised for brisk growth as producers seek to take advantage of the lifting of the EU's 50-year-old sugar quota system. Under the new regime, which came into effect at the start of the 2017/18 season, producers (led by France, Germany and the Benelux countries) will extend their crush seasons, thereby making better use of existing capacity without significant additional investments. Extended crush seasons will be supported by higher supply of beet, with some integrated sugar companies reporting that the area under cultivation has been increased by some 15% year on year in 2017/18. Favourable weather conditions are also supporting the beet crop, with the authorities in France projecting a record high harvest in 2017/18. We expect EU production to reach 18.8m tonnes in 2018/19, which will surpass EU demand and spur export growth. Higher supply and greater efficiency should leave the region's main producers able to withstand lower prices as the price of European sugar falls closer to the global average.
In Russia, sugar production is expected to remain robust, following the significant investment in the modernisation of sugar factories in recent years. The ensuing surplus will support Russia's emergence as a notable exporter as the government seeks to prevent stock build-ups from depressing domestic prices and deterring planting. However, we think that the authorities' forecast that exports will reach almost 1m t/y is overoptimistic, owing to soft demand for imports in Central Asia (Russia's main market) and the country's limited output of high-value sugar (which is in higher demand globally).
Output in Thailand is recovering from El Niño's long reach
In Thailand, favourable rainfall patterns will support a bumper harvest in 2017/18 of 11.9m tonnes. Assuming that rainfall normalises in 2018/19, we forecast a more moderate, albeit still decent, output of 10.5m tonnes. We have increased this forecast slightly, on the expectation that producers will also be incentivised by export opportunities to other Asian markets, where demand is rising and Thai sugar enjoys favourable access under the ASEAN free-trade arrangement. Following a challenge by Brazil, which argued that Thailand was violating World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules on free competition, the Thai government has agreed to remove production subsidies in December 2017. This will inflate costs, but we do not expect it to erode the country's competitiveness entirely. Increasing mechanis-ation will help to boost yields, and the sugar cane area in Thailand will continue to expand as farmers turn away from less profitable rice crops. However, the sugar industry's exposure to weather-related shocks is gradually increasing as production moves towards the more drought-prone interior regions. This signals that the risks to our Thai production forecasts are increasing.
A major recovery in China's sugar sector appears unlikely for now
China's sugar output has fallen sharply in recent years, owing to unfavourable weather and the impact of rapidly rising costs for labour, land and farm machinery. Amid political pressure from the local industry, some government support has been forthcoming in the form of input subsidies and soft loans, and the government has raised duties on out-of-quota sugar imports in a bid to protect local producers from cheaper imports. These measures will support the profitability of the local industry and should spur some investment, but we doubt that they will lead to a significant surge in domestic supply growth. The sector is dominated by smallholder farmers, labour costs are high and sugar cane areas do not lend themselves to mechanisation. Indeed, the cost of producing sugar cane in China is almost double that in Thailand, and this will deter investment. The government is attempting to encourage consolidation among the many disparate industry players in the country's main sugar region of Guangxi in an attempt to improve its competitiveness. However, similar moves in the past, for example in the soy market, have not yielded impressive results, and high local prices will probably allow some small, inefficient players to remain in the market. We do not, therefore, expect output to rise by the 10% per year that would be needed for the state to meet its medium-term production goals. However, given more favourable growing conditions (compared at least with the El Niño-linked dry conditions of 2015/16-2016/17), we expect output to rise to an average of 10.4m t/y in 2017/18-2018/19.

Stocks and prices
After successive supply deficits and a period of relatively high global prices, global sugar stocks shrank to 87.4m tonnes at end-2016/17. We expect the stocks to recover to 96.5m tonnes at end-2018/19 as the market swings back into surplus. The market surplus is forecast to reach 5.7m tonnes in 2017/18, amid bumper harvests from key producers and lacklustre demand growth, before moderating to 3.4m tonnes in 2018/19 as output remains flat and consumption accelerates slightly. Although overall stocks will remain comfortable (equivalent to an average of 54.3% of annual consumption in 2017/18-2018/19), the uneven distribution of these stocks means that reserves will not always be available to the market, and occasional supply squeezes are possible.

The latest sugar price rally has peaked
After peaking at over 23 US cents/lb in late 2016, global sugar prices fell by 30% over the first half of 2017, before stabilising in the third quarter, at 14.5 US cents/lb. In part, this reflects a market correction after overshooting in late 2016, with speculative investors unwinding the long positions that they had adopted during the price boom. More fundamentally, crop-friendly weather conditions in key producer markets are fuelling expectations of a global sugar surplus in the coming years, and policy moves to restrict import dependence in key consumers (notably, China, India and Europe) have further weakened market sentiment. Amid oversupply in the global market, we expect prices to average 16 US cent/lb in 2017, down by 11% on the previous year.
Beyond 2017, we expect prices to drift higher, to between 15.5 US cents/lb and 16.5 US cents/lb in 2018-19. This modest price recovery from the nadir of mid-2017 will be driven largely by market tightening from 2018 as the crucial Brazilian market diverts more cane to ethanol production over the coming years and therefore produces less sugar. A swing to ethanol that is substantial enough to bring the global sugar market into balance seems unlikely, however, and the prospects of global oversupply will probably prevent a more significant rebound to prices. Nonetheless, expectations of global surpluses are based on the assumptions of normal weather conditions in all producing countries and there therefore remains a risk of sharp supply shocks if crop conditions change. The sugar trading market is seemingly pricing in little risk at the moment, but, as the marker tightens in 2018/19, we think that this will change. Higher risk premiums will therefore probably provide some support to prices in 2019.

Sunflowerseed oil
Demand
The 2016/17 season has seen a remarkable 15% increase in global sunflowerseed oil consumption. The Economist Intelligence Unit has nudged up its estimate for sunflowerseed oil consumption in 2016/17 slightly, to 18.2m tonnes (18.1m tonnes previously). This growth reflects the substantial discounts of sunflower-seed oil to other oils. These discounts continue to be large, and early signs point towards sustained growth from this high base in 2017/18. However, there is a risk that insufficient availability will weigh on demand growth that season. We currently expect global consumption to increase by a more modest 2.7% in 2017/18, to 18.7m tonnes. Consumption is likely to exceed 19m tonnes in 2018/19, although this relies on sunflowerseed oil maintaining its competitive position against other oils.
Sunflowerseed oil's improving price competitiveness will boost EU usage
EU consumption of sunflowerseed oil in 2016/17 continues to surprise. The most recent data suggests that consumption reached almost 4.5m tonnes. Given the increasing discounts to rapeseed and soybean oils, consumption in the 2017/18 season is getting off to a good start. At this stage, we are forecasting a slight rise in EU consumption to just over 4.5m tonnes. Despite the higher local availabillty, this consumption total will continue to rely on sizeable imports of sunflowerseed oil. The recent reductions in likely ouput in Russia and the Ukraine pose a risk to this forecast. Given its favourable consumer image, demand should continue to grow in 2018/19 provided there is adequate availability.
Russian consumption will rise modestly as the economy emerges from recession
In Russia, higher local availability of sunflowerseed oil encouraged increased local consumption. We have maintained our estimate for Russian sunflower-seed oil consumption of 2.5m tonnes in 2016/17, reflecting robust growth of 8.5%. We expect local availability to tighten slightly in 2017/18, which may be reflected in local prices; however, we expect supply to remain comfortable enough to support continued demand growth, of 1.6%. In addition, this forecast remains contingent on Russia's continued economic recovery, with any setback in overall growth likely to weigh on consumption. In 2018/19 we expect demand growth to be sustained, at 3.7%, assuming good local availability.
Robust GDP growth and shifting preferences will boost India's usage
Indian imports of sunflowerseed have continued to run at high levels in the third quarter of 2017. We estimate that Indian consumption rose by nearly 33% that season, to 2.2m tonnes; this will boost stocks at the start of 2017/18, supporting continued demand growth that season. The growing consumer preference for sunflowerseed oil, especially in the south of India, and sustained economic growth should also be positive for demand although the recent increase in import duties on vegetable oils (including sunflowerseed oil) will, to a degree, constrain the growth rate. We think that 2017/18 consumption could exceed 2.3m tonnes with further growth in 2018/19.
Turkish consumption will increase in 2017/18-2018/19
Many countries have been increasing their purchases of sunflowerseed oil to take advantage of competitive prices. Supplies are likely to remain comfortable throughout the forecast period, which will continue this trend. Countries increasing their use of sunflowerseed oil include Turkey, Iran, Iraq and Egypt, as well as several smaller countries. Growth in consumption in these "other" countries will moderate in 2017/18, following a robust performance in 2016/17.

Supply
Global sunflowerseed oil production in 2016/17 rose by an estimated 15.4% to 18.4m tonnes, by far the highest level on record by far. The outlook for the 2017/18 sunflowerseed crop is mixed. The most recent estimates indicate that output in Russia and the Ukraine will not meet earlier expectations. This is partially offset by a higher estimate for the EU, but overall the likely global harvest will be smaller than previously forecast. Nonetheless, it remains a large crop by recent standards. In 2017/18 sunflowerseed oil output could approach the previous season's record; however, this relies on a reduction in sunflowerseed stocks and may turn out to be too optimistic. Our tentative projections suggest sufficient seed availability in 2018/19 to rebuild stocks and allow for an expansion of sunflowerseed oil output, to 18.8m tonnes.
Ukraine's 2016/17 sunflowerseed harvest exceeds our expectations
We estimate that Ukrainian sunflowerseed oil output jumped by over 25% in 2016/17, to a total of 6.3m tonnes. Harvesting of the 2017/18 sunflowerseed crop is in its final phase, and yields from the later harvested area have been disappointing. This has prompted a further reduction in our harvest estimate to 13.5m tonnes. However, with relatively plentiful sunflowerseed stocks carried over, this is not likely to have an immediate impact on crush rates; however, for the season as a whole, crushing will be lower in year-on-year terms. We forecast sunflowerseed oil production to fall to just below 6m tonnes in 2017/18. Local analysts suggest that both the harvest and sunflowerseed oil could turn out even lower than this. Although the 2018/19 outlook is still provisional, the industry's strong expansion in recent years should ensure ample seed availability despite concerns about crop rotations. We expect output in 2018/19 to rise to nearly 6.2m tonnes, slightly lower than the record outturn in 2016/17.
Sunflowerseed will remain a popular crop in Russia
In Russia, sunflowerseed crushing has also been running at high levels, and the 2016/17 outturn is likely to reach 4.5m tonnes, up by 15.2% year on year. Harvest prospects have also been downgraded here, reflecting both a lower planted area and signficantly lower yields than previously expected. Our current estimate is for a crop of 11.4m tonnes, although some local estimates are as low as 11m tonnes. With more than sufficient crush capacity in Russia, output tends to be limited by market availability for the oil. We forecast a modest rise in sunflowerseed oil output, to almost 4.6m tonnes in 2017/18. Export availability of sunflowerseed will be only around half of that recorded in 2016/17.
Estimates for the EU 2016/17 sunflowerseed harvest have improved
The production of sunflowerseed oil in the EU looks to have set a new record at just over 3.2m tonnes. A large local crop and good demand following the shortfall in rapeseed supplies underpin this new level. The more optimistic outlook for the 2017/18 sunflowerseed harvest has been maintained on account of higher estimates for Spain and France. We have increased our harvest estimate to 8.7m tonnes (8.5m tonnes previously). Better availability will allow higher levels of crushing, and we have increased our forecast for 2017/18 sunflowerseed oil output to 3.3m tonnes (3.2m tonnes previously).
Prospects for Argentina's crop remain good, but downside risks are mounting
In Argentina, we maintain our estimate that 2016/17 sunflowerseed oil production has reached 1.3m tonnes. We expect that the sunflowerseed area will expand for the 2017/18 season. Sowings got off to a good start, although wet conditions have hampered later plantings. We have made a small reduction to our estimate of sunflowerseed production to reflect the likely loss in area although the output will still be significantly higher than the 2016/17 harvest. Despite the lower harvest estimate, we still expect that sunflowerseed oil production will exceed 1.4m tonnes in both 2017/18 and 2018/19. Export availability of sunflowerseed in 2017/18 will also be higher than 2016/17 even with the reduced crop estimate.

Stocks and prices
At the end of the 2016/17 season, sunflowerseed oil stocks were ample both in absolute terms and relative to consumption. Sunflowerseed stocks fell during 2016/17 and ended the season below average levels. We expect the market to register a deficit in 2017/18 especially following the reductions in expected output recorded in this issue. Sunflowerseed oil stocks look likely to fall below normal levels. However, even this outcome assumes a significant drawdown of sunflowerseed stocks, to low levels. Indeed, the tightening of sunflowerseed stocks may be sufficient to cause a reduction in sunflowerseed crushing from the levels currently forecast. Even allowing for a normal production season in 2018/19, sunflowerseed oil stocks are likely to remain tight.

Upward pressure on prices will be felt in the coming months
Sunflowerseed oil prices eased in October under pressure from high levels of production. With the global market deficit set to widen in 2017/18, prices should start to edge up over the coming months. We expect this upward trend to persist into the 2018/19 season. The strength of rapeseed prices should also be positive for sunflowerseed oil values. Price rises are likely to be comparatively small but persistent, bringing average prices up to almost US$1,000 by the end of the 2018/19 season.

Tea
Demand
Global tea consumption is growing steadily, driven mainly by China, which accounts for one-third of world tea consumption and is consuming ever-greater quantities of green tea. However, demand is also growing in other major consuming regions, including India and the US. Demand for tea is less exposed to economic cycles than other commodities, reflecting its low cost, meaning that tea demand will be driven primarily by demographics. This explains why The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast rates for tea consumption growth, of 3.8% a year on average in 2018-19, are relatively high and in line with the long-term historical average. It also explains why our demand-side forecasts tend to remain relatively stable, since tea consumption is determined by structural factors to a much greater degree than other beverages. Global demand for black tea will continue to rise, but the pace of growth will be outstripped by that for green tea, fruit tea, herbal tea, rooibos (from South Africa), purple tea (mainly from Kenya) and high-end organic tea, reflecting their greater reported health benefits and heavy marketing. Iced tea and "ready to drink" tea beverages account for a small share of the tea market but have enjoyed rapid growth in sales-even in traditional markets such as China-which will also contribute to demand growth.
Tea demand will benefit from changing consumer habits
The main tea-consuming countries are the largest producers, with a rising share of output retained for domestic consumption. In producing countries, tea will benefit from changing consumption habits related to rising incomes, but in most places will remain a consumer staple, despite a steady increase in consumption of other beverages, including coffee. Combined with favourable demographics, consumption growth in producing countries should rise further. The fact that a smaller share of tea than coffee is consumed in the out-of-home sector-owing partially to customer perceptions that tea in cafés offers less value for money-will shield tea consumption from adverse economic developments, which tend to have less of an impact on at-home consumption.
Both India and China will continue to see robust demand growth in 2017-18
Tea consumption is dominated by Asia, particularly China and India, which together accounted for an estimated 59% of global demand in 2017, up from 48% in 2010. In China, we expect the government's efforts to rein in credit growth to contribute to an economic slowdown from 2018, but this will have only a muted impact on tea consumption growth, which is expected to rise by 4% per year, compared with 5% in 2017. Nonetheless, demand will remain strong compared with many other markets, helping to underpin continued firm global tea consumption growth. Moreover, this forecast is relatively cautious, with the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) projecting average annual Chinese demand growth of 15% until 2024, suggesting an upside risk to our forecasts. Average consumption per head stands at just over 1 kg/year, ranking China just 14th in the world. This leaves significant room for growth, particularly as only around 35% of the population drink tea.
Given that tea is regarded as a traditional drink, it will suffer from mounting com-petition from coffee and soft-drink retailers, owing to a growing preference for these beverages among younger Chinese consumers. Moreover, younger segments of the population are also showing a preference for black tea over green tea (black tea consumption has risen by an average of 40% per year since 2002, while green tea consumption has risen more gradually), which should bolster demand for black tea, albeit from a low base. Other changes in consumer habits will also affect tea sales, with greater demand for teabags globally (these are less wasteful than loose-leaf tea). However, given the importance attached to the quality of tea, sales of leaf teas will continue to dominate the local market.
In India, strong economic growth will be accompanied by higher household spending and firm consumer confidence, which will support annual average growth in tea consumption of 6.4% in 2018-19, marginally lower than estimated growth of 6.5% in 2017. Structurally, the Indian market has significant potential-aside from its sheer size, average consumption per head is even lower than in China, at just 740 g per year, which bodes well for longer-term demand growth. Currently, the out-of-home sector accounts for just under 50% of tea consumption, compared with 85% of the coffee market. The expansion of tea bars across many cities aims to lift this share, as well as fuelling overall tea consumption growth.
Structural constraints will hamper tea consumption growth in many markets
Demand in some large consuming countries will be hampered in 2018-19 by market saturation and weakening demographics. Indeed, the FAO forecasts an overall contraction until 2024 in many EU markets (which together account for just under 5% of global consumption), despite a firmer economic performance, as well as in Russia (2.5% of global consumption). Turkey, which also accounts for around 5% of global consumption, has a particularly saturated market, with the highest consumption of tea per head in the world by some margin. The EU also registers some of the world's highest levels, particularly in the UK and Ireland. Although our forecasts anticipate further growth in demand, reflecting continued population growth and steady growth in private consumption, the pace will be fairly mild. We forecast average annual growth in tea demand in 2018-19 of 1.9% in the EU and 0.4% in Turkey. Russian demand growth will be stronger, at an average of 2.5% per year, but is flattered by a weak base of comparison following a sharp decline in consump-tion in 2013-16.
There is plenty of room for market growth in the US
The US is a small market for tea, accounting for less than 2.5% of global consumption, and consumption per head is low. However, with most of the larger tea markets dominated by loose-leaf tea, the US remains one of the most important single markets for instant tea and iced tea. We expect demand to increase by an annual average of 2.6% in 2018-19, partly reflecting our fairly upbeat forecast for economic growth. Health concerns will also sustain demand for tea, with a gradual shift away from carbonated beverages and towards those perceived as healthier, including tea.
New tea markets are emerging
Export data from tea-producing countries reveal that new markets for tea are emerging, with the number of countries buying tea at the major auction houses in Asia and Africa on the rise. Demand from these new joiners in the tea market, mainly faster-growing emerging countries, is set to increase in 2018-19, underpinning our forecast for average consumption growth of 2.5% a year across all "other" countries, which together account for 18% of global consumption.

Supply
After an estimated 1.7% contraction in global tea production in 2017-the first fall in output since our data series (which is based on historical data from the FAO) began in 2000-tea production is forecast to recover in 2018-19, rising by 3.5% and 2.1% respectively. However, these growth rates remain weak by historical comparison; annual growth in tea output averaged 4.4% in 2004-14. Other than weather concerns, several structural factors will prevent faster production growth. In inflation-adjusted terms, farmers' profits are lower than in past decades because of the higher cost of inputs, and this has resulted in a fall in investment. Notwithstanding a recent softening of the US dollar, many currencies will remain comparatively weak against the dollar in 2018-19, which will hamper operating conditions for farmers.
Much of the increase in global tea production in 2018-19 will come from a rise in green tea output, where growth has outpaced black tea by a significant margin in recent years. Green tea now accounts for one-third of total global tea production, compared with less than one-quarter a decade ago. This mainly reflects the rise in tea production in China, where loose-leaf green tea accounts for 68% of domestic production, and in Vietnam, where it now represents 55% of tea output, compared with 43% a decade ago.
As in 2016, adverse weather will harm Chinese tea production in 2017
China experienced the second consecutive year of disappointing tea production growth in 2017. We estimate that output expanded by 2.2%, after heavy rains hit several of the large tea-producing provinces in southern China, including Hunan, Jiangxi and Zhejiang, in June. The government stated that over 750,000 ha of crops were damaged, and although it made no direct reference to tea, we believe that production was affected. The rains were followed by extremely hot weather in some areas (including parts of Zhejiang), which will also have hampered production.
Even on the assumption that weather conditions will improve in 2018-19, prod-uction growth is forecast to slow further, to an annual average of 2%. Under-lying economic growth will slow gradually during 2018 as the govern-ment takes action to bring debt levels under control, and is not projected to accelerate significantly in 2019. We expect government efforts to modernise the agri-cultural sector-through large-scale lending from the state-owned Agricultural Development Bank of China-to progress slowly, with some Chinese tea investors instead seeking to expand production overseas rather than in China (talks are under way to discuss the possibility of a 6,000-ha tea plantation in the Philippines). These factors will combine to undermine growth in tea output.
Beyond the forecast period there is scope for a return to firmer rates of tea production growth. The authorities are engaged in efforts to lift product quality and quantity in order to boost exports (only about 15% of tea production was exported in 2016). Given that China's average yield per hectare is low by global standards (at 785 kg in 2012-14, compared with 2,085 kg in India and 2,105 kg in Kenya), there is certainly potential for gains in productivity.
India's tea production will continue to grow in 2018 and 2019
We estimate tea production growth of 3.3% in India in 2017. Output fell in the first quarter of 2017, reflecting dry conditions in Assam (India's largest tea-growing state), as well as in Bengal and parts of southern India, but weather conditions improved subsequently. Assuming supportive weather conditions in 2018-19, we expect tea production to continue to rise, albeit more gradually. Continued efforts to channel funding to tea growers will provide support, but several structural factors will hold back production. There has been little progress on reforms to boost foreign direct investment in several sectors, including agriculture. Furthermore, India's tea bushes are old: nearly 40% of existing bushes are over 50 years old, compared with Kenya, where fewer than 30% are over 40 years old, and Vietnam, where the entire tea plantation is less than 20 years old. Replanting has progressed slowly and rising input costs have eroded profits, implying that in the long term India may struggle to increase growth as significantly as other major producers. We forecast average growth in tea production of 2% per year in 2018-19.
High costs will prevent a significant recovery in Sri Lanka's 2018-19 output
We estimate a double-digit decline in tea output in Sri Lanka in 2017, reflecting recent torrential rain that caused landslides and the worst flooding in over a decade. The authorities have said that this will affect tea output, as the worst-affected areas were tea-growing regions in the south of the country. Many of the 400,000 farmers, who account for 70% of national tea output, saw their bushes submerged by muddy water. Sri Lanka's tea production is forecast to rise in 2018, by 5.8%, but this will largely reflect a cyclical recovery after several disappointing years. As in India, there are several structural hurdles that will hamper growth, even assuming that weather conditions improve. Despite some replanting as a result of a 20% increase in subsidies to small tea farmers, the replanting rate is not yet sufficiently high to lead to a significant and sustained increase in output. In addition, there are local reports that fertiliser application has been low, and there is a continued risk of industrial unrest. Sharp wage rises and low mechanisation mean that production costs in Sri Lanka are some of the highest among the world's main tea producers. These factors explain why our projection for tea production growth in 2019 (1.8%) is relatively weak.
Moreover, the main customers for Sri Lankan tea-Russia, Turkey, Iran and Syria-have all experienced economic turbulence in recent years. Economic conditions are expected to improve markedly in Iran with the lifting of sanctions, and to a lesser degree in Russia and Turkey, but this is unlikely to be enough to boost demand for Sri Lankan tea significantly. Most of the country's tea is loose leaf, rather than mass-produced tea bags, which limits the extent to which the country can diversify its tea export market base towards Europe and the US. The Ministry of Plantation Industries has stated that it is considering a proposal to allow tea imports for blending in an attempt to boost export potential, and the Tea Board is continuing to urge the government to take measures to make the tea industry more competitive, but it is unclear if there is sufficient support domestically to push the measure through, as there is a strong perception among farmers that this would undermine local production.
A partial recovery in output is likely in Kenya in 2018-19
After a massive jump in tea production in Kenya in 2016, with output hitting an all-time high of 473,000 tonnes, weather conditions deteriorated sharply in 2017, with a renewed and persistent dry spell damaging tea plantations. Kenya's agriculture minister has stated that tea output is likely to fall by 12%, but our estimate envisages a much sharper drop, of 30%, given that production was down by about one-third in the first eight months of the year. Although tea production is forecast to stage a partial recovery in 2018-19, rising by 24.2% and 4.9% respectively, output levels even in 2019 will remain relatively weak. Periodic industrial activity in the sector over pay disputes, combined with a change in the tea levy on farmers, so that it is based on the value rather than the volume of sales, will also undermine profitability in the medium term. Although the government has pledged to support small farmers and reduce the tax burden, conflicting interests and a lack of funds will hinder progress.

Investment will have an impact beyond our forecast period
Many countries have been investing to stimulate tea production, including large producers such as India (which is raising subsidies for plantation rejuvenation), Kenya (where processing plants are being expanded and production is being diversified to non-black varieties) and China (which is concentrating on raising black tea output for export), and even a minor producer, Ethiopia (where Saudi investment is seeking to expand tea production). Smaller producers, such as Tanzania, Uganda, Rwanda and Bangladesh, have also seen renewed investment. However, we assume that some of these investment plans will be scaled back or suspended altogether, while others will progress only slowly, reflecting overambitious investment plans, bureaucratic hurdles and broader concerns about long-term global oversupply. In addition, it takes three to five years for a tea bush to become commercially productive, so the impact on output of recent price falls will be evident only after the forecast period.
Stocks and prices
We estimate a fourth consecutive year of market deficits in 2017, reflecting increasing consumption and a contraction in output from several of the main tea-producing countries. We expect consumption growth to outstrip production growth during 2018-19, meaning that we forecast deepening market deficits in those years.
Given that there is no global measure of total tea stocks, it is impossible to gauge how significantly these widening market deficits will affect stock levels. The fact that prices fell during 2015-16 despite market deficits in both years indicates that stock movements have only a limited effect on prices, not least because much of the increase in consumption and production is the result of consumption and output in China, which mainly consists of green tea. Although some of the production data are broken down into green and black tea, the consumption data are not, which prevents a calculation of the market balance in relation to black tea.

Only a fraction of the increase in production will be exported, and even this will not be in any of the three markets (Colombo, Kolkata and Mombasa) where our average tea price is measured. Prices in these markets respond to demand and supply dynamics in Sri Lanka, India and Kenya respectively (essentially, black tea). Often prices diverge between these three markets on the back of local developments that have an impact on supply and demand in the respective auction or to reflect the quality of tea offered at each auction. As an example, prices at the Colombo and Mombasa auctions have risen sharply in 2017 (with the former hitting record levels of US$4/kg as production has slumped), while prices at the Kolkata auction have remained similar to their year-earlier levels for much of the year. Although some of the auction houses are becoming digitised, we do not believe that the tea market will attract sufficient interest from investors to make price dynamics vulnerable to broader global macroeconomic changes (there is no futures market). Prices will therefore remain volatile and largely led by local supply-and-demand factors.
Prices will retreat slightly in 2018-19
We estimate a full-year average price of US$3.09/kg in 2017, a 17.2% year-on-year increase, reflecting the weak outlook for production and continued firm consumption growth. Although the market deficit will remain large in 2018-19, recovering production is expected to reduce prices by 2.8%, to an average of US$3/kg in 2018, and by a further 6.3% in 2019, to US$2.81/kg.

Wheat
Demand
Global wheat consumption has increased strongly in the past 50 years, rising from less than 250m tonnes/year (t/y) in the early 1960s to more than 700m t/y in recent years. Helped by solid gains in developing countries, growth was particularly rapid in the three decades to 1990, rising by an average of 3% a year, before slowing slightly since then. Although stronger demand for wheat has mainly been tied to a rising global population, it should also be noted that wheat demand growth has persistently outpaced population growth. Wheat's popularity in diets has been sustained, as has its use as an animal feed ingredient. A small proportion is also used for brewing and for the manufacture of starch and ethanol. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global consumption to rise marginally, by 0.5%, to nearly 739m tonnes in 2017/18. Although wheat use for food is expected to increase once again, in line with the recent trend, it appears likely that world feed consumption will decline, owing partly to competition from alternative products. A similar pattern is expected in 2018/19. Although use for feed is expected to slip back further, a rise for milling and food use should see total demand increase by 0.4%, to 742m tonnes.
Rising food use is being driven by emerging and developing markets
Annual growth in world food-wheat consumption has remained relatively consistent over the past decade or so, with increases averaging 1.4% a year. Urbanisation, together with shifts in diets and incomes, has also resulted in greater consumption of wheat-based convenience foods such as noodles, as well as Western-style bakery products, which are best produced using high-quality wheat and flour. With much of the growth in demand stemming from countries outside the main wheat-producing belts, rising demand for milling wheat and flour has been accompanied by an increase in imports, with world trade expanding in most years. Although diets in the fastest-growing consumer markets are expected to diversify as incomes improve, to include additional animal proteins, dairy products and oil crops, in general there has been little evidence of slowing food wheat demand in recent years. We therefore expect world food use to rise by 1.5% in 2017/18, exceeding 500m tonnes for the first time. Growth will be driven mostly by India, Indonesia and much of Sub-Saharan Africa. These trends are well established and are expected to continue into 2018/19, when food consumption could rise to 511m tonnes.
World feed use is forecast at a higher than usual level in 2016/17
Wheat contains high levels of starch, which makes it a good, energy-rich ingredient for livestock feed. Demand for feed wheat shows more annual variation than that for food-use wheat, and is highly dependent on price and underlying quality considerations. Direct, on-farm feed use also varies from one year to the next, depending on the size and quality of the crop in a particular season. Use for feed has averaged around 141m t/y during the past five years. Wheat is the world's second most important feed grain, although it is typically equivalent to one-quarter of feed-use of maize, with annual wheat use roughly matching that of barley, sorghum, oats and rye combined. The EU is typically the world's largest consumer of feed quality wheat, with consumption averaging close to 57m tonnes in recent seasons-around 40% of the world total. Other large users include Russia, with demand of around 17m tonnes, China (15m tonnes) and the US (5m tonnes). Depending on price, feed manufacturers in Asia, including South Korea, Indonesia and the Philippines, have also incorporated relatively large amounts into feed rations in recent years.
Assuming strong competition from maize-especially in the EU, China and the US-we expect use for livestock feed to fall back by 3.7% year on year in 2017/18, to around 144m tonnes. The figure for Canada is also forecast to be sharply lower than last year, dropping by about half, to 3m tonnes, on much smaller feed grade supplies. At the moment, we forecast a modest decline in global demand for feed-grade wheat in 2018/19, to around 144m tonnes. The drop stems mainly from a projected small decline in Russia, where a smaller crop is likely to limit discretionary on-farm feeding.
Mexico is eyeing wheat imports from Argentina
Mexico's phytosanitary authority recently finalised a long-awaited protocol al-lowing for the import of wheat from Argentina. A group of millers have already contracted a trial shipment, due to be loaded later next month, which will first be assessed for quality before further purchases are considered. Although there is talk that the move is in some way linked to the ongoing North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA) renegotiations, private importers have indicated that the deal instead reflects very competitive pricing in Argentina, which is currently the world's cheapest origin. Indeed, local users have proven quite willing to switch origins in recent years, sourcing a number of cargoes from the Black Sea and occasionally the EU. Compared with maize and sorghum, Mexico's wheat import market is much more diversified. However, millers still typically only use such wheats for blending with US supplies, which still account for as much as 75% of overseas purchases. Mexico typically imports around two-thirds of its annual needs, with domestic consumption increasing steadily in recent decades, forecast at around 7.8m tonnes in 2017/18. Although a series of anti-obesity campaigns have curbed demand for cakes, pastries and cookies in the past few years, production of other, plainer bread products remains strong, and population growth continues to drive demand.
