Supply
World wheat production has reached unprecedented levels in recent seasons, with cumulative output hitting new highs each year between 2013/14 and 2016/17. Production gains have stemmed mainly from the Black Sea region, predominantly in Russia, but China, India and parts of Latin America have also contributed bigger crops. The harvested area has increased across many parts of the globe, and average yields have also risen, despite concerns about years of underinvestment in wheat seed technology. However, given recent spells of poor weather across wheat belts in both hemispheres, the recent growth trend is expected to come to a halt. In 2017/18 we forecast global wheat production to decline by 0.8% year on year, to 749m tonnes, owing largely to lower output from the US, Canada and Australia. Russia's massive 2017/18 crop has diverted some attention away from the fact that supplies of the best quality, high-protein wheats from North America and parts of Europe will be below average levels and will therefore command a price premium. The 2018/19 sowing season is now coming to an end in parts of the northern hemisphere. With prices at relatively low levels, there is unlikely to be much incentive for farmers to increase plantings. Crop rotation needs will again be important, but in countries where there are few alternatives, seeded area is unlikely to show much year-on-year change. Assuming average yields, the world crop is forecast to contract by another 0.9% in 2018/19, to 742m tonnes.
After a small EU crop last year, output should rise in 2017/18
Despite a mixed year for the main EU wheat growers, the 2017/18 crop is expected to be slightly larger than average. We have lifted our production forecast by a further 1.4m tonnes, to a total of 151.5m tonnes, incorporating the latest official harvest data. Final results from the French harvest, which accounts for around one-quarter of the bloc's total output, were better than previously reported, with yields rebounding strongly from the previous season's sub-par results. Survey results have also confirmed its good quality, with a much higher percentage than last year meeting milling specifications. In contrast, a wet finish to the German harvest has led to a series of quality downgrades in key northern export-producing areas. As most of the EU crop is winter sown, producers are now wrapping up 2018/19 planting in some parts. Farmers have again expressed concerns about market prices currently being lower than production costs. Some planted area may be switched to attractively priced rapeseed, but given the lack of viable alternatives for many farmers, we do not expect much change in plantings for next year's harvest. Assuming normal yields, output is likely to be in line with the average, at 148m tonnes.
An enormous crop in Russia
The size of this season's winter wheat crop in Russia has caught market observers by surprise. With farmers continuing to report astounding yields, local production estimates increased on an almost daily basis at some points in the summer. Yields have been above or in line with record levels in all the major growing areas, with a particularly sharp improvement noted in the Volga District. Excellent yields are attributed mainly to abundant springtime rains, but with the crops also well established after a successful period of overwintering. We maintain our forecast that Russia's 2017/18 wheat outturn will rise by nearly 13% year on year, to a record 82m tonnes. Attention is now beginning to switch to 2018/19 prospects. Recent dry weather in southern areas has not been ideal for early crop establishment but has allowed for a quick start to planting, and winter sowings stand to beat the official target again. Assuming that yields are similar to the recent trend, but down from the record-breaking results achieved this year, we expect 2018/19 output to decline by around 12%, to 72m tonnes, which is still an impressive outturn.
US wheat production fell sharply in 2017/18
US all-wheat production in 2017/18 totals 47.4m tonnes, according to the Small Grains Summary of the US Department of Agriculture (USDA). This is slightly above earlier estimates but still down by 25% year on year, and at a fifteen-season low. The sharp drop in output mainly reflects a pullback in plantings, with the smallest harvested area in almost 130 years. The winter wheat outturn was 34.5m tonnes (down by 24% year on year), with durum at 1.5m tonnes (down by 47%) and other spring varieties at 10.7m tonnes (down by 27%). Sowing of next season's winter wheat crop was almost done by the first week of November, only slightly slower than average. Reflecting a dry start to the season in some states, only 52% of the crop had emerged in good or excellent condition, 6 percentage points lower than at the same point a year ago. Depressed prices and limited potential for profits mean that another drop in winter and spring plantings is now likely. Assuming better overall yields, however, mainly for spring-sown wheat, 2018/19 production is forecast to rise by 4.9%, to 49.7m tonnes, about 11% below the previous five-year average.
China's wheat support policies are starting to change
Latest official data from China confirmed a small rise in 2017/18 wheat production, as an improvement in yields more than compensated for a minor reduction in harvested area. After shortfalls in high-quality wheat the year before, Ministry of Agriculture officials reported far fewer problems with excessive moisture and disease this season. High- and low-gluten wheat varieties, needed to produce Western style breads and cakes, accounted for almost 28% of this year's crop, up by nearly 3 percentage points from 2016/17. After focusing first on efforts to realign cotton, maize, rapeseed and soybean markets with international prices, authorities are now beginning to tweak foodgrain price support policies too. Following changes to rice subsidy programmes last year, the government recently announced a 2.5% reduction in the 2018/19 minimum state purchase price for wheat, the first such cut since the initiative was introduced 11 years ago. Although unusual, next year's minimum price of Rmb2,300/tonne (US$348/tonne) is still about double the current price of US winter wheat and around US$100/tonne above milling wheat import prices, including freight costs. However, it must be stressed that imports are, in effect, limited by the country's tariff rate quota (TRQ), under which the private sector is only eligible to buy slightly less than 1m tonnes at the reduced 1% import duty. The policy announcement was not a big surprise and had been well-flagged by party officials in recent months.
With winter wheat planting for next year's crop already mostly finished, the policy shift is unlikely to have much of an impact for 2018/19. Sowings are expected to stay relatively high, more or less unchanged from the year before, with production tentatively placed at 129m tonnes. The announcement could, however, mark the start of some wider-ranging reforms in the years ahead as the government looks to unwind its excessively large wheat stocks, which have been built up in recent years. Should the lower support price feed through into lower market values for common wheat, a wider price differential could encourage farmers to further expand production of the higher-quality wheats in the years ahead. This could have some implications for imports, which have ranged from 1.9m tonnes to 6.8m tonnes during the past five years, and are mostly used to plug shortfalls in local high-quality wheat supplies.
Wheat is back in favour with Argentinian farmers
In Argentina, policy changes made under the government that came into power in late 2015, including exchange-rate liberalisation and the removal of export quotas and taxes, have greatly incentivised the country's wheat farmers. Planting of the 2017/18 crop was completed by late August, but with the planted area falling short of earlier expectations. Flooding prevented access to low-lying fields across southern parts of Buenos Aires and La Pampa provinces, where as much as 150,000 ha of intended wheat area was thought to have gone unseeded. Some local sources recently estimated that about half of the country's total wheat area had been affected by excessive water this season, which hindered farmers' ability to control disease and apply fertilisers. With dryness also persisting in more northerly areas, 2017/18 wheat production is forecast to decline by 8% year on year, to 16m tonnes.

Stocks and prices
Cumulative world stocks are predicted to rise for the fifth consecutive season in 2017/18, reaching 251m tonnes, up by 4% year on year to an all-time high. However, this large total figure masks some important features, as gains in world inventories are mostly attributed to rises in end-season stocks in India and China, whose stocks are not available on the world market. Indeed, with China's stocks having doubled over a five-year period, many observers have argued that China should be excluded from global stock calculations. Other organisations suggest that it is perhaps more useful to use carryovers in the eight largest exporters as a proxy for global supplies. Cumulative stockpiles in those countries are forecast to drop by around 7% year on year, to 70.8m tonnes, but will still be up by 12% from the average in recent years. The projection for 2018/19 is provisional, but suggests a continuation of the most recent trend. World stocks are likely to remain high, and are currently expected to be fractionally higher compared with the previous year, at 252m tonnes, but with the outlook skewed by an even larger figure for China. Exporter stocks of 62.7m tonnes, although not considered especially tight, would be the smallest in five years.
Russia's wheat stocks have almost tripled in just three years
Although Russia's exports have been running at a record pace in recent months, infrastructure capacity constraints mean that July-June shipments could be limited to around 33m tonnes, nowhere near enough to prevent a further build-up in 2017/18 stocks. Works to upgrade existing terminals are ongoing, and although new port facilities are also being planned for construction, including in eastern parts of the country, close to China, these projects are expected to take three or more years to complete. Following two successive massive crops, wheat stocks are expected to reach a record high at the end of the current marketing year, potentially reaching 16.8m tonnes, up from just 5.6m tonnes two seasons ago. According to the Russian Grain Union, a non-governmental farmers' association, the country currently has 120m tonnes of grain-storage capacity. Elevator capacity totals only about 40m tonnes or so, with the remainder made up mostly of on-farm barns and warehouses, which, although much cheaper for storing grains, are susceptible to greater post-harvest losses, estimated at up to 3%. Most of the country's storage facilities are in need of upgrading, with the best facilities mainly located close to the key southern producing and exporting areas. High stock levels are expected to keep a lid on prices heading into the next season and, even if 2018/19 production falls short of recent levels, the additional supplies should provide a cushion, allowing Russia to maintain its dominant position on the world export market.

Wheat prices are likely to remain weak in the short term
Trading in world wheat markets has fluctuated in recent months. Steep early-summer gains, linked primarily to a drought in parts of the US and Canada, were later erased on the back of better than expected results from harvests in the Black Sea region, predominantly in Russia. Amid overall heavy world availabilities and strong competition for available export business, wheat prices at most major origins eased during October, dipping by an average of 3%. Declines in the US were tied partly to sluggish overseas demand and a bearishly interpreted USDA supply-and-demand report. In contrast, buoyant export demand and logistical bottlenecks continued to shore up Black Sea export quotations, particularly in Russia, where port capacity is likely to be stretched this season. In addition, with some farmers said to have secured sufficient funds to cover near-term commitments, a number of producers were more reluctant to sell at current prices. With Russian shipments expected to remain high throughout the season, strong export competition is likely to keep a lid on prices, at least for next year. Assuming that crop prospects do not deteriorate further, we expect Hard Red Winter (HRW) wheat export prices (12% protein, fob Gulf) to fall steadily until mid-2018, before strengthening slightly thereafter. However, higher protein supplies are expected to command a hefty price premium, at least until the 2018/19 northern hemisphere crops enter the pipeline.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The intense political instability that followed the failed coup in July 2016 has eased partially since the approval in a referendum in April 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency. However, the narrow referendum vic-tory and allegations of vote fraud have deepened social and political divisions.
The presidential reform, which is due to take effect after the next presidential and parliamentary elections, in 2019, will further undermine Turkey's fragile democratic institutions and governance structures. It provides few checks on the powers of the president and moves the country closer to one-man rule.
The Justice and Development Party (AKP) has enjoyed 15 years of single-party rule, and for most of that period political and government effectiveness have improved. However, since 2013 economic policymaking institutions have become increasingly politicised.
Since the failed coup, Turkish foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by the domestic political goals of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government. This has resulted in a marked deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a complete rupture to be avoided, but tensions will remain high.
Real GDP growth slowed from an annual average of 7.4% in 2010-15 to 3.3% in 2016, owing in part to the disruption to the economy from the failed coup, but also to faltering foreign capital inflows amid expectations of tighter global liquidity. A recovery began in the fourth quarter of 2016, supported by government stimulus measures, political pressure on banks to extend credit and a pick-up in global demand. We expect growth to accelerate to an estimated 5.5% in 2017 and to average 4.2% in 2018-22.
We estimate that the Turkish lira will average TL3.66:US$1 in 2017, a fall of 17.4% compared with 2016. From 2018 we forecast that the exchange rate will remain broadly stable in real terms, depreciating mildly in nominal terms, to an average of TL4.28:US$1 in 2022. The Central Bank of Turkey will be constrained in its ability to tighten interest rates. It will have to resort to unorthodox and less effective tools to respond to currency weakness and high inflation.
We expect the current-account deficit to be slightly larger in the forecast period compared with 2016, and to remain sufficiently substantial to make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2018-22, but the country's global ranking falls by 13 places, to 58th. There is consensus among policymakers on the need to maintain macroeconomic stability. However, the failed coup and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of policy. Shortcomings include a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2020-22: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in a wide range of sectors, although the opening up of the energy market makes progress.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2020-22: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade and tourism following the lifting of Russian sanctions.
2020-22: Customs union with the EU could be extended, but negotiations are likely to be protracted given the deterioration in Turkish-EU relations. More free-trade agreements may come into force with the EU's trading partners.
Taxes
2018-19: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Some tax rate rises, including on company profits, have been announced for 2018, to curb the widening of the budget deficit.
2020-22: A broader income tax base as exemptions and exceptions are reduced. Possible tax cuts and increased incentives.
Financing
2018-19: Monetary policy remains cautious amid concerns about a possible deterioration in credit quality. Political pressure on c0mmercial banks to reduce interest rates. Renewed pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey.
2020-22: The banking system remains stable, despite some weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2018-19: Labour market remains rigid, with relatively high costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. Wage moderation after 30% minimum wage rise in 2016. Obstacles to employing foreigners have eased.
2020-22: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Progress, albeit slow, continues on investment plans in energy, transport and communications.
2020-22: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Third Istanbul airport becomes operational. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks could persist.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West, becoming a member of the Council of Europe (1949) and NATO (1952), and signing an association agreement with the then European Community (1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup at-tempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey has a unicameral parliamentary system of government, with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Under the AKP, Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019, and possibly earlier. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions will require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing political issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015 and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted long-standing institutional weaknesses, which, with the AKP's consent until 2013, allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Further politicisation of the judiciary is likely following the coup attempt. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax is 20%, but the government plans to increase it to 22% in 2018. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2016 goods exports (fob) came to US$150.2bn and imports (fob) to US$191bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$40.9bn-a contraction from US$48.1bn in 2015. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Among the most important political events in the 2018-22 forecast period will be the three crucial votes in 2019: municipal elections are due to be held in March of that year, and parliamentary and presidential elections in November. After these votes, an executive presidential system of government will replace the current parliamentary system. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his ruling, religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, to win the elections and remain in power until 2024, and probably beyond. Failure to win the elections could throw the political system into chaos and open up irreparable divisions in the AKP. The constitutional reforms to establish a presidential system, which were approved in a referendum in April 2017, provide few checks and balances on the powers of the president. This will further weaken Turkey's democratic institutions and governance structures, effectively moving the country to a system of one-man rule by Mr Erdogan.
Although the intense political instability that followed the failed coup has eased partially since the April referendum, we expect renewed social and political instability during the period up to and beyond the 2019 elections. The narrow presidential reform referendum victory, amid allegations of vote tampering, has further polarised the country. It has also raised concerns among the AKP's leaders that Mr Erdogan and his party are losing support. With the president's political future dependent on clear victories in all three elections, the government will continue its campaign against political opponents, critics and perceived enemies of the state, using the state of emergency law. Emergency rule was initially introduced after the failed coup to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric, who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. We expect emergency rule to remain in place for the foreseeable future because it will effectively allow Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is fully in place.
Security risk will remain high, with negative implications for the economy. The state is seeking to end an insurgency by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) in the south-east of Turkey, address the domestic security risk posed by terrorist attacks by Kurdish militants and Islamic State (IS) in cities across the country, and implement military operations in Syria and Iraq against both IS and the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds. The operational capacity problems created by the purge of the Turkish Armed Forces (TSK) and the police after the attempted coup appear to have eased to a large extent. In the short to medium term neither the government nor the PKK appears to be interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will intensify.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
We expect Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win the municipal, presidential and parliamentary elections in 2019. Although there are concerns within the AKP that the party has lost support since the referendum, Mr Erdogan's popularity is still unrivalled and his party has the ability to control the election process. Moreover, the opposition is fragmented and currently appears to have no candidates capable of challenging the incumbent. The right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP), which fielded a join candidate with the Republican People's Party (CHP) against Mr Erdogan in the 2014 presidential election, has more recently been supportive of the president. The charismatic Meral Aksener, who has broken away from the MHP, is a possible challenger. She has formed a new centre-right party, the Good Party (IP), and has declared that she will run against Mr Erdogan in the presidential election. However, it is unlikely that she will win, unless Mr Erdogan fails to obtain 50% of votes in the first round, leading to a second-round run-off against the candidate with the second-highest share of the vote. Ms Aksener would need the support of the CHP and have to attract votes from incompatible constituencies, including Kurds and nationalists, who currently vote for the AKP.
The clampdown on the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) since mid-2015, the decision of the MHP leadership to back the presidential reform, and the hardline nationalist stance adopted by Mr Erdogan and the AKP could have a considerable effect on voting patterns at the next parliamentary election. Both the MHP and the HDP have been weakened since the 2015 election and run the risk of falling below the high 10% national vote threshold for parliamentary representation, which would boost the AKP's seat share. Under the constitutional changes approved in the referendum, there will be 600 seats in a much weakened parliament from the next election, up from 550 currently.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
There is a growing risk of a rupture in Turkey's ties with its traditional Western allies, compounding concerns that under the leadership of Mr Erdogan and the AKP the country is pivoting eastwards. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration, including political upheaval in Europe and the US; a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; the US's military backing of Syrian Kurdish groups, which Turkey regards as terrorist organisa-tions affiliated to the PKK; the Turkish government's authoritarian tendencies and its strident anti-Western rhetoric; and Turkey's forging of closer relations with Russia, China and Iran. Turkey's confrontational approach to its traditional Western allies should also be viewed in the context of Mr Erdogan's need to maintain the support of Turkey's nationalists to achieve his domestic political goals, notably his push to become president with executive powers after the presidential and parliamentary elections in 2019.
We expect that Turkey and its Western allies will seek to avoid a complete breakdown in relations, which could materialise if, among other things, the EU suspends Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, the migrant deal with the EU collapses, Turkey closes the Incirlik airbase to US forces, or withdraws from NATO. However, if tensions remain at current levels for a prolonged period Turkey's strategic relationships with the EU and the US are likely to suffer irreparable damage, and become increasingly antagonistic and transactional.
The spillover of violence from the conflicts in neighbouring Syria and Iraq will continue to pose serious domestic and external security threats to Turkey. In addition to terrorist attacks carried out in Turkey by IS and the PKK, which has camps in the mountains in northern Iraq, Turkey now has military forces de-ployed in two areas in Syria, ostensibly as part of the fight against IS but also to prevent US-backed, PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurds from establishing a continuous autonomous region along Syria's northern border with Turkey.
The neighbouring conflicts are also likely to continue to influence the direction of Turkey's foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, and Russia has lifted almost all sanctions. The level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly in relation to the conflict in Syria, where both are militarily involved but have been pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to continue to be largely transactional. The risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector and its dynamic, diversified private business sector. However, the risk of an intensification of political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity could disrupt foreign capital inflows during the forecast period. These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, but tend to be short term and highly volatile. Shifts in capital flows have already put the lira under pressure on several occasions since late 2016, fuelling an acceleration in inflation. The most recent bout of volatility, in October and November, has probably been prompted by expectations of balance sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank) and geopolitical tensions in the neighbouring region. Even if the lira continues to depreciate, the Central Bank of Turkey will be constrained in its ability to further tighten interest rates. It will have to resort to unorthodox and less effective tools to respond to currency weakness and high inflation. An abrupt tightening of policy, which could strangle Turkey's economic recovery, may be necessary to halt the lira's slide. However, this is not our baseline scenario, as the central bank will remain under pressure from the government not to raise rates, especially ahead of the 2019 election.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The current direction of policy appears to be towards a difficult balancing act between fiscal loosening and tight monetary policy at the same time as encouraging banks to lend to households and businesses.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios-reflecting the impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past and major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-give the government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy. Our baseline forecast remains that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight to support investor confidence and to prevent a surge in domestic demand from causing an unsustainable widening of the current-account deficit. Nevertheless, we expect the central government deficit, which captures most of the public sector, to expand from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to an average of 2.2% in 2017-19, before narrowing to 1.5% in 2022. Although the government debt/GDP ratio edged up slightly in 2016, to 29.2%, we expect it to decline gradually, to 27.5% in 2022. The risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances cannot be ruled out.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
In November political pressure on the central bank to lower interest rates in order to support economic activity increased again, even as the government has focused its attention on Turkey's profitable commercial banks. We expect that the central bank will have to keep its monetary policy tight in the remainder of 2017 and in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent further depreciation of the lira amid political volatility and expectations of higher US interest rates and Fed balance sheet tapering. We expect the central bank to use a mix of interest-rate rises, macroprudential measures and other policies. The bank raised most of its main policy rates between November 2016 and April 2017, and from November 2017 will only be funding the banking sector at its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate, which was gradually raised by a total of 25 basis points, to 12.25% in late April, where it has since remained. The weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system has therefore increased to 12.25%, from 12% previously. This is well above its level of 7.8% in November 2016.
The central bank is seeking gradually to normalise its monetary policy frame-work to establish a single policy interest rate, which would help to improve transparency regarding monetary policy decisions. However, it is unlikely that this will happen until inflation is more firmly on a downward path towards its medium-term target of 5% and domestic political uncertainty eases.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Real GDP growth slowed from an annual average of 7.4% in 2010-15 to 3.3% in 2016, owing in part to the disruption to the economy caused by the failed coup in July that year, but also to faltering foreign capital inflows amid expectations of global liquidity tightening. A recovery got under way in October-December 2016, and we expect growth to accelerate to 5.5% in full-year 2017 and to average 4.2% in 2018-22. The rebound has been supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit and a pick-up in global demand. There are downside risks to our forecast, which is predicated on the assumption that the transition to a presidential system of government in the next few years does not lead to further political instability that could deter foreign capital inflows.
We expect a moderate improvement in household confidence, a recovery in employment growth and possible additional government incentives to support household spending. We forecast average real private consumption growth of 3.4% in 2017-22.
We expect government consumption growth to slow from an estimated 7% in 2017 to a still solid annual average of 6% in 2018-19 as the government continues to support the economy ahead of the 2019 elections. From 2020 we expect growth to be more moderate, but still robust.
The deterioration in the business environment since the attempted coup will continue to hold down private-sector fixed investment growth. However, we expect this to be offset by government investment, especially in infrastructure, generating real growth of 6% per year in 2017-19. In 2020-22 we forecast a deceleration to annual growth of 4.8% per year, reflecting firms' response to a more moderate expansion of domestic and external demand.
We expect the lifting of Russian sanctions on Turkey, the positive effect of a weaker lira on export competitiveness and stronger growth in main export markets, especially Europe, to drive a return to growth of exports of goods and services in 2017-22. However, we expect the perception of security risks to persist for some time, which will continue to deter some visitors and weigh on the tourism sector. Our expectation is that a slowdown in the Chinese economy in 2018 and a cyclical downturn in the US in 2020 will dampen external demand growth in those years.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target-as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disinflationary effects of low global oil prices. We expect the pass-through effects of past currency weakness and a moderate recovery in oil and other commodity prices from 2017 to keep consumer price inflation well above the official target during the first half of the forecast period. Assuming that the central bank does not loosen monetary policy too soon, we expect inflation to ease gradually, achieving the 5% target by end-2021. There are significant upside risks to our forecast.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
Amid further bouts of volatility we estimate that the lira will depreciate against the US dollar in 2017, to an annual average of TL3.66:US$1, a fall of 17.4% compared with 2016. From 2018 we forecast that the exchange rate will remain broadly stable in real terms, depreciating mildly in nominal terms, to an average of TL4.28:US$1 in 2022. The lira will depreciate sharply against the euro in 2017-22. There are substantial risks to our exchange-rate forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows, as well as the impact on investor confidence of domestic political tensions and geopolitical turmoil in the region.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
We expect the current-account deficit to widen moderately and remain large enough, at an average of 4.6% of GDP per year in 2017-22, to make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates. Although a weaker lira and the lifting of Russian sanctions will boost Turkey's main exports, we expect this to be largely offset by the moderately higher cost of imported energy and inputs for manufactured import-intensive exports. There has been a rebound in Russian tourist arrivals in 2017, but the sector is likely to take several years to recover to its 2015 pre-crisis levels, before the resurgence of terrorist attacks and the imposition of Russian sanctions.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart in May 2017 following the resignation of the ÖVP leader. An early election was held on October 15th.
The popularity of the ÖVP's new leader, the young minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, propelled his party into first place. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the ÖVP to form a coalition with the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). The SPÖ has announced its intention to go into opposition.
The inclusion of the FPÖ in the government will not lead to sanctions from other EU member states as in 2000, when the party was last part of a coalition, owing largely to the normalisation of the far right in Europe since then.
We expect any new government to focus on integration and immigration policy, and to attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and introduce some additional flexibility in labour and product markets. However, low government cohesion is likely to lead to limited progress.
The government budget is forecast to remain in deficit, albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP, throughout the forecast period (2018-22), as the fiscal consolidation process is likely to be restrained by limited government cohesion and effectiveness. The public debt/GDP ratio will fall gradually, to just above 71% by 2022, from an estimated 79.7% in 2017.
After several years of underperformance compared with its regional peers, the economy has performed relatively strongly since the start of 2016, growing by 1.4% in that year. We estimate an acceleration of growth this year, to 2.9%, and forecast that growth will moderate to 1.7% on average in 2018-22.
Consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) will continue to exceed the euro zone average in 2017-22, driven by structural domestic factors including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets. Annual inflation averaged 1% in 2016, up from 0.8% in 2015, and we expect an annual average of 2.1% in 2017-22.
The current-account surplus has been relatively stable in recent years, at about 2%. Although we expect small changes in the composition of the surplus, we expect it to remain relatively stable in the forecast period, at 2% of GDP on average in 2017-22.

Austria's business environment score improves slightly between the historical period (2013-17) and the forecast period (2018-22). As a result, the country remains in 11th place in the regional ranking but falls one place in the global ranking, dropping to 18th. Austria's strengths as a business location include decent infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited.
2020-22: Modest strengthening of competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2020-22: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal.
2020-22: EU likely to accelerate shift towards bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate. No progress on EU-US trade deal. Free-trade agreement between EU and UK.
Taxes
2018-19: Limited changes to the tax system aimed at reducing the sizeable income tax wedge.
2020-22: Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform, and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2018-19: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe.
2020-22: Further uptake in corporate bond issuance. Credit conditions continue to ease as banks' profitability recovers, in part supported by a gradual uptick in interest rates.
The labour market
2018-19: Economy-wide minimum wage introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment starts to fall.
2020-22: Continued modest expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2020-22: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure.

Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election was held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government's stated priorities were to reduce the budget deficit and debt pile, improve labour market participation rates, strengthen competitiveness, increase expenditure on research and development, continue to reform healthcare expenditure, stabilise the financial sector and raise educational standards. Progress on these issues will be modest at best under any next government, as tensions surrounding immigration, security and border controls will remain elevated across Europe, diverting attention to security and migration-related policy areas.
Taxation: Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is among the highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: In 2016 the value of exported goods was US$142.7bn and the goods import bill was US$142.3bn. The services surplus, traditionally boosted by tourism receipts, was US$12.2bn. Along with a modest primary income deficit and significant secondary income deficit, this yielded a current-account surplus equivalent to 2.1% of GDP.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
In May 2017, after several years of little progress on reforms and coalition and party in-fighting, the grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart following the resignation of Reinhold Mitterlehner from the positions of vice-chancellor, minister of economy and leader of the ÖVP, citing frustration within his party. The popular 31-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, took over the leadership of the ÖVP and reformed the party around himself. As a result, he led the ÖVP to a plurality of the vote in the early election on October 15th, winning a 31.5% share, up by 7.5 percentage points on its result in 2013. The SPÖ's vote share was unchanged, at 26.9%. The far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) increased its vote by 5.5 percentage points, to 26%. The liberal NEOS returned to parliament with just over 5% of the vote, and the Greens failed to cross the 4% electoral threshold for the first time in 31 years, in part because List Pilz, led by a former leader of the Greens, narrowly managed to cross it.
Coalition negotiations are continuing, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a coalition to emerge in late 2017 or early 2018, consisting of the ÖVP and the FPÖ, led by Mr Kurz as chancellor. Although technically a majority coalition including the SPÖ would be possible, either in the form of another grand coalition or an SPÖ-FPÖ coalition, the SPÖ has indicated that it will go into opposition. Mr Kurz has stated that he could also form a minority government should negotiations fail. However, there is little precedent for this in Austria. That the programmes of the ÖVP and the FPÖ are close to each other (during the campaign the leader of the FPÖ, Heinz-Christian Strache, regularly criticised Mr Kurz for stealing the FPÖ's programme) should help them to reach an agreement. The president, who has a relatively large role in the government-formation process, including the right to veto ministerial appointees, could still block the formation of a right-wing government, but this is not our core forecast.
Although we expect a chancellor from the ÖVP, the election should still be seen as a further step in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the ÖVP has been replaced to a large extent by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties have together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, and a renewed grand coalition has become almost impossible following the breakdown of relations between the two parties and the gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited both from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz owes much of his popularity to his strong stance on this issue and his plans to curtail migration into Europe and Austria.
Despite the overlap between the ÖVP and the FPÖ's programmes, we expect the government to struggle to implement its policies, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters, and the FPÖ could struggle to translate its opposition stance on matters such as immigration and integration into concrete policy proposals. As a result, we expect limited progress on significant structural reforms, and the risk of an early election in the next parliamentary term is high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The last general election was held on October 15th 2017. It was won by the ÖVP, who we expect to form a government with the FPÖ. Unless the government falls before then, it will sit until the end of the term of the new Nationalrat (the lower house of parliament) in late 2022.
Elections for several state parliaments are planned for the first half of 2018. The next election for the primarily ceremonial post of federal president will be in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this influx, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high. All three of the large parties have hinted that they want to limit labour migration within the EU, or at least give preferential treatment to Austrian citizens in the labour market, which could exacerbate tensions with many EU member states.
Nevertheless, Mr Kurz has been at pains to point out that any government under him will have to be pro-EU, and we therefore do not expect Austria's EU membership to be questioned in the coming years. The FPÖ has also moderated its critique of the bloc. We expect Austria to be a leading voice in the EU in the coming years, especially on reform of migration. We expect it to find broad support for proposals such as tighter controls of the EU's outer borders and processing asylum applications outside the EU.
Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ in government following the 1999 election led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations in 2000, we do not expect this to be repeated should the party join the next governing coalition. At that time a far-right nationalist party entering government was an unusual development, but since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority governments in several EU countries, including some Nordic countries, Italy and the Netherlands.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Alongside the 2016 tax reform, which provided about EUR5bn in tax relief to households, government policy has focused on challenges facing the country's financial sector. These have included the clean-up and debt restructuring of Heta Asset Resolution, a "bad bank" that was created to deal with the toxic assets of Hypo Group Alpe Adria (HGAA). The uncertainty surrounding Heta was removed in October 2016, when creditors accepted a debt-restructuring deal. The government has also had to manage the banking sector's exposure to central and east European economies.
In the renegotiation of its coalition agreement in January 2017 the coalition decided on a number of measures that it hoped to implement before the end of its term in 2018. These included a new annual minimum wage of EUR21,000, as opposed to only sector-specific negotiated minimum wages, and reducing red tape for employers, including more flexible rules on working hours. However, although the coalition parties agreed to implement a number of these measures before the election in October, little progress was made. The next govern-ment, which we expect to include the FPÖ, will move integration and immigration policy further to the right, and it is likely to focus on improving the business environment, including by reducing the sizeable tax wedge, but we expect it to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
In 2014 Austria's fiscal accounts deteriorated, mainly reflecting the govern-ment's decision to create a bad bank to deal with HGAA's toxic assets. The fiscal deficit widened to the equivalent of 2.7% of GDP, from 2% in 2013, and public debt rose to 83.7% of GDP. Mainly in response to steady direct revenue growth, the deficit narrowed to 1% of GDP in 2015, but widened again in 2016, to 1.6%, owing in part to fiscally expansionary tax reforms and higher migrant-related public spending.
We expect the budget to remain in deficit throughout the forecast period (2018-22), albeit safely within the EU mandated limit of 3% of GDP. Despite only limited fiscal consolidation, robust economic growth will help to narrow the deficit slightly. The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from an estimated 79.7% in 2017 to just above 71% in 2022. Although the public finances will remain worse than in peers such as Germany or the Netherlands, the low interest-rate environment and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals mean that funding risks are extremely low in our view.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The European Central Bank (ECB) is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that will run at EUR60bn per month until the end of 2017, and at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. The economic recovery in the euro zone has strengthened this year and has become more broad based. We expect a healthy expansion of real GDP in the euro zone in 2017, of 2.3%, after growth of 1.9% on average in 2015-16. The ECB continues to take stock of this growth momentum, but maintains a clearly dovish policy stance, with the reduction in the amount of monthly QE purchases in 2018 designed to extend its presence in the bond markets. The bank also plans to delay raising interest rates and reinvest the principal payments from maturing securities for a period well beyond the end of the QE programme. We expect the pace of monthly QE purchases to be reduced to zero in early 2019, but owing to subdued price pressure and persistent downside risks to growth, we forecast that the bank will delay raising policy rates until 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy largely stalled and under-performed in comparison with regional peers, notably Germany; this was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. A faltered reform process has contributed to higher inflation compared with regional peers and weakened productivity growth, admittedly from fairly high levels. Real GDP rose by a sluggish 1.1% in 2015, and although it accelerated in 2016, to 1.4%, it remained below Germany's 1.9% growth.
However, the economy has recently started to gain momentum again, with average quarterly growth of 0.7% between July 2016 and September 2017. Although in previous years the labour market had struggled to integrate the significant increase in the labour force, it seemed to have turned a corner in late 2016 and early 2017, in part owing to a surge in employment in the manu-facturing sector, when the unemployment rate started to fall. This is supporting private consumption, which we expect to grow by 1.6% this year. Furthermore, export and investment growth have also picked up. As a result, we expect real GDP growth to accelerate to 2.9% this year, above growth in Germany for the first time since 2005 and Austria's fastest growth rate since 2007.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-following an under-performance even compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue next year, although we forecast slower growth, at 2.1%, as we expect the impulse from the manufacturing sector in 2017 to have been a one-off. In the following years we expect a moderation of growth. Domestic demand will be the main driver of growth, which is likely to converge towards potential growth in these years. We therefore expect average real GDP growth of 1.6% in 2019-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.9% in 2015-16-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices and energy-price base effects fostered a gradual increase in inflation from October 2016 into 2017, when we estimate full-year average inflation of 2.2%. Recent strengthening of the euro will weigh slightly on inflation, but we expect it to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-22, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors as in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
The euro has moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1 since mid-2015. The annual average exchange rate was US$1.11:EUR1 in 2016, although a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the US presidential election led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. The euro has since rallied as the region's economic recovery has strengthened, and as political risk has waned in Europe but risen in the US. More recently, a rise in expectations of QE tapering by the ECB has prompted a sharp appreciation in the euro against the dollar. The value of the euro could yet come under pressure from political risk-especially in relation to the next general election in Italy, which we expect to take place in early 2018-and monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a gradual appreciation on average, to US$1.20:EUR1 by 2020-21, as the euro is supported by an ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, while the business cycle down-turn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020. We expect the euro to appreciate further in 2022 as the monetary policy tightening cycle begins.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values helped the trade balance to move into surplus in 2014-16, from a deficit in 2009-13. We expect the trade balance to move back into a modest deficit from 2017 as robust export growth is outweighed by higher import costs and strengthening domestic demand pushes up import volumes. However, this will be compensated for by a healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourism inflows. Modest primary income surpluses will not be enough to outweigh consistent secondary income deficits. However, we expect the services balance largely to outweigh the weakening trade balance and the current-account surplus to remain broadly flat throughout 2017-22, at about 2% of GDP on average.

World Commodity Forecasts Food Feedstuffs and Beverages November 2017

https://www.proquest.com/reports/world-commodity-forecasts-food-feedstuffs/docview/1972340229/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: Stocks are forecast to exceed 2m tonnes at the end of the 2018/19 season, which is very high by historical comparison. [...]there is potential for stocks to rise even more strongly; Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana have started discussions about how to bolster global market prices, and are considering stockpiling part of their output. [...]a modest slowdown in economic growth in emerging markets (particularly in Asia) will dampen the pace of consumption growth in the coming years. [...]heightened awareness about the health implications of excess sugar in diets will put pressure on consumption growth in developed markets, where the average consumption often already exceeds recommended levels. Amid consumer pressure on the food processing industry to reduce sugar and, in some markets, the introduction of "sin taxes" on sugary products, a gradual shift towards synthetic sweeteners will somewhat lessen demand for sugar. [...]owing to the growing supply of starch-based sweeteners in both Asia (where Chinese production is expanding rapidly) and Europe (whose market will be liberalised in September 2017), these cheaper alternatives will further limit demand for sugar in the food and drinks industry. Given that tea is regarded as a traditional drink, it will suffer from mounting com-petition from coffee and soft-drink retailers, owing to a growing preference for these beverages among younger Chinese consumers. [...]younger segments of the population are also showing a preference for black tea over green tea (black tea consumption has risen by an average of 40% per year since 2002, while green tea consumption has risen more gradually), which should bolster demand for black tea, albeit from a low base.

Note. WCF (World commodity forecasts) is an index of 22 hard and soft commodities. FFB (Food, feedstuffs and beverages) is a price index of 13 soft commodities. The beverages sector has a weight of 20% in the FFB index, grains 46.4%, oilseeds 28.6% and sugar 4.9%. The FFB index has a weight of 55.6% in the WCF index.
Agricultural prices will remain weak in early 2018, sinking the annual average
The Economist Intelligence Unit's food, feedstuffs and beverages (FFB) price index is set to fall in year-on-year terms in 2018-the seventh consecutive year of decline-by 1%. This is a smaller margin than the estimated drop in prices, of 1.3%, in 2017, as the markets for some agricultural goods, including oilseeds and grains such as wheat, maize and rice are beginning to tighten slightly. Nonetheless, most agricultural markets remain comfortably supplied, following several years of bumper harvests. Several crops have registered record harvests in 2016/17, including wheat and soybeans, and large carryover stocks will limit the potential for price growth in 2018. Although there is a risk that a La Niña weather event will have a negative effect on crop yields in the 2017/18 season, therefore pushing up prices, this remains unlikely at the moment, and we have not included an agricultural price shock in our forecast. We expect the FFB index to begin to firm from late 2018, rising by an average of 2.8% in 2019, as a number of markets tighten further, causing prices for a number of goods, including coffee, cocoa and wheat, to recover from rock bottom. Overall, we expect rising populations and incomes to continue to support modest growth in demand (and therefore prices) of FFB goods in the medium and long term.
There will be only a mild recovery in prices in 2019
Nonetheless, the road ahead will be bumpy. Agricultural markets have been well supplied for several consecutive seasons, providing ample stocks to draw upon. We expect global GDP growth to remain fairly robust, at an average of 2.7% per year in 2018-19, down only slightly from estimated growth of 2.9% in 2017. However, the looming economic slowdown in China and uncertainty about global monetary policy continue to pose downside risks to demand. In addition, exchange-rate trends may help to keep a lid on global commodity prices. We expect the US dollar (in which most raw materials are traded) to remain fairly strong against most emerging-market currencies in 2018-19, which will weigh on import demand in many emerging markets and encourage exporters to increase output, further inflating global supplies. As a result, even though prices will begin to recover in 2019, we expect the FFB index to remain well below 2014 levels, on the back of ample global supply.
Grain prices will post small rises, failing to recover to 2015 levels in 2017-18
We now expect grain prices to weaken on average in 2018, by a modest 0.4%; nonetheless, this is a downward revision from our previous forecast of a slight uptick in grain prices (1%), as wheat and soybean prices now look set to remain fairly weak. Nonetheless, the price declines in 2018 will be modest in comparison with the previous three seasons, when supply surged and global stocks accumulated. For wheat in particular, international prices appear to have found a floor after two years of sharp decline. Average world wheat prices surged in mid-2017, as drought in the northern US Plains region and dryness in parts of the EU, Australia and the Black Sea region, raised concerns over tighter global supply. However, the damage to crops was less serious than initially expected, and we forecast prices to ease gradually throughout 2018 as the rapid growth in 2017 proves difficult to replicate, before rising again in 2019. Maize prices will remain weak through the third quarter of 2017, undermined by the bumper 2016/17 crop, before rising steadily over the course of 2018-19 as global consumption rises-particularly for animal feed-and the market tightens.
Oilseed prices will rise in 2018-19 as oversupplied markets begin to tighten
Oilseed prices fell by an estimated 2.1% in 2017, owing largely to the bumper soybean crop in major producers, such as the US and Brazil. Despite strong global demand, this has driven global soybean stocks higher. However, we expect the price of soybeans, as well as rapeseed oil and sunflowerseed oil, to see robust growth in 2018-19 as market supply begins to tighten and global demand remains strong. Only palm oil prices are likely to drop throughout 2018-19 as global production surges, but changing consumer habits-particularly in developed economies, where health concerns have shifted consumer tastes to alternative products-will result in lower demand growth.
A forecast recovery in coffee prices in 2019 will lift the beverages sub-index
We forecast the beverages sub-index, which includes coffee and cocoa, to fall again in 2018, for the sixth consecutive year. We forecast cocoa prices to decline only modestly in 2018-19, by an average of 1.6% per year; nonetheless, this follows a massive drop, of an estimated 30%, in 2017, as a result of soaring global production and fairly weak demand growth. Global coffee prices are expected to dip slightly in 2018 as global supplies rise slightly and as the strong US dollar encourages exporters to sell their stocks. In 2019, however, we expect prices of higher-value arabica coffee beans to rise by 8.5% as several consecutive years of market deficits finally begin to erode global supplies.
Sugar prices will recover in 2018-19, but by a marginal amount
Sugar prices declined by an estimated 10.7% in 2017 as the market corrected after a price spike in late 2016 that was related to fears that supply from Thailand would be heavily affected by poor weather conditions. We expect global consumption to expand by a modest 1.3% per year on average in 2018-19 as high domestic prices limit demand in India, the second-largest global consumer. Recent weakness in global oil prices will also play a role as cheaper energy products incentivise farmers to divert more cane to sugar (rather than to its rival, ethanol), further increasing sugar supply and limiting price growth throughout the forecast period.

Cocoa
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that, after having contracted for two consecutive crop years, cocoa consumption grew by a marginal 0.4% in the 2016/17 season (October-September. Although cocoa demand is expected to accelerate slightly during the forecast period, by 1% in 2017/18 and by 1.2% in 2018/19, it remains fairly weak by historical comparison. Recent cocoa grind data point to a somewhat stronger third quarter of 2017 in Europe, in line with our current projections for a gradual pick-up in demand, but none of the main developed markets will be in a position to fuel rapid growth in cocoa consumption, reflecting high existing cocoa consumption levels per head. In contrast to some other soft commodity markets, where producing countries are starting to become major consumers, cocoa consumption levels among producers are (and will remain) extremely low, hampering the scope for firmer global growth in cocoa consumption. Meanwhile, recent falls in cocoa prices will be slow to feed through to retail prices, which will continue to push some consumers towards non-chocolate confectionery. The average size of many chocolate bars has shrunk-partly in response to consumer concerns about obesity, but also to protect profits during a time of high cocoa prices. Assuming that bar sizes do not increase, this will also hamper cocoa consumption growth.
Balancing demand between cocoa powder and butter will be challenging
Asian countries will see slightly faster growth in cocoa demand than the global average, as markets are far less saturated and GDP growth will remain higher than in much of the OECD-even bearing in mind the repercussions of a slowdown in China in 2018. Stronger demand in Asia will have implications for global demand for cocoa butter (used in richer products, such as chocolate confectionery) and cocoa powder (used to add chocolate flavour to products such as biscuits, cakes and drinks). The demand balance between cocoa powder and butter is both delicate and cyclical: manufacturers stepped up grinding in the previous decade in response to a rapid increase in demand for powder, only to be faced with a significant surplus since 2011. This subsequently caused shortages of butter. We expect demand for cocoa butter to remain strong in the short term, but it will not outstrip demand for powder indefinitely. Given that Asia accounts for 26% of the world's imports of cocoa powder, compared with just 13% of global imports of cocoa butter, firmer consumption growth in that market is likely to boost demand for powder.
Higher prices will slow consumption growth in developed markets
Consumers in the US (the largest cocoa-consuming country, which accounts for 20% of global demand) and Europe (which collectively accounts for 40% of global demand) are showing an increasing preference for premium chocolate (with a higher cocoa content), but with less frequent purchases. Recent sales figures from the main chocolate manufacturers indicate that, on balance, this is pushing down overall consumption. This is substantiated by data from 2015/16, which show that cocoa consumption contracted in several large markets (including the US and Canada) while registering marginal growth in others (particularly in Europe), despite stronger underlying economic conditions in many of these countries.
We forecast modest but positive growth in demand for cocoa in developed markets in 2017/18-2018/19. Health concerns and changing retail habits will constrain consumption (the rise of internet grocery shopping will erode spur-of-the-moment in-store chocolate purchases), as will market saturation. Europe's three largest buyers (Germany, France and the UK) have among the highest cocoa consumption rates per head in the world, at 3.5-4.5 kg annually. However, sharp increases in consumption growth of dark chocolate-which has a higher cocoa content than milk chocolate and is perceived to be healthier-will put a floor under overall cocoa consumption.
Russian and Brazilian cocoa consumption will begin to recover
Lower cocoa consumption in 2015/16 in Brazil and Russia, which together account for nearly 10% of global demand, demonstrate the extent to which cocoa demand is affected by underlying economic conditions, particularly in developing economies, where chocolate is not regarded as a basic good. We estimate that both of these countries saw consumption contract further in 2016/17-despite a return to modest GDP growth in both countries in 2017-reflecting the high cost of cocoa in local-currency terms. For Russia, restrictions on a number of imports from the EU that have been in place since mid-2014 are having an adverse effect on demand for many consumer goods. We expect cocoa demand in Russia to stage a gradual recovery in 2017/18 and 2018/19, growing by an average 1.4% per year. In Brazil, cocoa consumption rose rapidly until 2014 but has fallen steadily since then, amid a domestic recession. As with Russia, we forecast a gradual recovery in cocoa consumption growth in 2017/18 and 2018/19, averaging around 1.5% per year, on the assumption that underlying economic conditions improve somewhat.
