Cocoa consumption growth will slow in Asia
China and India have huge potential for further expansion in cocoa consumption, given currently low per-head consumption levels (at just 37 g in India and 59 g in China in 2015/16, compared with 2-6 kg in developed markets). However, cocoa demand will be hampered by high retail prices and, in China, consumer caution amid wider economic uncertainty, particularly in 2018-19. This will cut cocoa consumption growth in the coming years, from 5% in 2017/18 to 3.5% in 2018/19. In India, we expect demand growth to accelerate from 3.4% in 2017/18 to 4.2% in 208/19, owing to firmer underlying economic conditions.
Supply
Global cocoa production surged by an estimated 11.9% in 2016/17 on the back of improved weather conditions, after a particularly difficult El Niño event and a severe harmattan season (a dry winter wind blowing from the Sahara), cut cocoa output in many of Africa's main producers in 2015/16. We expect global cocoa production to fall during 2017/18 and 2018/19, by 3.8% and 1.2% respectively, mainly reflecting a projected drop in production in Côte d'Ivoire-the world's largest cocoa producer. Its output will remain high by historical comparison, but another bumper crop is unlikely, reflecting lower farmgate prices and weaker confidence among growers. Overall, recent price weakness is likely to dissuade farmers from investing in fertiliser and pesticide, contributing to the broader decline in global cocoa production.
Structural and geographic factors will hamper long-term supply
Longer-term structural problems will also constrain supply. Not only have farmgate prices in several large producing countries begun to fall in line with lower market prices for cocoa, but farmers receive a much smaller share of the final retail price than has been the case in previous decades, owing to higher costs further down the supply chain. Many farmers in West Africa remain below the poverty line, and as a consequence few young people in the region are choosing to work in the cocoa sector, instead opting for more profitable crops or moving to cities in search of non-agricultural work. Governments are trying to lift farmers' incomes to encourage people to work in the cocoa sector, but it is uncertain how effective these methods will be in the long term, particularly given recent falls in global prices and weak public finances.
Geographical considerations will also hamper the diversification of production. Cocoa can be grown only in certain regions (three-quarters of world production comes from regions that are located within eight degrees of the equator) and in warm, humid conditions. Cocoa production is therefore likely to remain concentrated among a small group of countries, limiting the scope for strong and sustained output growth. Nonetheless, there are countries that have significant potential to expand production, mainly in Latin America, where high-quality cocoa is produced. The expansion of manufacturing facilities to grind beans in producing countries may also encourage new investment to lift output.
Côte d'Ivoire's production is forecast to soar in 2016/17
In Côte d'Ivoire, cocoa production jumped by an estimated 25.9% in 2016/17 to a record 2m tonnes as the sector recovered from the impact of dry weather associated with El Niño in 2015/16, when output fell sharply. We expect cocoa production to fall by 8.5% in 2017/18 and by 2.2% in 2018/19. It is unlikely that the authorities will be able to replicate the exceptionally high level of output registered in 2016/17, with the state-run cocoa authority, the Conseil du Café-Cacao (CCC) issuing fewer export licences than ahead of the 2016/17 season and projecting production in 2017/18 in the range of 1.725m-1.75m tonnes. Although our forecast is slightly more upbeat, we still expect output to fall steadily in the forecast period. Policy will not be particularly supportive: following a sharp cut to farmgate prices ahead of the mid-crop in March 2017, the CCC has kept prices on hold for the 2017/18 harvest, with price levels around one-third lower than a year ago. The government had hoped to raise farmgate prices, but any increase in the producer price would mean cutting export duties and therefore forgoing fiscal revenue, which is unlikely. A stabilisation fund is supposed to protect farmers' revenue from global price volatility, but these funds have seemingly been insufficient to shield farmers' incomes and-given the lack of transparency over the financial reserves held by the CCC-neither farmers nor exporters have confidence that losses arising from low global prices will be recouped. These factors will combine to drag on overall cocoa production.
Ghanaian government will struggle to boost cocoa production significantly
In Ghana, we estimate that cocoa production continued to rebound in 2016/17, with favourable weather and a mild harmattan season lifting cocoa production to an estimated 850,000 tonnes (above the official target of 800,000 tonnes). We do not expect further significant and sustained growth in production during the 2017/18-2018/19 forecast period. For now, Ghana's cocoa board (Cocobod) has been more reluctant than the Côte d'Ivoire authorities to cut prices paid to farmers, but Cocobod has been forced to seek a bridging loan from the central bank, indicating that farmgate prices may need to be cut, particularly if global cocoa prices fail to recover. Combined with anxiety among farmers about the government's intentions to evolve agriculture towards other crops, ongoing encroachment by gold miners and the government's decision to stop providing free fertiliser, production will remain steady at best during the forecast period.
In the longer term, the New Patriotic Party government plans to rehabilitate cocoa farms, cutting down trees that are over 30 years old and replanting them while providing financial compensation to farmers until the trees start yielding fruit (generally three to five years). The authorities ultimately aim to raise production to 1.5m tonnes within four years, also driven by better soil management, and better pest and disease control. These plans are positive, since Ghana has a large share of unproductive trees (Cocobod estimates 40%) and a consequent low average yield per hectare (at 400 kg/ha, compared with 600 kg/ha in Côte d'Ivoire and 1 tonne/ha in Indonesia). Replanting, in particular, will help to address the problem of swollen shoot disease, which affects nearly one-fifth of cocoa trees and is associated with low yields. However, we think it unlikely that these ambitious plans will reach fruition, since the weak macroeconomic backdrop is likely to hamper public investment.
Cameroon's and Nigeria's production targets will prove overambitious
After falling for the second consecutive crop year in 2016/17, cocoa production in Cameroon will remain weak during 2017/18-2018/19. Cuts in farmgate prices will be a disincentive to farmers, meaning that the government will remain significantly off track from its 2020 production target of 600,000 tonnes-a level that even the national Cocoa Development Corporation has described as "unrealistic and unattainable". The fact that plans to increase the harvested area by 100,000 ha each year have failed to materialise, with the area under cocoa cultivation rising by only around 3,000 ha since 2014, will severely hamper the expansion of the cocoa sector.
Cocoa production in Nigeria has slumped in recent years, and the country has slipped from being the world's fourth-largest producer to the sixth-largest (on a par with Brazil). Government initiatives designed to support farmers have not proved successful, with efforts to introduce high-yielding cocoa and increase the distribution of free seedlings floundering. With the country's mining and energy sector suffering from still-low inter-national oil prices, there is official acknowledgement that investment in raising cocoa production could generate greater foreign-exchange earnings, and the Ministry of Agriculture has recently outlined its ambitious goal of boosting cocoa production above the levels recorded in Côte d'Ivoire. Its short-term goal is to lift cocoa production to 300,000-320,000 tonnes in 2017/18, with the medium-term target of raising output to 1m tonnes/year. However, problems with weak infrastructure, corruption, poor (and expensive) access to financing and weak implementation capacity will hamper these efforts.
Prospects are weak for Indonesia's cocoa sector
The authorities in Indonesia have ambitious plans to triple cocoa output by 2020, from 325,000 tonnes in 2014/15, but these are highly unlikely to materialise. Adverse weather, widely attributed to El Niño, hampered both the 2015/16 and the 2016/17 harvest, with cocoa output registering its third consecutive annual decline. On the assumption of more stable weather conditions, output should resume growth in 2017/18 and 2018/19, but at a forecast 320,000 tonnes at the end of the forecast period, cocoa output will remain weak by historical comparison. Indonesian firms are likely to rely increasingly on imported processed cocoa from neighbouring Malaysia to meet domestic demand.

Strong potential for growth in Latin America will not be realised in 2018-19
Agriculture in Latin America's two largest cocoa producers, Brazil and Ecuador, was affected by El Niño; in Brazil the main cocoa-producing regions reported drought conditions, and in Ecuador El Niño arrived late but continued for longer than usual. However, with better weather conditions, output is estimated to have recovered firmly in both countries in 2016/17. Structurally, there is scope for both countries to lift cocoa output as manufacturers look to boost investment in the region in an attempt to diversify production away from West Africa. The region's reputation for producing high-quality cocoa will help in this respect, given rising global demand for premium chocolate. However, some of this investment will be slow to materialise, as global prices remain depressed amid excess supply, which will act as a brake on growth potential.
Stocks and prices
We expect the global cocoa market to remain in surplus during the forecast period, but for the surplus to narrow from an estimated 402,000 tonnes in 2016/17 to 194,000 tonnes in 2017/18 and 98,000 tonnes in 2018/19. Although production is forecast to fall steadily, the fact that it will do so from such a high base (output was exceptionally strong in 2016/17) means that cocoa production will remain higher than consumption by some margin. Tepid demand growth makes a return to a market deficit unlikely during the forecast period. Stocks are forecast to exceed 2m tonnes at the end of the 2018/19 season, which is very high by historical comparison. Moreover, there is potential for stocks to rise even more strongly; Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana have started discussions about how to bolster global market prices, and are considering stockpiling part of their output.

Supply concerns will support prices, despite subdued demand growth
After remaining high for much of 2014-16, at around US$3,000/tonne, cocoa prices plummeted between December 2016 and late April 2017, to less than US$1,900/tonne. Although prices have recovered somewhat, they averaged less than US$2,000/tonne each month from May-September. We see little prospect of a recovery in average prices, owing to the global supply glut. We forecast an average annual price of US$1,975/tonne in 2018 (a 2.1% year-on-year fall) and US$1,955/tonne in 2019.

Coffee
Demand
Following estimated growth of 1.9% in 2016/17, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global coffee consumption to expand by a similar rate of 2% per year in 2017/18-2018/19. Coffee-importing countries (mainly developed economies) account for around two-thirds of global coffee consumption, and after a weak 2015/16 are showing signs of firmer demand on the back of stronger underlying economic conditions. Notwithstanding ongoing monetary policy tightening in some of the large coffee consumers, domestic demand is expected to remain firm, supporting coffee consumption. In coffee-producing countries (many of which are emerging markets), consumption growth is forecast to average 2.1% per year in 2017/18-2018/19. This is slightly weaker than in recent years, reflecting relatively tepid demand growth in Brazil (which currently accounts for around 40% of exporting countries' consumption, owing to the sheer size of its domestic market). Consumption growth will be strongest in Asia-notably China. Although we expect China's GDP growth rate to slow from 2018, the deceleration will be concentrated in the investment and industrial sectors, and we expect average income levels to continue to rise steadily, meaning that there is little risk of a fall in coffee demand growth. However, coffee consumption levels are low in China, so even as domestic coffee demand rises quickly, this will contribute only modestly to global consumption growth.
Coffee habits are shifting around the world
Consumption trends will change in both the home and out-of-home sectors. In the latter, the expansion of coffee-shop chains will continue, providing a boost to demand, particularly in North America and Europe, but store formats will evolve. Increasing demand for "on the go" beverages will result in larger numbers of smaller shops, including within petrol stations and supermarkets. In some markets-including the US and China-the large coffee chains are increasingly moving towards prepayment through smartphone apps, allowing customers to pick up their purchases without having to queue. These technological developments are likely to help the out-of-home sector to defend its market share at a time when a large number of consumers have single-serve coffee-capsule machines at home. This will be accompanied by heavy marketing of other coffee beverages, including iced coffee and cold brew. Although comprising a small market share of the out-of-home segment, sales of these products are likely to grow rapidly.
Single-serve coffee will help to drive growth in developed markets
Demand for coffee at home that rivals the quality of beverages found in cafes will result in a shift away from the consumption of instant coffee. On a global level, coffee pod sales are approaching the total combined value of instant and ground coffee, although the higher cost of pods means that, in volume terms, the instant and ground coffee market remains larger. Although sales growth of machines and capsules is showing signs of slowing, the coffee pod market will continue to provide important support for overall global coffee demand. Given that most pods contain either exclusively arabica beans or a high proportion of arabica with a small quantity of robusta, this will lift demand for arabica.
Coffee consumption growth in North America will increase steadily
US coffee consumption growth is forecast to average 2.6% a year in 2017/18-2018/19, with data from the US National Coffee Association showing that the percentage of people drinking coffee is rising rapidly (up from 57% in early 2016 to 62% in early 2017). Daily consumption is rising and consumers are increasingly attracted to a variety of products (US consumption of cold coffee products has risen by 75% over the past two years). There are indications that long-term consumption growth may continue to rise, with the share of 13-18-year-olds drinking coffee rising from 23% in 2014 to 37% in early 2017, and demand growth among 18-24-year-olds also rising strongly.
Similar dynamics are evident in Canada, with the share of 18-24-year-olds drinking coffee jumping from 48% in 2015 to 58% in 2016 (up from just 32% in 2009). Younger consumers show a much stronger preference for speciality coffees and for drinking coffee in out-of-home locations than other age brackets. We expect coffee consumption growth, which has been relatively steady at 2-3% in recent years, to pick up slightly, to 3.2%, in 2017/18.
Coffee consumption in Brazil is expected to falter
Brazil is the world's second-largest coffee consumer, but consumption levels per head are still modest (at around one-third of those in most European countries), so there is scope for a significant increase in demand. However, a sharp economic recession in 2015/16 hampered coffee consumption growth, which fell to 0.8%. After recovering to an estimated 1.5% in 2016/17, we expect coffee consumption to average 1.2% per year in 2017/18-2018/19. Although underlying economic growth is expected to pick up, household consumption will remain constrained by high unemployment, rising fuel prices and higher inflation, which will all drag on disposable income.
Fairly firm coffee consumption growth is expected in Japan and South Korea
Japan is the largest coffee market in Asia (and the fourth-largest in the world), with coffee boasting around the same share of the beverages market as tea. After rising by an estimated 2.8% in 2016/17, we expect coffee consumption growth to rise by an average of 2.5% a year in 2017/18 and 2018/19. This growth will be driven by coffee sales in convenience stores, given that the number of coffee shops is falling. In South Korea the coffee market has expanded rapidly in recent years, with coffee imports more than trebling between 2006 and 2016 and the number of coffee shops increasing even more rapidly. Although we forecast somewhat weaker growth in coffee consumption in 2017/18-2018/19, at an annual average of around 3% the pace of growth will remain firm.
Coffee consumption in China and India-currently both small consumers-will continue to grow. Much of the growth in Chinese coffee consumption will be in the out-of-home sector, reflecting the rising popularity of a coffee-shop culture in urban centres. A significant share of the new stores opened by Starbucks in 2016 were in Asia, with this trend continuing in 2017. The company now runs 2,800 outlets in 130 Chinese cities (nearly 600 in Shanghai alone, Starbucks' largest presence in a single city), up from 2,300 last October, and is planning to have 5,000 stores open by 2021. We expect an economic slowdown in China in 2018, but the deceleration will be less marked than previously forecast and will be concentrated in the construction and industrial sectors. Given that we expect average income levels to continue to rise steadily, we believe that there is little risk of a fall in coffee demand growth in the 2017/18-2018/19 forecast period.
Following a recent rapid expansion of the out-of-home sector in India, driven by comparatively low consumer price inflation, rising disposable income and favourable demographics (around one-half of the population is aged under 25), we expect a consolidation in 2018-19, with coffee consumption growth of around 3.5% per year. Meanwhile, south-east Asia also has relatively low levels of coffee consumption per head, although demand is increasing rapidly in certain countries (mainly coffee-producing economies such as Indonesia and Vietnam), and rising incomes are encouraging companies such as Starbucks to expand in Indonesia and the Philippines, where consumption is increasing. Costa Coffee is expanding in Thailand, Singapore and Cambodia and recently opened its first store in Vietnam.
Asian markets will drive demand for robusta beans
Given taste preferences for soluble and instant coffee (which generally use the robusta variety) in faster-growing Asian markets, demand will be stronger for robusta beans than for the more expensive arabica blends. Improved quality of robusta will also play a part here, with such beans slowly losing their reputation for inferior taste. In addition, improvements in processing technology mean that it is possible to use a larger proportion of robusta in coffee blends while maintaining quality.

Supply
After falling by an estimated 0.8% in the 2016/17 crop year (October-September), as adverse weather related to the El Niño weather phenomenon undermined the development of beans in Asia, coffee production is forecast to recover in 2017/18, rising by 1.3%. Production in Brazil-the world's largest producer-is forecast to fall as the biennial crop alternates between higher- and lower-producing years (2017/18 is an "off-season" crop year). However, this will be offset by firmer output growth in most other producing countries. Global coffee production growth is expected to be much stronger in 2018/19, at 4.6%, as Brazil's crop shifts to an "on-season" year.
We envisage a growing concentration of coffee production among the world's largest producers. Currently, a large number of countries (around 70) produce coffee, but the smaller producers have been struggling as a result of low world prices and rising overheads. In many of these countries, where coffee is not a particularly important area of the economy, farmers wield less power and are less likely to secure government support than in leading producers. Partly as a result, we expect coffee output in "other" countries to decline from 8.3m 60-kg bags in 2015/16 to 7.8m bags in 2018/19. Output in these countries-which fall outside the world's top 17 producers-will account for 5% of global production in 2018/19, compared with a peak of 8.8% in 2009/10.
Improved prospects for a recovery in coffee production in Brazil
In Brazil, by far the world's largest producer, prospects for the off-season 2017/18 crop year are fairly strong, and we expect only a moderate fall in production, to 50m bags. Although adverse weather in mid-2016-including drought in some areas and irregular rainfall in others-raised concerns that beans might be damaged ahead of the harvest, recent weather has been more supportive, and both quality and quantity of beans have been good. Moreover, the still-weak local currency is continuing to provide an incentive to growers.
The 2018/19 crop year remains some way off, with coffee bushes only just beginning to flower, so output projections remain highly speculative. Local commentators have stated that they believe that there is potential for a bumper crop in 2018/19, with some even suggesting that output of up to 60m bags is possible, which would represent a record high by some margin (to date, the highest production was recorded in 2012/13, at 55.4m bags). We expect coffee production to rise and we currently forecast output of 54m bags. Although weather conditions have been supportive in most places, some coffee-producing states have seen below-average rainfall, which is likely to hamper more rapid production growth.
Coffee production in Vietnam is set to recover from a severe drought
In Vietnam, the worst drought in three decades hampered production in 2016/17, and we estimate that coffee output dropped by 12%. Assuming that weather conditions stabilise for the 2017/18 crop, there is scope for a rebound in Vietnam's coffee output; we forecast production of 27m bags, implying growth of 6.7%, followed by 3% growth (to 27.8m bags) in 2018/19. The authorities remain pessimistic about the medium-term prospects for production, forecasting coffee output to stabilise or decline slightly. However, government efforts to replant 140,000 ha of coffee, targeting 25,000 ha a year, as well as a rising arabica crop, will support firmer output, particularly given that yields from new bushes are typically high. In addition, firm demand for robusta in the domestic market and other Asian countries will encourage growers.
Output from Mexico and Central America will slip in 2017/18
A severe outbreak of coffee rust, followed by El Niño, inflicted damage on coffee plantations in Mexico and Central America, and hampered production during three successive crop years, from 2013/14 until 2015/16. However, recent production and export data are much more positive, pointing towards a solid recovery in 2016/17. We estimate that coffee production rose by 12.2%, an upward revision from 9.5% previously, reflecting signs of stronger-than-anticipated output growth in Honduras. Nonetheless, there are reports that coffee rust is returning to some areas in the region, which could threaten output in 2017/18. Purchases of fungicides and fertiliser will help to prop up yields, but we nevertheless forecast a fall in coffee production of just under 2% in 2017/18. Assuming that coffee rust does not spread significantly and that weather conditions remain favourable, we forecast coffee production to grow by 3.9% in 2018/19.
Colombian production is set to continue to rise
Coffee production in Colombia has risen steadily in recent years, with recently released data from the local authorities indicating that output reached a 24-year high of 14.6m bags in 2016/17. Prospects for 2017/18 are uncertain. The structural underpinnings of the sector are strong, including a comparatively high percentage of rust-resistant bushes. In addition, efforts are being made to increase productivity, with recent additional planting in existing plantations aiming to raise average production per hectare, which at 18 bags per hectare in 2016 was much lower than in other large growers (27 bags per hectare in Brazil and 35 bags per hectare in Vietnam). However, recent cloudy weather conditions are affecting flowering on coffee bushes; if this continues, the crop yield will be hampered. For the time being, we project coffee production growth of 3.4% in 2017/18, but will monitor this closely in the coming months. In 2018/19 production should start to benefit from a 2016 peace agreement between the government and the left-wing FARC rebels, as coffee cultivation will increase in previously isolated areas of the country (the government has speculated that output could reach 20m bags by 2020 as a result). We forecast coffee production growth of 4.6% in 2018/19, to 15.8m bags.

In Indonesia coffee production is recovering, but remains weak overall
Indonesia's ambitious expansion plans for the coffee sector-which include more than doubling production within five years to make the country the world's second-largest producer after Brazil-have been completely derailed. El Niño brought excessive dry weather to the main coffee-growing areas, affecting the 2016/17 harvest, when output fell by an estimated 18%. However, exports have recently begun to recover owing to more supportive weather conditions, providing momentum heading into the 2017/18 season, when we expect production to rise by 5.9%. We expect production growth of 4.7% in 2018/19, but at just 11.2m bags output will remain low by historical comparison.
Stocks and prices
Global stocks are forecast to fall throughout 2017/18-2018/19 as the market remains in deficit and as producers continue to sell some of their old stocks in order to take advantage of the relatively weak local currencies against the US dollar. However, exporting countries have less scope for further extensive sales, since stocks have already been run down substantially (stocks in importing countries have risen as a result). Even assuming some continued sales of stocks, the market deficit is still forecast to be large. By end-2018/19 we expect global stocks to have fallen to 31.9m bags, from an estimated 41.1m bags in September 2016, which will support a partial recovery in prices.

After slumping again in 2017, arabica prices are set to rise in 2018
Although arabica coffee prices rose by an average of 2.4% in 2016, prices fell sharply during November-December, from US$1.97/lb in early November to US$1.55/lb at the end of the year. After a partial recovery to close to US$1.70/lb in January, arabica prices fell steadily over the first half of 2017, before stabilising at US$1.45-1.50/lb in the third quarter. Given that it appears likely that the global market will be in deficit in 2016/17, the fall in prices-to levels not seen since 2013-is curious. We believe that coffee prices are increasingly driven by investment trends, with swings in sentiment often due to a spate of positive or negative news on the supply side. Coffee prices are also becoming increasingly reactive to changes in the strength of the US dollar, with dollar depreciation tending to lead to higher coffee prices.
In recent weeks, speculation about bumper production in Brazil has kept prices low. The fact that several large exporting countries are continuing to sell spare stock in order to take advantage of weak local currencies is also suppressing prices, because this has been accompanied by a rise in coffee stocks in importing countries, which in turn may contain demand going forwards.
We believe that speculation about the 2018/19 harvest in Brazil will keep prices suppressed next year and forecast an average coffee price of US$1.53/lb in 2018. This is in line with recent developments in futures markets, with coffee for December 2017 delivery trading at well below US$1.30/lb. Given the underlying fundamentals and the likelihood that the next "off-season" in Brazil (2019/20) will hit market confidence during the 2019 calendar year, we forecast a recovery of prices, to an average US$1.66/lb.
Tighter supplies of robusta beans and firm Asian demand will support prices
Prices for cheaper robusta have fallen slightly since January, but have not seen the same sell-off as arabica beans, reflecting concerns about the supply of robusta beans in the context of disappointing weather conditions in Vietnam and Indonesia. Despite a sharp slide in prices in late April, from US$1.08/lb to 95 US cents/lb in the space of a week-as hedge funds liquidated their positions on the perception that robusta prices were extremely high-prices subsequently recovered quickly, trading at an average US$1.03/lb in the third quarter. We expect prices to average US$1/lb in 2018 and US$1.04/lb in 2019, underpinned by growing Asian con-sumption.

Maize
Demand
Maize is the most consumed (and produced) grain in the world, with total annual demand now in excess of 1bn tonnes/year (t/y). It is a versatile grain, with around 60% of the total used for animal feed, almost 30% for industrial processing (mainly fuel ethanol and starch) and the rest consumed directly as food or seed, or lost through waste. After a period of spectacular growth, demand for maize-based biofuels is now increasing more slowly, even though overall levels of consumption are still setting new records each year. However, following reports about China's plans for a massive expansion of its own fuel ethanol sector, world use for biofuels could potentially rise sharply from current levels over the medium term. Maize is the primary energy source in compound feed mixes, and with ample supplies predicted across the world, it is well placed to meet predicted gains in demand in meat-exporting countries, as well as in parts of Africa, Asia and Latin America, where consumption of animal protein continues to expand. Maize is by far the dominant feed grain in much of the world, with annual consumption typically more than four times that of wheat, the second most widely consumed feed cereal. In 2017/18 The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global demand to rise by 1.9% year on year to 1.03bn tonnes, with stronger uptake expected across the animal feed, industrial and food sectors. A similar trend is projected for 2018/19, with overall consumption rising by an additional 1.9%, to 1.05bn tonnes.
World feed demand will rise by 2% in 2017/18
World demand for meat and other animal proteins shows no sign of slowing, with consumption gains driven by population growth, greater purchasing power and changes in diets and tastes. Maize is an extremely useful ingredient, which, combined with other rations, can contribute to rapid livestock weight gain. Overall use, however, depends on availabilities and price relationships with other grains-mainly wheat-as well as high-protein oilmeals. A multitude of other factors can also have a direct impact on feed demand in any particular year, with producers having to consider pasture conditions and availability, as well as desired livestock weight, the economics of the meat industry and feed efficiency ratios. In 2017/18 we expect global growth in use of maize for livestock feed to slow to around 2%, down from almost 7% in the previous season. Although firmer demand for maize in complex feed rations is anticipated in China, Brazil, Iran, Egypt, the EU and India, discretionary on-farm feeding may drop back amid smaller predicted harvests in some countries, including the US. Predictions for the 2018/19 period remain provisional and will depend on future maize availabilities and pricing relative to alternative feeds. However, with the upward trend in world meat production unlikely to falter, a further increase in maize feed demand is likely, provisionally pegged at a record 595m tonnes. Gains are again likely to be tied to expansions in Asia and Latin America, but with an expected rise in the US too.
Use for fuel ethanol is at a record high, but growth is slowing
A substantial amount of maize is processed for use in a multitude of food, beverage and industrial applications, including corn oil, starches, sweeteners and ethanol. About 20 years ago approximately 70m tonnes of maize was used for industrial processing worldwide, equivalent to about 12% of overall use. Following the massive, mainly policy-driven, expansion in the global biofuels sector, world consumption surged between 2005/06 and 2009/10, expanding at an average rate of 16% per year over that time. Although subsequent growth has been comparatively much slower, industrial use has increased to successive records in each of the past five years. In 2017/18 processing is forecast to account for 27% of total consumption, rising by 4m tonnes year on year, to 286m tonnes, more than four times more than two decades earlier. Consumption in the following year is provisionally placed at 3m tonnes higher, at 289m tonnes. The US is by far the leading processor, with demand projected at almost 172m tonnes this year, including 12.5m tonnes for high fructose corn syrup (HFCS), 9.4m tonnes for glucose, 6.5m tonnes for starch and 3.8m tonnes for beverage alcohol. While consolidating somewhat in recent years, the amount of maize used to produce HFCS has declined from earlier peaks, partly reflecting consumer health concerns. Fuel ethanol is now the largest single component of US demand, with processors expected to use close to 140m tonnes of maize in 2017/18, 4m tonnes more than that used for feed/residual and compared to projected reports of less than 50m tonnes. Ethanol now accounts for about 10% of finished motor gasoline in the US, blending in excess of 15bn gallons per year. Although ethanol exports will be a useful outlet, infrastructure constraints mean than future growth prospects will probably be limited.
China announces plans to boost ethanol production
Years of supply and demand imbalances in China have led to a massive surplus, with stocks soaring to an unprecedented level in recent years. Over-production was mainly linked to a now discontinued official stockpiling scheme, under which farmers in the largest maize provinces were able to sell unlimited amounts into state reserves at guaranteed minimum prices. At the same time, cheaper feed grain imports flooded into southern consuming regions, choking off demand for locally produced maize. Authorities are now working hard to unwind part of these burdensome stocks. Under a plan jointly announced by 15 ministries and commissions in September, the government is seeking a massive expansion of the biofuel sector, targeting the blending of 10% ethanol (E10) into all automotive petrol by 2020. As well as mopping up surplus maize, the move is seen part of broader efforts to reduce China's carbon footprint. Although China is already one of the world's largest producers of biofuels, fuel ethanol is currently used only in a few provinces and accounts for around 1% of overall fuel consumption. The new plans are far more ambitious than those proposed last year, when the government announced its aim to double ethanol production by 2020. If E10 plans are fully implemented, an additional 35-40m tonnes of maize would be required as a feedstock each year.
Processing plants are already being built
China's targets are very ambitious, and it remains to be seen whether they can be achieved in such a short window. However, some local analysts recently reported that more than ten new fuel-ethanol plants are already planned to begin operating in 2018. Depending on how much processing capacity would need to be added, the initiative would require significant investment, tax incentives and probably additional subsidies. The local government in Heilongjiang, the largest maize province, has already issued guidelines on sharply boosting production of maize-based ethanol and high-quality starches.
China's maize stocks are likely to be larger than previously thought
Calls for such a steep and sustained increase in China's maize consumption suggest that local inventories could be much larger than we had previously expected. Our supply and demand estimates for the past decade have therefore been revised, with forecasts for feed use across this period lowered by an average of 18m tonnes per year, equivalent to around 10% of total annual consumption. With so much uncertainty about levels of feed demand in almost every country, such revisions are occasionally necessary when new data come to light. However, given the sheer size of its grain economy, any such changes for China can appear very large. Nevertheless, it should be stressed that the underlying trend is unchanged from before, and with so much of China's grain economy operating quite separately from the global market, these revisions do not have any wider price implications. We forecast China's overall maize demand to rise by 3.8% in 2017/18, and by a further 5.8% in 2018/19, as maize use in industrial processing begins to accelerate.

Supply
World maize supplies (production plus carryover stocks) have increased to record highs in recent seasons, topping 1bn tonnes each year since 2011/12. Encouraged by high market prices, production gains have stemmed from increases in plantings, as well as improved yields, with growers using new seed varieties, fertilisers and better farming practices to great effect. After surging by an estimated 10.7% in 2016/17, global output is projected to drop by 4.1% in 2017/18, to just over 1bn tonnes. Following earlier downgrades for Ukraine and the EU, we forecast production to fall in year-on-year terms in all major maize-growing countries. Nevertheless, total maize production would still be 4.2% above the five-year average. Boosted by ample carryovers from 2016/17, global supplies are still likely to remain comfortable, especially in the major exporting countries, where traders are likely to compete hard for available business. Forecasts for 2018/19 remain highly provisional, especially in the southern hemisphere, and will be subject to revision in the coming months. Overall, we expect global output to rise by around 1% in that season as good underlying demand and slightly tighter stocks encourage planting in some producers.
US output will drop in 2017/18, but by a lower margin than expected
The 2017/18 season has been quite unusual in the US, with many forecasters underestimating the size of this year's crop. Weather during the spring and early summer was mixed, and included periods of drought in some western growing states as well as excessive rainfall further east. Moreover, dry and hot conditions during July, usually the key determinant of Midwest yields, were thought likely to have resulted in widespread damage. A sustained drop in crop condition ratings across the season-with the proportion of plants rated good or excellent, and thus expected to yield at or above trend levels, down from the recent average-had reinforced this negative outlook. The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) took a much more optimistic view of the market, however. Its survey-based projections for the third-highest yields on record drew criticism from some quarters but, with combines now rolling, anecdotal yield reports have so far shown good results, with many farmers confirming better than expected output. The latest hybrids and varieties appear to be performing well, even under sub-optimal conditions. Advances in seed technology may also have been amplified by improved farming practices, including quicker seeding and more efficient use of fertilisers. With the harvest around 17% finished by the start of October, we have revised up our crop estimate to 360.3m tonnes (354m tonnes previously), although this is still 6% lower than the previous season's record outturn. There has been some recent chatter about the potential for a modest increase in sowings for the next crop, to be harvested in late 2018. Although prices nearer the time will shape final planting decisions, some growers are expected to rotate soybean area back into maize, reversing the trend seen in 2016/17. Assuming a 1% rise in planted area, output is forecast to increase fractionally, to 361.8m tonnes.
Southern hemisphere supplies will flood the market in the near term
The southern hemisphere maize production timetable is completely different from that north of the equator, with the earliest sowings beginning at least six months later on in the year. With much more known about the northern hemisphere prospects at that time, farmers in South America and parts of southern Africa are therefore better able to assess the market outlook in the run-up to planting. Should, for example, US crops be badly affected by a summer drought in a certain year, producers in Brazil and Argentina would be able to react to the inevitable spike in prices by upping maize plantings and looking to capture additional export demand. Although this might also be true for US growers assessing the outlook for South America before planting their next crops in the following year, the US is the price-setter and key market driver.
Southern hemisphere harvests are expected to be smaller in 2017/18
Planting of 2017/18 maize crops began in September in some parts of South America, with fieldwork stretching through until February. The heavy supply outlook and current weak market prices suggest that a pullback in area is likely. Assuming a normalisation of yields, cumulative production in the three top exporters could decline by about 8%, to 143.5m tonnes. The price outlook in Brazil is especially weak, with average local prices down by more than 40% year on year. Potentially better returns from soybeans mean that more area in the south of the country is likely to be diverted to oilseeds. As safrinha (second crop) maize will not be sown until soybeans are harvested in February, prices nearer the time will determine exactly how much is sown. We expect the outturn to fall to 91m tonnes in 2017/18, a decrease of 7% year on year. Similarly, a slump in South African prices means that sown area is likely to decline later this year, especially if exporters cannot dispose of the large surplus. Based on average yields, the crop could drop by a quarter, to 12.5m tonnes. The situation in Argentina is somewhat different. Producers there, still encouraged by the farm-friendly policies of the Macri administration, are expected to boost plantings, with production down by only 1m tonnes from the previous season, at 40m tonnes. The outlook for 2018/19 maize crops south of the equator is highly provisional, with sowings still 18 months away in some areas. We currently expect a modest expansion in South American crops but another static year in South African output.
Although Canada remains a small producer, output is trending higher
Although Canada is still a relatively small producer, consumer and exporter of maize, a number of interesting trends have developed in recent seasons. Annual production averaged almost 13m tonnes in the past five years, up from just over 11m tonnes in the previous five-year period. This expansion has turned Canada from a net importer of maize to a net exporter, while at the same time meeting increased demand from local ethanol producers. Despite far from perfect cropping weather so far this season, 2017/18 output is still expected to rise by 8%, to around 14.3m tonnes. Most maize is produced in the east of the country, where, similar to the US, the use of genetically modified varieties is widespread. However, the development of new maize hybrids, better suited to local growing conditions, has also allowed area to rise in non-traditional Western producing provinces. As technology improves further to better adapt to the relatively short summer and occasionally cool overnight temperatures, further expansion is expected in 2018-19, with more prairie farmers likely to include maize in their crop rotations. However, the required investment in machinery could be a limiting factor, especially if prices stay below earlier peaks.

Stocks and prices
We have raised our estimate of global maize stocks substantially, to 326m tonnes in 2017/18 (206m tonnes previously), following a detailed reassessment of China's maize supply and demand numbers over the past decade. Maize production in China is trending lower, and with consumption seen rising strongly in the years ahead it became clear that our previous forecast was too conservative and would have resulted in the depletion of China's stocks in just a few years. With feed use adjusted lower from 2011/12 onwards, projections for China's stocks are lifted across the whole period and are now seen at 201m tonnes at the end of 2017/18, a figure much closer to that circulating in the local press. We now expect China to account for 62% of total world stocks (40% previously). Yet with so much uncertainty about the size, location and quality of its stocks, many analysts prefer to exclude China when modelling world inventories. Combined stocks in the four main maize exporters (Argentina, Brazil, Ukraine and the US) are forecast to remain above the recent average in 2017/18, at a total of 75.1m tonnes, down by 1.5% year on year-with more than three quarters of this (59.8m tonnes) concentrated in the US. A relatively sharp drop is predicted in 2018/19, to 309m tonnes. Although exporter stocks will also tighten further, overall market supplies will remain at comfortable levels.

China's stock estimate is revised sharply higher
China's grain stocks have long been considered a state secret, with all parts of the grain balance sheet quite notional and based on very limited information. Sometimes the assumptions are proven to be incorrect, as highlighted by new information or a change in underlying market conditions. The USDA and other agencies last made major revisions to their own Chinese estimates in 2001, when the cumulative forecast for wheat, maize and rice stocks was more than tripled as it became apparent that inventories were much larger than previously assumed due to years of feed use being overestimated. Although our revised stock forecast diverges from those of the USDA and other major forecasting bodies, it brings stocks in China much closer to the levels that have been widely reported in local press in recent years, including figures quoted by key policy advisers and other Communist Party officials. However, the fact remains that these supplies are held primarily as a food security measure and will never be made available on the world market. Indeed, with China only a small importer, its domestic stock levels are unlikely to have a major impact on global prices. Moreover, the underlying trend for Chinese maize stocks remains unchanged, with stocks having built up since 2007/08, before tightening in recent seasons. We expect stocks to be drawn down further in 2018-19 as the government seeks to boost domestic consumption, particularly in the biofuels industry.
Prices are unlikely to show any significant growth in 2018-19
World maize markets have eased slightly in recent months, averaging more than 10% lower year on year in early October. Although US export prices were initially pulled higher by concerns about worse than normal Midwest crop conditions, early summer gains have eroded, as participants shed speculative long positions on signs that final yields would outperform earlier expectations. Light seasonal harvest pressure also weighed on markets in September as newly harvested supplies added to bountiful US stockpiles. Barring a late-season severe frost, the US crop is widely expected to be one of the biggest on record and supplies looks set to remain ample thorough the next season. Export prices in South America remained weak, hovering close to an eight-year low in Argentina, as traders worked hard to secure sales. However, with large customers well aware of the possibility of further price weakness, many have been reluctant to extend coverage. Despite some chatter about a potential La Niña weather shock in South America over the next six months, maize market fundamentals currently point to a low price environment. Given ample global stocks and easy feedgrain availabilities, we expect prices to remain low in 2018-19. With limited growth in consumption and trade, prices will begin to rise from the fourth quarter of 2017, with values likely to stay well below recent peaks.

Palm oil
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that global palm oil consumption grew by just 2.3% in 2016/17, to a total of 63.8m tonnes, despite its lower price compared with other oils. This compares unfavourably with annual average growth of 5.4% over the last five years. On current assessments, consumption growth in 2017/18 and 2018/19 looks likely to improve, but to remain below recent averages. Both Indonesia and Malaysia are looking for market opportunities, with the biodiesel market in China the most likely to absorb significant quantities of palm oil. However, it is likely only to offset declining consumption in the EU. The development of the biodiesel market in India, Malaysia and Indonesia could also contribute to stronger consumption growth.
India will remain the largest market for palm oil
Following a slow start to the 2016/17 season, Indian palm oil imports have increased each month since March. Recent import levels are consistent with our estimate for Indian consumption of 9.3m tonnes in 2016/17. Changes in the duties applied to imported palm oil will weigh on demand in 2017/18, and we expect below-average consumption growth that season, of 3.8%. Strong overall GDP growth in 2018/19 will help to support demand for palm oil, which we expect to increase by 4.5% year on year, to over 10m tonnes.
Indonesia's biodiesel sector will post decent growth in 2016/17 and 2017/18
Prospects for palm oil demand in Indonesia appear slightly more positive than we had initially thought. In addition to rising food use, palm oil is likely to become increasingly competitive against mineral oil as a base for biodiesel. The recent implementation by the EU of reduced duties for Argentinian biodiesel is expected to be followed by a similar reduction for Indonesian biodiesel. This good news is partially offset by the application by the US of anti-dumping duties on biodiesel from Indonesia (as well as Argentina). Nonetheless, we have revised up our forecast for Indonesian palm oil consumption to an aveage of 3.8% per year in 2017/18-2018/19 (3% previously). Overall consumption in 2018/19 should comfortably exceed 10m tonnes.
China's palm oil demand is hindered by competition from soybean oil
Buying interest from China at the start of the 2016/17 was strong but has since declined. Recent import levels have been below normal levels. Higher local crushing of imported soybean for meal has resulted in soybean oil being available at more competitive prices. As a result, we now estimate that palm oil consumption fell by 4.5% in 2016/17 (2.2% previously), to just over 5m tonnes. Looking ahead, there is some hope of a sustained recovery in instant noodle production; apparently, higher quality product has rekindled consumer interest. More significantly, the planned expansion of biodiesel use, part of a broader biofuels policy, has the potential to absorb large quantities of palm oil. We remain cautious about growth in China's palm oil demand in 2017/18 and 2018/19, given recent declines. An expansion of biofuels use underpins our forecast for steady demand growth, averaging 3.7% per year over the forecast period, to reach a total of 5.4m tonnes in the 2018/19 season.
Energy demand in the EU will rise, boosting usage
In 2016/17 the edible market for palm oil in the EU is likely to be broadly stable. Our estimate for palm oil consumption in 2016/17 is increased to 7.2m tonnes (7.1m tonnes previously), on a par with the previous two seasons. Lower palm oil prices should, in principle, stimulate additional consumption in 2017/18 and 2018/19. However, the use of palm oil in the biodiesel sector faces increased competition from recycled oils and fats, especially in the Netherlands and Italy, although this may be partially offset by higher use in Spain. An EU resolution that seeks to reduce palm oil use in the biodiesel sector on sustainability grounds also hangs over future consumption prospects. Biodiesel consumption in the EU is expected to increase over the next two years, reflecting changes in incorporation mandates. However, other feedstocks are likely to be the main beneficiaries of this growth. Therefore, we expect EU consumption to remain fairly flat on average during the forecast period.
Biodiesel consumption in Malaysia faces challenges
Malaysian palm oil consumption was hampered in 2017 by delays in implementing biodiesel incorporation mandates. We have made a small reduction in our estimate of 2016/17 consumption to reflect the difficulties of the biodiesel sector. The government continues its efforts to get the B10 mandate accepted by automobile manufacturers. However, we have also made small reductions in our forecasts of consumption in 2017/18 and 2018/19 to reflect the sluggish growth in biodiesel uptake.
Prospects for palm oil consumption in other countries are broadly positive
The top five consumers account for less than 55% of global demand, and a large number of other countries also consume palm oil. Consumption growth in these countries has been buoyant, but has slowed during the second half of 2016/17. A number of these countries are the target of palm oil exporters, especially in Africa and the Middle East. The largest of these other consumers, Pakistan, is showing steady growth in palm oil consumption. Attempts to encourage local oilseeds production have been largely unsuccessful since neither sunflowerseed nor rapeseed fit in well with other, more profitable crops. By 2018/19, Pakistan's palm oil consumption should be at almost 3m tonnes, similar to expected consumption in Malaysia.

Supply
We estimate that global palm oil production surged ahead by 12.2% in 2016/17, to a total of 65.4m tonnes. However, the rate of area increase is slowing, and yield growth is inhibited by the slow rate of tree replacement, especially in Malaysia. In 2017/18 we expect global palm oil production growth to be closer to the historical average, at 5.1%, which would push the total outturn to 68.7m tonnes in that season. The growth rate is likely to slow further in 2018/19 as the impact of stressed trees combines with a further slowdown in mature area growth. We expect output to be up by only 1% to 69.4m tonnes.
Yields in Indonesia are slowly recovering from the 2015/16 drought
Indonesia's palm oil output growth in 2016/17 continues to exceed expectations. At an estimated 36m tonnes, output is more than 15% higher than the drought-affected 2015/16 season. Yields have the potential to rise further in 2017/18, albeit at a slower rate, to over 37m tonnes. Although the rate of planting is slowing, the higher area in 2018/19 will offset any slowdown in yields from tree stress. We expect output of at least 38.4m tonnes.
Malaysian production is set to return to 2013/14 peak by 2017/18
Malaysia's recorded palm oil production in August was well below expectations, and even below the total recorded in July. Consequently, our estimate of the 2016/17 season's output is lower, at just over 19m tonnes (19.2m tonnes previously). Persistent labour shortages, the age profile of the trees and lower extraction rates all suggest only slow growth in output in 2017/18. In some regions, fertiliser uptake is estimated to be sub-optimal. For 2017/18 we retain our forecast that output will reach 20.2m tonnes, up by 6.2%. The factors mentioned above are unlikely to be resolved in the near term, although there appears to be some movement on the recruitment of foreign workers. For 2018/19 we expect output to remain fairly flat year on year, at about 20.1m tonnes. Given the difficulties of finding new land for planting, growth in Malaysian output relies on replacing ageing trees with younger, higher-yielding trees. The rate of replanting in recent years has been too low to prevent a slump in yields. To date there is little evidence to suggest a change in this pattern.
Thailand will register robust production growth in 2016/17-2017/18
For Thailand, the third-largest producer, we estimate that production will exceed 2.1m tonnes in 2016/17. Higher output is putting pressure on local prices of palm fruit. Some local sources suggest that prices are below the costs of production, inhibiting the use of inputs to stimulate yields. We expect an increase in the mature area to ensure continued growth in palm oil output in 2017/18-2018/19, albeit at a relatively slow rate, reflecting the difficulties of securing new land for planting. The slow growth in palm oil output is expected to result in a lower target for biodiesel use in Thailand. We expect Colombian output to show steady growth over the forecast period as its mature area expands. Recent yields have largely been above year-earlier levels, and returns to the crop have been favourable. A higher biodiesel incorporation rate mandate should also help to maintain interest in the crop.

Stocks and prices
Recorded palm oil stocks in Malaysia at the end of August showed a further substantial increase month on month, and remained above year-earlier levels. However, the increase was less than expected by many analysts, and it had a positive impact on market values. Our own estimates suggest that stocks at the end of the 2016/17 season will be adequate but below the historical average. We expect the market surplus to widen markedly in 2017/18, on the back of robust global production growth. A surplus, albeit smaller than that of 2017/18, is also expected in 2018/19. Stock levels could rise to an unprecedented 78 days of consumption by the end of the 2018/19 season.

Rising stock levels will push prices down further in 2018
In September both physical and futures prices for palm oil showed surprisingly large gains. The unexpected fall in Malaysian palm oil output and the comparatively low current stock levels appear to have been the main reasons for this increase. Futures prices have now retreated from the peak level recorded in mid-September. We consider that these price gains are likely to be only temporary, given the scale of the prospective surplus for the 2017/18 season. However, there remain significant uncertainties over the prospective increases in production, and markets are likely to remain firm until evidence of the production growth, and the consequent stock increases, is more firmly established. We consider that price falls in the final quarter of 2017 will be small, but will be larger in each of the quarters during 2018. By the end of 2018 palm oil is expected to be below US$600/tonne, with further falls in 2019.

Rapeseed oil
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that global rapeseed oil consumption fell by 7% year on year in 2016/17. We expect the same factors that constrained demand growth that season-namely rapeseed availability and competition with other oils-to weigh on consumption in 2017/18. Prospects for demand in China have been especially affected by lower availability estimates. As a result, we forecast global demand to contract by a further 0.7% in 2017/18, to less than 25m tonnes. We expect demand to improve in 2018/19, rising by 4.9%, on the assumption of improved availability and a further small drawdown in stocks.
EU consumption in 2016/17 will be limited by availability
EU consumption in 2016/17 was constrained by the availability of supply. Crop availabilities improved towards the end of that season, and as a result we now estimate that EU rapeseed oil demand contracted by 2.1% in 2016/17 (2.4% previously). However, at less than 10m tonnes, consumption was lower than in the previous three seasons. The 10m-tonne mark is unlikely to be breached in the 2017/18 season. Given current offtake levels, we now forecast EU demand to contract by 1.8% that year (2.6% previously). Nonetheless, potential usage is limited by the expected resumption of biodiesel imports from Argentina and possibly from Indonesia in mid-2018, which will weigh on consumption in the latter part of that season. There is an upside risk, however, that higher biodiesel exports to the US and minor upward revisions in mineral oil prices could offset this competition. Better local availability could push demand up in 2018/19, although the sluggish increase in mineral oil prices remains a downside risk.
Demand in China will be aided in 2016/17 by the release of reserve stocks
In China it appears that consumption in 2016/17 was marginally higher than previously estimated. Drawdowns of rapeseed stocks helped to support consump-tion of 5.6m tonnes (5.5m tonnes previously), although this remains well below the previous season. It is unlikely that a further drawdown of stocks can be used to maintain consumption in 2017/18. The downgrading of local production estimates means that usage is likely to fall further in 2017/18. We forecast Chinese consumption to drop by nearly 5% in that season, to 5.4m tonnes; even this level will require a significant increase in rapeseed imports for local crushing, and the maintenance of recent levels of rapeseed oil imports. The forecast is vulnerable to any change in price differentials, especially between rapeseed oil and palm oil.
India's consumption will rebound in 2016/17 in line with local availability
In India, competition from imported oils was strong during the 2016/17 season despite good local supplies. We estimate that consumption climbed by nearly 10% in 2016/17 to reach nearly 2.4m tonnes. Although India has struggled to achieve a sustained increase in its rapeseed oil output, global availability should be sufficient to help to keep import costs down and therefore support consumption growth in 2017/18. An acceleration in real GDP growth over the forecast period, to nearly 8% per year, will also support demand growth. We expect rapeseed oil consumption to increase by an average of 3% per year over 2017/18-2018/19, to over 2.5m tonnes each year. This forecast implies a significant increase in rapeseed oil imports to levels similar to the previous high of 2014/15.
Limited supplies will keep US and Japanese demand in check
Imports of rapeseed oil into the US continue to run ahead of earlier expectations. Coupled with improved domestic output, we expect consumption to have reached a record of over 2.6m tonnes in 2016/17. The recent application of anti-dumping duties on biodiesel from Argentina and Indonesia could stimulate additional demand for rapeseed oil as a feedstock during the forecast period. Overall, we expect US rapeseed oil consumption to expand by an average of 4.6% per year, to reach nearly 2.9m tonnes in the 2018/19 season. Several smaller consumers have switched away from rapeseed oil during 2016/17 as a result of its comparatively high price relative to other oils. Demand among these "other" consumers has fallen in 2016/17, but is expected to recover in 2017/18 and 2018/19.

Supply
Global rapeseed oil production declined for the third consecutive season in 2016/17, falling by 2.5% year on year to 24.7m tonnes. This is a downward revision from our previous forecast, of a 2.1% drop, owing to lower than expected production from China. We have also downgraded our outlook for 2017/18, when we expect global production to fall by 1.8% (0.7% previously) to 24.3m tonnes, the lowest level since 2010/11. Reductions in expected production in China and the EU will only be partially offset by higher estimates for Canada and India. Nonetheless, rapeseed remains an attractive crop to farmers and the 2018/19 area should expand. The impact of weather on yields is the major factor determining the size of the rapeseed harvest; normal yields would allow a significant jump in rapeseed oil output in 2018/19 as it recovers from several years of decline. We currently forecast growth of 6.8%, to 25.8m tonnes.
The EU rapeseed crop will recover only partially in 2017/18
The latest crush statistics suggest that 2016/17 EU rapeseed oil output will reach almost 10.2m tonnes, only marginally below the 2015/16 total. Prospects for rapeseed oil production in the following season have been helped by a further increase in the size of the 2017/18 rapeseed harvest. Higher estimates for crops in Romania, Bulgaria and the Baltic States more than offset a slightly lower estimate for Germany. At 21.8m tonnes, production is set to be 1.4m tonnes higher than last season, but still well below the 24.3m tonnes harvested in 2014/15. Greater local availability will be needed to offset expected lower imports from Australia, which will have a dampening effect on rapeseed oil output that season. We forecast production to remain flat in 2017/18, at 10.2m tonnes, although some analysts put the total lower. Assuming a return to normal crop yields in 2018/19, we expect rapeseed oil production to approach the record output of 10.7m tonnes recorded in 2014/15.
Chinese production will fall in 2016/17
Chinese farmers have lost interest in rapeseed production, with other crops showing higher levels of profitability in the absence of government support. Recent data show that the 2017/18 planted area was below previous reports, and that yields were also disappointing. As a result, we estimate that the 2017/18 harvest will reach just 5m tonnes. China's rapeseed oil production increasingly relies on imported rapeseed/canola through the additional capacity located at ports. Yet, the smaller domestic crop will have an impact. We currently forecast 2017/18 rapeseed oil production to expand by just 1.8% (7.7% previously), to 3.7m tonnes. Given the deteriorating return on rapeseed cultivation, higher rapeseed oil production for the 2018/19 season will require yet more imports. We currently forecast oil output to expand by 7% that season, but at less than 4m tonnes, this is still down by more than 25% from the 2014/15 season.
Canada's 2016/17 harvest may be below expectations
At just shy of 4m tonnes, Canadian canola oil production in 2016/17 was easily a new record. A recent Statistics Canada report indicates that the 2017/18 canola harvest will also be record-setting, at over 19.7m tonnes. Better than expected yields have so far been achieved and farmers are reported to be ready sellers. The Canadian crush industry will, however, face strong competition for available supplies, especially considering the downgraded estimate for Australian production. The strongest competition will come from the US and China. Under these circumstances, we expect Canadian 2017/18 canola oil production to increase by a modest 0.6% in that season, to just over 4m tonnes. Canola remains an attractive crop to Canadian farmers, and we assume an expansion of the planted area in 2018/19 to levels similar to the 2012/13 record. Normal yields should allow canola oil output to rise by 3.7%, to 4.2m tonnes.
India's production is poised for a rebound in 2016/17
In India, 2016/17 rapeseed crushings have been inhibited by imported vegetable oils, despite a large local harvest. We have made a further small reduction in our estimate of 2016/17 rapeseed oil production. The recent decline in rapeseed prices may dampen enthusiasm for the crop in 2017/18, however, and local rapeseed output is unlikely to replicate the 2016/17 level. Despite this, we expect 2017/18 rapeseed oil production to match that of 2016/17 at around 2.1m tonnes.

 % change -0.6 -4.8 -2.5 -1.8 6.3
Sources: Oil World; USDA; The Economist Intelligence Unit.

Australian production is likely to fall in 2017/18 owing to dry conditions
Overly dry conditions have persisted in most of the main canola producing areas of Australia. For example, in Western Australia, the largest producing state, yields are expected to drop by as much as 35%, owing to the lack of rainfall. Overall, Australian production in 2017/18 is expected to reach less than 3m tonnes, well below the 4.4m tonnes harvested in 2016/17 and the lowest total since 2010/11. In Ukraine, harvesting of the winter rapeseed planted area is complete, with production confirmed at 2.1m tonnes. Winter plantings to date suggest a further increase in output in 2018/19.
Stocks and prices
The global rapeseed oil market will remain in deficit in 2016/17, for the third consecutive season. Stocks of both rapeseed and rapeseed oil (when measured against consumption) are well below normal levels, although still not at record lows. Another market deficit is expected in 2017/18, with oil stocks expected to drop to their lowest level. However, rapeseed stocks will remain available during 2017/18, and a potential acceleration in crush rates could help to ease pressure on rapeseed oil stocks. With the Canadian harvest so well advanced, the major uncertainty remains that of the Indian crop to be harvested in the February-April 2018 period. Our current projections suggest that the market will remain in deficit in the 2018/19 season. Depending on the outcome of the 2018/19 harvests, crush rates could increase but global consumption may need to be further rationed from current projected levels.

Low stocks will put upward pressure on prices from late 2017
In line with market tightening, physical prices of rapeseed oil continued to rise in September, although the increase was comparatively small. Canola futures prices eased during September, reflecting good progress with the harvest, although they began to rise again in early October. Given that stocks appear set to remain tight over the forecast period, sustained price rises are the most likely course for rapeseed oil prices. Price gains will be limited by the high availability of other oils. However, prices look set to be above US$900/tonne during 2018 with the potential to exceed US$1,000/tonne by the end of the 2018/19 season.

Rice
Demand
With human consumption of rice continuing to drive up overall use in Asia, where populations are rising, global rice usage is expected to reach a new high of 495m tonnes in 2017/18, up by almost 2% from the previous season. As in the past, relatively tiny volume increases are likely in other regions, such as Africa and South America. With respect to other components of demand, however, such as feed and industrial sectors, these are anticipated to contract. The outlook for the 2018/19 season is still uncertain, since it depends on factors that will remain unknown for quite some time, such as policy frameworks, local crop outcomes and import needs. As such, our projection of 501m tonnes rests on the assumption that annual consumption growth will return close to trend.
Trade in rice will continue to grow, but at a slower rate than in 2017
Africa and Asia account for three-quarters of all rice imports, primarily white and parboiled grades sourced from Thailand, India, Pakistan and Vietnam. In Sub-Saharan Africa in particular, a significant share of demand-mainly for high-quality white and parboiled supplies-is met by imports. With buyers in those regions expected to remain active in the global market, trade is projected to continue to grow in the next two years, to reach 44.4m tonnes in 2019, which would be the largest volume on record. However, this is a downward revision from our previous forecast, of 45.1m tonnes, owing to the sharp rise in trade volumes in 2017 and the possibility that many importers will buy less in the coming years, owing to more comfortable domestic stocks. In addition, we believe that a portion of the increase in demand in 2017 was due to strong interest in Thai government reserves, especially among African importers.
China's needs are expected to be central to the rice trade in 2018-19
China is currently the world's leading buyer, with annual imports likely to be between 4.5m and 5m tonnes during the forecast period. Indonesia, Bangladesh and the Philippines are set to be significant importers as they aim to maintain buffer reserves. In Sub-Saharan Africa, a significant share of total demand-mainly for high-quality white and parboiled supplies-is met by imports. Shipments to Africa are likely to rise in 2017/18-2018/19 after contracting in the two previous seasons, as economic growth improves slightly and international rice prices remain low.
China is by far the world's largest consumer of rice, accounting for about 30% of global demand. The bulk of national consumption is made up of locally produced rice, but in recent years China has also become the biggest importer of rice, mainly of high-quality broken types from Thailand and Vietnam. Prices for domestic long-grain milled rice still command hefty premiums over supplies from other major origins in Asia, owing to the easy availability of rice from major suppliers outside China, supporting China's import demand.
Lower duties will encourage rice imports by Bangladesh in 2018-19
Bangladesh is one of the leading rice markets within Asia, with annual demand reaching at least 35m tonnes. Three domestic crops are cut each year, namely the boro (seeded in December-January and harvested in April-May), aus (planted in March-April and cut in June-July) and aman (sown in July-August and normally threshed in November-December). Although the bulk of the country's rice needs are met by domestic crops, significant quantities are sometimes procured from the world market. Bangladesh importers and millers have sought to get tariffs reduced as a means of boosting imports, primarily from Thailand and India, with the latter typically the largest supplier in recent years. The country has recently entered into a long-term arrangement with Vietnam for up to 1m tonnes of imports per year until 2022. Trade reports have also highlighted the possibility of significant purchases from Myanmar.
The government is looking to boost rice imports to build reserves and rein in local prices after flash floods hit domestic output. To this end, the government announced in mid-2017 that the tariff applied to rice imports had been cut from 28% to 10% to boost purchases. Shortly afterwards, it was reported that imports in fiscal year 2017/18 (October-September) were likely to amount to 1.5m tonnes, the highest in many years, which will boost buffer stocks.
The Philippines may be a large buyer, as state reserves are historically low.
In the Philippines, stocks held by the National Food Authority, the grain procurement agency, have dwindled to their lowest level in around a decade. In contrast, however, inventories held by private households and commercial warehouses remain especially comfortable. Underscoring thin state reserves, imports progressed strongly over the course of the 2017, with the total for the first six months of the year at 530,000 tonnes, an 80% increase on the same period of 2016. With more imports expected throughout the rest of the year, arrivals are forecast to be 40% larger in 2017, at 1.4m tonnes. Purchases are likely to remain high in the following years.
