Supply
We have revised down our forecast slightly for world rice output in 2017/18, to 487m tonnes (488.6m tonnes previously), translating into a year-on-year increase of just 0.3%. With limited prospects for an expansion of seeded area in China, by far the world's most important producer, output there is likely to again fall below its 2015/16 peak of 146m tonnes. Conversely, we assume that area increases in other parts of Asia, together with some improvement in yields, will boost output in those areas. The outlook for 2018/19 is highly provisional. Nonetheless, given that only a small expansion of paddy plantings is likely, an increase in global output will almost certainly be dependent on better yields. At 492m tonnes, the world outturn is projected to be up by 1.1% year on year. All of our scenarios assume continued state support to farmers in Asia and beneficial weather.
India's main agricultural crops are cultivated during two distinct seasons: kharif crops are sown between June and October and rabi crops in November-December. Kharif crops, of which rice is by far the most important, are rain-fed and therefore critically reliant on monsoon precipitation, which typically arrives in the southern state of Kerala in early June and lasts for about four months, accounting for 70% of the country's annual rains.
The 2017 monsoon was 5% below average, weighing slightly on output
In India, where the kharif-planting season is now finished, the area planted to paddy was slightly smaller year on year, but still fairly resilient compared with the average of recent seasons. The 2017 monsoon was around 5% below the long-term average; taking into account its impact on yield potential in some regions, as well as prospects for the winter-sown rabi crop, we project acreage to be broadly steady year on year. Accordingly, we have revised down slightly our forecast for full-year output in 2017/18, by 2m tonnes, to 108.5m tonnes, representing a small contraction year on year. Nevertheless, this should still ensure that availabilities for domestic use and exports are sufficiently comfortable to maintain each at high levels. In 2018/19 everything will again depend on the pattern of the monsoon, which will begin around June 1st 2018. If it is beneficial, and the support price is maintained at an attractive level, another above-average kharif outturn is likely.
India should remain the biggest rice exporter in 2017 and 2018
Based on their strong pace to date, which has been supported by large ship-ments to Africa and South Asia, India's exports in 2017 are expected to reach 11m tonnes, making the country the largest supplier to the world market for the sixth consecutive season. This represents an upgrade of 300,000 tonnes from our previous export forecast. Shipments in 2018 are anticipated to be slightly smaller year on year, at 10.7m tonnes. Within the total, basmati rice is mostly exported to Middle Eastern countries and Europe, while non-basmati rice is largely exported to Africa and some markets in Asia, principally South Asia. We assume that in 2019, competition from Thailand and, to a lesser extent, Vietnam, will result in a slight decline in sales, to 10.5m tonnes.
China's exports have expanded in 2017, mainly because of sales to Africa
Although China has emerged as the world's biggest importer of rice in recent years, it has, for the most part, been a tiny exporter. Over recent seasons its exports have fluctuated between 200,000 tonnes and 500,000 tonnes, with most heading to markets in Asia, including South Korea and Japan-these being part of minimum commitments to import by those nations under World Trade Organisation obligations.
However, in contrast with recent years, trade data show a significant expansion of exports in early 2017, mainly to destinations in Africa. Customs data show that January-June shipments amounted to almost 600,000 tonnes, roughly five times higher than in the same period last year. It is unclear whether such high sales can be sustained, especially since some of these shipments may have come in the form of aid. Nevertheless, it is worth noting that China is believed to sit on massive state reserves, despite a significant share of it being unfit for human consumption. China's exports have occasionally risen above 2m tonnes, notably in 2003, with much of the increase going to Africa and the Americas. In full-year 2017 volumes could be as large as 950,000 tonnes, but are likely to return to more normal levels in the following two years.
Production prospects for 2017/18 in Thailand are very positive
For many years Thailand was the biggest supplier of rice to world markets. However, a combination if its intervention buying programme and heavy competition from India resulted in it losing that position. More recently, exports have been boosted by availabilities from the government's stockpile, but prospects for production will ultimately shape the country's exportable surplus over the next two years. In the current season (2017/18) prospects for the main crop appear solid, with harvesting due to take place in late 2017. Cultivation is currently in the reproductive stage and progressing well. Cummulative precipitation during 2017 is estimated to be around one-quarter higher than average, while the impact of flooding in September is expected to be minimal. Good water levels will also be important during the development of the irrigated, off-season crop, which will be threshed next year.
Support from the Thai government will support output in 2017/18
Assuming the planted area is expanded in both seasons, total production is projected at 20.4m tonnes, up from 19m tonnes in the previous year and a five-year high. A further increase in main-crop sowings is projected to push output up to 22m tonnes in 2018/19.
In mid-September the Thai government approved a THB73bn (US$2.2bn) budget for 2017/18 on farm paddy pledging program to include main-crop rice varieties from November 1st 2017 through to the end of February 2018. The scheme is aimed at supporting domestic prices during the main crop harvest, with up to 2m tonnes of paddy set to be procured. The intervention price for white rice is 3% above that of the previous season. Additional measures have been announced, with farmers, millers and traders also receiving support in the form of subsidies and soft loans, as a means of encouraging participants to store rice through to 2018.
The government's stock dispoals have largely been successful
The Thai government has been saddled with excess reserves in recent years, an overhang of its earlier-and much-criticised-intervention buying programmes. However, considerable progress was made in disposing of this stockpile during the first half of 2017. Most government-held reserves have been of a questionable quality, with a large portion being sold to feed (as a substitute for corn and for imported feed wheat in swine feed rations) and industrial (ethanol) producers. However, a considerable volume of food-grade stocks have been made available to exporters at attractive prices, and these have been sold, or earmarked, for shipment to markets in Africa. This will help to sustain Thailand's exports at about 10.2m tonnes in 2018, with the potential to edge higher, to 10.5m tonnes, in the following year.
Vietnam faces competition from smaller and established exporters in Asia
Vietnam is a medium-sized rice producer but a major exporter. It typically accounts for 5-6% of global output but 15% of exports, making it the world's third-largest exporter, behind India and Thailand. The Vietnam Food Association oversees policy surrounding rice export registration requirements and the setting of the country's minimum export price for grades. Most exports are broken rice grades, including 5% and 25% varieties, with total sales usually shaped by deliveries to Asian markets, especially China, as well as to Africa. Exports are expected to pick up in 2017 and 2018, to reach 5.7m tonnes and 6.3m tonnes respectively. This will be because of firmer demand from leading importers. We expect Vietnam to maintain its position as the world's third biggest exporter in 2019 and beyond, although volumes are unlikely to exceed 7m tonnes in any season, given continued volumes from India and Thailand, as well as the growing competitive threat from other, relatively small exporters such as Cambodia and Myanmar.
A much smaller crop will constrain US rice exports in 2017/18
The US rice harvest is well advanced, estimated at close to 80% finished by late the beginning of October. Based on a heavy drop in plantings, production in 2017/18 is expected to fall to just 5.7m tonnes, down from 7.1m tonnes in the previous season. This would be the smallest outturn in two decades, and is expected to tighten availabilities for sale on the international market, notwith-standing a drop in domestic use. Nevertheless, the contraction will be limited by large opening stocks. Shipments in the local marketing year, starting on August 1st 2017, are forecast at 3.4m tonnes, down from 3.7m tonnes in the previous year. US rice is sold globally, but major markets, mainly for paddy (rough rice) exports, include Central and Latin America, owing to proximity.

Stocks and prices
Following a marginal drop in 2016/17, world rice stocks are forecast to fall more appreciably in 2017/18, by 8m tonnes, to a seven-year low of 96.9m tonnes. Although we expect China's supportive policies for farmers to ensure another rise in inventories, this will be in contrast to falls in the major global suppliers, as well as in other countries. In Thailand, for example, the government has had much success in disposing of its huge intervention stockpile. Inventories held by the world's leading exporters, which also include India, Pakistan, the US and Vietnam, are forecast at 22m tonnes, down by 5m tonnes year on year. This would be the smallest amount in a decade and highlights a global market that appears to be tighter than headline figures might suggest.
Stocks are expected to drop in the next two seasons on rising consumption
In 2018/19 although world output is still expected to climb from this season's record level, rising consumption will also cut into stocks, pushing them to another multi-year low of 87.7m tonnes. It is assumed that stockbuilding in China will continue, especially since imports are set to remain high, but exporters' reserves may fall once more.

Following significant, demand-driven increases in earlier months, markets in Asia have generally eased since mid-2017. The price of Thailand's 100% Grade B, a world benchmark, was quoted at US$389/tonne fob Bangkok in the first week of October, up marginally over the month, but still almost 20% below the high of mid-May. Downward pressure at Asian origins has come from slower open-market demand and seasonal pressure as some leading exporters harvested crops. In addition, while tighter supplies have supported values on some occassions, prospects for another good kharif outturn will have had a bearish influence on India's market.
However, in contrast, US milled rice export prices have remained high despite a slight fall month on month as the certainty of a heavy fall in production in 2017/18, and recent adverse weather, has boosted sentiment. The 4% broken variety was trading at US$515/tonne on October 5th, down by US$5/tonne from previous month, but well above the US$400/tonne level seen in April.
The pace of demand is likely to slow in the final months of 2017, at a time when the bulk of main crop harvests in major exporters come on stream. As a result, we have revised down our fourth-quarter price forecast slightly, to US$395/tonne (US$410/tonne previously). This results in an average price for that year of US$391/tonne, up by just 1.2% year on year.
Our supply and demand forecasts to the end of 2019 suggest there is potential for some upward pressure on prices as global supplies begin to tighten, owing to contraction in major exporters. By the fourth quarter of 2019 we forecast a price of US$425/tonne and, while this would equate to a five-year high, it would still be well below the levels witnessed in 2009-13. Accordingly, this would suggest that rice should remain attractively priced relative to the past. Of course, our forecasts for supply and demand, and hence prices, do imply that actual crop outcomes are as set out, and that there will be no significant changes in trade policy by importers or exporters during the next two years.

Soybeans
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global soybean consumption to expand by 4.3% in 2017/18-building on strong growth in the previous season, of an estimated 6.1%-in line with rising usage in animal feed and other sectors. At a total of 339m tonnes, global consumption in 2017/18 would be more than 100m higher than a decade earlier, largely owing to higher demand from China. However, some smaller consuming regions, including the EU, Africa and the Middle East, will also contribute to rising demand. Prospects for 2018/19 are unclear, since crop outcomes will not be known for another 12-18 months. However, we expect that rising usage in the animal feed sector could support similar demand growth that season, of 4.4%, to reach a record 354m tonnes.
World soybean trade in 2017/18 is forecast to rise for the seventh year in a row, to a record of 148.7m tonnes, with most of the expansion due to rising needs in China, as well as smaller markets in Asia. With demand from those same countries provisionally expected to increase, traded volumes could surpass 153m tonnes in 2018/19. These figures have been revised up (from 147m tonnes and 152m tonnes, respectively), owing to quicker than expected sales in 2016/17.
Feed usage will drive overall demand up and will mostly be met by imports
China is by far the world's largest consumer and importer of soybeans, with growth largely driven by expanding demand from the country's vast animal feed sector. In 2017/18 we expect China's total consumption to reach a new record of 105m tonnes, representing impressive growth of about 6% and approaching a third of the amount used globally. Imports are forecast to total 95.5m tonnes, or more than 90% of consumption-which highlights the global market's dependence on Chinese processors. Although the government is looking to boost local output, it seems that imports will continue to account for a dominant, and possibly rising, share of overall requirements, especially in feed sectors. Most of what is produced locally is likely to be channelled to food and other smaller markets.
China's imports in 2018/19 are expected to close in on 100m tonnes
Despite reports of large stocks of soybeans and associated pressure on crush margins, import demand growth has remained robust throughout 2017, with buyers encouraged by a world market that is amply supplied and attractively priced. The country's value-added tax (VAT) rate was reduced by 2 percentage points from July 1st, which has helped to boost imports. The outlook for 2018/19 is tentative, but China's full-season purchases could approach 100m tonnes.
Nonetheless, the Chinese government's intention to end maize stockpiling, announced in 2016, remains a downside risk. The move aims to encourage the use of maize at the expense of other feed grains, which have been imported in great quantities in recent years. Higher maize consumption in the pork and poultry sectors could also raise questions surrounding the use of high-protein meals, primarily soybean meal. The impact, however, is likely to be marginal, as soybean meal is the most abundantly produced of all oilseed meals, with its attractiveness as a feed ingredient stemming from its high-protein quality and nutritional value compared with alternatives.
Ample domestic supplies will support demand in the US
With another bumper crop expected to result in a further swelling of domestic supplies, US consumption in 2017/18 is forecast to remain close to the previous season's high, at 56m tonnes. Aside from requirements locally, total use will be underpinned by rising exports of soybean meal. Similar trends will enable domestic demand potentially to edge up in 2018/19, to 57m tonnes.
Soybean consumption in Argentina will continue to be underpinned by growing international demand for soybean meal, of which Argentina is the dominant supplier to world markets. In Brazil, further increases in consumption are anticipated as bigger local soybean crops boost supplies for processing.

Supply
Since the planting season in South America is only now getting underway, there is considerable uncertainty about prospects for the 2017/18 world outturn. Never-theless, in the northern hemisphere, another season of big or record crops can be expected, judging by completed plantings and intentions, and early field reports. We expect these factors to support the second-largest harvest ever. With yields potentially falling short of what was achieved in 2016/17, production will be shaped by area gains. The following year (2018/19) will ultimately depend on outcomes in 2017/18, which are currently subject to speculation. Accordingly, our projection of a 0.7% year-on-year increase, to 344.7m tonnes, reflects our assumption of a slight rise in sowings and trend yields.
US production in 2017/18 is likely to set a new record, helped by better yields
The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) expects seeded area in 2017/18 to increase by around 7% year on year, to 36.2m ha, the highest on record. In addition to a switch of acreage from maize and spring wheat, expanded area also stems from a steep contraction in winter wheat sowings.
Weather patterns during the current growing season have been a cause for concern in many parts of the Midwest, including dry and hot conditions in the east and in the northern Plains, with excessive rains a problem in eastern regions. Accordingly, it seems highly likely that average yields will not match those of the previous year. Nonetheless, local official projections and recent field reports reflect a more positive yield outlook; to reflet this, we have raised our 2017/18 production forecast to a record 120m tonnes, an increase of 2.6% year on year (from a marginal decrease previously). Together with high carryover stocks from the season before (ending August 31st), a crop of that size will ensure ample supplies for domestic use and export. We assume that recent delays to harvesting in parts of the Midwest will not have a detrimental impact.
US exports will reach a new record in 2017/18, but to stay below Brazil
US exports progressed strongly during the 2016/17 season, totalling 58.1m tonnes by end-August 2017 (the end of the marketing year), up significantly from 2015/16. The solid pace was shaped by international demand from Asia, but also a range of other, relatively small importers, including those in Africa and the Middle East. For 2017/18 we expect shipments to expand to 60m tonnes, a new high. Although the pace of sales has stepped up significantly in recent weeks, they remain well behind a year earlier; in the week to September 28th-which largely corresponds to the end of the first full month in the marketing year-all export commitments totalled 23.3m tonnes, down by almost 20% year on year. This proabaly reflects Brazil's strong export pace in 2017; some buyers appear hesitant to enter the world market, preferring to wait for the bulk of northern hemisphere supplies to come on stream at attractive prices.
Growers are likely to increase the planted area in 2018/19
Planting intentions for 2018/19 in the northern hemisphere are highly tentative at this stage and much will depend on relative prices at the time of planting, as well as crop rotation. While there is an argument in favour of increased corn plantings at the expense of soybeans following 2017/18 seeding patterns, support for soybean acreage could come from the continued expansion of global trade, driven by China's needs. We anticipate that the area planted to soybeans could contract by up to 3% in 2017/18. Combined with assumed trend yields, the 2018/19 outturn is projected at 114m tonnes-which is 5% lower than the previous season, but still the third-largest harvest of all time.
A huge crop will be cut in Canada, with further increases likely in the long term
The area for harvest in Canada is estimated at a record of 2.9m hectares, an unprecedented year-on-year expansion of 33%, driven by expanded acreage in the non-traditional growing areas of Manitoba and Saskatchewan, largely at the expense of wheat and canola. One of the key attractions is that Canadian growers are able to tap in to a fast-growing global market. Added to this, the crop requires less intensive application of inputs, such as fertilisers, compared with alternatives, and new varieties have been developed that can be cultivated in areas that were previously unsuitable. Despite the significant expansion of seeded area, some reduction in yields is expected, especially as earlier reports from Manitoba and Saskatchewan pointed to difficulties with crop development due to challenging weather. According to Canada's Department of Agriculture and Agri-Food, output is expected to increase by 1.5m tonnes to 8m tonnes in 2017/18. Exports are projected to rise to 5.6m tonnes, up from 4.4m tonnes in the previous season.
Brazil's exports are likely to smash previous records in 2017/18
Brazil's huge 2016/17 crop boosted availabilities to record levels and, given expected growth in trade, positioned Brazil to export significantly larger volumes in the local marketing year (which closes at end-January 2018). We believe that total shipments could reach a record of at least 62m tonnes, up by 14% from 54.4m tonnes the previous year. With prospects for a marked rise in domestic prices in Brazil given current conditions, farmers may have significant stocks available for sale in the closing stages of the current year. Furthermore, with another big US crop anticipated and availabilities coming on stream in the final quarter of this year, there is potential for significant supplies in late 2017 and associated downward pressure on prices.
Growth in sowings in Brazil is expected in 2017/18, but may be limited by low prices
With plenty of land available, a further expansion of soybean area in Brazil is possible in 2017/18, and we are projecting 2% growth, to 34.5m hectares. Nevertheless, downside risks remain; current market conditions, including low domestic and soybean prices, coupled with exchange-rate uncertainty, will make it hard for many growers to cover production costs. Much will depend on the US harvest later this year and its global market impact.
It seems likely that, despite the aformentioned area increase, some growers will be tempted to scale back expenditure on essential inputs to minimise overall costs. Nevertheless, maize prices in Brazil are signficantly below year-ago levels-having fallen by a larger margin than soybean prices did-which makes it likely that some farmers will have switched a portion of their intended primary, or full-season, maize cropland to soybeans (most likely in areas where yields are lowest). Planting of the 2017/18 soybean crop began on September 11th in the state of Paraná-a few days earlier than normal-as part of a government experiment to see if early fieldwork is viable. Other states, including the major producing region of Mato Grosso, followed shortly after.
A potential La Niña event stands to bring drier than usual weather in late 2017
Planting was, however, stalled by difficult conditions with soils deemed to be too dry for seeding to advance in many areas. However, the first significant rains fell across central and southern Brazil in early October, improving the outlook somewhat. The rainfall was expected to continue throughout the first ten days of the month, before drier weather returns. Precipitation has been heavier in southern Brazil, including hail and high winds, with more expected in future. Moreover, the Brazilian National Meteorological Institute (Inmet) has released its forecast for the final quarter of 2017, which highlights the risk that a La Niña weather event will form. Many farmers in Brazil are already concerned about the potentially slow start to the season, so the potential of a mild La Niña-which typically brings below-normal rainfall for east-central and south-eastern Brazil-has added to their concerns.
With yields unlikely to be near those achieved in 2016/17, we forecast output to fall slightly in 2017/18, by 5% year on year, to 108m tonnes. Planting of the 2018/19 crop will not begin until mid-September 2018, so the outlook is highly provisional. Based on some further area expansion and trend productivity, output could be close to the 2016/17 high.
Soybean-Free Institute, a new body that is tasked with promoting the production of varieties of the oilseed that have not been genetically modified (GM), will promote non-GM soybeans around the world. Its membership includes producers, fertiliser suppliers, exporters and a range of other bodies. Non-GM varieties typically command a premium in the global market, and the Mato Grosso Institute of Agricultural Economics estimates that 10%-15% of acreage in the state in 2016/17 was seeded to those types.
Access to Northern Arc ports will be key to lifting export volumes in long term
We expect Brazil's exports to rise to an average of 65m tonnes per year in the 2017/18 and 2018/19 marketing seasons (February-January). In the longer term, however, soybean export growth will depend on the ability to move supplies more effectively to Brazil's Northern Arc ports-a collection of facilities designed to boost exports. As was the case last season, data from the Mato Grosso Institute of Agricultural Economics underscored slow farmer sales amid low domestic and world prices: by mid-September just 15% of anticipated 2017/18 crops had been sold, down from 26% one year ago.
Production in Argentina could fall in 2017/18 on potential area declines
In Argentina, production in 2017/18 is forecast to fall by 4.4% year on year, to 54m tonnes, as many farmers are still likely to favour other crops, such as corn, following the late-2015 elimination of export taxes. While the government is set gradually to reduce soybean export levies over the course of 2018 and 2019, the crop will still not be as an attractive as others. Fieldwork for the 2017/18 crop is expected to begin in central areas in late October and early November. As such, there have been hightened concerns about the impact of earlier heavy rains and flooding, with some fields too wet ahead of the planting campaign. A period of dry weather is needed to ensure that soils are in good shape. However, as with Brazil, seeding decisions will depend on market conditions at the time of planting. In both years Argentina will remain by far the dominant supplier of soybean products to world markets.
China's output is rising, but still only meets a fraction of domestic demand
Despite being by far the world's largest importer, China is also a minor producer of soybeans. However, its potential has been capped by limited yield gains compared with those of the world's big players, as well as the attraction of alternative crops such as wheat, corn and rice. Nonetheless, in August 2016 the Chinese authorities published a National Oilseed Development Plan, which aims to boost domestic production to 60m tonnes by 2020. The scheme will provide support for oilseed production, processing, technical extension and innovation. In 2016/17 total acreage is up by an estimated 10% from the previous season, and a further increase is likely in 2017/18, with a small portion of land coming from the switching out of corn production in north-eastern areas. Total output in that season is expected to rise to a peak of 14.3m tonnes, up from 13.1m tonnes in the previous year, while the same influences will underpin another increase in output to 15.2m tonnes in 2018/19.

India's production remains reliant on seasonal variations in rainfall
The monsoon season is now complete in India-where the soybean crop is entirely a summer-sown crop-with cumulative precipitation in the June-September period down by 5% from the long-term average. Seeding fell by 900,000 hectares compared with the previous season, to 10.5m hectares. As a result, we now expect production to fall to 11m tonnes in 2017/18, a decrease of 8.3% year on year (4.2% previously). As it does every season, the production outlook in 2018/19 will hinge on the monsoon, which will arrive on the south-west coast in early June 2018. Output is pegged at 12m tonnes in that year.
Stocks and prices
Following a record-breaking year in 2016/17-both in terms of production and growth in global stocks-the situation in future years is likely to be somewhat tighter. While a further increase in inventories is expected in 2017/18, this is likely to be extremely modest, given that world output will fall as consumption expands. At 121.7m tonnes, global reserves are forecast to be around 3m tonnes larger than in the prior season, although this would be around 35m tonnes higher than the previous five-year average.
Looking below the top-line numbers, US ending stocks (at the close of its marketing year, on August 30th 2018) are projected to be slightly bigger year on year, although this contrasts with potential falls in Argentina and Brazil. China may also see some destocking following recent years of heavy imports.

While this suggests little scope for a price recovery in that year, the supply and demand outlook does assume that conditions for crop development are favourable in most countries. Should crops falter in any of the main producing countries, then the balance sheet could be significantly tighter and may fuel a run-up in prices. Nevertheless, based on our current projections, we see a drop in inventories of a little over 9m tonnes in 2018/19. This is significant since it would be the first annual contraction in carryovers in seven seasons.
Export quotations in the US were modestly lower in the month leading up to October 5th. US futures showed strength at times, linked to firmer international demand, as well as to concerns about southern hemisphere weather as the 2017/18 planting campaigns got underway; however, weakening basis levels at US Gulf export terminals, as harvesting in the Midwest advanced, weighed on prices overall. More recently, reports of delays to fieldwork have supported prices, limiting overall monthly declines. At an average of US$376/tonne fob Gulf in early October, export prices were down by US$7/tonne over the month. Given the concerns about the impact of adverse seeding conditions on Argentina and Brazil, quotations there held steady at US$380/tonne and US$383/tonne, respectively.
We expect prices to contract slightly in the final quarter of 2017, pushing the full-year average price down by 3.3% compared with 2016, to US$377/tonne fob. On the basis of our forecast for a modest rise in global stocks, the potential for price gains in 2018 is very limited. We expect prices to rise by just 1.2% that year, before climbing more quickly, by 3%, in 2018 as global stocks dip slightly.

Sugar
Demand
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that global annual sugar consumption will expand by an average of 1.2% in 2017/18-2018/19 (October-September), roughly in line with the average over the past four seasons. Rising demand will continue to be underpinned by population growth and rising incomes in emerging markets, where urbanising populations are gradually adopting the food-and-drink habits of developed-world countries. Sugar plays a key role in this dietary shift, as a sweetener in food and beverages, and as a binding and preserving agent in processed foods, including use by fast-food outlets. However, a modest slowdown in economic growth in emerging markets (particularly in Asia) will dampen the pace of consumption growth in the coming years. Moreover, heightened awareness about the health implications of excess sugar in diets will put pressure on consumption growth in developed markets, where the average consumption often already exceeds recommended levels. Amid consumer pressure on the food processing industry to reduce sugar and, in some markets, the introduction of "sin taxes" on sugary products, a gradual shift towards synthetic sweeteners will somewhat lessen demand for sugar. Moreover, owing to the growing supply of starch-based sweeteners in both Asia (where Chinese production is expanding rapidly) and Europe (whose market will be liberalised in September 2017), these cheaper alternatives will further limit demand for sugar in the food and drinks industry. Meanwhile, the impact of relatively low global sugar prices on consumption will be muted by long-standing domestic pricing policies in many developed countries and new protectionist moves in several emerging markets, both of which will limit the extent to which lower prices are passed through to consumers.
Slower GDP growth in China will weigh on sugar demand
Sugar consumption in China is low, at around 11 kg per head compared with an average of 24 kg in developed countries, leaving considerable room for growth. Changing consumer tastes and rising urbanisation will continue to spur demand. However, we expect the pace of consumption growth to moderate as slower economic growth dampens investment and weighs on income growth. This will be compounded by the growing supply of starch-based sweetener, which is a cheaper rival to sugar in the beverages industry, and higher domestic sugar prices, which are a likely consequence of the government's recent move to restrict imports. Amid pressure from domestic producers to support the local industry, the government has reduced permits (to 1m tonnes, roughly half the previous level) and raised duties (from 50% to 95%) on out-of-quota sugar imports. These measures have led to a sharp drop in import demand, which shrank by 45% in August compared with year-earlier levels. However, we doubt that China will be able to scale up domestic production in 2017/18-2018/19 to a level that could fully satisfy its domestic demand and preserve its strategically high level of stocks. It is therefore expected to remain a fairly significant player in the global market.
Consumption in India is forecast to recover as prices normalise
After consumption in India slumped in 2016/17, amid high post-drought prices and unsupportive policy moves (including demonetisation and the removal of some consumer subsidies), we expect demand to recover in the coming years as domestic supply improves. The government has come under pressure from industry stakeholders to protect the local industry from a flood of imports, as low global sugar prices and a strong rupee leave domestic producers struggling to compete. In response, it raised import duties from 40% to 50% in mid-2017. However, the near-term impact of this will be muted by the strong local harvest and, with large supplies from 2017/18 hitting the market imminently, we expect domestic prices to fall. This, together with rising incomes, will support demand.
Beyond China and India, the outlook for sugar consumption in Asia is positive. Some of the more developed countries, such as Malaysia and South Korea, are likely to grow only slowly as markets mature, but this will be more than offset by populous developing countries such as Indonesia, Thailand and Vietnam. However, demand growth in this region will be somewhat dampened by a gradual shift in the food and drink industry to cheaper, starch-based sweeteners as China (Asia's largest producer) increases production and seeks export markets. Tax measures to ensure that sugar consumption remains within recommended health guidelines could also dampen demand, with Thailand, the Philippines and Indonesia pursuing plans to introduce a so-called sugar tax. This has the potential to put a sharp brake on demand; for example, the introduction of a sugar tax in Mexico in 2015 has contributed to a 12% drop in sugar demand since then. Nevertheless, we assume that any such policies in Asia will be rolled out only slowly over the coming years, amid concerns over restricting growth in the otherwise burgeoning food and drink manufacturing industries.
Health warnings may eventually dent sugar demand in the developed world
Demand growth in the mature EU market is likely to be sluggish in 2017/18-2018/19. Many EU countries already average far higher consumption levels of sugar than recommended by the World Health Organisation (WHO), much of which is hidden in processed foods, and the EU Consumer Organisation is urging the food industry to take notice of WHO guidelines. So far, tax measures have been proposed to curb use in countries including the UK, Spain and Belgium. The policy response is likely to be watered down somewhat by opposition from the powerful food and drink industry, but consumer pressure will lead to a gradual shift in the food industry toward lower sugar levels. In addition, the production of isoglucose (a starch-based sweetener) will be liberalised in September 2017 and, as in the US, this is likely to steal market share gradually from sugar over the medium term.
EU net sugar import demand in recent years averaged over 2m tonnes/year (t/y), but a liberalisation of the EU's sugar regime in September 2017-when production quotas, guaranteed farmgate prices and export caps were abolished-will limit the need for imports. As well as the adjustment to the new liberalised regime, the UK's exit from the EU is generating uncertainty in the European sugar industry. The UK is the largest importer of EU sugar and the second-largest contributor to the bloc's agricultural programme, but there is little clarity over how this relationship will play out in the long term.
Changing consumer tastes will boost demand growth in Africa
African consumption will continue to increase, with the bulk of growth coming from expanding indigenous supplies that make sugar more affordable. Several consumers (including Nigeria, the region's largest importer, as well as Kenya and Ghana) are pursuing long-term investment plans in the sugar sector in the hope of becoming self-sufficient. But inefficient domestic supply chains will impede the development of Africa's sugar industries, and aggregate import demand from Sub-Saharan Africa is expected to remain well above 5m t/y in 2017/18-2018/19. Health warnings could temper the pace of consumption growth. However, as in EU countries, this is meeting resistance from its food and beverage industries; in South Africa, for example, plans to introduce a sugar tax have reportedly been pushed back to 2018 amid pressure from businesses. Overall, changing consumer tastes and population growth will drive average demand growth of 2.1% per year in 2017/18-2018/19.
Policy changes will shift the dynamics of the global sugar trade
The overhaul of EU sugar policy in 2017 is likely to have a significant effect on global trade patterns as the bloc transitions from being a net importer to becoming a net exporter. Barring any unexpected weather-related shocks to the EU harvest, we expect this transition to be complete by the end of the 2017/18 season. The smaller producers, particularly in Africa and the Caribbean, which supply the EU under preferential trade deals, will be hardest hit by this shift. Global trade dynamics will also be affected by the introduction of heavy import tariffs in China, with small producers (exempt from the new tariffs) likely to increase their market share. A trade deal between the US and Mexico came into effect in July, tightening up the rules for Mexican producers and granting Mexico the right of first refusal for the US's above-quota import demand. Moreover, a planned trade deal between Australia and Indonesia may help Australian producers to capture a greater share of this growing market.
Although these policy measures and trade deals will shift the direction of global trade flows, trade volumes will ultimately be defined by countries' preference for holding strategic stockpiles of sugar to hedge against future shocks. We expect trade to increase in 2017/18 as countries (notably China) seek to rebuild stocks after several years of low domestic production and relatively high global prices, before trade flows slow in 2018/19 on the back of bumper local harvests in markets that traditionally swing between net imports and net exports (notably India).

Supply
After fairly modest growth of 2.1% in 2016/17, and shrinking global supply in the two previous years, world sugar production is forecast to increase by 6.8% in 2017/18, to 179.2m tonnes. This is a slight upward revision from our previous forecast (177.7m tonnes), as the impact of lower than expected output from Latin America (following the destructive impact of Hurricane Irma on sugar production in Cuba) is more than offset by brisk supply growth in Russia and India. Russia is on course for a record beet harvest, while in India the area under cane cultivation is wider than previously expected (up by more than 10% year on year). This puts India on course for its highest output since 2014/15, despite a slightly sub-average monsoon season. Elsewhere, global supply will also be supported by strong crop revivals in Thailand, following weather-related shocks during the previous harvest, and strong output growth in the EU as producers seek to capitalise on the newly liberalised sugar regime. The world's largest producer, Brazil, will benefit from a second consecutive year of crop-friendly growing conditions and, with a significant amount of output locked into generously priced forward contracts, the supply of cane to sugar production is likely to remain above historical levels.
In 2018/19 we forecast global production to remain well above average annual production of 169m tonnes over the past five years, albeit declining by 0.5% year-on-year, to 178.3m tonnes. This is down slightly on our previous forecast, owing to more muted expectations on output in Brazil. As price parity between sugar and ethanol in Brazil prompts crushers to balance their cane supply between the two, we expect production from that country to drop in 2018/19. This will be only partially offset by higher production in the EU and China as the governments of these countries promise cane growers higher prices, and in Europe, where efforts among producers to capture global market share will sustain higher output levels. However, our forecast is contingent on normal weather conditions, and even fairly modest disruptions to rainfall patterns pose significant risk on both the upside and downside of our projections.
Output growth in Brazil is in prospect as cane supply increases
Brazil is on course for a bumper cane harvest, with both yields and volumes surpassing market expectations in the early months of the local 2017/18 season (April-March). This stems largely from favourable weather conditions, since sugar cane fields are ageing and field renewal rates are low. With cane supply robust, the main factor shaping Brazil's sugar output will be the supply of cane for sugar vis-à-vis ethanol production. The government reduced a federal ethanol tax in late July, which has the potential to boost ethanol demand and therefore to prompt crushers to divert cane to the fuel industry. With sugar and ethanol prices now hovering around parity, there is already some evidence that mills are shifting to ethanol production. Indeed, only 50% of cane was used for sugar production in August; this is the lowest share in several months, although it is still above the historical average of 44%. A significant volume of cane was locked into sugar contracts at a time of higher global prices, and the overall production mix for the 2017/18 local season will probably favour sugar. In 2018/19 the weakness of the Real will support the attractiveness of the export-oriented sugar industry, while only marginal growth in global oil prices will sap demand for biofuels. Overall, we expect ethanol and sugar prices in Brazil to hover around parity. This will spur further diversion of cane supply back to ethanol, at the expense of sugar production. Moreover, low field renewal rates will probably begin to take a toll on cane output from 2018/19, thereby reducing the overall cane crush. Sugar production is therefore forecast to moderate to 38.6m tonnes in 2018/19, from 39.6m tonnes in 2017/18.
EU production will recover as the sugar regime is liberalised
In Europe, sugar output is poised for brisk growth as producers seek to take advantage of the lifting of the EU's 50-year-old sugar quota system. Under the new regime, which came into effect at the start of the 2017/18 season, many producers in the less-efficient producing regions will close down owing to reduced support. Yet those in the more efficient areas (led by France, Germany and the Benelux countries) will easily extend their crush seasons, thereby making better use of existing capacity without significant additional investments. We expect EU production to reach 18m tonnes in 2017/18, up from 15.9m tonnes in 2016/17, and this will probably surpass EU demand. The pace of export growth will be limited in 2017/18 by moves to bolster local stocks. This will, however, serve to protect local producers from the current global price slump and should therefore sustain relatively high levels of output in 2018/19.
Favourable weather conditions are expected to lead to a record beet crop in Russia's 2017/18 local season (August-February), building on strong growth in 2016/17. Owing to significant investment in the modernisation of sugar factories in recent years, sugar production is likely to remain robust throughout the forecast period. The ensuing surplus will support Russia's emergence as a notable exporter as the government seeks to prevent stock build-ups from depressing domestic prices and deterring planting. However, we think that the authorities' forecast that exports will reach almost 1m t/y is overoptimistic, owing to soft demand for imports in Central Asia (Russia's main market) and the country's limited output of high-value sugar (which is in higher demand globally).
Output in Thailand is recovering from El Niño's long reach
In Thailand, favourable rainfall patterns will support a bumper harvest in 2017/18 of 11.9m tonnes. Assuming that rainfall normalises in 2018/19, we forecast a more moderate, albeit still decent, output of 10.2m tonnes. The sugar industry's exposure to weather-related shocks is, however, gradually increasing as production moves towards the more drought-prone interior regions. This shift is a result of ongoing efforts to scale up production. Following a challenge by Brazil, which argued that Thailand was violating World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules on free competition, the Thai government has agreed to remove production subsidies in December 2017. This will inflate costs, but we do not expect it to erode the country's competitiveness entirely. Increasing mechanis-ation will help to boost yields, and the sugar cane area in Thailand will continue to expand as farmers turn away from less profitable rice crops. Producers will also be incentivised by export opportunities to other Asian markets, where demand is rising and Thai sugar enjoys favourable access under the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) free-trade arrangement.
A major recovery in China's sugar sector appears unlikely for now
China's sugar output has fallen sharply in recent years, owing partially to the effects of state subsidies, at a time of rapidly rising costs for labour, land and farm machinery. Amid political pressure from the local industry, some support has been forthcoming in the form of input subsidies and soft loans, and the government has raised duties on out-of-quota sugar imports in a bid to protect local producers from cheaper imports. These measures will support the profitability of the local industry and should spur some investment, but we doubt that they will lead to a significant surge in domestic supply growth. The sector is dominated by smallholder farmers, labour costs are high and sugar cane areas do not lend themselves to mechanisation. Indeed, the cost of producing sugar cane in China is almost double that in Thailand, and this will deter investment. The government is attempting to encourage consolidation among the many disparate industry players in the country's main sugar region of Guangxi in an attempt to improve its competitiveness. However, similar moves in the past, for example in the soy market, have not yielded impressive results, and high local prices will probably allow some small, inefficient players to remain in the market. We do not, therefore, expect output to rise by the 10% per year that would be needed for the state to meet its medium-term production goals. However, given more favourable growing conditions (compared at least with the El Niño-linked dry conditions of 2015/16-2016/17), we expect output to rise to an average of 10.3m t/y in 2017/18-2018/19.

Stocks and prices
After successive supply deficits and a period of relatively high global prices, global sugar stocks shrank to 87.4m tonnes at end-2016/17. We expect the stocks to recover to 95.5m tonnes at end-2018/19 as the market swings back into surplus. The market surplus is forecast to reach 5.7m tonnes in 2017/18, amid bumper harvests from key producers and lacklustre demand growth, before moderating to 2.4m tonnes in 2018/19 as output levels decline. Although overall stocks will remain comfortable (equivalent to 54% of annual consumption), the uneven distribution of these stocks means that reserves will not always be available to the market, and occasional supply squeezes are possible.

The latest sugar price rally has peaked
After peaking at over 23 US cents/lb in late 2016, global sugar prices fell by 30% over the first half of 2017, before stabilising in the third quarter, at about 14.5 US cents/lb. In part, this reflects a market correction after overshooting in late 2016, with speculative investors unwinding the long positions that they had adopted during the price boom. More fundamentally, crop-friendly weather conditions in key producer markets are fuelling expectations of a global sugar surplus in the coming years, and policy moves to restrict import dependence in key consumers (notably, China, India and Europe) have further weakened market sentiment. Amid oversupply and only modest consumption growth, we expect prices to remain under pressure in the final months of 2017, averaging an estimated 16.1 US cent/lb over the full year, down by 11% on the previous year.
The price outlook beyond 2017 will depend largely on supply dynamics. In the crucial Brazilian market, higher diversion of cane to ethanol production over the coming years will dampen production and provide some support for prices, but a swing to ethanol that is substantial enough to bring the global sugar market into balance seems unlikely. Meanwhile, barring any weather-related shocks, the prospects of global oversupply will continue to weigh heavily on prices. On the back of upward revisions to our forecast of the global surplus in 2017/18-2018/19, we have shaved our price projections slightly and now expect prices to be range-bound between 15.5 US cents/lb and 16.5 US cents/lb. More aggressive policy moves to curb sugar consumption could weigh further on sentiment (and therefore prices). Nonetheless, with the sugar trade aware that the global market needs to offer a workable price for producers, we doubt that prices will remain lower than this range for prolonged periods. Weather-related shocks in producer markets continue to pose the most significant upside risk to prices.

Sunflowerseed oil
Demand
Sunflowerseed oil consumption continues to exceed expectations. The Economist Intelligence Unit has again revised up its estimate for sunflowerseed oil consumption growth in 2016/17, as global consumption is likely to have breached 18m tonnes, up by an estimated 14.6% year on year. Increasing availability of sunflowerseed oil should help it to maintain competitiveness in 2017/18, when we expect demand to rise by a further 3.5%, to 18.7m tonnes. Consumption is likely to exceed 19m tonnes in 2018/19, although this relies on sunflowerseed oil maintaining its competitive position against other oils.
Sunflowerseed oil's improving price competitiveness will boost EU usage
EU consumption of sunflowerseed oil in 2016/17 has exceeded previous expectations. We now estimate consumption of 4.4m tonnes (previously 4.3m tonnes), a year-on-year increase of over 12% Sunflowerseed oil is a preferred oil among consumers, owing in part to its persistent discount to both rapeseed and soybean oils. Overall consumption in 2016/17 includes a substantial volume of imported sunflowerseed oil. With better global availability, we expect EU sunflowerseed oil consumption to continue to expand in 2017/18-2018/19, albeit at a more modest rate of 2.1% per year.
Russian consumption will rise modestly as the economy emerges from recession
In Russia, higher local availability of sunflowerseed oil will help to keep a lid on domestic prices, which will support consumption growth. We maintain our estimate for Russian sunflowerseed oil consumption of 2.5m tonnes in 2016/17, reflecting robust growth of 8.3%. Sunflowerseed oil availability looks set to remain comfortable in 2017/18, and this will support continued demand growth. Our current forecast is for consumption of just under 2.6m tonnes, up by 3% year on year. However, the consumption forecast remains contingent on the continued economic recovery, and any setback in overall growth is likely to weigh on consumption. In 2018/19 we expect demand growth to be sustained, at 2.9%, assuming good local availability.
Robust GDP growth and shifting preferences will boost India's usage
India has been an active buyer of Black Sea sunflowerseed oil in the 2016/17 season. High import levels and increased local sunflowerseed crushing have both contributed to consumption growth. Imports were notably high in July and are reported to have been strong in August. We estimate that India's sunflowerseed oil consumption reached nearly 2.2m tonnes in 2016/17, up by 32.3% year on year. It will be difficult to stimulate much growth, following the surge in 2016/17; nonetheless, the rising consumer preference for sunflowerseed oil, especially in the south of India, is likely to see consumption expand again in 2017/18, by 5.1%. The recent increase in import duties on vegetable oils (including sunflowerseed oil) and lower domestic sunflowerseed production will constrain demand growth over the forecast period. We expect consumption growth to continue in 2018/19, but, again, at a lower rate, of 2.6%.
Turkish consumption will increase in 2017/18-2018/19
Many countries have been increasing their purchases of sunflowerseed oil to take advantage of competitive prices. Supplies are likely to remain comfortable throughout the forecast period, which will continue this trend. Countries increasing their use of sunflowerseed oil include Turkey, Iran, Iraq and Egypt, as well as several smaller countries. Growth in consumption in these "other" countries will moderate in 2017/18, following a robust performance in 2016/17.

Supply
We now estimate that global sunflowerseed oil production in 2016/17 reached 18.3m tonnes, up by more than 15% year on year. Another bumper sunflowerseed crop is expected in 2017/18; indeed, recent upward revisions to crop estimates mean that it will fall just short of the 2016/17 total. We expect sunflowerseed oil output to rise by 1% in 2017/18, to a record 18.5m tonnes, reflecting improved seed availability. Sunflowerseed remains a profitable crop in its major growing areas, and a further expansion of area is likely in 2018/19. Our tentative projections suggest sufficient seed availability to rebuild stocks and allow for sunflowerseed oil output of 18.9m tonnes, up by 2% year on year.
Ukraine's 2016/17 sunflowerseed harvest exceeds our expectations
Steady export demand for sunflowerseed oil continues to maintain strong rates of crushing in Ukraine. As a result, we have revised up our estimate for Ukraine's sunflowerseed oil production in 2016/17, to 6.3m tonnes, a 24.5% increase year on year (23% previously). Harvesting of the 2017/18 sunflowerseed crop is progressing well, with about 70% of the area harvested by the first week of October. Yields have failed to live up to early expectations; our harvest estimate has been reduced, to 13.7m tonnes, and some local estimates put the total even lower. With relatively plentiful sunflowerseed stocks carried over, this is not likely to have an immediate impact on crush rates; however, for the season as a whole, crushing will be reduced. We forecast sunflowerseed oil production to fall to 6.1m tonnes in 2017/18, down by 3%. This forecast may be reduced further if the harvest is further downgraded or sporadic reports of low oil content are confirmed. Although the 2018/19 outlook is still provisional, the industry's strong expansion in recent years should ensure ample seed availability despite concerns over crop rotations. We expect output in 2018/19 to rise to nearly 6.3m tonnes, on a par with the record outturn in 2016/17.
Sunflowerseed will remain a popular crop in Russia
In Russia, sunflowerseed crushing has also been running at high levels, and we expect oil production to have reached 4.6m tonnes in 2016/17, up by 17%. Unlike Ukraine, yield estimates based on the area harvested so far are optimistic. Along with a record area, these better yields suggest a crop of almost 11.8m tonnes in 2017/18, which would be another record. With more than sufficient crush capacity in Russia, output tends to be limited by market availability for the oil. We forecast a modest rise in sunflowerseed oil output, to nearly 4.7m tonnes.
Estimates for the EU 2016/17 sunflowerseed harvest have improved
EU crushing demand for sunflowerseed has remained strong, reflecting the shortfall in rapeseed supplies. Over the 2016/17 season as a whole, we continue to expect that production of sunflowerseed oil will reach 3.2m tonnes, almost exceeding the previous record of 2014/15. Harvesting is making steady progress and yields appear to be better than first thought. Notably, the outturn in Romania and Hungary will be higher than previously expected, offsetting lower output from Bulgaria. We have increased our harvest estimate to 8.5m tonnes in 2017/18, above last year but still short of the 2013/14 and 2014/15 harvests, both of which exceeded 9m tonnes. We have maintained our assessment that sunflowerseed oil output will be similar to that of 2016/17, at 3.2m tonnes.
Prospects for Argentina's crop remain good, but downside risks are mounting
In Argentina, we maintain our estimate that 2016/17 sunflowerseed oil production will come in at 1.3m tonnes. We expect that the sunflowerseed area will expand for the 2017/18 season. Sowings got off to a good start, although wet conditions have hampered later plantings. Sunflowerseed production could be almost 4m tonnes, the highest total for a decade. We expect that sunflowerseed oil production will exceed 1.4m tonnes in both 2017/18 and 2018/19, leaving room for additional sunflowerseed exports.

Stocks and prices
At the end of the 2016/17 season we expect sunflowerseed oil stocks to remain high, both in absolute terms and relative to consumption. Indeed, relative to consumption, oil stocks have been at similar levels for each of the last three seasons. However, this is only achieved at the expense of sunflowerseed stocks, which, at the end of 2016/17, will be below average. We expect the market to register a small deficit in 2017/18, bringing sunflowerseed oil stocks back to normal levels. However, the tight sunflowerseed stocks are likely to persist during 2017/18, despite the expected good harvest. Indeed, the tightening of sunflowerseed stocks may be sufficient to cause a reduction in sunflowerseed crushing from the levels currently forecast. As production growth moderates, we expect stock levels to fall further in 2018/19, to below normal levels.

Upward pressure on prices will be felt in the coming months
Sunflowerseed oil prices increased again in September, although the increase was relatively small. With a market deficit likely in 2017/18 and tightening sunflowerseed stocks, prices should start to edge up over the coming months. We expect this upward trend to continue into the 2018/19 season. The strength of rapeseed prices should also be positive for sunflowerseed oil values. Price rises are likely to be comparatively small but persistent, bringing average prices up to the US$900/tonne level by the end of the 2018/19 season.

Tea
Demand
Global tea consumption is growing steadily, driven mainly by China, which accounts for one-third of world tea consumption and is consuming ever-greater quantities of green tea. However, demand is also growing in other major consuming regions, including India and the US. Demand for tea is less exposed to economic cycles than other commodities, reflecting its low cost, meaning that tea demand will be driven primarily by demographics. This explains why The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast rates for tea consumption growth, of 3.8% a year on average in 2018-19, are relatively high and in line with the long-term historical average. Global demand for black tea will continue to rise, but the pace of growth will be outstripped by that for green tea, fruit tea, herbal tea, rooibos (from South Africa), purple tea (mainly from Kenya) and high-end organic tea, reflecting their greater reported health benefits and heavy marketing. Iced tea and "ready to drink" tea beverages account for a small share of the tea market but have enjoyed rapid growth in sales-even in traditional markets such as China-which will also contribute to demand growth.
Tea demand will benefit from changing consumer habits
The main tea-consuming countries are the largest producers, with a rising share of output retained for domestic consumption. In producing countries, tea will benefit from changing consumption habits related to rising incomes, but in most places will remain a consumer staple, despite a steady increase in consumption of other beverages, including coffee. Combined with favourable demographics, consumption growth in producing countries should rise further. The fact that a smaller share of tea than coffee is consumed in the out-of-home sector-owing partially to customer perceptions that tea in cafés offers less value for money-will shield tea consumption from adverse economic developments, which tend to have less of an impact on at-home consumption.
Both India and China will continue to see robust demand growth in 2017-18
Tea consumption is dominated by Asia, particularly China and India, which together accounted for an estimated 59% of global demand in 2017, up from 48% in 2010. In China, we expect the government's efforts to rein in credit growth to contribute to an economic slowdown from 2018, which will moderate tea consumption growth. Nonetheless, demand will remain strong compared with many other markets, expanding by 4% a year in 2018-19. This forecast is relatively cautious, with the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) projecting average annual Chinese demand growth of 15% until 2024, suggesting an upside risk to our forecasts. Average consumption per head stands at just over 1 kg/year, ranking China just 14th in the world. This leaves significant room for growth, particularly as only around 35% of the population drink tea.
Given that tea is regarded as a traditional drink, it will suffer from mounting com-petition from coffee and soft-drink retailers, owing to a growing preference for these beverages among younger Chinese consumers. Moreover, younger segments of the population are also showing a preference for black tea over green tea (black tea consumption has risen by an average of 40% per year since 2002, while green tea consumption has risen more gradually), which should bolster demand for black tea, albeit from a low base. Other changes in consumer habits will also affect tea sales, with greater demand for teabags globally (these are less wasteful than loose-leaf tea). However, given the importance attached to the quality of tea, sales of leaf teas will continue to dominate the local market.
In India, strong economic growth will be accompanied by higher household spending and firm consumer confidence, which will support annual average growth in tea consumption of 6.4% in 2018-19, marginally lower than estimated growth of 6.5% in 2017. Structurally, the Indian market has significant potential-aside from its sheer size, average consumption per head is even lower than in China, at just 740 g per year, which bodes well for longer-term demand growth. Currently, the out-of-home sector accounts for just under 50% of tea consumption, compared with 85% of the coffee market. The expansion of tea bars across many cities aims to lift this share, as well as fuelling overall tea consumption growth.

Structural constraints will hamper tea consumption growth in many markets
Demand in some large consuming countries will be hampered in 2018-19 by market saturation and weakening demographics. Indeed, the FAO forecasts an overall contraction until 2024 in many EU markets (which together account for just under 5% of global consumption), despite a firmer economic performance, as well as in Russia (2.5% of global consumption). Turkey, which also accounts for around 5% of global consumption, has a particularly saturated market, with the highest consumption of tea per head in the world by some margin. The EU also registers some of the world's highest levels, particularly in the UK and Ireland. Although our forecasts anticipate further growth in demand, reflecting continued population growth and steady growth in private consumption, the pace will be fairly mild. We forecast average annual growth in tea demand in 2018-19 of 1.9% in the EU and 0.4% in Turkey. Russian demand growth will be stronger, at an average of 2.5% per year, but is flattered by a weak base of comparison following a sharp decline in consump-tion in 2013-16.
There is plenty of room for market growth in the US
The US is a small market for tea, accounting for less than 2.5% of global consumption, and consumption per head is low. However, with most of the larger tea markets dominated by loose-leaf tea, the US remains one of the most important single markets for instant tea and iced tea. We expect demand to increase by an annual average of 2.6% in 2018-19, partly reflecting our fairly upbeat forecast for economic growth. Health concerns will also sustain demand for tea, with a gradual shift away from carbonated beverages and towards those perceived as healthier, including tea.
New tea markets are emerging
Export data from tea-producing countries reveal that new markets for tea are emerging, with the number of countries buying tea at the major auction houses in Asia and Africa on the rise. Demand from these new joiners in the tea market, mainly faster-growing emerging countries, is set to increase in 2018-19, underpinning our forecast for average consumption growth of 2.5% a year across all "other countries", which together account for 18% of global consumption.
Supply
After an estimated 1.2% contraction in global tea production in 2017-the first fall in output since our data series (which is based on historical data from the FAO) began in 2000-tea production is forecast to recover in 2018-19, rising by 3% and 2% respectively. However, these growth rates remain weak by historical comparison; annual growth in tea output averaged 4.4% in 2004-14. Other than weather concerns, several structural factors will prevent faster production growth. In inflation-adjusted terms, farmers' profits are lower than in past decades because of the higher cost of inputs, and this has resulted in a fall in investment. Notwithstanding a recent softening of the US dollar, many currencies will remain comparatively weak against the dollar in 2018-19, which will hamper operating conditions for farmers.
Much of the increase in global tea production in 2018-19 will come from a rise in green tea output, where growth has outpaced black tea by a significant margin in recent years. Green tea now accounts for one-third of total global tea production, compared with less than one-quarter a decade ago. This mainly reflects the rise in tea production in China, where loose-leaf green tea accounts for 68% of domestic production, and in Vietnam, where it now represents 55% of tea output, compared with 43% a decade ago.
As in 2016, adverse weather will harm Chinese tea production in 2017
China experienced the second consecutive year of disappointing tea production growth in 2017. We estimate that output expanded by 2.2%, after heavy rains hit several of the large tea-producing provinces in southern China, including Hunan, Jiangxi and Zhejiang, in June. The government stated that over 750,000 ha of crops were damaged, and although it made no direct reference to tea, we believe that production was affected. The rains were followed by extremely hot weather in some areas (including parts of Zhejiang), which will also have hampered production.
Even on the assumption that weather conditions will improve in 2018-19, production growth is forecast to slow further, to an annual average of 2%. Underlying economic growth will slow during 2018 as the government takes action to bring debt levels under control, and is not projected to accelerate significantly in 2019. We expect government efforts to modernise the agri-cultural sector-through large-scale lending from the state-owned Agricultural Development Bank of China-to progress only slowly, with some Chinese tea investors instead seeking to expand production overseas rather than in China (talks are under way to discuss the possibility of a 6,000-ha tea plantation in the Philippines). These factors will combine to undermine growth in tea output.
Beyond the forecast period there is scope for a return to firmer rates of tea production growth. The authorities are engaged in efforts to lift product quality and quantity in order to boost exports (only around 15% of tea production was exported in 2016). Given that China's average yield per hectare is low by global standards (at 785 kg in 2012-14, compared with 2,085 kg in India and 2,105 kg in Kenya), there is certainly potential for gains in productivity.
India's tea production will continue to grow in 2018 and 2019
We estimate tea production growth of 3.3% in India in 2017. Output fell in the first quarter of 2017, reflecting dry conditions in Assam (India's largest tea-growing state), as well as in Bengal and parts of southern India, but weather conditions improved subsequently. Assuming supportive weather conditions in 2018-19, we expect tea production to continue to rise, albeit more gradually. Continued efforts to channel funding to tea growers will provide support, but several structural factors will hold back production. There has been little progress on reforms to boost foreign direct investment in several sectors, including agriculture. Furthermore, India's tea bushes are old: nearly 40% of existing bushes are over 50 years old, compared with Kenya, where fewer than 30% are over 40 years old, and Vietnam, where the entire tea plantation is less than 20 years old. Replanting has progressed slowly and rising input costs have eroded profits, implying that in the long term India may struggle to increase growth as significantly as other major producers. We forecast average growth in tea production of 2% per year in 2018-19.
High costs will prevent a significant recovery in Sri Lanka's 2018-19 output
We estimate a double-digit decline in tea output in Sri Lanka in 2017, reflecting recent torrential rain that caused landslides and the worst flooding in over a decade. The authorities have said that this will affect tea output, as the worst-affected areas were tea-growing regions in the south of the country. Many of the 400,000 farmers, who account for 70% of national tea output, saw their bushes submerged by muddy water. Sri Lanka's tea production is forecast to rise in 2018, by 5.8%, but this will largely reflect a cyclical recovery after several disappointing years. As in India, there are several structural hurdles that will hamper growth, even assuming that weather conditions improve. Despite some replanting as a result of a 20% increase in subsidies to small tea farmers, the replanting rate is not yet sufficiently high to lead to a significant and sustained increase in output. In addition, there are local reports that fertiliser application has been low, and there is a continued risk of industrial unrest. Sharp wage rises and low mechanisation mean that production costs in Sri Lanka are some of the highest among the world's main tea producers. These factors explain why our projection for tea production growth in 2019 (1.8%) is relatively weak.
Moreover, the main customers for Sri Lankan tea-Russia, Turkey, Iran and Syria-have all experienced economic turbulence in recent years. Economic conditions are expected to improve markedly in Iran with the lifting of sanctions, and to a lesser degree in Russia and Turkey, but this is unlikely to be enough to boost demand for Sri Lankan tea significantly. Most of the country's tea is loose leaf, rather than mass-produced tea bags, which limits the extent to which the country can diversify its tea export market base towards Europe and the US. The Ministry of Plantation Industries has stated that it is considering a proposal to allow tea imports for blending in an attempt to boost export potential, and the Tea Board is continuing to urge the government to take measures to make the tea industry more competitive, but it is unclear if there is sufficient support domestically to push the measure through, as there is a strong perception among farmers that this would undermine local production.
A partial recovery in output is likely in Kenya in 2018-19
After a massive jump in tea production in Kenya in 2016, with output hitting an all-time high of 473,000 tonnes, weather conditions deteriorated sharply in 2017, with a renewed and persistent dry spell damaging tea plantations. Kenya's agriculture minister has stated that tea output is likely to fall by 12%, but our estimate envisages a much sharper drop, of 24%. Although tea production is forecast to stage a partial recovery in 2018-19, rising by 15.3% and 3.6% respectively, output levels even in 2019 will remain relatively weak. A change in the tea levy on farmers, so that it is based on the value rather than the volume of sales, will undermine profitability in the medium term. Furthermore, although the government has pledged to support small farmers and reduce the tax burden, conflicting interests and a lack of funds will hinder progress.

Investment will have an impact beyond our forecast period
Many countries have been investing to stimulate tea production, including large producers such as India (which is raising subsidies for plantation rejuvenation), Kenya (where processing plants are being expanded and production is being diversified to non-black varieties) and China (which is concentrating on raising black tea output for export), and even a minor producer, Ethiopia (where Saudi investment is seeking to expand tea production). Smaller producers, such as Tanzania, Uganda, Rwanda and Bangladesh, have also seen renewed investment. However, we assume that some of these investment plans will be scaled back or suspended altogether, while others will progress only slowly, reflecting overambitious investment plans, bureaucratic hurdles and broader concerns about long-term global oversupply. In addition, it takes three to five years for a tea bush to become commercially productive, so the impact on output of recent price falls will be evident only after the forecast period.
Stocks and prices
We estimate a fourth consecutive year of market deficits in 2017, reflecting increasing consumption and a contraction in output from several of the main tea-producing countries. We expect consumption growth to outstrip production growth during 2018-19, meaning that we forecast deepening market deficits in those years.
Given that there is no global measure of total tea stocks, it is impossible to gauge how significantly these widening market deficits will affect stock levels. The fact that prices fell during 2015-16 despite market deficits in both years indicates that stock movements have only a limited impact on prices, not least because much of the increase in consumption and production is the result of consumption and output in China, which mainly consists of green tea. While some of the production data are broken down into green and black tea, the consumption data are not, which prevents a calculation of the market balance in relation to black tea.

Only a fraction of the increase in production will be exported, and even this will not be in any of the three markets (Colombo, Kolkata and Mombasa) where our average tea price is measured. Prices in these markets respond to demand and supply dynamics in Sri Lanka, India and Kenya respectively (essentially, black tea). Often prices diverge between these three markets on the back of local developments that have an impact on supply and demand in the respective auction or to reflect the quality of tea offered at each auction. As an example, prices at the Colombo and Mombasa auctions have risen sharply in 2017, while prices at the Kolkata auction have remained similar to their year-earlier levels for much of the year. Although some of the auction houses are becoming digitised, we do not believe that the tea market will attract sufficient interest from investors to make price dynamics vulnerable to broader global macroeconomic changes (there is no futures market). Prices will therefore remain volatile and largely led by local supply-and-demand factors.
Prices will retreat slightly in 2018-19
We estimate a full-year average price of US$3.05/kg in 2017, a 15.7% year-on-year increase, reflecting the weak outlook for production and continued firm consumption growth. Although the market deficit will remain large in 2018-19, recovering production is expected to reduce prices by 5.7%, to an average of US$2.88/kg in 2018, and by a further 2.2% in 2019, to US$2.81/kg.
