Wheat
Demand
Global wheat consumption has increased strongly in the past 50 years, rising from less than 250m tonnes/year (t/y) in the early 1960s to more than 700m t/y in recent years. Helped by solid gains in developing countries, growth was particularly rapid in the three decades to 1990, rising by an average of 3% a year, before slowing slightly since then. Although stronger demand for wheat has mainly been tied to a rising global population, it should also be noted that wheat demand growth has persistently outpaced population growth. Wheat's popularity in diets has been sustained, as has its use as an animal feed ingredient. A small proportion is also used for brewing and for the manufacture of starch and ethanol. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global consumption to rise marginally, by 0.4%, to nearly 738m tonnes in 2017/18-up slightly from our previous forecast of 0.1% growth, owing to higher demand projections for the EU and Russia. Although wheat use for food is expected to increase once again, in line with the recent trend, it appears likely that world feed consumption will decline, owing partly to competition from alternative products. A similar pattern is expected in 2018/19. Although use for feed is expected to slip back further, a rise for milling and food use should see total demand increase by 0.6%, to 742m tonnes.
Rising food use is being driven by emerging and developing markets
Annual growth in world food-wheat consumption has remained relatively consistent over the past decade or so, with increases averaging 1.4% a year. Urbanisation, together with shifts in diets and incomes, has also resulted in greater consumption of wheat-based convenience foods such as noodles, as well as Western-style bakery products, which are best produced using high-quality wheat and flour. With much of the growth in demand stemming from countries outside the main wheat-producing belts, rising demand for milling wheat and flour has been accompanied by an increase in imports, with world trade expanding in most years. Although diets in the fastest-growing consumer markets are expected to diversify as incomes improve, to include additional animal proteins, dairy products and oil crops, in general there has been little evidence of slowing food wheat demand in recent years. We therefore expect world food use to rise by 1.5% in 2017/18, exceeding 500m tonnes for the first time. Growth will be driven mostly by India, Indonesia and much of Sub-Saharan Africa. These trends are well established and are expected to continue into 2018/19, when food consumption could rise to 511m tonnes.
Wheat is a key staple across South Asia
By tonnage, South Asia is the world's largest food wheat-consuming region, with cumulative consumption in 2017/18 projected at around 135m tonnes, equivalent to more than one-quarter of the global total. India is easily the largest single consumer, with wheat being a staple food for most of the population in northern, western and central growing areas. Most is consumed as unleavened flat breads, but western-style loaves, confectionery and bakery products are gaining in popularity. Consumption gains are underpinned by population growth, averaging 1.3% a year over the past decade, as well as various food-security programmes, under which grains are distributed to eligible beneficiaries at highly subsidised prices. Wheat food use in India in 2017/18 is projected to rise by 2%, to 93.5m tonnes (the majority of India's total wheat demand of 98.5m tonnes). For 2018/19 food demand is likely to rise further, to 95.4m tonnes. In Pakistan, where rice output is smaller, wheat is an even more important food staple, and consumption per head exceeds that of most countries with similar incomes. However, local diets are beginning to diversify, with demand for dairy and meat products rising strongly over the past decade.
World feed use is forecast at a higher than usual level in 2016/17
Wheat contains high levels of starch, which makes it a good, energy-rich ingredient for livestock feed. Demand for feed wheat shows more annual variation than that for food-use wheat, and is highly dependent on price and underlying quality considerations. Direct, on-farm feed use also varies from one year to the next, depending on the size and quality of the crop in a particular season. Use for feed has averaged around 141m tonnes a year during the past five years. Wheat is the world's second most important feed grain; although it is typically equivalent to one-quarter of feed-use of maize, with annual wheat use roughly matching that of barley, sorghum, oats and rye combined. The EU is typically the world's largest consumer of feed quality wheat, with consumption averaging close to 57m tonnes in recent seasons-around 40% of the world total. Other large users include Russia, with demand of around 17m tonnes, China (15m tonnes) and the US (5m tonnes). Depending on price, feed manufacturers in Asia, including South Korea, Indonesia and the Philippines, have also incorporated relatively large amounts into feed rations in recent years.
Assuming strong competition from maize-especially in the EU, China and the US-we expect use for livestock feed to fall back by 3.7% year on year in 2017/18, to around 144m tonnes. The figure for Canada is also forecast to be sharply lower than last year, dropping by about half, to 3m tonnes, on much smaller feed grade supplies. At the moment, we forecast a modest decline in global demand for feed-grade wheat in 2018/19, to around 144m tonnes. The drop stems mainly from a projected small decline in Russia, where a smaller crop is likely to limit discretionary on-farm feeding.

Supply
World wheat production has reached unprecedented levels in recent seasons, with cumulative output hitting new highs each year between 2013/14 and 2016/17. Production gains have stemmed mainly from the Black Sea region, predominantly in Russia, but China, India and parts of Latin America have also contributed bigger crops. The harvested area has increased across many parts of the globe, and average yields have also risen, despite concerns about years of underinvestment in wheat seed technology. However, given recent spells of poor weather across wheat belts in both hemispheres, the recent growth trend is expected to come to a halt. In 2017/18 we forecast global wheat production to decline by 0.9% year on year, to 748m tonnes, owing largely to lower output from the US, Canada and Australia. Nonetheless, this is a slight upward revision from our previous forecast (1.5% contraction), owing to improved prospects for several producers, including the EU, India, the US and Canada. Russia's massive 2017/18 crop has diverted some attention away from the fact that supplies of the best quality, high-protein wheats from North America and parts of Europe will be below average levels and will therefore command a price premium. The 2018/19 sowing season is now under way in some parts of the northern hemisphere. With prices at relatively low levels, there is unlikely to be much incentive for farmers to increase plantings. Crop rotation needs will again be important, but in countries where there are few alternatives, seeded area is unlikely to show much year-on-year change. Assuming average yields, the world crop is forecast to contract by another 0.8% in 2018/19, to 742m tonnes.
After a small EU crop last year, output should rise in 2017/18
Despite a mixed year for the main EU wheat growers, the 2017/18 crop is expected to be slightly larger than average. We have lifted our production forecast by a further 1.9m tonnes, to a total of 150.1m tonnes, incorporating latest official harvest data from France and Romania. Final results from the French harvest, which accounts for around one-quarter of the bloc's total output, were better than previously reported, with yields rebounding strongly from the previous season's sub-par results. Survey results have also confirmed its good quality, with a much higher percentage than last year meeting milling specifications. In contrast, a wet finish to the German harvest has led to a series of quality downgrades in key northern export-producing areas. As most of the EU crop is winter sown, producers are now gearing up for the start of 2018/19 planting. Farmers have again expressed concerns about market prices currently being lower than production costs. Some area may be switched to attractively priced rapeseed, but given the lack of viable alternatives for many farmers, we do not expect much change in plantings for next year's harvest. Assuming normal yields, output is likely to be in line with the average, at 148m tonnes.
An enormous crop in Russia
The size of this season's winter wheat crop in Russia has caught market observers by surprise. With farmers continuing to report astounding yields, local production estimates have been increasing on an almost daily basis. When harvesting of winter crops started a few months ago, early yields were good, surpassing the previous year's record by around 5%. As threshing progressed, the proportional improvement over the previous season continued to rise, and by the end of harvesting in late September average yields were up by about 17% year on year. Yields have been above or in line with record levels in all the major growing areas, with a particularly sharp improvement noted in the Volga District. Excellent yields are attributed mainly to abundant springtime rains, but with the crops also well established after a successful period of overwintering. Attention is now shifting to the lower-yielding spring-sown crops, grown predominantly in more northerly areas, in the Volga, Ural and Siberian Districts. Spring wheat production prospects are also favourable, with recent good moisture boosting yield potential. We maintain our forecast that Russia's 2017/18 wheat outturn will rise by nearly 13% year on year, to a record 82m tonnes. With large barley and maize crops also expected, the main issue facing exporters this year is one of logistical constraints. Although there are no definitive numbers, analysts have estimated that the country has the capacity to ship only up to 45m tonnes of grain, of which wheat might account for around three-quarters. Constraints are therefore likely to be felt across the supply chain, including storage silos, railcars and port infrastructure.
The fact that large volumes of wheat will be pouring into stockpiles this season could potentially be a disincentive to 2018/19 planting. However, given that international prices are still well above the cost of production in some areas, we expect the planted area to remain high in the coming season. Recent dry weather has not been ideal for early crop establishment but has allowed for a quick start to planting, and winter sowings stand to beat the official target again. Assuming that yields are similar to the recent trend, but down from the record-breaking results achieved this year, we expect 2018/19 output to decline by around 12%, to 72m tonnes, which is still an impressive outturn.
US wheat production fell sharply in 2017/18
US all-wheat production in 2017/18 totals 47.4m tonnes, according to the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Small Grains Summary. This is slightly above earlier estimates but still down by 25% year on year, and at a fifteen-season low. The sharp drop in output mainly reflects a pullback in plantings, with the smallest harvested area in almost 130 years. The final crop estimate was 1.4m tonnes above our previous forecast, after US authorities confirmed slightly better yields and lower than expected abandonment from the spring harvest. The winter wheat outturn was 34.5m tonnes (down by 24% year on year), with durum at 1.5m tonnes (down by 47%) and other spring varieties at 10.7m tonnes (down by 27%). Sowing of next season's winter wheat crop is under way but making unusually slow progress so far. Recent rains across the central Plains were beneficial for germination, but slowed fieldwork in many key Hard Red Winter (HRW) wheat states. However, concerns about dryness lingered in Soft Red Winter wheat-producing zones across the Midwest. Depressed prices and limited potential for profits mean that another drop in winter and spring plantings is now likely. Assuming better overall yields, however, mainly for spring-sown wheat, 2018/19 production is forecast to rise by 4.9%, to 49.7m tonnes, about 11% below the previous five-year average.
Canada's production in 2017/18 is likely to drop significantly
For the first time in Canada, more area of the 2017/18 harvest was sown with canola than with wheat, traditionally the nation's number-one field crop. Updated official plantings data confirm that the 2017/18 all-wheat planted area declined to 6.4m ha, down by 4% year on year, with losses stemming mainly from a 16% drop in durum plantings. After a wet spring, hot and dry weather has since spread across southern and central parts of the Prairies, with Saskatchewan, the number-one provincial grower of spring wheat and durum, worst affected. By early October about three-quarters of the spring crop had been cut. Although poor results have been confirmed in southernmost parts of Saskatchewan, yields have exceeded expectations elsewhere, including in Manitoba, where crops appear to have benefitted from wet soils earlier on in the cropping season. Indeed, many operators have been surprised at just how well spring wheat yields have held up, given periods of extremely dry weather this year. Some local breeders have attributed this to the latest (non-genetically modified) wheat varieties, which appear to make more efficient use of available moisture and nitrogen fertilisers. We have therefore increased our forecast by a further 1.5m tonnes, to 27m tonnes, but this is still a 15% drop year on year. We currently expect a modest increase in overall area in 2018/19. Should yields also rise, output could increase by 7%, to 29m tonnes.
Australia has seen a poor start to the 2017/18 crop season
In Australia, winter wheat prospects took a turn for the worse in September as searing temperatures spread across eastern cropping areas, further depleting soil moisture in already dry fields, with parts of New South Wales and Queensland worst affected. With spring weather so crucial for yield formation, 2017/18 production prospects were probably badly affected. Production is forecast to drop to 20.5m tonnes, down by 42% year on year (36% previously). The scale of the fall is particularly dramatic because of the record crop in 2016/17, when plentiful rains pushed yields up by 45% year on year, to unprecedented highs.

Wheat is back in favour with Argentinian farmers
In Argentina, policy changes made under the government that come into power in late 2015, including exchange-rate liberalisation and the removal of export quotas and taxes, have greatly incentivised the country's wheat farmers. Planting of the 2017/18 crop was completed by late August, but with area falling short of earlier expectations. Flooding prevented access to low-lying fields across southern parts of Buenos Aires and La Pampa provinces, where as much as 150,000 ha of intended wheat area was thought to have gone unseeded. Some local sources recently estimated that around half of the country's total wheat area had been affected by excessive water this season, which hindered farmers' ability to control disease and apply fertilisers. With dryness also persisting in more northerly areas, 2017/18 wheat production is forecast to decline by at least 5% year on year, to 16.5m tonnes.
Stocks and prices
Cumulative world stocks are predicted to rise for the fifth consecutive season in 2017/18, reaching 251m tonnes, up by 4% year on year to an all-time high. However, this large total figure masks some important features, as gains in world inventories are mostly attributed to rises in end-season stocks in India and China, whose stocks are not available on the world market. Indeed, with China's stocks having doubled over a five-year period, many observers have argued that China should be excluded from global stock calculations. Other organisations suggest that it is perhaps more useful to use carryovers in the eight largest exporters as a proxy for global supplies. Cumulative stockpiles in those countries are forecast to drop by around 8% year on year, to 70m tonnes, but will still be up by 10% from the average in recent years. The projection for 2018/19 is provisional, but suggests a continuation of the most recent trend. World stocks are likely to remain high, and are currently unchanged compared with the previous year, at 251m tonnes, but with the outlook skewed by an even larger figure for China. Exporter stocks of 61.3m tonnes, although not considered especially tight, would be the smallest in five years.
China's wheat stocks are large, and likely to get larger
Discussions about grain stocks in China are usually centred on maize inventories, which have dominated the headlines in recent years. However, a steep rise in wheat and rice stockpiles has also been witnessed over the past decade. Although no definitive grain-stock data are made publicly available, it is thought that wheat inventories have risen from just below 40m tonnes in 2006/07 to a projected 111m tonnes at the end of the 2016/17 season, equivalent to around 95% of annual domestic consumption. Our projections suggest that inventories could rise to as much as 128m tonnes in 2017/18 and 141m tonnes in 2018/19. Similar to the maize market, policy has been the key driver behind this surge, with the government committed to defending a pre-set minimum price by buying local supplies for temporary reserves. Farmers receive the same price for all average-quality wheat, regardless of protein or gluten content, meaning that quality is generally fairly low. The reserves are stored, with the help of subsidies, until the grain can be auctioned off at a higher price.

Wheat prices are likely to remain weak in the short term
Trading in world wheat markets has been extremely volatile over the past four months or so. Initial steep gains, linked primarily to a drought in parts of the US and Canada, were later erased on the back of better than expected results from harvests in the Black Sea region, predominantly in Russia. Despite overall heavy world availabilities and strong competition for available export business, wheat prices at all major origins firmed during September, rising by an average of 5%. Gains in the US were tied partly to logistical issues in the wake of storm-related loading disruptions at the country's key Gulf ports, as well as heightened concerns about the outlook for crops in Australia and Argentina, which will potentially provide additional export opportunities. Buoyant overseas demand and logistical bottlenecks also shored up Black Sea export quotations, particularly in Russia, where port capacity is likely to be stretched this season. In addition, with some farmers said to have secured sufficient funds to cover near-term commitments, a number of producers were more reluctant to sell at current prices. With Russian shipments expected to remain high throughout the season, strong export competition is likely to keep a lid on prices, at least for next year. Assuming that crop prospects do not deteriorate further, we expect HRW export prices (12% protein, fob Gulf) to fall over the remainder of 2017 and in the first half of 2018, before strengthening slightly thereafter. However, higher protein supplies are expected to command a hefty price premium, at least until the next (2018/19) northern hemisphere crops enter the pipeline.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Although the regime of the president, Nicolás Maduro, will strengthen its grip on power in the wake of the installation of a Constituent Assembly, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect Mr Maduro to remain in power beyond 2019. The most likely scenarios for a transition to an opposition-led government are through ad hoc elections after economic collapse or a military coup. There is a risk that the regime will cling to power if either Chinese or Russian finance helps the sovereign to avoid debt default, or should Mr Maduro be replaced by another member of the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela to appease critics.
We estimate that inflation will exceed 1,400% by end-2017 and 2,000% by end-2018, and forecast an overall contraction of GDP of one-third between 2014 and 2019. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consumption and operating conditions have hurt investment. We forecast a recovery beginning in 2020, by which time the current opposition is expected to be in government, leading to macro-economic adjustments, and institutional and structural reforms.
Sweeping reforms are required to restore confidence in contract and property rights, and thereby promote a recovery in investment. The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will encourage private investment, re-establish market mechanisms for price stability and attempt to undo the constraints imposed by the government on private firms.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and quadruple-digit inflation will hit private consumption, and the increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate the fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices, and the economy will not return to growth until 2020-assuming that a new government takes power and implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
At almost 300bn barrels, Venezuela has the world's largest proven oil reserves, but its oil sector has suffered from disinvestment and mismanagement owing to political interference. The government claims that rising investment in the energy sector will lift oil production significantly in the medium term, but we foresee a continued fall in production until 2019, followed by rising output from 2020 onwards as economic conditions stabilise.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela is in 80th position globally in our business environment rankings for 2018-22, out of 82 countries covered, making the country one of the least attractive investment locations. This reflects state interventionism, highly hetero-dox macroeconomic policies, a lack of legal security and weak institutions. Regionally, Venezuela remains last of the 12 countries covered, notwithstanding our assumption of improvements after 2019.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Nationalisation poses a diminished threat, given fiscal weaknesses. Property rights remain weak. Price fixing undermines profitability.
2020-22: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists. A new government in 2019 brings new policies.
2020-22: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain fairly low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2018-19: Unorthodox exchange-rate policy framework adds to uncertainty. The state continues to exercise tight control over access to official-rate US dollars. New government in 2019 removes exchange controls.
2020-22: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2018-19: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2020-22: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2018-19: Credit growth remains firm, but sectoral allocation is distorted by administrative interventions. Banks remain highly profitable, although unpredictable enforcement and a weak regulatory framework heighten instability.
2020-22: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2018-19: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2020-22: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Access to water and electricity supplies remains precarious. Underinvestment in power transmission ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2020-22: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued electricity rationing.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s t wo parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Chávez was diagnosed with cancer in 2011 but, after declaring in July 2012 that he had fully recovered, won a fourth presidential term in October 2012. However, his health quickly deteriorated and he died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has since plummeted.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is a federal republic, successive administrations have proven reluctant to devolve political authority, with the transfer of financial resources from federal to local level highly dependent on the central government. The legislature is unicameral, and elections for the National Assembly take place every five years. In December 2015 the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the legislature. In August 2017 the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) installed a Constituent Assembly with powers over all branches of government and a remit to rewrite the 1999 Constitution-apparently a ploy to entrench the PSUV in power.
Policy issues: Political radicalisation has been reflected in increasingly heterodox economic policymaking, with massive fiscal and monetary stimulus and the nationalisation of industries deemed strategically important. Distortions created by this approach have become evident, with inflation rising sharply in spite of price controls, and with capital controls spawning a rampant black market for foreign exchange. Failure to invest part of the oil windfall has led to a startling decline in physical infrastructure. Non-oil production has in effect ground to a halt, leaving the economy entirely dependent on the energy sector. With large oil shipments going to China to repay loans, and (on subsidised terms) to regional neighbours via the PetroCaribe oil-financing scheme, the country is running very short of US dollars, forcing cuts in import spending.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 60% for oil firms. Since 2011 a maximum royalty of 95% has applied to oil extraction. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Official data are unavailable, but we estimate that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$11bn in 2016 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages, narrowing the current-account deficit to 0.7% of GDP.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Even as Venezuela's economic crisis deepens, amid growing default and risk of hyperinflation, the governing Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has strengthened its hold on power as the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) has slid into disarray and infighting. Despite economic crisis making the president, Nicolás Maduro, extremely unpopular, the government's history of electoral manipulation means that it is unlikely that the PSUV would leave power via normally scheduled, free and fair elections. Instead, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects worsening economic conditions to result in a more chaotic political transition process, most likely ushering the MUD into power by 2019.
The MUD's inability to effect change to date is explained by the PSUV's successful attempts at dividing the opposition and eliminating its influence in government and political institutions. Government tactics have included banning candidates, imprisoning popular opposition figures and stripping all power from the MUD-controlled National Assembly, which in August was superseded by a new Constituent Assembly (ANC). The ANC is formally concerned with rewriting the Constitution but has also taken over all legislative powers during its two-year remit. The ANC's members are all PSUV representatives. The latest blow came in the October regional elections, which were marred by what the opposition states was electoral fraud. The PSUV took 18 of 23 governorships available and successfully triggered infighting in the MUD when four governors-elect from Acción Democrática, an MUD member, agreed to be sworn in by the ANC.
The PSUV's future in power currently depends on the support of key backers. These include the state's coercive apparatus (the security forces and military); a sizeable sector of the population that is dependent on handouts of basic goods, including food; and activist groups (so-called colectivos), which are something between community organisers and PSUV paramilitaries. To remain in power, the government will need to ply these groups with resources, the vast majority of which come from PDVSA, the state-owned oil company. A prolonged interruption in exports by PDVSA would cause this support to waver while also increasing dissatisfaction in the populace, as it would exacerbate the pronounced shortages of basic goods and trigger an increase in inflation (already estimated at over 1,000%).
We believe that two main scenarios would lead to a drop in PDVSA exports and see the PSUV leave office as support wanes and unrest increases. The first involves a disorderedly default of sovereign and/or PDVSA external debt. Legal action in the US (as permitted by the debt contracts) could result in seizures of PDVSA's assets (such as those of PDVSA-owned Citgo). Such actions, if widespread, could curtail exports dramatically. We believe that PDVSA has taken defensive measures that may limit the effectiveness of seizures.
The second path to regime change is based on PDVSA's falling output. Output dipped to 1.9m barrels/day in October (it was 2.4m b/d in 2013, when Mr Maduro took office), and we expect production to continue dropping into 2018. On the basis that this trend continues and oil prices remain relatively subdued, we would expect PDVSA's US dollar earnings to continue to dwindle, eventually causing the support of the PSUV's backers to be withdrawn. There is a risk that the Maduro administration will avoid this fate, if sufficient Chinese, Indian or Russian investment in the sector supports output.
Given the level of political violence and the traumatic economic context that the country would find itself in were either main transition scenario to materialise, it would be difficult for the PSUV to appease critics by replacing Mr Maduro with another high-ranking PSUV figure. It also seems unlikely that the PSUV would quietly leave office via fair and free elections. Instead, the most likely transition scenario would involve the military pushing the PSUV out and restoring order while paving the way for eventual elections.
Regardless of how and when political transition occurs, the second half of our forecast period is likely to remain volatile and uncertain. The broad, diverse opposition coalition will have to contend with huge economic distortions and deep political differences that would test even a unified political party.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
A combination of victory in the gubernatorial elections and the MUD's disarray has emboldened the government, which has announced municipal elections for December 10th. The largest opposition parties will boycott the contests, meaning an almost guaranteed victory for the PSUV. However, the centralisation of power means that the results will have little impact on overall government policy.
Presidential elections are due on December 2018. Although the government has signalled in recent weeks that it may bring these forward (taking advantage of opposition disarray), we currently believe it more likely that the government will try to postpone them, using the excuse that the ANC's mandate runs until August 2019. Approval from the politicised Supreme Court would be forthcoming. Given the PSUV's history of electoral manipulation, a rigged election, or one with null opposition participation is a possibility. Regardless, both of our transition scenarios assume that relatively free and fair elections will be held following economic collapse, ushering the opposition into power.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Following the installation of the ANC in August, Venezuela has come under increasing regional and international pressure. The country has been suspended from Mercosur, a regional bloc comprised of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, owing to "violations to the constitutional order". In addition, a regional group of 12 nations have declared both the October gubernatorial elections and the ANC vote illegitimate. The EU has also denounced the regime, banning weapons sales and condemning the "non-respect of democratic principles".
US sanctions remain the most relevant variable. Such sanctions have made it near-impossible for PDVSA or the government to renegotiate its debts. Given Venezuela's extreme dependency on trade with the US (Venezuela exports oil and imports distillates from the US), an embargo would cripple the economy and likely trigger one of our transition scenarios. A key priority for the Maduro administration will be the maintenance of good relations with China and Russia, who have provided financing to Venezuela as international markets have shunned the nation.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The government's immediate economic policy concern will be fending off default and associated legal challenges. The government has gone into arrears on some sovereign and state-owned firms' bonds (including PDVSA), while also making late payments on others. It has restated its commitment to pay and blamed the delays on US sanctions and the payment system. The situation has been classified as technical default (a default that occurred earlier than our baseline forecast of 2018). The government has announced its intention to restructure existing debts. To this end, the government invited bondholders to a meeting on November 13th to restructure the debt, which produced no results. A successful restructuring by the Maduro regime appears impossible. This is partly because creditors will be unable to negotiate a deal with the many Venezuelan officials sanctioned by the US. More fundamentally, the Maduro regime has no economic or political programme underpinning restructuring that would be acceptable to creditors.
There is no sign yet of acceleration by bondholders, who so far appear to prefer late payment to lengthy legal battles. Eventually, this stance is likely to change. To avoid PDVSA asset seizures, the government may choose to default on sovereign bonds but adhere to PDVSA's repayment schedule. Sovereign creditors would undoubtedly ask US courts to define PDVSA as an "alter ego" of the government in order to seize its assets, but this would take time, pushing back asset seizures. In this environment, the timing of likely seizures is unclear. When they do happen, the consequences for import capacity will be devastating. We assume that they will trigger a transition of power and, eventually, a change of economic policy direction.
In the meantime, the government must also grapple with a build-up of huge inflationary and currency depreciation pressures. We assume that the Maduro government will be forced to weaken the currency more substantially in 2018 than it has done so far. However, other much-needed reforms are unlikely to be addressed by a government that has proved unwilling or technically incapable of adjusting policy sufficiently to move Venezuela's economy away from the brink of collapse. Fiscal and monetary policies will remain expansionary, and ad hoc policy intervention and heavy state control of the economy will persist. Amid subdued oil prices, import compression will remain necessary, as other sources of foreign exchange will be hard to find.
Under our baseline scenario we expect the opposition to come to power in 2019 at the latest, ushering in much-needed, market-driven adjustments designed to correct currency distortions, alleviate shortages of basic goods, tighten expansionary fiscal policy and rebuild institutional capacity after years of deterioration under PSUV rule. It is probable, given the scale of the challenge, that the new government will seek a financing agreement with the IMF to support the adjustment process; we have factored in accumulated lending of US$19bn in 2019-22. Efforts to secure increased inflows of foreign direct investment would also be likely under a new government, and would help to improve the balance-of-payments dynamics, although we expect direct investors to remain cautious for some time with regards to Venezuela, with the possible exception of the oil sector.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
The authorities' failure to publish data on the non-financial public sector since 2012 demonstrates the opacity of the public finances and complicates accurate forecasting of the size of the deficit. We estimate a non-financial public-sector deficit of 19.4% of GDP for 2017 and expect the deficit to remain in double digits in 2018. A transition to a new government should help to ease the deficit to 5.6% of GDP by 2022. The large deficits of the present are mostly being financed by printing money. High inflation and an overvalued currency are eroding the relative value of domestic and external debt, making debt/GDP ratios unreliable indicators of fiscal stability. There is considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing, mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China. As these items are excluded from the public debt statistics, the true size of total public liabilities is understated. Under our baseline forecast of severe economic stress that would see an MUD-led opposition government in 2019, we expect a restructuring process with external creditors to happen.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
Monetary policy under the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) will continue to be driven by the government's desire to keep real interest rates negative and to print money to finance large fiscal deficits; money supply (M2) rose by 534% year on year in September, the highest rate on record. In the context of extremely high inflation, we expect real rates to remain deeply negative until 2019. After that, our forecast of substantial currency and fiscal adjustment under a new government, which implies a substantial tightening of monetary policy, will see real interest rates turn positive.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending mean that we project further contractions in real GDP in 2018-19, following an estimated contraction of 9.5% in 2017, Our forecast for a recovery in 2020-22 rests on an assumption of slightly higher oil prices, alongside a political transition that produces a combination of macroeconomic adjustment (supported by IMF financial assistance), and institutional and structural reform. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, given the scale of the recession, and our forecasts therefore imply only a partial rebound, after a real GDP decline of a third in 2014-19.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2018, reflecting the effect on real wages of soaring inflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will continue to contract sharply, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange, and remitting profits. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition, progress on long­delayed joint projects with Chinese firms in energy and-later in the forecast period-a pick-up in public-sector investment. Exports will continue to shrink through 2019 as oil production falls further, but will pick up thereafter, reflecting renewed investment under a new government and a removal of constraints to domestic production. Import demand will rise faster than exports, in line with an alleviation of basic goods shortages and the release of pent-up demand from recession. Even after the change in govern-ment, however, dependence on oil will persist.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
A decimation of domestic supply and severe shortages of foreign-exchange reserves have caused inflation to soar for much of the past two years, and in the short term there is little sign that the situation will improve, despite deep recession. No new official inflation data have been released since end-2015, but since the start of the year the National Assembly has begun producing a consumer price index. This showed monthly inflation of 45.5% in October, bringing accumulated inflation for January-October to 826%. Assuming that price pressures remain high, we expect inflation to exceed 1,400% by year-end and reach over 2,000% by the end of 2018. We continue to forecast a decline in inflation over time, under the assumption of a recovery in oil output and corrective economic policies under an MUD-led government. However, for now, a lack of funds available for importing basic goods suggests that shortages will be rife, and the risk of hyperinflation (monthly inflation of over 50%) will remain substantial.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
Currently, a dual exchange-rate system is in operation, comprising an official peg, known as the Dipro, which is limited to priority public-sector imports and set at BsF10:US$1, and a heavily managed rate known as the Dicom, used for private-sector operations (but where demand for US dollars vastly outstrips supply). The Dicom was suspended in August, with Mr Maduro announcing the future usage of a "basket of currencies" (such as the rupee, rouble, yuan and euro) to replace the use of the dollar. However, the system is yet to be implemented, as the government seems to be hoarding all foreign-exchange available to meet its debt obligations. Amid huge pressures on the dual-currency exchange-rate system, our forecasts assume substantial devaluations in 2018, but the exchange rate will remain extremely overvalued. The suspension of the Dicom, coupled with runaway money supply, has led to a spike in the black-market foreign-exchange rate, which reached BsF52,128:US$1 on November 12th.
We assume that further major currency adjustment under a new, MUD-led government in 2019 will involve immediate exchange-rate unification. Until that occurs, given existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market, there is an extremely high risk of a debilitating currency crisis in the short term. If confidence in the bolívar collapses amid hyperinflation, dollarisation-or the launch of a new domestic currency-could occur.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
We forecast a current-account deficit of 3.4% of GDP in 2018, as exports, held back by decaying infrastructure, falling oil production and lack of exploration, will be unable to offset imports, despite the government's best efforts at dampening them (we estimate that the value of imports in 2017 will be equivalent to a quarter of those of 2012). In 2019, with a new administration in place, exports and imports will begin a recovery; however, in the years ahead the latter will outstrip the former owing to years of pent-up demand and an easing of external financing constraints. Our assumption of economic adjustment in the medium term suggests some recovery in capital inflows, particularly into the oil sector. Together with IMF loans, this should help to rebuild reserves coverage. However, given increased imports, our forecasts assume that even by the end of the forecast period in 2022 reserves will cover less than two months of goods and services imports.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCRP: Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Following the snap general election on June 8th, in which the Conservative Party lost its parliamentary majority, the prime minister, Theresa May, formed a minority government based on a "confidence and supply" agreement with the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP). The government will be fragile, and The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect it to last a full five-year term; its working majority of 13 (down from 17 before the election) will be eroded by by-elections, and it will face domestic and external challenges during the Brexit process.
Mrs May's position has been greatly weakened by a series of scandals relating to the misconduct of members of parliament in late 2017-which led to the resignation of two ministers. There is a significant risk that tensions within the cabinet and the Conservative Party over the government's Brexit strategy will come to a head, resulting in a political crisis.
In March 2017 parliament approved Article 50, beginning the two-year process by which the UK will leave the EU. Mrs May said that the UK would leave the single market and the customs union, but her government will face pressure to soften the terms of Brexit. The government will aim to reach a deal on the new UK-EU trading relationship by March 2019. At that stage the UK will leave the single market, and the terms of the new relationship will be phased in gradually. If negotiations fail and no extension of the deadline is agreed by all 27 EU members, the UK will leave the EU in 2019 without any deal in place and will revert to World Trade Organisation (WTO) trade rules.
The economy has been resilient in the wake of the Brexit vote. However, we expect growth to slow to 1.6% in 2017 as rising inflation and uncertainty about the Brexit negotiations dampen domestic demand. We forecast average real GDP growth of 1.5% per year in 2018-19 as the economy adjusts, picking up to an average of 1.9% per year in 2020-22.
We expect the government's budget deficit to widen to 3.3% of GDP this year, after narrowing to 2.9% in 2016 (from 4.3% in 2015). A deficit will persist throughout the forecast period (2017-22). In November 2017 the Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) raised interest rates for the first time in a decade, but is likely to go into wait-and-see mode for the duration of the Brexit negotiations, before moving to normalise policy again in mid-2019.

The UK's business environment score rises in 2018-22 compared with 2013-17, and the UK rises three places in the global and regional rankings. The Brexit vote has introduced some policy uncertainty. However, the UK's traditional strengths as a business location-a pro-business policy orientation, a welcoming attitude to foreign investment, and flexible labour and product markets-will endure.
Country forecast overview: United Kingdom's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Lloyds, one of two banks rescued post-crisis by the state, returns to full private ownership; government retains big stake in struggling Royal Bank of Scotland. Brexit focus constrains reforms to improve weak trends in investment and productivity.
2020-22: Shake-up of regulatory and competition frameworks post-Brexit. Continued state support underpins house prices.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Business lobbying for government "assurances" will intensify during Brexit talks. Government pursues policies to encourage foreign direct investment inflows.
2020-22: Infrastructure plans offer investment opportunities. Likely changes in tax policies to bolster inward investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Informal talks begin on post-Brexit UK-EU free-trade agreement, alongside divorce negotiations. UK leaves EU single market (and probably customs union). Possible disruption to crossborder trade. Risk of no deal, with UK subject to World Trade Organisation (WTO) trade rules.
2020-22: Terms of new UK-EU trading arrangement phased in.
Taxes
2018-19: Gradual rise in total tax burden, alongside further reduction in corporate tax rate. Changes to system of business rates. Possible tax incentives to encourage investment and prevent companies from relocating outside UK prior to Brexit.
2020-22: Ongoing efforts to reduce revenue lost to tax evasion. Possible tax increases to support the public finances.
Financing
2018-19: Modest tightening in financial conditions likely in run-up to Brexit. Loose monetary policy persists. "Ring-fencing" bank reforms and ongoing capital strengthening (ahead of 2019 deadlines). Demand for alternative forms of debt financing.
2020-22: Availability of finance unchanged. Possible loss of "passporting" rights and restrictions on EU services trade.
The labour market
2018-19: Firms defer some hiring decisions amid Brexit uncertainty. Possible modest decline in inflows of EU workers. New apprenticeship levy and phased increase in compulsory "national living wage". Wage growth remains subdued.
2020-22: Some form of restrictions on free movement of labour from EU, but most likely flexible in response to business concerns. Policymakers struggle to respond to weak productivity and deficit in intermediate skills.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Modest rise in spending on housing, roads and digital infrastructure. Crossrail service in London begins operating.
2020-22: Construction continues on contentious high-speed rail link between London and the north of England. Steady decline in EU-funded investment activity across the UK.

Background: The end of the second world war coincided with the decline of the UK as an imperial power. Residual links with former colonial territories, close relations with the US and a separate sense of identity delayed UK membership of the European Community (now the EU) until 1973. Successive governments have resisted closer EU integration. In a referendum in June 2016 the UK electorate voted to leave the EU. The future contours of the UK's relationship with the EU are uncertain, but a diminution of UK influence in the region looks inevitable.
Political structure: The UK is a constitutional monarchy. The head of state is Queen Elizabeth II. Parliament has an elected House of Commons (the lower house, 650 seats) and a non-elected House of Lords (the upper house, non-fixed membership of about 800). The general election in June 2017 produced a minority centre-right Conservative Party government, dependent on the support of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) for a working majority. The union between the UK's constituent nations will come under pressure when the UK leaves the EU. The Conservatives will devolve more powers to Scotland and introduce a system of "English votes for English laws". The status of Northern Ireland has become more uncertain. The main opposition Labour Party increased its parliamentary seats by 30 in the June 2017 snap general election, but its ability to compete with the Conservatives will be undermined when the government redraws parliamentary constituency boundaries, which are currently favourable to Labour.
Policy issues: UK economic policy has yet to return to normal after the financial crisis, with an exceptionally loose monetary stance and unprecedented fiscal retrenchment. Real GDP growth accelerated in 2014, but momentum slowed in 2015-16. The fallout from the Brexit vote will dominate the policy agenda; The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to focus efforts on negotiating the terms of its departure from the EU and on reducing the damaging impact on the economy of the uncertainty created by the vote. This has led to a shift in the UK's monetary and fiscal policy mix, with fiscal policies becoming more significant. Managing Brexit could force policymakers to address structural deficiencies in the UK, such as weak productivity.
Taxation: The headline rate of corporation tax has been steadily reduced, from 28% in 2010 to 20% since April 2015. There are three bands of personal income tax, set at 20%, 40% and 45% (the 45% rate came into effect in April 2013, replacing the 50% rate that was introduced in 2010). The standard rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 20% (increased from 17.5% in 2011). Excise duties on tobacco and alcohol are among the highest in Europe.
Foreign trade: In 2016 exports of goods totalled US$407.3bn and imports amounted to US$588.4bn, resulting in a trade deficit of US$181.1bn. The traditional services surplus fell to US$131.1bn. The overall current-account deficit narrowed in absolute terms, to US$115.5bn, from US$122.6bn in 2015, although it edged higher as a share of GDP, to 4.3%, from 4.2%.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
The decision of the prime minister, Theresa May, to call an early general election in June 2017 backfired disastrously for the Conservative Party, which lost its majority. Mrs May's authority was further undermined by a calamitous speech at the Conservative Party conference in October, prompting calls by some in the party for a leadership contest. However, Mrs May will stay in place for now because there is no obvious alternative who could unite both wings of the party. The Conservatives fear another general election given that the momentum is with the main opposition Labour Party. Lacking a parliamentary majority and divided over Brexit, the government will do well to last the duration of the Brexit negotiations, until March 2019, and there is a significant risk of another pre-term election.
The Conservatives have formed a working government, based on a "confidence and supply" arrangement with Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP). This arrangement is likely to work in the short term because neither party wants another election, they are natural allies on questions of sovereignty and the EU, and the DUP is committed to preventing the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, from coming to power given his past association with Northern Ireland's main nationalist party, Sinn Fein. However, the arrangement is politically fragile, and the government's 13-seat working majority (down from 17 seats before the election) will dwindle with each by-election.
In early November 2017 the government was rocked by a series of scandals. Allegations of sexual misconduct by members of parliament led to the resignation of Michael Fallon as defence secretary on November 1st, and to Damian Green, the first secretary of state, being placed under investigation. Then on November 9th Priti Patel resigned from her position as international development secretary after failing to follow ministerial procedures and disclose a series of meetings held with politicians and lobbyists on a recent trip to Israel.
Mrs May's authority has been further undermined by these events, which prompted a mini-reshuffle of her cabinet. Divisions in the cabinet over Brexit are putting further strain on the government and represent a significant threat to political stability. Brexiteers in the cabinet and the Conservative Party have been supportive of Mrs May since the election because they want her to hold fast to her earlier pledges to leave the single market, the customs union and the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice (ECJ). This faction includes the Brexit secretary, David Davis; the international trade secretary, Liam Fox; the environment minister, Michael Gove; and the foreign affairs minister, Boris Johnson. They will support the prime minister as long as she pursues their vision of Brexit. However, Mrs May is also under pressure from those advocating a "softer" Brexit, who favour an extended post-2019 transition period during which the UK retains single market access, including the chancellor of the exchequer, Philip Hammond; the home secretary, Amber Rudd; and Mr Green. Cabinet divisions over Brexit have intensified in recent months and could prove difficult to contain if the Brexit negotiations become deadlocked, possibly leading to a leadership challenge and the collapse of the government.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
A snap general election was held on June 8th 2017, three years ahead of schedule. Mrs May's decision to call the election was a political miscalculation, resulting in the Conservatives losing 13 seats, leaving them with 318 seats in the 650-seat House of Commons (the lower house of parliament). The Labour Party won 30 seats in a swing of almost 10 percentage points from the 2015 election, giving it 262 parliamentary seats.
The DUP, which increased its share of parliamentary seats from eight to ten, became kingmaker. The Scottish National Party (SNP) lost 21 seats as the Conservatives and Labour both made a comeback in Scotland. The SNP leader, Nicola Sturgeon, overplayed her hand in pressing for a second independence referendum, which was not popular, and suffered from the SNP's poor record in power. The Liberal Democrats won 12 seats, up from eight in 2015. Sinn Fein won seven seats, but does not take its seats in parliament.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
The Brexit negotiations will shape the UK's international relations during The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast period (2018-22) and beyond. On March 29th the UK invoked Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union, beginning the formal two-year process of the country's withdrawal from the bloc. In line with the government's intention to honour the Brexit vote by taking control of laws, borders and the budget, the UK will formally leave the single market at the end of the Article 50 process in March 2019, but we expect the new relationship to be phased in gradually, to minimise disruption. This could mean continued adherence to EU rules for a period after withdrawal. The UK would like to have tariff-free access to EU markets, but customs union membership would mean a common external tariff and would prevent the UK from negotiating trade deals with non-EU countries. The UK has proposed alternatives to customs union membership, including a "highly streamlined" arrangement and a new customs "partnership" that reduce non-tariff barriers to trade such as technical regulations, compliance requirements and rules of origin documentation.
Negotiations over the terms of the UK's withdrawal from the EU are in deadlock over issues relating to citizens' rights, avoiding a border in Northern Ireland and, in particular, on the matter of the financial settlement. Mrs May has proposed that during a two-year transition period after March 2019, the UK could match the net financial contribution that it would have made to the end of the current EU budget phase in 2020 had it remained a member of the EU. However, the EU wants a settlement on long-term budgetary commitments that the UK is not prepared to provide at this stage.
As expected, the EU summit on October 19th-20th concluded that insufficient progress had been made on first-round issues (relating to the divorce) for trade talks to begin. However, EU leaders gave the "green light" to begin internal preparations for this. A breakthrough by the December summit is looking increasingly unlikely, as both sides refuse to budge on the financial settlement, but we expect talks to move to the next stage in early 2018.
Political exigencies on both sides reduce the scope for an amicable divorce and the risk that the negotiations will break down is high. If they do, and an extension of the Article 50 deadline is not agreed by all 27 EU members, the UK will leave the EU in 2019 without a deal and revert to World Trade Organisation (WTO) trade rules. However both sides have an incentive to agree a deal, given the mutual benefits of maintaining economic, political and security relations.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
The Brexit vote will encourage policymakers to address some of the structural deficiencies that have held back the economy in recent years, including lacklustre productivity growth, insufficient innovation and poor infrastructure. Mr Hammond announced a National Productivity Investment Fund to boost the UK's digital infrastructure and spending on research and development over the next five years. Proposals to reform the UK's housing market have focused on introducing greater speed and flexibility into the planning process. There will also be a new effort to improve vocational skills. We expect these measures to support the recovery in productivity, but they are too modest in size and scope to close the UK's productivity gap with its G7 peers.
The Queen's Speech in June set out the government's legislative agenda, which was dominated by Brexit. Eight of the 27 bills relate to the transfer of EU law into British law, a UK customs regime, independent trade policy, controls on immigration, fisheries policy, agricultural policy, nuclear safeguards and the UK's ability to impose international sanctions. In a further sign that Brexit is the government's priority, the parliamentary session will last for two years rather than one, ending two months after the UK's withdrawal at end-March 2019.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
The political pressure to ease austerity has increased since the government's poor performance in the election. In response, Mr Hammond may be tempted to spend some of the windfall from a better than expected fiscal performance this year in the forthcoming autumn budget, to be presented on November 22nd. However, policy adjustments since the last fiscal statement, in March, and likely downward revisions to the growth and productivity forecasts look set to make future deficit reduction more difficult to achieve. As a result, we do not expect big spending plans to be announced. Mr Hammond has also indicated that deficit reduction will remain a priority and the government may want to hold something in reserve for later, once the Brexit negotiations are concluded.
In the wake of the Paradise Papers data leak, the budget may also place a greater emphasis on measures to crack down on tax evasion and non-compliance. Mr Hammond is likely to focus on the progress made so far in reducing the so-called tax gap between the amount due and the amount collected, which reached a record low in the 2014/15 fiscal year.
The government's fiscal position improved in 2016, but we estimate that the deficit will expand to 3.3% of GDP in 2017, from 2.9% last year, and stay at around that level in 2018 as the government eases off from its austerity drive. Automatic stabilisers will push up spending on social transfers as unemploy-ment increases. However, revenue will still be rising, and in the remainder of our forecast period the government will aim to nudge down discretionary spending as a proportion of GDP. We expect the deficit to narrow to 2% by 2020 and 1.7% by 2022. The public debt burden edged up to 88.3% of GDP in 2016, from 88.2% in 2015. We forecast that public debt will peak at just below 92% of GDP in 2019, before falling thereafter.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
At its meeting in November, a majority of members of the monetary policy committee (MPC) of the Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) voted in favour of increasing the main policy interest rate-for the first time in a decade-by 25 basis points, to 0.5%. There had been no material change in the MPC's assessment of the outlook for growth and inflation in its November Inflation Report since the previous report, in August. Rather, the bank responded to a continuation of positive trends and reversed the rate cut from last year.
Diminished supply capacity within the economy also played into the MPC's decision, which it viewed as necessary to bring inflation back to target in the medium term and prevent a further squeeze in real incomes. However, downside risks to the outlook persist, particularly around the Brexit adjustment. The bank is therefore likely to keep monetary policy accommodative and go into wait-and-see mode following the latest decision.
We now expect the BoE to move again to normalise policy earlier than previously assumed, in the third quarter of 2019 rather than early 2021. The stock of asset purchases-made up of £435bn (US$574bn) of government bonds and £10bn of corporate bonds-will remain unchanged.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
The economy has been resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote. Average annual real GDP growth in 2016 was firm, at 1.8%. The latest GDP data point to a slowdown in the UK economy in 2017. A preliminary estimate of real GDP for the third quarter of 2017 shows that it increased by 0.4% quarter on quarter, and by 1.5% year on year, down from 1.8% year-on-year growth in the first quarter. Rising cost pressures and uncertainty about the Brexit negotiations and the UK's future relationship with the EU are likely to weigh more heavily on economic activity later this year. We therefore expect a slowdown in the pace of economic growth, to 1.6%.
UK consumer spending has been resilient in the face of a squeeze on household disposable incomes from falling real wages. This reflects higher tourism spending, employment gains and high levels of consumer borrowing. Nevertheless, the trend in retail sales has weakened: over the first nine months of 2017 annual sales volume growth averaged 2.2%-well below the full-year growth rate of 4.7% recorded in 2016. We assume that consumers and businesses will delay spending decisions in response to heightened uncertainty. After private consumption growth of 2.8% in 2016, we expect growth of 1.6% in 2017. A resilient trend in business sentiment has supported investment growth in the first half of this year, and we expect it to accelerate to 2.1%, from 1.3% in 2016, before slowing in 2018-19 as uncertainty increases as the difficulties of the Brexit negotiations become more evident. We expect the pace of real GDP growth to decelerate to 1.5% in 2018-19.
Mitigating the extent of the economic slowdown this year and in 2018 will be a deceleration in the pace of import growth as export volumes benefit from the depreciation of sterling. A deal on the UK's new trading relationship with the EU is likely to be phased in from 2019. We expect the pace of real GDP growth to accelerate to 2.1% on average in 2021-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
In April-September the headline rate of annual inflation-as measured by the consumer price index including owner occupiers' housing costs (CPIH)-fluctuated between 2.6% and 2.8%, up from 1.9% in January. The acceleration partially reflects the recovery in oil prices at the beginning of the year, but has been amplified by the sharp depreciation of sterling since the Brexit vote. With retailers passing on high input costs to customers, we expect inflation to exceed 3% in the coming months-well above the BoE's official 2% target. We expect inflation to average 2.7% in 2017 and remain high at 2.5% in 2018, even though domestic price pressures are likely to weaken. Thereafter we forecast that inflation will ease to 2% on average in 2019-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
There was a sharp drop in the external value of sterling after the Brexit vote. Sensitivity in the foreign-exchange markets to the Brexit newsflow means that the value of the pound has remained volatile, albeit within a range of US$1.20-1.27:£1 until April 18th, when Mrs May called the snap election. This initially boosted the value of the pound, but it fell back sharply in June in response to the shock result. The pound appreciated to US$1.35:£1 by mid-September, after a stronger than expected inflation outturn and commentary from the BoE that revived expect-ations of tighter monetary policy, but slipped back to US$1.33:£1 after the fifth round of Brexit talks ended in deadlock. We forecast that sterling will depreciate against the US dollar and the euro on average in the next couple of years as the economy slows. However, we expect the pound to make a gradual recovery against the dollar in the final years of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
The merchandise trade balance will keep the current account in deficit through-out 2017-22, offsetting surpluses on the services account. However, we expect a relatively sharp narrowing of the deficit, from an estimated 4.4% of GDP in 2017 to 4% in 2022, reflecting continued growth in goods exports and a shift in the primary income balance as the under-performance of the UK economy reduces income debits (the return that foreign residents receive on their investments in the UK) relative to credits (the return that UK residents receive from their foreign direct investment). Despite a decline in secondary transfers as the UK reduces its contribution to the EU budget in 2021, weaker exports to the EU will lead to a modestly expanding current-account deficit in the final years of the forecast period.

Country Forecast Turkey November 2017 Updater

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-turkey-november-2017-updater/docview/1961258216/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: In response to the failed coup in 2016 the government has carried out an extensive purge of public-sector personnel, which risks undermining institutional capacity. Since the failed coup, Turkish foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by the domestic political goals of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government. Under the AKP, Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019, and possibly earlier. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. [...]the opposition is fragmented and currently appears to have no candidates capable of challenging the incumbent. The neighbouring conflicts are also likely to continue to influence the direction of Turkey's foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, and Russia has lifted almost all sanctions.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Turkey+November+2017+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2017-11-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.issn=09668632&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The intense political instability that followed the failed coup in July 2016 has eased partially since the approval in a referendum in April 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency. However, the narrow referendum vic-tory and allegations of vote fraud have deepened social and political divisions.
The presidential reform, which is due to take effect after the next pres-idential and parliamentary elections, in 2019, will further undermine Turkey's fragile democratic institutions and governance structures. It provides few checks on the powers of the president and moves the country closer to one-man rule.
The Justice and Development Party (AKP) has enjoyed 15 years of single-party rule, and for most of that period political and government effectiveness have improved. However, since 2013 economic policymaking institutions have become increasingly politicised. In response to the failed coup in 2016 the government has carried out an extensive purge of public-sector personnel, which risks undermining institutional capacity.
Since the failed coup, Turkish foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by the domestic political goals of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government. This has resulted in a marked deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies.
Real GDP growth slowed from an annual average of 7.4% in 2010-15 to 3.3% in 2016, owing in part to the disruption to the economy from the failed coup, but also to faltering foreign capital inflows amid expectations of tighter global liquidity. A recovery began in the fourth quarter of 2016, supported by government stimulus measures, political pressure on banks to extend credit and a pick-up in global demand. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects growth to accelerate to an estimated 5.5% in 2017 and to average 4.2% in 2018-22.
We estimate that the Turkish lira will average TL3.64:US$1 in 2017, a fall of 17% compared with 2016. From 2018 we forecast that the exchange rate will remain broadly stable in real terms, depreciating mildly in nominal terms, to an average of TL4.12:US$1 in 2022. In response, we expect that the Central Bank of Turkey will have to keep a tight monetary policy stance throughout 2018.
We expect the current-account deficit to widen slightly in the forecast period compared with 2016 and remain sufficiently large to make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained.
