Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2018-22, but the country's global ranking falls by 13 places, to 58th. There is consensus among policymakers on the need to maintain macroeconomic stability. However, the failed coup and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty about the direction of policy. Important shortcomings are a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities, and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2020-22: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in a wide range of sectors, although the opening up of the energy market makes progress.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2020-22: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade and tourism following the lifting of Russian sanctions.
2020-22: Customs union with the EU could be extended, but negotiations are likely to be protracted given the deterioration in Turkish-EU relations. More free-trade agreements may come into force with the EU's trading partners.
Taxes
2018-19: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Some tax rate rises, including on company profits, have been announced for 2018, to curb the rise in the budget deficit.
2020-22: A broader income tax base as exemptions and exceptions are reduced. Possible tax cuts and increased incentives.
Financing
2018-19: Monetary policy remains cautious amid concerns about a possible deterioration in credit quality. Political pressure on c0mmercial banks to reduce interest rates. Renewed pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey cannot be ruled out.
2020-22: The banking system remains stable, despite some weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2018-19: Labour market remains rigid, with relatively high costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. Wage moderation after 30% minimum wage rise in 2016. Obstacles to employing foreigners have eased.
2020-22: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Progress, albeit slow, continues on investment plans in energy, transport and communications.
2020-22: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. The construction of major airport and urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks could persist.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West, becoming a member of the Council of Europe (1949) and NATO (1952), and signing an association agreement with the then European Community (1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup at-tempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey has a unicameral parliamentary system of government, with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Under the AKP, Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019, and possibly earlier. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions will require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing political issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015 and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted long-standing institutional weaknesses, which, with the AKP's consent until 2013, allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Further politicisation of the judiciary is likely following the coup attempt. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax is 20%, but could rise to 22% in 2018. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2016 goods exports (fob) came to US$150.2bn and imports (fob) to US$191bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$40.9bn-a contraction from US$48.1bn in 2015. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
The political outlook for 2018-22 will be dominated by a series of crucial votes in 2019, after which an executive presidential system of government will replace the current parliamentary system. Municipal elections are due to be held in March, and parliamentary and presidential elections in November. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the incumbent president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his ruling, religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, to win the elections and remain in power until 2024, and probably beyond. Failure to win the elections could throw the political system into chaos and open up irreparable divisions in the AKP. The constitutional reforms to establish a presidential system, which were approved in a referendum in April 2017, provide few checks and balances on the powers of the president. This will further weaken Turkey's democratic institutions and governance structures, effectively moving Turkey to a system of one-man rule by Mr Erdogan.
Although the intense political instability that followed the failed coup has eased partially since the April referendum, we expect renewed social and political instability during the period up to and beyond the 2019 elections. The narrow presidential reform referendum victory, amid allegations of vote tampering, has further polarised the country. It has also raised concerns among the AKP's leaders that Mr Erdogan and the AKP are losing support. With the president's political future dependent on clear victories in all three elections, the government will continue its campaign against political opponents, critics and perceived enemies of the state, using the state of emergency law. Emergency rule was initially introduced after the failed coup to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric, who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. We expect emergency rule to remain in place for the foreseeable future because it will effectively allow Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is fully in place.
Security risk will remain high, with negative implications for the economy. The state is seeking to end an insurgency by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) in the south-east of Turkey, address the domestic security risk posed by terrorist attacks by Kurdish militants and Islamic State (IS) in cities across the country, and implement military operations in Syria and Iraq against both IS and the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds. The purge of the Turkish Armed Forces and the police since the attempted coup has created operational capacity problems. In the short to medium term neither the government nor the PKK appears to be interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will intensify.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
We expect Mr Erdogan and the AKP to win the municipal, presidential and parliamentary elections in 2019. Although there are concerns within the AKP that the party has lost support since the referendum, Mr Erdogan's popularity is still unrivalled and his party has the ability to control the election process. Moreover, the opposition is fragmented and currently appears to have no candidates capable of challenging the incumbent. In 2014 Mr Erdogan won the presidential election in the first round, with just over 50% of the vote, against a joint candidate presented by the Republican People's Party (CHP) and the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The MHP's support in parliament for the presidential reform makes it unlikely that either of the two parties will consider fielding a joint candidate at the next election. The charismatic Meral Aksener, who has broken away from the MHP, is a possible challenger. She has formed a new centre-right party, the Good Party, and declared that she would run against Mr Erdogan in the presidential election. However, it is unlikely that she will win. She would have to have the support of the CHP and attract votes from incompatible constituencies, including Kurds and nationalists, who currently vote for the AKP.
The clampdown on the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) since mid-2015, the decision of the MHP leadership to back the presidential reform, and the hardline nationalist stance adopted by Mr Erdogan and the AKP could have a considerable effect on voting patterns at the next parliamentary election. Both the MHP and the HDP have been weakened since the 2015 election and run the risk of falling below the high 10% national vote threshold for parliamentary representation, which would boost the AKP's seat share. Under the constitutional changes approved in the referendum, there will be 600 seats in a much weakened parliament from the next election, up from 550 currently.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
There is a growing risk of a rupture in Turkey's ties with its traditional Western allies, compounding concerns that under the leadership of Mr Erdogan and the AKP the country is pivoting eastwards. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration, including political upheaval in Europe and the US; a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; the US's military backing of Syrian Kurdish groups, which Turkey regards as terrorist organisa-tions affiliated to the PKK; the Turkish government's authoritarian tendencies and its strident anti-Western rhetoric; and Turkey's forging of closer relations with Russia, China and Iran. Turkey's confrontational approach to its traditional Western allies should also be viewed in the context of Mr Erdogan's need to maintain the support of Turkey's nationalists to achieve his domestic political goals, notably his push to become president with executive powers after the presidential and parliamentary elections in 2019.
We expect that Turkey and its Western allies will seek to avoid a complete breakdown in relations, which could materialise if, among other things, the EU suspends Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, the migrant deal with the EU collapses, Turkey closes the Incirlik airbase to US forces or it withdraws from NATO. However, if tensions remain at current levels for a prolonged period Turkey's strategic relationships with the EU and the US are likely to suffer irreparable damage, and become increasingly antagonistic and transactional.
The spillover of violence from the conflicts in neighbouring Syria and Iraq will continue to pose serious domestic and external security threats to Turkey. In addition to terrorist attacks carried out in Turkey by IS and the PKK, which has camps in the mountains in northern Iraq, Turkey now has military forces de-ployed in two areas in Syria, ostensibly as part of the fight against IS but also to prevent US-backed, PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurds from establishing a continuous autonomous region along Syria's northern border with Turkey.
The neighbouring conflicts are also likely to continue to influence the direction of Turkey's foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, and Russia has lifted almost all sanctions. The level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly in relation to the conflict in Syria, where both are militarily involved but have been pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to remain largely transactional, and the risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector and its dynamic, diversified private business sector. However, the risk of an intensification of political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity could disrupt foreign capital inflows to Turkey during the forecast period (2018-22). These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, but tend to be short term and highly volatile. Faltering capital inflows put the lira under intense pressure in late 2016 and early 2017, fuelling an acceleration in inflation that prompted the Central Bank of Turkey to start tightening monetary policy in November 2016 after a prolonged period of loosening. The lira has recovered the ground that it lost in January 2017, but it remains vulnerable to sudden shifts in investor sentiment, as illustrated by short, sharp drops in value against the US dollar in July and October, probably prompted by expectations of balance-sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank) and geopolitical tensions in the neighbouring region. If the lira depreciates sharply again, an abrupt tightening of policy, which could strangle Turkey's economic recovery, may be necessary to halt the slide. However, this is not our baseline scenario, as we currently expect US monetary policy to be tightened only gradually in the remainder of 2017 and in 2018.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The current direction of policy appears to be towards a difficult balancing act between fiscal loosening and tight monetary policy while encouraging banks to lend to households and businesses.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Low budget deficit- and public debt-to-GDP ratios-reflecting the impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past and major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-give the government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy. Our baseline forecast remains that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight to support investor confidence and prevent a surge in domestic demand from causing an unsustainable widening of the current-account deficit. Nevertheless, we expect the central government deficit, which captures most of the public sector, to widen from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to an average of 2.2% of GDP per year in 2017-19, before narrowing, to 1.5% in 2022. Although the government debt/GDP ratio edged up slightly in 2016, to 29.2%, we expect it to decline gradually, to 27.6% in 2022. The risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances cannot be ruled out.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
Political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey to lower interest rates in order to revive economic activity has eased as the government has switched its atten-tion to Turkey's profitable commercial banks. We expect that the central bank will have to keep its monetary policy tight in the remainder of 2017 and in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent further depreciation of the lira amid political volatility and expectations of higher US interest rates and Fed balance-sheet tapering. To do this, we expect the Turkish central bank to use a mix of interest-rate rises, macroprudential measures and other policies. The bank raised most of its main policy rates between November 2016 and April 2017, and has increased funding to the banking sector at its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate, which was gradually raised by a total of 250 basis points, to 12.25% in late April, where it has remained. Since then the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system has been about 12%, compared with 7.8% in November 2016.
The central bank is seeking gradually to normalise its monetary policy frame-work to establish a single policy interest rate, which would help to improve transparency regarding monetary policy decisions. However, it is unlikely that this will happen until inflation is more firmly on a downward path towards its medium-term target of 5% and domestic political uncertainty eases.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Real GDP growth slowed from an annual average of 7.4% in 2010-15 to 3.3% in 2016, owing in part to the disruption to the economy caused by the failed coup last July, but also to faltering foreign capital inflows amid expectations of global liquidity tightening. A recovery got under way in the fourth quarter of last year, and we expect growth to accelerate to 5.5% in 2017 and to average 4.2% in 2018-22. The rebound has been supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit and a pick-up in global demand. There are downside risks to this forecast, which is predicated on the assumption that the transition to a presidential system of government in the next few years does not lead to further political instability, deterring foreign capital flows into the Turkish economy.
We expect a moderate improvement in household confidence, a recovery in employment growth and possible additional government incentives to support household spending. We forecast average real private consumption growth of 3.4% in 2017-22.
We expect government consumption growth to slow from an estimated 7% in 2017 to a still solid annual average of 6% per year in 2018-19 as the government continues to support the economy ahead of the 2019 elections. From 2020 we expect growth to be more moderate, but still solid.
The deterioration in the business environment since the attempted coup will continue to hold down private-sector fixed investment growth. However, we expect this to be offset by government investment, especially in infrastructure projects, generating real growth of 6% per year in 2017-19. In 2020-22 we forecast a deceleration to annual growth of 4.8% per year, reflecting firms' response to a more moderate expansion of domestic and external demand.
We expect the lifting of Russian sanctions on Turkey, the positive effect of a weaker lira on export competitiveness and stronger growth in the main export markets, especially Europe, to drive a return to growth of exports of goods and services in 2017-22. However, we expect the perception of security risks to persist for some time, which will continue to deter some visitors to Turkey and weigh on the tourism sector. Our expectation is that a slowdown in the Chinese economy in 2018 and a cyclical downturn in the US in 2020 will dampen external demand growth in those years.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target-as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disin-flationary effects of low global oil prices. We expect the pass-through effects of past currency weakness and a moderate recovery in oil and other commodity prices from 2017 to keep consumer price inflation well above the official target during the first half of the forecast period. Assuming that the central bank does not loosen monetary policy too soon, we expect inflation to ease gradually, achieving the 5% target by end-2021. There are upside risks to our forecast.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
Amid further bouts of volatility we estimate that the lira will depreciate against the US dollar in 2017, to an annual average of TL3.64:US$1, a fall of 17% compared with 2016. From 2018 we forecast that the exchange rate will remain broadly stable in real terms, depreciating mildly in nominal terms, to an average of TL4.12:US$1 in 2022. The lira will also depreciate sharply against the euro in 2017-22. There are substantial risks to our exchange-rate forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows, as well as the impact on investor confidence of domestic political tensions and geopolitical turmoil in the region.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
We expect the current-account deficit to widen moderately and remain large enough, at an average of 4.4% of GDP per year in 2017-22, to make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates. Although a weaker lira and the lifting of Russian sanctions will boost Turkey's main exports, we expect this to be largely offset by the moderately higher cost of imported energy and inputs for manufactured import-intensive exports. There has been a rebound in Russian tourist arrivals in 2017, but the sector is likely to take several years to recover to its 2015 pre-crisis levels, before the resurgence of terrorist attacks and the imposition of Russian sanctions.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart in May 2017 following the resignation of the ÖVP leader. An early election was held on October 15th.
The popularity of the ÖVP's new leader, the young minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, propelled his party into first place. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the ÖVP to form a coalition with the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). The SPÖ has already announced its intention to go into opposition.
The inclusion of the FPÖ in the government would not lead to similar EU sanctions as in 2000, when the party was last part of a coalition, owing largely to the normalisation of the far right in Europe since then.
We expect any new government to focus on integration and immigration policy, and to attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and introduce some additional flexibility in labour and product markets. However, low government cohesion is likely to lead to limited progress.
The government budget is forecast to remain in deficit, albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP, throughout the forecast period (2018-22), as the fiscal consolidation process is likely to be restrained by limited government cohesion and effectiveness. The public debt/GDP ratio will fall gradually, to just above 71% by 2022, from an estimated 79.8% in 2017.
After several years of underperformance compared with its regional peers, the economy has performed relatively strongly since the start of 2016, growing by 1.5% in 2016. We estimate an acceleration of growth this year, to 2.9%, and forecast that growth will moderate to 1.7% on average in 2018-22.
Consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) will continue to exceed the euro zone average in 2017-22, driven by structural domestic factors including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets. Annual inflation averaged 1% in 2016, up from 0.8% in 2015, and we expect an annual average of 2% in 2017-22.
The current-account surplus has been relatively stable in recent years, at about 2%. Although we expect small changes in the composition of the surplus, we expect it to remain relatively stable in the forecast period, at 2.2% of GDP on average in 2017-22.

Austria's business environment score improves slightly between the historical period (2013-17) and the forecast period (2018-22). As a result, the country remains in 11th place in the regional ranking but loses one place in the global ranking, dropping to 18th. Austria's strengths as a business location include decent infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited.
2020-22: Modest strengthening of competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2020-22: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal.
2020-22: EU likely to accelerate shift towards bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate. Little progress on EU-US trade deal. Free-trade agreement between EU and UK.
Taxes
2018-19: Limited changes to the tax system aimed at reducing the sizeable income tax wedge.
2020-22: Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform, and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2018-19: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe.
2020-22: Further uptake in corporate bond issuance. Credit conditions continue to ease as banks' profitability recovers, in part supported by a gradual uptick in interest rates.
The labour market
2018-19: Economy-wide minimum wage introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment starts to drop.
2020-22: Continued modest expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2020-22: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure.

Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election was held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government's stated priorities were to reduce the budget deficit and debt pile, improve labour market participation rates, strengthen competitiveness, increase expenditure on research and development, continue to reform healthcare expenditure, stabilise the financial sector and raise educational standards. Progress on these issues will be modest at best under any next government, as tensions surrounding immigration, security and border controls will remain elevated across Europe, diverting attention to security and migration-related policy areas.
Taxation: According to the European Commission, Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is the second highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: In 2016 the value of exported goods was US$142.7bn and the goods import bill was US$142.3bn. The services surplus, traditionally boosted by tourism receipts, was US$12.2bn. Along with a modest primary income deficit and significant secondary income deficit, this yielded a current-account surplus equivalent to 2.1% of GDP.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
In May 2017, after several years of little progress on reforms, and coalition and party in-fighting, the grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart following the resignation of Reinhold Mitterlehner from the positions of vice-chancellor, minister of economy and leader of the ÖVP, citing frustration within his party. The popular 31-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, took over the leadership of the ÖVP and led the party to a plurality of the vote in the early election on October 15th, with 31.5% of the vote, up by 7.5 percentage points on its result in 2013. The SPÖ's vote share was unchanged, at 26.9%. The far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) increased its vote share by 5.5 percentage points, to 26%. The liberal NEOS returned to parliament with just over 5% of the vote, and the Greens failed to cross the 4% electoral threshold for the first time in 31 years, in part because List Pilz, led by a former leader of the Greens, narrowly managed to cross it.
In the coming weeks or months The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a coalition to emerge consisting of the ÖVP and the FPÖ, led by Mr Kurz as chancellor. Although technically a majority coalition including the SPÖ would be possible, either in the form of another grand coalition or an SPÖ-FPÖ coalition, the party has already indicated that it will go into opposition. Mr Kurz has stated that he could also form a minority government should negotiations fail. However, there is little precedent for this in Austria. The ÖVP and the FPÖ have already started negotiations, and the fact that the parties' programmes are quite close (during the campaign the leader of the FPÖ, Heinz-Christian Strache, regularly criticised Mr Kurz for stealing the FPÖ's programme) should help them to reach an agree-ment. The president, who has a relatively large role in the government forma-tion process, including the right to veto ministerial appointees, could still block the formation of a right-wing government, although this is not our core forecast.
Although we thus expect a chancellor from the ÖVP, the election should still be seen as a further step in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the ÖVP has been replaced to a large extent by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties have together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, and a renewed grand coalition has become almost impossible following the breakdown of relations between the two parties and the gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited both from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz also owes much of his popularity to his strong stance on this issue and his plans to curtail migration into Europe and Austria.
Although the two parties share common ground on several issues, we expect the government to struggle to implement its policies, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters and the FPÖ could struggle to translate its opposition stance on matters such as immigration and integration into concrete policy proposals. As a result, we expect limited progress on significant structural reforms, and the risk of an early election in the next parliamentary term is high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The last general election was held on October 15th 2017. It was won by the ÖVP, who we expect to form a government with the FPÖ. Unless the government falls before then, it will sit until the end of the term of the new Nationalrat (the lower house of parliament) in late 2022.
Elections for several state parliaments are planned for the first half of 2018. The next election for the primarily ceremonial post of federal president will be in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this influx, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high. All three of the large parties have hinted that they want to limit labour migration within the EU, or at least give preferential treatment to Austrian citizens in the labour market, which will exacerbate tensions with many EU member states.
Nevertheless, Mr Kurz has been at pains to point out that any government under him will have to be pro-EU, and we therefore do not expect Austria's EU membership to be questioned in the coming years. The FPÖ has also moderated its critique of the EU. We expect Austria to be a leading voice in the EU in the coming years, especially on reform of migration into the bloc. This should not lead to significant tensions, however, as it is likely to find broad support for proposals such as tighter controls of the EU's outer borders and processing asylum applications outside the EU.
Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ in government following the election in 1999 led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations in 2000, we do not expect this to be repeated should the party join the next governing coalition. At that time a far-right nationalist party entering government was an unusual development, but since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority governments in parliament in several EU countries, including some Nordic countries, Italy and the Netherlands.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Alongside the 2016 tax reform, which provided about EUR5bn in tax relief to households, government policy has focused on challenges facing the country's financial sector. These have included the clean-up and debt restructuring of Heta Asset Resolution, a "bad bank" that was created to deal with the toxic assets of Hypo Group Alpe Adria (HGAA). The uncertainty surrounding Heta was removed in October 2016, when creditors accepted a debt-restructuring deal. The government has also had to manage the banking sector's exposure to central and east European economies.
In the renegotiation of its coalition agreement in January 2017 the coalition decided on a number of measures that it hoped to implement before the end of its term in 2018. These included a new annual minimum wage of EUR21,000, as opposed to only sector-specific negotiated minimum wages; and reducing red tape for employers, including more flexible rules on working hours. However, although the coalition parties agreed to implement a number of these measures before the election in October, little progress was made. The next govern-ment, which we expect to include the FPÖ, will move integration and immigration policy further to the right and is likely to focus on improving the business environment, including by reducing the sizeable tax wedge, but we expect it to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
In 2014 Austria's fiscal accounts deteriorated, mainly reflecting the govern-ment's decision to create a bad bank to deal with HGAA's toxic assets. The fiscal deficit widened to the equivalent of 2.7% of GDP, from 1.4% in 2013, and public debt rose to 83.7% of GDP. Mainly in response to steady direct revenue growth, the deficit narrowed to 1.1% of GDP in 2015, but widened again in 2016, to 1.5%, owing in part to fiscally expansionary tax reforms and higher migrant-related public spending.
We expect the budget to remain in deficit throughout the forecast period (2018-22), albeit safely within the EU mandated limit of 3% of GDP. Despite only limited fiscal consolidation, robust economic growth will help to narrow the deficit slightly. The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from an estimated 79.8% in 2017 to just above 71% in 2022. Although the public finances will remain worse than in peers such as Germany or the Netherlands, the low interest rate environment and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals mean that funding risks are extremely low in our view.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The European Central Bank (ECB) is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a quantitative easing (QE) programme that will run at EUR60bn per month until the end of 2017, and at EUR30bn per month in January-September 2018. The economic recovery in the euro zone has strengthened this year and has become more broad based. We expect a healthy expansion of real GDP in the euro zone in 2017, of 2.2%, after growth of 1.9% on average in 2015-16. The ECB continues to take stock of this growth momentum, but maintains a clearly dovish policy stance, with the reduction in the amount of monthly QE purchases in 2018 designed to extend its presence in the bond markets. The bank also plans to delay raising interest rates and reinvest the principal payments from maturing securities for a period well beyond the end of the QE programme. We expect the pace of monthly QE purchases to be reduced to zero in early 2019, but owing to subdued price pressure and persistent downside risks to growth, we forecast that the bank will delay raising policy rates until 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy largely stalled and under-performed in comparison with regional peers, notably Germany; this was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. A faltered reform process has contributed to higher inflation compared with regional peers, and weakened productivity growth, admittedly from fairly high levels. Real GDP rose by a sluggish 1.1% in 2015, and although it accelerated in 2016, to 1.5%, it remained below Germany's 1.8% growth.
However, the economy has recently started to gain momentum again, with average quarterly growth of 0.7% between July 2016 and June 2017. Although the labour market had in previous years struggled to integrate the significant increase in the labour force, it seemed to have turned a corner in late 2016 and early 2017, in part owing to a surge in employment in the manufacturing sector, when the unemployment rate started to fall. This is supporting private consumption, which we expect to grow by 1.7% this year. Furthermore, export and investment growth have also picked up. As a result, we expect real GDP growth to accelerate to an upwardly revised 2.9% this year, above growth in Germany for the first time since 2005.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-following an under-performance even compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue next year, although we forecast slower growth, at 2%, as we expect the impulse from the manufacturing sector in 2017 to have been a one-off. In the following years we expect a moderation of growth. Domestic demand will be the main driver of growth, which is likely to converge towards potential growth in these years. We therefore expect average real GDP growth of 1.6% in 2019-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.9% in 2015-16-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices and energy-price base effects fostered a gradual rise in inflation from October 2016 and in 2017, when we estimate full-year average inflation of 2.1%. Recent strengthening of the euro will weigh slightly on inflation, but we expect inflation to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-22, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors as in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
The euro has moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1 since mid-2015. The annual average exchange rate was US$1.11:EUR1 in 2016, although a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. The euro has since rallied as the region's economic recovery has strengthened, and as political risk has waned in Europe but risen in the US. More recently, a rise in expectations of QE tapering by the ECB has prompted a sharp appreciation in the euro against the dollar. The value of the euro could yet come under pressure from political risk-especially in relation to the next general election in Italy, which we expect to take place in early 2018-and monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a gradual appreciation on average, to US$1.20:EUR1 by 2020-21, as the euro is supported by an ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, and the business cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020. We expect the euro to appreciate further in 2022 as the monetary policy tightening cycle begins.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values helped the trade balance to move into surplus in 2014-16, from a deficit in 2009-13. We expect the trade balance to move into a modest deficit from 2017 as robust export growth is outweighed by higher import costs and strengthening domestic demand pushes up import volumes. However, this will be compensated for by a healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourism inflows. Modest primary income surpluses will not be enough to outweigh consistent secondary income deficits. However, we expect the services balance largely to outweigh the weakening trade balance and the current-account surplus to remain broadly flat throughout 2017-22, at about 2.2% of GDP on average.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Although the regime of the president, Nicolás Maduro, will strengthen its grip on power after the installation of a Constituent Assembly, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect Mr Maduro to remain in power beyond 2019. The most likely scenarios for a transition to an opposition-led government are through ad hoc elections after economic collapse (probably as foreign-exchange shortages culminate in debt default) or a military coup. There is a risk that the regime will cling to power if either Chinese or Russian finance helps the sovereign to avoid debt default, or should Mr Maduro be replaced by another member of the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela to appease critics.
We estimate year-on-year inflation to exceed 1,000% by end-2017 and 1,900% at end-2018. We forecast that GDP will have contracted by a third between 2014 and 2019. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consump-tion and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. We forecast a recovery beginning in 2020, by which time the current opposition is expected to be in government, leading to macro-economic adjustments, and institutional and structural reforms.
Sweeping reforms are required to restore confidence in contract and property rights, and thereby promote a recovery in investment. The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will encourage private investment, re-establish market mechanisms for price stability and attempt to undo the constraints imposed by the government on private firms.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and quadruple-digit inflation will hit private consumption, and the increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate the fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices, and the economy will not return to growth until 2020, assuming that a new government takes power and that implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
At almost 300bn barrels, Venezuela has the world's largest proven oil reserves, but its oil sector has suffered from disinvestment and mismanagement owing to political interference. The government claims that rising investment in the energy sector will lift oil production significantly in the medium term, but we foresee a continued fall in production until 2019, followed by rising output from 2020 onwards as economic conditions stabilise.

Venezuela is in 80th position globally in our business environment rankings for 2018-22, out of 82 countries covered. It is therefore one of the least attractive investment locations. This reflects state interventionism, highly hetero-dox macroeconomic policies, a lack of legal security and weak institutions. Regionally, Venezuela remains last of the 12 countries covered, notwithstanding our assumption of improvements after 2019.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Nationalisation poses a diminished threat, given fiscal weaknesses. Property rights remain weak. Price fixing undermines profitability.
2020-22: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists. A new government in 2019 brings new policies
2020-22: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain fairly low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2018-19: Unorthodox exchange-rate policy framework adds to uncertainty. The state continues to exercise tight control over access to official-rate US dollars. New government in 2019 removes exchange controls
2020-22: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2018-19: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2020-22: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2018-19: Credit growth remains firm, but sectoral allocation is distorted by administrative interventions. Banks remain highly profitable, although unpredictable enforcement and a weak regulatory framework heighten instability.
2020-22: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2018-19: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2020-22: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Access to water and electricity supplies remains precarious. Underinvestment in power transmission ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2020-22: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued electricity rationing.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Chávez was diagnosed with cancer in 2011 but, after declaring in July 2012 that he had fully recovered, won a fourth presidential term in October 2012. However, his health quickly deteriorated and he died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has since plummeted.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is a federal republic, successive administrations have proven reluctant to devolve political authority, with the transfer of financial resources from federal to local level highly dependent on the central government. The legislature is unicameral, and elections for the National Assembly take place every five years. In December 2015 the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the legislature. In August 2017 the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) installed a Constituent Assembly with powers over all branches of government and a remit to rewrite the 1999 Constitution-apparently a ploy to entrench the PSUV in power.
Policy issues: Political radicalisation has been reflected in increasingly heterodox economic policymaking, with massive fiscal and monetary stimulus and the nationalisation of industries deemed strategically important. Distortions created by this approach have become evident, with inflation rising sharply in spite of price controls, and with capital controls spawning a rampant black market for foreign exchange. Failure to invest part of the oil windfall has led to a startling decline in physical infrastructure. Non-oil production has in effect ground to a halt, leaving the economy entirely dependent on the energy sector. With large oil shipments going to China to repay loans, and (on subsidised terms) to regional neighbours via the PetroCaribe oil-financing scheme, the country is running very short of US dollars, forcing cuts in import spending.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 60% for oil firms. Since 2011 a maximum royalty of 95% has applied to oil extraction. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Official data are unavailable, but we estimate that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$7bn in 2016 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages, narrowing the current-account deficit to 1.8% of GDP.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Political and social tension will remain high following a controversial vote on July 30th organised by the president, Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), to establish a Constituent Assembly (ANC) with powers over all branches of government-including the opposition-controlled National Assembly-and a remit to write a new constitution. However, protests led by the Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) opposition between April and July over the country's slide towards authoritarian government (the protests led to over 120 civilian deaths, mostly caused by the security forces) have died down as the MUD's focus shifts briefly to state governorship elections scheduled for October 15th. The scale of protests is likely to wax and wane in response to government measures to stifle democratic procedures, and those that are likely to persist will be from more violent and hardline youth groups of the opposition, known as the "Resistencia".
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a change of government at some point in the forecast period. The government will resist holding the presidential election that is due in December 2018. It seems unconcerned about ever more damning criticism from the international community, including a threat of further US economic sanctions after the imposition of financial constraints in late August. Nonetheless, we do not expect Mr Maduro to manage to cling to power for the entire 2018-22 forecast period, on the basis that economic conditions seem set to deteriorate further, with Venezuela already on the brink of hyperinflation and default. These conditions will generate an unsustainable level of pressure, resulting in a change of government. International oil prices are not expected to rise sufficiently to provide the foreign-exchange proceeds needed to ease chronic consumer goods shortages (Venezuela depends heavily on imports) and allow the government to meet external debt obligations falling due over the next 12-15 months. We therefore believe that a transition involving the opposition is likely in the medium term.
Given the highly volatile political situation, accurately forecasting when and how a transition of power will occur is challenging. We believe that there are two main triggers to a transfer of authority. The first involves a traumatic descent into hyperinflation and default. In this scenario, Mr Maduro could manage to muddle through for the remainder of 2017 and much of 2018, running down reserves to meet external debt repayments, before ultimately being unable to avoid default, perhaps in the context of the imposition of sanctions by the US on Venezuela oil imports. This would be likely to bring about Mr Maduro's downfall, as his allies in government and the military would be hit financially, and remaining popular support from his constituents (chiefly the poor and public-sector workers) would fade owing to heightened economic hardship as hand-outs dry up. Subsequently, a negotiated exit for key government figures would pave the way for the holding of fresh elections and an eventual victory for the MUD.
The second of the most likely potential transition scenarios involves a military coup, triggered by dissent among the ranks of the armed forces. Although successive PSUV governments have given increasing power to the generals and trained lower-ranking soldiers that share their ideology, unease among other stakeholders in the armed forces appears to be growing, judging by sporadic episodes of rebellion in recent months. In this scenario, a military government could replace the current PSUV leadership, although we would expect such a government to pave the way for free and fair elections relatively quickly.
Although it is not our baseline forecast, we recognise that there is a high risk that the PSUV will cling on to power. If, for example, Russia or China were to provide sufficient financial assistance to allow Venezuela to avoid default and boost oil output, or if oil prices were to rise significantly beyond our expectations, there is a possibility that the government would manage to withstand political pressure for elections and regime change. In another possible scenario, Mr Maduro could leave office but be replaced by another high-ranking PSUV official in an attempt to appease critics. However, no likely successor to Mr Maduro would appease opposition demands for elections and political transition, and tension would remain high.
Regardless of when and how political transition occurs, the second half of our forecast period is likely to remain volatile and uncertain. The broad, diverse opposition coalition will have to contend with huge economic distortions and deep political differences that would test even a unified political party. Although we expect significant financial support from multilateral lending agencies, the risk of renewed political volatility will remain high, even under an opposition government.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
In both of our transition scenarios we assume that elections will eventually be held and will be relatively free and fair, ushering the MUD-led opposition into power. However, as part of the government's efforts to cling to power in the meantime, we expect that the Maduro regime and the ANC will push back the schedule for the next presidential election, which is due in December 2018. The ANC began work in August and has a two-year mandate, so at the very least elections could be pushed back to August 2019, with approval from the politicised Supreme Court likely to be forthcoming. State governor elections are scheduled for October 15th, and we expect the MUD to do well. However, the centralisation of power means that the results will have little impact on overall government policy.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Following the installation of the ANC, Venezuela has become much more isolated diplomatically and is coming under increasing regional and international pressure. To date, this has done little to weaken the government's grip on power, but US sanctions could prove significant. After ratcheting up individual sanctions on key government figures in recent months, the US administration has escalated this policy and, in late August, restricted the government's financing by barring dealings in new debt with both the government and PDVSA, the state-owned oil company. There is a growing likelihood of other economic measures such as cuts in US exports of distillates that Venezuela needs for its oil exports, which would lift costs and hence reducing foreign-exchange proceeds. Ultimately, the US could cut purchases of Venezuelan oil, a move that would cripple the economy.
Mercosur, a regional bloc comprised of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, and Uruguay, has suspended Venezuela indefinitely owing to "violations to the constitutional order", and a group of major countries in the region has denounced the regime and said that they will not recognise laws passed by the new ANC. The Vatican, which has in the past tried to mediate between the Venezuelan government and opposition, has also criticised the ANC. After some progress in mid-September, a new round of internationally-mediated talks between the MUD and the government seems to have stalled. Talks may restart in coming weeks, but huge obstacles remain to a negotiated exit to the political crisis.
A key priority for the Maduro administration will be the maintenance of good relations with China (a key creditor) and Russia, whose state oil company, Rosneft, is active in Venezuela. Financial assistance from these countries could help the Maduro regime to survive for longer by providing much-needed external financing in exchange for lucrative oil contracts for Rosneft.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
It is unlikely that the government will be able to manage the build-up of inflationary and currency depreciation pressures without significant policy adjustments. We assume that the Maduro government will be forced to weaken the currency more substantially in 2018 than it has done so far. However, other much-needed reforms are unlikely to be addressed by a government that has proved unwilling or technically incapable of adjusting policy sufficiently to move Venezuela's economy away from the brink of collapse. Fiscal and monetary policies will remain expansionary, and ad hoc policy intervention-ism and heavy state control of the economy will persist. Amid subdued oil prices, import compression will remain necessary, as other sources of foreign exchange will be hard to find. We currently expect Venezuela to meet its 2017 obligations, which are mostly owed by PDVSA. However, given an extremely thin reserves cushion (less than US$10bn by late September, most of which is held in gold), we have now factored into our forecasts the likelihood of a debt default in 2018, which would have dramatic consequences in the form of lower oil production, reduced import capacity, hyperinflation and political turmoil.
In our baseline scenario, we expect the opposition to hold power by 2019, ushering in much-needed, market-driven adjustments designed to correct currency distortions, alleviate shortages of basic goods, tighten expansionary fiscal policy and rebuild institutional capacity after years of deterioration under PSUV rule. It is probable, given the scale of the challenge, that the new government will seek a financing agreement with the IMF to support the adjustment process; we have factored in accumulated lending of US$19bn in 2019-22. Efforts to secure increased inflows of foreign direct investment would also be likely under a new government, and would help to improve the balance-of-payments dynamics, although we expect direct investors to remain cautious for some time with regards to Venezuela, with the possible exception of the oil sector.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
The authorities' failure to publish data on the non-financial public sector since 2012 demonstrates the opacity of the public finances and complicates accurate forecasting of the size of the deficit. We estimate a non-financial public sector deficit of 19.5% of GDP for 2017 and expect the deficit to remain in double digits in 2018. A transition to a new government should help to ease the deficit to 4.4% of GDP by 2021. The large deficits of the present are mostly being financed by printing money; money supply (M2) rose by 452% year on year in August, the highest rate on record. High inflation and an overvalued currency are eroding the relative value of domestic and external debt, making debt/GDP ratios unreliable indicators of fiscal stability. There is considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing, mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA. As these items are excluded from the public debt statistics, the true size of total public liabilities is understated. Our forecasts now assume that Venezuela will default on its external debt at some stage in 2018. This will be followed by a restructuring process with external creditors under an MUD-led opposition government.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
Monetary policy under the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) will continue to be driven by the government's desire to keep real interest rates negative and to print money to finance large fiscal deficits. In the context of extremely high inflation, we expect real rates to remain deeply negative until 2019. After that, our forecast of substantial currency and fiscal adjustment under a new government, which implies a substantial tightening of monetary policy, will see real interest rates turn positive.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending mean that, after an estimated contraction of 9.3% in 2017, we project further contractions in real GDP in 2018-19. Our forecast for a recovery in 2020-22 rests on our assumption of slightly higher oil prices, alongside a political transition that produces a combination of macroeconomic adjustment (supported by IMF financial assistance), and institutional and structural reform. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, given the scale of the recession. Our forecasts there-fore imply only a partial rebound, after a real GDP decline of a third in 2014-19.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2018, reflecting the effect on real wages of soaring inflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will continue to contract sharply, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange, and remitting profits. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition, progress on long­delayed joint projects with Chinese firms in energy and-later in the forecast period-a pick-up in public-sector investment. Exports will continue to shrink through 2019 as oil production falls further, but will pick up thereafter, reflecting renewed investment under a new government and a removal of constraints to domestic production. Import demand will rise faster than exports, in line with an alleviation of basic goods shortages and the release of pent-up demand from recession. Even after the change in govern-ment, however, dependence on oil will persist.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
A decimation of domestic supply and severe shortages of foreign-exchange reserves have caused inflation to soar for much of the past two years, and in the short term there is little sign that the situation will improve, despite deep reces-sion. No new official inflation data have been released since end-2015, but since the start of the year the National Assembly has begun producing a consumer price index. This showed monthly inflation of 33.7% in August, bringing accumu-lated inflation for January---August to 366%. Assuming that price pressures remain high, we expect inflation to exceed 1,000% by year-end and reach over 1,900% by the end of 2018. We continue to forecast a decline in inflation over time, under the assumption of a recovery in oil output and corrective economic policies under an MUD-led government. However, for now, a lack of funds available for importing basic goods suggests that shortages will be rife, and the risk of hyperinflation (monthly inflation of over 50%) will remain substantial.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
In late August, Mr Maduro announced the implementation of a "basket of currencies" (such as the rupee, rouble, yuan and euro) for international transactions to avoid the use of the US dollar. The basket of currencies will include currencies that are not easily convertible, meaning that this will probably make external transactions even more complicated. Amid huge pressures on the dual-currency exchange-rate system, our forecasts assume substantial devaluations in 2018, but the exchange rate will remain extremely overvalued. The dual exchange-rate system is composed of an official peg, known as the Dipro, which is limited to priority public-sector imports and set at BsF10:US$1, and a heavily managed rate known as the Dicom, used for private-sector operations (but where demand for US dollars vastly outstrips supply). After the government unexpectedly announced a suspension of the Dicom system in early September, the black-market rate shot up; it was BsF23,781:US$1 on September 25th.
We assume that further major currency adjustment under a new, MUD-led government in 2019 will involve immediate exchange-rate unification. Until that occurs, given existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market, there is an extremely high risk of a debilitating currency crisis in the short term. If confidence in the bolívar collapses amid hyperinflation, dollarisation-or the launch of a new domestic currency-could occur.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
We forecast the current-account deficit will be 4% of GDP in 2018, as exports, held back by decaying infrastructure, falling oil production and lack of exploration, will be unable to offset imports, despite the government's best efforts at dampening them (we estimate that the value of imports in 2017 will be equivalent to one-third of those of 2012). In 2019, with a new administration in place, exports and imports will begin a recovery; however, in the years ahead the latter will outstrip the former owing to years of pent-up demand and in line with an easing of external financing constraints. Our assumption of economic adjustment in the medium term suggests some recovery in capital inflows, particularly into the oil sector. Together with IMF loans, this should help to rebuild reserves coverage. However, given increased imports, our forecasts assume that even by the end of the forecast period in 2022 reserves will cover less than two months of goods and services imports.

Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCRP: Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart in May 2017 following the resignation of the ÖVP leader. An early election will be held on October 15th.
The popularity of the ÖVP's new leader, the young minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, propelled his party into first place in the polls. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the ÖVP to win the largest vote share. The most likely coalition to emerge is one that is led by the ÖVP and includes the Freedom Party (FPÖ), although negotiations to form one could be fraught.
The inclusion of the FPÖ in the government would not lead to similar EU sanctions as in 2000, when the party was last part of a coalition, owing largely to the normalisation of the far right in Europe since then.
We expect any new government to focus on integration and immigration policy, and to attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and introduce some additional flexibility in labour and product markets. However, low government cohesion is likely to lead to limited progress.
The government budget is forecast to remain in deficit, albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP, throughout the forecast period (2018-22), as the fiscal consolidation process is likely to be restrained by limited government cohesion and effectiveness. The public debt/GDP ratio will fall gradually.
After several years of underperformance compared with its regional peers, the economy has performed relatively strongly since the start of 2016, growing by 1.6% in 2016. We estimate an acceleration of growth this year, to 2.5%, and forecast that growth will moderate to 1.6% on average in 2018-22.
Consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) will continue to exceed the euro zone average in 2017-22, driven by structural domestic factors including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets. Annual inflation averaged 1% in 2016, up from 0.8% in 2015, and we forecast an annual average of 2% in 2017-22.
In 2016 the current-account surplus decreased slightly, to 1.7% of GDP. We forecast that it will average about 2.3% in 2018-22 as a weakening trade balance continues to be offset by strong tourism receipts.

Austria's business environment score improves slightly between the historical period (2013-17) and the forecast period (2018-22). As a result, the country remains in 11th place in the regional ranking but loses one place in the global ranking, dropping to 18th. Austria's strengths as a business location include decent infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited.
2020-22: Modest strengthening of competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2020-22: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal.
2020-22: EU likely to accelerate shift towards bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate. Little progress on EU-US trade deal. Free-trade agreement between EU and UK.
Taxes
2018-19: Limited changes to the tax system aimed at reducing the sizeable income tax wedge.
2020-22: Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform, and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2018-19: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe.
2020-22: Further uptake in corporate bond issuance. Credit conditions continue to ease as banks' profitability recovers, in part supported by a gradual uptick in interest rates.
The labour market
2018-19: Economy-wide minimum wage introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment starts to drop.
2020-22: Continued modest expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2020-22: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure.
