Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election will be held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government's stated priorities were to reduce the budget deficit and debt pile, improve labour market participation rates, strengthen competitiveness, increase expenditure on research and development, continue to reform healthcare expenditure, stabilise the financial sector and raise educational standards. Progress on these issues will be modest at best under any next government, as tensions surrounding immigration, security and border controls will remain elevated across Europe, diverting attention to security and migration-related policy areas.
Taxation: According to the European Commission, Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is the second highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: In 2016 the value of exported goods was US$142.8bn and the goods import bill was US$143bn. The services surplus, traditionally boosted by tourism receipts, was US$11.3bn. Along with a modest primary income deficit and significant secondary income deficit, this yielded a current-account surplus equivalent to 1.7% of GDP.

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
Following several years of little progress on reforms, and coalition and party in-fighting, the grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart in May 2017 following the resignation of Reinhold Mitterlehner from the positions of vice-chancellor, minister of economy and leader of the ÖVP, citing frustration within his own party. The popular 31-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, has taken over the leadership of the ÖVP and will run as the party's lead candidate in the early general election on October 15th. However, probably owing to the party's poor performance in the polls (it has languished in third place since the first half of 2016), Mr Kurz decided to leverage his own popularity by demanding full control over the ÖVP and that the party appear on the ballot as "List Sebastian Kurz-the New People's Party", which would also include a number of people not previously associated with the ÖVP. Following Mr Kurz's arrival as party leader the ÖVP shot to the top of the polls, pushing the opposition far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) to third place, from first. The campaign still holds some potential to derail Mr Kurz's efforts, as he is inexperienced, especially on topics relating to economic policy, an area in which his main challenger, the current SPÖ chancellor, Christian Kern, is significantly stronger. However, owing in part to the ÖVP's lead (it is polling around 33%, compared with 24% for the second-placed SPÖ), The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the ÖVP to emerge as the largest party in the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house of parliament).
Nevertheless, the election will be a further step in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the ÖVP will have been replaced to a large extent by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties have together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, and a renewed grand coalition has become almost impossible following the break-down of relations between the two parties and the gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited both from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz looks to be mostly drawing voters away from the FPÖ, in large part based on his strong stance on immigration and border control.
The most likely coalition to emerge after the election is one led by the ÖVP, with the FPÖ as a junior coalition partner, as the other parties-including the Greens; NEOS, a liberal party; and List Pilz, a new group recently set up by Peter Pilz, a former Green member of parliament (MP)-are unlikely to be large enough to help either the SPÖ or the ÖVP to reach a parliamentary majority. Risks to this outlook remain, as the election could turn, and coalition negotiations could falter because the FPÖ will probably demand significant concessions from Mr Kurz. Regardless of which coalition emerges, we expect political stability to deteriorate further. The government will struggle to implement its policies, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters and the FPÖ could struggle to translate its opposition on matters such as immigration and integration into concrete policy proposals. As a result, we expect little progress on significant structural reforms, and the risk of an early election in the next parliamentary term is high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The next general election is scheduled for October 15th 2017. The most likely scenario is that the rebranded ÖVP under Mr Kurz will win the largest share of the vote-but not an outright majority-and subsequently form a coalition with the FPÖ.
Elections for several state parliaments are planned for the first half of 2018. The next election for the primarily ceremonial post of federal president will be in 2022.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this influx, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high. All three of the large parties have hinted that they want to limit labour migration within the EU, or at least give preferential treatment to Austrian citizens in the labour market, which will exacerbate tensions with many EU member states, regardless of the composition of the coalition that emerges after the election.
Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ in government following the election in 1999 led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations in 2000, we do not expect this to be repeated should the party join the next governing coalition. At that time a far-right nationalist party entering government was an unusual development, but since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority governments in parliament in several EU countries, including some Nordic countries, Italy and the Netherlands.
The rerun of the presidential election in December 2016 demonstrated the relatively broad support for EU membership. Many voters cited as one of their main reasons for voting for Alexander Van der Bellen-the independent candidate running against Norbert Hofer, the FPÖ candidate-suggestions by Mr Hofer of a possible membership referendum in Austria. This experience should moderate any further attempts by the FPÖ to use the EU as a divisive issue.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Alongside the 2016 tax reform, which provided about EUR5bn in tax relief to households, government policy has focused on challenges facing the country's financial sector. These have included the clean-up and debt restructuring of Heta Asset Resolution, a "bad bank" that was created to deal with the toxic assets of Hypo Group Alpe Adria (HGAA). The uncertainty surrounding Heta was removed in October 2016, when creditors accepted a debt-restructuring deal. The government has also had to manage the banking sector's exposure to central and east European economies.
In the renegotiation of its coalition agreement in January 2017 the coalition decided on a number of measures that it hoped to implement before the end of its term in 2018. These included a new annual minimum wage of EUR21,000, as opposed to only sector-specific negotiated minimum wages; and reducing red tape for employers, including more flexible rules on working hours. However, although the coalition parties agreed to implement a number of these measures before the election in October, little progress has been made. The next govern-ment, which is likely to include the FPÖ, will move integration and immigration policy further to the right and is likely to focus on improving the business environment, including by reducing the sizeable tax wedge, but we expect it to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
In 2014 Austria's fiscal accounts deteriorated, mainly reflecting the govern-ment's decision to create a bad bank to deal with HGAA's toxic assets. The fiscal deficit widened to the equivalent of 2.7% of GDP, from 1.4% in 2013, and public debt rose to 84.4% of GDP. Mainly in response to steady direct revenue growth, the deficit narrowed to 1.1% of GDP in 2015, but widened again in 2016, to 1.6%, owing in part to fiscally expansionary tax reforms and higher migrant-related public spending.
We expect the budget to remain in deficit throughout the forecast period (2018-22), albeit safely within the EU mandated limit of 3% of GDP. Despite only limited fiscal consolidation, robust economic growth will help to narrow the deficit slightly. The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from 84.6% in 2016 following a positive contribution from the Heta deal, to about 74% in 2022. In the context of the quantitative easing (QE) undertaken by the European Central Bank (ECB) and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals, funding risks are extremely low in our view.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
The ECB is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a EUR60bn per month quantitative easing (QE) programme, which will run until the end of 2017. However, the economic recovery in the euro zone has strengthened in the first half of 2017-supported by an acceleration in credit growth and a decline in unemployment-and looks to be more broad-based. We expect a healthy expansion of real GDP in the euro zone in 2017, of 2.2%, after growth of 1.9% on average in 2015-16. The ECB continues to take stock of this growth momentum, and has revealed that it may make an announcement on the future of its QE programme in October. We maintain our view that the bank will begin to wind down gradually, or "taper", the programme in 2018. Nevertheless, underlying price pressure remains relatively subdued, and downside risks to wage growth and the global economy during that year could yet slow the pace at which the ECB will reduce its monthly asset purchases. We forecast that the ECB will raise policy rates in 2022, although there is a high risk that this move will be brought forward to 2021.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy largely stalled and under-performed in comparison with regional peers, notably Germany; this was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. A faltered reform process has contributed to higher inflation compared with regional peers, and weakened productivity growth, admittedly from fairly high levels. Real GDP rose by a sluggish 0.8% in 2015, and although it accelerated in 2016, to 1.6%, it remained below Germany's 1.8% growth.
However, the economy has recently started to gain momentum again, with average quarterly growth of 0.7% between July 2016 and June 2017. Although the labour market had in previous years struggled to integrate the significant increase in the labour force, it seemed to have turned a corner in late 2016 and early 2017, when the unemployment rate started to fall. This is supporting private consumption, which we expect to grow by 1.9% this year. Furthermore, export and investment growth have also picked up. As a result, we expect real GDP growth to accelerate to 2.5% this year, slightly above growth in Germany for the first time since 2005.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-following an under-performance even compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue next year, when we forecast that the economy will expand by 1.9%. In the following years we expect a moderation of growth. Domestic demand will be the main driver of growth, which is likely to converge towards potential growth in these years. We therefore expect average real GDP growth of just 1.5% in 2019-22.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.8% in 2015 and 1% in 2016-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices and energy-price base effects fostered a gradual rise in inflation from October 2016, and will continue to do so in the rest of 2017, when we estimate full-year average inflation of 2%. Recent strengthening of the euro will weigh slightly on inflation, but we expect inflation to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-22, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors as in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
The euro has moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1 since mid-2015. The annual average exchange rate was US$1.11:EUR1 in 2016, although a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. The euro has since rallied as the region's economic recovery has strengthened, and as political risk has waned in Europe but risen in the US. More recently, a rise in expectations of QE tapering by the ECB has prompted a sharp appreciation in the euro against the dollar. The value of the euro could yet come under pressure from political risk-especially in relation to the next general election in Italy, which we expect to take place in early 2018-and monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a gradual appreciation on average, to US$1.20:EUR1 by 2020-21, as the euro is supported by an ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, while the business cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020. We expect the euro to appreciate further in 2022 as the monetary policy tightening cycle begins.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values helped the trade balance to move into surplus in 2014-15, from a deficit in 2009-13. The recent recovery has pushed up imports and moved the trade balance back into a small deficit in 2016. We expect the trade deficit to widen gradually in the coming years as robust export growth is outweighed by higher import costs and strengthening domestic demand pushes up import volumes. However, this will be compensated for by a healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourism inflows. We therefore expect continued current-account surpluses in 2017-22, of about 2.4% of GDP on average.

Country Forecast Turkey October 2017 Updater

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-turkey-october-2017-updater/docview/1954095629/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: In response to the failed coup in 2016 the government has carried out an extensive purge of public-sector personnel, which risks undermining institutional capacity. Since the failed coup Turkish foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by the domestic political goals of the incumbent president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government. Under the AKP, Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019, and possibly earlier. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. [...]the opposition is fragmented and currently appears to have no candidates capable of challenging the incumbent. The neighbouring conflicts are also likely to continue to influence the direction of Turkey's foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, and Russia has lifted almost all sanctions.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Turkey+October+2017+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2017-10-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.issn=09668632&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The intense political instability that followed the failed coup in July 2016 has eased partially since the approval in a referendum in April 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency. However, the narrow referendum vic-tory and allegations of vote fraud have deepened social and political divisions.
The presidential reform, which is due to come into effect after the next presidential and parliamentary elections, in 2019, will further undermine Turkey's fragile democratic institutions and governance structures. It provides few checks on the powers of the president and moves the country closer to one-man rule.
The Justice and Development Party (AKP) has enjoyed 15 years of single-party rule, and for most of that period political and government effectiveness have improved. However, since 2013 economic policymaking institutions have become increasingly politicised. In response to the failed coup in 2016 the government has carried out an extensive purge of public-sector personnel, which risks undermining institutional capacity.
Since the failed coup Turkish foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by the domestic political goals of the incumbent president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government. This has resulted in a marked deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies.
Real GDP growth slowed from an annual average of 7.4% in 2010-15 to 3.3% in 2016, owing in part to the disruption to the economy from the failed coup, but also to faltering foreign capital inflows amid expectations of tighter global liquidity. A recovery began in the fourth quarter of 2016, supported by government stimulus measures, political pressure on banks to extend credit and a pick-up in global demand. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects growth to accelerate to an estimated 5.5% in 2017 and to average 4.4% in 2018-21.
We estimate that the Turkish lira will average TL3.61:US$1 in 2017, a fall of about 16% compared with 2016. From 2018 we forecast that the exchange rate will remain broadly stable in real terms, depreciating mildly in nominal terms, to an average of TL4.1:US$1 in 2022. In response, we expect the Central Bank of Turkey to have to keep a tight monetary policy stance throughout 2018.
We expect the current account to widen moderately and remain sufficiently large to make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates.

Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2018-22, but the country's global ranking falls by 13 places, to 58th. There is consensus among policymakers on the need to maintain macroeconomic stability. However, domestic political tension has created uncertainty about the direction of policy. Important shortcomings are a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion. The failed coup and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2018-19: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2020-22: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in a wide range of sectors, although the opening up of the energy market makes progress.
Policy towards foreign investment
2018-19: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2020-22: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2018-19: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade and tourism following the lifting of Russian sanctions.
2020-22: Customs union with the EU could be extended, but negotiations are likely to be protracted given the deterioration in Turkish-EU relations. More free-trade agreements may come into force with the EU's trading partners.
Taxes
2018-19: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Tax rates remain largely unchanged.
2020-22: A broader income tax base as exemptions and exceptions are reduced. Possible tax cuts and increased incentives.
Financing
2018-19: Monetary policy remains cautious amid concern about a possible deterioration in credit quality. Political pressure on c0mmercial banks to reduce interest rates. Renewed pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey cannot be ruled out.
2020-22: The banking system remains stable, despite some weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2018-19: Labour market remains rigid, with relatively high costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. Wage moderation after 30% minimum wage rise in 2016. Obstacles to employing foreigners have eased.
2020-22: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2018-19: Progress, albeit slow, continues on investment plans in energy, transport and communications.
2020-22: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. The construction of major airport and urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks could persist.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West, becoming a member of the Council of Europe (1949) and NATO (1952), and signing an association agreement with the then European Community (1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup at-tempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey has a unicameral parliamentary system of government, with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Under the AKP, Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019, and possibly earlier. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions will require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing political issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015 and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted long-standing institutional weaknesses, which, with the AKP's consent until 2013, allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Further politicisation of the judiciary is likely following the coup attempt. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax is 20%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2016 goods exports (fob) came to US$150.2bn and imports (fob) to US$191bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$40.9bn-a contraction from US$48.1bn in 2015. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2018-22: Political stability
The intense political instability that followed the failed coup by parts of the military in July 2016 has eased only partially since the approval in a referendum in April 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency. The narrow referendum victory and allegations of vote fraud have deepened social and political divisions. Opposition demonstrations and rallies have been peaceful, but there is a risk that future protests could result in clashes between protesters and pro-government supporters or in a government clampdown. The presidential reform, which will take effect after the next presidential and parliamentary elections, both due in 2019, will further undermine Turkey's fragile democratic institutions and governance structures. It provides few checks and balances on the powers of the president, and moves the country closer to one-man rule by the incumbent president and leader of the ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP), Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Mr Erdogan and the AKP have continued to tighten their grip on power. The state of emergency law introduced after the failed coup has been repeatedly extended on a three-month basis. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects it to remain in place for the foreseeable future because it will effectively allow Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is fully in place.
Emergency rule was initially introduced to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric, who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. However, the use of these powers has been extended to eliminate the pro-Kurdish political opposition, which the government accuses of having links with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), and to silence government critics. Almost 150,000 people-mainly in the judiciary, the military, the police, academic institutions and the media-have so far been suspended, dismissed or detained.
Security risk remains high, with negative implications for the economy. The state is seeking to end an insurgency by the PKK in the south-east of Turkey, address the domestic security risk posed by terrorist attacks by Kurdish militants and Islamic State (IS) in cities across the country, and implement military operations in Syria and Iraq against both IS and the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds. The purge of the Turkish armed forces and the police since the attempted coup has created operational capacity problems and contributed to intelligence failures that have exacerbated Turkey's domestic security issues. In the short to medium term neither the government nor the PKK appears to be interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will intensify.
Outlook for 2018-22: Election watch
The next parliamentary and presidential elections are due to be held in 2019, but they could be called earlier if Mr Erdogan decides to accelerate the transfer of executive powers to the presidency once the institutions and instruments of the new presidential system are in place. We expect Mr Erdogan to win the presidential election and remain in office with enhanced powers for at least one more five-year term, if not two (the maximum allowed), up to 2029. Although there appear to be concerns within the AKP that the party has lost support since the referendum, Mr Erdogan's popularity is still unrivalled and his party has the ability to control the election process. Moreover, the opposition is fragmented and currently appears to have no candidates capable of challenging the incumbent. In 2014 Mr Erdogan won the presidential election in the first round, with just over 50% of the vote, against a joint candidate presented by the Republican People's Party (CHP) and the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The MHP's support in parliament for the presidential reform makes it unlikely that either of the two parties will consider fielding a joint candidate at the next election.
The clampdown on the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) since mid-2015, the decision of the MHP leadership to back the presidential reform, and the hardline nationalist stance adopted by Mr Erdogan and the AKP could have a considerable effect on voting patterns at the next parliamentary election. Both the MHP and the HDP have been weakened since the 2015 election and run the risk of falling below the high 10% national vote threshold for parliamentary representation, which would boost the AKP's seat share. Under the consti-tutional changes approved in the referendum, there will be 600 seats in a much weakened parliament from the next election, up from 550 currently.
The next local elections are scheduled to take place by March 2019.
Outlook for 2018-22: International relations
There is a growing risk that the recent sharp deterioration in Turkey's relations with the EU and the US will lead to a rupture in the country's ties with its traditional Western allies, compounding concerns that under the leadership of Mr Erdogan and the AKP Turkey is pivoting eastwards. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration, including political upheaval in Europe and the US; a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey immediately after the failed coup; the US's military backing of Syrian Kurdish groups, which Turkey regards as terrorist organisations with close ties with the PKK; the Turkish government's authoritarian tendencies and its strident anti-Western rhetoric; and Turkey's forging of closer relations with Russia, China and Iran. Turkey's confrontational approach to its traditional Western allies should also be viewed in the context of Mr Erdogan's need to maintain the support of Turkey's nationalists to achieve his domestic political goals, notably his push to become president with executive powers after the presidential and parliamentary elections due by late 2019.
We expect that Turkey and its Western allies will seek to avoid a complete breakdown in relations, which could materialise if, among other things, the EU suspends Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, the migrant deal with the EU collapses, Turkey closes the Incirlik airbase to US forces or it withdraws from NATO. However, if tensions remain at current levels for a prolonged period Turkey's strategic relationships with the EU and the US are likely to suffer irreparable damage and become increasingly antagonistic and transactional.
The spillover of violence from the conflicts in neighbouring Syria and Iraq will continue to pose serious domestic and external security threats to Turkey. In addition to terrorist attacks carried out in Turkey by IS and the PKK, which has camps in the mountains in northern Iraq, Turkey now has military forces deployed in two areas in Syria, ostensibly as part of the fight against IS but also to prevent US-backed, PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurds from establishing a continuous autonomous region along Syria's northern border with Turkey. The neighbouring conflicts are also likely to continue to influence the direction of Turkey's foreign policy. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved, and Russia has lifted almost all sanctions. The level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly in relation to the conflict in Syria, where both are militarily involved but have been pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to remain largely transactional, and the risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2018-22: Policy trends
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector and its dynamic, diversified private business sector. However, the risk of an intensification of political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity could disrupt foreign capital inflows to Turkey during the forecast period. These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, but tend to be short-term and highly volatile. Faltering capital inflows put the lira under intense pressure in late 2016 and early 2017, fuelling an acceleration in inflation that prompted the Central Bank of Turkey to start tightening monetary policy in November 2016 after a prolonged period of loosening. The lira has recovered the ground that it lost in January 2017, but it remains vulnerable to sudden shifts in investor sentiment, as illustrated by short, sharp drops in value against the US dollar in July and October, probably prompted by expectations of balance-sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank) and geopolitical tensions in the neighbouring region. If the lira depreciates sharply again, an abrupt tightening of policy, which could strangle Turkey's economic recovery, may be necessary to halt the slide. However, this is not our baseline scenario, as we currently expect US monetary policy to be tightened only gradually in the remainder of 2017 and in 2018.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The current direction of policy appears to be towards a difficult balancing act between fiscal loosening and tight monetary policy while encouraging banks to lend to households and businesses.
Outlook for 2018-22: Fiscal policy
Low budget deficit- and public debt-to-GDP ratios-reflecting the impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past and major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-give the government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy. Our baseline forecast remains that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight to support investor confidence and prevent a surge in domestic demand from causing an unsustainable widening of the current-account deficit. Nevertheless, we expect the central government deficit, which captures most of the public sector, to widen from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to an average of 2.2% of GDP per year in 2017-19, before narrowing to 1.4% in 2022. Although the government debt/GDP ratio edged up slightly, to 29.2% in 2016, we expect it to decline gradually, to about 27% in 2022. The risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances cannot be ruled out.
Outlook for 2018-22: Monetary policy
Political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey to lower interest rates in order to revive economic activity has eased as the government has switched its attention to Turkey's profitable commercial banks. We expect that the central bank will have to keep its monetary policy tight in the remainder of 2017 and in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent further depreciation of the lira amid political volatility and expectations of higher US interest rates and Fed balance-sheet tapering. To do this, we expect the Turkish central bank to use a mix of interest rate rises, macroprudential measures and other policies. The bank raised most of its main policy rates between November 2016 and April 2017, and has increasingly provided funding to the banking sector at its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate, which was gradually raised by a total of 250 basis points, to 12.25% in late April, where it has remained. Since then the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system has been about 12%, compared with 7.8% in November 2016.
The central bank is seeking gradually to normalise its monetary policy frame-work to establish a single policy interest rate, which would help to improve transparency regarding monetary policy decisions. However, it is unlikely that this will happen until inflation is more firmly on a downward path towards its medium-term target of 5% and domestic political uncertainty eases.
Outlook for 2018-22: Economic growth
Real GDP growth slowed from an annual average of 7.4% in 2010-15 to 3.3% in 2016, owing in part to the disruption to the economy caused by the failed coup last July, but also to faltering foreign capital inflows amid expectations of global liquidity tightening. A recovery got under way in the fourth quarter of last year, and we expect growth to accelerate to 5.5% in 2017 and to average 4.4% in 2018-22. The rebound has been supported by government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit and a pick-up in global demand. There are downside risks to this forecast, which is predicated on the assumption that the transition to a presidential system of government in the next few years does not lead to further political instability, deterring foreign capital flows into the Turkish economy.
We expect a moderate improvement in household confidence, a recovery in employment growth and possible additional government incentives to support household spending. We forecast average real private consumption growth of 3.7% in 2017-22.
We expect government consumption growth to slow from an estimated 7% in 2017 to a still solid annual average of 6% per year in 2018-19 as the government continues to support the economy ahead of the 2019 elections. From 2020 we expect growth to be more moderate, but still solid.
The deterioration in the business environment since the attempted coup will continue to hold down private-sector fixed investment growth. However, we expect this to be offset by government investment, especially in infrastructure projects, generating real growth of 6% per year in 2017-19. In 2020-22 we forecast a gradual deceleration to annual growth of 4.8% per year, reflecting firms' response to a more moderate expansion of domestic and external demand.
We expect the lifting of Russian sanctions on Turkey, the positive effect of a weaker lira on export competitiveness and stronger growth in the main export markets, especially Europe, to drive a return to growth of exports of goods and services in 2017-22. However, we expect the perception of security risks to persist for some time, which will continue to deter some visitors to Turkey and weigh on the tourism sector. Our expectation is that a slowdown in the Chinese economy in 2018 and a cyclical downturn in the US in 2020 will dampen external demand growth in those years.
Outlook for 2018-22: Inflation
Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target-as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disin-flationary effects of low global oil prices. We expect the pass-through effects of past currency weakness and a moderate recovery in oil and other commodity prices from 2017 to keep consumer price inflation well above the official target during the first half of the forecast period. Assuming that the central bank does not loosen monetary policy too soon, we expect inflation to ease gradually, achieving the 5% target by end-2021. There are upside risks to our forecast.
Outlook for 2018-22: Exchange rates
Amid further bouts of volatility we estimate that the lira will depreciate against the US dollar in 2017, to an annual average of TL3.61:US$1, a fall of about 16% compared with 2016. From 2018 we forecast that the exchange rate will remain broadly stable in real terms, depreciating mildly in nominal terms, to an average of TL4.1:US$1 in 2022. The lira will also depreciate sharply against the euro in 2017-22. There are substantial risks to our exchange-rate forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows, as well as the impact on investor confidence of domestic political tensions and geopolitical turmoil in the region.
Outlook for 2018-22: External sector
We expect the current-account deficit to widen moderately and remain large enough, at an average of 4.4% of GDP per year in 2017-22, to make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates. Although a weaker lira and the lifting of Russian sanctions will boost Turkey's main exports, we expect this to be largely offset by the moderately higher cost of imported energy and inputs for manufactured import-intensive exports. There has been a rebound in Russian tourist arrivals in 2017, but the sector is likely to take several years to recover to its 2015 pre-crisis levels, before the resurgence of terrorist attacks and the imposition of Russian sanctions.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
Global data

US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP growth and components: Turkstat

Exchange rates and interest rates: IMF, IFS

Central government financial balance: IMF, IFS; Turkish Treasury

Country Forecast Peru September 2017

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-peru-september-2017/docview/1962096540/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: According to official figures for the first semester of 2016, 84% of the urban population had access to potable water through the public network (a further 9% are served, but water is not deemed potable). According to the World Health Statistics 2017 report published by the WHO, which for Peru contains 2015 data, maternal mortality rates have more than halved over the past 15 years (from 160 to 68 per 100,000 births), but are still above the regional average of 52. [...]the current-account deficit will remain mostly stable, averaging 2% of GDP in 2017-21. Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. [...]in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2017-21, not to the likely situation in 2021 only.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Peru&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Peru+September+2017&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2017-09-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Peru&amp;rft.issn=09669477&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Peru--highlights: Political outlook
The president, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, a former banker and experienced technocrat, is unlikely to make major changes during the remaining three years of his five-year term, which ends in July 2021. However, the president's small base of congressional support-his party holds just 17 of 130 seats-will complicate policymaking and hinder government effectiveness. In addition, a tepid economic recovery puts further pressure on the government. Institutions will remain weak and there are lingering security threats that need to be addressed, namely rising urban crime, drug-trafficking and the illicit activities of remnants of Sendero Luminoso (a terrorist group). Protests over controversial extractive projects could also affect political stability.
Peru--highlights: Demographic outlook
Population (m) 2011 2016 2021

Labour force growth   1.0 1.3
The labour force will expand more quickly than the overall population in 2017-21, thereby contributing to a demographic bonus over the next two decades. The formal economy, despite having expanded relatively firmly in recent years, will struggle to absorb new entrants to the labour market. Consequently, the level of informal employment will remain high. Underdevelopment in rural areas will encourage the trend towards urbanisation, which stands at close to 80%. There should also be further improvements in education and health indicators, in line with lower levels of poverty (which has been more than halved since 2000). However, high levels of deprivation will persist in rural and indigenous communities.
Peru--highlights: Business environment outlook

5.97 6.19 50 51 5 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Peru's business environment score rises in 2017-21, mostly owing to improvements in the regulatory environment and financing. Nonetheless, the country falls one position in The Economist Intelligence Unit's global ranking and remains in fifth place in the regional ranking. Peru's key strengths are its openness to foreign trade-secured by multiple free-trade agreements-and its prudent macroeconomic management. The business-friendly approach that existed during the historical period (2012-16) will remain in place under Mr Kuczynski, and is likely to be deepened and enhanced. Infrastructure will improve, although significant gaps will remain. Peru's labour market, albeit improving, will remain the weakest aspect of the business environment. Corruption and weak institutions will also prove a weakness.

GDP growth will average 3.4% in 2017-21, driven by a moderate recovery in investment. In the longer term, growth will hinge more on productivity improvements, as commodity prices will be lower than during the 2004-12 boom. Social and political pressure for higher public spending will persist, but the fiscal accounts will remain prudently managed and characterised by one of the lowest debt stocks in the region. The stable macroeconomic outlook will also be underpinned by low inflation and a manageable current-account deficit.

Peru is a fairly small market and opportunities will remain restricted by low purchasing power measured in terms of GDP per head, as well as by high levels of poverty and inequality. That said, two decades of strong economic growth have gradually led to the emergence of a growing middle class, notably in the capital, Lima. Rising demand from lower-income districts has led to a transformation in consumer patterns. Although progress will be gradual (constrained by still low disposable incomes among much of the population), we expect this trend to continue in 2017-21. Public investment in infrastructure will support greater integration of outlying regions.
Peru--highlights: Long-term outlook
  2017-30 2031-50 2017-50

Growth of real GDP per head 2.7 2.5 2.6
Growth of real GDP 3.8 3.1 3.4

Growth in Peru's real GDP per head is forecast to slow from an annual average of 2.7% in 2017-30 to 2.5% in 2031-50. The weak institutional environment and widespread income and regional inequalities will continue to hold back stronger growth. The demographic bonus will have run its course by the mid-2030s, weighing on total GDP growth. At the same time, education levels will remain low, with only marginal progress forecast. Low inflation and a stable currency will contribute to macroeconomic stability. Abundant opportunities in energy, mining and infrastructure will continue to attract investment. Nevertheless, Peru will remain vulnerable to fluctuations in external demand and the prices of commodities.

Background: More than 12 years of military rule ended in 1980. Following a decade of economic and social instability, the government of Alberto Fujimori (1990-2000) ended hyperinflation, advanced reforms to liberalise the economy and defeated the Maoist Sendero Luminoso insurgency. However, Mr Fujimori subverted Peru's democratic institutions and committed grave human rights abuses. His government collapsed over a corruption scandal. The subsequent governments have been successful in consolidating macroeconomic stability, but have largely overlooked the structural reforms required to raise productivity levels. The current president, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, took office in July 2016. His term runs to July 2021.
Political structure: The 1993 constitution established a presidential regime with a powerful executive, elected for five years. Consecutive presidential re-election is not permitted. A 130-member unicameral legislature, elected at the same time as the president, also sits for five years. The government is decentralising revenue and responsibility to the 25 regions (including the constitutional province of Callao).
Policy issues: The Economist Intelligence Unit assumes that there will be continuity of orthodox economic policies and that the business environment will remain attractive. Mr Kuczynski is a former World Bank economist and mining minister, and we expect gradual progress on structural reform under his government. The public education and healthcare systems will continue to underperform, despite increases in funding. The government will also increase spending on social programmes to reduce poverty levels. Despite government involvement in the market, private investment in transport, energy and water infrastructure will remain strong. Bilateral free-trade agreements with Peru's main trading partners-including the US, China and the EU-as well as initiatives within Latin America, will help to keep investment and trade flows strong in 2017-21.
Taxation: The corporate income-tax rate is 29.5% (mining companies that do not benefit from tax-stability contracts pay additional taxes). Dividends and other profit distribution schemes are taxed at 5%. Branch-profit tax is levied at 30% and remittance tax at 10%.Interest paid abroad stands at 5%.
Foreign trade: Tariffs are levied on imports at either 0%, 6% or 11%. The World Bank's calculation of the average effective tariff was 1.4% in 2014. Most non-tariff barriers have been eliminated. In 2016 merchandise export earnings increased by 8%, to US$37bn, whereas the import bill declined by 6%, to US$35.1bn.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
The president, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, of the centre-right Peruanos por el Kambio (PPK), started the second year of a five-year term in July. Although PPK is the second largest bloc in Congress, it holds just 17 of the 130 seats in the legis-lature. PPK has so far had trouble advancing Mr Kuczynksi's legislative agenda, as it has often been obstructed by the right-wing Fuerza Popular (FP), which holds an outright congressional majority, with 71 seats. FP is led by Keiko Fujimori, who lost a bitterly contested presidential run-off election to Mr Kuczynski in June 2016 by a margin of 41,000 votes (17m valid votes were cast). Although hostilities have eased following a July 2017 meeting between Mr Kuczynski and Ms Fujimori, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects relations to remain fraught. The meeting with Ms Fujimori was followed by similar meetings with the other parties represented in Congress, including the left-wing Frente Amplio (FA), which holds ten seats, the centrist Alianza para el Progreso (nine seats), the centre-right Acción Popular (five seats) and the centre-left Partido Aprista Peruano (five seats). The latter has regularly voted with FP, whereas the FA and the others have been less co-operative. In the past, congress-sional blocs in Peru's congress have often fragmented, and 13 lawmakers have already left their original blocs since the start of Mr Kuczynski's term. They are currently unaffiliated, as they are banned from forming new blocs or joining existing ones due to an August 2016 law pushed through by FP. Of the 13, ten are former members of the FA (which split in July), two originate from the FP bloc and one was a PPK member. The 2016 law has been legally challenged, and we expect the Constitutional Court to declare it unconstitutional.

Political outlook: Political stability
The president, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski of the centre-right Peruanos Por el Kambio (PPK), has now entered the second of his five-year term (ending July 2021) and will continue to face a challenging political environment, as his party holds just 17 seats in the 130-seat unicameral Congress. He will need to negotiate with the opposition to pass legislation-in particular, the right-wing Fuerza Popular (FP), which holds a majority, with 71 seats. FP has not hesitated to flex its legislative muscles, taking advantage of the Peruvian legislature's power to force ministerial resignations with a simple majority of 66 votes. FP has now thrice ejected ministers, with the last ousting coming in June. FP's leader, Keiko Fujimori, has faced some internal criticism for her hard opposition, but has maintained party discipline, in part thanks to meeting with Mr Kuczynski in mid-July. Since then, tension has eased and, as a show of good faith, FP confirmed the government's candidate for the post of comptroller-general. On July 27th Congress voted on its leadership positions for the 2017-18 term, with an FP congressman, Luis Galarreta, appointed speaker. Mr Galarreta has been a harsh critic of Mr Kuczynski, but has promised to put partisanship aside amid ongoing negotiations with the newly-appointed economy minister, Fernando Zavala, to boost public and private investment in the economy. Independent of short-term relations, we expect FP's opposition to seriously hamper Mr Kuczynski's ability to carry out policy initiatives.
When ousting Mr Kuczynski's three ministers, FP legislators cited potential (currently unsubstantiated) acts of corruption. Investigations into malfeasance have paralysed progress on large public works projects and landed prominent politicians, including the former president, Ollanta Humala (2011-16), in prison. On August 4th Mr Humala and his wife Nadine Heredia lost an appeal that would have led to their release from pre-trial detention. The couple continue to deny accusations of criminal misconduct. Corruption will continue to be a key issue, as opinion polls show widespread popular anger over graft. Despite FP's best efforts to stay clear of perceptions of corruption, party members are at risk of being implicated in the Odebrecht money-laundering and bribery scandal. In late August prosecutors confirmed that they were investigating Ms Fujimori and her links to alleged money laundering operations. Ms Fujimori denies any wrongdoing, but she risks losing popularity and siling the party's image.
Social conflict resulting from impoverished rural and indigenous communities' opposition to extractive projects poses an ongoing latent risk, given economic dependence on mining. Weak institutions will allow corruption and mismanagement to endure, especially at the local level. Police corruption and institutional weaknesses in the legal system will obstruct progress, as will the illicit drugs trade (Peru is a major coca producer).
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Mr Kuczynski's government will continue to adhere to the market-friendly policies that have guided Peru since 1990. The Kuczynski administration's stated goal is to promote policies to boost economic growth by unlocking investments-particularly in infrastructure-broadening the tax base, and improving the quality and scope of public services.
Given Peru's constitutionally weak presidency and the fact that Mr Kuczynski's modernising and infrastructure upgrade agenda require congressional approval, the government's relationship with Congress is crucial for success. So far, governability has been weak owing to fraught relations with the FP. Opposition lawmakers have triggered the resignation of three Cabinet ministers by taking advantage of the Peruvian legislature's power to force ministerial resignations with a simple majority of 66 votes. Under the constitution, Mr Kuczynski can counter such a vote against a single minister by demanding a vote of confidence in his full cabinet. Two failed votes of confidence in his cabinet trigger the dissolution of Congress and "snap" legislative elections. Mr Kuczynski threatened to take this route during the removal process of all three of his ousted ministers, but FP did not flinch and the president backed down. Given Mr Kuczynski's similarly low popularity ratings in comparison to the opposition and his party's low presence in many regions of the country, it is unlikely that he would increase his parliamentary representation if an election were held. As such, the threat of forcing "snap" legislative elections is not a credible one from Mr Kuczynski. The possibility of a game of brinkmanship going awry, however, cannot be discounted. Regardless, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects relations to remain fraught, impeding government effectiveness.
Despite its poor relations with Congress, the administration was able to secure congressional approval for special powers to rule by decree between September 2016 and January 2017. It produced 112 decrees across five broad areas-administrative reform, anti-corruption, public security, economic reform, and water and sanitation measures. FP has so far also been co-operative on recon-struction plans in the wake of flooding that devastated infrastructure across the country in the first quarter of 2017. The reconstruction effort is expected to cost US$6.2bn between 2018 and 2021. In August Congress approved a loosening on the fiscal rule, allowing the government to widen the non-financial public deficit to 3.5% of GDP in 2018 (albeit before narrowing it gradually back to 1% by 2021). Nonetheless, Mr Kuczynski's ambitious infra-structure plans must be approved by an obstructive legislature. Indeed, two of the ejected ministers were dismissed owing to a now-scrapped infrastructure project.
Given congressional resistance, Mr Kuczynski will fare better when re-organising the executive's own internal bureaucratic processes. So far, the presi-dent has re-structured procedures at a variety of government offices. Crucially, and in a bid to meet its infrastructure investment pledges, the administration streamlined approval procedures, replacing the Sistema Nacional de Inversión Pública, the national public investment system, with a new body, Invierte.pe (capital expenditure and budget execution rates for public works have since remained sluggish). Despite these reforms, government effectiveness will continue to be hampered by longstanding institutional problems, chiefly the ineffectiveness of bureaucracy, especially at the sub-national level. To address this, the Kuczynski administration has moved to strengthen the decentralisation process, instituting quarterly meetings with the Asamblea Nacional de Gobiernos Regionales, which brings together the country's 25 governors, and the Asociación de Municipalidades del Perú, which unites more than 1,800 mayors.
The administration's efforts to empower regional governments have been hampered by the high level of corruption at the sub-national levels. Four sitting governors were arrested on corruption charges in the 18 months ending in September 2017, with two now in prison, and two released and allowed to retake office. Six former governors were in prison as at September 2017. Corruption has also hampered national government effectiveness, with the case surrounding Odebrecht, a Brazilian firm that admitted to bribery in Peru during 2004-15. The immediate result was the cancellation of a US$5bn gas pipeline project, but the scandal's breadth and unpredictability heightens political uncertainty, as there is a risk that members of both the opposition and the government will be implicated. So far, the investigation has resulted in an arrest warrant against a former president, Alejandro Toledo (2001-06), and the arrest of another former president, Ollanta Humala (2011-16), and his wife, Nadine Herrera. Mr Toledo, for whom Mr Kuczynski served as both economy minister (2004-05) and prime minister (2005-06), remains a fugitive in the US. Mr Humala and Ms Heredia are in pre-trial detention. The judiciary has also initiated investigations against another former president, Alan García (1985-90, 2006-11) and the FP leader, Keiko Fujimori. Messrs Toledo, García and Humala deny all charges, as do Mses Herrera and Fujimori.
Corruption continues to be a serious problem in many government agencies. Using his special legislative powers in 2016, Mr Kuczynski approved nine legis-lative decrees on corruption, which mandate restructuring the system governing ad-hoc prosecutors, implementing a whistle-blower law to protect people who denounce corruption, strengthening data-protection laws, and creating a registry of attorneys sentenced or fined for violations. However, the judiciary will remain slow, opaque, underfunded and riddled with a culture of bribery and political manipulation. The Kuczynski administration proposed legislation in July 2017 to restructure the Consejo Nacional de la Magistatura, which selects and evaluates judges and prosecutors, but the bill met with strong opposition from the judiciary and a judicial reform is unlikely in the coming months. Although high-level cases are usually successfully prosecuted, there is nevertheless a high degree of tolerance of corruption by the political establishment as a whole, as well as close links between politicians and special interest groups.
Political outlook: Election watch
Presidential and congressional elections, held every five years, last took place in mid-2016. The next elections are municipal and regional polls in October 2018; presidential and legislative elections will next be held in mid-2021; Mr Kuczynski will not be in the running for the presidency, as consecutive re-election is prohibited. Congress is currently in the process of discussing bills on electoral reform. There is broad consensus among legislators regarding the need for changes to electoral rules, but agreements are currently far off. Peru currently lacks a formal nationwide party structure, and local-level parties tend to have little affiliation with national parties, leading to disassociation between the results of local and national elections. The elections in 2021 are likely to see Ms Fujimori as the presidential candidate for FP, despite increasingly clear ambitions for party leadership on the part of her brother, Kenji. Verónika Mendoza of the left-wing Nuevo Perú (formerly of the left-wing Frente Amplio coalition), who came third in the first round of the presidential race in 2016, will also feature. However, the lack of party structures facilitates the rapid ascent of personalities and political outsiders.
Political outlook: Key players to watch
Pedro Pablo Kuczynski
The president, Mr Kuczynski, scored a narrow victory over a former congresswoman, Keiko Fujimori, in the 2016 election, winning by a margin of around 41,000 votes. Mr Kuczynski, is a former banker and experienced technocrat who served as minister of economy and finance, and as cabinet chief, during the term of a former president, Alejandro Toledo (2001-06). He also held the post of minister for energy and mines in the 1980s, before spending decades in the private sector. Mr Kuczynski's first year in office was plagued by problems, including a rocky relationship with congress and massive flooding during the first quarter of 2017. He started his government with an approval rating of around 60% and finished his first year in office at around 30%.
Keiko Fujimori
Ms Fujimori narrowly lost to Mr Kuczynski in the June 2016 presidential election, her second defeat in a presidential contest (she lost to Ollanta Humala in 2011). This loss was partly due to a concerted effort by Ms Fujimori's opponents to keep her from office, stemming from fears that her government would mark a return to the excesses of the regime of her father, a former president, Alberto Fujimori (1990-2000), who is currently serving a 25-year sentence (from 2009) for human rights violations and corruption. Ms Fujimori has consolidated her political party, Fuerza Popular (FP), as the principal opposition. She has faced some internal dissidence in FP owing to her insistence on party discipline and her strong opposition to Mr Kuczynski, but remains the undisputed leader of FP. Ms Fujimori will continue to command significant power to guide policy in Peru, despite her election loss. She is likely to stage a third bid for the presidency in 2021.
Kenji Fujimori
The younger brother of Keiko Fujimori, Mr Fujimori is currently in his second term in Congress. A popular figure, he received a record number of votes in the 2011 and 2016 congressional elections. Mr Fujimori has emerged as a de facto leader of the internal opposition to Ms Fujimori within FP. He has often clashed with FP's congressional leaders regarding the party's militant opposition to Mr Kuczynski. His sister has so far re-asserted control (she suspended him from the FP congressional caucus for 60 days in July 2017). However, Mr Fujimori has received the support of Alberto Fujimori and matched his sister's approval ratings in August 2017. He will remain a key figure in Peruvian politics.
Luis Galarreta
Mr Galarreta, serving his third five-year term in Congress representing the capital, Lima, was elected speaker of Congress for the 2017-2018 legislative year. Although in his third term as congressman, Mr Galarreta is new to the FP caucus. He was elected on an FP ticket in 2016, but first came to Congress in 2006 on a coalition ticket. He was re-elected in 2011 as part of a coalition led by Mr Kuczynski. This political past helps cast Mr Galarreta as a better consensus-builder than his predecessor, an FP congresswoman, Luz Salgado. Mr Galarreta has pledged to work with the administration to find common ground to avoid legislative gridlock.
Verónika Mendoza
Ms Mendoza came third in the 2016 presidential race as head of the left-wing Frente Amplio (FA). She received 19% of the vote and the FA secured 20 seats in Congress, making it the second largest bloc. However, the FA proved incapable of remaining united in Congress, and split in two in July 2017. Ten lawmakers followed Ms Mendoza into a new party, Nuevo Perú, while ten remained in the FA under the leadership of Marco Arana, a congressman who represents the region of Cajamarca. Ms Mendoza and Mr Arana are bitter rivals, despite the fact that he ran as her vice presidential candidate. Ms Mendoza's relevance going forward will hinge on Nuevo Perú securing the signatures required-approximately 750,000-to officially register and be able to field candidates in the 2018 subnational and 2021 national elections.
Political outlook: International relations
Peru will continue to support regional integration efforts, such as the Pacific Alliance, an economic integration pact that also includes Colombia, Chile and Mexico, and others implemented under the Union of South American Nations (Unasur). Members of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay; Venezuela was suspended in 2016) have stated a desire for greater integration with the Pacific Alliance, but we do not currently forecast any progress in 2017-21.
In May Peru and another ten of the 12 signatories of the Trans-Pacific Partnership announced their intention to move ahead despite the US's exit from the trade pact, but short-term progress is unlikely. Instead, bilateral agree-ments will become the focus of Peruvian trade policy. Peru currently has 16 trade deals in place, covering nearly all of the world's largest economies, including Canada, China, the EU, Japan, South Korea and the US. The government is now in advanced talks with India and Australia. A deal with Australia may come through the Pacific Alliance, as the members have announced that trade talks will begin with Australia, Canada, New Zealand and Singapore in September as part of those countries' accession to the group as associate members (of the four, Peru lacks a bilateral free-trade agreement with only Australia).

Working-age population will outstrip overall population growth
Population growth slowed to 1.1% a year in 2012-16, down from 2.2% in the 1980s and 2% in the 1990s, owing to migration abroad and a declining birth rate. Growth will pick-up slightly in 2017-21, to 1.2%, and will remain above the global average, reflecting high birth rates among lower income households and advances in healthcare (reflected in outcomes including lower infant mortality). The population will remain younger than in most industrialised countries. A modest rise in the old-age dependency ratio-the proportion of the population above working age-will be more than offset by a decline in the young-age dependency ratio in the medium term. The number of people of working age will therefore continue to rise faster than the growth of the population as a whole, providing a demographic bonus to the economy.
As with many Latin American countries, Peru has experienced rapid urban-isation in recent decades. In 2015, according to the latest data estimation available from the national statistics institute, 77% of the total population lived in cities, with 80% of those living in Lima, the capital. Urbanisation will continue to rise during the forecast period as Peruvians seek better living and employment conditions. Informal employment, which is estimated to account for over 70% of the economically active population, will remain high, notably in the construction and retail sectors. Informal unemployment is expected to decline only gradually, helped by government efforts to ease labour costs for businesses via tax simplification and subsidies, but will remain high by international standards. The unemployment rate reached a record low of 6% in 2013, but has been slowly creeping up since then as the economy has cooled. The level reached 7% in the May-July 2017 rolling quarter. Although still relatively low, this masks high levels of underemployment, which affects as much as 35% of those employed, and is tied to a mismatch between labour market demands and the focus and quality of education.
Demographic indicators to improve but from a low base
Although Peru's demographic indicators will make progress in the next decade-as education standards rise, nutrition improves, and access to safe water and sanitation is expanded-they will remain relatively poor. Poverty levels have declined significantly in the past decade. The proportion of the population living in poverty fell from around 55% in 2000 to 20.7% in 2016. However, there are marked regional disparities, with 44% of the population in rural areas still living below the poverty line in 2016 (down from 74% in 2007). According to official figures for the first semester of 2016, 84% of the urban population had access to potable water through the public network (a further 9% are served, but water is not deemed potable). Meanwhile, only 61% of the rural population is reached by the public network, and only 15% of those served receive potable water. The extension of the water and sanitation network will remain one of the highest public healthcare priorities and will continue to receive substantial investment in the forecast period, as the government has planned large expenses in 2018-21.
Health status indicators have improved significantly in recent decades, although regional variations in infant and maternal mortality rates are pronounced. Average life expectancy at birth has risen to 75.5 years, according to the World Health Organisation (WHO); its figures differ from the local-source data on which The Economist Intelligence Unit's current forecasts are based. According to the World Health Statistics 2017 report published by the WHO, which for Peru contains 2015 data, maternal mortality rates have more than halved over the past 15 years (from 160 to 68 per 100,000 births), but are still above the regional average of 52. The mortality rate of children under five has been on a declining trend, reaching 16.9 per 1,000 births in 2015 (down from 40 in 2000), although it remains a serious problem, especially in the more remote rural districts. Latest cause-of-death data (2014) show malignant tumours are the single highest cause of mortality, followed by influenza and pneumonia. Cardiovascular diseases and diabetes also rank high amongst the main sources of mortality. Our projections assume that there will be some progress in health statistics in 2017-21 but that Peru will continue to lag behind most other countries in the region.
