Peru's business environment rankings remain broadly stable for the 2017-21 forecast period: the country falls to 51st place globally (from 50th in 2012-16), despite a slight increase in score, and remains in fifth place regionally. Peru's ranking will be constrained by limited market opportunities, which will worsen owing to slower economic growth, and by its labour market score, which, despite some improvement, remains low. The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline scenario assumes that the president, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, who started the second of his five years in office in July 2017, will continue with orthodox macroeconomic policies and prudent fiscal management during his five-year term. There will be no significant changes to the existing business-friendly approach, but a weak global climate for Peru's principal exports, coupled with persistent difficulties in reducing bureaucracy and corruption, mean that the country slips in the global rankings.
Peru will be open to trade and will have a stable macroeconomic outlook
Peru's key strengths in the forecast period will be its stable macroeconomic environment and openness towards foreign trade and investment, secured by free-trade agreements (FTAs) with most of the world's major economies. Regionally, Peru is part of the Pacific Alliance, an economic integration pact that also includes Colombia, Chile and Mexico. As of May 2016, 92% of the goods traded between the Pacific Alliance countries are tariff-free (100% of goods will be tariff-free by 2033). Peru was also part of the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) negotiations, and has remained in the so-called TPP11 grouping following the US's withdrawal. Economic growth in 2017-21, although not reaching the levels of 2006-2011, will still be solid, averaging 3.4% annually, and above the Latin American average. We anticipate that the Kuczynski administration will upgrade Peru's infrastructure as a result of rising public spending and investment through public-private partnerships (PPPs). However, significant gaps will persist, owing to weak project execution by the public sector, preventing a more substantial rise in Peru's infrastructure ranking. Peru's rigid labour market and weak institutions are expected to remain the weakest aspects of the business environment in the outlook period.
Business environment outlook: Peru's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Reforms to reduce some taxes and streamline bureaucracy are introduced by the government.
2019-21: Government to allow increased private participation in state-run firms, including electricity and water utilities. Policies to induce formalisation in small and medium-sized enterprises expected.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Changes to regulations in order to stimulate foreign investment in value-added mining projects and infrastructure.
2019-21: Foreign investment in infrastructure strengthens, primarily in transportation and telecommunications. Investment picks up in mining, although on a smaller scale than in the past.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Consolidation of the Pacific Alliance, an integration project that also includes Chile, Colombia and Mexico, boosts trade and investment flows.
2019-21: Free-trade agreements signed with Turkey, India and Australia. Companies benefit from conclusion of Trade in Services Agreement under negotiation by 52 countries.
Taxes
2017-18: Corporate income tax increased from 28% to 29.5% and taxes on dividends cut from 6.8% to 5%. Increasing use of "public works for taxes" schemes, allowing companies to invest part of their tax bill in transport and social infrastructure.
2019-21: Further tax breaks to boost labour market formality. Tax credits for large firms that reinvest profits.
Financing
2017-18: Merger with Colombian, Chilean and Mexican stockmarkets deepens capital markets, as does legislation from late 2015 exempting capital gains tax on the sale of shares until 2018 to increase stockmarket liquidity. Sovereign bonds can now be settled through Euroclear, a platform allowing easier access to international finance. Private firms will follow suit.
2019-21: Deeper penetration of the financial system as new mechanisms, such as an electronic money platform, take hold.
The labour market
2017-18: Labour rigidity remains a serious problem, despite government measures to reduce regulation.
2019-21: Government continues the use of tax incentives in an attempt to increase formality in the labour market to 60%, up from 27% in July 2017. Wages increase in key public sectors, including healthcare, the police force and schools.
Infrastructure
2017-18: The government's infrastructure plan starts to gain steam, with a focus on roadways and hydraulic structures. Broadband penetration increases. New thermal and hydroelectric plants provide sizeable power surplus, opening the way for electricity exports.
2019-21: Government ramps up investment to provide universal coverage of water and sewerage systems. Work launched on third and fourth lines of metro system in the capital, Lima. Gasoducto del Sur Peruano pipeline completed.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
7.8 8.0 22 14 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Macroeconomic environment will remain attractive to investors
Peru's macroeconomic environment will remain one of the most attractive features of the business environment in 2017-21, with the score increasing slightly. GDP expanded by 4% in 2016, but growth will slow to 2.5% in 2017 owing to natural disasters, depressed consumption and falling investment. We expect the economy to recover in 2018, expanding by 3.6%, supported by fiscal expansion, and recovering investment and private consumption.
Our baseline scenario continues to be that the institutional underpinnings of macroeconomic and fiscal policy will remain solid. The inflation rate was 3.2% in August, slightly above the target range of 1-3% set by the Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (BCRP, the central bank) for the year. However, the result was influenced by the flooding that struck the country at the start of the year, and we expect end-2017 inflation to fall into the target range. We expect inflation to average 2.7% in 2018-21, assuming moderate demand pressures and a gentle rate of nominal currency depreciation. The Kuczynski administration will maintain a prudent fiscal policy. The government recently announced that it has widened its 2018 target for the non-financial public-sector deficit to 3.5% of GDP, to accommodate its ambitious infrastructure plans. The administration foresees deficits narrowing to 1% of GDP by 2021. We do not expect such an improve-ment, but do expect a narrowing of the deficit to 1.4% of GDP by 2021. Although the government will take advantage of the low public debt/GDP ratio (24% in 2016) to pursue debt-fuelled spending, we do not expect the debt/GDP ratio to exceed 30% in 2017-21.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
5.0 5.5 51 53 7 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The score for policy towards private enterprise and competition improves during the outlook period, although Peru's ranking falls both at the global and regional level, as conditions will improve more rapidly in other countries. Legislation approved in December 2016 strengthened the Instituto Nacional de Defensa de la Competencia y de la Protección de la Propiedad Intelectual (Indecopi), which oversees issues relating to competition and intellectual property rights, although new laws were approved to enhance the state's capacity to expropriate land required for public works. Additional legislation to enhance expropriation powers was submitted by July, but had not been debated in Congress by September. However, Mr Kuczynski's regulatory overhaul will have to contend with an obstructionist Congress in which the government only holds 17 of 130 seats. This raises the risk that the government will water down proposed reforms-or withdraw them entirely.
Government looks to re-organise state-run companies and open private partnerships
The Kuczynski administration has not modified the approach to public companies adopted by the previous three administrations. It does not plan on allowing private participation in emblematic state-owned firms, including Petróleos del Perú (Petroperú, the state oil company) or the Servicio de Agua Potable y Alcantarillado de Lima, which provides water and sanitation to residents of the capital city. However, the administration, did make some key decisions regarding Petroperú: in January 2017 it published legislation related to the corporate reorganisation of the company and approved a debt strategy for the US$5.4bn modernisation of the company's flagship refinery, Talara, on the northern coast. As part of this, in May the company placed US$2bn in bonds. Although not considering privatisation of assets, the administration announced the possibility of bringing in a private partner for management of the 1,100-km northern oil pipeline, which is operated by Petroperú but was closed in February 2016 for repairs. The pipeline remains closed as at September 2017.
The government has also taken action on the two upstream blocks in which Petroperú is involved. In November 2016 the administration published a decree formalising an agreement in which Argentina-based GeoPark took a 75% stake in Block 64 in the northern jungle. Production of approximately 7,000 barrels/day of light crude is scheduled to begin in 2019. In April 2017 Petroperú began negotiations on an agreement with Canada's Frontera Energy regarding Block 192 in the northern jungle. Frontera was awarded a temporary concession in August 2015 to operate the block, but this will expire in August 2018, at which point responsibility for the block will revert to Petroperú. However, Petroperú will seek a similar agreement to that reached with GeoPark before then.
The state continues to implement reforms to increase competition and improve the business environment. It approved 16 legislative decrees for bureaucratic simplification in the final quarter of 2016. In addition to overhauling Indecopi in December 2016, the administration improved legislation for consumer defence and protection, and implemented changes to regulations related to obtaining an operating license. It currently takes 26 days to start a business, according to the World Bank's Doing Business 2017 report.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.9 7.3 39 36 5 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Peru will retain its support of foreign investment
Peru's score for policy towards foreign investment improves in 2017-21, and Peru climbs three positions in the global ranking, to 36th place. The country's regional ranking remains unchanged. The government will adhere to orthodox macroeconomic policies, and there is little risk of a change in its largely open policy and attitude towards foreign capital. Peru's investment-grade credit rating and the availability of investment-protection schemes (resulting from a wide array of FTAs) will sustain foreign investor confidence.
Major risks to foreign investment exist in both mining and the oil and gas sector, in which social and environmental concerns have paralysed a significant number of projects. To minimise social conflict around extractive projects legislation enacted in September 2011 created a framework for consulting indigenous communities before extractive and public-works projects take place. The process, known as consulta previa, means that indigenous communities must be consulted formally by the state instead of project sponsors, which had been the approach under the previous system. The Ministry of Culture oversees the organisation of the consultations, in co-ordination with the responsible sector. To better manage the socio-economic impact, Mr Kuczynski has unveiled a social development fund that will channel public funds towards providing basic services in areas where mining projects will be developed. In July the state Ombudsman's Office, which monitors conflicts, reported 55 active social conflicts involving mining projects and 11 involving oil and gas projects. The government calculates that social conflict and bureaucracy related to mining and energy projects are currently blocking expected foreign direct investment worth a total of around US$20bn. In July the state oil and gas promotion agency, Perupetro, reported that the country had 24 blocks under exploration (down from 36 a year earlier). Operations of seven of the 24 are stalled because of social protests, and a further five have been delayed by slow approval of environmental permits. Indeed, the government considers environmental rules too complex; in late 2016 it modified the rules regarding forestry concessions to facilitate investment, in addition to announcing changes at the government bureau in charge of reviewing environmental-impact assessments for all sectors, including mining and energy.
Administrative barriers around land use and expropriations have also meant delays in infrastructure works, which often rely on PPP schemes with foreign companies, owing to their complexity and size. The administration considers US$18bn in investment, including the US$6bn Line 2 of the Lima Metro and US$1.2bn second runaway at Lima's international airport, to be held-up by regulations regarding expropriation and land use. New rules for expropriations were approved in August 2015, guaranteeing the market value of the expropriated property and mandating an additional 10% to be paid on top of this sum, but delays continue. The administration proposed additional modifications in July, but Congress has yet to debate the bill related to these.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
8.7 8.2 28 39 2 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The score for foreign trade and exchange controls falls in 2017-21 and Peru loses ground in the global and regional rankings. The reduced score is due to the county's relative underperformance (compared with countries of a similar size) in foreign trade as the country adapts to lower prices and reduced output growth of its mineral exports. Transactions on the current and capital accounts will remain free from restrictions, and the structural strength of the external position virtually eliminates the threat of exchange controls being imposed. The BCRP will continue to tweak reserve requirements on US dollar deposits and credit from abroad, as well as intervening actively in the currency markets, in order to manage liquidity and stem those financial foreign-exchange inflows that could easily be reversed. The currency has been fully convertible since 1990. Trade as a share of GDP has declined as export earnings have fallen in line with global commodity prices. Peru has a tripartite tariff structure, with 70.4% of items entering tariff-free, and the remaining items paying a tariff of either 6% (in the case of 20.8% of goods) or 11% (8.8% of goods).
Trade liberalisation will remain a priority in 2017-21
Trade liberalisation has been one of the pillars of Peru's economic strategy since implementation of a watershed FTA with the US in February 2009. The government implemented the Pacific Alliance's trade protocol in May 2016, making 92% of goods entering from Colombia, Chile and Mexico tariff-free (the remaining tariffs will be eliminated over a 17-year period). In addition, Peru has 15 FTAs in place, the most recent of which, with Honduras, was implemented this year. The government began bilateral trade negotiations with Australia in July and with India in August, and is scheduled to begin talks with Indonesia in November. The administration has held five rounds of negotiations with Turkey, but the process has been stalled since early 2016. Peru remains engaged in two of the world's largest potential agreements, including the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA), which involves more than 50 World Trade Organisation members, and the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), which was signed in February 2016, but cast in doubt when the US pulled out in January 2017. Despite protectionist rhetoric from the US, we do not expect Peru to be targeted by potential US protectionist measures The remaining 11 countries that signed the TPP held their first meeting in Japan in July to look for pathways forward without US participation.
There is only a low risk that the government will introduce non-tariff trade barriers during the forecast period, although regulatory issues could come into play. Indecopi currently has 11 anti-dumping measures in place, including five on products from China, two each on products from Argentina and the US, and one each on products from India and Pakistan. Concerns remain about legislation prohibiting imports of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) for ten years, starting in 2013. In July 2016 the government began to publish lists of GMOs that were not allowed into Peru. There have also been objections to legislation requiring labelling on packaged snack food, which came into force in May. In July Mr Kuczynski vetoed legislation that would have prohibited the use of powdered milk in finished dairy products.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
5.6 5.9 52 51 5 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Additional tax reforms could be in store
The score in this category improves slightly in the forecast period, and Peru improves its position in both the global and regional rankings. The Kuczynski administration changed tax legislation in December 2016, increasing the corporate income rate to 29.5% and rolling back a law approved by the previous administration in 2015 that progressively lowered the rate, which was scheduled to fall to 27% in 2017 and to 26% in 2019. The government also set the tax on dividend payments at 5% (down from 6.5%) and in January 2017 announced that it would lower the value-added tax (VAT) rate by 1 percentage point, to 17%, as of July 1st. That reduction was contingent upon VAT collections reaching 7.2% of GDP by May, which did not happen. The administration hopes to implement the reduction in 2018. A 5% capital gains tax has been suspended until end-2019, when it will come under review.
The government plans to widen the tax base by providing incentives to companies, simplifying payment procedures and cracking down on tax evasion. To this end, in December 2016 it created new and lower tax brackets for small and medium-sized companies, in addition to providing relief on back taxes. Tax revenue was 14% of GDP in 2016, down from 15.2% the previous year. In nominal terms, tax collection was down by 2.3% year on year in January-July 2017.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.3 6.6 36 38 4 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Prudential indicators show that the banking sector remains solid
The score in this category improves slightly in 2017-21, owing to an improvement in the availability of medium-term financing. Despite this, Peru falls two positions in the global ranking and remains in fourth spot regionally. The sector's balance sheet is strong-the overall non-performing loan ratio has remained relatively stable in recent years, at between 1.5% and 3%. The capital adequacy ratio is well above the legal minimum, and liquidity levels are adequate. Capital markets are shallow but growing, and Peruvian companies with solid credit ratings will continue to have ample access to long-term finance through a multitude of channels such as stock issues, bonds and bank loans. Obtaining foreign financing will be easier in the future, as a recent sovereign bond issuance was made available to foreign investors through Euroclear, a clearing house designed to improve access and security for investors. The government and financial authorities have stated that they expect the scheme will be used by private firms in the future.
The national roll-out in 2016 of a new single electronic money platform, which involves all financial institutions and telecommunications providers, should increase the penetration of the banking system, incorporating new clients into the system and encouraging banks to offer new financial products for small and medium-sized enterprises where financial inclusion is lowest.
Further progress expected on stockmarket integration
The Bolsa de Valores de Lima (the Lima stock exchange) will continue its integration into the Mercado Integrado Latinoamericano (the Latin American Integrated Market)-a joint initiative of the bourses of Peru, Colombia, Chile and Mexico-to become a single unified equity and securities exchange. Regulatory issues (such as harmonising tax rules) mean that integration is expected to proceed slowly, but it will deepen Peru's shallow capital markets.
Large domestic corporations currently enjoy captive demand for their securities from three main institutional investors: the Administradoras de Fondos de Pensiones (AFPs, private pension funds), insurance companies and mutual funds. Deeper capital markets would boost retail trading, introducing some dynamism. Issuance will continue to grow in the forecast period to include mid-sized companies-allowing equity finance to become a source of capital for a wider range of companies than the present limited group of blue-chip businesses-but a weak corporate governance culture and concerns over public information disclosure will remain the main restriction to issuance of shares.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
5.0 5.5 74 69 9 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The labour market will remain an area of weakness, weighing on Peru's score
Although Peru's labour market will remain one of the weakest aspects of the business environment, the score increases in 2017-21, lifting the country in the global rankings (Peru's regional ranking remains unchanged). The rigidity of Peru's labour regime hampers job creation, and the low quality of education has resulted in a low-skilled labour force with poor productivity. As at July 2017 73% of the economically active population works in the informal sector, and only a minority of workers have access to health insurance or pensions, or pay taxes. Regional differences in employment quality-particularly its adequacy in terms of hours worked and remuneration-and productivity levels are stark. Poor areas register extremely low levels of productivity and are dominated by subsistence farming. Income inequality is high; the monthly minimum wage has been set at S850 (US$261) since May 1st 2016, and the government has not intimated any plans of a planned increase.
The Kuczynski administration did not attempt labour reforms in its first year in office, and is unlikely to present sweeping reforms. It has limited its attempts at encouraging formal employment to tax incentives for small companies and subsidies for youth employment. In terms of labour standards, the administration did submit legislation to Congress in July 2017 to increase the scope of labour inspections. In addition, lawmakers presented, but Congress did not debate, 20 separate bills on labour issues in the first seven months of 2017.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
5.4 5.9 67 68 10 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Infrastructure set to improve but large gaps will remain
The score for infrastructure improves in 2017-21, reflecting increased public and public-private investment. In addition to increased private investment in telecoms (an important recipient of foreign investment), the improvement is attributable to a series of fiscal stimulus packages that have been implemented since 2009, as well as increased budgeted expenditure and an ambitious programme of PPPs that the government envisages will exceed US$25bn in 2017-21. This includes an estimated US$6.2bn that will be used to repair and reorganise infrastructure destroyed during vast flooding in the first quarter of 2017. Another important move is the decision to strengthen and broaden a "public works for taxes" scheme that allows private companies to invest part of their tax payments in infrastructure. Originally designed for transport infrastructure, it has been expanded to cover schools, clinics, water and sanitation, and security infrastructure. The programme has involved the approval of 295 projects since 2009, including 55 in the first seven months of 2017. Nevertheless, infrastructure will remain a weak aspect of Peru's business environment.
Major infrastructure works have started slowly but are under construction
Major infrastructure projects, such as construction of the US$6bn second line of the Lima Metro, a US$5.4bn modernisation of the state-owned Talara oil refinery, and the US$1.2bn construction of a second runway at Lima's international airport are under construction, but behind schedule. The state has postponed tenders on several major projects, including the third and fourth lines of the Lima Metro, which the Kuczynski government has pledged to jump-start. The government has also promised construction of a commuter rail line that would connect Lima with nearby cities to the north and south.
The contracts for two major projects, the US$7.3bn construction and 30-year management contract for a natural gas pipeline, and the US$560m construction of a new airport in the Cusco region, were cancelled in 2017. The first was scrapped because of a corruption scandal involving the concession-holder, Odebrecht (a Brazilian construction firm at the centre of corruption cases across the region), and the second because of objections in Congress to a change in the contract. Regardless of the issues of corruption, the design and execution of infrastructure concessions has traditionally been poor, reflecting low technical capacity in the public sector and persistent corruption surrounding public projects. Flaws in the design of contracts mean that public projects struggle to raise finance and need several amendments before they can go ahead, causing severe delays that have deterred some international participants. Successful bidders should act strategically to navigate the public sector's restrictions.
Peru's telecoms and technology infrastructure has grown and modernised-largely as a result of foreign investment. Increased competition in the mobile telephony market and the introduction of new technologies will result in a fall in costs for consumers in the forecast period. A new fibre-optic network was completed in the third quarter of 2016, allowing broadband service to reach 180 provincial capitals. In May 2016 the government awarded a 700-MHz band, allowing for high-speed broadband service in high-density areas in Lima and other cities. Roll-out of the service continues.
Port infrastructure is expected to improve in 2017-21, and the cost of moving goods through the ports is set to decline. At present, Peru's ports are among the most expensive in the region. Major upgrades have been completed on the south pier at Callao (Peru's largest port), which is operated by Dubai-based DP World, and on the north pier, operated by Holland-based APM Terminals.
The construction of highway corridors in 2011 linking Peru to Brazil's highway network (known as the inter-oceanic highway) has improved Peru's road network and connections between the two countries' Atlantic and Pacific ports. We expect further projects to improve transport links between Peru, Bolivia and Ecuador.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Peru will retain its prudent, business-friendly policy framework in 2017-21. Mr Kuczynski has cast himself as a technocratic reformer with a mandate to address a multitude of longstanding structural shortcomings, but progress will be limited. So far, he has focused on three areas: labour formalisation, administrative simplification and infrastructure investment. To achieve the first objective, the government has created new (and lower) tax brackets for small businesses, and changed regulations to make it easier to obtain business licences and register companies in decentralised government offices, which will also provide advisory services and training to businesses. In late July the government presented a bill to address labour informality and working conditions; the outcome will depend on support from FP.
In terms of more dynamic public procedures and administration, Mr Kuczynski has restructured or overhauled procedures at a variety of government entities. These include the tax authority, the state-owned petroleum company, the state investment-promotion agency and government bureaux that administer public investment. The administration hopes that a more streamlined government will not only entice private investment, but also facilitate an ambitious infra-structure programme (of which a sizable share consists of public-private partnerships). The latter is a key concern, as the administration has pinned its hopes for dynamic GDP expansion on infrastructure investment. However, capital expenditure and budget execution rates for public works remain low (by August 24th only 31.7% of the budgeted investment for 2017 had been carried out), and the legislature has proven a significant obstacle to infrastructure plans. Congress has not only impeded projects, but has also ejected the ministers of transport and finance, who between them headed the infrastructure efforts.
The government will remain committed to attempting reforms in 2017-21, including major changes to the pension system, and to education and security policy. We are not optimistic about the government's chance of success. Polls indicate that Mr Kuczynski's popularity has reached a new low with a job approval rating of less than 30%. He has also faced much criticism for his mismanagement of ongoing strikes by public-sector employees. As the president's party has surrendered most of its political leverage, FP has free reign to determine the legislative agenda. It may well support some reforms that are aligned with its own platform, but it has shown a tendency to resist some measures, even those that may be ideologically in line with its own platform, for political gain.

The non-financial public-sector (NFPS) deficit is forecast to widen to 2.7% of GDP in 2017 and to 3.3% of GDP in 2018, before recurrent expenditure restraint and increased tax collection help to narrow it to 1.4% by 2021. In terms of outlays, capital expenses will be the government's primary focus. In early May the government presented Congress with a US$7.1bn (3.6% of 2016 GDP) public investment package for 2017-20 to both boost economic growth and address infrastructure shortcomings that were made evident during floods in February-March this year. Despite the expected negotiations in Congress, the plan will be approved. The Ministry of Economy and Finance is slated to present eight bills to Congress in September to catalyse the economic recovery. Mr Zavala has also sought to increase budgetary flexibility so that reallocation of funds does not have to go through Congress each time; however, we don't think he will prevail.

The government's capacity to implement all the infrastructure measures is in doubt, given its past performance; hence, our forecast does not foresee complete compliance. Furthermore, the infrastructure plan will raise outlays, and push capital and overall expenditure respectively to highs of 8.5% of GDP and 31.3% of GDP in 2018. As for revenue, we expect improved tax collection in 2017-21. This is due in part to reforms at the tax authority and changes to tax legislation introduced in January 2017, which included an increase in corporate income tax to 29% and attempts to broaden the tax base. These changes will result in higher receipts in GDP terms in the forecast period. In 2017-18 these will only partly offset the rise in spending, but will result in deficit reductions in 2019-21, when we expect public expenditure to be reined in.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)
  2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021
Short-term lending rate (av; %) 16.5 16.5 15.7 16.1 16.1 16.0
We forecast that the public debt/GDP ratio will reach 25.7% of GDP in 2017 and average 29.5% of GDP in 2020-21. Nonetheless, this level will be low by regional and global standards. Peru will retain good access to voluntary financing from domestic and international markets and, in the event that external conditions deteriorate sharply (not our baseline scenario), the country would be able to access multilateral funding with relative ease.
Given sluggish economic activity and ebbing core inflation, the Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (BCRP, the central bank) has both the opportunity and cause for monetary easing. On July 13th the BCRP cut its rate policy rate for the second time this year, bringing it to 3.75%, but kept the rate unchanged at its mid-August meeting. In line with our baseline expectation of continued low growth and easing inflation, we expect a further cut in 2017, to 3.5%. In 2018-19 the bank will be wary of pursuing overly expansionary policy in the context of rising interest rates in the US. A loosening of monetary policy in the US in 2020 will provide breathing space for the BCRP to allow for more expansionary policy to support economic growth. By 2021 the Peruvian economy will be on an upswing, allowing the central bank to start a tightening cycle.

We expect Peru's economy to pick up in the forecast period, but the annual average rate of 3.6% in 2018-21 will be much lower than during the commodities boom. This partly reflects the dampening effects of slowdowns forecast in China and the US, in 2018-19 and 2020, respectively.
GDP growth picked up to 0.7% quarter on quarter in the second quarter of 2017, after weak first-quarter growth of 0.2%, partly reflecting flooding brought on by the El Niño weather phenomenon. The recovery in the second half will continue, but growth for 2017 as a whole will be tepid, at 2.5%, as the government struggles to implement infrastructure plans amid transparency issues, congress-sional opposition, and ineffective and cumbersome regulatory procedures that hinder public expenditure and project implement-ation. These problems have recently been exemplified by two projects: the Gasoducto del Sur, a gas pipeline scheme that reverted to the state after financing fell through owing to corruption investigations, and the project to build the new Chinchero International Airport near Cusco, the controversy over which led to the ousting of two ministers and the scrapping of the entire project. Notwithstanding these obstacles, we expect the pace of public investment to accelerate in the forecast period. We expect private consumption growth to pick up, but it is unlikely that consumption will return to the growth rates seen in the past decade, given limited progress in addressing levels of labour informality that are among the highest regionally.
Peru's economy will remain dominated by mining, but the main productivity gains will come from the agro-industrial sector, which has grown quickly in recent years. Manufacturing will continue to face constraints related to external competition, fluctuations in global demand competition and a lack of skilled labour. All of this will discourage investment in the sector, leaving foreign investment mainly focused on the mining sector. Services growth will be supported by expansion in retail, finance, tourism and transport. The continued expansion of an emerging middle class will boost the services sector.
Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Industry will grow by an annual average of 4.4% in 2017-21, although its growth rate will be skewed by stronger performance at the start of the forecast period. Although prices for copper and other key metals exports have recovered during the first half of the year (and we expect them to continue recovering into 2019), they will not reach the levels seen during the commodities supercycle, which will depress investment. Indeed, investment in mining has been waning since reaching a high of US$10bn in 2013, and the current pipeline of projects suggests that output growth will taper-off after 2017. A forecast slowdown in China (a key trading partner) in 2018 will also contribute to less dynamic mining performance and investment. Peru, however, retains significant mineral wealth and the government calculates that potential mining projects, principally in copper, gold, iron ore and silver, could mean as much as US$50bn in new investment. We expect much more modest investment, as several of the largest projects the government is counting on are on standby while companies either resolve financing issues or face opposition from local communities. Community groups oppose the arrival of mining investment, citing concerns about damage to the environment and the fact that not enough locals are hired to work at the mines. Anti-mining protests often turn violent and mining projects suffer delays. Regardless, Peru will retain its place as a pre-eminent copper producer (it is currently the second-largest producer in the world, behind Chile) and mining output show consistent, albeit unimpressive, growth.
Manufacturing will also remain fairly dynamic, despite its vulnerability to fluctuations in demand from the US and China, and competitiveness issues brought on by the combination of low productivity, an appreciated real exchange rate and myriad Free-Trade Agreements. As such, the areas that will see the most growth will be extractive or non-tradeable in nature. Significant investments in 2017-21, including in the expanding petrochemicals sector and gas pipeline infrastructure, will boost industrial capacity in the latter part of the forecast period. Successive administrations have moved towards the medium- to-long-term goal of developing industrial centres that will take advantage of the high quantity of ethane in Peruvian gas to produce polyethylene and other petrochemicals. The construction of large hydroelectric plants in the Amazon region will also boost growth in the energy sector. Construction, which has boomed in recent years, will continue to expand during the forecast period, although at a slower rate. This will be driven by the Kuczynski government's plans for public infrastructure projects (electrification, sanitation, housing, roads and new transport facilities in major cities), and private projects, including large retail investments in secondary cities and industrial schemes (such as a natural-gas pipeline, hydroelectric plants and mining projects).
Agriculture will record average annual growth of 3.2% in the forecast period, although the figure is skewed by the poor growth of 2017, at 2%, owing to the effects of the "coastal El Niño" weather pattern, which brought massive flooding and loss of crops. Peru is carving out a niche in international markets for agro-exports, taking advantage of growing conditions at home and new opportunities created by Peru's numerous FTA agreements. Considerable investment in irrigation and export capacity has gone into the sector in the past years, and output will be lifted in the latter part of the forecast period by the completion of large irrigation projects in the southern and northern coastal areas. These will add more than 100,000 ha of new farmland. The fishing sector is expected to grow moderately, with the focus shifting from traditional fishmeal and fish-oil exports towards fish for human consumption.
Services are expected to grow by an annual average of 3.1% in 2017-21, lower than that of recent years, owing to slower growth and constrained consumption. Regardless, growth in services will be supported by expansion in retail, finance, tourism and transport. Planned expansion of large retail chains across the capital, Lima, and in smaller cities will respond to the changing consumer patterns of a growing middle class. Tourism will gain in importance, as infrastructure (such as the construction of a modern airport in Cusco), and hence access to the country's main tourism destinations, improves gradually. The continued emergence of a growing middle class will boost the services sector and will gradually contribute more to Peru's GDP growth as the latest wave of investment comes to an end.

Despite a pick-up owing to supply shortages caused by extreme weather, we expect annual inflation (2.9% in July) to return to a downward trajectory, ending 2017 at 2.6% and remaining inside the BCRP's 1-3% target band in 2018-21. Lower demand pressures will help the BCRP to bring inflation into the target band, although higher international energy costs and moderate currency weakening will counter this to some extent. There are several risks to this forecast, including adverse weather, which could drive up food prices, as well as pronounced currency depreciation, which would lead to higher import costs.

After appreciating during the first four months of 2017, the sol has since hovered at around S3.25:1US$1. In the coming months, we expect the sol to gradually depreciate, ending the year at S3.3: US$1. On an annual average basis, however, we expect the exchange rate to strengthen in 2017 as a whole before depreciating by an average of 1.3% per year in 2018-21. Debt and investment inflows will provide support for the sol. We expect the BCRP to continue to intervene in currency markets to smooth volatility while accumulating reserves. The BCRP will continue to support the ongoing process of de-dollarisation and protection of the financial sector, which is moderately exposed to currency risk. The balance of risks is tilted towards greater sol weakening. However, the risk of sharper than expected depreciation is mitigated by confidence in the monetary policy framework, strong reserves and steady long-term capital inflows.

The trade surplus will come in at US$3.7bn in 2017, owing to strong external demand in conjunction with a recovery in prices of Peru's key commodities exports. However, as terms of trade deteriorate and import growth outpaces export growth, the trade surplus will fall to an average of US$2.4bn in 2018-21. We expect the primary income deficit to remain below the level seen in previous years, at an average of 4.5% of GDP in 2017-21. The secondary income (transfers) surplus will average 1.8% of GDP in 2017-21, owing to high levels of remittances. As a result, the current-account deficit will remain mostly stable, averaging 2% of GDP in 2017-21. Peru's current-account deficit will be financed by inward foreign direct investment (FDI) flows, which we expect to reach US$5.7bn (2.7% of GDP) in full-year 2017. We expect inflows to average 2.4% of GDP in a more challenging international environment in 2018-19, before recovering slightly, to 2.8% of GDP in 2021. FDI will not reach the levels seen in 2010-12, when inflows averaged 5.5% of GDP.

Foreign reserves stood at US$61.4bn on August 22nd, equivalent to 15.6 months of import cover. We expect reserves to grow slightly in nominal terms in the forecast period and although import cover will ease to 12.8 months by 2021, this will offer adequate protection against external shocks.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Peru
Stocks and flows
Foreign direct investment (FDI) peaked in 2012 at a historic high of US$11.8bn (6.2% of GDP). FDI flows have since ebbed, reflecting the end of the commodities boom, reaching US$6.9bn in 2016 (3.5% of GDP). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects FDI inflows to largely remain close to (albeit below) 3% of GDP in 2017-21, owing to weak governability and lower export prices when compared with 2007-12, when FDI inflows averaged 5.5% of GDP. The stock of inward FDI totalled US$91.5bn at end-2016, or 46.8% of GDP. Peru does not have significant outflows of FDI; these totalled only US$303m in 2016, resulting in a stock of just US$4.2bn. Despite its small size, this stock has increased sharply over the past decade.
Origin and distribution
According to the government's investment-promotion agency, ProInversión, by end-2016 Spain, the UK and the US respectively accounted for 18%, 17% and 13% of the accumulated FDI stock in the country, followed by Chile (12%), the Netherlands (6%) and Brazil (5%). The stock of FDI was dominated by the mining sector, with 23% of the total, ahead of telecommunications (19%), finance (19%), energy (14%) and industry (13%); all other sectors had low single-digit shares. This suggests that there is considerable potential outside the traditional recipient sectors, with retail, transport, and tourism considerably under-represented compared with their shares of FDI in similar economies. One notable investment in the past resulted from the sale of the national telephone company to Telefónica (Spain), which partly explains that country's (and the telecoms sector's) large share of the FDI stock.
Determinants
Macroeconomic stability and liberalisation in the 1990s allowed for large increases in FDI inflows, following a period of sharp economic recession in the late 1980s. Annual average inflows rose from the negligible amounts of the 1980s to US$1.7bn (3.5%% of GDP) in the 1990s. During the first half of the 1990s in particular, the government aggressively pursued foreign investment in privatisation, above all in communications and financial services, and the development of abundant mining and energy resources. The implementation of business-friendly policies in the early 2000s, coupled with political stability-in addition to an ongoing rise in commodity prices throughout most of the last decade-helped to boost FDI inflows to an average of US$3.7bn in 2000-10, and to an average of US$9bn in 2011-15. During 2017-21 the government will continue to seek to attract private investment into mining, hydroelectricity, hydrocarbons exploration and infrastructure projects, although a less favourable global outlook for commodities than in the past suggests that efforts to diversify into other sectors (such as services) could prove increasingly lucrative.
Impact
Increases in FDI during the mid-1990s funded a growing share of gross fixed investment. The impact of FDI on the wider economy in terms of technology transfer has been confined mainly to the spillover effects from a much-improved telecoms sector and a more efficient financial services sector, with investment in mining having only limited links to the rest of the economy. This is changing, as foreign investment in natural gas and hydroelectricity is improving sources of energy. The award of infrastructure concessions will also promote economic development across various regions (some of which are relatively poor). An estimated US$80bn shortfall in infrastructure and communications investment will also be a driver for increased public-private partnerships (PPPs).
Potential
Although the administration of the president, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, aims to boost the declining inflows of FDI, the outlook for limited government effectiveness and low metal prices (compared with the previous decade) will weigh on investment inflows. Complex legislation and procedures on public tenders will also delay public private partnerships in infrastructure plans. Regardless, Peru's improving track record of prudent policymaking, free-trade agreements with the US and the EU (which include FDI clauses), and Peru's rich hydrocarbon and minerals resources will continue to pique interest during the forecast period. Although the pipeline of projects over the next decade includes more than US$55bn in mining projects and more than US$10bn in hydroelectric plants, the actual investment flows will be lower. owing to bureaucratic delays, local opposition, governability concerns, difficulty with environmental licences and pessimism about the direction of metals prices. Other areas that will receive investment include hydrocarbons exploration, transport infrastructure, water and sanitation, petrochemicals, and telecoms. Non-capital investment will be led by the financial and tourism sectors.

The emerging middle class will expand, but remain concentrated in urban areas
Although the Peruvian consumer market will remain characterised largely by inequality, two decades of strong economic growth have gradually led to the emergence of a growing middle class. Over the past decade, the capital, Lima, where most affluent consumers are concentrated, has seen a rapid transformation in consumer patterns. Retail and entertainment chains have expanded from the traditional wealthy areas, owing to increasing demand from lower-income districts and the emerging neighbourhoods (former slums) located in the periphery of the metropolitan area. This new consumer demand is also evident in secondary cities such as Arequipa, Trujillo, Chiclayo, Cusco, Piura, Iquitos and Ica, where economic growth has had a wider impact. However, the growth of market opportunities will still be limited to urban areas, and the majority of the population (particularly in rural areas) will continue to have low disposable income during the forecast period.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects average annual GDP growth of 3.4% in 2017-21-solid in historical terms, but a marked deceleration from 2012-16-to contribute to the continued gradual expansion of the middle class as the number of formal-sector jobs grows, albeit from a low base. The economy is expected to generate jobs for unskilled and skilled workers alike. However, those who remain in rural areas, or are confined to the informal sector by a lack of skills (where underemployment will keep the supply of labour high and will hold down income), will continue to see fewer benefits from economic growth.
The government's efforts to reduce labour costs-especially at small firms-could help to increase formal job creation, but raising skill levels will prove challenging, given poor educational outcomes. Although an increase in conditional cash transfer programmes will increase purchasing power for lower-income groups, their access to consumer goods and services will remain limited. Despite a sharp reduction in overall poverty levels (from more than half the population in 2000 to less than a quarter today), indigenous communities in the Andes and the Amazon areas will remain isolated, and high levels of illiteracy will persist, although literacy programmes have made some progress during the past decade.

Poverty and social inequality will remain barriers to market growth
Owing to still high levels of poverty and vast social inequalities, the total size of the population is a poor guide to market opportunities in Peru. The World Bank estimates the country's Gini coefficient (a widely used indicator of inequality, with zero equalling complete equality and 1 maximal inequality) at 0.441 in 2014, less than in some other regional economies, but high by global standards. Low inflation, steady growth of real incomes and targeted poverty-alleviation programmes will gradually lift more families out of poverty, allowing the share of food in overall household expenditure slowly to decline, although it will remain high by international standards. Increased household incomes will bring about a shift in consumption patterns, with food and beverages losing ground to expenses in healthcare and telecommunications. Over time, growth of credit will encourage increased expenditure on durable consumer goods by a greater proportion of the overall population and those living outside the capital, Lima.
The market is geographically skewed, with metropolitan Lima accounting for just under 30% of the population, well over 50% of all economic activity and 75% of consumer bank credit. Although Lima will continue to be the focus for investors, they will increasingly tap demand in areas outside the capital. Indeed, the last few years have seen a rapid expansion of retailers in the larger cities along the coast and in the Andes, and although economic growth will be moderate in 2017-21, this trend is likely to continue in the medium term. Greater market integration is also expected as the government continues to increase spending on infrastructure. Growth, macroeconomic stability, low tariffs and a plentiful supply of foreign exchange should allow Peru to become a more significant importer of consumer goods. This trend will be accelerated by greater access to the US, Chinese and European markets under free-trade agreements. Although Peru's population is ageing, it will remain much younger than in developed markets, and the ongoing demographic boom will make consumption patterns more dynamic.

Initial conditions: Peru's real GDP growth averaged 3.2% between 1982 and 2015, and growth of real GDP per head averaged 1.1%. However, these figures disguises a marked improvement in economic performance during the 1990s, when the policy environment was transformed and the economy was liberalised after a period of macroeconomic instability in the 1980s, character-ised by a debt crisis and hyperinflation later in the decade. These policy improvements spurred economic growth in the 2000s and helped the economy to withstand the 2008-09 global financial crisis fairly well. Although rapid GDP growth over the past two decades has enabled Peru to catch up with the Latin American median in terms of GDP per head, it is still well below that of developed countries. Weaker external conditions and slow progress in pushing the reform agenda forwards to tackle longstanding structural issues means that Peru will still lag behind developed economies by 2030. Peru is well endowed with natural resources-ranging from metals and natural gas to productive agricultural land. Its main weaknesses are the poor quality of its institutions, coupled with widespread income and regional inequalities. Overall education levels will remain low, and the slow pace of institutional improvement, together with lower investment in capital spending, will be the main factors behind a slowdown in average annual growth in the second half of the long-term outlook period. Opportunities in energy and mining will continue to foster investment. Nevertheless, with export-oriented industries the mainstay of the economy, Peru will remain vulnerable to fluctuations in external demand and commodities prices.
Demographic trends: The Economist Intelligence Unit expects population growth to average 1.1% annually in 2017-30, before slowing to 0.6% per year in 2031-50. Fertility will decline in line with continued urbanisation, but the birth rate will remain relatively high, even by Latin American standards, and well above developed-country norms. Declining fertility and increasing life expectancy point to an ageing population. However, even by the end of the long-term forecast period, the proportion of the population aged 65 and over, at around 17%, will remain much lower than in OECD countries. Lower birth-rates and the current low numbers of pensioners means that the dependency ratio (the ratio of children and elderly to the working-age population) will bottom out at 51% by 2034, before beginning a steady upward trend. Emigration has been substantial enough to have had an impact on population growth; each year, around 300,000 individuals are estimated to leave Peru to seek work abroad, although significant numbers have returned in recent years, as the economy has expanded rapidly and opportunities in traditional migrant destinations such as Spain have been limited. However, economic growth, by increasing disposable income for those in work, will put the option of emigration within reach of a greater proportion of the population, and the gap in economic opportunities between Peru and a variety of countries, including the US and neighbouring Chile, will remain wide. Internal migration will also have a decisive influence on the development of the economy. The level of urbanisation will rise from its present level of just under 79%, but it is already high by global standards, so the increase will be modest.
External conditions: The export-oriented sectors of the Peruvian economy, ranging from mining to export agriculture, have long been the most dynamic. Peru is expected to continue to benefit from free-trade agreements (FTAs) with the US, the main market for non-traditional exports, and China, which over the past few years has been trading places with the US as the recipient of the largest proportion of total exports. FTAs with the EU and other Asian economies will provide similar benefits. Integration efforts within Latin America are also gaining pace, particularly under the auspices of the Pacific Alliance, an integration pact composed of Peru, Chile, Colombia and Mexico, which focuses not only on trade in goods, but also on services, capital and free movement of people. Global trade flows will outpace world output growth over the long term, and Peru's increasing integration with the world economy should allow the country to benefit from global demand. Although the Peruvian economy is highly exposed to world commodity prices, the easing of the commodities supercycle and the corresponding deterioration of Peru's terms of trade will be partly mitigated by greater export diversification.
Institutions and policy trends: Peru's institutions were weakened during the 1990s under the rule of the then president, Alberto Fujimori (1990-2000). The media and forces in Congress became co-opted by the executive, and the political system became more authoritarian. The transition from Mr Fujimori's regime highlighted popular demands for a greater degree of effective democracy and decentralisation, made evident by rising protests in Peru's regions. Nevertheless, the quality of institutions remains weak, characterised by a politicised judiciary, widespread corruption and the lack of a strong political-party system, which leads to legislative fragmentation. Despite the efforts of the president, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, little progress in addressing these issues is expected, given the government's relative political weakness and the pervasiveness of the issue. Despite this, our long-term forecast assumes that improvements in the conduct of economic policy and in the policy environment will largely be sustained. We expect the public finances to be prudently managed, characterised by low debt levels. Bureaucracy will gradually be reduced and the business environment, which in some respects remains non-conducive to entrepreneurship, will improve. Increased spending on healthcare and education will gradually have productivity-enhancing effects. Private investment will lead to improvements in infrastructure. A continued commitment to inflation targeting by the Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (the central bank), along with responsible fiscal management and a low debt stock, will help to maintain macroeconomic stability, while a flexible exchange rate will help the economy to cope with external shocks.
Long-term performance: We forecast average real GDP growth of 4% per year in 2021-30, easing to an average of 3.1% in 2031-50; this is strong by regional standards. Past reforms, in particular the establishment of private pension funds, will continue to bear fruit, helping to deepen capital markets and raise the savings rate. Nevertheless, growth is likely to be focused on resource-intensive areas, export agriculture and specialised areas of manufacturing, such as textiles. Relatively low levels of education for the majority, coupled with low spending on research and development-at less than 1% of GDP-will constrain the economy from moving into higher value-added areas, despite frequent attempts by governments to improve domestic productive capacity and develop industrial clusters. Economic performance will become more dependent on productivity gains as growth in the labour force slows and the economy continues to adapt to the end of the commodities supercycle. Reflecting investments made in previous years and slow but sustained institutional improvements, labour productivity will rise by an average of 2.4% in 2017-50. We expect GDP per head, measured at purchasing-power parity levels, to increase to 36.7% of the US level by 2050, up from just 20.4% in 2016.

Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCRP: Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines ten separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, and infrastructure. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 16 (infrastructure), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2012-16) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2017-21). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2012-16. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2017-21 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
The main sources used in the business rankings model include CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce; Freedom House, Annual Survey of Political Rights and Civil Liberties; Heritage Foundation, Index of Economic Freedom; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; UN, Human Development Report; US Social Security Administration, Social Security Programs Throughout the World; World Bank, World Development Report; World Development Indicators; Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Report.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2012-16 ranges are then used to derive 2017-21 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2017-21, not to the likely situation in 2021 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2014 or 2019). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Country Forecast Europe September 2017

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-europe-september-2017/docview/1961653440/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: [...]the government is weak and vulnerable to political manoeuvrings within the PD and the wider coalition ahead of the next election. Because of the fragmentation of the political system into three main blocs-the centre left, the centre right and the Eurosceptic, anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S)-and the return to a strongly proportional one-round electoral system, we expect that there will be no clear winner at the next general election. According to a survey conducted by Ifop, a pollster, for Le Journal du Dimanche, a weekly newspaper, Mr Macron's approval ratings slipped by 10 percentage points in July and by a further 14 points in August, to just 40% (significantly lower than his two immediate predecessors, François Hollande and Nicolas Sarkozy, at this stage in their presidencies). [...]a durable alliance remains elusive, and it is unclear whether a broad centre-right formation would poll as well as the sum of its constituent parties. [...]there is no consensus on who would head such a coalition; Silvio Berlusconi, FI's leader, remains reluctant to accept the leadership of the Lega Nord's Matteo Salvini, who opinion polls suggest is the favoured candidate among centre-right supporters. The BoE is likely to hold rates down until 2021 In 2016 the BoE took several steps to limit the financial and economic fallout from the Brexit vote. Since August 2016 the MPC has kept the main policy interest rate at 0.25%, the stock of government bond purchases at £435bn (US$581bn) and the stock of corporate bond purchases at £10bn.
