Background: The political geography of Europe has been defined by two world wars and the legacy of the cold war, during which Europe was divided into two blocs. The ending of Soviet control over central and eastern Europe from 1989, followed by the collapse in 1991 of the Soviet Union, provided an opportunity to expand the EU eastwards. Ten new member states (eight from the former communist bloc) were admitted to the EU in 2004, followed by a further two in 2007, and Croatia in 2013. In June 2016 the UK electorate voted in a referendum to withdraw from the EU. The economic transition of the Visegrad countries (the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia) has proceeded more smoothly than that of other east European countries. The effects of war in former Yugoslavia in the 1990s and a slower pace of reform have shaped developments in south-east Europe.
Political structure: All 28 EU member states are parliamentary democracies, although in some of the newer, former communist members in particular the substance of democracy-including a political culture based on trust and healthy levels of political participation-is often absent. The communist period lasted much longer in the former Soviet Union, and political developments in most parts of that region have been characterised by a drift towards authoritarianism.
Policy issues: Many aspects of domestic policy for EU member states-in particular those relating to the single market-are decided collectively at the EU level. Nineteen EU member states share the euro as their currency. These countries are subject to a single monetary policy administered by the European Central Bank (ECB). They are supposed to comply with common fiscal rules, although these have often been ignored. During the euro zone debt crisis several member states (Cyprus, Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain) ceded varying degrees of policy control to the EU and the IMF in exchange for receiving financial support. Although the euro zone crisis has passed its peak, normalisation remains a long way off. The Economist Intelligence Unit continues to attach a 60% probability to Greece leaving the euro zone during its medium-term forecast period (2017-21). Outside the EU, the speed and extent of reform and institutional change vary widely. Countries with proximity to Western markets and with stable political outlooks have proceeded faster and more successfully with economic stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation. Institutional problems, such as weakness in the rule of law and widespread corruption, plague much of non-EU Europe.
Taxation: Individual tax regimes operate in all countries. All EU member states must operate a system of value-added tax (VAT), with a minimum of 15% as the standard rate.
Foreign trade: If intra-EU trade is included, the EU accounts for about half of all global trade. About 60% of trade conducted by EU member states is intra-regional.

Summary
Political stability
Populist parties did not triumph in elections across Europe in 2017, but popular disaffection with mainstream parties will persist.
The main question in the September 24 federal election in Germany is not who will win the largest share of the vote, but which party or parties will join the likely winner, the Christian Democratic Union (CDU), in a new coalition.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Brexit negotiations between the UK and the EU to result in a deal in March 2019 on a transitional period lasting up to two years, but the risk that negotiations will break down is significant.
The collapse of Iceland's government in September 2017 is the latest example of how increased political fragmentation is making it more difficult to form stable governments and implement policy.
We expect EU sanctions on Russia to be maintained and for relations with Russia to remain difficult.
Economic policy
If the UK economy remains resilient to Brexit uncertainty, there is a chance that the Bank of England will reverse the post-referendum interest rate cut of 0.25%. If growth momentum slows, however, the prospects of a rate rise will fade.
We expect the monetary stance to remain exceptionally loose across much of the rest of the region. We do not expect the European Central Bank (ECB) to increase policy rates by 2021.
There could be some rebalancing of the mix between monetary and fiscal policy in the euro zone as governments seek to respond to voter dissatisfaction. However, the bloc's rigid fiscal rules could make this a contentious process.
Economic reform has progressed well in some countries, notably the Baltic states, Spain and Ireland, but for most the main challenges lie ahead. With political fragmentation on the rise, policymaking is becoming more difficult.
Economic growth
We expect a growth slowdown in the UK in 2017-19 as Brexit negotiations heighten uncertainty, before growth accelerates in 2019-21.
We forecast a pick-up in average real GDP growth in the EU28 to 2.1% in 2017 and an average of 1.7% in 2018-21.
Business environment rankings
The business environment has improved in most European countries as the post-crisis economic recovery has gathered pace. However, fragilities remain.

Political outlook: Political stability
The UK's vote in June 2016 to leave the EU represents a challenge to the future cohesion of the bloc. Despite the professed unity of the other 27 member states, the departure of one of the biggest members is a profound shock. Brexit represents a further stage in a rolling regional political and economic crisis that began in 2010. This crisis has been defined by a failure of the region's institutions to provide effective governance and leadership in response to political and economic challenges. The early stages of the crisis were characterised by challenges to the survival of the single currency. The threat of a euro zone break-up has receded as firewalls have been put in place, notably through the intervention of the European Central Bank (ECB), and the economic recovery has gathered pace in recent years, but the euro crisis has not yet been banished. The intra-bloc tensions that it has engendered, especially between northern and southern states and between east and west, were compounded by the 2014-15 migration crisis. This crisis strengthened anti-establishment and anti-EU political parties, which in recent years have given voice to popular disaffection with mainstream political parties.
In managing its multiple crises since 2010, the region has resorted to "muddling through". This policy approach has been moderately successful so far, certainly when compared with some of the disastrous outcomes that could have transpired. However, muddling through does not offer a long-term strategy for addressing the region's problems, and it has eroded the political capital of the policymakers involved. The region faces major unanswered questions, not least about its relatively poor economic growth and productivity performance compared with the US and with developing regions such as Asia, and about whether further integration in the euro zone is economically necessary and politically feasible. The resistance of policymakers to confronting these questions head on should not be underestimated. However, if Europe's leaders continue with this muddle-through policy, the political and economic costs may prove to be their undoing.
Populist parties fail to take power, but popular disaffection will persist
Many have interpreted the results of recent elections in Austria, the Netherlands, France and the UK as a defeat for populist forces in Europe. The disappointing result for the Front national (FN) in France, for example, has been taken as proof that populism has run its course. The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that this is a mistaken view. The persistence of popular disaffection with the status quo was very much evident in the presidential and parliamentary elections in France, where anti-establishment parties attracted more support than la République en marche (LRM), the party of the president, Emmanuel Macron, and high abstention rates indicated widespread dissatisfaction with all parties.
Our expectation was not that populist parties would take power in major elections this year. However, we expected that some of them would continue to serve as vehicles for expressing widespread popular disenchantment with the established political order, giving them increasing influence in shaping the main topics of domestic political debate. We anticipate growing difficulties with coalition-building as disparate mainstream parties try to find common ground to work together to keep the populists out of power.
Populist parties have shown themselves to be more prepared than the main-stream parties to debate the big political issues of the day, such as the impact of globalisation on income equality and national identity, and they have mobilised people to become engaged in the political process and to vote. Ruling elites have responded by seeking to delegitimise the insurgent parties, and they have sometimes adopted some of the populists' rhetoric and policies. Even if some of today's populist movements dissipate or their support dwindles, we expect that popular disaffection will continue to cause political upsets and that there is little likelihood of a return to the stable post-war political order in Europe.
The Brexit negotiations will test EU cohesion
The Brexit negotiations began in June 2017, after the UK government invoked Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union on March 29th, beginning the formal two-year process of the country's withdrawal from the bloc. In the Article 50 letter, Theresa May, the prime minister, confirmed that the UK would not seek membership of the EU's single market. This is in line with the government's intention to honour the Brexit vote by taking control of laws, borders and budget. The UK will also leave the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice (ECJ).
The UK would like to have tariff-free access to EU markets, but customs union membership would mean a common external tariff and would prevent the UK from negotiating trade deals with other countries. The UK will therefore try to negotiate a free-trade agreement with the EU and has proposed alternatives to customs union membership, including a "highly streamlined" arrangement and a new customs "partnership".
Negotiations over the terms of the UK's withdrawal from the EU are taking place on a four-week cycle. So far the talks have made some progress on important issues relating to Northern Ireland and citizens' rights, but given the divergence in views on a range of other issues, including the financial settlement, we do not expect "sufficient progress" to have been made by the EU summit in October-a condition set by the EU for discussions on trade to begin. However, we expect a breakthrough by the December summit. This will push back the timeline for trade talks, but the impact on the final outcome will be limited if, as we expect, a transitional period is agreed after the UK's withdrawal at the end of March 2019. At that stage the UK will formally leave the single market, but the new relationship will be phased in gradually, to minimise disruption. This could mean continued adherence to EU rules until the new agreement is ratified.
The UK has committed to paying some financial liabilities, but the EU will also have to show flexibility if it is to avoid deadlock. We expect that a deal will be reached on a transitional period lasting up to two years, but the risk that the negotiations could break down is significant. If negotiations fail and an extension of the deadline is not agreed by all 27 EU members, the UK will leave the EU in 2019 without a deal and revert to World Trade Organisation (WTO) trade rules. The chances of an amicable divorce from the EU are slim, but both sides have an incentive to agree a deal given the mutual benefits of maintaining economic, political and security relations.
The result of the June 2017 snap general election in the UK heightened uncertainty about the Brexit negotiations. The decision of Mrs May to call an early general election on June 8th backfired disastrously for the Conservative Party, which lost its majority. Mrs May has lost authority but could stay in place because her party fears another general election, which it could lose given that momentum is with the main opposition Labour Party. The Conservatives have formed a working government based on a "confidence and supply" arrange-ment with Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP).
This arrangement is likely to work in the short term because neither party wants another election, they are natural allies on questions of sovereignty and the EU, and the DUP is committed to preventing the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, from coming to power given his past association with Northern Ireland's main nationalist party, Sinn Fein. However, the arrangement is politically fragile, and the government's 13-seat working majority (down from 17 seats before the election) will dwindle with each by-election.
Another threat to political stability and government effectiveness is the division in the cabinet between pro- and anti-EU forces over the government's Brexit strategy. The Brexiteers in the cabinet and the Conservative Party have been supportive of Mrs May since the election because they want her to hold fast to her earlier pledges to leave the single market, the customs union and the jurisdiction of the ECJ. This faction includes the Brexit secretary, David Davis; the international trade secretary, Liam Fox; the environment minister, Michael Gove; and the foreign affairs minister, Boris Johnson. They will support the prime minister as long as she pursues their vision of Brexit. However, Mrs May is also under pressure from those advocating a "softer" Brexit, who favour an extended post-2019 transition period during which the UK would retain single market access, including the chancellor of the exchequer, Philip Hammond; the home secretary, Amber Rudd; and the first secretary of state, Damian Green. There is a risk that cabinet divisions over Brexit will intensify, leading to a leadership challenge and even the collapse of the government. The minority government will do well to last the duration of the Brexit negotiations, until March 2019 (with or without Mrs May), and there is a significant risk of another pre-term election.
After leading his movement to power, the hard work begins now for Mr Macron
Emmanuel Macron, the leader of a new centrist party in France, la République en marche (LRM), began a five-year term as president on May 14th 2017. He succeeded François Hollande of the centre-left Parti socialiste (PS), who left office as the most unpopular president of the post-war period. The prime minister, Édouard Philippe, hails from the main centre-right party, Les Républicains, balancing out Mr Macron's ties with the PS after two years as economy minister under Mr Hollande. He leads a post-partisan government with several figures from the private sector. LRM and its centrist ally, Mouvement démocrate (MoDem), have a comfortable majority in parliament, with 413 out of 577 seats between their two parliamentary groups. The government also benefits from support from a group of 35 moderate "Constructive" deputies from Les Républicains and its centre-right ally, the Union of Democrats and Independents (UDI).
Mr Macron came into office on a promise of economic reform and political renewal. His policy agenda includes ideas from both the left and the right, and he encouraged non-politicians to run for office to bring a broader range of people into the National Assembly. In the current parliament only 25% of deputies are incumbents, the share of women has risen to 39% and the average age has fallen to 49. Mr Macron is also intent on elevating the presidency after public approval of the office suffered under Nicolas Sarkozy's hyperactivity and Mr Hollande's attempt to be an "ordinary man". In contrast, Mr Macron aspires to embody a "Jupiterian" presidency, setting the government's strategic direction but remaining aloof from day-to-day affairs. His address to both houses of parliament at Versailles in July was an initial example of this approach, with a lofty "state of the union" speech, which he intends to make an annual event.
In the presidential and parliamentary elections Mr Macron and LRM won decisive shares of the vote, with 66% and 43% of second-round votes respectively. However, the scale of this victory was qualified by unusually high abstention. In the second round of the presidential election 34% of voters abstained or submitted a blank or spoiled ballot, and in the legislative election the equivalent figure was 62%. This indicates a significant share of public dis-satis-faction with the electoral options available, including Mr Macron and LRM. Those voters who have disengaged with the political process are more likely to express their discontent on the street. With trade union protests taking place in September and more planned-backed by a newly resurgent far-left party, La France insoumise, under Jean-Luc Mélenchon-we anticipate a disruptive degree of public resistance to the president's reform agenda.
However, we do not expect these protests to derail Mr Macron's plans or stymie policymaking to the degree that similar protests did under Mr Hollande. Nor is the resistance that Mr Macron will face in parliament likely to be enough to block legislative progress. The largest opposition party, Les Républicains (with 112 seats), has split into two parliamentary groups-a "constructive" group of deputies sympathetic to the president's reform plans, and the rest of the party-and the formerly ruling PS now has only 30 seats. Mr Macron could face resistance from within his own party however, especially as some of LRM's newer deputies gain experience and start to assert themselves. His parlia-mentary majority is sufficiently large that Mr Macron can afford some rebellion on the backbenches, but he will want to avoid a repeat of the public splits in the PS under Mr Hollande's presidency.
We expect Angela Merkel to remain in power after the 2017 election
Despite a marked increase in political volatility in Germany since 2015-largely as a result of the unprecedented number of migrant arrivals-the country is likely to remain, in comparative terms, a source of political stability in Europe. Germany's current government-comprising a grand coalition of the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU), its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD)-is led by Angela Merkel, who is in her third term as chancellor. Our baseline forecast is that the CDU/CSU will win the largest share of the vote in the September election and that Ms Merkel will continue as chancellor.
Election result puts to rest speculation about a Dutch exit from the euro or the EU
The parliamentary election in the Netherlands on March 15th 2017 led to a fragmented result, with the centre-right People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD) winning the most seats in the 150-seat parliament, with 33, down from 41 in 2012. The right-wing, populist Party for Freedom (PVV), led by Geert Wilders, which is the main outlet for public frustration with much of the traditional political mainstream, came second, albeit with 13 seats fewer than the VVD.
Coalition negotiations have been difficult and are continuing. The VVD, the Christian Democratic Appeal (CDA) and Democrats 66 (D66) have made several attempts at forming a coalition, first with GreenLeft (GL), then with the Christian Union (CU), and then with GL again. They are currently in discussions with the CU again. Despite deep differences remaining between the CU and D66, especially on medical-ethical issues, a leaked compromise in mid-August suggested that the parties were close to reaching an agreement. However, given the secretive nature of these talks, a risk remains that the parties will fail to form a government together. This four-party coalition would enjoy only a wafer-thin majority in both houses of parliament, heightening the risk of an early election. As this would leave few other options for a majority coalition, there is an increased risk that the parties will fall back on a minority coalition, or even a renewed election, although we would expect a lot more time to pass before either option (especially a renewed election) is considered.
The impact on the economic outlook of this protracted period of policy uncertainty, including the budget for 2018 being put together by a caretaker government and thus remaining broadly unchanged, is minimal given the strength of the economy and the public finances, and the fact that there is little need for immediate significant reforms.
Italy remains a particular pressure point within the euro zone. The over-whelming rejection of the flagship constitutional reform of the then prime minister and leader of the Partito Democratico (PD), Matteo Renzi, in a referendum in December 2016 has increased political instability, which will hinder prospects for political and economic reform in Italy. We expect that the coalition government formed by Paolo Gentiloni of the dominant centre-left Partito Democratico (PD) in December 2016 will remain in place until the end of the current parliamentary term, in early 2018. However, the government is weak and vulnerable to political manoeuvrings within the PD and the wider coalition ahead of the next election. Because of the fragmentation of the political system into three main blocs-the centre left, the centre right and the Eurosceptic, anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S)-and the return to a strongly proportional one-round electoral system, we expect that there will be no clear winner at the next general election. This will complicate government formation, which is likely to lead to the establishment of another executive backed by a broad centre-left/centre-right coalition and possibly led by Mr Gentiloni. Consequently, we expect the next government to be unstable, limiting its effectiveness and its ability to pass long-overdue political and economic reforms. A government led by M5S cannot be ruled out, as we expect it to emerge as the largest party in parliament after the election. However, it is unlikely given the leadership's refusal to work with the mainstream parties.
A shift to one-man-rule and deepening polarisation in Turkey will continue
The intense political instability in Turkey that followed the failed coup by parts of the military in July 2016 has eased partially since the approval in a referendum in April 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency. However, we maintain our negative medium-term political outlook. The narrow referendum victory and allegations of vote fraud have deepened the social and political divisions. The "justice march" from the capital, Ankara, to Istanbul, headed by Kemal Kilicdaroglu, the leader of the opposition Republican People's Party (CHP), ended peacefully on July 9th, but further protests are likely, keeping high the risk of clashes between protesters and pro-government supporters or a government clampdown. The presidential reform, which will take effect after the next presidential and parliamentary elections, both due in 2019, will further undermine Turkey's fragile democratic institutions and governance structures. It provides few checks and balances on the powers of the president, and moves the country closer to one-man rule by the incumbent president and leader of the ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP), Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Mr Erdogan and the AKP have continued to tighten their grip on power. The state of emergency law introduced after the failed coup has been repeatedly extended on a three-month basis. We expect it to remain in place for the foresee-able future, because it will effectively allow Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is fully in place.
Emergency rule was initially introduced to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. However, the use of these powers has been extended to eliminate the pro-Kurdish political opposition, which the government accuses of having links with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), and silence government critics. More than 100,000 people-mainly in the judiciary, the military, the police, academic institutions and the media-have so far been suspended, dismissed or detained.
Political outlook: French government unveils labour market reform bill
The government unveiled its labour market reform bill on August 31st, fulfilling a campaign pledge to prioritise this legislation in a bid to reduce the high level of unemployment. The bill essentially increases flexibility for employers and scales back France's notoriously high levels of worker protection. It is now with the National Assembly (the lower house of parliament), which will vote on September 22nd, but the large parliamentary majority of the president, Emmanuel Macron, means that the bill's passage into law is assured, despite opposition from some trade unions. Our expectation is that the reform will lead to an improvement in labour market conditions, but that it will not be enough on its own to prompt the kind of job-creation that would result in a significant fall in unemployment.
Several major components of the current labour legislation will be retained, including the 35-hour working week and minimum-wage provisions, but the new bill introduces changes in many other areas. It will make it possible for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to negotiate directly with their employees on issues pertaining to training and working conditions, rather than with a union appointee, as is currently the case. It also caps the indemnities that can be awarded by employment tribunals in cases of wrongful dismissal at between one month of salary (for workers employed for less than a year) and 20 months of salary (for workers employed for 30 years). Currently there is no cap on the payments that companies are required to make by employment tribunals, which in most cases rule in favour of the fired employee. Payouts can be huge, with little consistency between cases. Employees who have been fired will have a maximum of one year to file a case for wrongful dismissal, compared with two years currently.
Greater flexibility for SMEs and foreign multinationals
Many of the reform proposals relate specifically to SMEs, which account for about 30% of total employment, but there are also changes for large foreign companies with operations in France. These companies currently have to request permission before making French workers redundant, and although this process will remain intact, the ruling will now be decided by the company's financial results in France rather than their global results, as is currently the case. This will make it easier for foreign multinationals to scale back personnel if local operations are not proving profitable. However, severance payments will be raised slightly, to 25% of monthly salary for each year of employment, from 20% currently.
Previous presidents have tried and failed to increase labour market flexibility, but Mr Macron stands a much greater chance of success, owing to his large parliamentary majority. There is opposition from the public, labour unions and opposition political parties, but it is not particularly co-ordinated. One of the largest unions (and the most hardline), the Confédération générale du travail (CGT), called a strike on September 12th. Another large union, the Confédération française démocratique du travail (CFDT), joined the protests later, and another, Force Ouvrière (FO), is also planning protests. Others, including the Confédération française des travailleurs chrétiens (CFTC), have been more circumspect, stating that the "worst has been avoided" in the formation of the proposed bill.
Opposition lacks cohesion
Jean-Luc Mélenchon's far-left party, La France insoumise, has also heavily criticised the bill, but despite a meeting between Mr Mélenchon and the head of the CGT, Philippe Martinez, on September 6th, the two men failed to agree on a plan of united opposition to the reform bill, with Mr Mélenchon organising his own protest action for September 23rd. Meanwhile, there is no clear line from the Parti socialiste (PS), the party of the previous government, although some factions have voiced criticism (albeit falling short of endorsing strike action). By contrast, the centre-right Les Républicains has been broadly supportive of the measures. The varied response from the main political actors, combined with the lack of co-ordination among those opposed to the bill, will work in Mr Macron's favour, reducing the likelihood of sustained industrial action and anti-government protests, which might have otherwise forced a watering down of some measures.
President's popularity is set to remain weak
This bodes well for the bill's safe and rapid passage into law, but will do little in the short term to reverse the slide in Mr Macron's popularity. According to a survey conducted by Ifop, a pollster, for Le Journal du Dimanche, a weekly newspaper, Mr Macron's approval ratings slipped by 10 percentage points in July and by a further 14 points in August, to just 40% (significantly lower than his two immediate predecessors, François Hollande and Nicolas Sarkozy, at this stage in their presidencies). In large part this reflected discontent with Mr Macron's governing style, which was elevated and uncommunicative, rarely giving interviews (he has modified this in recent weeks, having realised that more communication was necessary), and political missteps such as his stand-off with General Pierre de Villiers, the former head of the armed forces, over the defence budget.
However, there is also public opposition to some of his policy changes, in particular a reduction of a housing supplement, the aide personnalisée au logement (APL), and the labour reform bill. The government had promised that the bill would promote "flexicurity", whereby labour market regulations would be simplified but in combination with stronger social protection for those who lost their jobs, but there is a sense among the public that the reform bill is more about increased flexibility for firms than better personal security for individuals. There is particular public disquiet about the loss of union representation in negotiations about working conditions.
The labour reform bill addresses important deficiencies in the current system and goes further than measures proposed during recent administrations. It will also benefit from a supportive economic context, with the euro zone experiencing a cyclical upswing at present and growth strengthening in France. However, reforms that make it easier for firms to dismiss workers do not typically result in a pick-up in job-creation on their own. For greater labour market flexibility to lead to a rise in employment, there must also be stronger incentives for firms to hire, a sufficient pool of trained workers and sufficient demand in the economy to make expansion worthwhile. Mr Macron does intend to pass further reforms to make the tax system more conducive to hiring and to expand training programmes, but these are unlikely to be immediate, and his determination to maintain a tight fiscal stance removes one lever that he could have used to boost aggregate demand. In any case, changing perceptions of the attractiveness of France's labour market will not happen overnight. Our forecast is that unemployment will edge down in 2017-18, before falling more noticeably in the final years of Mr Macron's mandate, on the assumption that progress in other areas of the reform agenda contribute to a more holistic improvement in the business environment.
Political outlook: Election watch
We expect political risk to remain high in Europe throughout the forecast period (2017-21). In the euro zone, in particular, the negative political fallout from the financial crisis, coming on top of the long-term erosion of the post-war political party system, is proving to be electorally disruptive. Moreover, recent evidence suggests that fragmentation and difficulties forming a government occur even in countries that are registering solid rates of growth, such as Spain and Ireland, and in traditionally politically stable countries, such as the UK.
Centre right wins Norwegian election
Norway has a history of coalition governments and cross-party consensus that typically delivers a high level of political stability. In the general election held on September 11th the centre-right parties in the Storting (parliament)-comprising the Conservatives, the Progress Party (FrP), the Christian Democrats (KrF) and the Liberals-emerged as the winners of the election, obtaining 88 seats out of 169 in parliament, giving the bloc a working majority of three. This left the centre-left parties with 81 seats, if the Green Party (MDG) is included. Erna Solberg, the leader of the Conservatives and the incumbent prime minister, benefited from the economic recovery and is likely to lead another centre-right government. However, despite securing a three-seat majority in this election, Ms Solberg will face significant challenges in leading another government, largely because the external support provided by the Liberals and the KrF during her previous term in office might no longer be assured.
Although in 2013-17 the ruling coalition could obtain majority support in parliament with the backing of only one of the junior centre-right parties, it will now need the support of both. The Liberals are likely to back Ms Solberg (even if it is unclear at this stage whether they will choose to enter government or remain an external ally), but we expect the KrF to refrain from supporting a government that involves the far-right FrP-a condition on which the party was firm throughout the election campaign. We therefore expect the KrF to go into opposition and to strike deals on a case-by-case basis, leaving the three remaining centre-right parties controlling only 81 seats in the Storting-four short of a majority. This would give the KrF leeway to vote with the centre left against tighter immigrant integration policies while supporting the centre right in business-friendly measures. It would also allow the party to disassociate itself from the expansive oil-drilling policy that both the Conservatives and the FrP defend. If this scenario materialises, we can expect a more protracted policy-making process, which could undermine government effectiveness and make it harder for the future ruling coalition to implement measures sought by the FrP. This could increase political instability in Norway, although it would remain limited by European standards. There are risks to this scenario, however, especially if the Conservatives manage to show the KrF that they will have a stronger hand with the FrP, and if they respond positively to the KrF's demands.
The CDU-CSU looks on course to win the election in Germany
In the September 24th federal election in Germany, currently governed by a grand coalition comprising the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU), its smaller Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD), we expect the CDU to win a plurality of votes, but not a majority of seats. Recent polls show that the CDU has about 37% of public support, ahead of the SPD on 23%. As a result, a variety of CDU-led coalitions are possible, with Angela Merkel remaining as chancellor for a fourth term.
There is a general election in the Czech Republic in October 2017. We forecast that the centrist ANO movement, led by Andrej Babis, a billionaire businessman and until recently the minister of finance, will gain the largest vote share and lead a majority coalition government, provided that it successfully manages any further controversies. A minority ANO-led government or anti-Babis rainbow coalition are alternative, but less likely, options. The next presidential election will be held in January 2018. In March Milos Zeman, aged 72, announced that he would be running for a second term, despite having health problems. Unless the other parties succeed in uniting around a single candidate, which appears unlikely, we expect him to win a second term. Mr Zeman, who has been a controversial and disruptive force in Czech politics in recent years, has forged an alliance with Mr Babis, but it remains to be seen whether this will be maintained after the presidential election.
Following several years of scant reform progress and coalition and party in-fighting in Austria, the grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart in May 2017. This followed the resignation of Reinhold Mitterlehner from the positions of vice-chancellor, minister of economy and leader of the ÖVP, citing frustration within his own party. The popular 31-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, has taken over the leadership of the ÖVP and will run as the party's lead candidate in the early general election on October 15th. Mr Kurz decided to leverage his own popularity by demanding full control over the ÖVP and that the party appear on the ballot as "List Sebastian Kurz-the New People's Party". After Mr Kurz's arrival as party leader the ÖVP shot to the top of the polls, pushing the opposition far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) to third place, from first. The campaign still holds the potential to derail Mr Kurz's efforts, as he is inexperienced, especially on topics relating to economic policy-an area in which his main challenger, the current SPÖ chancellor, Christian Kern, is stronger. However, owing in part to the ÖVP's lead (it is polling around 33%, compared with 25% for the second-placed SPÖ), we expect the ÖVP to emerge as the largest party in the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house of parliament).
The election will be a further step in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the ÖVP will have been replaced to a large extent by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties have together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, and a renewed grand coalition has become almost impossible following the breakdown of relations between the two parties and the gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited both from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz looks to be mostly drawing voters away from the FPÖ, in large part based on his strong stance on immigration and border control.
The most likely coalition to emerge after the election is one led by the ÖVP, with the FPÖ as a junior coalition partner, as the other parties-including the Greens; NEOS, a liberal party; and List Pilz, a new group recently set up by Peter Pilz, a former Green member of parliament (MP)-are unlikely to be large enough to help either the SPÖ or the ÖVP to reach a parliamentary majority. Risks to this outlook are high, as the election could turn, and coalition negotiations could falter because the FPÖ will probably demand significant concessions from Mr Kurz. Regardless of which coalition emerges, we expect political stability to deteriorate further. The government will struggle to implement its policies, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters and the FPÖ is likely to struggle to translate its opposition on matters such as immigration and integration into concrete policy proposals. As a result, we expect little progress on significant structural reforms, and the risk of an early election in the next parliamentary term is high.
Iceland is to hold its second snap poll in the space of a year
On October 28th Iceland is set to hold its second snap election within a year, after the collapse of the coalition government, consisting of Bright Future (BF), the Independence Party (IP) and Vidreisn (Reform). On September 15th BF announced its withdrawal from the coalition, citing a "serious breach of trust within the government". This referred to recent news that Benedikt Sveinsson, a judge and the father of the prime minister and IP leader, Bjarni Benediktsson, had granted a controversial "restored honour" letter (which expunges a criminal record) to Hjalti Sigurjon Hauksson, who was convicted of raping his stepdaughter. Following a ruling by a parliamentary committee, the Ministry of Justice revealed the information, of which Mr Benediktsson had reportedly been aware since July. The news is likely to undermine further public trust in government, which had already been seriously damaged by the panama Papers leak in April 2016. The leak implicated the then prime minister, and prompted an early election, held in October 2016.
The election fragmented Iceland's parliament, making the government formation process extremely difficult and protracted. As such, the collapse of the government does not come as a big surprise. Coalition formation talks between the IP, BF and Vidreisn had already failed once before they reached an agreement in January 2017. BF provided the IP-led coalition with only four seats, but its withdrawal was enough to bring about the collapse of the government, which had only a one-seat majority in the 63-seat parliament. The IP has 21 seats and Vidreisn has seven. A snap election risks returning BF to the political sidelines, as the party has fallen below the 4% threshold for parliamentary representation in recent opinion polls, although it is possible that its support will increase in the wake of these events.
Before the next parliamentary election in Italy, which we expect to take place in early 2018, the regional election in Sicily on November 5th could provide some indication of the relative strength of the political parties and their ability to form electoral coalitions. However, we continue to expect that the main contest at the parliamentary election will be between the PD and M5S. Support for the two parties remains broadly similar, at about 30%, according to opinion polls. Although M5S's credibility has been dented by recent political blunders and local-level scandals-most notably in the city government of Rome-we expect it to emerge as the largest party, boosted by Mr Renzi's defeat in the referendum, the split in the PD and an increase in anti-politics sentiment. However, under a strongly proportional voting system, we expect that M5S will not obtain a majority of parliamentary seats. This would require it to enter a coalition with other parties to form a government. Given M5S's hardline stance towards the established parties across the political spectrum, and these parties' concerns about M5S's policies, we believe it unlikely that M5S would succeed. It is more likely that the established parties will be persuaded to join forces to keep M5S out of government, leading to the establishment of an unstable coalition between the centre left and the centre right.
Recent polls suggest that the centre-right parties, led by Forza Italia (FI) and the Lega Nord, could hypothetically outperform both the PD and M5S. However, a durable alliance remains elusive, and it is unclear whether a broad centre-right formation would poll as well as the sum of its constituent parties. Moreover, there is no consensus on who would head such a coalition; Silvio Berlusconi, FI's leader, remains reluctant to accept the leadership of the Lega Nord's Matteo Salvini, who opinion polls suggest is the favoured candidate among centre-right supporters.
In Spain the political dysfunction has been pronounced. At end-October 2016, following an inconclusive general election in December 2015 and a re-run ballot six months later, parliament elected Mariano Rajoy, the leader of the conservative Popular Party (PP), prime minister for a second term. However, Mr Rajoy's PP minority government is one of the weakest in Spain's democratic history, and we do not expect it to serve a full four-year term. It relies on just 170 votes-those of the PP, Ciudadanos (Citizens) and the Canary Island Coalition (CC)-in the 350-seat Congress of Deputies (the lower house of parliament).
We do not expect an early election until 2018 (when budget negotiations could prove to be a trigger point) or 2019. That the PP is keen to claim credit for strong economic growth and is currently topping opinion polls further supports this view, although the gap with the second-placed PSOE has begun to narrow. Over the medium term Spanish politics will remain fluid, with scant prospects for major political or economic reforms until a stronger administration enters office.
Another source of instability is the separatist challenge posed by Catalonia. The regional government has scheduled an independence referendum for October 1st, which it will consider binding, regardless of turnout. We believe that the vote is likely to go ahead in some form, and to deliver a strong vote for independence, but participation will be low, as the region's unionist political parties will boycott the ballot. The government's most likely response will be to ignore the result, ruthlessly prosecuting the referendum's organisers and using other legal means to prevent the regional government from breaking away. Ultimately, we think that Catalonia is unlikely to secede from Spain, although tensions in the region remain high, and there is a significant risk of unrest and a legal stand-off in the aftermath of the vote.
A presidential election will take place in Russia in March 2018. We expect Vladimir Putin, the president, to contest the election and win by a wide margin in the first round, owing to the lack of any credible alternative candidate. Aleksei Navalny, an anti-corruption campaigner and one of the most dynamic of the "non-systemic" opposition leaders, will probably be barred from participating following a second conviction for de-frauding Kirovles, a timber company. This suggests that the authorities intend to run a tightly controlled contest, offering voters no meaningful alternatives to Mr Putin. The main challenge for the authorities will be to prevent a sharp fall in turnout, which would cast doubt on the legitimacy of Mr Putin's popular mandate.
The next parliamentary and presidential elections in Turkey are due to be held in 2019, but they could be called earlier if Mr Erdogan decides to accelerate the transfer of executive powers to the presidency once the institutions and instruments of the new presidential system are in place. Given the popularity of the president, and his party's ability to control the election process, we expect Mr Erdogan to win the presidential election and to remain in office with enhanced powers for at least one more five-year term, if not two (the maximum allowed), up to 2029. His popularity is unrivalled, and the opposition is fragmented and currently appears to have no candidates capable of challenging him.

Political outlook: The inevitable chancellor's new coalition
The main question ahead of the federal election on September 24th is not who will win the largest share of the vote, but which party or parties will join the probable winner, the Christian Democratic Union (CDU), in forming a coalition, with the current chancellor, Angela Merkel, again at the helm.
Current polls suggest that the CDU could have its pick of a single smaller party, either The Greens or the liberal Free Democratic Party (FDP), or form a coalition with both. It could also form another grand coalition with the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD).
As the margins are likely to be small, it remains impossible to say which exact coalition will emerge, although The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that another grand coalition is unlikely, in part because the SPD will be hesitant to enter another one.
For domestic policy, the differences will be limited. However, the smaller parties have considerably different views on reform of the euro zone. We expect this to factor into Ms Merkel's considerations for her choice of coalition partner, but it could also prove to be a brake on euro zone reform in the coming years.
Opinion polls have in recent months moved decisively in favour of Ms Merkel, both for her party and her personal approval rating. With the gap between the CDU and the SPD widening in the closing weeks of the election campaign, we expect the CDU to win the largest share of the vote. Ms Merkel has captured most of the middle ground in a country that has enjoyed several years of economic stability and growth, with a recent poll showing that 81% of the electorate are happy with their own economic situation-a historical high. She has thereby turned herself and her party into the default option for a large part of the electorate, who would clearly prefer stability to a shake-up of the apparently satisfying status quo. This has made it difficult for any challengers to come up with a platform on which to oppose her, especially now that the political salience of the refugee issue has diminished, as inflows have returned to normal levels after spiking during the European migrant crisis in 2015-16.
SPD struggles to stand out
Martin Schulz, the former president of the European Parliament who took over the leadership of the SPD in early 2017, has evidently been found lacking in this regard by the German electorate. Following a short period of hype after his arrival on the domestic political scene-as he had spent most of his career in Brussels, he was largely unknown in Germany-both his personal approval ratings and his party's poll ratings have fallen back to only just above where they were at the end of 2016. His emphasis on social justice and on rolling back many of the labour market reforms that many Germans credit with the country's recent economic success has not captured the electorate's imagination. That the SPD seems not to have changed its election strategy since then, building its campaign so far around Mr Schulz and emphasising the same issues, has in our view made it even more unlikely that the SPD will pose a serious threat to the CDU.
The most interesting question that will be answered in the election is how the smaller parties will fare, as this will determine the type of coalition that will emerge. All of the smaller parties that are likely to cross the 5% electoral threshold-the FDP, The Greens, the Left Party and the far-right, populist Alternative for Germany (AfD)-are polling around 8-10%. However, the exact number of seats that they manage to win will be crucial for the subsequent coalition talks, as this will determine the number of parties needed for a CDU-led majority coalition.
Domestic policy stable, movement on euro zone reform possible
Assuming that the CDU wins the largest share of the vote, it will be first in line to try to form a coalition. The SPD would be highly unlikely to take the lead in forming a government in this event, as the three left-wing parties would almost certainly fall short of a majority of seats in the Bundestag (the lower house of parliament), and in any case the SPD remains hesitant to work with the Left Party (the hard-left successor to East Germany's communist party).
We see four possible CDU-led coalitions after the election. Current polls suggest that it will be close as to whether the CDU and its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), will be able to form a coalition with just one of the smaller parties or whether they will need two. We believe that there is some upside risk to the CDU's eventual vote share, making a two-party coalition without the SPD more likely to be possible.
The different coalitions would implement different domestic policies, for instance regarding the balance between tax cuts and additional public investment-the large fiscal surpluses in recent years have led to a broadly shared understanding that fiscal room has opened up-but we expect the differences to be relatively modest. A CDU-Green coalition would enact more green policies, for example expediting the closure of coal-fired power plants, and the FDP would demand large tax cuts. However, in part given the satisfaction with the status quo, we would not expect any party to push for a large-scale reform effort. The major question of interest will be to what degree Germany will be willing to work together with France to reform the institutions of the euro zone and, for instance, set up a European Monetary Fund. The CDU-CSU's choice of coalition partner or partners will have a large influence on this-although Germany will in any case only agree to increased risk-sharing if it is accompanied by increased oversight of national economic and budgetary policies.
Some coalitions would be less willing to work with the French president
The most natural ally for the CDU, based both on historical experience and overlap in election programmes, would be the FDP, with which Ms Merkel formed her second coalition government in 2009-13. The FDP would also be by far the preferred partner for the CSU, which tends to be slightly to the right of the CDU, especially under Ms Merkel. Although the FDP has been at pains to declare that it does not plan to enter government after the election, this is likely to be political posturing to make sure that potential voters do not defect to the CDU.
However, the FDP has taken a hard line on European issues, including against many of the reforms suggested by the new French president, Emmanuel Macron. Senior CDU figures, including Ms Merkel and the notoriously hardline finance minister, Wolfgang Schäuble, have already expressed a willingness to implement reform of the euro zone, including possibly more risk pooling. The CDU's willingness to move on this issue is visible in one of its campaign slogans, which claims that "strengthening Europe means strengthening Germany". The FDP would thus present a significant barrier to implementing the kind of reform that Ms Merkel might see as the crowning achievement of her decade-and-a-half chancellorship, or simply as a necessary step for the EU and the euro zone.
The second option would be a CDU-Green coalition. Although we do not have any privileged insight into Ms Merkel's thinking, we would expect this to be her preferred coalition partner. She has gravitated towards The Greens in recent years in policy terms, if not in outcomes then at least in perceptions among the voting public. In its election programme the CDU opened up this option by arguing for the medium- to long-term abolition of coal-fired power plants, one of the few hard requirements for The Greens for participation in government. The Greens have embraced the agenda set out by Mr Macron and would therefore not be a hindrance to euro zone reform efforts. Furthermore, this would allow Ms Merkel to sideline those forces within the CDU opposed to reform of the euro zone, which are sizeable and could in themselves threaten these efforts given the need for consensus in the German political system.
A coalition between the CDU, the FDP and The Greens (referred to as the Jamaica coalition in reference to the parties' colours matching the Jamaican flag) would come into view if the CDU and either The Greens or the FDP do not have a majority together, or if the majority is prohibitively small. Coalition negotiations would be significantly more difficult in such a case, as The Greens and the FDP are far apart on several issues-although such a coalition was recently agreed in the state of Schleswig-Holstein. This would also create a more complicated picture for euro zone reform, but given the balance within the coalition, we would expect an outcome closer to that of a CDU-Green coalition than one with the FDP.
The final realistic option would be for another grand coalition, which would be the third under Ms Merkel. Despite some rumblings from CDU and SPD officials that they do not want to embark on another grand coalition, the election programmes presented by both parties remain close enough that they could come to a credible coalition agreement. However, although the CDU would probably be amenable to continuing with the current coalition, this would make it difficult for the SPD to differentiate itself from the CDU, and we would expect the party to be hesitant for this reason. On the domestic front, such a coalition would probably lead to a continuation of the current bargaining between the two parties. As they are relatively well-aligned on EU and euro zone issues, this combination would guarantee strong German support for reforms of the euro zone.
Political outlook: Intra-regional tensions
East-West political tensions in the region are at their highest since the dissolution of the Soviet Union. Russia is slowly dismantling the security and arms control agreements that were put in place in at the end of the cold war. Russia's opposition to the post-cold war security architecture was evident in its decision to withdraw from the Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe and its breach of the 1987 Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) treaty, which bans short- and medium-range ballistic missiles. Western countries have accused Russia of funding opposition parties in western Europe and employing cyber warfare against Western targets, as well as engaging in a propaganda war though media outlets that it controls in the West.
Tensions with Russia are unlikely to abate
Russia accuses the EU and the US of interfering in its sphere of influence, supporting the so-called "Colour Revolutions" in former Soviet space. Russia has accused NATO of going back on its post-cold war commitments by expanding relentlessly, first taking in central Europe and the Baltic republics, then Albania and Croatia in 2009 and, most recently, Montenegro in June 2017. Bosnia and Hercegovina, Macedonia and Georgia are now in the waiting room for admission. The Iraq War and Colour Revolutions fuelled Russian insecurity and convinced Russia that the US wanted "regime change" in the country, and possibly the break-up of the Russian Federation. In the face of such an existential threat, from the Kremlin's perspective any counter-measures are justified.
In March 2014 Russia annexed Crimea and has since been providing military support to pro-Russian rebels in eastern Ukraine. The EU imposed sanctions on Russia's energy, defence and banking sectors in July 2014 following the downing of a passenger plane over Ukrainian territory controlled by Russian-backed separatists. The sanctions are subject to regular renewal, requiring the approval of all 28 EU member states.
The Minsk II ceasefire agreement, signed in February 2015, is highly unlikely to lead to a resolution of the conflict in Ukraine. Russia sees Ukrainian integration with the EU and NATO as a direct threat to its national interests. The current status quo, of a regularly breached ceasefire with contained levels of fighting, seems likely to endure for several years. This will serve Russia's interests, as a frozen conflict will prevent any Ukrainian move towards the EU.
Russia will remain vehemently opposed to EU and NATO integration with the countries of the former Soviet Union. Regime change in any country in Russia's immediate neighbourhood, particularly via a popular uprising similar to the Ukrainian Maidan revolution in 2014, would trigger a crisis in relations between Russia and the West.
Policy-related tensions remain high within the euro zone, but the risk that they will prompt a breakdown in inter-governmental relations has fallen sharply over the past year, as economic growth has picked up across the bloc. The ECB has successfully overcome objections in a number of countries-notably in Germany-to its use of unconventional policy in-struments. However, the breathing space created by the ECB's programme of sovereign quantitative easing (QE) has, up to now, not been used by political leaders to bolster the economic recovery with a strong united position on fiscal policy and structural reform. This might change after the recent elections in France (and the UK), where there are calls for an easing of fiscal austerity.
The rise of anti-establishment political sentiment across much of the bloc has generated increased pressure for economic policymaking that is focused on national considerations rather than on the integrity of the euro zone, creating new centrifugal forces at a time when policymakers are already struggling to remedy the institutional shortcomings of the single currency. Huge political capital has been invested in keeping the euro zone together in recent years. This should ensure its survival in the short term, but the risk of a partial break-up in the medium term remains significant. We attach a 60% probability to Greece leaving the euro zone during our five-year forecast period.
The refugee relocation policy will be a bone of contention in the EU
The issue of refugee relocation is a focal point for existing tensions between integration-minded countries of west Europe and a core of central European countries. In September 2015 the European Council established a temporary scheme to relocate across the EU some of the Syrian refugees who had arrived in Italy and Greece, with the aim of sharing the burden of accommodating them. This was particularly controversial in central and eastern Europe, where governments characterised it as an attempt by western Europe to export the consequences of misguided foreign policies, and raised the prospect of terrorist attacks as a result of Islamist infiltration. Public opposition to the scheme has been high across the region.
Tension between Turkey and the EU will remain high
Despite talk of agreeing a new roadmap to ease tensions and improve co-operation in the main areas of interest such as security, trade and investment, neither Turkey nor the EU is genuinely interested in Turkish membership of the bloc anymore. However, neither has yet been willing to suspend negotiations unilaterally. If Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, as Mr Erdogan has suggested, the EU might not be able to avoid suspending the process. The sus-pension of accession negotiations would almost certainly prompt Turkey to end its collaboration with the EU to stem the movement of migrants and refugees into Europe. A settlement of the de facto division of Cyprus between the Greek Cypriot south and the Turkish Cypriot north could help to improve Turkey's relations with the EU, but talks collapsed in July 2017. We maintain our forecast that a settlement is unlikely during the forecast period.
Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved. Russia has lifted almost all sanctions, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly in relation to the conflict in Syria, where both are militarily involved but have pursued contrasting goals. We expect relations to remain largely transactional, and the risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Since January 2017 tensions with Greece have escalated over Cyprus, disputed islands in the Aegean and the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's application for the extradition of Turkish military officers who fled to Greece after the July 2016 coup attempt. We expect relations to remain tense, with sporadic flare-ups, but we do not expect an outbreak of conflict.
Political outlook: Hungary leads defiance of ECJ ruling on refugee relocations
The Hungarian foreign minister, Peter Szijjarto, has said that his country will continue to challenge the EU's policy of sharing out some of the refugees that arrived in Greece and Italy during the migration crisis among the other EU members. Mr Szijjarto's comments followed remarks by the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, who said in a newspaper interview on September 12th that it was "unacceptable" that Hungary was defying a judgment by the European Court of Justice (ECJ), which had ruled that the EU's policy on relocating refugees was legal and proportionate. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Hungary's nationalist government and its ally, Poland, to continue refusing to accept their quotas of refugees-in contrast to Slovakia, which has said that it will comply with the ruling. The fourth member of the Visegrad group of countries, the Czech Republic, is unlikely to adopt a clear response until after the upcoming election in October.
The ruling by the ECJ, pronounced on September 6th, came in response to a legal challenge to the EU's refugee relocation policy originally launched by Hungary and Slovakia in December 2015. The two countries had taken their case to the ECJ three months after the EU countries decided, by a majority vote, to redistribute 120,000 refugees-mostly from the Middle East-who were stuck in Greece and Italy, following a huge inflow of migrants. At the time of the EU's meeting in September 2015 four countries-the Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia-voted against the decision to share out the refugees.
In dismissing Hungary and Slovakia's legal actions "in their entirety", the ECJ ruled that the decision by a qualified majority of EU countries was lawful, justified by the emergency posed by the unprecedentedly large inflow of displaced persons. The court also noted that the relative ineffectiveness of the relocation programme-only about 28,000 refugees have been moved from Greece and Italy in the past two years-was no reason to question the legality of the policy. European Commission officials have explained that, apart from the non-compliance of several east-central European states, another reason for the small number of relocations was that fewer people than anticipated in 2015 were actually eligible to benefit from the scheme.
ECJ judgment boosts European Commission's stance
The ECJ ruling will strengthen the hand of the Commission, which in June 2017 launched an infringement procedure against the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland for their failure to comply with the relocation policy. According to the Commission, Hungary and Poland have not accepted any refugees, and the Czech Republic stopped doing so in August 2016.
Despite the ECJ's clear ruling, Hungary and Poland have both indicated that they will not change their stance on this issue. Both countries are led by nationalist, socially conservative governments, which claim that they are protecting the Christian identity of their countries against an inflow of mainly Muslim migrants. They also blame the recent flare-up in Islamist terrorist incidents in a number of west European countries on the affected states' more liberal asylum policies.
The Polish prime minister, Beata Szydlo, has said that the ECJ's judgment will not change her government's position on immigration. Her Hungarian counterpart, Viktor Orban, has argued that although the ECJ's ruling needs to be "acknowledged", it applies only to the legality of the EU's policy and not to its implementation. For that reason, he has said that Hungary will maintain its policy of rejecting immigration, adding that the "real battle" against the EU's relocation programme is just beginning.
Slovakia will not follow Hungarian-Polish defiant stance
The defiant statements of the Hungarian and Polish governments are in stark contrast to Slovakia's more accommodating approach. Despite challenging the EU's relocation policy before the ECJ, Slovakia has been in compliance with the programme, taking in one more than the minimum number of refugees it is required to accept. It is therefore not one of the targets of the Commission's infringement procedure, and the Slovak prime minister, Robert Fico, has made it clear that his country will respect the ECJ's judgment.
Unlike Hungary and Poland, whose illiberal policies have prompted the Commission to launch a number of infringement procedures against them, Slovakia is well integrated into the EU's mainstream both politically and economically. It is the only member of the Visegrad group to be in the euro area; its government fully appreciates the benefits of EU membership; and it has no wish to be embroiled in disputes with Germany and other leading members of the EU.
The Czech Republic has adopted an approach somewhere between the two positions represented by Hungary and Poland on the one hand and Slovakia on the other. Czech leaders have said that they are not opposed to the relocation policy in principle, but that their country can continue to do more by providing financial assistance to the countries directly affected by the refugee problem. However, the Czech Republic could adopt a more co-operative approach after the election, scheduled for October 20th-21st, when the new government will be under less pressure to accommodate anti-migrant sentiment among the electorate.
Hungary and Poland are set to pay a price for non-compliance
If the defiance of the ECJ's ruling continues, the infringement procedure could result in fines being imposed on Hungary, Poland and possibly the Czech Republic (although only a handful more refugees would need to be taken in by the Czech Republic to meet the minimum criteria). However, the fines are likely to be relatively small in the context of the huge transfers that hese countries receive each year from the EU's structural and cohesion funds: they are, along with Romania, the largest net beneficiaries of EU assistance.
In the case of Hungary and Poland, the nationalist governments-which are in dispute with the Commission on a broad range of issues-believe that they have little to gain politically on their home ground by accepting the ECJ's ruling. This is especially so in the case of Hungary, where the ruling party, Fidesz-Hungarian Civic Union (Fidesz), faces a challenge from the far-right, anti-immigrant Jobbik party ahead of the next election, due in April 2018. Given these domestic political concerns, both Hungary and Poland will continue to challenge EU institutions, bringing the two countries into greater conflict with Germany, France and other EU members that insist on burden sharing and respect for the rule of law.
Economic policy
A conservative fiscal bias has prevailed across most of the region since the global crisis in 2008-09, leaving policymakers to rely heavily on low interest rates and unconventional monetary policy tools as the main levers with which to manage their economies. This created a significant degree of exposure to the impact of the monetary policy cycle in the US, where The Economist Intelligence Unit expects further tightening over the forecast period (2017-21). Although we continue to expect monetary policy to remain accommodative in most countries, we now expect fiscal policies to be slightly more supportive during the forecast period.
Upheaval since the EU referendum drives a shift in UK's policy framework
The UK faces particularly stark economic policy challenges following its decision in a referendum in June 2016 to withdraw from the EU. Leaving the EU will represent a break with decades of settled policy and, depending on how negotiations with the remaining member states proceed, could require a major reconfiguration of the country's regional and global trade, investment and migration ties. In response to the referendum result, monetary policy in the UK was loosened further, but with consumer price inflation including owner occupiers' housing costs (CPIH) rising to 2.7% in August 2017, well above the official 2% target of the Bank of England (BoE, the UK central bank), and sterling likely to remain under pressure, the balance of opinion within the monetary policy committee (MPC) has shifted. If the economy remains resilient to Brexit uncertainty in the coming months, there is a chance that a majority of MPC members will vote to reverse last year's move to cut the interest rate from 0.5%. However, if there is building evidence that the economy is slowing, the prospect of a rate increase will fade.
Importantly, the absence of a pick-up in wage growth reduces the chance that domestically driven price pressure will persist after exchange-rate effects have faded. Nevertheless, MPC members have demonstrated a reduced tolerance for above-target inflation and a desire to return interest rates to more "normal" levels, suggesting that the discussion on tightening will persist, especially as domestic demand picks up post-Brexit in 2019. We assume that the BoE will remain cautious in 2020, but as economic growth accelerates and inflation looks set to rise above target, we expect a 25-basis-point increase in interest rates in the first quarter of 2021, and another later in the year. The pace at which the BoE will tighten monetary policy will be gradual, and subdued wage growth will remain a downside risk to this forecast.
Another country in which the overall economic policy framework has been clouded by uncertainty is Turkey. Concerns about the policymaking implications of political instability deepened following the failed coup attempt in July 2016. However, since the approval in a referendum in April 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency, household, business and investor sentiment has improved, and the lira and the economy have continued to recover. Given the healthy state of Turkey's public finances, the government is using the considerable room that it has to loosen fiscal policy and support the economy. Despite its concerns about growth, it has allowed the Central Bank of Turkey to tighten monetary policy to counter severe pressure on the lira in early 2017 and a surge in inflation. With the US likely to raise interest rates further this year, we expect the central bank to have to keep monetary policy tight for some time, until inflationary pressures ease.
In Russia the fall in oil prices, which led to a significant contraction in real GDP and household consumption in 2015-16, has underlined the imperative for reforms to encourage investment and diversification away from commodity exports. Two competing centres of expertise-one under Aleksei Kudrin, a former minister of finance, and the other centred around the Stolypin Group, headed by Boris Titov, the business ombudsman-have put forward contrasting proposals for structural reforms. However, we do not expect significant reforms to be undertaken before the presidential election in 2018. We expect Vladimir Putin, the incumbent, to be re-elected and to continue prioritising social and political stability. We expect state involvement in the economy to remain substantial. Reform of the tax system and a gradual rise in the pension age appear likely. Institutional reform to strengthen the rule of law and protection for businesses looks much more difficult to achieve.
