We expect fiscal consolidation to exert a much less powerful drag on growth over the forecast period compared with the preceding five years. Almost all European countries improved their fiscal positions in 2009-16, with the star performers being Iceland (by 26.1 percentage points of GDP), Greece (15.8), Ireland (13.1) and Lithuania (9.4). In the EU only Spain and France had deficits larger than the EU's 3% of GDP limit in 2016 (4.5% and 3.4% respectively). Although we expect fiscal policies to be slightly more supportive of economic growth, significant fiscal loosening remains off the agenda for most countries, especially for those with high public debt loads, owing to the rigidity of the rules agreed by EU members at the height of the euro zone crisis. The average EU government debt/GDP ratio was 85.6% at end-2016, but Belgium, Cyprus, Greece, Italy and Portugal had debt ratios in excess of 100%, and those for France and Spain were only slightly below 100%. Hefty debt loads will remain a challenge for much of the euro zone for many years, although the cost of debt servicing has fallen dramatically owing to the exceptionally low interest rates that currently prevail across the bloc.
IMF and EU disagree on Greek government debt sustainability
A long-running disagreement between the IMF and some euro zone members on the sustainability of Greece's public debt and debt relief for Greece cast doubt over the country's ability to meet a July 2017 deadline for EUR7bn of bond repayments. However, a Eurogroup meeting on June 15th resulted in an agreement to disburse EUR8.5bn to Greece in two tranches in early July, following the conclusion of the second bail-out programme review. The IMF's managing director agreed in principle to support Greece with a stand-by programme, pending approval by the IMF board. However, there was no agreement on debt relief for Greece, with a discussion of the issue being deferred until after the end of the third bail-out programme, in August 2018. The government is hoping to establish a track record of borrowing on the international capital markets over the coming year and to be invited to join the quantitative easing (QE) programme of the European Central bank (ECB). These are preconditions for Greece avoiding having to sign a fourth bail-out programme. We are not convinced that these preconditions will be met.
The UK's vote to leave the EU has transformed the fiscal outlook
The UK's fiscal position improved in 2016, but we forecast that the deficit will increase to 3.6% of GDP in 2017, from 3% of GDP last year, and will stay at around that level in 2018, as we expect the government to ease off from imposing further austerity policies. The chancellor of the exchequer, Philip Hammond, is likely to end the seven-year public-sector pay freeze for some state employees and announce new spending plans in the autumn budget, including extra spending on health and education. The government had already retreated (in November 2016) from previous plans to balance the budget by fiscal year 2019/20, and we do not expect this to be achieved by the end of the current parliament in 2022. Before the June 2017 snap election was called, Mr Hammond had aimed to return the budget to balance "as early as possible" in the next parliament. The target leaves some fiscal room for manoeuvre, although this would be undermined in the event that the economic fallout from Brexit is more severe than we expect.
Within the EU, over the past year a number of national governments have shown signs of pushing back against centralised fiscal constraints, which are significantly more rigorous as a result of changes introduced in response to the crisis. In 2016 tensions between several member states and the European Commission, which enforces the EU's budgetary rules, came to a head. In early July 2016 the Commission proposed that Spain and Portugal should be fined for their failure to meet deficit targets in 2015, but the Commission ultimately stepped back from this position. The episode highlighted the growing tension between the strict fiscal rules agreed at the height of the crisis and the mounting political and economic arguments within member states for a greater degree of fiscal flexibility.
The fiscal position has deteriorated across the former Soviet Union
The steep fall in commodity prices and the sharp reduction in export demand and remittance inflows from Russia caused a significant deterioration in economic conditions across the former Soviet Union in 2015-16. This has contributed to a general deterioration in the fiscal picture across the region. The three major former Soviet oil exporters-Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Russia-were particularly hard hit and drew down reserves from their sovereign wealth funds to cover wider budget deficits and maintain investment as bank lending fell. All three countries have announced privatisation programmes to plug funding gaps, but we remain sceptical about the scope and pace of these plans. Russia completed the sale of a 19.5% stake in Rosneft, a major oil producer, in December 2016; however, the terms of the deal remain unclear and the state retains control of the company. Russia's financing challenges are acute, as international sanctions make it difficult for the country to increase foreign borrowing. However, despite international sanctions and the reluctance of Western banks to handle international bond issuances, Russia placed two Eurobonds in mid-June 2017, which were oversubscribed.
In 2016 the deficit was the equivalent of 3.4% of GDP; however, this included extraordinary income from the sale of a stake in Rosneft. Without this the deficit would have exceeded 4% of GDP. The Russian Ministry of Finance has put forward ambitious austerity measures that, if implemented in full, would decrease spending by the equivalent of 2-3% of GDP in three years. We do not expect the ministry to succeed in holding expenditure steady in nominal terms in 2017-19 as it intends, owing in part to the presidential election in 2018. However, revenue planning has been set on the basis of a conservative oil price, and we therefore expect the budget deficit to shrink to 0.7% of GDP by 2021.
Weak institutional structures, high inflation and rapid currency depreciation have limited the ability of many countries in the region to respond to the economic slowdown with an expansive fiscal policy. Tajikistan, which has experienced a serious banking crisis, is seeking funding from the IMF, but is more likely to receive further bilateral support from China or Russia. The most notable exception in Central Asia is Kazakhstan, which is drawing on its substantial reserves to implement an ambitious counter-cyclical spending programme to offset the impact of falling household demand. The country avoided recession in 2016, recording real GDP growth of 0.9%. This is nevertheless significantly below the average growth rate of the past ten years.
Economic policy: Monetary policy and exchange rates

In most of Europe monetary policy remains exceptionally accommodative, and we expect this to remain the case throughout the forecast period. We expect the Bank of England to begin raising rates in 2021, although it is possible that a rate rate rise could come sooner than this. We expect the ECB to begin to taper its QE programme in 2018, but that its first rate increase will not take place until 2022.
We expect tapering of the ECB's QE programme to begin in 2018
The euro zone economy is showing increasing momentum and we expect an acceleration in growth to 2.1% this year, after growth of 1.8% on average in 2015-16. Nonetheless, the ECB is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero and a EUR60bn per month QE programme, which will run until the end of 2017. The ECB continues to take stock of this growth momentum, and has revealed that it may make an announcement on the future of its QE programme in October. We maintain our view that the bank will begin to wind down gradually, or "taper", the programme in 2018. Nevertheless, underlying price pressure remains relatively subdued, and downside risks to wage growth and the global economy during that year could yet slow the pace at which the ECB will reduce its monthly asset purchases. We forecast that the ECB will raise policy rates in 2022, although there is a high risk that this move will be brought forward to 2021.
The euro has moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1 since mid-2015. The annual average exchange rate was US$1.11:EUR1 in 2016, although a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. The euro has since rallied to US$1.20:EUR1 as the region's economic recovery has strengthened, and as political risk has waned in Europe but risen in the US. More recently, a rise in expectations of QE tapering by the ECB has prompted a sharp appreciation in the euro against the dollar. The value of the euro could yet come under pressure from political risk-especially in relation to the next general election in Italy, which we expect to take place in early 2018-and monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a gradual appreciation through 2020-21, as the euro is supported by an ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus, whereas the business cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020.
The BoE is likely to hold rates down until 2021
In 2016 the BoE took several steps to limit the financial and economic fallout from the Brexit vote. Since August 2016 the MPC has kept the main policy interest rate at 0.25%, the stock of government bond purchases at £435bn (US$581bn) and the stock of corporate bond purchases at £10bn. It also launched a Term Funding Scheme (TFS) for banks, the drawdown period for which will end after February 2018.
A rapid depreciation of the pound following the Brexit vote has exacerbated inflationary pressure, with the result that inflation has overshot its 2% target since February 2017. If the economy remains resilient to Brexit uncertainty in the coming months, there is a chance that a majority of MPC members will vote to reverse last year's move to cut the interest rate from 0.5%. However, if there is building evidence that the economy is slowing, the prospect of a rate increase will fade.
Importantly, the absence of a pick-up in wage growth reduces the chance that domestically driven price pressure will persist after exchange-rate effects have faded. Nevertheless, MPC members have demonstrated a reduced tolerance for above-target inflation and a desire to return interest rates to more "normal" levels, suggesting that the discussion on tightening will persist, especially as domestic demand picks up post-Brexit. We assume that the BoE will remain cautious in 2020, but as economic growth accelerates and inflation looks set to rise above target, we expect a 25-basis-point increase in interest rates in the first quarter of 2021, and another later in the year. The pace at which the BoE will tighten monetary policy will be gradual, and subdued wage growth will remain a downside risk to this forecast.
There was a sharp drop in the external value of sterling after the Brexit vote, reflecting investor unease about the implications of the vote. Sensitivity in the foreign-exchange markets to the Brexit news flow means that the value of the pound has remained volatile, albeit within a range of US$1.20-1.27:£1 until April 18th, when Theresa May, the prime minister, called the snap election. This initially boosted the value of the pound, but it fell back sharply in June in response to the shock result. By July it had started to strengthen again, reaching a post-referendum high of US$1.32:£1 in early August. The pound weakened again in response to data pointing to a softening in economic activity, but has since appreciated back to US$1.35:£1 by mid-September, after a stronger than expected inflation outturn and commentary from the BoE that revived expect-ations of tighter monetary policy. We forecast that sterling will depreciate against the US dollar and the euro on average in the next few years as the economy slows. However, we expect the pound to make a gradual recovery against the dollar in the final years of the forecast period.
Policy to be kept tight to support the Turkish lira and lower inflation
Political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey to lower interest rates to revive economic activity has eased as the government has switched its attention to Turkey's profitable commercial banks. We expect that the central bank will have to keep its monetary policy tight in the remainder of 2017 and in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent a further depreciation of the lira amid expectations of higher US interest rates and balance-sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank). To do this, we expect the Turkish central bank to use a mix of interest rate rises, macroprudential measures and other policies. The bank raised most of its main policy rates between November 2016 and April 2017, and has increasingly provided funding to the banking sector at its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate, which was gradually raised by a total of 250 basis points, to 12.25%, in late April. In mid-September 2017 the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system was about 12%, compared with 7.8% in November 2016.
The central bank is seeking to normalise gradually its monetary policy frame-work to establish a single policy interest rate, which would help to improve transparency regarding monetary policy decisions. However, it is unlikely that this will happen until inflation is more firmly on a downward path towards its medium-term target of 5% and domestic political uncertainty eases.
The Turkish lira has been highly volatile and on a generally depreciating path against all major currencies since mid-2013, when the prospect of a gradual reduction in ultra-loose global liquidity and an eventual tightening of policy took shape. Amid further bouts of volatility we expect the lira to depreciate against the US dollar, to an annual average of TL3.56:US$1 in 2017-a fall of about 15% compared with 2016. In 2018-21 we forecast that the exchange rate will remain broadly stable in real terms, depreciating in nominal terms to an average of TL3.80:US$1 in 2021. The lira will also depreciate sharply against the euro in 2017-21. There are substantial risks to our exchange-rate forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows as well as the impact on investor confidence of domestic political tensions and geopolitical turmoil in the region surrounding Turkey.
Inflationary pressures have continued to weaken in Russia in 2017
In Russia inflation averaged 15.5% in 2015 as the sharp depreciation of the rouble in the fourth quarter of 2014 fed through into high import prices. A combination of weak demand and relatively tight monetary policy by the Central Bank of Russia (CBR) led to significant disinflation in 2016; over the year as a whole inflation averaged 7%. Inflation fell from 5.4% year on year in December 2016 to 3.9% in July, meaning that the CBR is on track to achieve its end-of-year inflation target (currently set at 4%). Disinflation has been assisted by strong harvests last year and this year, as well as the relative strength of the rouble. We forecast that consumer price inflation will decline further in the second half of the year, to average 4.1% in 2017. External inflationary pressures are likely to be relatively low. Tax changes in 2019 are expected to push up inflation to 4.8% in that year. Overall, we expect inflation to remain close to-but slightly above-target in 2018-21.
For central and east European countries with currencies pegged to or managed against the euro (mostly in the western Balkans), risks of volatility have moved in line with expectations of tightening by the Fed. However, we do not see significant risks to the currency boards in Bosnia and Hercegovina (BiH) or Bulgaria, or to the peg in Macedonia. Croatia had been more of a concern, in the light of the 2015 legislation to force banks to convert Swiss franc-denominated loans into euro. However, the country's improved external and fiscal positions, and increased demand for the kuna as a result of the record tourism season, have driven appreciation, which we forecast will continue in 2017.
Currencies across the former Soviet Union depreciated sharply in 2015 as a result of the weakening of the rouble and lower oil prices, which have hit commodity exporters. Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan both officially abandoned their US dollar pegs in 2015. In practice, the commitment of both countries to a free float would be seriously tested in the event of further oil volatility. We would expect the central banks of both countries to intervene-at least temporarily-in such a scenario to prevent sharp fluctuations in the currency and to maintain financial and monetary stability.
The Central Bank of Azerbaijan (CBA) had to grapple with a serious banking crisis in 2016 and struggled to restore confidence in the manat following the devaluation in December 2015. Ten banks failed in 2016, which further undermined confidence in the banking system and encouraged a flight to the US dollar. In early 2017 the CBA made substantial foreign-exchange reserves from the State Oil Fund of the Republic of Azerbaijan (SOFAZ, the sovereign wealth fund) available to the CBA in an effort to restore confidence in the currency. This appears to have had a positive effect on sentiment.
Officially, the CBA is seeking to establish a free-floating currency and a monetary policy focused on inflation targeting. However, it does not currently have the monetary policy levers to control inflation effectively through open market operations. The financial sector is small, banking penetration rates are low, and the transmission mechanism between the cost of CBA lending and the money supply is weak. Dollarisation of the economy remains high, and oil prices will continue to play a dominant role in shaping inflation expectations, the exchange rate and the money supply.
Uzbekistan liberalises the som
In a significant move on September 5th the Central Bank of Uzbekistan (CBU) ended its long-running policy of administratively supporting the official exchange rate of the som on a crawling peg, allowing it to float freely. This move saw the official exchange rate converge to the black market rate of Som8,100:US$1, marking a depreciation of almost 50%. The president, Shavkat Mirziyoyev, had announced in November 2016 that he would liberalise the exchange rate, allowing it to be determined by market forces. Since his announcement, the som's crawling peg was allowed to depreciate at a faster pace. Ahead of the currency liberalisation, the authorities implemented measures aimed at stemming the use of the black market. For example, following the issuing of a government decree, GM Uzbekistan, the country's largest automobile manufacturer, abandoned its practice of selling vehicles in foreign currency (primarily US dollars) in June. In addition to allowing the som's depreciation, Mr Mirziyoyev also sanctioned the relaxation of some stringent capital controls on foreign currency for businesses and individuals. Enterprises registered in Uzbekistan are now permitted to buy and sell currency for any purpose, including imports and the repatriation of profits (previously subject to controls). However, Uzbek citizens are still required to credit hard foreign currency to debit cards for spending abroad, leaving in place one significant capital control despite the currency reform. The Mirziyoyev administration has indicated that it will further reduce capital controls in the coming months, which will aid domestic competiveness. After depreciating in 2017-18, we expect broadly stable global commodity prices to bring about a modest appreciation against the US dollar in 2019-21.
Non-commodity exporters' currencies should stabilise from 2017
The currencies of most non-commodity exporters should continue to stabilise from 2017 onwards, as the main price adjustment from lower remittances from Russia and the weaker regional growth outlook has now taken place. However, the outlook remains uncertain. Weaker than forecast commodity prices or a return to fighting in eastern Ukraine could trigger another bout of currency volatility in Russia, which would be transmitted to most of the regional economies. Currency volatility over the past year has led to the increased dollarisation of many economies in the region, which will hamper the effectiveness of monetary policy and the ability of the central banks to stabilise inflation and output.

The UK economy has been resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote. Average annual real GDP growth in 2016 was firm, at 1.8%, albeit a modest slowdown from 2.2% growth in 2015. Activity weakened in the first quarter of 2017, with the quarterly increase in real GDP slowing to 0.2%. This largely reflected lower output in consumer-focused industries as rising inflation, stemming from a weaker pound, dampened domestic demand. Rising cost pressures and uncertainty about the Brexit negotiations and the UK's future relationship with the EU are likely to weigh more heavily on economic activity later this year. The Economist Intelligence Unit therefore expects a slowdown in the pace of economic growth, from 1.7% in 2017 to 1.3% in 2019. A deal on the UK's new trading relationship with the EU is likely to be phased in from 2019. We expect the pace of real GDP growth to rise to 2.1% by 2021.
The economic impact of the UK's vote to leave the EU on the wider regional economy could be substantial. In addition to the direct effect via trade and investment channels, over time the referendum result is also likely to compound centrifugal political and institutional dynamics in the EU and the euro zone. However, the short-term economic fallout from Brexit will be modest for Europe as a whole.
Europe's growth outlook improves as euro zone recovery broadens
The economic expansion in Europe is gaining momentum as the recovery that has been building since 2013 broadens and becomes more entrenched. We expect EU28 growth to accelerate this year, from 1.9% in 2016 to 2.1%, and to an average of 1.7% in 2018-21. The unemployment rate has declined steadily, to 7.7% in July 2017-its lowest level since late 2008-and there is little pressure on wages. This upswing mitigates the risk to the region's economic prospects from external factors, notably monetary policy tightening in the US and an expected slowdown in China. On the first of these, we expect the Fed, which raised its policy rate by 25 basis points in March, to increase the policy rate by another 100 basis points over the remainder of 2017 and in 2018. The election in November 2016 of Donald Trump as US president raised upside risks to economic growth in the country, and therefore increased the chance of a faster pace of monetary tightening by the Fed. However, we remained sceptical that the new administration would drive significantly faster US growth. In our view, therefore, the path of Fed tightening is likely to remain gradual. This should ease pressure on several countries in the wider region-notably Turkey, Russia, Poland, Hungary, Georgia and Croatia-that are more exposed than others to the effects of Fed tightening. We now expect a mild downturn in the US in 2020, but unprecedented Fed policies have inflated asset prices, and a turn in investor sentiment could harm consumer and business confidence.
The Chinese economy has continued to defy gravity, with official data showing growth slowing smoothly, despite persistent inefficiencies in the state sector and recessionary conditions in the industrial north-east. However, we think that the spectacular build-up of debt since the global financial crisis of 2008-09 is unsustainable and that a correction will occur in 2018, which, unless it is managed carefully by policymakers, will make a hard landing difficult to avoid. Such an outcome would have a severe global impact-far more than would have been the case in earlier decades.

Outlook for the euro zone will remain challenging
The euro zone economy is showing increasing momentum, and after average growth of 1.8% in 2015-16 we expect another healthy expansion of 2% this year, and annual average growth of 1.6% in 2018-21, with the risks weighted on the upside. In our view the economic recovery has further to run, partly because it is rooted in factors that will underpin sustainable demand, such as rising employment and household deleveraging. Furthermore, there remains significant slack in the euro zone economy that has yet to be absorbed. Nevertheless, the longer-term outlook for the single currency area will remain challenging. Demographic factors will begin to exert a more powerful drag on an increasing number of countries in the bloc. We do not expect policymakers to find a game-changing solution to remedy some of the euro zone's institutional shortcomings. In particular, they are unlikely to reform the bloc's fiscal policy framework. This means that tensions will persist between member states over targets for budget deficits, and it is almost inconceivable that the bloc's fiscal authorities will significantly ease the pressure on their monetary counterparts by pursuing an actively expansionary policy.
Much of central and eastern Europe also faces a challenging environment in the longer term. However, countries that benefit from EU funding in particular will see real GDP growth well above the EU average during the forecast period (2017-21). A deadline at the end of 2015 for fund drawdowns from the EU's 2007-13 fiscal period brought an end to a surge in investment spending. Funding inflows for projects under the 2014-20 funding period were slow to get under way in 2016, holding back activity last year, but there are now clear signs that funds are starting to flow and projects are beginning, which will lift economic growth rates during the forecast period. We expect that growth in Germany-a major market for these countries-will remain solid. The German economy's changing structure, with investment and private consumption rising, will provide a boost to central and east European countries with strong trade links to their larger neighbour.
Within central and eastern Europe there are some divergences in terms of average growth rates and overall economic performance, and we expect these to persist. The Visegrad states-the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary and Poland-are set to record healthy growth rates in 2017-21, with low oil prices, significant trade integration with Germany, generally weighty and competitive external sectors (measured as exports relative to GDP), and a much smaller fiscal drag than previously supporting growth. Lower EU fund inflows, as projects financed under the 2014-20 fiscal period were slow to get started held back growth rates in 2016, but there is strong evidence to suggest that this has changed in 2017. Growth in the Czech Republic-the star performer in 2015, with 5.4% growth-slowed to 2.5% in 2016, but is forecast to reach 4.5% in 2017; and to average 2.5% per year in 2018-21. In Slovakia, real GDP growth slowed from 3.8% in 2015 to 3.3% in 2016; we expect this annual growth rate to be maintained on average over 2017-21. In Hungary, growth slowed to 1.9% in 2016, from 3.1% in 2015, but is expected to pick up to 3.7% this year and to average 2.6% per year in 2017-21. In Poland real GDP growth slowed from 3.8% in 2015 to 2.7% in 2016, reflecting a deterioration in policy and a rise in political risk. We expect real GDP to rebound to 3.7% in 2017 and to expand at an average annual rate of 3.3% in 2018-21.
Economic activity is picking up in south-east Europe
In south-east Europe the situation is generally improving after a protracted and difficult post-crisis recovery, with growth rates in the region set to equal or even exceed those of the Visegrad states and the Baltics in 2017-18. We expect continued strong real GDP growth in the region's biggest economy, Romania, which grew by 4.8% in 2016. We expect growth of 5.3% this year and average annual growth of about 4% per year in 2018-21. However, rapid wage growth is driving a consumer boom that is sucking in imports and inflating the current-account deficit, and tax cuts have widened the fiscal deficit. Bulgaria will also maintain the momentum established in 2015, with growth in 2017 expected to be 3.6%. Over the medium term we expect real GDP growth to average 3% per year in Bulgaria. This sustained pick-up is driven by improved performance in the euro zone, robust export performance and increased expenditure on infrastructure projects, which received a boost from a surge in the inflow of EU funds.
Growth in the western Balkans and Baltics to accelerate; Visegrad to slow
We forecast average real GDP growth in the western Balkans (Albania, BiH, Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia) of about 3% in 2017 and 3.5% in 2018, up from an annual average of 2.7% in 2015-16. Growth in the three Baltic states is forecast to increase from an average of 1.9% per year in 2015-16 to an average 3.4% per year in 2017-18.
Economic activity in the western Balkans has picked up in the past two years, reflecting a combination of favourable base effects and externally driven cyclical factors such as low oil prices. In 2015-16 private investment and exports were the main drivers of growth in Albania, Montenegro and Serbia, with private consumption remaining weak, pointing to a more balanced growth trajectory. The region has undergone a significant economic adjustment in the years since the global economic crisis in 2007-09, largely correcting fiscal and current-account imbalances (with some notable exceptions, such as Montenegro). Inflation has fallen to historical lows for the region, allowing a more accommodative monetary policy that has supported growth. The revival of investment is set to continue, and over the medium and long term the region should benefit from the structural reforms that are now under way in most countries. On the downside, slow progress on structural reforms, high public and/or private debt loads, and (in some cases) continued large fiscal deficits remain impediments to faster growth. We do not think that the fallout from the Brexit vote will be unduly negative for the Balkans, whose slow progress towards EU membership is set to continue.
Croatia was the worst-performing economy in the former communist region in 2009-15, when annual growth averaged -1.6%. It emerged from six years of recession in 2015 with growth of 2.2%. Growth accelerated to 3% in 2016, driven by private consumption and investment, and benefiting from favourable base effects and cyclical factors, including low international oil prices and a record tourism season. In 2017-21 we forecast that real GDP will expand by an average of 2.6% per year-a significantly improved growth outlook compared with the years following the global financial crisis. Absorption of EU funds is improving. Nevertheless, the economy will only reach its 2008 level towards the end of the forecast period. Croatia is still at a relatively early stage in the reform process and is working off the excesses of the pre-crisis years. The need to pay down large public- and private-sector debt, a deteriorating demographic picture, poor competitiveness and a subdued external outlook will all contribute to the weak trend growth rate.
Greece's economy has been in almost permanent recession since 2008. Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than a quarter during this period, government consumption also by nearly a quarter, house-hold consumption by one-fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery, under way since 2016, is fragile and vulnerable to domestic and external developments. After stagnating on average in 2016, we are fore-casting that real GDP will expand by 1% in 2017 and 1.8% per year in 2018-21.
With the threat of a bail-out breakdown and default in July avoided, we expect the pace of real GDP growth to pick up. Investment growth will return and household consumption will increase modestly, averaging 3.8% and 1.8% per year respectively in 2018-21. However, headwinds will persist in 2018 and beyond given the bail-out programme's emphasis on fiscal restraint and meeting ambitious primary surplus targets of 3.5% of GDP per year, as well as still high unemployment and limited lending growth. The decline in fixed investment since the start of the sovereign debt crisis will have a significant negative effect over the longer term, undermining the economy's ability to generate growth. Greece's external trade will be constrained by the continuation of the capital controls regime, as well as by its relatively uncompetitive goods exports. After a strong second-half export performance in 2016, base effects will reverse this pattern in 2017. Over the medium term we expect tourism to support services export growth, but we forecast only modest growth of exports of goods and services, averaging 2% per year in 2017-21.
In Turkey domestic political instability, perceived security risks from terrorist attacks and uncertainty about the global economic outlook weighed on the economy in 2015-16, but relative stability following the April 2017 presidential reform referendum and fiscal stimulus measures will support solid economic growth of 5.5% in 2017 and an average of 4.5% per year in 2018-21. By far the biggest risk to our growth forecast is the possibility of a severe disruption to capital inflows to Turkey triggered by tighter than currently expected US monetary policy, although this is not our central forecast and we consider the probability of it happening to be low.
Russia's economy has moved into a recovery phase this year
Although low energy prices contributed to a modest recovery in EU growth in 2015, they triggered a deep recession across most of the former Soviet Union. Russia's real GDP growth, which is an important driver of economies in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) region, contracted by 2.8% in 2015. The recession persisted in 2016, as oil prices remained low and households and companies continued to deleverage. Household incomes declined in real terms for a second successive year. This was compounded by a contractionary fiscal policy. The weak banking sector and high political risk continued to depress investment. Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan likewise faced the combined impact of contracting household and government expenditure and corporate deleveraging in 2016. Russian GDP fell by 0.2% last year. Kazakhstan's economy posted low growth of just 0.9%, and real GDP in Azerbaijan declined by 3.1%. The weakness of the Russian economy held down growth across the rest of the region, largely through low remittances and export demand.
Growth in Russia is expected to rebound moderately from 2017, driven by a recovery in commodity prices, which should encourage a strengthening of the rouble and household spending power. We expect the banking sector to start to stabilise, allowing for a modest recovery in investment. We forecast real GDP growth of 1.6% in 2017. Risks are to the downside, as household consumption might be weaker than we currently forecast, and fiscal consolidation will continue to constrain public consumption and infrastructure spending. The external political environment remains uncertain, and a further upsurge in tensions with the West cannot be excluded. Moreover, oil prices could remain lower than currently forecast. In the medium term, structural constraints-the weak institutional environment, poor demographics and weak competition-will hold trend growth below 2% per year.
After the shocks of revolution and war real GDP contracted by 9.8% in Ukraine in 2015, before bouncing back by 2.3% in 2016, driven by a recovery in private consumption and investment. Subdued growth in Russia and restrictions on trade will limit the prospects for an export-led recovery. We forecast average annual growth of about 1.8% per year in 2017-21; our forecast assumes little progress in reforming the economy and stabilising the political system, but that there will not be a return to all-out war in eastern Ukraine. Ukraine's fiscal position has improved but remains weak, and the potential for political instability to trigger an economic crisis is high.

The slump in global oil prices in late 2014 exacerbated a marked disinflationary trend in Europe, but helped to boost to the region's real economy in 2015, and to a limited extent in 2016, as households benefited from higher real earnings and businesses from lower input costs. Since late 2016 inflation has picked up, with base effects-notably those related to energy prices-providing much of the initial impetus in early 2017. As base effects have fallen out of the arithmetic, inflation has stabilised again. We expect it to average 1.7% in the EU28 this year, 1.5% in 2018 and an average of 1.8% per year in 2019-21.
In a number of specific instances across the region, very different inflationary patterns will be recorded-Turkey, for example, will struggle throughout the forecast period to bring its inflation rate down to its 5% target. Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high, as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disinflationary effects of plunging global oil prices since mid-2014. Assuming that the Central Bank of Turkey keeps monetary policy tight and does not loosen it too soon, we see inflation gradually easing, achieving the 5% target by end-2021.

The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings model seeks to measure the attractiveness of a country's business environment and its major components. The model's assessment of the business environment-based on the opportunities for and hindrances to the conduct of business-enables us to rank each of the 82 countries covered on its overall position and in each of ten categories on a global and a regional basis. The model uses quantitative data and expert assessments to measure the attractiveness of countries' business environments. The framework has been designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies in formulating their global business strategies and investment location decisions. The overall scores (on a 1-10 scale) and rankings are based on scores for 91 indicators, grouped into ten categories.
There is a moderate improvement in Europe's aggregate regional scores between the historical period (2012-16) and the forecast period (2017-21), reflecting the transition from the post-crisis period to one in which recovery and repair, although patchy, have in most countries been under way for some time. Western Europe's score remains broadly stable, rising from 7.5 in the historical period to 7.6 in the forecast period, and eastern Europe's score moves up from 6.1 to 6.5 over the same timeframe. Across the region as a whole, the strongest ranking improvements are recorded by Croatia, Romania, Netherlands, Latvia, Cyprus, Spain and Sweden. By contrast, Turkey dropped by 12 places, Poland and Greece by six, Lithuania by four, and Germany and Hungary by three.
EU countries remain well represented in the top 20 of our global rankings. Two non-EU countries, Switzerland and Norway, also occupy leading positions. The large number of west European countries in the top 20 reflects the high degree of political stability in the region (a post-crisis rise in social and political tension notwithstanding), large and competitive domestic markets, and a strong degree of openness to world trade. Although we continue to highlight the risks of political fragmentation and rising anti-establishment sentiment, we do not forecast a marked anti-market backlash in policy choices.
Recent years have brought considerable improvement to the investment climate of central and eastern Europe. The early reformers among the countries of central Europe led the way in the early 1990s in adopting far-reaching stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation programmes. Reform in the Balkans has been much more uneven and subject to periodic reversals, but significant progress has been made even here. Factors such as a low-cost but well-qualified labour force, proximity to developed markets and, in some cases, ample natural-resource endowments have attracted considerable foreign direct investment to the region during the past decade. However, many east European countries still face fundamental reform challenges; meeting those challenges will test already fraying relations between governments and electorates, and heighten the risk of political instability and social unrest.
The outlook for the business environment in the countries of the former Soviet Union is mixed. In Russia the business environment has suffered as a result of Western sanctions and a rise in tariff and non-tariff barriers. There is little evidence that the government intends to undertake disruptive structural reform to improve the dynamism of the economy. Low energy prices have prompted some regional commodity exporters, notably Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan, to attempt to open up and diversify their economies. Ukraine has committed itself to an ambitious reform programme; however, its economic prospects will be harmed by disruption of trade and financial ties with Russia. Throughout the region the barriers to enacting wide-ranging reform remain formidable.
Data sources and definitions
Methodology
The forecast tables have been constructed from the individual data series available in the respective Economist Intelligence Unit Country Forecasts. In addition, the Economist Intelligence Unit runs the National Institute's Global Econometric Model (NIGEM), which is developed and maintained by the London Business School at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines ten separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, and infrastructure. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 16 (infrastructure), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2012-16) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2017-21). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2012-16. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2017-21 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
The main sources used in the business rankings model include CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce; Freedom House, Annual Survey of Political Rights and Civil Liberties; Heritage Foundation, Index of Economic Freedom; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; UN, Human Development Report; US Social Security Administration, Social Security Programs Throughout the World; World Bank, World Development Report; World Development Indicators; Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Report.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2012-16 ranges are then used to derive 2017-21 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2017-21, not to the likely situation in 2021 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2014 or 2019). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Although the regime of the president, Nicolás Maduro, will strengthen its grip on power after the installation of a Constituent Assembly, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect Mr Maduro to remain in power beyond 2019. The most likely scenarios for a transition to an opposition-led government are through ad hoc elections after economic collapse (probably as foreign-exchange shortages culminate in debt default) or a military coup. There is a risk that the regime will cling on to power if either Chinese or Russian finance helps the sovereign to avoid debt default, or should Mr Maduro be replaced by another member of the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela to appease critics.
Inflation is likely to exceed 1,000% by end-2017 and 1,900% at end-2018. The risk of hyperinflation is rising as the government increasingly prints money for spending. We forecast that GDP will have contracted by a third between 2014-19. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consump-tion and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. We forecast a recovery beginning in 2020, by which time the current opposition is expected to be in government, leading to macro-economic adjustments, and institutional and structural reforms.
Sweeping reforms are required to restore confidence in contract and property rights, and thereby promote a recovery in investment. The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will encourage private investment, re-establish market mechanisms for price stability and attempt to undo the constraints imposed by the government on private firms.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and quadruple-digit inflation will hit private consumption, and the increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate the fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices and the economy will not return to growth until 2020 on the assumption of a new government that implements reforms. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
At almost 300bn barrels, Venezuela has the world's largest proven oil reserves, but its oil sector has suffered from disinvestment and mismanagement owing to political interference. The government claims that rising investment in the energy sector will lift oil production significantly in the medium term, but we foresee a continued fall in production in 2017, and only a minor increase from 2018 as economic conditions stabilise.

Venezuela is in 80th position globally in our business environment rankings for 2017-21, out of 82 countries covered. It is therefore one of the least attractive investment locations. This reflects state interventionism, highly hetero-dox macroeconomic policies, a lack of legal security and weak institutions. Regionally, Venezuela remains last of the 12 countries covered, notwithstanding our assumption of improvements after 2019.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Nationalisation poses a diminished threat, given fiscal weaknesses. Property rights remain weak. Price fixing undermines profitability.
2019-21: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists.
2019-21: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain fairly low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2017-18: Frequent ad hoc adjustments to the unorthodox exchange-rate policy framework add to uncertainty. The state continues to exercise tight control over access to official-rate US dollars. Private firms must use a much weaker rate.
2019-21: Efforts to remove trade and exchange controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly, after a political transition takes place.
Taxes
2017-18: Government's low approval ratings reduce the risk of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2019-21: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2017-18: Credit growth remains firm, but sectoral allocation is distorted by administrative interventions. Banks remain highly profitable, although unpredictable enforcement and a weak regulatory framework heighten instability.
2019-21: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2017-18: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2019-21: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Access to water and electricity supplies remains precarious. Underinvestment in power transmission ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2019-21: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued electricity rationing.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Chávez was diagnosed with cancer in 2011 but, after declaring in July 2012 that he had fully recovered, won a fourth presidential term in October 2012. However, his health quickly deteriorated and he died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has since plummeted.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is a federal republic, successive administrations have proven reluctant to devolve political authority, with the transfer of financial resources from federal to local level highly dependent on the central government. The legislature is unicameral, and elections for the National Assembly take place every five years. In December 2015 the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the legislature. In August 2017 the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) installed a Constituent Assembly with powers over all branches of government and a remit to rewrite the 1999 Constitution-apparently a ploy to entrench the PSUV in power.
Policy issues: Political radicalisation has been reflected in increasingly heterodox economic policymaking, with massive fiscal and monetary stimulus, and the nationalisation of industries deemed strategically important. Distortions created by this approach have become evident, with inflation rising sharply in spite of price controls, and with capital controls spawning a rampant black market for foreign exchange. Failure to invest part of the oil windfall has led to a startling decline in physical infrastructure. Non-oil production has in effect ground to a halt, leaving the economy entirely dependent on the energy sector. With large oil shipments going to China to repay loans, and (on subsidised terms) to regional neighbours via the PetroCaribe oil-financing scheme, the country is running very short of US dollars, forcing cuts in import spending.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 60% for oil firms. Since 2011 a maximum royalty of 95% has applied to oil extraction. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Official data are unavailable, but The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$7bn in 2016 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. The current-account deficit is estimated to have fallen from 4.3% of GDP in 2015 to 1.8% of GDP in 2016.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
Political and social tension will remain high following a controversial vote on July 30th organised by the president, Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), to establish a Constituent Assembly (ANC) with powers over all branches of government-including the opposition-controlled National Assembly-and a remit to write a new constitution. However, protests led by the Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) opposition between April and July over the country's slide towards authoritarian government (the protests led to over 120 civilian deaths, mostly caused by the security forces) have died down as the MUD's focus shifts briefly to state governorship elections scheduled for October 15th. The scale of protests is likely to wax and wane in response to government measures to stifle democratic procedures, and those that are likely to persist will be from more violent and hardline youth groups of the opposition, known as "Resistencia".
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a change of government at some point in the 2017-21 forecast period. The government will resist holding the presidential election that is due in December 2018. It seems unconcerned about ever more damning criticism from the international community, including a threat of further US economic sanctions after the imposition of financial constraints in late August. Nonetheless, we do not expect Mr Maduro to manage to cling to power for the entire 2017-21 forecast period, on the basis that economic conditions seem set to deteriorate further, with Venezuela on the brink of hyperinflation and default, producing unsustainable pressure for a change of government. International oil prices are not expected to rise to such a level as to provide the foreign-exchange proceeds needed to ease chronic consumer goods shortages (Venezuela depends heavily on imports) and allow the government to meet external debt obligations falling due over the next 12-15 months. We therefore believe that a transition involving the opposition is likely in the medium term.
Given the highly volatile political situation, accurately forecasting when and how a transition of power will occur is challenging. We believe that there are two main triggers to a transfer of authority. The first scenario involves a traumatic descent into hyperinflation and default. In this scenario, Mr Maduro could manage to muddle through for the remainder of 2017 and much of 2018, running down reserves to meet external debt repayments, before ultimately being unable to avoid a debt default, perhaps in the context of the imposition of sanctions by the US on Venezuela oil imports. This would be likely to bring about Mr Maduro's downfall, as his allies in government and the military would be hit financially, and remaining popular support from his constituents (chiefly the poor and public-sector workers) would fade owing to heightened economic hardship as hand-outs dry up. Subsequently, a negotiated exit for key government figures would pave the way for the holding of fresh elections and an eventual victory for the MUD.
The second of the most likely potential transition scenarios involves a military coup, triggered by dissent among the ranks of the armed forces. Although successive PSUV governments have given increasing power to the generals and trained lower-ranking soldiers that share their ideology so as to cultivate pro-PSUV sentiment, unease among other stakeholders in the armed forces appears to be growing, judging by sporadic episodes of rebellion in recent months. In this scenario, a military government could replace the current PSUV leadership, although we would expect such a government to pave the way for free and fair elections relatively quickly.
Although it is not our baseline forecast, we recognise that there is a high risk that the PSUV will cling on to power. If, for example, Russia or China were to provide sufficient financial assistance to allow Venezuela to avoid default and boost oil output, or if oil prices were to rise significantly beyond our expectations, there is a possibility that the government would manage to withstand political pressure for elections and regime change. In another possible scenario, Mr Maduro could leave office but be replaced by another high-ranking PSUV official in an attempt to appease critics. However, no likely successor to Mr Maduro would appease opposition demands for elections and political transition, and tension would remain high.
Regardless of when and how political transition occurs, the second half of our forecast period is likely to remain volatile and uncertain. The broad, diverse opposition coalition will have to contend with huge economic distortions and deep political differences that would test even a unified political party. Although we expect significant financial support from multilateral lending agencies, the risk of renewed political volatility will remain high, even under an opposition government.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
In both our transition scenarios we assume that elections will eventually be held and will be free and fair, ushering the MUD-led opposition into power. However, and as part of the government's efforts to cling to power in the meantime, we expect that the Maduro regime and the ANC will push back the schedule for the next presidential election, which is due in December 2018. The ANC began work in August and has a two-year mandate, so at the very least elections could be pushed back to August 2019, with approval from the politicised Supreme Court likely to be forthcoming. State governor elections are scheduled for October 15th and we expect the MUD to do well, but the centralisation of power means that the results will have little impact on overall government policy.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Following the installation of the ANC, Venezuela has become much more isolated diplomatically and is coming under increasing regional and international pressure. To date this has done little to weaken the government's grip on power, but US sanctions could prove significant. In August the US government prohibited fresh US-dollar-denominated bond issuance and bond trading between the Venezuelan government and US institutions-complicating already difficult financing conditions. There is a growing likelihood of other economic measures such as cuts in US exports of distillates that Venezuela needs for its oil exports, lifting costs and hence reducing foreign-exchange proceeds, before ultimately cutting US purchases of Venezuelan oil, a move that would cripple the economy. Mercosur, a regional bloc comprised of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, and Uruguay, has suspended Venezuela indefinitely owing to "violations to the constitutional order", and a group of major countries in the region has denounced the regime and said that they will not recognise laws passed by the new ANC. The Vatican, which has in the past tried to mediate between the Venezuelan government and opposition, has also criticised the ANC. The government is participating in a new round of internationally mediated negotiations with the opposition, brokered by the former Spanish prime minister, José Luís Rodríguez Zapatero (2004-11). A return to negotiations could potentially provide a path to fresh elections and a political transition, but huge obstacles remain.
A key priority for the Maduro administration will be the maintenance of good relations with China (a key creditor) and Russia, whose state oil company, Rosneft, is active in Venezuela. Financial assistance from these countries could help the Maduro regime to survive for longer by providing much-needed external financing in exchange for lucrative oil contracts for Rosneft.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
It is unlikely that the government will be able to manage the build-up of inflationary and currency depreciation pressures without significant policy adjustments. We assume that the Maduro government will be forced to weaken the currency more substantially in 2017-18 than it has done so far. However, other much-needed reforms are unlikely to be addressed by a government that has proved unwilling or technically incapable of adjusting policy sufficiently to move Venezuela's economy away from the brink of collapse. Fiscal and monetary policies will remain expansionary, and ad hoc policy intervention-ism and heavy state control of the economy will persist. Amid subdued oil prices, import compression will remain necessary, as other sources of foreign exchange will be hard to find. We currently expect Venezuela to meet its 2017 obligations, which are mostly owed by PDVSA, the state-oil company. However, given an extremely thin reserves cushion (less than $10bn in September), we have now factored into our forecasts the likelihood of a debt default in 2018, which would have dramatic consequences in the form of lower oil production, reduced import capacity, hyperinflation and political turmoil.
In our baseline scenario, we expect the opposition to hold power by 2019, ushering in much-needed, market-driven adjustments designed to correct currency distortions, alleviate shortages of basic goods, tighten expansionary fiscal policy and rebuild institutional capacity after years of deterioration under PSUV rule. It is probable, given the scale of the challenge, that the new government will seek a financing agreement with the IMF to support the adjustment process; we have factored in accumulated lending of over US$16bn in 2019-21. Efforts to secure increased inflows of foreign direct investment would also be likely under a new government, and would help to improve the balance-of-payments dynamics, although we expect direct investors to remain cautious for some time with regards to Venezuela, with the possible exception of the oil sector.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
The authorities' failure to publish data on the non-financial public sector since 2012 demonstrates the opacity of the public finances and complicates accurate forecasting of the size of the deficit. After ballooning to an estimated 24.3% of GDP in 2016, we expect the deficit to stand at a still-large 19.5% of GDP in 2017 and remain in double digits in 2018. A transition to a new government should help to ease the deficit to 4.7% of GDP by 2021. The large deficits of the present are mostly being financed by printing money; the money supply (M2) rose by around 450% year on year in August, the highest rate on record. High inflation and an overvalued currency are eroding the relative value of domestic and external debt, making debt/GDP ratios unreliable indicators of fiscal stability. There is considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing, mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA. As these items are excluded from the public debt statistics, the true size of total public liabilities is understated. Our forecasts now assume that Venezuela will default on its external debt at some stage in 2018. This will be followed by a restructuring process with external creditors under an MUD-led opposition government.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Monetary policy under the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) will continue to be driven by the government's desire to keep real interest rates negative and to print money to finance large fiscal deficits. In the context of extremely high inflation, we expect real rates to remain deeply negative in 2017-18. Our forecast of substantial currency and fiscal adjustment under a new government in 2019 also implies a substantial tightening of monetary policy. We expect interest rates to rise sharply that year, declining only moderately thereafter.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending mean that we project further contractions in real GDP in 2017-19. Our forecast for a recovery in 2020-21 rests on our assumption of slightly higher oil prices, alongside a political transition that produces a combination of macroeconomic adjustment (supported by IMF financial assistance), and institutional and structural reform. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, given the scale of the recession, and our forecasts therefore imply only a partial rebound, after a real GDP decline of a third in 2014-19.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2017-18, reflecting the effect of soaring inflation on real wages, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will continue to contract sharply, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange, and remitting profits. Our forecast for a recovery in invest-ment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition, progress on long­delayed joint projects with Chinese firms in energy and-later in the forecast period-a pick-up in public-sector investment. Exports will continue to shrink in 2017 as oil production falls further, but will pick up in 2019-21, reflecting renewed investment under a new government and a removal of constraints to domestic production. Import demand will rise faster than exports, in line with an alleviation of basic goods shortages and the release of pent-up demand from recession. Even after the change in govern-ment, however, dependence on oil will persist.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
A decimation of domestic supply and severe shortages of foreign-exchange reserves have caused inflation to soar for much of the past two years, and in the short term there is little sign that the situation will improve, despite deep reces-sion. No new official inflation data have been released since end-2015, but since the start of the year the National Assembly has begun producing a consumer price index. This showed monthly inflation of 33.7% in August, bringing accumu-lated inflation for January---August to 366%. Assuming that price pressures remain high, we expect inflation to exceed 1,000% by year-end and over 1,900% by the end of 2018 (this is an upwards revision of the forecast included in our previous monthly report for Venezuela). We continue to forecast a decline in inflation over time, under the assumption of a recovery in oil output and corrective economic policies under a MUD-led government. However, for now, a lack of funds available for importing basic goods suggests that shortages will be rife, and the risk of hyperinflation (monthly inflation of over 50%) will remain substantial.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
As the central government has no apparent expectations of an increase in inflows of US dollars to the country, and using financial sanctions imposed by the US in late August as an excuse, Mr Maduro also announced the implementation of a "basket of currencies" (such as the rupee, ruble, yuan and euro) for international transactions to avoid the use of the US dollar. The basket of currencies will include currencies that are not easily convertible, meaning that this will probably make external transactions even more complicated. Amid huge pressures on the dual-currency exchange-rate system, our forecasts assume substantial devaluations in 2017-18, but the exchange rate will still be extremely overvalued. The dual exchange-rate system is composed of an official peg, known as the Dipro, which is limited to priority public-sector imports and set at BsF10:US$1, and a heavily managed rate known as the Dicom for private-sector operations (but where demand for US dollars vastly outstrips supply). After the government unexpectedly announced a suspension of the Dicom system in early September, the black-market rate shot up above BsF22,000:US$1.
We assume that further major currency adjustment under a new, MUD-led government in 2019 will involve immediate exchange-rate unification. Until that occurs, given existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market, there is an extremely high risk of a debilitating currency crisis in the short term. If confidence in the bolívar collapses amid hyperinflation, dollarisation-or the launch of a new domestic currency-could occur.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
The current-account deficit will narrow further in 2017, reflecting severe import compression and a moderate recovery in oil prices, which will outweigh a continued decline in oil output. A sharp fall in oil output in 2019 will lift the current-account deficit. In 2020-21 a recovery in oil output will help to offset a rise in imports after years of pent-up demand and in line with an easing of external financing constraints. Our assumption of economic adjustment in the medium term suggests some recovery in capital inflows, particularly into the oil sector. Together with IMF loans, this should help to rebuild reserves coverage, although our forecasts assume that even by the end of the forecast period in 2021 reserves will cover only slightly more than three months of goods and services imports.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The intense political instability that followed the failed coup in July 2016 has eased partially since the approval in a referendum in April 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parlia-mentary system of government with an executive presidency. The narrow referendum victory and allegations of vote fraud, however, have deepened social and political divisions.
The presidential reform, which is due to come into effect after the next presidential and parliamentary elections, in 2019, will further undermine Turkey's fragile democratic institutions and governance structures. It provides few checks on the powers of the president, and moves the country closer to one-man rule.
The Justice and Development Party (AKP) has enjoyed 15 years of single-party rule, and for most of that political and government effectiveness have improved. However, since 2013 economic policymaking institutions have become increasingly politicised. In response to the failed coup in 2016 the government has carried out an extensive purge of public-sector personnel, which risks undermining institutional capacity.
Since the failed coup Turkish foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by the domestic political goals of the incumbent president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government. This has resulted in a marked deterioration in Turkey's relations with its Western allies.
Real GDP growth slowed from an annual average of 7.4% in 2010-15 to 3.3% in 2016, in part owing to the disruption to the economy from the failed coup but also because of faltering foreign capital inflows amid expectations of global liquidity tightening. A recovery got under way in the final quarter of 2016, supported by government stimulus measures, political pressure on banks to extend credit and a pick-up in global demand. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects growth to accelerate to 5.5% in 2017 and to an average of 4.5% in 2018-21.
Inflation is expected to average 10.6% in 2017 following a sharp depreciation of the lira due to the political turmoil in the country at the end of 2016. The lira will recover some ground in 2017-18 (on average), although we expect it to depre-ciate mildly against the US dollar in 2019-21. In response, we expect the Central Bank of Turkey to have to keep a tight monetary policy stance through 2018.
We expect the current account to widen moderately and remain sufficiently large to make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates.
