Turkey's score deteriorates only slightly in 2017-21, but the country's global ranking falls by 12 places, to 58th. There is consensus among policymakers on the need to maintain macroeconomic stability. However, domestic political tension has created uncertainty about the direction of policy. Important shortcomings are a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion. The failed coup and the government's response have increased the level of uncertainty.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2019-21: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in a wide range of sectors, although the opening up of the energy market makes progress.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2019-21: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade and tourism following the lifting of Russian sanctions.
2019-21: Customs union with the EU could be extended, but negotiations are likely to be protracted given the deterioration in Turkish-EU relations. More free-trade agreements may come into force with the EU's trading partners.
Taxes
2017-18: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make some progress. Tax rates are largely unchanged.
2019-21: A broader income tax base as exemptions and exceptions are reduced. Possible tax cuts and increased incentives.
Financing
2017-18: Monetary policy remains cautious amid concern about a possible deterioration in credit quality. Political pressure on c0mmercial banks to reduce interest rates. Renewed pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey cannot be ruled out.
2019-21: The banking system remains stable, despite some weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2017-18: Labour market remains rigid, with relatively high costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. Wage moderation after 30% minimum wage rise in 2016. Obstacles to employing foreigners ease.
2019-21: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Progress, albeit slow, continues on investment plans in energy, transport and communications.
2019-21: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. The construction of major airport and urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks could persist.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West, becoming a member of the Council of Europe (1949) and NATO (1952), and signing an association agreement with the then European Community (1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup at-tempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey has a unicameral parliamentary system of government, with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Under the AKP, Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019, and possibly earlier. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions will require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing political issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015 and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted long-standing institutional weaknesses, which, with the AKP's consent until 2013, allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Further politicisation of the judiciary is likely after the coup attempt. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax is 20%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2016 goods exports (fob) came to US$150.2bn and imports (fob) to US$191bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$40.9bn-a contraction from US$48.1bn in 2015. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
The intense political instability that followed the failed coup by parts of the military in July 2016 has eased partially since the approval in a referendum in April 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit maintains its negative medium-term political outlook. The narrow referendum victory and allegations of vote fraud have deepened the social and political divisions. The "justice march" from the capital, Ankara, to Istanbul, headed by Kemal Kilicdaroglu, the leader of the opposition Republican People's Party (CHP), ended peacefully on July 9th, but further protests are likely, keeping high the risk of clashes between protesters and pro-government supporters or a government clampdown. The presidential reform, which will take effect after the next presidential and parliamentary elections, both due in 2019, will further undermine Turkey's fragile democratic institutions and governance structures. It provides few checks and balances on the powers of the president, and moves the country closer to one-man rule by the incum-bent president and leader of the ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP), Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Mr Erdogan and the AKP have continued to tighten their grip on power. The state of emergency law introduced after the failed coup has been repeatedly extended on a three-month basis. We expect it remain in place for the foresee-able future, because it will effectively allow Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is fully in place.
Emergency rule was initially introduced to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. However, the use of these powers has been extended to eliminate the pro-Kurdish political opposition, which the government accuses of having links with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), and silence government critics. More than 100,000 people-mainly in the judiciary, the military, the police, academic institutions and the media-have so far been suspended, dismissed or detained.
Security risk remains high, with negative implications for the economy. The state is seeking to end an insurgency by the PKK in the south-east of Turkey, address the domestic security risk posed by terrorist attacks by Kurdish militants and Islamic State (IS) in cities across the country, and implement military operations in Syria and Iraq against both IS and the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds. The purge of the Turkish armed forces and the police since the attempted coup has created operational capacity problems and contributed to intelligence failures that have exacerbated Turkey's domestic security issues. In the short to medium term neither the government nor the PKK appears to be interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will intensify.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The next parliamentary and presidential elections are due to be held in 2019, but they could be called earlier if Mr Erdogan decides to accelerate the transfer of executive powers to the presidency once the institutions and instruments of the new presidential system are in place. Given the popularity of the president, and his party's ability to control the election process, we expect Mr Erdogan to win the presidential election and remain in office with enhanced powers for at least one more five-year term, if not two (the maximum allowed), up to 2029. His popularity is unrivalled, and the opposition is fragmented and currently appears to have no candidates capable of challenging him. In 2014 Mr Erdogan won the presidential election in the first round, with just over 50% of the vote, against a joint candidate presented by the CHP and the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The MHP's support in parliament for the presidential reform makes it unlikely that either of the two parties will consider fielding a joint candidate at the next election.
The clampdown on the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) since mid-2015, the MHP leadership's decision to back the presidential reform, and the hardline nationalist stance adopted by Mr Erdogan and the AKP could have a considerable effect on voting patterns at the next parliamentary election. Both the MHP and the HDP have been weakened since the 2015 election and run the risk of falling below the high 10% national vote threshold for parliamentary representation, which would boost the AKP's seat share. Under the consti-tutional changes approved in the referendum, there will be 600 seats in a much weakened parliament from the next election, up from 550 currently.
The next local elections are scheduled to take place by March 2019.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Since the failed coup Turkish foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by Mr Erdogan's domestic political goals, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government. This approach, combined with ongoing political upheaval in Europe and the US, has resulted in a marked deterioration in Turkey's inter-national relations with its traditional Western allies.
Having deployed armed forces to back rebel groups in Syria to fight IS and prevent the expansion of territory held by US-backed, PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurds, Turkey risks becoming embroiled in the conflict. Tensions and the risk of confrontation between Turkey and US-backed forces could escalate once IS is defeated. The US administration appears unlikely to grant Turkey's request for Mr Gulen to be extradited from the US to face trial in Turkey on charges of masterminding the failed coup. Even if the AKP government provides evidence of his role in the coup that would stand up in a US court, there would be a strong chance that his extradition would be rejected on the grounds that he might not get a fair trial in Turkey.
Despite talk of agreeing a new roadmap to ease tensions and improve co-operation in the main areas of interest such as security, trade and investment, neither Turkey nor the EU is genuinely interested in Turkish membership of the bloc anymore. Although neither has yet been willing to suspend negotiations unilaterally, there is a growing probability that this will occur in 2017-21. If Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, as Mr Erdogan has suggested, the EU might not be able to avoid suspending the process. The suspension of accession negotiations would almost certainly prompt Turkey to end its collaboration with the EU to stem the movement of migrants and refugees into Europe. A settlement of the de facto division of Cyprus between the Greek Cypriot south and the Turkish Cypriot north could help to improve Turkey's relations with the EU, but talks collapsed in July 2017. We maintain our forecast that a settlement is unlikely during the forecast period (2017-21).
Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved. Russia has lifted almost all sanctions, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly in relation to the conflict in Syria, where both are militarily involved but have been pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to remain largely transactional, and the risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances; its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector; and its dynamic, diversified private business sector. However, the risk of an intensification of political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity could disrupt foreign capital inflows to Turkey during the forecast period. These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, but tend to be short-term and highly volatile. Faltering capital inflows put the lira under intense pressure in late 2016 and early 2017, fuelling an acceleration in inflation that prompted the Central Bank of Turkey to start tightening monetary policy in November 2016 after a prolonged period of loosening. The lira has recovered all the ground that it lost in January 2017, but it remains vulnerable to sudden shifts in investor sentiment, as illustrated by a short, sharp drop in value against the US dollar in the first week of July, probably prompted by expectations of balance-sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank). If the lira depreciates sharply again, an abrupt tightening of policy might be necessary, which could strangle Turkey's economic recovery. However, this is not our baseline scenario, as we currently expect US monetary policy to be tightened only gradually in the remainder of 2017-18.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges have blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The current direction of policy appears to be towards a difficult balancing act between fiscal loosening and tight monetary policy while encouraging banks to lend to households and businesses.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
Low budget deficit- and public debt-to-GDP ratios-reflecting the impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past and major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-give the government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy. Our baseline forecast remains that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight to support investor confidence and prevent a surge in domestic demand from causing an unsustainable widening of the current-account deficit. Nevertheless, we expect the central government deficit, which captures most of the public sector, to widen from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to an average of 2% of GDP per year in 2017-19, before narrowing to 1.3% in 2021. Although the government debt/GDP ratio has edged up slightly, to 29.2% in 2016, we expect it to drop gradually, to 27% in 2017-21. The risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances cannot be ruled out.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey to lower interest rates in order to revive economic activity has eased as the government has switched its attention to Turkey's profitable commercial banks. We expect that the central bank will have to keep its monetary policy tight in the remainder of 2017 and in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent a further depreciation of the lira amid expectations of higher US interest rates and Fed balance-sheet tapering. To do this, we expect the Turkish central bank to use a mix of interest rate rises, macroprudential measures and other policies. The bank raised most of its main policy rates between November 2016 and April 2017, and has increasingly provided funding to the banking sector at its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate, which was gradually raised by a total of 250 basis points, to 12.25%, in late April. In mid-September 2017 the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system was about 12%, compared with 7.8% in November 2016.
The central bank is seeking to normalise gradually its monetary policy frame-work to establish a single policy interest rate, which would help to improve transparency regarding monetary policy decisions. However, it is unlikely that this will happen until inflation is more firmly on a downward path towards its medium-term target of 5% and domestic political uncertainty eases.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Real GDP growth slowed from an annual average of 7.4% in 2010-15 to 3.3% in 2016, in part owing to the disruption to the economy caused by the failed coup last July, but also faltering foreign capital inflows amid expectations of global liquidity tightening. A recovery got under way in the final quarter of last year, and we expect growth to accelerate to 5.5% in 2017 and an average of 4.5% in 2018-21. The rebound has been supported by government stimulus measures, political pressure on banks to extend credit and a pick-up in global demand. There are downside risks to this forecast, which is predicated on the assumption that the transition to a presidential system of government in the next few years does not lead to further political instability, deterring foreign capital flows into the Turkish economy.
We expect a moderate improvement in confidence, a recovery in employ-ment growth and government incentives for the purchase of certain household durable goods (in the short term, at least until September 2017) to support household spending. We forecast average real private consumption growth of 3.8% in 2017-21, from 3.7% in 2016.
In 2016 government spending expanded by 9.7%. We expect it to increase by nearly 7% per year on average in 2017-19 as the government seeks to revive the economy and boost support ahead of the 2019 elections. From 2020 we expect growth to be more moderate, but still solid.
The deterioration in the business environment since the attempted coup will continue to hold down fixed investment growth at about 5% per year in 2017-18, as a more cautious approach by businesses will offset government plans to invest heavily in infrastructure projects. In 2019-21 we forecast a gradual acceleration to annual growth of 6% by 2021, assuming that domestic political tensions ease after the elections.
We expect the lifting of Russian sanctions on Turkey, the positive effect of a weaker lira on export competitiveness and stronger growth in the main export markets, especially Europe, to drive a return to growth of exports of goods and services in 2017-21. However, we expect the perception of security risks to persist for some time, which will continue to deter some visitors to Turkey and weigh on the tourism sector. Our expectation is that a slowdown in the Chinese economy in 2018 and a cyclical downturn in the US in 2020 will dampen external demand growth in those years.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target-as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disin-flationary effects of low global oil prices. We expect the pass-through effects of past currency weakness and a moderate recovery in oil and other commodity prices from 2017 to keep consumer price inflation well above the official target during the first half of the forecast period. Assuming that the central bank does not loosen monetary policy too soon, we expect inflation to ease gradually, achieving the 5% target by end-2021. There are upside risks to our forecast.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
Amid further bouts of volatility we expect the lira to depreciate against the US dollar, to an annual average of TL3.56:US$1 in 2017-a fall of about 15% compared with 2016. In 2018 we forecast a small appreciation, to an average of TL3.49:US$1. In 2019-21 we expect the exchange rate to remain broadly stable in real terms, depreciating mildly in nominal terms, to an average of TL3.80:US$1 in 2021. The lira will also depreciate sharply against the euro in 2017-21. There are substantial risks to our exchange-rate forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows, as well as the impact on investor confidence of domestic political tensions and geopolitical turmoil in the region.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
We expect the current account to widen moderately and remain large enough, at a forecast average of 4% of GDP per year in 2017-21, to make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates. Although a weaker lira and the lifting of Russian sanc-tions will boost Turkey's main exports, we expect this to be largely offset by the moderately higher cost of imported energy and inputs for manufactured import-intensive exports. There has been a rebound in Russian tourist arrivals in 2017, but the sector is likely to take several years to recover to its 2015 pre-crisis levels, before the resurgence of terrorist attacks and the imposition of Russian sanctions.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit

Global data

Domestic data
GDP growth and components: Turkstat
